name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Soledad Cabezón Ruiz, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014 (2015/2231(INI)) (A8—0020/2016).

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, 40% of European citizenship, according to the Eurobarometer, is wary of the institutions and trusts them with 46%. Complaints arriving at the Ombudsman's office are mostly concerning transparency, access to documents or maladministrating as a whole, in particular in 20% of cases. Whereas the Charter of Fundamental Rights lays down the right to information and that the Treaty on European Union empowers the Ombudsman , under the principle of ensuring respect for citizens' rights, to investigate cases of maladministr administration, this must be his central task in order to strengthen that confidence. The Ombudsman has competence to be able to carry out this function, as well as to initiate strategic investigations of his own motion. On the basis of all this, I can only begin by giving my support and congratulations to the work which the Ombudsman and the Office she is leading throughout this year which we are analysing have been doing, for the proper fulfilment of her obligations. The Office has specifically responded in some way to more than 23 complaints, directly processed more than 2,000 and initiated 325 investigations, with an average response time of eleven months. However, in my view, the most important thing to highlight is the initiation of 17 ex officio investigations in relation to major issues of interest to European citizenship or of strategic importance in the European Union which, in the Ombudsman's view, needed greater transparency or better administration. In this regard, I would like to acknowledge and welcome the impetus it has given to the progress made on transparency in TTE, to investigations into revolving doors and to the call it makes to the Commission to establish a clear internal procedure, with clear rules and criteria, an interest in transparency in stakeholders and the request for compulsory registration and , at the same time, to be legislate on this subject, ensuring transparency in the composition of expert groups, in particular with regard to the development of the new CAP Regulation, which, as you know, represents the largest percentage of the Union budget. I also welcome the long battle it has given for the EEA to publish data on clinical trials, as well as the analysis of ensuring respect for fundamental rights in Frontex's cohesion policy and migrant return policy, requesting a mechanism for individual complaints. In short, and in my view, a brilliant, courageous and tenacious work is carried out by the Ombudsman's Office, which, in my view, deserves our approval. But that is not why I would like to miss the opportunity to emphasize not only that it continues to work on this line, but to point out challenges that we believe are still important for citizens, such as transparency and research in the field of health and conflict with the right to health protection , the accessibility of persons with disabilities to the documents and media of the European institutions, the mandatory registration of interest groups, the guarantee of fundamental rights, especially in the current refugee crisis, the improvement of transparency in the Council, which, I believe, is a pending subject — and we ask whether delays in decision-making by the Council in legislative initiatives such as the Anti-Discrimination directive or ratification Marrakesh Treaty are not cases of maladministrion—the improvement of the European Citizens' Initiative, or the erratic response by Member States to requests and whether we should not promote legislation establishing obligations and guarantees in this regard. In short, I would like to express this appreciation and reiterate the recognition of the work that the Ombudsman's Office has been doing during this time. Of course, my thanks to the Members of the Committee on Petitions for the understanding and good weather they have made it possible for us to reach a compromise in virtually every single amendment.

name: Emily O’Reilly
text: Ombudsman. – Madam President, good morning and thank you to Ms Cabezón-Ruiz and to all the shadow rapporteurs for your work over the past number of months on this report. The text before the Chamber today shows a very clear understanding and support for my strategy for the office of the European Ombudsman, for which I am profoundly grateful. As I have said on many occasions, my office cannot function as it should without the positive engagement of Parliament, and time and time again, both I and my predecessors have received that vital support. We are a small office with fewer than 80 staff, but we are charged with a big mission on behalf of the citizens of Europe. I will endeavour to play my role in helping the EU institutions to keep pace with the evolving and increasing expectations placed upon us by European citizens and forced upon us by events, and especially at this time. I would like to thank, in particular, the Petitions Committee for its engaged cooperation and support. In our separate but complementary roles, we work not in the abstract but directly with citizens as they come to us either to seek our help our to assert their rights, at a time when, as Vice-President Timmermans has spoken of so well and so frequently, the rule of law and democracy needs even more strongly to be upheld and defended throughout the Union. Honourable Members, this is my second time addressing you in plenary since coming into office in October 2013. I have also addressed you in committee several times before the Petitions, Budget Control, Employment, Legal Affairs and Civil Liberties Committees. Each time I have benefited from your expertise, advice and support, and that has fed directly into the strategy that I have developed and which I am now implementing.  I thank the Petitions Committee for welcoming specifically my strategic use of proactive inquiries and for the reorganisation of my office in order to better support the strategy. I use the strategic inquiry approach to enter a dialogue at the highest levels in order to assist the institutions to achieve the highest possible standards of public administration. However, my office is, and always will be, driven by the complaints we receive. Today’s report notes that over 20% of complaints follow a refusal of an access to documents request. Transparency and the Treaty-based right of access to documents must play a crucial part, both in democratic participation and in democratic accountability. The EU does set higher standards than many Member States, but perhaps, given its reach and its role, so it should, and so should it also strive to achieve even higher standards. Thank you to Ms Cabezón Ruiz for welcoming my focus on the challenge of the so-called revolving doors issue in the EU. That is when officials leave the service for the private sector, allowing a potential conflict of interest to arise. My inquiry into how the European Commission deals with it has resulted in some positive improvements and, notably, the publication by the Commission, for the first time ever, of the list of names of senior officials who left for new jobs, with details of their move and assessments of any potential conflict of interest. This list will now be published annually, in accordance with the staff regulations, and I thank the Budget Control Committee for its attention to this important issue. The report also recognises the real progress by the Commission, following my inquiry, and much pressure of course from this Parliament, on the transparency of the TTIP negotiations. This was an excellent example, in my view, of the Ombudsman, Parliament and administration working together for a better outcome for citizens. The issue of lobbying transparency also features in my work. I have welcomed the Juncker Commission’s work in this area, through its Transparency Initiative, and have encouraged more to be done. I should, however – and conscious that issues concerning the tobacco industry will shortly be discussed in this Chamber – express my disappointment at the Commission’s recent decision not to accept my recommendation for the proactive publication of all meetings with that industry, and not just – as is currently the case – with DG Health. The legally-binding UN Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, to which the EU is signatory, is predicated on the recognition of the tobacco industry as one to whom the normal rules of industry-government dialogue should not apply. Briefly, we have also recently worked with the ECB on their transparency and ethics policies, and I am happy to see the ECB executive board now publish details of their meetings. I would like to thank President Mario Draghi for his cooperation on these issues, which are so vital for the public trust. As for the Commission, I expect shortly to receive its response to my strategic inquiry on expert groups and on DG Agriculture’s civil dialogue groups. I also very much welcome the upcoming public consultation on how to improve the transparency register, and I support a mandatory register. Such a register should not only have real sanctions but also full financial transparency requirements, to make sure that everyone is aware of who precisely is registering and being given access to decision-makers. Thank you to Ms Cabezón Ruiz for raising clinical trials’ transparency in her report, an issue about which I know she feels very strongly. I am continuing my inquiry into the public disclosure of clinical studies reports relating to Humira, a multibillion-euro drug sold worldwide. The report also recognises the work of my office in relation to how to ensure European fundamental rights and migration. I wish to thank Members for your overwhelming support for my special report to Parliament following the refusal of Frontex to establish a complaints mechanism. Following the parliamentary vote in plenary, I thank the Commission for including my recommendations on the complaints mechanism and on the treatment of people being deported from the EU in its new Border Agency proposal. Ms Cabezón Ruiz’s report also recognises the work of my office in the areas of whistle-blowing, fundamental rights and EU cohesion policy, the European citizens’ initiative, and in relation to the UN Convention on the rights of people with disabilities. Another new strategic initiative concerns the European Network of Ombudsmen, which I have the honour to chair, and the development of parallel inquiries into issues relevant to both EU and national and regional levels. This June, I will also host a major network conference in Brussels, inviting all national and regional ombudsmen to discuss and debate issues of mutual relevance. This will not just be an opportunity for us at the EU level to learn from their experiences but also for them to learn about the things that the EU institutions do well and which too often go remarked or unnoticed. An invitation to all Members to this conference will be sent to you in the coming weeks. One final issue concerns the compliance rate of the EU institutions to my recommendations. For many years, this is been around 80%, and I note the continued concern of the Parliament at the 20% non-compliance rate in my 2014 Annual Report. However, I am happy to report to you today, already, that the figure in the 2015 Annual Report has risen to 90% – a very satisfactory achievement, which would not have been possible without the increased support of all of the EU institutions and agencies, and especially the support of this House. Before I conclude I think it important to put on record again how impressed I am by the high standards of the European civil service, of the thousands of dedicated people who work in the EU institutions and agencies all over Europe. The vast majority work hard to achieve high standards in their work and display a true ethic of public service. People will regain trust in their governing administrations when they begin to see positive changes for their families in their daily lives. This is mainly a political challenge, but a strong and ethical public administration is often what separates strong democracies around the world from weak and failed states. In order to achieve higher levels of popular legitimacy, it is important for the EU administration to be not only of the highest possible quality, but indeed the ‘gold standard’ in ethics, transparency, accountability and effectiveness. My task as European Ombudsman is to work with those institutions and agencies, and to work with this Parliament, to help to make that happen. Finally, let me conclude by again thanking the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, their staff and the secretariats for all the work on this report, and I look forward to your contributions.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Ms Cabezón Ruiz for her excellent report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. The Commission considers the work of the European Ombudsman in fighting maladministration to be of the utmost importance. Good administration in the service of European citizens is our shared objective, and in that sense the Spanish translation of ‘ombudsman’ really describes the function in a perfect way – defensor del pueblo. I would like, therefore, to take the opportunity to thank the Ombudsman for her efforts, for the consistently good cooperation with her and her services, and for the excellent quality of her work. The report in particular comments on the importance of the Ombudsman’s work on transparency as a guarantee of good administration. In that regard, let me recall that the Commission has set itself very ambitious objectives on transparency and has taken important steps in that regard which have also been acknowledged in the report. For instance, we decided that as from 1 December 2014, all Commissioners, their cabinet members and directors-general have to publish information on meetings with stakeholders and lobbyists. Moreover, the Commission has also ensured an unprecedented degree of transparency in the context of the TTIP negotiations. This is one of the elements of the dynamic relationship, I can say, with the European Parliament. The Commission welcomes the fact that the Ombudsman, as well as the Committee on Petitions (PETI), has commended the Commission for its pro-active approach in both areas, and I of course will then also have to commend Parliament for taking such an active role in bringing this about. The Commission has also accepted the majority of the Ombudsman’s recommendations in relation to the ‘revolving doors’ issue and adopted last year its first annual report concerning the occupational activities of senior officials after leaving the services. The Commission has also committed itself to improving the functioning and transparency of expert groups. There are also other important areas where the Ombudsman’s recommendations have been followed up by the Commission. For instance, we have taken numerous steps to make the Citizens’ Initiative more user-friendly, reflecting the recommendations of the Ombudsman. In its proposals for a European Border and Coast Guard – and the Ombudsman already referred to that – the Commission has included a complaint mechanism for fundamental rights issues. That is how we took into account the suggestion made by the Ombudsman in the recommendations in the Frontex investigation, so I think we did what you wanted us to do on this. This brings me to the comments in the report about the compliance rates of the institutions. I think we, as the Commission, had a generally high compliance rate. In 2014 it was 86%, and I am very glad to hear today the Ombudsman’s answer that for 2015 it will be 90%. Let us try and improve that even further. It is important to look at the Commission’s approval rate, because we are concerned in about 60% of all the cases, so it is very important that we do our best to approach 100% as much as we can. Naturally, over the years the compliance rates may vary, as the cases and the conclusions of the Ombudsman are different every year. However, the Commission always takes the Ombudsman’s remarks very seriously, and we will comply with her recommendations whenever possible. She referred to one issue where we did not agree, and we will come back to the issue of the tobacco industry at a later stage also in the European Parliament. I want to conclude by again thanking the rapporteur and you for this debate, and I want to confirm that the Commission is looking forward to continuing our excellent cooperation with the Ombudsman and her services. I can say also, as a personal remark, that Ms O’Reilly fully deserves the title defensor del pueblo.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to extend my thanks to Ms O’Reilly for her work. Not only in 2014, but ever since she took office, her work has been exemplary. The Committee on Petitions’ annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman serves not only as summary, an approval of the work of the European Ombudsman in any given year, but also as a reminder to us and other European institutions to be more service-minded, to be more open-minded to our citizens. Living up to the highest standards of good administration in the European Union needs continuous effort on our part. The Ombudman’s power to open strategic investigations on her own initiative often gives us the necessary push we need. In that matter, I would like to extend my support for the Ombudsman’s drive for greater transparency and progress with regard to the transparency register. The register, which has been set up jointly by the European Parliament and the Commission, aims to answer some profound public concerns. The fact that over 7 000 institutions have voluntarily registered, with the news circulating that in the past week another 49 have signed up, shows the willingness to address the transparency issue, which is very important. I believe that the information provided in the register to ensure and confirm a balanced representation of various stakeholders is a great push forward, and I believe this will allow us, the decision-maker, greater transparency and greater understanding of what exactly we need to do in the European institutions and the European Union as a whole. Thank you very much once again, Madam Ombudsman. Thank you for your hard work.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, we welcome the presence here of the European Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, and congratulate her on her solemn re-election. The European Ombudsman's annual activity report in 2014 highlights the important action of this institution, in ensuring good administration and in protecting the rights of citizens, who are now becoming more accountable and transparent within the European Union, not only in relation to its institutions, but also with informal bodies such as the Eurogroup and the troika which are taking as they are known to be harsh and consequently anti-social measures imposed on the countries in a memorandum.  In this context, it is particularly important that the European Central Bank was forced, following the actions of the ombudsman, to make its letter to the Irish Government on the economic crisis public, when the ECB's interventionist policy towards Ireland was solemnly demonstrated. However, important steps still need to be taken in relation to monitoring the functioning of the troika, which is why the ombudsman must investigate the conflict of interest between the role of the European Central Bank, as a member of the troika, as a creditor of the Member States of the Memorandum, and the mandate of the ECB under the Treaty. The same applies to the conflict of interest within the Commission, between the Role of the Commission in the Troika and its responsibility as guardian of the Treaties. At a time of intensity of refugee flows there must be control and accountability of Frodex itself, and in relation to TTIP it is a given that the ombudsman must step up her action because there is a lack of transparency and accountability. After all, MEPs only have access to TTIP documents in harsh terms of confidentiality that violate democratic principle and establish a regime of secret diplomacy. In fact, until recently, the ministers of the Member States of the Union, in order to obtain the TTIP documents, had to go to visit the local embassies of the United States.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, I would like to congratulate the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, on her excellent work and personally thank you, Emily, for the good cooperation between you and your institution and my committee. It is always a pleasure working with you. I appreciate that the Ombudsman has focused in particular on transparency-related issues and transparency, as a guarantee of good governance. The Ombudsman plays a very important role in helping the European institutions to become more transparent, effective and, not least, citizen-friendly, as it contributes to increasing public confidence in our Union. One issue that has been particularly important in the year we are talking about, i.e. 2014, is the work of the Ombudsman in relation to Frontex. It is important that Frontex should have sufficient its own equipment and staff to ensure the sustainable protection of our external borders and to ensure the same functioning throughout the EU. I therefore particularly welcome the fact that the Commission has taken into account the Ombudsman's views in the new proposal on Frontex, to establish a mechanism for individual complaints about potential violations of fundamental rights. I also welcome the Ombudsman's inquiries into citizens' right to participate in the EU decision-making process. In relation to this, I would also like to draw your attention to an investigation presented in Sweden, the country that I know best, which shows very great ignorance of the role of the EU institutions. This is worrying, because it reduces the ability of citizens to actively participate and create influence on matters that we decide on in europe. In a prosperous democracy, anyone who wants to influence political decisions needs to be in a position to do so. Public discourse across our Member States often does not contribute to this. A more active public conversation could have improved democratic conditions. In this context, it is important that all institutions take greater responsibility for communicating information, dialogue and increasing people's knowledge. It is important that we take our responsibility and our time to inform about this. Together we can help to improve knowledge of europe and increase the sense of participation of our citizens. For your commitment and for the Ombudsman's commitment, I would like once again to express my many thanks.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, if there is one thing that makes this Ombudsman's report clear, it is the lack of transparency of the European institutions. How the doors that open wide for interest groups, the lobbies, close in the noses of citizens. The report stresses that this obscurantism has been particularly serious in the case of the TIC negotiations.  Two investigations had to be opened by the Ombudsman relating to the refusal to make the documents public, while certain interested parties had privileged access to those documents. Despite the Ombudsman's guidelines, secrecy continues. In order to access the documents, Members of this Parliament have to enter a locked reading room. We have to sign that we are going to keep secret about what we read there and, most seriously, still do not allow the debate of the citizen initiative, with more than three million signatures, against TTE.

name: Margrete Auken
text: verts/ALE Group. Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank Ruiz for a good report and good cooperation. And of course, most of all, thank you, Emily, for living up to what we fought for when we had to have you chosen. We need to make it clear that these institutions should have a real ombudsman and not a partisan 'stick-in-the-rend-boy'. We have got that and I think we are getting it fixed now. We can also feel that all the institutions, including Parliament, are now preparing for this to be the case. I will not repeat what everyone else has said. I agree with it all and rejoice at what you have done for Frontex and what it has meant that we have been given openness – or some openness, let's put it this way – some openness about TTIP.  In particular, I will emphasize the work that you continue to get good administration into everything. Good administration is about citizens being well served, being at the centre. That's the service principle! They need quick answers, they need clear answers, proper explanations. But they also need to be comfortable with our system. In this respect, I would like to stress in particular that we have not yet managed to make it clear that problems of integrity, i.e. conflicts of interest, must not occur at all. It is still the case in many of our institutions that one thinks that as long as one has a 'declaration of conflicts of interest' then all is well. Then the rest of us are going to take an interest in whether they are nice people, whether they pay taxes on time, whether they are faithful to their spouses, and what do I know! Non of our business! It's none of our business! We must be sure that there is not the slightest shadow of conflict of interest. In this respect, therefore, we are going to look quite hard at the EMA in particular, where I have a feeling that it has gone completely wrong again. Now there are just two words I would just like to slam in here: the Aarhus Convention, it is not properly implemented here in the EU because we do not have access to justice. On the other hand, it is not properly respected in the Member States either. Although it is up to the Member States' Ombudsman to ensure this, I am glad that you are also doing something about it. The very last sentence: you are the only Ombudsman who has the right to examine Parliament, your own parliament. This means that you have a duty to do so, and you can do more of that!

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, for her work, because her efforts have indeed been very effective and very important in continuing to make these institutions more transparent. And I wanted to focus on transparency, because, as we have said, the greatest number of complaints and investigations relate precisely to requests for information and access to documents and transparency, and all too often these requests are rejected.  In particular, I would like to focus on the need to shed light and investigate the use and expenditure with regard to the Structural Funds, structural funds which, unfortunately, do not yet provide for an effective control mechanism and also where there are mechanisms such as auditing, very often we fall into the situation where the controller is also the controller. Moreover, all too often we talk about projects that have no added value for society. I am thinking, for example, of an absurd project such as the Tav, the Turin-Lyon high-speed project, which is in fact a major imposed and harmful project which has been highly contested by the local population for many years and which, moreover, is also financed from European funds. I therefore call on the Ombudsman to shed light on these aspects too, in close cooperation with the Court of Auditors, so that the too many irregularities and lack of transparency that remain are swept away by our work.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this report aims to give quitus to the 2014 activities of the European Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly. I recognise that Mrs O'Reilly has sought to improve the transparency of the functioning of the European Union. In this area, it has taken two initiatives that deserve to be commended. When it comes to lobbying, it has succeeded in creating a transparency register in which more than 7,000 lobby groups have registered. While this register will certainly not reduce the influence of the 35,000 lobbyists on the decisions of the European Union, it has at least the merit of existing. Ms. O'Reilly has also been successful in improving transparency in clinical trials. The information on these trials is now partly published. This is particularly the case with clinical study reports that determine the authorization to market drugs. This provides more information about the effectiveness of drugs and the actual cost of research. Transparency, however, has its limits. Ms O'Reilly has thus failed to achieve real transparency on the negotiation of the transatlantic free trade treaty, the TAFTA. While access to the negotiating documents has been officially relaxed, in practice their consultation remains problematic, including for MEPs. The Union really wants to prevent real democratic control over the TAFTA. Tomorrow, she will explain to us that national parliaments do not have the power to vote on this treaty, which will nevertheless change the lives of the peoples of Europe. In addition, Ms. O'Reilly has committed a political fault in my view by calling for a complaint procedure against Frontex officers for migrants. This procedure will be used to allow migrants to stay in Europe.  For all these reasons, I will vote against this report.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Another wonderful morning here in Brussels, in the plenary session of the European Parliament. The dynamics and the mood are normal, this time it is the European Ombudsman who is presenting his annual report. Of course, he has no legal qualifications, lest ideological clarity be disturbed by some kind of professionalism. About 25 out of 150 members are present, and they have a convivial conversation about how to make the European Union more democratic, so that they can somehow love it more on the issue of citizens, especially asylum and migration.  Dear Ombudsman, Dear Colleagues, I have an idea. How about you hear the voices of European citizens who say that we sympathize with the unfortunate people, the poor, the wretched, those who otherwise flee the wars caused by the Western world, but we cannot take any more refugees, stop the flow of migration, and democracy would be if you took the right decisions. What are they doing compared to this? They tolerate water cannoning of people defending their homelands in supposedly democratic European countries. Shame on you. And I would advise the citizens of Europe to achieve what we Hungarians have achieved by exercising their human rights, with real democracy and, if necessary, by fighting for what we Hungarians have achieved, that there will be a referendum on this issue. Now we are finally teaching you democracy and human rights.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A big thank you to our Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly. Cooperation with the Committee on Petitions is good, no, it is not only good, it has improved. If we had given your predecessor three stars in the Office for Cooperation with our committee, you would get one more asterisk. So thank you again for the good cooperation. It is right that you have said – or it is stated in your report – that transparency is at the heart of it. Now I can speak on my group: we see it in a similar way. Lack of transparency leads to mistrust, mistrust leads to false rumours, and false rumours lead to a loss of trust. We are witnessing it at TTIP. The most heated debates take place on matters that are not in the documents at all. It is true that we MEPs have access. I would also ask my fellow Members to make more use of these reading rooms, because what is in the TTIP is quite interesting, and we can then also prevent false rumours accordingly. One wish on the transparency register: you have the full support of me. I would just ask you to ensure that we then ensure that it remains practicable in the practical implementation procedure. Nor must it hinder Parliament's work. Where are the reserves? In my view, the reserves are still in that we are directing citizens' complaints or citizens' petitions more quickly to where they belong. We have the Ombudsman, the Committee on Petitions, OLAF, the courts, the institutions of the European Union – in this sense, we are all players in a common team. Close to the people for a better European Union. In this sense, we should continue to maintain good cooperation. Thank you again, until then! We will soon have the next report, and then we can discuss it further. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, as you know, the Ombudsman launched various investigations in 2014 and 2015. Considering this terrible situation with migrants that is splitting the European Union countries, do you not think that the Ombudsman should launch an investigation on how the Schengen Area Agreement is respected by members and how this is affecting European Union citizens?

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The first remark is that I think it is a good thing that the Ombudsman is dealing with this, because we must be honest with ourselves: we have a migration problem, a huge problem in the European Union. What annoys me most: In times of need, a family usually stands together. Here it seems rather that everything is flying apart. That is why I strongly support the Ombudsman. Secondly, all the bodies – the Ombudsman, Parliament, the Commission and the Council – should come together to resolve this problem. Citizens are not interested in describing the problem, but in solving problems. In this sense, we should continue to work intensively together to solve the problem.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Madam President, it is quite difficult, in a minute, to mention all the activities of the European Ombudsman, as they are numerous and very diverse. Furthermore, I believe that Mrs O'Reilly is showing a real availability towards European citizens, which we should welcome. I will therefore focus only quickly and quickly on one subject, which is that of transparency actions within institutions and in the context of lobbying. I share with you the idea that it is essential to guarantee the existence of European institutions free of conflicts of interest if we are to focus precisely on preserving the confidence of European citizens. It is in this sense that codes of ethics have emerged in recent years and a public register of representatives of interests has been created. I would like to take this opportunity to point out to the representatives of the National Front that this register does not date from their arrival, but from a little longer, since it dates back to 2011. I'm closing the bracket. However, are we well-armed enough to act? Indeed, how can we be credible if one of the institutions, such as the Council, does not play the game and participates in this collective effort of transparency on the relations we have with the lobbies? I wanted to ask you a question, Madam: is it not time to consider the creation of an independent authority which, like the High Authority for the Transparency of Political Life in France, is careful to prevent and detect cases of conflict of public or private interest by public officials?

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I too would like to thank you, Mrs O'Reilly, as Ombudsman. Both the high number of questions to you and your team and the report we are voting on today show that you are doing an excellent job in the interests of the citizens in improving Europe – an approach that I can only support on behalf of my group, the ECR Group. In addition, your commitment shows me that it was good to put you in this position as a professional with national experience and not to give fellow Parliamentarians a comfortable seat. I also think it is a good idea to give the Ombudsman's office a political profile. If, as discussed in Strasbourg, you launch a kind of own-initiative report on the subject of TTIP, for example, in order to see whether the European Commission complies with the rules of transparency, then that is a good thing. In short, thank you for your work, thank you for your efforts to give the Ombudsman's post, which is still far too unknown, more profile, more weight, more publicity!

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Mrs O'Reilly, it is a great pleasure for me to welcome you back to this House and to receive it as what we consider it to be, as a member of the Committee on Petitions. For us it is our alter ego in service and direct attention to European citizens. It is extremely satisfying to work in a coordinated manner with your Office and to monitor your activity interactively and enrichingly. Do you know why? For their determination and results. The Ombudsman's contribution to improving the functioning of the entire European administration is hugely satisfactory and very significant because, from the revolving doors to transparency in the TTE negotiations and in clinical trials, from the critical and constructive look at Frontex to the permanent defence of the fundamental rights of Europeans , we're just talking about work and results. And that's what enriches our joint work. I would like to thank you personally for your work on the issue of migration and asylum, not only in 2014, which covers this report, but especially last year, in which the refugee crisis put us in front of the mirror. You have defended European values and the need to give a common response from the outset. In one of our previous meetings we have talked about the special nature that you have given to your mandate and your Office, a high performance team in constant search of excellence in service to citizens. I can only encourage and applaud your efforts.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, we trust the European Ombudsman because she remains one of the few institutions in the European Union that European citizens deserve to trust. At a time when Europe is experiencing its greatest existential crisis, unable to protect human rights, as evidenced by the images of suffering refugees, images that go back to the thirties, the institution of the European Ombudsman is a mainstay of transparency and respect for citizens' rights. We welcome and support the European Ombudsman's call for Frontex to set up an independent mechanism for individual complaints of violations of the fundamental rights of refugees and call on it to investigate this issue further by turning its attention to the drama that is unfolding at the borders of the European Union, to Europeans, to people who beg behind the wires for rights to life and remain trapped today in Idomeni, Athens and Piraeus.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I am not here to criticise an Ombudsman who is doing a difficult job under tough circumstances. When 46% of people have no trust in the European Union, the figure in the United Kingdom is surely far higher. We have revolving door cases involving high-ranking officials; we have an incredibly low rate of any officials actually being sacked when there is any misconduct. It was The Beatles who used to finish their shows by telling the audience: You’re such a lovely audience, we’d love to take you home with us, but unfortunately we took the last audience home and there’s no more room. Well, I truly believe that if the British people could be the audience, if they could come out here to Brussels and see what I see on a daily basis, if it were not so remote, if they could see all the excesses of this place then on 23 June they would vote to leave.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, on her re-election and for her excellent work with the ultimate goal provided that the European institutions provide the best possible public service to citizens and of ensuring, of course, respect for the rights of citizens. There's been a lot of talk here about transparency. Indeed, it is one of the main objectives and complaints that are made, and therefore congratulates it on all the work that has been done on the new procedure and the new rules in order to achieve the final objective and also the coordinator for investigations on its own initiative.  I would like to focus on mismanagement. One of the Ombudsman's also objectives is to have good administration. We mean maladministring when a public body does not comply with the rules that have been established or do not comply with the principles of the Union. I wonder whether the fact that the Anti-Discrimination Directive has been standing in the Council for six years or the non-ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty so that persons with disabilities can access reading are not an example of maladministration. And that is why I, who know that the Ombudsman is a person very committed to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, ask her for help in unlocking in the Council — those countries that are exercising the veto — that Anti-Discrimination Directive and that Marrakesh Treaty. It will mean that we will be complying with the principles of the Union.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms O’Reilly and our rapporteur. Our report emphasises the crucial role that the European Ombudsman plays in ensuring European democracy and her key mission to make the voices of citizens heard. In her renewed mandate, the Ombudsman has demonstrated a clear commitment to increasing transparency, protecting fundamental rights and taking action to the benefit of the general public. The Ombudsman’s investigations into the ongoing TTIP negotiations have helped us achieve a greater deal of transparency than ever before in EU trade policy. More documents have been published and greater access to documents granted. To secure a decent TTIP agreement, we need to demonstrate that cherished institutions, such as our NHS in the UK, are not under threat. Transparency is crucial to delivering public trust in our trade policy, and the UK Government could learn a great deal from your work, Ms O’Reilly, in releasing the legal advice that they undertook on the impact of TTIP on the NHS and releasing that information as soon as possible. Citizens’ concerns for the protection of the fundamental rights of refugees have been heard loud and clear by Parliament’s Committee on Petitions and by the European Ombudsman. I fully support the Ombudsman’s call to establish a complaints mechanism for refugees fleeing war, who deserve to have their fundamental rights respected and upheld by Frontex. Her actions to ensure that clinical reports on medicines by the European Medicines Agency are published not only shows a commitment to proactive transparency but is also securing another step towards making lifesaving drugs for diseases such as hepatitis C available at affordable prices for those who need them. I congratulate the European Ombudsman on her achievements so far and encourage her to continue pressing and pursuing her five-year plan and strategy towards 2019 for the benefit of all of us. We look forward to your continued work, and we look forward to working with you and your team. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Kirton-Darling, I note that you give guarantees about TTIP and that it will not impact on the NHS. I further note that that is very different from what the unions are currently saying and, indeed, from the legal advice that I believe Unison came out with just a couple of days ago. Are you saying that you completely reject the advice on that position from the trade unions?

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Arnott, I think you have fully misunderstood what I just said. What I said is that to ensure that there is public trust in trade policy, we need transparency. The legal advice undertaken not by Unison but by Unite on the impact of TTIP on the NHS is actually very worrying. The UK Government has undertaken its own legal advice around the impact of the TTIP Agreement on the NHS. I have been calling for its publication, and unions in the UK and NHS campaigners in the UK have been calling for its publication. The UK Government should now publish that advice.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam Chairman, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate The European Ombudsman Emily O'Rilley on her re-election to the post. Behind her, at least for now, are very impressive results. The level of dedication we have witnessed since her taking office is a guarantee that we have many more quality initiatives ahead of us. First of all, I welcome its engagement in the field of the transaparence of the European institutions. The European Commission has failed this exam too many times, and the TTIP negotiations are an obvious example. Representatives of the EU institutions, having the proverbial mouthful of the digital market, need to understand that the digital age has changed not only the economy but also politics significantly. Closed-door deals, as the public gropes in the dark, are a relic of the past. Thank you Emily O'Rilley for reminding them of that. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you have spoken of the lack of transparency and have set an example for TTIP. Can you explain to us how you would like to continue the negotiation? Because we know it's a negotiation process now.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleagues, everything that is done behind closed doors, even if it is done in the best intentions, honestly, people doubt it. If you work honestly, there is no reason why this should not be transparent because we are all citizens of this Union and we all wish the best for our citizens.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to join in the thanks that have been expressed here to the Ombudsman for his good work. I would also like to thank him and his office for their effective work. According to these documents, there are only 67 employees in your office and you are doing an effective job. When you compare the offices of most political groups, they have many more employees, which means that you would have to have more money so that you could act even more efficiently and better and focus on certain issues.  But I have one wish for you. In fact, the Treaty of Lisbon has mentioned that the EU will have legislation on good governance. We don't have one at the moment. There are only ethical guidelines for good administration drawn up by the Ombudsman's office. I know your office has worked on this, and you're not an obstacle. There is opposition from the Commission, the Council and also here in Parliament. Good governance and binding regulations are important to citizens, but they are also important for civil servants. At present, citizens cannot appeal to the Court because there is no binding legislation. Civil servants are also in a bad legal position if there is no binding legislation.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cuirim fáilte roimh an tuarascáil seo ó Emily O'Reilly, an tOmbudsman, agus tréaslaím léi as an dea-obair atá idir lámha aici.  Is léir go bhfuil sé fíorthábhachtach go bhfuil a leithéid d'oifig with feidhmiú, go háirithe nuair and chuirtear san áireamh cásanna faoi leith; abair an fiosrú a dhein sí faoin gComhbheartas Iascaigh le cinntiú go mbeadh sé trédhearcach agus go mbeadh fáil na doiciméid úd. Cé gur dhiúltaigh an Coimisiún rochtain iomlán a sholáthar, tá dualgas orthu anois and bheith go hiomlán trédhearcach. Tá an scéal céanna againn on ndóigh maidir le TTIP, agus arís tá sé chomh tábhachtach go mbeadh an chumhacht with an Ombudsman cure and chuir on na sainghrúpaí go bhfuil aon cheist ann faoi choinbhleacht leasa and bheith freagrach. Tá dualgas on an gCoimisiún and bheith trédhearcach go dtí saoránaigh atá thar and bheith diúltach agus amhrasach le cúis mhaith maidir le TTIP. By imperial, ní fhéadfainn mar Éireannach by tagairt don éacht and dhein Emily O'Reilly maidir le brú and chur on an gCoimisiún i dtaobh an Bhainc Ceannais Eorpaigh agus mar thoradh on an mbrú sin go raibh orthu litir and thaispeáint don Rialtas Éireannach faoin ngéarchéim airgeadais with tabhairt chun solais an chaimiléireacht and bhí on bun ag an am.  Níl ansin ach cúpla sampla den dea-obair atá ar bun agus tá a fhios agam go bhfuil i bhfad níos mó ná sin idir lámha aici. Mar sin, léiríonn sé go bhfuil oifig an Ombudsman with feidhmiú mar is ceart agus with dul ó neart go neart on son shaoránaigh na hEorpa.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The perception of what international protection for refugees means has gradually changed and now also includes a very distorted interpretation of the Convention on Human Rights. It is a problem that the majority of the refugees we receive are in fact economic migrants, and that only 10-20% of those who come here receive refugee status. A large number of people who do not have the right to asylum in Europe must therefore expect to be returned – often under duress. From a human rights perspective, the return cannot be seen as a violation, and the ombudsman's suggestion that Frontex should set up a special service to receive and deal with complaints from migrants who feel mistreated during the return is the result of a policy that is not realistic. Personally, I see the proposal as a new gravel in the machinery of those politicians who are opposed to the organised and effective return of illegal migrants.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Dear Guardian, we are actually adopting this report every year in the form of a European Parliament resolution. I have no doubt that you are doing a good job, as my colleagues. The very title of authority, however, has a great deal of promise at first sight: the European Ombudsman. However, I would like to point out that this is not an appropriate title: the Ombudsman is neither pan-European nor has sufficient powers to protect human rights in the Union. For example, the Ombudsman only accepts complaints if they relate to a Union institution or body, otherwise she redirects complaints to the relevant authorities in the Member States. I myself have personal experience of the operation of this institute. In the past, I wanted to explain to the Ombudsman the infamous case of violations of fundamental rights in the case of Patria and the abuse of the judiciary in this case, but there was no success. The Ombudsman found, within the limits of her powers, that the case did not touches on EU law. She redirected me back to the system I was protesting for. Perhaps there is no question at this place whether such a guardian, with such powers, we need at all. I guess i do. However, we should consider a genuine, comprehensive European Ombudsman of Fundamental Rights within the EU, who will have sufficient powers to react when it is also the most klatant violations of the rights of citizens of the European Union.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are debating a good report which, in addition to being good, is true. Just the information given contains what happened and it just happened positively. I wanted to make it very clear that cooperation with the Ombudsman is not just today's debate. We meet the Ombudsman as a College of Quaestors of the European Parliament. Soon there will be another meeting, so our cooperation is ongoing cooperation. What would I particularly like to emphasise? Transparency register, that is, the question of the idea and the way of implementation. Here I am very pleased with the cooperation. The second very important factor is respect for fundamental rights. We have a report that came out literally yesterday or yesterday. It shows that respect for fundamental rights is deteriorating dramatically, including in the European Union, including in particular among some Member States of the European Union. So, wishing me success, I would like to continue to thank and declare: I am very pleased to support this report.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the defensor del pueblo for his truly valuable inquiries. I would like to focus on the forced returns of migrants managed by Frontex, in the light of increasing arrivals, an increasingly closed Union and agreements with countries indifferent to the law, such as Turkey. You rightly called for Frontex to set up mechanisms to denounce the violations of rights resulting from its actions. I would like to ask you whether the task of the controller can be entrusted to the controller, whether it is enough to demand that Frontex guarantee respect for the welfare of returnees on return flights (welfare is a vague word), whether it is not appropriate for border guards to provide for the possibility of anonymous complaints or NGOs and appeals when complaints are considered inadmissible.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE).
text: – I am pleased to welcome European Ombudsman O'Reilly back. I welcome the Ombudsman's inquiry into fundamental rights, which was designed to show the extent to which Member States respect fundamental rights in the implementation of EU cohesion policy. The good use of resources received by cohesion policies in the Member States protects the interests of citizens. I trust that the enforcement of fundamental rights will be part of your work in other areas. As Vice-President of the Committee on Petitions, I welcomed the initiative to consult on the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative. This instrument will only be usable if it achieves its objective and facilitates the participation of EU citizens in European debates and decision-making. Transparency and objectivity are still bumpy in the proceedings, so the Ombudsman is likely to have more work to do on this subject. However, I do not agree with the part of the report which attempts to include the Council's legislative activities in the category of abuse of office. I think that's a strong exaggeration. The ombudsman's data also shows that complaints outside his resimatic powers receive twice as much from his office as from complaints that actually concern him. We can change that a lot by providing more effective information. More information will be made available to citizens in as many languages as possible.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, thank you to the rapporteur for the excellent and comprehensive report and Mr Timmermans for recognising the added value of the Spanish term Ombudsman, which we can apply with full justice to Mrs O'Reilly, whom I congratulate on her active defence of European citizens. We are particularly pleased with the modernisation and dynamism it has imprinted on its institution and its tireless work in favour of effective transparency, fundamental rights in these critical times, citizen participation and european Union competition and trade policy. In this regard, I encourage her to be more proactive with the transparency of the Horizon 2020 programme, which affects fundamental issues and which needs more rigorous supervision, as the rapporteur tells or proposes in paragraph 22. I also encourage you to improve communication policy, because although we know — you first, by your profession — that, unfortunately, what you sell is sensationalism and blood, we also need pedagogical work that recognizes the results. You have said this: the recognition of the thousands of European officials who work quietly under enormous pressure with fewer and more means and more demands, often at the price of their health and even their lives in some cases. Progress and success also need to be acknowledged, and in comparison I am concerned that in my country, for example, where there are many more complaints, on the other hand, no action is opened. Perhaps stronger cooperation with national and regional ombmbly defenders would help us not to be the last resort of so many citizens who do not go where they should also go at national and regional level.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, first of all we would like to stress the importance of the Ombudsman's figure. A much-needed figure to defend citizens from the excesses of European administration and legislation, and yes, refugees as the main victims of Frontex's excesses and the external walls of this European Union. I would like to focus my speech on the case of revolving doors as well, and to thank Mrs O'Reilly for her efforts in this area. Unfortunately, we cannot thank the European Commission for its efforts, because every day it shows its opacity in information with other institutions, as with this European Parliament. All cases of high-ranking officials leaving their post should be published, as article 16 of the relevant regulations states. Ending revolving doors should be a priority objective of all actors, including institutions. In the European Union of lobbies this is the main way of hijacking democracy, kidnapping sovereignty and creating ad hoc laws for private and private interests.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, much has been done, Madam Public Defender, there is much more to do. And there are high expectations, as you can see, of us MEPs, there are high expectations of various European institutions, and especially the high expectations of our citizens. You have our support, practically, from all the clubs here in this home. You have undivided support obviously in the European public.  And that is why we believe that you will do everything to make the range of things that are happening today, that are essential for the future of the European Union, as accessible as possible to citizens. Here I think first of all about TTIP, but I also think about everything that is happening with the migrant crisis. You have our support, we expect you to run your office even more firmly and decisively.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, Mrs O'Reilly's effort is commendable, given the short time since her election. Its role as a European ombudsman in helping the institutions of the European Union to become more open, effective and citizen-friendly, with a view to strengthening citizens' confidence in the Union, is very difficult. The idea of European integration must be consistent with more transparency and control of its institutions. In view of last May's Eurobarometer, public confidence in the Union is only 40%, but the lack of it reaches 46%. In addition, there is 20% of the ombudsman's proposals with which the institutions have not complied.  There is still a long way to go in areas such as transparency, the rule of law, ethics, the fight against corruption in the management of conflicts of interest in the public sector, transparency in clinical trials and, above all, openness in the TTIR negotiations.  To this end, I support an increase in the annual budget of the European Ombudsman's Office, but I would also like to see the legal commitment of these recommendations examined.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Madam Ombudsman, the existence of an Ombudsman and, above all, her activity are a guarantee of defence and strengthening of citizenship in Europe. The ombudsman's interventions are based on citizens' complaints and are therefore reactive in nature, but For my part I believe that a genuine Ombudsman of the European Union should take a proactive stance, i.e. he should take initiatives, even without complaints from the citizens, with a view to correcting certain acts of the organs of the European Union or even some Member States. For example, the recent adoption in Denmark of laws allowing the state to confiscate refugees' assets should merit strong intervention by the Ombudsman because they are an unnameable attack on citizenship.  On the other hand, since poverty is one of the worst enemies of citizenship, its eradication should also be a priority for a true Ombudsman. Fighting poverty is strengthening citizenship.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, an overwhelming majority of the honourable Members who spoke today came out in support of the Ombudsman’s work and Ms O’Reilly’s report, so there is no need for me to dwell on that. I would like to limit my comments to two issues. First, pertaining to the transparency on the TTIP negotiations: I would challenge any Member of this House to give me an example of any trade negotiation worldwide where there is more transparency than on this negotiation on the side of the European Union, and I would challenge those people who say that everything should be in the public eye. It is true of any negotiation on an international Treaty that parts of it will have to be dealt with in confidence for several reasons, and I think that is why the method of allowing Members of the European Parliament to know what is in the documents and asking them not to disclose that is the best possible method for people’s representatives to be fully informed about the subject without violating the necessary rules of confidentiality. The other subject I wanted to raise, which was raised by quite a number of Members, is transparency. We will launch a public consultation on transparency next month in preparation of a proposal we will make to Parliament and Council on a mandatory transparency register, which I think is the next step of where we need to take transparency. It would already be a great leap forward if Parliament and Council would apply the same rules on transparency that we apply today in the Commission. I hope that all of you who are so much in favour of transparency as far as the Commission is concerned will have the same zeal when it comes to transparency of the European Parliament’s work and especially also the Council’s work. I think that is very much in line with Emily O’Reilly’s report, and let us work on this together.

name: President. –
text: Madam Morvai, just very briefly, we are hearing a lot of interference so perhaps you could just allow the speaker to speak. Thank you for your enthusiasm.

name: Emily O’Reilly
text: Ombudsman. – Madam President, could I very warmly thank everybody who has contributed to this debate for their contributions. I found the overall impact very invigorating and very encouraging and it will encourage me to work even harder in relation to my strategy. I think this has shown again something which I greatly value – I valued it enormously as the Irish Ombudsman and I value it greatly now – because my work cannot be done properly and as it should be without the engaged support of Parliament, and I certainly felt that support that today. As First Vice-President Timmermans noted, an overwhelming majority of people mentioned transparency in their contributions. I think that at least 80% to 85% mentioned it, and that is not just reflecting the fact that so many of the complaints that I get have to do with transparency but because Members are reflecting citizens’ concerns about what is perceived to be a lack of transparency, perhaps leading to a lack of public trust within the EU. That again encourages me to continue even more vigorously, with Parliament’s assistance, the work that I am doing in relation to making all of the institutions of the EU more transparent. Another issue that emerged quite a lot was TTIP. As you know, I did an own-initiative investigation into the transparency of TTIP, and I posed the question that First Vice—President Timmermans has posed in relation to what is the appropriate space for confidentiality in any trade agreement and what is appropriate to be made open. As one speaker noted today, we are living in a digital age and, whether we like it or not, there is a much greater expectation, particularly among young people, that certain matters are going to be made transparent. I think that is something that we are going to have to live with. I shall be meeting Commissioner Malmström on Monday next, and I will be reflecting on some of the issues in relation to the transparency of the TTIP negotiations with her. Of course, it is very important for me, if I am to deal with this issue, to get complaints on it. Another issue that was mentioned a lot was Frontex, and here I would again like to thank Parliament for supporting me in relation to the complaints mechanism, which is something I believe is now going to happen in relation to a reformed Frontex. With my colleagues in the network, many of whom are greatly engaged in this migration issue, I will continue to see what we can do collectively to help in this. So again, thank you to the rapporteur, thank you Madam Vice-President for chairing this debate, and thanks to all the Members for their interest in, and engagement with, my office.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you to all the shadow rapporteurs for their work, because, after all, this report is the result of everyone's work. Thank you in particular to the Ombudsman, for actually having made this report possible and thank you to the Commission, for being so receptive to all the proposals that come from the Ombudsman and also for having collected the proposals which have been shown here. Therefore, I would like to thank everyone and say that I am left with a positive balance. I think we've started a good path and that's what has to be left as the conclusion of this day. We are all aware — I do not think it is necessary to reiterate that we are aware - that the Ombudsman's Office and the Committee on Petitions are key bodies to ensure the participation of citizens and need the full support of the institutions as a whole so that we can truly place citizens at the heart and make them part of this great project. Especially important in recent times when everything is questioned — needless to say the reasons – is to insist that we all have an obligation to represent all citizens in each of our actions. Therefore, being aware of this is what allows us and supports us to be here today. I especially reiterate my thanks to Mrs. O'Reilly.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Ombudsman's task is to protect the rights of persons with disabilities and to ensure that the EU administration is aware of its responsibilities in respect of compliance with these rights. Persons who believe that an EU institution does not comply with the provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities have the right to lodge complaints with the Ombudsman. At the beginning of 2014, a seconded national expert joined the Ombudsman's team to help develop a work programme on disability issues and to find ways to better reach citizens and staff of the EU institutions and inform them of their rights and obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The European Parliament agrees with the Ombudsman that the EU institutions should ensure access to their services for persons with disabilities and that they have access to information and means of communication. Parliament also calls on the EU institutions to ensure that the working environment is open, inclusive and accessible to persons with disabilities, so that they can participate effectively and fully in political and public life. The Ombudsman also meets regularly with MEPs and institutional staff to discuss ways of improving the quality of administration, to highlight the procedures for the proper handling of complaints and to ensure appropriate follow-up to the Ombudsman's recommendations and reports. The European Parliament calls on the Ombudsman to continue to support the European Network of Ombudsmen in order to raise awareness among EU citizens of the division of competences between the European Ombudsman, national and regional ombudsmen and Parliament's Committee on Petitions.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Ombudsman plays a special role in protecting citizens and their fundamental rights. The main task of the independent agency is to investigate complaints of maladministration in the activities of the EU institutions, such as abuse of powers, discrimination or unjustified delay. In 2014, the European Ombudsman dealt with a total of 2 163 complaints, of which 325 were initiated. The complaints received are largely related to public access to the documents of the institutions. I think it is important to pay attention to cases where the Ombudsman has found maladministration and to take the necessary steps to improve the situation.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. I would like to commend the excellent work of Emily O'Reilly, who is firmly taking on her role as European Ombudsman. In order to ensure the proper administration of our institutions, it is committed to ensuring that they respect the democratic principles and values of the Union. In particular, I commend his actions with regard to Frontex. It is essential that the Agency respects the Ombudsman's proposals to protect the human rights of migrants during its joint return operations, particularly with regard to pregnant women and children. This issue is all the more important today in the context of the increase in the number of refugees at the borders of the European Union.  I also fully support Emily O'Reilly in pushing Frontex to set up its own human rights complaints mechanism. It is unthinkable that the Agency would refuse to do so on the grounds that it would not be responsible for violations of fundamental rights in the course of its activities.  This should also apply to The work agreements concluded by Frontex with the competent authorities of third countries, implemented in complete opacity. The fight for transparency is essential to give europe's democracy a place of life.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I would like to begin by applauding the Ombudsman's work not only for the evaluation year, but also for her entire term of office in increasing fairness and transparency in the EU. Anyone who has read the report must recognise that the Ombudsman's work is very responsible and not easy at all. It must also be said that it is the European institutions that do not make the Ombudsman's work any easier. The report notes that, as in previous years, most of the inquiries launched by the Ombudsman concerned the Commission (59.6 %) and the number of inquiries concerning other EU institutions, including the EP, launched by the Ombudsman in 2014 show that we are not facilitating her work. Transparency, openness, access to information, respect for citizens' rights and high ethical standards are essential for the trust of citizens and institutions, especially the European institutions, when we want to maintain people's trust. I therefore believe that the European institutions will also contribute to greater openness and transparency in their activities, thanks to the open, innovative and transparent work of the Ombudsman, the new publication of the European Code of Good Administrative Behaviour.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – MEPs have an important role to play in dealing with the work of the European Ombudsman.  The report shows that the Ombudsman closed 387 complaints in 2014. Most often, the Ombudsman dealt with the transparency of EU documents, competition and selection processes. Sometimes we are not aware of what it means to be the European Ombudsman. First and foremost, it is about resolving complaints relating to the functioning of institutions.  Nevertheless, I believe that the Ombudsman did the right thing in 2014. I would like the Ombudsman to be given a review by the court systems of individual Member States, which often do not work for the good of their citizens.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. – The office of the European Ombudsman has proved that an institution such as this one is much needed in the European Union. In 2014, the Ombudsman’s office significantly contributed to an increase in the transparency and integrity of other European institutions and the Union as whole. The Ombudsman initiated several important activities, including the establishment of the so-called Own-Initiative Inquiry, which has addressed fundamental issues at European level. I think it is essential that it looked into the composition of the Commission’s expert groups, transparency in lobbying and the work of the Agencies. The Ombudsman’s new strategy is also very welcome for further promotion of good public administration.  I would like to encourage the institution to continue its good work, to continue its pressure on other European bodies and to prevail as a good role model of integrity. The European institutions, on the other hand, should comply with the Ombudsman’s recommendations and make transparency their priority. That will not only have an increased impact on the reputation of the European Union in the eyes of the citizens, but it will especially protect the Union’s financial interests at EU level.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on  – the oral question to the Commission on tobacco agreement (PMI agreement) by Bart Staes, José Bové, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance (O—000010/2016 – B8—0109/2016) (2016/2555(RSP)), – the oral question to the Commission on Tobacco agreement (PMI agreement) by Ingeborg Gräßle, Petri Sarvamaa, on behalf of the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) (O—000014/2016 – B8—0110/2016) (2016/2555(RSP)), – the oral question to the Commission on Tobacco agreement (PMI agreement) by Marco Valli, Rolandas Paksas, on behalf of the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group (O—000015/2016 – B8-0111/2016) (2016/2555(RSP)), – the oral question to the Commission on Tobacco agreement (PMI agreement) by Inés Ayala Sender , on behalf of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament (O—000016/2016 – B8—0112/2016) (2016/2555(RSP)), – the oral question to the Commission on Tobacco Agreement (PMI agreement) by Michael Theurer, on behalf of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (O—000017/2016 – B8-0113/2016) (2016/2555(RSP)), – the oral question to the Commission on Tobacco agreement (PMI agreement) by Ryszard Czarnecki, on behalf of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group (O—000018/2016 – B8-0114/2016) (2016/2555(RSP)), and – the oral question to the Commission on Tobacco agreement (PMI agreement) by Dennis de Jong, Rina Ronja Kari, Anne-Marie Mineur, Martina Anderson, Matt Carthy, Liadh Ní Riada, Sofia Sakorafa, Tania González Peñas, Xabier Benito Ziluaga , Miguel Urbán Crespo, Estefanía Torres Martínez, Lola Sánchez Caldentey, Luke Ming Flanagan, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left – Nordic Green Left (O—000019/2016 – B8-0115/2016) (2016/2555(RSP)).

name: Bart Staes
text: Author. Commissioner, I thank you for the evaluation report on the tobacco agreement with Philip Morris that we received from you yesterday. We have had to wait a long time, but the 31 pages are now in front of us. I am sorry, Commissioner, but I do not think that there are sufficient elements in this evaluation to extend the existing agreement. For example, the report states that between 2006 and 2014, the number of cigarettes confiscated fell by 85%. But is that a good argument? In the trade journal Tobacco International of May 2002 I read that the number of cigarettes confiscated fell to one tenth compared to the 1997-1999 evaluation period, i.e. by 90%. Was that because of the tobacco deal we signed with Philip Morris? No, because it didn't exist in 2002. This good result came thanks to the leadership taken by the European Union in the fight against tobacco smuggling. For example, there was the European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry in 1996-1997. There was the good work of uclaf's Tobacco Task Force and later of OLAF. There was the good work of the Commission and a number of Member States, by suing Philip Morris in court in New York. All this created pressure and a good result, as I can read in that trade magazine Tobacco International. Moreover, it is not an amiable agreement that ensures a good result in the fight against tobacco smuggling, it is sustained commitment. Moreover, 2004 2016 is not. In the meantime, we have the new tobacco directive, which contains elements of 'tracking and tracing' and which include the amendments tabled by Mrs Grässle and myself. There is, and you know this very well, because you are a strong supporter of the WTO agreement. There is the FTCT Protocol, which introduces new elements to combat tobacco smuggling worldwide. Let's not pretend that the tobacco industry is our friend. She's an opponent. Tobacco companies are suing the Tobacco Directive. They are suing member states or states such as Australia through ISDS mechanisms. Commissioner, let me be clear: I support your fight to have the WTO agreement and the FTCT protocol ratified by as many states as possible and first and foremost by the 28 Member States of the European Union. Let us work towards the proper implementation of the Tobacco Directive. Let us work towards a proper ratification of the WTO agreement. But if you are going to decide with the Commission later to continue or extend the existing agreement with Philip Morris, you are causing reputational damage to the WTO and the European Union. After all, why should other states outside the EU, why would our neighbouring countries sign that WTO agreement when they see the EU itself concluding or extending agreements, such as the one now before Philip Morris? Commissioner, we have a dialogue today, we have a debate today. We are going to vote on a resolution on 8 March. I ask the Commission not to take a decision before parliament's resolution is before it. I think that's simple courtesy. I would like you to listen to the plenary session of Parliament as it will give its verdict on 8 March.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Author.
