Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I come to a different conclusion with the same arguments. But first of all, I would like to thank the Commission for finally presenting the report on the tobacco agreement after more than twelve years. Hurrah for that! The document is interesting. It shows the Commission's internal struggle in dealing with the tobacco industry, and I think we will have to fight this one here – unfortunately! For me, it is not a question of principle or even a decision of conscience, for me it is a matter of very pragmatic things. We should not attach more importance to this agreement than it actually does. The crux of the matter is this: what will be done in the next three years until the Tobacco Products Directive enters into force in the EU and outside the EU in the next six years, until the WHO Protocol can hopefully enter into force? These two new legal instruments are very, very important. The ratification process, the implementation process, must not and should not be jeopardised under any circumstances. That is why, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, you should comment on what the Secretary-General of the WHO Secretariat wrote yesterday, namely that the extension of this agreement undermines possible ratifications or that, under such an agreement, the EU would not be able and even allowed to make such an agreement. We need an answer to that. And then, of course, we need answers to everything. We budgetary controllers are concerned with tobacco smuggling and the fight against it. We need answers to everything that does not cover the agreement, the Tobacco Products Directive or the Protocol, namely the smuggling market with cheap white. I would therefore ask for further action. What we need is track and trace and due diligence for 1) cut raw tobacco – here we have five producers, two of them in the EU – 2) cigarette paper with its 25 manufacturers worldwide and 3) cigarette filters with around ten manufacturers worldwide. If we do something here – at the beginning of the product chain – rather than at the end, we would be able to achieve results much more quickly. From the present point of view and from the point of view of budgetary control, I can allow the agreement to continue for three years, provided that it does not jeopardise ratification. I do not believe that the industry will continue to apply the agreement voluntarily. There is also a point: those who believe in industry can refrain from continuing to apply the agreement, from extending it. I believe that we are well advised not to do so.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to remind the citizens who are following us that we are talking here about cigarette smuggling by the cigarette manufacturers themselves. The European Commission has taken a number of legal action against these manufacturers: at the moment there are four agreements in force, with Philip Morris, Japan Tobacco, Imperial Tobacco and British American Tobacco. Of these agreements, the one with Philip Morris is the most striking: one billion euros within twelve years, but Philip Morris has used it to ensure political interference in Europe and also in all Member States. For years the Commission has continued to postpone the publication of the evaluation of the agreement with Philip Morris and we have reached the point where the agreement expires in six months' time and Parliament has been kept in the dark about everything and all this time. I would point out that, while the Commission spends part of its resources on combating cigarette smuggling in the Hercule programme, it is not known how this money is spent within the Member States: we are talking about EUR 1.6 billion, the final destination of which the citizens are completely unaware of. In response to a question from me in November 2015, the Council washed its hands of it completely, saying that it could not provide any clarification on this because it is not an official part of the cooperation agreements. Meanwhile, in Italy Philip Morris invests and grows blessed with the approval of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, opens factories, obtains 50% discounts on excise duties to place its new products on the market, even receives a promise to be able to use its Codentify technology to manage traceability systems, before the Commission adopts the delegated acts required by the tobacco directive and before the European Union ratifies the Protocol of the World Health Organization on the same subject. You know, controller and checked. So gentlemen, what more to say? Thank you for tuxedo!

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: Author. – Madam President, before I begin I would like to dedicate a thought to the active and passive victims of tobacco, including my father and grandfather. Perhaps that is why I have never smoked and, therefore, I always take into account these necessary measures and support the drastic measures imposed in my country by the Socialist Government, which have achieved a better approach. My group, therefore, has always been in favour of strong marking and demanding framing. That is why I recognise the excellent work which I recognise, and which I believe we should all recognise today, of Mrs McAvan with the Tobacco Products Directive, which I believe is the legislative framework in which we have to work. And we were also so when the Commissioner presented her agreement to us and we therefore intended to have a legal instrument for the European institutions, so that we could control and deal with an absolutely inadequate and uncontrolled situation regarding the capacity and impact of tobacco companies. I believe that this agreement, and we all agree, served to improve knowledge on how to deal with illegal importation and tobacco trafficking and smuggling, but also to teach us how to track and trace and improve the control situation of that. But now, at present, I only have questions about the new situation, because it turns out that the agreement expires and we have a loophole from this year on. And the new legal framework of the Directive and its implementation in 2019 and the WHO Convention from 2022 leave us enormous questions, Commissioner.  Madam Vice-President, I know its effectiveness and I would therefore like to know, first of all, what will happen to the three outstanding agreements with so many other tobacco companies. I would like to know whether at the time the Directive also comes into force we can avoid it and we could just work to get them to finish.  But also if our customs are strong enough right now—since their assessment recognizes that it is the most important factor—and under what conditions they are, just like ports. We have vacuums there (I am transporting I know from experience that the ports are getting bigger and more uncontrollable), how can you guarantee us, or, since you are not alone, but with the College, how can the Commission guarantee it?  And also the fears of those who think that the extension of the agreements would only delay the implementation of the Directive and the ratification of the Convention. I would like you to also be able to give us guarantees in that regard, how to ensure that this is not going to happen.  On the other hand, absolutely convinced of the need of the rule of law to defend our democracy, I do not like to run out of any kind of instrument in this vacuum. So what do you propose as an alternative, Commissioner, or what does the Commission propose? How can we reassure us to demonstrate our commitment to the fight against tobacco?

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: Author. – In any event, I would like to thank the Commission for publishing its assessment of the agreement with Philip Morris International. Unfortunately, the detailed examination of this flagship document was not helped by the fact that we had to wait quite a long time for it, nor by the fact that the date of its publication was only yesterday. Despite these facts, I would like to share my views on this issue on the part of our group. The agreement with Philip Morris International partially served its purpose, as there has been a significant decrease in the smuggling of goods into the EU since its conclusion, and there have been substantial changes in legislation. We now have a directive on tobacco products, which represents a Pan-European system for monitoring and tracking cigarettes from 2019 on the one hand, and the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control ratified by five Member States, on the other. Unfortunately, however, there has also been a significant increase in market share for unbranded cigarettes. The ALDE Group has always been synonymous with the fight against trafficking in human beings, counterfeiting or smuggling of goods. We intend to continue the trend of zero tolerance in this area, because these phenomena are not only harmful to our economy, but are the driving force behind the grey economy and the black market linked to organised crime. Any loophole in the rules could serve as an open door for criminal groups. It is therefore our duty to ensure that illicit trade in tobacco products has no place at all in the EU, starting with active prevention and ending with sanctions of liquidation.  However, I must admit, Commissioner, that I do not find the Commission's published findings to be very convincing. There is no sufficient data clearly showing a link between the agreement with Philip Morris International and the reduction in the number of confiscations. After reading the Commission's opinion, I rather got the impression that only a few hypotheses were presented here. I therefore believe that, before the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control enters into force, we should conclude another agreement for this as if for a transitional period. And that we will help to combat the current problems with illicit tobacco and that we will use all measures that are proven to work, such as tracking and tracing obligations. How do you want, Commissioner, to prepare a policy and legislative framework that is fully transparent in the future with the utmost responsibility?

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today's debate is of great importance, firstly because of the importance of the subject matter, but also because our Parliament has already repeatedly asked the European Commission questions about the state of negotiations with Philip Morris International. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular the smuggling of counterfeit cigarettes, means that the European Union and the Member States together have revenue losses of EUR 10 billion per year, and the value of one European anti-fraud programme (Hercule III) is around EUR 100 million for the period 2014-2020.  Tobacco smuggling is a serious crime that contributes to the financing of other types of organised crime. It is also a public health problem, because these illegal cigarettes pose a greater health risk because no one really knows how they are produced. The Agreement with Philip Morris has therefore made a contribution here to the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco, and the initiative must therefore be supported, and President Georgieva's efforts to extend such an agreement must be supported.  This agreement was concluded 20 years ago, now the market and the mirroring environment are completely different than they were then, but such agreements seem necessary, and there is another thing, namely that this global protocol to combat smuggling will enter into force 50 years after ratification, i.e. around 2020. If this contract expires this year, philip morris will not be obliged to pay the so-called supplemental payments for years to come, and the question arises – is it worth it to us?

name: Dennis de Jong
text: Author. I am pleased that Parliament has finally received the securities report on the agreement with Philip Morris. According to the report, the number of pmi cigarettes intercepted has fallen by 85% since 2004. However, as the researchers themselves have pointed out, that doesn't say much yet. Since 2004, more and more unbranded cigarettes, cheap whites, have been smuggled into the EU. The researchers therefore had to conclude – i think this is very important – that cooperation with PMI has not produced a demonstrable benefit for public health in Europe. Remarkably, the small amount of fines that PMI has had to pay, i.m. to more than EUR 68 million. The researchers note that the intercepts involve smaller and smaller quantities of cigarettes. They therefore remain under the radar because the agreement with PMI only includes intercepts of at least 50 000 cigarettes. This means that the tobacco industry is getting away with it very well. Now to the key question: should we extend the agreement with PMI? In my group's opinion, not. The researchers already point out that it is at least curious to conclude a cooperation agreement with the same manufacturers that are legally challenging the European Tobacco Directive. In addition, new legal rules will come into force within a few years that force PMI to make similar provisions as agreed in the agreement. The main argument, however, remains that, according to world health organisation rules, any appearance of conflict of interest or entanglement with the tobacco industry should be avoided. Let us not make ourselves dependent on money with blood attached. That is why I hope that today we can see with the Commission that cooperation with PMI will not be extended.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it is very clear from the discussion we are having here that the smuggling of tobacco products is something that concerns us all. It affects our public health, our public finances and the quality of our law enforcement. The interest of Parliament is shared by the Commission. This is an important priority in our work. Today we are debating it because the EU’s first anti—fraud agreement with the largest tobacco manufacturer in Europe, Philip Morris International (PMI), is set to expire in July. We are currently reflecting on the way forward and we are benefiting from the debate in this Chamber. Yesterday we disclosed the Commission assessment of the agreement. It is the result of very thorough discussions with the Member States and all relevant services. We wanted to make sure that it was as good as it could be, and we acted on our promise to Parliament that we would engage all the services of the Commission, and in particular the Directorate—General responsible for health, to produce this assessment. We did that. Let me start by recalling why we have this agreement in the first place. In the past, significant volumes of contraband cigarettes from the major tobacco manufacturers were being smuggled illegally in the EU. We pushed the companies to take action, and the very extensive investigation by OLAF led to litigation by the EU and its Member States before the US courts against several tobacco manufacturers, resulting in anti-fraud agreements.  Under these agreements, the manufacturers accepted regulatory discipline that, at that time, was very innovative, included global tracking and tracing of their products, due diligence and know-your-customer, as well as anti-money-laundering provisions. They also offered financial incentives to these companies to comply with the agreements. What is the assessment telling us? First, even if we cannot make – as has been pointed out – direct causality between the agreement and the results in terms of the reduction of smuggling, we have achieved the key objective. The seizure of PMI contraband notified by Member States under the agreement was reduced by 85% between 2006 and 2014. That is a fact. Second, the agreement provided national and European investigators with intelligence that has led to many seizures, arrests and criminal indictments. Transnational criminal organisations were dismantled and illegal factories in some Member States were closed down. Third, it must also be made clear that the reduction of the PMI contraband did not lead to the overall reduction of the EU tobacco black market. The assessment is very clear about that. What we shrank has been taken over by the so—called ‘cheap whites’. Fourthly, the total payments asked by us – annual and seizures – made by the four manufacturers into the EU have so far surpassed EUR 1.1 billion, including around EUR 100 million in seizure payments. Fifth, lessons have been learned from the implementation of these agreements, especially in terms of global tracking and tracing, and these lessons are now very valuably integrated at international level. Today, the growing problem of cheap whites requires us to continue to work with our Member States to tackle it. I am very pleased to report that OLAF has taken this mission of tackling illegal smuggling very seriously, together with Member States. Last year, 2015, 600 million cigarettes were confiscated, and a vast share of those were cheap whites. As has been stated, we have new tools today. The world has changed. We have the Tobacco Products Directive from 2014 which focuses on production and sales into the European Union. The track and trace features under this Directive will become mandatory for all manufacturers and importers in May 2019. Just as importantly, we have the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. It requires 40 ratifications to enter into force. So far we have 15. I look forward to Parliament voting in May on ratification by the EU, and I can tell you that we are putting a lot of attention and energy into facilitating more ratification so we can have it in force by 2022. So what is the future of the PMI agreement? We are clear that our overarching goal to fight the illicit tobacco trade remains, and we have to make sure we are as effective as possible. We are strengthening our capacity for that. In March this year we will have an independent laboratory to help us in this fight. We are very keen for the regime that is put in place in the EU and internationally to be active and to deliver in this fight. Now the question is whether or not, between today and the time when we have the directive in place, 2019, or the time when we have the protocol enacted in 2022, we still need a legally-binding instrument to fight illegal trade. This is what I am here to listen to. I will take this debate into account so we can make an informed decision in the Commission in the weeks to come.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Madam Vice-President, thank you for your presentation and for the assessment made available yesterday. The assessment arrived right on time for this discussion, although we had to wait for two years for it. So yesterday with the paper in our hands, we already knew what the reality out there is. We had gotten the information from out there. Which, by the way, gives me reason to ask this little side question: besides the tobacco industry, does the Commission have any other sources of information than the Member State listings of seized cigarettes exceeding 50 000 smuggled cigarettes? No matter how well the industry takes care of its responsibilities, smoking as such is annually causing well over EUR 30 billion of damage to our economies, not even mentioning the immense human suffering. While the Commission’s staff working document provides us with a comprehensive view of where we stand with the PMI agreement, I must say, even after the words you have just said, that after such a long wait I wished for a more thorough assessment about what all this means. The reality that is out there: the amount of illegal cigarettes is still about the same – at least, it is too much. So should we prolong the PMI agreement or not? If the answer is yes, then what should it consist of? If we do not know yet – if we do not know before 2019 or 2022 – then that is wasted years. We are running out of time, as the agreement with PMI expires in July and we really need to know now what the future is about, because we need more strong action for this.

name: Karin Kadenbach
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work The fight against cigarette smuggling has been assessed economically here. EU budgets miss out on between EUR 10 and 12 billion a year. What has not been assessed is the 700 000 deaths that die prematurely each year due to tobacco consumption. What has not been assessed is the health costs of the systems resulting from the smuggling of tobacco, but above all from the use of tobacco. In other words, we must not only consider today whether we want to have a cooperation agreement with a tobacco producer in the future, but we must also look at how we can take action together to ensure that far fewer young people, above all, use cigarettes. What is presented to me here in the assessment does not do that. This speaks of the fact that the project of controlling the tobacco market has in fact failed if those who are to be controlled also decide what has come onto the market and say: all right, these are not our products at all. About 80 percent of the products, Philip Morris itself has found, do not come from them, so they don't have to pay fines. In other words, there is a traceability system, but it is also assessed by those who control it themselves to see if it works. In other words, we urgently need an independent traceability system, and we have really created the principles for this here with the Tobacco Products Directive of 2014. Those with whom we are to enter into a cooperation agreement here are the ones who are now suing us because they believe that they do not want an independent system of tracing. Why don't they want it? Because then what is actually happening on a daily basis in this market would come to light: that in reality those who are supposed to control are those who also benefit from illegal transport to the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Madam President, the European Commission, in the event of an agreement with Philip Morris International, continues the practice we have seen in the TTIP negotiations. Ignoring Parliament as the only directly elected body and negotiating away from the eyes of citizens is not the way to building trust.  The complete lack of transparency, while very important issues of public health, member states' financial interests and the fight against smuggling, creates suspicion that the Commission is not working in the interests of citizens, but in big business. As a member of a country with the longest external land border and is particularly exposed to the activities of the so-called tobacco mafia, I ask that the Commission remove any doubt and make a statement as soon as possible on the results of the application of the agreement with Philip Morris International and the plans for its extension. The European public and this home have a right to know!

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, smuggling and cigarette smuggling is about as old as the cigarette itself, as much as smoking itself. That is why this agreement that is planned to be signed is of utmost importance and comes at a time when we really have to speak out here to the end about everything that means the harm of smoking, to public health, to what it means for young people and all that it means for our community in general.  Indeed, it is certainly far more important than this agreement that we succeed in ratifying the World Health Organisation convention, that we have the right directive on tobacco products, because that is what is essential for this Parliament, not the creation of an agreement behind closed doors and without any information on what is really wanted to be achieved by that agreement. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you talked about cost. Have you thought, when you talked about the cost, and the cost that we now don't know and ask to know, namely deaths from smoking? Have you thought about this cost when you talked about the costs of the tobacco industry?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Madam Mp Grapini, I want to make it absolutely clear that I am one of those great opponents of smoking and I can say that I have never lit a cigarette in my life, nor have I had it on my mouth and I am sure that cigarettes are a great, great evil, that it harms young people, that it harms anyone who smokes and creates enormous public health costs and ultimately people die from smoking and this is that great tragedy.

name: José Bové
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, just a little chronological reminder, since things have already been said a little bit by everyone. In 1998, the tobacco industry in the United States was fined more than $200 billion. In Europe, in the face of the complaint, the industry agreed that Philip Morris should pay 1.2 million euros, but in return there was this agreement. This is a problem, because it means that the wolf has entered the fold, in the European institutions, and in particular in OLAF. In 2012, at a time when we were debating the reform to put in place binding rules, Philip Morris - again himself - had the head of the European Commissioner, Mr Dalli, with the complicity of some people at OLAF, so much so that, for ten months, the Belgian justice system has been calling for the lifting of Mr Kessler's diplomatic immunity. Finally, in 2014, two months after the vote and the introduction of the new regulations on tobacco and tobacco control, the industry, including Philip Morris, took the matter to the European Court of Justice to challenge the content of our own texts. On the basis of this observation, I would like to ask three very simple questions. First, how can a multi-recidivist criminal enterprise be assigned to a multi-recidivist criminal enterprise against public health? Today, that is not acceptable. Secondly, how can we accept that the European Parliament should be kept out of the decision that could be taken next week, even before a resolution is voted on in Parliament? Finally, third question, how to get the approval of the protocol that requires the rejection of non-binding partnerships and agreements with the tobacco industry to be voted on in May? In conclusion, extending the agreement with Philip Morris is like entrusting the fight against organized crime to Al Capone. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask our colleague whether he thinks that that the Commission should have to clarify the reasons for the delay in the publication of the assessment related to the PMI agreement of last year. Moreover, does he not think that we should be informed as soon as possible about the financial implications for the Union and the Member States of the application of this agreement?

name: José Bové (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, colleague, I fully agree with your opinion. I am surprised: we have some very interesting pages and a conclusion which is three lines long and does not respond to the demands of the European Parliament at all. There's still a problem! A student would have done this work in less than six months, whereas there it took a year and a half for the Commission to do it.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, back in England there is a debate going on about our EU membership, where this relationship between unelected Commission and elected Parliament comes up time and again. So when the Commission ignores Parliament’s request for over two years, and when documents finally turn up just before a debate, this is yet another practical example of how real power actually still lies with the Commission – unelected – rather than Parliament. So, what of cigarette smuggling? Well, first let us do no harm, let us note that the evidence on a link between plain packaging and smuggling is mixed and make sure that Member States can decide their own laws. While we are on public health, we should welcome, not condemn, moves from traditional cigarettes to e-cigarettes, and I have a lot of concerns about the revised Tobacco Products Directive on that one, which is going to put people in my constituency out of work, which is going to increase the share of the market held by big tobacco, make it harder for people to quit smoking , and result in more deaths. There are a lot of things that I think really need to be looked at again.

name: Gianluca Buonanno
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am making this speech, although I would like to say that I do not smoke, but here once again there is terrible hypocrisy. This hypocrisy is the fact that we are talking here against smoking, against Philip Morris, the Commissioner tells us certain things, but then in reality everyone exploits what is the big tobacco lobby. Why do we want to make fun of each other? There's also a lot of audiences. There are tobacco lobbies out here, there are those who pay for politicians' election campaigns, there are those who send politicians here just because they have to do the interests of Philip Morris and all the other lobbyists, as well as for so many other companies. And then we come here to hear, "we have to fight smuggling," but do you know why they want to fight smuggling? But because if there is smuggling, you do not pay taxes, if there is smuggling, the state does not earn money, because all the hypocritical states of this Europe say 'Do not smoke, because it hurts, you die, health costs...', but everyone collects tobacco money, everyone collects tobacco money. That is the reality. This is the greatest hypocrisy, and of this cigarette, which I have only a very small part in my mouth, it goes to tobacco producers, who may be a little enslaved and earn very little, but the vast majority go into what? Advertising, and of course try to give as much feed as possible to all those battery chickens that are in politics. Simple. That's what's happening. So, fewer election campaigns, less hypocrisy and try to really make a breakthrough. And then, Commissioner, you come here, but I'd like to know, tell us, show us, if you've ever taken it, let's say so... if he's befriending someone from Philip Morris? Have you ever had any help in the election campaign? Tell us, has your party ever had any help? Just to know, because then at least we are all clearer.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: Please stop your thoughts. I hope it wasn't too hard to talk about decorative cigarettes.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, in many Member States of the Union, if not as a whole, the rates of tobacco smuggling are much higher than those provided by the statistical services because of political and economic interests. The illegal tobacco trade has two aspects to take into account: the purposes of inter-party politicians of all parties pan-European, and the invasive role of the large tobacco companies that claim the lion's share in a large profitable market. The interests are enormous and the budgetary implications at Community and national level are immediate.  Tobacco companies interact at all levels of the decision-making process. For example, the four largest agreed to pay $2.15 billion to avoid legal penalties after lawsuits were filed. If they were innocent, they wouldn't pay such a huge sum. In-house, voluntary or unintentional, it leads to a budget deficit of 12 billion at Union level each year. Especially in Greece, tobacco retailers are a big loser, as the weak link in the market, while losses for the State lead to an increase in unemployment, a reduction in insurance contributions and an increase in the risk of public health from smoking contraband cigarettes.  The ratification of the Protocol of the World Health Organisation on the eradication of illegal tobacco and the implementation of independent tracing is a first step. We should also deal with the taxation of hookah tobacco, which has never been counted and there is no evidence of lost profits, of the refillable liquids of e-cigarettes, which in some countries coincide with excise duty, and the fight against the markets of foreigners and illegal immigrants in which the illegality committed is impossible to control due to gableisation.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, this House, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this The European Parliament has been waiting since 2014 for a paper assessing the tobacco agreement between the EU and Philip Morris International, also as a basis for further negotiations. The results are still not finished or even published. However, we all know that the tobacco agreement with Philip Morris International expires on 9 July this year. In a Commission working document of 24.2 this year, you indicate that, although smuggling of PMI cigarettes has decreased significantly, the EU still loses ten billion in tax revenue every year because smuggling is still a business for the pockets of a few. Hence my questions: how can we ensure that there is no area of insecurity when the agreement with PMI expires without a transitional solution being found? How do the changes in the market since 2004 affect the Commission's negotiating position, when we consider that at the beginning 75% of the smuggled goods were original cigarettes and that smuggled goods now consist only of 25% of original cigarettes? And how does the Commission plan to counter the business practices around cheap whites and illicit whites when third countries flood the market with cheap cigarettes to the detriment of the EU? (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. A lot has been said here, and there are even ugly accusations about who is corrupt, Member States, Commission, smugglers, everyone – and I, as a smoker, pay for it all. However, I would like to ask you, if things do not work so well, do you agree that from now on the negotiations can only be conducted in such a way that they take place in full public? It's like a video.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not know whether a broad public is likely to bring the negotiations to a good end, but at least in the public eye of various parliaments, I would welcome that.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, let us go back to the 2004 agreement with Philip Morris, an agreement reached for twelve years. Market of dupes, that has been said; lack of transparency, this has been confirmed; opacity, we can see this and we saw it with the 2014 directive, which was the subject of unbridled lobbying by Philip Morris. It is a market of dupes because we have an agreement where Philip Morris gives 1.25 billion for twelve years while the tax shortfall for the Member States is between 10 and 12 billion euros per year! Secondly, Madam Vice-President, the European Commission's assessment shows that this agreement has not put an end to the illicit tobacco trade, which takes new forms, as seen with cheap whites, manufactured in third countries of the European Union, such as Belarus, China, Ukraine or the United Arab Emirates. Madam Vice-President, new tools are in place to effectively combat smuggling. There was talk earlier about the tobacco directive adopted in 2014, which provides for the implementation of traceability by 2019, but also the Memorandum of Understanding of the World Health Organization, a UN institution that you know well and which requires us that by ratifying this protocol, we organize an independent traceability to effectively combat this deadly smuggling. , against counterfeiting, which penalises Member States, and against border purchases. Finally, let us not forget that this parallel world of tobacco trafficking is one of the sources of terrorist financing, notably of Mokhtar Belmokhtar's Al-Mourabitoune group, aka "Mr. Marlboro", which was behind the attacks in Burkina Faso or Mali. Madam Vice-President, in the face of the suspicion of corruption by tobacco companies, which has haunted the corridors of the European Commission for several years, I think it is very important today to refuse to maintain this agreement with Philip Morris in order to enable the Commission to be effective but also transparent.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking in this debate on the Tobacco Agreement with Philip Morris, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the Commission took almost two years to present an impact assessment of this agreement to Parliament. Unfortunately, this assessment is incomplete. Despite this negligence, however, it seems beneficial to renew the PMI agreement, since it contains, inter alia, provisions allowing transparency in the traceability of the company's tobacco supply chain and thus enabling them to be restricted from smuggling. It just so happens that my country Poland is neighbouring three countries: Russia, Belarus and Ukraine, where tobacco products are three or four times cheaper, and thus the attractiveness of smuggling them is particularly high. The existence of such agreements with the main tobacco companies, including the PMI, makes it possible to reduce this smuggling and thus to reduce losses, including the Polish budget, which amounts to at least PLN 100 million per year, i.e. EUR 25 million.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I believe that this agreement with Philip Morris is not a good agreement and I confess that I do not understand why you want this signing to take place. It is not a good deal for the states, for their tax revenues, for the buralists - the legal tobacco sellers, who are losing money - and it is not a good deal for public health. In fact, through this agreement, Philip Morris buys a morality and gets away with it, because the key point is this: the illicit tobacco trade is fed by the tobacco manufacturers themselves, and this agreement is a white-seing for the tobacco companies, who can thus continue their small business quietly. A single figure illustrates the duplicity of tobacco manufacturers: in the Principality of Andorra, while 120 tons of tobacco are needed to meet local demands, manufacturers deliver 850 tonnes. Why, if not to feed the illicit tobacco trade? You are telling us that this agreement will bring tax revenue to the states. That's right, you're right. But we are a long way from what the contraband itself brings to these same tobacco companies. We consider that the smuggling of tobacco in France is 3 billion euros, in the United Kingdom, 2 billion euros, in Greece, 2 billion euros, and we are told of a few hundred million euros of tax revenue per year... No, Commissioner, even financially, it is not a good agreement. Therefore, cooperation agreements should not be renewed, they must be replaced by the WHO protocol you mentioned. We need truly independent traceability. Commissioner, I say this quietly but solemnly: do not sign this agreement, it is a question of fiscal efficiency, it is a matter of public health and - I dare say - it is also a question of morality.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, like other colleagues I welcome the belated Commission assessment of the PMI agreement, and there is no doubt that there have been some positive results. There has been a reduction in illicit trade of genuine products. It has given us the opportunity to share intelligence with Member States and with OLAF, and it has provided some public revenue. I also welcome the establishment of an anti-fraud team relating to tobacco within OLAF, although there are of course outstanding issues. Nobody is saying that the existing agreements are perfect; in fact they are far from perfect. There is the issue of smuggling of non-branded cigarettes, and hopefully the WHO Protocol can start to address this. But of course we need a large number of countries to sign up for this new agreement or protocol to be effective. It would also be useful if the new EU agreements, when they are completed, are compliant with the WHO Protocol, and I would welcome the Commissioner’s view on that. We also need any new agreements to become more transparent, with more regular reporting of measures and results on websites. This would allow us, the Member States and the public to judge the effectiveness of any new agreements, because I think it is fair to say that not everyone supports new tobacco agreements, and we have heard that from colleagues here this morning. Therefore we do need to demonstrate that any new agreements are effective, at least as an interim measure, before the WHO Protocols are put in place.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has As a non-smoker, I say that a great deal has already been done to protect non-smokers, and the new Tobacco Products Directive is intended to take further measures. There are also successes: tobacco consumption is constantly declining, which is a good sign. However, those who want more must work to ban the production and distribution of tobacco products. However, this seems unrealistic and would only encourage illegal production and smuggling and trafficking. Tobacco products, however, are also an asset, highly taxed, with significant revenue for the Member States. In addition, many thousands of legally paid jobs in the EU depend on tobacco production. This contradiction must be resolved. The contracts concluded so far with the tobacco industry were certainly only a compromise in order to resolve this contradiction. There have also been some successes in the fight against illegal trade, although the number of unreported cases is still very high in terms of smuggling and trafficking. It must therefore now be possible to keep the tobacco companies, all of which are no longer based in the EU, in the boat and to make them jointly responsible in the fight against smuggling and illegal trade. However, the Member States must also fulfil their obligations and provide the investigative and prosecution authorities with the necessary resources for their work. This has not happened enough in the past.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam Vice-President, I do not think that the agreement is in the spirit of the tobacco directive, which is why I am opposed to it. I wonder why the Commission would pursue the renewal of the agreement if we adopted in 2014 a tobacco directive that already offers certain instruments in Article 15 to prevent illicit trade. The assessment of the effectiveness of the agreement does not provide a basis for its extension. Does the Commission consider it more appropriate to step up efforts in support of the Protocol to the Framework Convention for Tobacco Control, which provides for action at international and national level, but has so far been ratified by only a few countries. I also wonder what opinion and the Commissioner for Health andriukaitis has in this regard, who has fought hard against the harmful effects of tobacco.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Commissioner asked what to do about the regulatory gap. I do not think we have a regulatory gap. I was a rapporteur on the Tobacco Products Directive, and many colleagues have referred to that directive here this morning. That directive does provide, as you know, for a track and trace system, which will come into effect in 2019. We have heard from all the colleagues that it is true that the number of cigarettes from Philip Morris has gone down, but the number of illegal cigarettes on the market remains the same. So there is no health gain from this agreement. It is a very strange kind of world in which companies make agreements to help obey the law and to help tackle illicit smuggling. It is also very strange that the companies that are running around the Commission and Parliament are lobbying in favour of this agreement. We ought to be asking ourselves why they want a new agreement. So I really urge you not to go ahead with this agreement, but to stop in our tracks and to focus on implementing the Tobacco Products Directive with an independent track and trace system, not the one the tobacco companies want.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, as early as 2004, Philip Morris and the European Commission signed a 12-year cooperation agreement to combat the illicit trade in cigarettes to which the Member States of the Union also joined. However, the Commission postpones the publication of the assessment relating to the agreement with Philip Morris. Why is this happening? Why is the European Parliament, the predominantly democratic body, not informed? What is the added value of this agreement? The European Union and the Member States must take serious measures to combat cigarette smuggling, both for reasons of health protection and for reasons of combating tax evasion. At the same time, measures should be taken, particularly in Greece, to support small tobacco growers and tobacco retailers.  We are waiting, Madam Vice-President, for your answers, because this is a very serious matter, you understand that all colleagues have raised key questions.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I am also among those fellow Members who do not support the continuation of this agreement. In my opinion, it is not good for the consumer or the taxpayer.  In my opinion, it is also necessary to agree with those who call for some action on the Commission's procedure and transparency in the negotiations. I really miss that. I also lack sincerity in these negotiations, because the progress of many so far is not, in my view, sincere. I would also like to argue with those contributions that reflected the consumer's right to decide on this matter as well as tobacco consumption. They were sporadic contributions, but they were also made. I do not think that a public authority like the EU or the state should go against tobacco consumption. It is not good for health, it is undoubted and I think we should rather put up barriers and fight smuggling networks.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against cigarette smuggling in Europe is an important battle, worth around EUR 10 billion a year. In order to combat this scourge, the European Union has concluded several agreements with the large tobacco multinationals. However, several years after the entry into force of these agreements, the results still do not seem satisfactory: smugglers continue to do business. There is a major problem of transparency: the Commission must overcome the secrecy surrounding these agreements and ensure that any new agreements are negotiated in the open, so that Parliament, and therefore the citizens of Europe, can understand its pros and cons. Specifically, given that the agreement with Philip Morris will expire in less than six months' time and that we only received the assessment of the agreement yesterday, I would like to ask the Commission what concrete results have been achieved, in what direction it intends to move to improve these agreements and what the positive aspects would be for the citizens of Europe and for the Union's economy should these agreements be renewed.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – I myself join those who say that these agreements need to be very rethought and in no way renewed in their current form. Somehow, I feel a little bit that the profits of tobacco companies are skyrocketing, smugglers' incomes are skyrocketing, and even though there are losses and tax losses for states and governments, after all, the tax revenues of governments are skyrocketing, and somewhere it is all paid by society, smokers, non-smokers alike, with their health or with taxes paid. I therefore urge that the influx of products from third countries in uncontrolled quality and quantity must be prevented in any way. This is not a matter of agreement with companies, and in general, member state governments also need to take much stricter action. I feel like a lot of times they turn a blind eye. I urge the Commission to clarify these concerns.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: However, the Vice-President will answer on an extremely important issue, and I ask my fellow Members to watch and remain silent until this happens. Madam Vice-President, this is an important issue, many proposals, few opinions in support, several opposing opinions, my fellow Members consider it to be in deficit. They want an independent monitoring system. You have the word. ("Catch the eye end")

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank most sincerely all those who have taken the floor. Very clearly this is an issue that is on top of our minds as a concern for many of us, and also very clearly there are certain points on which we have full agreement: firstly, that we ought to concentrate our efforts on making sure that the Tobacco Directive becomes effective by May 2019, as well as that the WHO Protocol is ratified by at least 40 countries , so it can become effective at the earliest possible time which is 2022, no later. Secondly, there is full agreement in this Chamber and full agreement from the side of the Commission that we ought to fight illegal smuggling of cigarettes. Not only does that come from the companies covered by agreements, but especially the so-called ‘cheap whites’ that have taken the space that used to be taken by the companies. Where there are clearly also differences in views is around what we do between now and 2019, and what we do between now and 2022. There have been very fair comments made that it has taken the Commission time to complete the assessment. Just listening to us in this Chamber – the divergence of views, the difficulty of the questions that are being asked – this is why it has taken us so much time. We have promised to make sure that we involve all our services, including, in particular, our health service, and we have done it. Now we have an assessment that we all have subscribed to, but it has taken time because the questions we are debating are not easy. So what do I take out of this discussion today? I take a recognition that we have to deliver on the issues where we have full agreement, and that we need to focus our efforts where it matters the most. And I also take under advisement the views that have been expressed on what we do between now and then, and I can tell you we will reflect on those very carefully. Going back in history, Parliament was very supportive of the signing of the agreements – for a reason, because at that time we had nothing. And now Parliament is not so supportive – there are divergent views. Why? Because we have better tools to fight illegal smuggling. But we do not quite have them just yet, and this is what puts us in a debate that we have to integrate in our decision. I was asked a specific question – what information do we use? We use information on seizures from the 28 Member States, provided to us on a daily basis. We also use data from Euromonitor, and we are currently discussing with our health colleagues the carrying-out of a targeted study on the illicit tobacco market in the EU, with an eye to focusing attention on the ‘cheap whites’ and strengthening our fight against their smuggling. Again I want to confirm that, on transparency, we have made the agreements available to Parliament, and we will do all we can to promote more transparency in the future. Again, thank you for the debate, and of course we will come back to you on this issue whenever you invite us to do so.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. A vote will take place at the next meeting. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The contract with Philip Morris International (PMI) expires in July 2016. That is why the European Parliament has requested information from the Commission on the details of the negotiations between the European Commission and the IIA. Parliament asked the Commission to present an evaluation of the PMI agreement, in which the Commission was to indicate the benefits of the agreement or possible problems with it. Unfortunately, the Commission did not cooperate properly with Parliament and did not respond to further requests (m.in. Parliament's own-initiative report entitled 'Annual report 2012 on the protection of the EU's financial interests' and its resolution on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2012). It is unacceptable that the only EU body directly elected is not timely and duly informed on such an important issue. The Commission, which calls for transparency, should itself comply with the principle it promotes. It is the Commission's responsibility to make public, transparent and submit information to the European Parliament. We hope that yesterday's submission by the Commission of a technical assesment will initiate a proper, transparent cooperation that will enable the european taxpayer to develop results that are beneficial to the taxpayer.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – July 2016 one of the four EU cooperation agreements with tobacco companies, i.e. the agreement with Philip Morris International, will expire. On the basis of these agreements, tobacco manufacturers have agreed to pay the EU and its countries EUR 2.5 billion. dollars for withdrawing uncollected cigarette smuggling claims. They have also committed themselves to actively combating smuggling and counterfeiting tobacco production. However, it is clear that there is a serious lack of evidence on the benefits of this partnership for Member States. These agreements do not contribute in any way to the reduction of tobacco products. White cigarettes are also spreading in Europe, which do not have any inscriptions. This shows that the fight against smuggling is not effective, although the total amount of cigarette smuggling seized has decreased. This is, by the way, the only important fact that can be very diverse - for example, better verification by Member States. Last but not least, the European Commission will re-sign agreements with tobacco companies, in spite of the questionable benefits of the agreements. If this were to happen, the Commission would once again prove that it does not want to ensure democratic decision-making processes.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. For years, the Commission has continued to postpone the publication of the evaluation of the agreement expiring in July with Philip Morris, and Parliament continues to be kept in the dark about any contacts to renew this agreement. I would like to remind you that the agreements with the tobacco industries were born because the Commission took legal action against Philip Morris International and other companies, accusing them of cigarette smuggling. In fact, a large proportion of the goods smuggled came directly from the manufacturers. Philip Morris has paid the Member States eur 1 billion over twelve years, of which no one knows anything. We do not know how this proceeds, and the proceeds of fines for seizures of original material, were used by the Member States. We know, however, that in this way Philip Morris has been able to secure interference in Europe and in the Member States. In fact, Philip Morris has been promised to be able to use its Codentify technology to manage traceability systems, before the Commission adopts the delegated acts required by the Tobacco Directive and before the European Union ratifies the World Health Organisation protocol on the same subject, which renders these agreements useless. That is why I believe that they should not be renewed and that the Protocol should be ratified as soon as possible.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to tell you just one thing, and I would ask you to pay some attention because this is a very serious matter that has happened and which has been reported in the Italian press over the past few days. We have learned that the United States of America, according to the wikileaks website, in another chapter of the datagate, intercepted the then Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, in 2011 and even earlier, and his close collaborators. So after Germany, after France, Italy is also intercepted by an allied country. I use the words of President Schulz, words he used the other day on an Italian programme: 'this is a very serious matter, because it is not right for allied countries to be intercepted'. The Italian Government is monitoring with the United States, and we are calling for the European Parliament to reopen its investigation into espionage activities against Europe, which ended in March 2014. We do not want there to be suspicions and shadows between allied countries, and we therefore call on Parliament to help us clarify, because otherwise even the delicate trade negotiations could be put at risk, as well as the sharing of data that is otherwise important.

name: President. –
text: Ms Gardini, the House has heard what you had to say.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we would just like to point out, for our part too, that the reports we have heard in the press and which reveal spying by US organisations on European countries are very alarming and disturbing news. It's something we can't resign ourselves to, just because it's done everywhere, because everyone does that. I dream of countries and relations between countries that are based on transparency, fairness and respect for each other's autonomy, and that is why I want to fight. I believe that the European Parliament must fight in this direction.

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Ms Toia, we have heard what you had to say. The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Viktor Uspaskich
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Colleagues, 1965. The Hague Convention creates a framework for simplifying the exchange of documents between the countries of the European Union, simplifying and facilitating judicial cooperation in cross-border and civil and commercial disputes, and the Convention therefore demonstrates its usefulness. This Convention is used by 25 countries of the European Union. Following austria and Malta's wish to accede to the Hague Convention, after lengthy discussions in the Council and the interpretation of the Court of Human Rights, these two Member States are given the opportunity to accede to the Convention. I therefore call on my colleagues to support this recommendation and to allow Austria and Malta to accede to the Hague Convention.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D)
text: , Chairman of the Committee on International Trade. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The rapporteurs and I regret that the text negotiated with the Council and the Commission has not been adopted unchanged. This is, of course, an emergency measure in support of Tunisia. In order not to waste more time now, I would ask that we suspend the final vote and immediately enter into a trialogue with the Council, so that we can find a solution as quickly as possible and organise really rapid aid to Tunisia.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, quickly: they informed us from Parliament's services that there was an error on Amendment No 13, because we had clearly not included any reference to the banking union, but to the structural reform of the banking system, and instead 'banking Union' was inserted, so the amendment is without the words 'banking Union'.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I thank the House for voting in favour of the report which contains several points of criticism of the action of the European Central Bank and the troika. Of course, there are aspects in the report, as in every report, that do not reflect the rapporteur, such as the third part of paragraph 15. For all this, I will put my views on the record in writing. Finally, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, our group is against the amendment tabled by several groups - the Socialists, the Liberals and others - which makes the resolution very unbalanced. It is a text that will be very much in Saudi Arabia's favour. We believe that the embargo is important, but that it must apply to all actors in the region, including Iran, especially since we sent a delegation to Saudi Arabia, which was received by the king. The political groups that proposed this amendment did not support that position when they were there. You can't support one thing in Saudi Arabia and one thing... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Mr Preda, we are not having a debate today, we are having a vote. We have already discussed this in Strasbourg.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I just wanted to raise my disgust. This matter was delayed from a vote on 4 February for no better reasons than to save embarrassment and the diplomatic niceties ahead of the delegation visit. Since that time, I am sure colleagues across the House will be disgusted that more people have died, cholera has spread further and the infrastructure has decayed further. I think it is a shame on this place that this vote was delayed from the 4th at the hands of innocent Yemeni civilians. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Madam President, I am terribly sorry but people are coming and going in this Chamber right now and there is a lot of talking going on, like in a cafeteria. It is an abuse and an insult against our voters, against our citizens, that we have to give speeches in this environment. Please make sure that people calm down, keep silent and then we can talk. I do not even know which explanation of vote is going on because the table does not show it, so please make sure that we can see what is going on and that we can also hear, because at this point in time I cannot hear anything and I cannot see anything.

name: President. –
text: Ms Morvai, I am sorry but there was a technical reason.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Service of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters aims to harmonise the legal systems of the acceding countries. Rapid transmission of information on judicial documents is certainly in the interests of the European Union, and the Convention has proved to be an excellent tool for speeding up cross-border notification of these documents. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of authorisation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation in favour of Austria signing and ratifying the Hague and Malta Convention, since these two Member States are not yet part of this Convention on the notification or transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. As it is a Convention which facilitates procedural aspects and which have already been ratified by all but these two Member States, I have had no problem giving my vote in favour of Malta and Austria subscribing to it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft recommendation on the Council's proposed decision authorising Austria and Malta to join the Hague Convention in the EU's interest. The purpose of the Convention is to simplify the service and notification of civil and commercial court and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states.  Even if this authorisation to join is tantamount to strengthening the European Union, we must respect the sovereign will to join these two countries.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of austria's authorisation to sign and ratify, and Malta's to accede to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965, as it has been shown that it (the Convention) is useful in the field of cross-border document provision and the successful establishment of a system where which documents of a judicial and extrajudicial nature of civil or commercial matters can be served on a State which has signed-acceded to the Convention.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a draft recommendation on the Council's proposed decision authorising Austria and Malta to accede to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the meaning and notification abroad of judicial and extrajudicial acts in civil and commercial matters.  This convention simplifies the service and notification of civil and commercial court and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. It is an effective instrument that streamlines globalized judicial relations. Austria and Malta have shown a willingness to join, so the EU must respect their sovereign choice. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency I would like to confirm that I abstained on this issue. It is not for me or anyone else to vote on matters that concern other sovereign states such as Austria and Malta.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to allow Austria and Malta to accede to the Hague Convention on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. (1965-11-15)15 November 1965 The Hague Convention establishes a system under which documents may be served in another State signatory to the Convention. Of the 28 Member States, this Convention already applies in 26 member states. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have expressed their willingness to join it. Malta has already deposited its instrument of accession to the Convention, but has issued a declaration that its accession will not enter into force until this decision has been taken. Austria is awaiting this decision in order to complete the accession formalities. Since it is in the interest of the two Member States concerned to apply a single procedure for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, I support the proposal allowing Austria and Malta to accede to the Convention.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention simplifies the service and notification of civil and commercial court and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. Applying only to relations with third countries in the EU, it streamlines globalised judicial relations. Since Austria and Malta had expressed their willingness to join, I did not object. The Convention does not allow the membership of international organizations. But following the adoption of Regulation (EC) No. 1393/2007 of the EP and the Council of 13 November 2007 on the cross-border meaning and notification of acts (the 'Regulation'), the Union has acquired exclusive external competence in this area, article 3, paragraph 2, of the TFUE states: "The Eu also has exclusive jurisdiction to conclude an international agreement when this conclusion [...] may affect common rules or alter their scope." It is under this article that the decision in question was put to the vote of the European Parliament.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The 1965 Hague Convention establishes a system that allows for the service and notification of judicial and extra-judicial documents in civil and commercial matters in other signatory states. It applies only to documents intended for or from third countries in the EU. 26 Member States already apply the Convention.  Following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service and notification of acts, the EU has acquired exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. It must therefore authorise the Member States in question to act on its behalf in order to accede to the Convention. I have endorsed this recommendation which is in favour of Austria and Malta's accession to the Convention.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Uspaskich report on the draft Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify, and Malta to accede, to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965. The Convention, already applied by 26 Member States of the Union, establishes a system where under which judicial and extrajudicial documents may be served in another signatory State. Since it is not possible for the EU as such to accede to the Convention, although it is the exclusive competence of the Union, it has been necessary for the Council to be authorized to allow the two countries to accede to this important international treaty.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is a recommendation for accession to the Hague Convention on the notification or transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. All Member States, in addition to Malta and Austria, have already signed this convention, which is procedural in nature.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The adoption of Regulation (EC) 1393/2007 the Union has acquired exclusive external jurisdiction over membership of an international organisation. It calls for Austria and Malta to allow permission to accede to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service and notification abroad of judicial and extrajudicial acts in civil and commercial matters. Twenty-six Member States already apply this convention and overall, the Convention has been widely adopted (EU, China, Russia, Switzerland,...).  The Convention is an effective instrument that streamlines globalised judicial relations. In theory, this authorisation to join is tantamount to strengthening the EU, but in reality we must respect the sovereign will to join demonstrated by Austria and Malta. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is shareable and unbleased. I voted to support the authorisation for Austria and Malta to accede to the Hague Convention on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation granting Parliament its approval for the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention on the Notification or Transfer Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system by which documents may be notified or transferred to another signatory State. Of the twenty-eight Member States, twenty-six already apply the Convention. To the extent that the EU had acquired exclusive competence over the service of cross-border documents, it is necessary for the Union to give its authorisation to these two Member States for accession to the Convention.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this document because it supports the decision authorising Austria to sign and ratify in the interests of the European Union in 1965. The Hague Convention on the Service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters and Malta is hereby authorised to accede to it. 1965 The Hague Convention establishes a system under which documents may be served in another State signatory to the Convention. It should be noted that this Convention applies only to the cross-border service of documents in third countries or the service of documents received from them. In the case of cross-border service of documents within the European Union, Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 on the service in the Member States of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters shall apply. Currently, of the 28 Member States, this Convention already applies in 26 member states. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have expressed their willingness to join it. International organisations shall not be allowed to accede to the Convention. By adopting EU legislation on cross-border service, the EU has acquired exclusive external competence in this regard. This means that the Union must authorise the Member States concerned to act on its behalf in order to accede to the Convention.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the European Parliament's proposed recommendation to allow Austria to sign and ratify the Hague Convention and malta to accede to it.  The Hague Convention lays down a system under which documents may be served in another Contracting State, but applies only to the cross-border service of documents in or out of third countries. The rules for service between EU Member States are laid down in a horizontal regulation on the service of court files.  Austria and Malta have so far been the only two countries in the EU that have not applied the provisions of the Hague Convention but have recently expressed their desire to join it. However, before it actually take effect, the EU must empower these two countries to act on its behalf. I agree with the rapporteur that the area of cross-border service of documents is very useful, and it is therefore in the interest of both the EU and the acceding countries that there is a single exchange regime.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The Convention simplifies the service and notification of civil and commercial court and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. It applies only to relations with third countries in the EU.  Twenty-six Member States already apply it. The Convention does not allow the membership of international organizations. But following the adoption of Regulation (EC) No. 1393/2007 of the EP and the Council of 13 November 2007 on the cross-border meaning and notification of acts (the 'Regulation'), the Union has acquired exclusive external competence in this area, in accordance with Article 3, paragraph 2, of the TFUE.  In theory, this authorisation to join is tantamount to strengthening the European Union. But in this case, we must respect the sovereign will to join manifested by Austria and Malta. I voted for it as I did in the Legal Affairs Committee

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1965 Hague Convention on the Communication and Notification abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters aims to simplify the way in which such acts are transmitted between the Contracting States. This convention facilitates judicial cooperation in the event of transnational civil or commercial litigation. Twenty-six of the twenty-eight Member States already apply the Convention. Only Austria and Malta are missing, but they have shown their willingness to join. The European Parliament must contribute to strengthening and improving judicial cooperation in Europe, and it is therefore its task to ensure the accession of Austria and Malta to this Convention, with a view to improving mutual legal assistance to this end by simplifying and speeding up the procedure.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The report focuses on Austria's ratification and Malta's accession to the Convention on the Meaning and Notification of Civil and Commercial Judicial and Extrajudicial Acts Abroad. This convention applies only to documents intended for third countries in the European Union and allows, in particular, to smooth the judicial relations between states. In addition, the sovereign will of Austria and Malta to accede to any international convention must be respected. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The effectiveness of justice within the European framework is intrinsically linked to the collaboration of the judicial bodies of the various Member States because, in an era of exponential growth in the movement of persons, the extraneous elements of legal relations become the rule, not the exception. In strengthening this efficiency and with third countries we have the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965, which applies exclusively to cross-border notification of documents in or from third countries – as regards cross-border notification within the European Union, with Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 1393/2007. The manifestation of the wish of Austria and Malta, the only Member States which have not acceded to the Convention, to join the other Member States is welcome and I support the authorisation of the Member States concerned by the Union to act on its behalf by ratifying that Convention. The usefulness of the Convention in the field of cross-border document notification is already proven, and it is in the interest of both the Union as a whole and of the two Member States concerned to have a single document notification regime in cross-border relations with third countries, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Austria and Malta have already formally expressed their willingness to join; With this vote, it is proposed that Parliament should give its assent to the proposal for a decision authorising the accession of Austria and Malta to this Convention.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify respectively and Malta to accede to the Hague Convention on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters.
