The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system where by which acts may be served in another signatory State and is already applied in 26 of the 28 Member States. The two remaining Member States, Austria and Malta, have expressed their willingness to join. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 demonstrated its usefulness in the field of cross-border service of documents. Furthermore, it is in the interests of the Union as a whole that the two Member States in question have a uniform system for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries. Consequently, I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal for a decision authorising the accession of Austria and Malta to the Convention.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this procedural report which recommends that Malta and Austria accede to the Hague Convention on Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters.  All the other EU countries (including Ireland) are already signatories to this Convention, which indicates the channels for transmission from one contracting state to another in the event of service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial acts. The method is through a central authority, which is organised by each State in accordance with its own law. As I recognise the sovereign right of countries to sign up to Conventions, I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of ratification of and accession to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters by Austria and Malta as it allows for the cross-border service of documents in or from third countries without the use of consular or diplomatic services. It has already proved to be very useful and makes the entire procedure much faster and in most cases much cheaper.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1965 Hague Convention lays down common rules on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. It is therefore an important instrument aimed at promoting the streamlining of the cross-border civil justice system, to which most Member States have long since acceded. The delegation of the 5-Star Movement therefore voted in favour in relation to the accession by Austria and Malta to this Convention. In fact, in order to create a single European area of justice, it is essential that the Member States coordinate also in order to facilitate the speed of judgments with links with third countries and the EU.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the Recommendation. Of the 28 Member States of the Union, 26 are already parties to the Hague Convention. The other two, Austria and Malta, have expressed their interest in accession, which we welcome.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising Austria to sign and ratify malta to accede to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial acts in civil or commercial matters in the interests of the European Union. It is obvious that these types of procedures concern the proper functioning of the justice system and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I recognise the usefulness shown by the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 in the field of cross-border service of documents and I believe that it is in the interests of the Union as a whole and of the two Member States concerned to have a uniform system for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a Europe of 28 Member States, it is good that there should be no disparity between one State and another. I voted in favour of this draft decision because I believe that Austria and Malta, the last two to have not yet implemented the Hague Convention, did not have the right to continue to establish islands of anarchy within our territory. In fact, knowing that acts, whether judicial or extra judicial, could not be transmitted automatically, created perverse incentives that were finally eliminated.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention allows the recognition of cross-border notifications of judicial and extra judicial documents in the civil and commercial sphere. However, in the case of the European Union, it applies only to documents of origin or destination in third countries, since Community legislation already exists for the same purpose between Member States. Because it has exclusive competence in this matter and cannot, as a signatory, accede to the Convention, the Union must authorise the individual acceding of the Member States. Given the obvious European interest in the existence of a common regime, the European Parliament thus gives its consent to the agreement.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. With regard to the recommendation drawn up by the European Parliament on the Council decision authorising Austria to sign and ratify and Malta to accede to the 1965 Hague Convention, I have decided to vote in favour, as this would allow those States to be able to notify and communicate to third countries, which are also parties to the Convention, judicial and extrajudicial acts in civil or commercial matters. This practice has proved to be very useful and effective because, by adopting a uniform system, all Member States will benefit from better information sharing and greater cooperation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention only applies to the cross-border service of documents in or from third countries for cross-border service within the European Union, improving the transmission of judicial and extrajudicial documents abroad. This Convention facilitates judicial cooperation in cross-border litigation thereby benefiting citizens in cross-border proceedings even with third country connections. The Convention has been broadly ratified, having 67 Contracting States. Malta should not waste time in ratifying this Convention.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system where by which acts may be served in another signatory State. It should be pointed out that the Convention applies only to acts intended for or coming from third countries. The Convection is already applied in 26 of the 28 Member States. The two remaining Member States, Austria and Malta, have expressed their willingness to join. The Union must therefore authorise the Member States concerned to act on its behalf in order to accede to the Convention. Since the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 has proved its usefulness in the field of cross-border service of documents and that it is in the interests of both the Union as a whole and the two Member States concerned to have a uniform system for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, it is proposed that Parliament give its assent to the proposal for a decision authorising the accession of Austria and Malta to that Convention. This seems to me to be a good report and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation in favour of Austria signing and ratifying the Hague and Malta Convention, since these two Member States are not yet part of this Convention on the notification or transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. As it is a Convention which facilitates procedural aspects and which have already been ratified by all but these two Member States, I have had no problem giving my vote in favour of Malta and Austria subscribing to it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 makes it possible to service official documents in another State Party. The Convention applies only to cross-border service of official documents originating in or sent to third countries: cross-border service within the European Union is subject to Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. Already 26 of the 28 Member States apply the Hague Convention. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have also indicated their intention to join. The Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations. Following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service of documents, the Union has acquired exclusive external competence on this issue within the meaning of Article 3(2) of the TSCM. This approach has been confirmed by the Court of Justice. As stated above, the Union should allow the Member States in question to act on its behalf with a view to accession to the Convention. It is in the common interest of the EU and the two Member States concerned to have a uniform system for the service of documents in their cross-border relations with third countries. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention provides for the channels of transmission to be used when a judicial or extrajudicial document is to be transmitted from one state party to the convention to another state party. I voted in favour of this report as the framework that it provides is both efficient and effective. The Convention already applies to 26 Member States, with Malta and Austria indicating their wish to join, I support the view that, in accordance with Article 3(2) TFEU and Court of Justice Opinion 1/13, the Union must authorise both Malta and Austria to act on its behalf in order to accede to the Convention. This accession would be beneficial for both the Union and the two Member States.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. Austria and Malta, the only Member States not to accede to the Convention, have expressed their desire to join the other Member States. I welcome this decision.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report gives the Approval of the European Parliament to the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965. It sets up a system that allows the service and notification of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters between the European Union and the third countries that are signatories.  Within the Union, only Austria and Malta had not yet applied it, and expressed their desire to join. Considering that the Convention has proven its usefulness in the cross-border area and that Member States have an interest in having a uniform regime in this area in their relations with third countries, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention on the Meaning and Notification abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Acts in Civil and Commercial Matters. I support these measures aimed at facilitating cooperation with third countries in the area of judicial cooperation in the event of transnational civil and commercial disputes. The Hague Convention contributes to this objective by simplifying the way in which judicial and extrajudicial acts are transmitted between the contracting states.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure to allow Austria and Malta to ratify and accede respectively to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965. I believe that it is in the interests of both the European Union and the two Member States to have a uniform system for the service of documents in relations with third countries.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965, a system of service of documents was established between the countries which signed the Convention. It is important to note that the Convention is a cross-border service that applies only to documents and documents received from third countries or third countries. 26 of the 28 Member States already apply the Convention and the two remaining Member States, Malta and Austria, have expressed their desire to join. Since the Convention proved its usefulness, it has been in the common interest for the two Member States in question to have a simple procedure for the service of documents beyond the border to third countries. In the plenary vote, I voted in favour of the accession of the two Member States to the Hague Convention.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system whereing the service of official documents in another State Party. It should be noted that the Convention applies only to cross-border service of official documents originating in or sent to third countries: cross-border service within the European Union is subject to Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 November 2007 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have also indicated their intention to join. The Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations. However, following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service of documents, the Union has acquired exclusive external competence on this issue within the meaning of Article 3(2) TSI. This approach was confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. On this basis, the Union should allow the Member States in question to act on its behalf with a view to accession to the Convention. It is in the interest of both the Union as a whole and the two Member States in question to have a uniform system for the uniform service of documents in their cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This convention has the merit of simplifying the service and notification of judicial and extrajudicial documents, in civil and commercial matters, in other signatory states. It applies only to relations with third countries in the European Union.  It is an effective tool to contribute to the proper functioning of judicial reports. Of course, this authorisation is part of the strengthening of the European Union, but the elected representative I am, who is committed to respecting the sovereignty of States, must allow Austria and Malta to join the Convention, as they wish. For this reason, I voted for this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 My colleague Uspakic's report concerns the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. I and my group oppose the fact that the EU should not have legal competence in this area. This is the reason why I abstained. I am not against Austria and Malta joining the Hague Convention. I believe that as sovereign states, the governments of both countries should be able to take this decision at national level without needing approval at European level.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The signing and ratification by Austria and malta's accession to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 is something we fully agree with. We note, however, that it is regrettable that independent states must seek approval from the Union in order to join conventions.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system whereing that official documents may be served in another State Party. It should be noted that the Convention applies only to cross-border service of official documents originating in or sent to third countries: cross-border service within the European Union is subject to Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 November 2007 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have also indicated their intention to join. The Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations. However, following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service of documents, the Union has acquired exclusive external competence on this issue within the meaning of Article 3(2) TSI. This approach was confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. On this basis, the Union should allow the Member States in question to act on its behalf with a view to accession to the Convention. It is in the interest of both the Union as a whole and the two Member States in question to have a uniform system for the uniform service of documents in their cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 aims to seek the approval of the rules of law by establishing a system by which documents of one State may serve in another signatory State, covering for example different matters such as the law applicable to food obligations, road traffic accidents, , to liability for facts or marriage regimes and for successions. Currently in the EU, of the 28 Member States, 26 are already implementing the Convention, and the remaining two, Austria and Malta, have indicated their desire to unite. The Committee on Legal Affairs approved the report on the draft Council Decision authorising Austria and Malta to sign and ratify the Convention. Since this Convention has proved useful, and it is in the EU's interest to establish a single regime for the transfer of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, I welcome Parliament's consent to the proposal for a decision to allow Austria and Malta to join the Convention.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system whereby documents may be delivered in another signatory State. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply this Convention. Austria and Malta, the two Member States that have not yet applied it, have expressed their willingness to join. Malta has already submitted its instrument of accession, but has issued a statement that its accession will not be effective until this Decision is adopted. Austria awaits this Decision in order to carry out the formalities of the entry. Since the Hague Convention has demonstrated its usefulness in the field of cross-border document notification, and it is in the interests of both the Union as a whole and the two Member States concerned to have a single regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, I agree with the decision allowing Austria and Malta to join that Convention.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Convention is to service judicial and extrajudicial documents abroad in civil and commercial matters. It also defines the means to be used where a judicial act is to be transmitted from one Contracting State to another in order to be served there. It improves the transmission of judicial and extrajudicial acts, facilitates judicial cooperation in transnational judicial proceedings and creates an efficient and reliable system for service of judicial and extrajudicial documents. The EU cannot be part of the convention because it does not establish anything about regional economic organisations, only individual states. Member States may not conclude the Convention without being authorised by the EU in accordance with the TFEU. A reality that we reject and which is just another expression of the loss of sovereignty of states through the deepening of the process of capitalist integration that is the EU.   This is the formalisation of the procedure for the application to the Hague Convention of the only two Member States that did not integrate it. For your own free and sovereign decision. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. No objections.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the report authorising Austria to sign and ratify and in Malta to accede to the Convention of 15 November 1965.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I am not against the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention. I abstained from the vote because I believe that it is not the competence of the European Union to impose on the citizens and authorities of these countries the decision to accede to the Convention.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The signing and ratification by Austria and the accession by Malta to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 is something I fully agree with. I note, however, that it is regrettable that independent states must seek approval from the Union in order to join conventions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Austria and Malta have indicated their wish to join the Hague Convention of 1965. Since the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 has proven its usefulness in the field of the cross-border service of documents, and it is in the interest both of the Union as a whole and of the two Member States in question to have a single regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, I supported the proposal for the decision allowing the accession of Austria and Malta to that Convention.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system whereing that official documents may be served in another State Party. It should be noted that the Convention applies only to cross-border service of official documents originating in or sent to third countries: cross-border service within the European Union is subject to Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 November 2007 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have also indicated their intention to join. The Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations. However, following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service of documents, the Union has acquired exclusive external competence on this issue within the meaning of Article 3(2) TSI. This approach was confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. On this basis, the Union should allow the Member States in question to act on its behalf with a view to accession to the Convention. It is in the interest of both the Union as a whole and the two Member States in question to have a uniform system for the uniform service of documents in their cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 26 of the 28 Member States already apply the Convention. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have also indicated their intention to join. The Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations. However, following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service of documents, the Union has acquired exclusive external competence on this issue within the meaning of Article 3(2) TSI. This approach was confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. I am convinced that, on this basis, the Union should allow the Member States in question to act on its behalf with a view to accession to the Convention.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the draft Resolution on the accession of the Republic of Austria and Malta to the Convention on the Notification or Transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters, with the desire that these two countries be equated in this area at EU level, thus deepening the process of European integration.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify respectively and Malta to accede, in the interests of the European Union, to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters.  The Convention, which establishes a system for the service of documents destined for and coming from a foreign country, has proved very useful in the context of cross-border service of judicial and extrajudicial documents with third countries.  In order to achieve a more uniform and robust system in the interests of the European Union itself, I therefore recommend that Austria and Malta, which are currently the only two countries of the Union not to be members, should join the Convention.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents abroad in civil and commercial matters. Twenty-six out of 28 countries have already signed this important bureaucracy-avoiding agreement, which, in accordance with the rules, cannot be signed by the EU itself. The move of Malta and Austria is a logical – and only supportive.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The Hague Convention has proved useful for the Union as a whole in the field of cross-border service. Today's vote on the accession of the last two EU countries, Austria and Malta, completes the agreement as a single system for the delivery of documents and in the area of cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this authorisation for Austria to sign and ratify, and Malta to accede to, the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965, which offers an effective system for transmitting extra—judicial documents  from one state party to another.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is a recommendation for accession to the Hague Convention on the notification or transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. All Member States, in addition to Malta and Austria, have already signed this convention, which is procedural in nature.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the draft Council decision because Member States cannot conclude the Hague Service Convention without being authorised to do so. Therefore, 24 Member States had acceded to the Hague Service Convention before the adoption of EU legislation. The remaining Member States which have to be authorised to accede to the convention are Austria and Malta. These countries should sign it in the interest of the European Union because it will make the process of authorisation in regards to the Hague Service Convention much easier.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system where according to which judicial documents may be ed by another Contracting State. Of the 28 Member States of the Union, 26 are already Contracting Parties to the Convention. The other two, Austria and Malta, have expressed their interest in accession. Malta has already submitted the accession documents, but has issued a declaration that its accession will not apply until the adoption of the decision under consideration. Austria awaits this decision in order to make the formalities for accession. Because of the procedural nature of the report, we voted in favour of it.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote for the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents as I believe that the Convention facilitates judicial cooperation in cross-border civil and commercial litigations among the contracting parties. As the Convention does not allow for international bodies such as the EU to be party to it, it is essential that all EU Member States accede. I believe that the Hague Convention of 1965 is beneficial to its Member States and to the European Union as a whole. Cross-border judicial and legal cooperation is paramount to the smooth running of the Union.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report, as the Hague Convention establishes a system whereby documents can be served in another signatory state, which is very important for the Union. Of the 28 Member States, 26 are already applying the convention. Austria and Malta, as the two remaining Member States, have indicated their wish to join.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)

The Convention shall apply only to the cross-border service of official documents originating in or sent to third countries. Cross-border service within the European Union is subject to Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 November 2007 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Recommendation which proposes that Parliament grant its approval to the proposal for a Decision allowing Austria and Malta to join the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With regard to the opinion of the Court of Justice from 14 October 2014 and the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I believe that it is in the interest of the European Union to authorise the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify, while Malta accedes to, the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial matters.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on a draft Council decision authorifying the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extra-judicial documents in civil or commercial matters, and the Republic of Malta to join the Convention in the interest of the European Union, as the European Parliament expresses its consent.  I consider that the Convention is of particular importance in the field of cross-border delivery of documents and it is in the interest of the Union and the Member States concerned to strengthen the uniform regime for the delivery of documents in cross-border relations with third countries. It is also important to emphasise the role of the Union in this process, which authorizes Member States to act on its behalf in order to accede to the Convention. Accordingly, and as this Convention is already applied by the 25 EU Member States, I support the will of Austria and Malta to join it.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In the spirit of respecting the wishes of national sovereignty of both Austria and Malta, we can only agree with these two states to sign and ratify for the former, and to accede to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 for the second.  The Convention makes globalised judicial relations more fluid and the development that the two States intend to take is quite commendable in this view of European cohesion, although this authorisation to join is tantamount to strengthening the European Union, which we are theoretically opposed to.  I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Viktor Uspaskich's report on the authorisations given to Austria to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 and malta to accede to that convention. Twenty-six of the 28 EU Member States already apply the Hague Convention and Austria and Malta have also wished to join.  This decision will make it possible to standardise the European regime for relations with third countries. That is why I agree with the Council's decision to allow Austria and Malta to join this convention. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation. This text approves Austria's decision to sign and ratify the 1965 Hague Convention and Malta to join it. 26 of the 28 EU Member States are members of the Convention, which facilitates international exchanges of judicial and extra-judicial acts. As this Convention was deemed useful by the other 26 Member States, it was necessary for Austria and Malta to join in turn in order to definitively standardise the European regime of relations with third countries on this issue.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents abroad in civil and commercial matters regulates the cross-border service of documents in and from third countries. I agree with this report because it helps to take better account of Austrian interests.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the Convention has proven its usefulness in the field of the cross-border service of documents, and it is in the interest both of the Union as a whole and of the two Member States in question to have a single regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, I voted for the decision allowing the accession of Austria and Malta to that convention.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system where by which judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters may be served in another signatory State. It is already applied in 26 of the 28 Member States. The two remaining Member States, Austria and Malta, have expressed their willingness to join. The European Union must therefore authorise the Member States to accede to the Convention. Having a uniform system for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries is in the interests of both the Union and the two Member States concerned. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report giving Austria permission to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 and Malta to accede to that convention. The Convention is a rather effective instrument, which smoothes globalised judicial relations. In theory, this accession authorization could be like strengthening the European Union since it acquired exclusive external competence in this area in 2007. But in this case, we must respect the sovereign will to join manifested by Austria and Malta.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because we must respect the sovereign will shown by Austria and Malta to join the Hague Convention.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation in favour of Austria signing and ratifying the Hague and Malta Convention, since these two Member States are not yet part of this Convention on the notification or transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. As it is a Convention which facilitates procedural aspects and which have already been ratified by all but these two Member States, I have had no problem giving my vote in favour of Malta and Austria subscribing to it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Normally, I would abstain when voting on a Member State wishing to carry out an act, such as a contract, but in this case a Member State must request authorisation from the EU. I am against the principle that any Member State must request permission for anything.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to the 1965 Hague Convention, a system was established to define how each signatory state can deliver abroad court documents in civil or commercial proceedings. The Convention does not to they on the work of international organisations and the EU must vote on the participation of each Member State in the Convention. Currently, of the 28 Member States, 26 adhere to the Convention and now Austria and Malta have expressed their desire to sign the Convention. I supported austria and Malta's accession to the Hague Convention, as in past practice the Convention has proven to be a practical tool for resolving judicial and extra-judicial disputes. It is in the EU's interest that all Member States are in one system for the cross-border delivery of documents to third countries.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Service of Judicial and Extrajuband document in Civil or Commercial Matters was signed in 1965 and entered into force in 1969, replacing the 1905 Convention on Civil Procedure, which was previously active. The main objective is to guarantee different types of official bodies and ordinary people the possibility of transmitting official documents between countries without the use of diplomatic channels, thus issuing them to other signatory countries. Malta already ratified this Convention a few years ago, while Austria has yet to do so after the appropriate consent process has been taken out of the European Union institutions, including the European Parliament. While To some extent, I am surprised that these countries are the last in the European Union, which has not yet fully joined this Convention, I congratulate this step. The cross-border service of documents is an integral part of international law and other areas, the effective implementation of which must be facilitated in every possible way – and another very important contribution has been made in this respect today.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 regulates the conditions for the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters in signatory States. The Convention applies to 26 of the 28 Member States. The EP gave its consent to a draft decision allowing Austria and Malta to accede to the Convention. This will create a uniform system of cross-border service with third countries in the Member States of the Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorising the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify and Malta to accede to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters, in the interests of the European Union, because it is not complete.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. This Convention simplifies the service and notification of civil and commercial court and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. It is already applied by 26 of the Member States and only concerns relations with third countries in the EU. In fact, this Convention tends to strengthen the European Union, but we must respect the sovereign will shown by Austria and Malta to accede to this Convention...

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify respectively and Malta to accede, in the interests of the European Union, to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. The aim of this Convention is to create the means to ensure that judicial and extrajudicial documents, which must be served abroad, are known to their addressees in good time and thus improve mutual judicial assistance, simplifying and speeding up the procedure. It is therefore in the interests of both the European Union and the two states in question to have a uniform regime for notifying acts in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Hague Convention has proved to be very useful in the field of the notification and transfer of cross-border documents, and, in view of the interest of both the Union as a whole and Austria and Malta in having a single regime for the notification and transfer of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, it is positive that both countries join this Convention. My support, therefore, for the proposal to authorise Austria to ratify the Hague Convention and Malta to accede to it, in the interests of the European Union.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a decision authorising Austria and Malta to accede to the Hague Convention on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. All EU Member States except Austria and Malta are signatories to this Convention.  The benefits of this Convention in the area of cross-border service are undeniable, and it is in the interest of EU countries to apply a single procedure for service in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Parliament is consulted here on Malta and Austria's willingness to join the Hague Convention on notification to any other country related to judicial and extrajudicial acts in civil and commercial matters (convocations and court decisions, orders, judgments and judgments etc.). More than 50 states are linked to this act of private international law. Knowing that this is the sovereign will of two countries to participate, I support the Council's decision.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Convention in question aims to facilitate globalised judicial relations by simplifying them. Although this requires EU authorisation, I believe it is essential to respect the sovereign will of Austria and Malta to accede to the Convention, as formulated by these two nations. As a result I voted for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the authorisation for Austria and Malta to adhering to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965. Of the 28 Member States, 26 Member States apply the Convention on Service abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Acts in Civil and Commercial Matters, a key instrument for judicial cooperation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution as it is in Malta’s and the Union’s best interest to have a uniform system for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on authorisation for Austria to sign and ratify, and Malta to accede to, the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 since this Convention has proven its usefulness in the field of the cross-border service of documents. Twenty-six Member States already apply the Convention. Austria and Malta, as the two remaining Member States, have indicated their wish to join. It is in the interest both of the Union as a whole and of the two Member States in question to have a single regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 allows judicial and extrajudicial documents to be served in another State Party. Only States, international organisations, and thus the European Union, cannot accede to the Convention. Austria and Malta are the last two EU Member States not to apply the Convention, but both have now indicated their intention to join, but under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union they can only do so with the consent of the Union. The Council has submitted a draft decision approving the intention of the two Member States to join, but Parliament must agree. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the draft Council decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention simplifies the service and notification of civil and commercial court and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. Currently, 26 of the Member States apply it and most of the other major world powers too (United States, China, Russia, Switzerland, ...). The Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations such as the European Union. But according to Article 3 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the European Union has acquired the competence to give agreement to the conclusion of a treaty that could affect the common rules. Malta and Austria must therefore obtain EU approval to join the Convention. The latter being an effective tool for streamlining judicial relations, and because Malta and Austria's applications for membership are within their sovereign will, we support these applications for authorisation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Convention is an effective instrument that streamlines globalized judicial relations. In theory, this authorisation to join is tantamount to strengthening the European Union. But in this case, we must respect the sovereign will to join manifested by Austria and Malta. That is why I voted for it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the USPASKICH report. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system that allows the service and notification of judicial and extrajudicial civil and commercial documents in other signatory states. It is important to note that it applies only to documents intended for or from third countries in the European Union. Twenty-six of the 28 Member States already apply the convention. The two Member States that have not yet applied it, Namely Austria and Malta, have expressed their desire to join.  Since the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 proved its usefulness in terms of cross-border notification and notification of documents and since both the European Union as a whole and the two Member States in question have an interest in having a uniform regime in this area in their relations with third countries, it is proposed that Parliament give its approval to the decision authorising the accession of Austria and Malta to The Accession of Austria and Malta to convention.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system where by which acts may be served in another signatory State. The Convection is already applied in 26 of the 28 Member States. The two remaining Member States, Austria and Malta, have expressed their willingness to join. I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters, also known as The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 allows for ‘service of process’ of legal documents from one member state to another without use of consular diplomatic channels. I voted for this recommendation that will apply this Convention in Austria and Malta, after they indicated their wish to join the other 26 Member States that already apply it.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention is intended to regulate the cross-border service of documents in and out of third countries. I would have voted in favour of this report because it helps to ensure that Austrian interests are better taken into account.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report is an authorisation from the European Parliament for the accession of Malta and Austria to the Hague Convention on the Meaning and Notification abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Acts in Civil and Commercial Matters. Considering that all eu-largest countries, with the exception of Austria and Malta, were already parties to the Convention, I voted in favour of this report, in order to have a more harmonious application of this Convention to all the countries of the Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is in the interest of the Union as a whole and the two Member States concerned to ensure the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report today because it opposes in principle any requirement that a Member State of the EU must obtain authorisation from the EU before signing certain international treaties.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is well known that the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 provides for the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. At present, of the 28 Member States, 26 are already part of it. Austria and Malta, the last two remaining countries, have expressed their willingness to join. Given that the Convention does not allow the possibility of accession for international organisations, the EU, which has exclusive external competence in this regard, must authorise these States to act on its behalf. Considering it important that all Member States should be party to this Convention, I say that I am voting in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Austria's authorisation to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 and to grant Malta accession to it, which will allow the States to ratify the Convention.  The Hague Convention established a system in 1965 to enable the service of documents between states. Cross-border service of documents in or out of third countries is governed by Regulation No 1393/2007 transposing the validity of the Hague Convention to the EZ. The Convention has been applied to date by 26 of the 28 Member States, and it is in the interest of the EEZ that there is a uniform regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the decision for Austria and Malta to join the Hague Convention on Foreign Service of Judicial and Extra-Judicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters. Austria and Malta are the only two Member States of the European Union that have not yet acceded to that convention and their accession will allow Member States to act on behalf of the Union, as the EU as an international organisation cannot accede to the convention. That is why I call on Parliament to support austria and Malta's accession to the aforementioned Hague Convention, and I hope that this accession will be another step in a series of steps taken by Member States to strengthen the Union's position in its appearance towards third countries.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The sovereign states concerned, Austria and Malta, have expressed their willingness to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965. It is normal to respect this will. I therefore vote in favour of this decision.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. The Convention on the Service abroad of Judicial and Extra-Judicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters is a multilateral agreement signed at The Hague on 15 November 1965. The Convention provides channels for the transfer of judicial or extra-judicial documents sent by one Member State of the Convention to another Member State of the latter.  In other words, the Convention provides one formal channel for transmission, through the central authority of the requested State and several alternative transmission channels. The Hague Conference currently has 80 members: 79 Member States and 1 regional organisation of the economic community. A total of 26 EU Member States apply the Convention. Given that the Hague Convention has demonstrated its usefulness in the area of cross-border delivery of documents, as evidenced by the number of accessions to the Convention, it is in the union's interest as a whole for all Member States to accept one regime for document service in cross-border relations with third countries.  Therefore, I also support the accession of the last two Member States, Austria and Malta, to the Hague Convention on service abroad of judicial and extra-judicial documents in civil or commercial matters.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Convention is to service judicial and extrajudicial documents abroad in civil and commercial matters. It also defines the means to be used where a judicial act is to be transmitted from one Contracting State to another in order to be served there. It improves the transmission of judicial and extrajudicial acts, facilitates judicial cooperation in transnational judicial proceedings and creates an efficient and reliable system for service of judicial and extrajudicial documents. The EU cannot be part of the convention because it does not establish anything about regional economic organisations, only individual states. Member States may not conclude the Convention without being authorised by the EU in accordance with the TFEU. A reality that we reject and which is just another expression of the loss of sovereignty of states through the deepening of the process of capitalist integration that is the EU.   This is the formalisation of the procedure for the application to the Hague Convention of the only two Member States that did not integrate it. Despite reservations about the EU's prior authorisation procedure, we voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. The 1965 Hague Convention provides transmission channels that are used when court or out-of-court documents must be transferred from one contracting party to another. However, it is important to note that the Convention applies only to cross-border document deliveries to or from third countries, and of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. Austria and Malta, as the two remaining Member States, have expressed their desire to join the Convention, and the EU must authorise the Member State in place so that it can act on its own and join the Convention. Malta has already passed its accession instrument, but has adopted a declaration that its accession will not be in force until this decision is upheld. Austria also awaits this decision in order to be able to implement the formalities of accession to that Convention. The Hague Convention has demonstrated its usefulness in the area of cross-border document delivery and it is in the interest of the EU as a whole as well as the two Member States concerned that they have one document delivery regime for cross-border relations with third countries and therefore Austria and Malta should be allowed to join the 1965 Hague Convention smoothly.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system where by which acts may be served in another signatory State. The Convention applies only to acts intended for or coming from third countries. It is in the interests of both the Union as a whole and the Member States to have a uniform system for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries. That is why I welcome the fact that Austria and Malta have expressed their willingness to accede to the Hague Convention. These are the last two EU Member States that had not yet joined. I therefore voted in favour of their accession to the Convention.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 is a system under which documents can be served in another signatory State. It applies exclusively to the cross-border delivery of documents to or from third countries. The Convention is already in place in 26 of the 28 Member States. Following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service of documents within the meaning of Article 3(2) TFEU, the EU has acquired exclusive external competence in this area. This means that the Union must authorise the Member States in question to act on their behalf in order to accede to the Convention. I consider this authorisation requirement by the EU to be excessive and believe that the EU does not have to decide on accession. Only Austria and Malta should have to decide on this. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial acts in civil and commercial matters aims to improve the transmission of judicial and extrajudicial acts to or from third countries. It now applies to 26 Member States, with the remaining two - Austria and Malta - expressing an interest in acceding to that Convention.  Since, as it is certain that, in accordance with Article 3(2) TFEU, the Union has exclusive external competence in this regard, those Member States require authorisation in order to accede to the Convention. Moreover, since the Union cannot become a Contracting Party to the Convention, it is necessary for the Union to exercise its powers through the Member States and it is therefore in its interest to authorise its application.  Accordingly, and considering that it is in the interests of both the Union as a whole and of the two Member States concerned to have a single regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries, I voted in favour of this draft decision authorising the accession of Austria and Malta to that Convention.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system whereby documents may be delivered in another signatory State. This Convention applies only to cross-border notification of documents to or from third countries. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply this Convention. Austria and Malta, the two Member States that have not yet applied it, have expressed their willingness to join.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation granting Parliament its approval for the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention on the Notification or Transfer Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system by which documents may be notified or transferred in another signatory State. Of the twenty-eight Member States, twenty-six already apply the Convention. To the extent that the EU had acquired exclusive competence over the service of cross-border documents, it is necessary for the Union to give its authorisation to these two Member States for accession to the Convention.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system that allows the service and notification of civil and commercial judicial and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. This convention applies only to documents intended for or from third countries in the European Union.  Twenty-six of the 28 Member States already apply the convention. The two Member States that have not yet applied it, Namely Austria and Malta, have expressed their desire to join. Since the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 proved its usefulness in terms of cross-border meaning and notification of documents and since both the European Union as a whole and the two Member States in question have an interest in having a uniform regime in this area in their relations with third countries, I voted this lunchtime for Parliament to give its approval to the decision authorising the accession of Austria and Malta to that convention.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this recommendation because I see no reason why we should prevent the Republic of Austria from signing and ratifying the republic of Austria on 15 November 1965. the Hague Convention on the Service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters and malta to accede to the said Convention. It should be noted that this Convention already applies in the 26 Member States and, once Austria and Malta join, its scope will extend to all EU members.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 regulates how to service judicial and extrajudicial acts abroad in civil and commercial matters. Of the 28 Member States of the European Union, only two still did not apply this Convention: Austria and Malta.  As this Convention does not allow the membership of international organisations, the EU should allow the Member States concerned to act on their behalf in order to accede to it. Since this Convention has proved useful in the field of cross-border notification of judicial and extrajudicial documents, it is in the interests of both the Union as a whole and of the two Member States concerned to implement that Convention, and I therefore voted in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report deals with the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965, which establishes a system for the service and notification of civil and commercial judicial and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. These are documents intended for or from third countries. Currently, 26 Member States apply this convention. Austria and Malta have expressed their willingness to join. In order to follow the European Parliament's approval procedure for Austria and Malta's accession to the Hague Convention and given the use of this uniform regime for the transmission of documents, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is a recommendation for accession to the Hague Convention on the notification or transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. All Member States, in addition to Malta and Austria, have already signed this convention, which is procedural in nature.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal because the Hague Convention is of the utmost importance to the judiciary for the cross-border handling of judicial matters and leads to greater efficiency in the European judicial system.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation in favour of Austria signing and ratifying the Hague and Malta Convention, since these two Member States are not yet part of this Convention on the notification or transfer abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. As it is a Convention which facilitates procedural aspects and which have already been ratified by all but these two Member States, I have had no problem giving my vote in favour of Malta and Austria subscribing to it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system where both judicial and extra-judicial documents can be served in another signatory state, which widens the scope of access to justice for EU citizens. Of the 28 Member States only Austria and Malta have yet to accede to the convention. So this vote represents my support and welcoming of the fact that these two countries will cooperate in this convention with the other 26.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament granting its consent to the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria, in the interest of the European Union, to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters and authorising the Republic of Malta to accede to this Convention in the interest of the European Union.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1965 Hague Convention allows cross-border service of documents in individual signatory States. It concerns the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters to third countries outside the EU, as a specific regulation applies to this matter within the EU. Up to 26 Member States are already applying the Hague Convention, while Austria and Malta, which have now expressed a wish to accede to the Convention, remain. As the Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations, the EU has adopted specific legislation conferring exclusive competence on it by the Member States on matters of cross-border service of documents. I supported the Position of the European Parliament because this will allow the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify the Hague Convention and the Republic of Malta will be able to accede to the Convention. Both countries will thus participate in the exchange of documents with third countries within the current European framework.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system under which judicial and extrajudicial documents may also be served in another State Party to the Convention in civil or commercial matters. The Convention applies to the service of documents in or out of third countries and has already been applied by 26 EU Member States.  The Hague Convention has proved very useful in the field of cross-border service of documents. Austria and Malta, which until now have not been signatories to the Convention, have expressed their wish to join. However, the Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations, which is why the EU must specifically authorise Member States wishing to accede to the Convention to act on its behalf. The existence of a uniform regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries is in the interest of both the EU and Austria and Malta, which wish to join the Conventions.  For the sake of what I described, I voted in plenary to adopt the recommendation and to support it.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. Since 15 November 1965, the Hague Convention establishes a system in which documents can be available in another signatory state of the convention. The Convention refers to the cross-border service of the delivery of documents within the European Union, Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council since 13 November 2007 on service in the Member States of judicial and extra-judicial documents in civil or commercial cases. Of the 28 Member States, 26 are already applying conventions. Austria and Malta, as the two remaining Member States, have shown a desire to join. Taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs (A8-0018/2016), I supported the consent for the Draft Council Decision authoring the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extra-judicial documents in civil or commercial matters, and for the Republic of Malta to accede to that Convention in the interest of the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Hague Convention adopted on 15 November 1965 established a system allowing Member States of the European Union to submit court and extra-judicial documents in civil or commercial cases abroad. It should be noted that the Convention applies only to cross-border service of judicial and extra-judicial documents in or from third states.  Today, the system is used by 26 of the 28 member states. The Republic of Austria and the Republic of Malta are two members who have not yet joined the Convention and have expressed their desire to join it. A draft Council decision is proposed to allow the Republic of Malta access to the Convention and authorizes the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify the Convention. The importance and usefulness of this Convention has already proven itself and it is in the interest of Austria and Malta, but also of the Union as a whole, to be part of a single system for the service of judicial and extra-judicial documents in civil or commercial cases abroad. I therefore support the decision to allow the Republic of Austria and the Republic of Malta access, signature and ratification of the Convention.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision author ing the Republic of Austria, in the interest of the European Union, to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters abroad and the Republic of Malta's accession to it.  Austria and Malta are the only countries out of 28 that do not yet apply the Hague Convention. As both have expressed their desire to join, Malta has already deposited the charter, Austria will continue to do so, and since it is in the interest of the Union and the Member States, I supported the recommendation.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system where according to which judicial documents may be ed by another Contracting State. Of the 28 Member States of the Union, only Austria and Malta are not parties to the Convention, but have expressed their interest in accession.  The Union should authorise these two States to act on its behalf in order to join the Convention. As it is the desire of the sovereign states to join the Convention, we voted in favour of the report, which. called on Parliament to adopt the proposal for a decision allowing Austria and Malta to join the Convention.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The ratification and signature by Austria and accession to the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 is something we fully agree with. It is regrettable that independent states are seeking union approval to join conventions.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system whereing the service of official documents in civil and economic matters in another State Party. It should be noted that the Convention applies only to cross-border service of official documents originating in or sent to third countries: cross-border service within the European Union is subject to Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 November 2007 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have also indicated their intention to join. The Convention does not allow the accession of international organisations. However, following the adoption of EU legislation on cross-border service of documents, the Union has acquired exclusive external competence on this issue within the meaning of Article 3(2) TSI. This approach was confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. On this basis, the Union should allow the Member States in question to act on its behalf with a view to accession to the Convention. It is in the interest of both the Union as a whole and the two Member States in question to have a uniform system for the uniform service of documents in their cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention represented a turning point in the procedure for the cross-border notification of judicial, extrajudicial and commercial documents in or from third countries. It allowed the decisions of the institutions of the signatory States to be applied to the territory of other signatory States, contributing to the strengthening of international legality. Currently, 26 EU Member States are signatories to this important convention, which also gives it a European dimension. Austria and Malta, the only Member States that have not signed the Convention, are in the process of becoming signatory members. In this respect, the consent of the European Parliament, representing the will of the citizens of the Union, is needed in order to allow the two States to accede to the Convention. This step would complement the union-wide ratification process. It is therefore necessary to adopt this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Since the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 proved its usefulness in terms of cross-border document service and notification and since both the European Union as a whole and the two Member States in question have an interest in having a uniform regime in this area in their relations with third countries, it had been proposed that Parliament give its approval to the decision authorising the accession of Austria and Malta convention. It's now done.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Austria signing and ratifying, and Malta of acceding to the Convention ensuring that judicial and extrajudicial documents are served abroad, and that the organisation of mutual judicial assistance is improved. I believe that a single regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries is in the interest both of the EU as a whole and of Austria and Malta, as it will allow a quicker, less bureaucratic and more effective access to justice.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Given that the Hague Convention has proved useful and effective in the area of cross-border delivery of documents and that the existence of a single document delivery regime in cross-border relations with third countries is in the interest of the European Union as a whole, as well as of the two Member States concerned, it is not surprising that Parliament give its consent to the proposal for a decision to allow Austria and Malta to join that Convention. Of the 28 Member States of the European Union, 26 already apply the Hague Convention. Austria and Malta, as the two remaining member states, have expressed their desire to join the convention. The two countries have the absolute right to access and ratify the Convention, but without legal jurisdiction and without the need for the european Union to approve those requirements. Accordingly, and as I have always pointed out, I am primarily committed to the principle of sovereign integrity and genuine subsidiarity of the Member States, and I would like these principles to be applied both in terms of Austria and Malta's approach to the Hague Convention. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ Recommendation on a draft Council decision author ing the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters abroad and the Republic of Malta' accession to it, as the Hague Convention already allows documents to be served on other Contracting States.  26 of the 28 Member States already apply the Convention, and Austria and Malta have expressed their wish to accede to it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This Convention simplifies the service and notification of civil and commercial court and extrajudicial documents in other signatory states. It applies only to relations with third countries in the EU. Twenty-six Member States already apply it. Overall, the Convention has been widely adopted (EU, China, Russia, Switzerland,...). This Convention remains an effective instrument, which smoothes globalised judicial relations. In theory, this authorisation to join is tantamount to strengthening the European Union. But in this case, we must respect the sovereign will to join manifested by Austria and Malta. So I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 established a system whereing the service of documents in another State Party. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. The remaining two Member States, Austria and Malta, have also indicated their intention to join. Since the Convention has demonstrated its usefulness in the field of cross-border service of documents and it is in the interest of both the Union as a whole and the two Member States in question to have a uniform system for the uniform service of documents in their cross-border relations with third countries, I voted in favour of the document.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the notification and communication abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters facilitates judicial cooperation on cross-border disputes in civil and commercial matters by simplifying the methods of transmission of judicial and extrajudicial acts between Contracting States. Of the 28 Member States of the Union, only two, namely Austria and Malta, have not yet acceded to the Convention. As a legal entity, the Union cannot accede to the Convention and must therefore exercise its powers through its Member States. It is therefore necessary to authorise the accession of the Member States.  The main objective of the council's proposal for a Council decision was therefore drawn up to authorise the accession of the two States to the Hague Convention.
