In view of the importance and usefulness of this legal instrument and noting that all legal conditions have been met, the European Parliament, through its legislative resolution, agrees on the accession of these States and approves the draft Council decision on this legal procedure.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical report which allows Austria and Malta to implement the Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I strongly support this recommendation because the Hague Convention creates a framework for simplifying the exchange of documents between the countries of the European Union. Simplifies and facilitates judicial cooperation in cross-border, civil and commercial disputes. The Convention has proven its usefulness.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the authorisation for Austria to sign and ratify, and Malta to accede to, the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters, in the interest of the European Union. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 establishes a system whereby documents in or from third countries can be served in another signatory state.  Twenty-six Member States already apply the convention, leaving Austria and Malta as the two remaining Member States who are still not part of the system. These two Member States have now filed a request to join and, given that the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 has proven useful in the field of the cross-border service of documents, it is in the interest both of the Union and of the two Member States in question to have a single regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a decision that would incorporate into the Convention the two countries which, of the 28 Member States, remain to join. In this way, the EU as a whole would go on to have a single regime relating to the service of transfer or notification abroad of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters. By this decision, Parliament would consent to the proposal for a Council Decision and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this resolution because it is in the interests of both the European Union and Malta to have a uniform system for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Convention is to service judicial and extrajudicial documents abroad in civil and commercial matters. A judicial act is one that is done by a judge or by the parties involved in a judicial proceedings. An extrajudicial act is one that originates outside the judicial area, for example notary acts.  This Convention defines the means to be used where a judicial act is to be transmitted from one Contracting State to another in order to be served there. Countries shall define the competence of an authority to transmit and service, taking that authority the measures necessary to implement that service. Previously, this was done by consular or diplomatic means. It defines alternative means of transmitting the acts, for example by post.  This is a formal aspect. These two countries are the only two Member States that are not part of this Convention.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Hague Convention would regulate the cross-border service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters in and out of third countries. Although Austrian and Maltese standards are being respected here, I believe that the current national system in Austria would be sufficient. That is why I abstained.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with Parliament's resolution on the draft Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria to sign and ratify the Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 on the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents abroad in civil and commercial matters in the interests of the European Union, and on Malta's authorisation to accede to it in the interests of the European Union. I refused to give my assent not because I am opposed to the accession of Austria or Malta to this convention, but because I believe that this should be a matter for the Member States and not for the EU. Malta and Austria should be able to join if they wish, without the EU Parliament or EU institutions approving it.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the Recommendation of the European Parliament on the accession of Austria and Malta to the Hague Convention, which establishes a system through which documents can be notified in another signatory State. Of the 28 Member States, 26 already apply the Convention. The Hague Convention of 15 November 1965 has proved its usefulness in the field of cross-border document notification and it is in the interest of both the Union as a whole and of the two Member States concerned to have a single document notification regime in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision for the accession of Austria and Malta to the Convention, as it is in the interest of the union as a whole and the two Member States that there is a uniform regime for the service of documents in cross-border relations with third countries.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU.  Accordingly UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of fiscal and financial cooperation is relevant from the point of view of compliance with tax obligations at international level. The European Union and the Republic of San Marino have signed an agreement for the automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of their residents in order to combat fraud, avoidance and tax evasion. This should lead to an improvement in the current situation. However, the agreement still contains regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text of the Agreement obliges San Marino to apply financial account information standards equivalent to those of the European legislative framework, which will strengthen controls on tax evasion and evasion. Although insufficient, this is a step in the right direction, so I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text to validate the agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. This decision will limit the possibility for taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations to the tax authorities. The agreement also proposes the exchange of information on savings income, account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.  Tax transparency and an end to bank secrecy both within the EU and on its doorstep is a priority in order to preserve the tax revenues of states.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it is an important step in efforts against tax fraud and tax evasion, ensuring the automatic exchange of financial transaction information, aiming at international tax cooperation and compliance. With this report, the EU and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial statements of their residents, starting in 2017, with the aim of dealing with situations where the taxpayer is trying to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to validate the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations.  The aim is to combat ordinary tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid such a tax bracket. In accordance with OECD standards, the agreement provides that the information exchanged relates not only to savings income (interest and dividends), but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. In line with our previous votes on the end of banking secrecy in Europe (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra), I voted in favour.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency I would like to confirm I voted against this report. I am against the European Union having any authority over the financial interests, especially taxation, which should be controlled only by elected national Parliaments.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information. On 8 December 2015, the European Union and San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information in order to improve international cooperation and tax compliance. This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. It will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents from 2017 on the EU and San Marino. The aim is to respond to cases where a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. The aim is also to ensure that not only information on income such as interest and dividends is exchanged, but also on account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. Thanks to the new agreement, tax authorities in the Member States and San Marino will be able to: identify the relevant taxpayers fairly and clearly; administer and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border cases; assess the possibility of tax evasion; avoid unnecessary further investigations.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Serenissima Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and hence compliance with tax obligations at international level. The text provides that the European Union and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the accounts of their respective residents from 2017.  However, the agreement received early application on 1 January 2016. The aim is always to deal with "ordinary" tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation. In accordance with OECD standards, the agreement provides that the information exchanged relates not only to savings income (interest and dividends), but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.  That is why I supported this agreement, in line with my previous votes on the end of banking secrecy in Europe (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra).

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I obviously voted in favour of this agreement reached in December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at the international level. This is an important step in current efforts to combat tax evasion and evasion, as San Marino can be considered an important tax haven. The new agreement provides that the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents from 2017. The ultimate goal is to prevent a taxpayer from concealing capital that corresponds to income or assets on which the tax has not been paid. In particular, San Marino will have to comply with OECD standards for the automatic exchange of financial account information in 2014.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the van Nieuwenhuizen report because I am convinced that the agreement signed by the EU and the Republic of San Marino on 8 December 2015 represents an important step towards combating fraud and tax evasion. As early as 2004, a first agreement was signed guaranteeing measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. With these new measures, it will be easier to enforce their tax legislation in cross-border situations, by more effectively assessing cases of tax evasion and thus avoiding unnecessary investigations.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which establishes an agreement between the Union and San Marino establishing a framework for cooperation for the exchange of convergent tax information with which it already operates between Member States. This Agreement relates only to interest taxes received by savers as creditors. The Agreement moves forward to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion and facilitate transparency.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. This will mean that from 2017 on the basis of 2017 they will exchange information on the bank accounts of European residents of the country and sanmarinens residing in the EU and it will be more difficult for EU citizens to evade taxes by opening bank accounts in that country. This agreement will also enable the tax authorities of the 28 Member States to correctly identify the taxpayers involved, enforce tax rules in cross-border situations, assess the possibility of tax evasion and avoid unnecessary investigations.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report must validate the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This text received an early application on 1 January 2016 instead of 2017. The agreement provides that the information exchanged relates to savings income (interest and dividends) but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets in order to be in line with OECD standards and to better deal with ordinary tax evasion. Following my previous votes on the end of banking secrecy in Europe (Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Andorra), I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino represents an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion. That is why I supported it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution approving the conclusion of the Agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This agreement advances the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, with an automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of their respective residents being established between the parties from 2017. In this way, situations in which a taxpayer tries to hide an estate representing income or assets on which no taxes have been paid may be addressed. It is also proposed to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest or dividends, but also to account balances and income from the sale of financial assets. The agreement also ensures the unconditional exchange of information upon request, in accordance with the latest OECD developments and EU work in this area.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the agreement between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information. This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and improves the 2004 agreement, which ensured that San Marino applied measures equivalent to those of the EU Savings Tax Directive. Under the new agreement, from 2017, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information about the financial accounts of their residents. The aim is to respond to cases where a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. The agreement aims to ensure that San Marino applies stricter measures that are equivalent to the EU legal order, as improved in December 2014.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. It is estimated that the grey economy in the EU Member States represents a staggering EUR 1000 billion per year in un collected taxes and contributions. Despite the fact that this is an assessment, it is undoubtedly a major anomaly which constitutes damage both in the area of free competition and in ensuring access to public services financed by tax. The fight against tax fraud is one of the priorities of the whole EU, which is already showing results. The examples of revelations about the tax malversation of multinationals that we have witnessed since the LuxLeaks revelations are undoubtedly steps in the right direction. If we do not properly punish the great offenders and build our apparent power on chicken thieves, if I may express myself, we will lose credibility with citizens and citizens. In order to achieve such objectives, however, we need an enhanced exchange of information on financial accounts and all other relevant information concerning the cross-border business of companies. I am therefore pleased that the EU and San Marino have reached an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which represents an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud. The agreement provides for the automatic exchange of information on residents' financial accounts in a way that will help identify those residents who conceal income or capital.  I therefore supported the proposed decision to conclude the agreement.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU.  Accordingly UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to validate the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at the international level. The aim is always to deal with "ordinary" tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation. I voted for it like my previous votes on ending banking secrecy in Europe (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra).

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must finale the agreement with San Marino in order to ensure that san marino continues to apply fiscal measures equivalent to those of the Union.  The importance of the automatic exchange of information as a means of combating cross-border tax fraud and evasion by ensuring maximum transparency and cooperation between tax administrations has also been recognised at international level.  In order to minimise administrative costs and burdens for both tax administrations and economic operators, it is essential to ensure that the amendment of the current agreement on the taxation of savings income with San Marino is in line with EU and international developments. This will increase tax transparency in Europe and provide the legal basis for the application of the OECD global standard for the automatic exchange of information between San Marino and the EU.   The European Parliament must approve the text of the negotiating amending protocol, as it aligns the agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino establishing measures equivalent to those defined in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on income taxation in the form of interest payments.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The text in question aims to strengthen tax transparency and combat bank secrecy in San Marino. From now on, the European Union and the Republic of San Marino will exchange data on both savings income but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. While the signing of such an agreement should first fall within the regal competence of the Member States and not of the European Union, the fact remains that, given the urgent need to combat tax evasion effectively, such a text is a step in the right direction and must be supported. That is why I voted for the report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic developments are linked to the most organised circulation of information, which is why the 2015 Agreement signed between the Union and San Marino on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in order to improve tax cooperation and compliance with tax rules at international level is only a first step, relations having to be continued. The next step is the unconditional exchange of on-demand information, which will be ensured under the new 2017 agreement, in line with the latest developments in OECD and EU work in this area. I appreciate the purpose of this approach, which is to deal with situations where the taxpayer tries to hide capital representing income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. The agreement is an important step in the current efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and updates the 2004 agreement, which ensures that the Republic of San Marino applies measures equivalent to those of the EU directive on taxation of savings income, which is why I voted in favour of this draft resolution.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The agreement represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and improves the 2004 agreement guaranteeing the application by the Republic of San Marino of measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The fight against fraud and tax evasion must be carried out both inside and outside the EU's borders. This provision is all the more striking in the case of the Republic of San Marino because the micro-state is landlocked within a Member State, Italy. The agreement between San Marino and the European Union, signed in December 2015, will allow for an automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts which will improve tax cooperation between that state and the Union. I voted in favour of this report, which is another step in strengthening tax transparency.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino, on the following grounds: the agreement represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion; it improves the 2004 agreement guaranteeing the application by the Republic of San Marino of measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income; I agree with the rapporteur that the aim is to deal with situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion; the new agreement also provides for the unconditional exchange of information on request, in accordance with the latest developments in the work of the OECD and the EU in this area.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Under the new agreement, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents, starting in 2017. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. The agreement aims at ensuring that San Marino applies strengthened measures that are equivalent to the EU legal framework, as upgraded in December 2014 (amending the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, ‘DAC2’) and that comply with the procedures for automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standard.  I voted in favour of this report which represents an important step forward in efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and evasion.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU.  Accordingly UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the successful Council negotiations with San Marino in relation to the Savings Directive. Its aim is to update the existing agreement in line with international developments and the changing EU laws. I voted in favour of the report so that the outcomes of the negotiations can be applied as soon as possible and the automatic exchange of information can be continued. This will allow for a continued and smooth cooperation in the area of taxation, including the combat against tax evasion and tax fraud.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution expresses the European Parliament's favourable opinion on the conclusion of a protocol to the agreement between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on measures equivalent to those defined by Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income. The protocol amending the agreement represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. Under the agreement as amended, from 2017 the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information relevant to taxation. This is an important measure to combat the concealment of capital and tax evasion and therefore the delegation of the 5 Star Movement voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report on the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 by the European Union and San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which aims to improve international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement is an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments concerns a formal, but important, procedure relating to clarity in economic procedures within the European area. In this light I think this is a positive move and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I believe that the automatic exchange of financial information between the EU and San Marino for tax purposes improves cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level and is also an important step forward in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. The agreement is intended to ensure that the Republic of San Marino applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework. As a result of the agreement, the tax administrations of the Member States and San Marino will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, to apply and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border situations and to assess more effectively the likelihood of tax evasion.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I share the legal purpose, even if the practical aspect puzzles me. Indeed, while it is right that the savings of rimini's citizens and those who live only a few kilometres away should not be subject to completely different conditions, on the other hand I am not sure that the EU should exert its economic giant pressure to get San Marino to legislate differently than its citizens want. However, as an Italian politician, I must admit that all possible resources must be rounded up these days and left it to some citizens to escape, knowing that this is the case, is irresponsible.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of San Marino have signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information from financial accounts to improve tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. Under the new agreement, from 2017 on, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other party. The aim is to prevent situations where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid. I support this report because I believe that this agreement represents important progress in the efforts being made to combat tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU.  Accordingly UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the agreement between the EU and the Republic of San Marino because it is an important step in combating tax fraud and evasion. In fact, it is an agreement which provides for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, which will make it possible to cope with attempts to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments through automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion, will enhance transparency, accountability and ethical financial management. The resolution develops the 2004 agreement with San Marino further. Economies need to ensure fair administration and enforcement of their tax laws even in cross-border situations.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and San Marino have signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. This is the third in a package of five agreements, covering Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Andorra and Monaco. Although these agreements make improvements, they actually solve most of the problems that exist with all these countries. On the basis of this agreement, from 2016 the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, in order to increase efforts to combat fraud, avoidance and tax evasion, which they see as one of the most sensitive countries in these respects. The agreement certainly contains improvements compared with the current situation, but it is also true that a more complete and in-depth agreement could and should have been seeking, as this still leaves a number of regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented. That is why I abstained during the vote in plenary.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text of the Agreement obliges San Marino to apply financial account information standards equivalent to those of the European legislative framework, which will strengthen controls on tax evasion and evasion. Although insufficient, this is a step in the right direction, so I voted in favour.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information on 8 December 2015. The agreement aims to ensure that San Marino applies measures equivalent to the EU legal framework modernised in December 2014. The purpose of the Agreement is to improve international tax cooperation and compliance with the relevant rules. The agreement is an important element in the fight against tax fraud and evasion, which will allow automatic exchange of information between the EU and San Marino on the financial accounts of residents of the two states from 2017.  Cooperation is in place to resolve situations where taxable persons seek to conceal capital conboding income or property for which the tax has not yet been paid. The agreement contributes to strengthening the fight against tax evasion. The above method of tax fraud and avoidance adversely affects the income of EU economies and cooperation on the subject is therefore justified and important. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union and San Marino will automatically exchange financial information on residents of the other party in accordance with the updated requirements set out in the Administrative Cooperation Directive as well as with the 2014 OECD Global Standards. This will take place from 2017. The aim is to remedy situations where the taxpayer is attempting to conceal capital constituting income or assets from which no taxes have been paid. Similar updates have been made to the agreements with Switzerland and Liechtenstein, and agreements with Andorra and Monaco will also be updated. I welcome this update as the agreement has been adapted to current EU and OECD global standards, without applying double standards to the exchange of information. I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal in question concerns the approval of a cooperation agreement between the European Union and San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement is a positive step forward in addressing tax fraud and tax evasion. The outcome of this agreement would result in a strengthened relationship between the European Union and San Marino, in line with OECD standards. I am in favour of this agreement being concluded and ratified in a timely manner, and of keeping the transitional phase as short as possible. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report gives the European Parliament the approval of the amendment of the agreement between the European Community and San Marino, in order to better combat tax evasion. The new protocol aims to make it more difficult for EU citizens to hide capital from the taxman by providing for the automatic exchange of information on residents' financial accounts from 2017. Considering that tax evasion is one of the consequences of bank secrecy, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the conclusion of this agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino providing measures on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The agreement aims to strengthen measures to combat tax evasion and evasion within the framework of cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of San Marino. The adoption of this new set of measures will notably enable enforcement of tax laws in cross-border situations but also to assess the likelihood of tax evasion.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because it represents an important step forward in the fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thanks to this decision, the European Union and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents. A step of clarity and accountability to ensure fiscal fairness and financial transparency at a sensitive time for the European economy.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the European Council Savings Directive and in order to preserve a level playing field for economic operators, the EU and San Marino signed an Agreement laying down provisions equivalent to those laid down in the Council Directive. Commission Decision 2011/108/EC of 28 June 2011 (TS On 17 June, it adopted a proposal for negotiations with San Marino in order to improve EU agreements in line with the international development of the countries and to ensure that these countries continue to apply equivalent provisions. Commission Decision 2013/108/EC of 28 May 2013 (not to be On the 13th, he reached an agreement. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the agreement signed in December 2015 between the EU and San Marino to combat tax evasion and evasion. In accordance with this agreement (which will come into force on 1 January 2017), San Marino will now apply stricter measures, equivalent to those in place within the EU since March 2014. The agreement also complies with the 2014 global standard promoted by the OECD on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The information exchanged will relate not only to income, such as interest and dividends, but also to balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. Tax administrations in the EU Member States and San Marino will therefore be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, manage and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and avoid further unnecessary investigations.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. It was proposed to validate the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic and reciprocal exchange of information relating to savings and financial accounts. Its implementation, originally scheduled for 2017, was anticipated on 1 January 2016. This text enhances transparency, tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations, including the fight against ordinary tax evasion. Consistent with my previous votes on the end of banking secrecy in Switzerland, Liechtenstein, and Andorra, I voted for this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tax fraud is one of the areas from which the Union budget suffers on the largest scale. It is important that Member States cooperate with each other in the fight against them. Moreover, the EU needs cooperation with European non-member countries but still part of the European economic community.  I supported the report, but nevertheless I believe that huge efforts are needed to continue signing similar agreements with other European countries, which are known as tax haven countries. This will bring the rest of the continent to the Union by making it a stable and economically evolving place.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of San Marino have signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information from financial accounts to improve tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. Thus, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other Party. The aim is to prevent situations where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid. Under the new agreement, the tax administrations of the Member States and The Navy will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned; enforce and enforce its tax laws in cross-border situations; assess the likelihood of tax evasion and dispense with unnecessary additional investigations. I voted in favour.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signed agreement on the automatic exchange of information on accounts and financial interest, which aims, among other things, to improve international tax cooperation, represents an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. With the new agreement, San Marino and the EU will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each's residents from 2017. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide his sources of untaxed financial income. The agreement aims to ensure that San Marino applies measures that are equivalent to the legal framework of the European Union and the OECD. We have nothing to owe and we recognize the positive (though limited) aspects that can result from this.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Combating capital from tax evasion and illegal activities is one of the Union's priorities. The agreement between the EU and San Marino is a good one, as I believe it is essential that the San Marino Republic complies with the procedures for the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standard. It will be possible to assess, with greater certainty and transparency, any tax evasion and avoid unnecessary investigations.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the agreement, which represents a step forward in the fight against fraud and tax evasion.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the EU-San Marino agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The Republic of San Marino is a well-known tax haven and therefore the exchange of tax information serves international tax cooperation and compliance with the relevant provisions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I consider that the agreement represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that San Marino applied measures equivalent to those in an EU directive on the taxation of savings income. Under the agreement, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2017. Therefore, I support its aim to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. Moreover, I support the agreement as it is in line with the need for more transparency on tax issues in the EU and in its relations with third countries.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement represents an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and updates the 2004 agreement to ensure that the Republic of San Marino applies measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. Under the new agreement, an automatic exchange of information between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the financial accounts of each other's residents will be established from 2017 onwards. The aim is to address situations where taxable persons seek to conceal capital conbodied in the sense of income or property for which the tax has not yet been paid. I support the aim of the agreement to ensure that San Marino applies reinforced measures equivalent to the EU legal framework modernised in December 2014 (amending the DAC2 Directive on administrative cooperation) and to comply with the automatic exchange procedures for financial account information advocated by global OECD standards in 2014.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the amendment to the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino, as this change gives us a set of weapons to combat tax evasion. With this amendment, from 2017, the Republic of San Marino will exchange financial information of its residents with the EU in order to combat wealth concealment and tax fraud.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, particularly that which takes place in third States by natural or legal persons who are nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino laying down measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The agreement, signed in December 2015, between the European Union and San Marino for compliance with international tax obligations marks an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion and guarantees the automatic exchange of financial information to identify, without error and without delay, the taxpayers concerned.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-San Marino agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. Transparency and greater fairness in the financial market are an honest concern for me. That is why I also support this agreement.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is an important step in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. It will also ensure the timeliness of the 2004 agreement and the security of the application of equivalent rules.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU.  Accordingly UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-San Marino agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which concerns a cooperation agreement between the European Union and San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which establishes an agreement between the Union and San Marino establishing a cooperation framework for the exchange of convergent tax information with which it already operates between member countries. This Agreement relates only to interest taxes received by savers as creditors. The Agreement moves forward to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion and facilitate transparency.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino laying down measures concerning the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. I voted in favour of the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino. As in the case of Switzerland or Liechtenstein, this will avoid the taxpayer hiding capital constituting income or assets without tax. The exchange of financial information between the residents of each party in accordance with the current requirements is an integral part of a transparent relationship with the European Union and effective prevention of irregularities in this field.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement between the EU and San Marino on the automatic exchange of financial account information. This is an important step towards fighting corruption in the area of tax in the country.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 San Marino is considered an attractive destination for large-income accounts, which transfer their accounts there to avoid taxing their wealth. That is why we consider the position of voting to be an appropriate position, because the report promotes more transparency in the taxation of savings income.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because under the new agreement, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2017. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU.  Accordingly UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this report which improves the benefits of the Agreement signed between the European Union and San Marino on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to improve international tax cooperation and compliance, the EU and San Marino signed an agreement on 8 December 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information. An automatic exchange of information on financial accounts will start in 2017. This should reduce the possibility for tax evasion. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino on measures equivalent to those set out in the Savings Interest Income Tax Directive, as this enhances tax cooperation and reinforces measures against tax evasion and fraud.  The Union legal framework in this area was improved at the end of 2014 and San Marino is expected to apply measures equivalent to that framework. In my view, the exchange of information should concern not only income but also account balances and revenues from the sale of financial assets. This will strengthen their efficiency, consistency and efficiency in member states and San Marino, and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Transparency is key to identifying aggressive corporate tax planning practices and ensuring fair tax competition. It seems necessary that national authorities exchange tax information on the activities of multinationals, country by country. All Member States must have essential information to detect the risks of tax evasion and better target their tax controls. This EU-San Marino tax transparency agreement is in line with previous agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Andorra. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU.  Accordingly UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Cora van Nieuwenhuizen's report on the EU-San Marino agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The European Union has developed this agreement for greater tax transparency in the exchange of information between administrations. I support these exchanges of information between the administrations of the European Union and San Marino, which are essential for the fight against fraud and tax evasion. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to set up an automatic system of exchange of tax-related information between the EU and San Marino. This will help to combat the many taxpayers seeking to hide their capital in San Marino to evade tax and strengthen the fight against fraud and tax evasion in Europe.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The new agreement with San Marino, which updates the agreement that has been in place since 2004, is intended to cooperate in tax matters and to contribute to the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. I therefore agree with the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, as it is in line with the need for more transparency on tax issues in the EU and in its relations with third countries.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report deals with the agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information between the EU and San Marino signed on 8 December 2015. As regards the effort in order to clamp down on tax fraud and evasion, Directive 2003/48/EC is only limited to taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments on debt claims, to the exclusion of the issues relating to the taxation of pension and insurance benefits. Hence, this new agreement aims at ensuring that San Marino applies strengthened measures, equivalent to the EU legal framework. Particularly, it will help to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income for which taxes have not been paid. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ San Marino’s agreement to cooperate with the EU on tax transparency could serve as an example to the world how the fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion should be conducted. There is no doubt that the automatically exchange of information between the EU Member States and San Marino will contribute to the efforts to deter hiding income and assets abroad and will promote fair distribution of the tax burden for all citizens. For the good of the Union and Member States, the EU should sign same type of agreement with all of its partners.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. On 8 December 2015, the European Union and the Republic of San Marino signed an agreement aimed at strengthening international cooperation and compliance with tax obligations. The primary objective is to deal promptly with cases in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. It is therefore necessary for the Republic of San Marino to align itself with EU standards, in accordance with the procedures concerning the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standard. Finally, I would like to stress that this agreement provides for an unconditional exchange of information on request, in accordance with the latest developments in the work of the OECD and the EU in this area. I have decided to vote in favour not only in view of what has been said, but also because it will be ensured that the information exchanged will cover both income such as interest and dividends, but also account balances and proceeds from sales of financial assets.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the EU-San Marino agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The text provides that the European Union and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the accounts of their respective residents from 2017.   The aim is to deal with "ordinary" tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation. In accordance with OECD standards, the agreement provides that the information exchanged relates not only to savings income (interest and dividends), but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it supports the EU's implementation of a tax transparency agreement with San Marino.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons nationals of a Member State of the Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text of the Agreement obliges San Marino to apply financial account information standards equivalent to those of the European legislative framework, which will strengthen controls on tax evasion and evasion. Although insufficient, this is a step in the right direction, so I voted in favour.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the principle that the Republic of San Marino should transfer savings taxes to other states. Such an agreement should possibly be a matter for San Marino and the state, which wants to agree with it on the transfer of money.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union loses EUR 1 billion annually due to tax evasion. Much of the evasion is done in existing tax havens, including in Europe and other Member States.  Today I voted in favour of the Protocol amending the agreement between the Commission and San Marino. It makes it possible to automatically exchange information on residents' financial accounts. They cover those situations where potential tax payers try to hide capital from receipts for which they have not paid taxes.  Similar regulations have been made for other countries where tax havens, such as Switzerland or Lichtenstein, exist. Next up is Andorra and Monaco.  Automatic exchange of information is an efficient and rapid method of combating cross-border tax fraud and evasion, for which the OECD has been given a mandate from the G20.  We cannot live together in a society where some pay taxes and others trick us all by hiding their income in tax havens.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU and San Marino signed an agreement in December 2015 on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts aimed at improving tax cooperation and tax liability at international level. The deal is a step towards introducing tougher measures against tax fraud and evasion. Under the new agreement, San Marino would automatically exchange information about the financial accounts of its residents. This would ensure that no taxpayer could conceal capital representing income or assets and would pay tax for each capital. The data will not only relate to income, such as interest rate and dividend, but also account balances and revenues from the sale of financial assets, so I supported this agreement.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As with Liechtenstein two and a half months ago, today's vote concerned an agreement between the European Union and San Marino on the exchange of financial information between bank account holders. This agreement should potentially contribute to more effective international cooperation in the field of taxation policy, as well as to promote the legitimisation of the income of EU citizens directly through the full payment of these taxes. Compared to other countries, San Marino was never an influential player among low-tax asylum seekers such as Liechtenstein or Switzerland. However, the signing of this agreement is clearly of great importance, as it will both increase the transparency of tax payment and, in principle, stimulate further improvement of relations between our national community and San Marino, and will, of course, eliminate another actual or potential tax haven.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By resolution, the EP approved the conclusion of an amending protocol to the Agreement with the San Marino country of 8 December 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The agreement aims to improve international cooperation and compliance in the field of taxation and to reduce tax fraud and tax evasion in the signatory countries. Under the amended Protocol, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on their residents' financial accounts from 2017. This will contribute to reducing tax fraud and tax evasion in the signatory countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino, providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, because it is not complete and because it also does not effectively combat tax evasion and avoidance as it is based on OECD standards which, as we know, allow for the existence of "grey zones" which facilitate tax evasion and avoidance, not only of different individuals, but also of multinational enterprises through known triangular relations.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement. The aim here is to validate the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. The text provides that the European Union and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the accounts of their respective residents from 2017.  However, the agreement received early application on 1 January 2016. The aim is always to deal with "ordinary" tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the EU-San Marino agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes is in favour of me. This report represents the continuing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. Under the new agreement, from 2017 the EU and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents. The aim is to address situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU-San Marino Agreement for the Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations is an important step in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion and updates the 2004 agreement, which ensured the implementation by San Marino of measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU Tax Directive. savings yields. I therefore support the proposal to ratify this Agreement which will undoubtedly benefit both EU and San Marino citizens.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. The agreement aims to ensure that San Marino applies more stringent measures that are equivalent to eu legal order. In addition, the signing of the agreement will allow for a more rapid response to cases where the taxpayer attempts to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which no taxes have been paid.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On 8 December 2015, the European Union and San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information to combat tax evasion and evasion. The objective is to deal with situations where a taxpayer seeks to conceal capital that corresponds to income or assets over which the tax has not been paid.  In the case of the similar agreement with Switzerland, even the largest tax haven (even concealing the income of a minister ...) the EU had in the end maintained bank secrecy, not providing for a requirement to disclose full and detailed information about account holders.  I am voting in order to support this step in the fight against tax evasion, even if in any case Parliament is simply consulted here and the decision has already been taken. One more time.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement promotes transparency for taxation and savings. Its aim is to actively combat tax evasion. It follows such agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Andorra which we supported for the end of banking secrecy. Therefore I voted for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. The agreement is an essential tool for fiscal cooperation in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, increasing tax efficiency in tax collection.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal because it seeks to update the existing agreements that San Marino has with the Union and enacts measures that are in sync with the upgraded EU legal framework to effectively investigate and prosecute tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this agreement because it is in line with the need for more transparency on tax issues in the EU and in its relations with third countries.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU and San Marino agreed in 2004 that the Republic should apply measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. An agreement was reached on 8 December 2015 to establish an automatic exchange of information between the two parties on the financial accounts of each other's residents from 2017 onwards. The purpose of the agreement is to deal with situations where taxable persons seek to conceal capital conbodied in income or property for which the tax has not yet been paid. The Council has submitted a proposal for a decision to ratify the Agreement. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the Council's motion. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to validate the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at the international level. The text provides that the European Union and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the accounts of their respective residents from 2017.  However, the agreement received early application on 1 January 2016. The aim is always to deal with 'ordinary' tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation. In accordance with OECD standards, the agreement provides that the information exchanged relates not only to savings income (interest and dividends), but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. Following on from our previous votes on the end of banking secrecy in Europe (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra), we support these agreements.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this agreement is to deal with "ordinary" tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid taxation. Following on from my previous votes on the end of banking secrecy in Europe (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Andorra), I voted in favour on this text.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 8 December 2015, the European Union and the Republic of San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, an important step forward in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. I voted in favour of amending the agreement so that the administrations of the Member States and San Marino are able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, apply and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border situations and finally assess the likelihood of tax evasion.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to improve international tax cooperation and compliance on 8 December 2015 the European Union and San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. I voted for this report that will bring a provisional entry into application of the agreement starting 1 January, thus tax administrations in the European Union and in San Marino will be able to administer and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion being perpetrated, identify correctly and unequivocally the concerned taxpayers and avoid unnecessary further investigations.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this agreement as it is an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. The agreement is intended to ensure that San Marino applies stricter rules and that the tax administrations in the Member States are able to correctly identify the tax obligations in question.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to improve international taxation cooperation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU exercising its legal personality to enter into international agreements in its own capacity. Treaties concerning tax evasion can be easily conducted on a bilateral or multilateral basis without the need for the involvement of the EU. Accordingly, UKIP voted against the EU entering into the agreement for measures on taxation of savings income.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement concluded between the European Union and the Republic of San Marino on 8 December 2015 provides for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, consoting an important step in the fight against fraud and evasion. In fact, the aim is to deal with situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital by considering whether there is a crime. I welcome the efforts made by the two players in this regard and therefore vote in favour of it.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. This agreement is an important step towards better international cooperation to prevent tax fraud, which was also possible due to the non-exchange of financial information between countries. By adopting the Agreement with San Marino, we will make significant progress, enabling the automatic exchange of information on residents' financial accounts between the EZ and San Marino. In this way, it will be easier to prevent the concealment of money for the purpose of tax evasion.  I also supported the recommendation because it will allow for enhanced measures equivalent to those of the EZ acquis, which are also promoted by the 2014 OECD standards. The agreement will thus give member states' tax administrations more control over their citizens' accounts in San Marino, leading to a reduction in the number of tax evasion.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome this report and fully support it. The new agreement between the European Union and the Republic of San Marino on measures to tax savings interest income will allow better exchange of information on the financial accounts of its nationals. I call on Parliament to support this report, as well as the signing of the agreement itself, the application of which will greatly contribute to combating tax evasion and avoidance. Although a similar agreement with San Marino was signed in 2004, this document will allow San Marino to apply tightened measures related to the exchange of financial account information, which have since been accepted by the European Union and improved by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.  I therefore welcome the signing of this agreement because I see it as another step in achieving the rule of law at the European level.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns a tax transparency agreement with San Marino. Equivalent agreements have already been signed with Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Andorra. Transparency is a major issue in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and San Marino signed a treaty on 8 December 2015 that set a tax transparency landmark, an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion. Under the agreement, starting in 2017, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on their residents' financial accounts, allowing for tackling situations where the taxpayer wants to conceal capital representing income or assets for which no tax has been paid.  Given that tax evasion and avoidance are very widespread and cause a significant loss of revenue, I support the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on measures to tax savings interest income which ultimately is in line with the need for more transparency on EU-third country tax matters.

name: Joao Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement, signed this year on the automatic exchange of account information and financial interest, aims to ensure that San Marino applies measures that are equivalent to the legal framework of the European Union and the OECD, and aims to improve international tax cooperation and compliance, representing an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion.  Under its control, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on their residents' financial accounts from 2017.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Following the adoption of the Austerity Directive to maintain a level playing field for economic operators, the EU signed agreements with Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco and San Marino, which provide for measures equivalent to those set out in the Directive.  Member States also signed agreements with dependent areas of the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. Automatic exchange of information is a very important tool for combating cross-border tax fraud and cross-border tax evasion, ensuring full tax transparency and cooperation between tax administrations around the world, which has recently been recognised internationally.  In order to reduce costs and administrative burdens for tax administrations and economic operators, it is necessary to ensure that the amendment to the existing Savings Agreement concluded with San Marino complies with developments at EU and international level. This will increase tax transparency in Europe, which will be the legal basis for implementing the OECD's global standard on automatic information sharing between San Marino and the EU. For these reasons, I support colleague Core van Nieuwenhuizen's report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of San Marino, in order to ensure compliance with international tax obligations, have signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information relating to the financial accounts of their residents. This agreement, which will officially enter into force from 2017, aims to address the situation in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. I voted in favour of approving this agreement because it represents a further step towards combating tax fraud and evasion at European level.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
