text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Agreement of the European Union and the Republic of San Marino concluded on 8 December 2015 concerning the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at deepening international tax cooperation and tax compliance. Under the agreement, in early 2017, the EU and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each national residing in the partner country of the agreement. I am in favour of the Republic of San Marino applying stronger measures equivalent to those laid down in the EU legal framework. As a result of this new agreement, the tax authorities in the Member States and San Marino will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned and apply and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border situations, while avoiding unnecessary further investigations.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU and San Marino will automatically exchange financial information on the other party's residents in accordance with the updated requirements of the Administrative Cooperation Directive (DAC2) and the 2014 OECD Global Standards. This will take place from 2017. The aim is to remedy situations where the taxpayer is attempting to conceal capital constituting income or assets from which no taxes have been paid. Similar updates have been made to the agreements with Switzerland and Liechtenstein, and agreements with Andorra and Monaco will also be updated. I welcome this update because the agreement has been adapted to current OECD standards and global standards, without applying double standards to the exchange of information. The amendments include, for example, a more detailed set of data protection rules, rules on the exchange of information on request according to the OECD model and a mechanism for rapid adoption of amendments to the OECD global standard with the agreement of the other party. The information to be exchanged relates not only to income, e.g. interest and dividends, but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. That is why I supported this report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – This resolution is about an agreement between the European Union and San Marino, in which an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts takes place. This exchange is intended to combat effective international cooperation in tax matters and tax evasion. The agreement is in line with OECD standards, which does not establish double standards. This is to be welcomed. The agreement allows the tax authorities of the Member States, inter alia, to identify the taxable person concerned without any doubt and to avoid unnecessary further investigations. The new agreement will not only affect information on income such as interest and dividends, but also information on account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. I am voting in favour of this agreement because it is an effective international means of countering tax evasion.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, in which this House endorses the agreement signed in December 2015 between the European Union and San Marino. The agreement aims to set up an automatic exchange of information relating to the financial accounts of the respective residents of the two signatory parties, an exchange that will begin in 2017. In addition, the agreement provides that San Marino will implement enhanced measures, equivalent to those in place within the Union since 2014. Finally, it should be noted that the agreement remains in line with 2014 OECD standards on the automatic exchange of financial account information. With this agreement, a new step is being taken to combat tax evasion and evasion, since it will be more difficult for a taxpayer to hide money on which the tax must apply. To this end, tax authorities will be able to identify the taxpayers involved, manage and enforce their tax laws in cross-border cases, or assess the likelihood of tax evasion involved. Finally, I would like to point out that this agreement remains similar to those reached with Switzerland on 27 October 2015 and with Liechtenstein on 2 December 2015, to which I had already supported it.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement concerns the automatic exchange of information from financial accounts, aimed at improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. It represents important progress in the efforts being made to combat tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution by which Parliament approves the conclusion of the Agreement with San Marino on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This Agreement advances the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, with an automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of their respective residents being established between the parties from 2017. In this way, situations in which a taxpayer tries to hide an estate representing income or assets on which no taxes have been paid may be addressed. It is also proposed to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest or dividends, but also to account balances and income from the sale of financial assets. The Agreement also ensures the unconditional exchange of information upon request, in accordance with the latest OECD developments and EU work in this area.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted this afternoon in favour of the agreement between the European Union and San Marino, signed in December 2015, to combat tax evasion and evasion. The information exchanged will relate not only to income, such as interest and dividends, but also to balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. In accordance with the agreement, San Marino will apply stricter measures, equivalent to those in place within the EU since March 2014. The agreement also complies with the 2014 global standard on the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the OECD. In practical terms, tax administrations in the EU Member States and in San Marino will be able to: - correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned; - manage and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations; - assess the likelihood of tax evasion; - avoid unnecessary further investigations. The agreement will enter into force on January 1, 2017.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it expresses the european Parliament's full support for the agreement signed between the European Union and San Marino. The agreement is another step towards closer cooperation, in which case financial information on the accounts held by the population will be shared. This will aim to avoid tax evasion and reduce the cost of investigating abuse cases.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of San Marino concluded at the end of 2015 an agreement on the automatic exchange of information from financial accounts, with the aim of improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This agreement represents another milestone in the efforts that have been made to combat tax fraud and evasion. Following this new agreement, the EU and San Marino will now automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of the other party's residents, and automatic exchange of information on demand is also ensured, measures in line with the latest developments in the work of the OECD and the EU in this area. Under the new agreement, the tax administrations of the Member States and San Marino may, in addition to correctly and unequivocally identifying the taxpayers concerned, enforce and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations.  Because I think it is important to ensure the smooth functioning of financial matters between San Marino and the EU, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the conditions for the automatic exchange of information with the Republic of San Marino on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The aim is to endorse the Council's position that complies with the international standard for the automatic exchange of financial information on taxation provided by the OECD.  The agreement will enter into force on January 1, 2017. Tax administrations in the EU Member States and San Marino will be able to identify the taxpayers concerned, manage and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, and also assess the likelihood of tax evasion. Europe must take concrete and effective measures against fraud and tax evasion. An agreement with the Republic of San Marino was needed and this project is going in the right direction.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 8 December 2015, the European Union and the Republic of San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level, which will enter into force from 2017. The agreement is part of the European Union's wider project to improve transparency and cooperation on tax matters both between Member States and neighbouring countries and, in particular, to combat the existence of tax havens. The differences between different tax regimes cannot allow tax avoidance and evasion, which leads to lost earnings in the coffers of states already deeply affected by the crisis, an unbalanced distribution of costs between taxpayers and unfair competition between large multinationals and less "smart" companies, SMEs and the self-employed.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which establishes an agreement between the Union and San Marino establishing a cooperation framework for the exchange of convergent tax information with which it already operates between member countries. This Agreement relates only to interest taxes received by savers as creditors. The Agreement moves forward to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion and facilitate transparency.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The text of the Agreement obliges San Marino to apply financial account information standards equivalent to those of the European legislative framework, which will strengthen controls on tax evasion and evasion. Although insufficient, this is a step in the right direction, so I voted in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and the Republic of San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of tax information on 8 December 2015, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level.  I have decided to support the conclusion of the agreement as it represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. From 2017, the EU and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, with the aim of addressing situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. The agreement, which is in line with oecd global standards, also ensures that the information exchanged will cover not only income such as interest and dividends, but also account balances and income from financial assets.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ While the Tories are bent on preserving tax evasion techniques for the rich in Britain, we have been tackling tax evasion in the EU. This agreement means that the EU and San Marino will exchange information automatically on the financial accounts of each other’s residents from 2017. There needs to be more transparency on tax issues between third countries and the EU and this is one step in that direction.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ in the event of a vote on a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the conclusion of an amending protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino regulating measures on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. The signing of this amending Protocol will allow the implementation of the Agreement on the Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information, which aims to improve international cooperation and compliance with tax rules signed by the European Union and San Marino in December 2015. The aim is to address situations where the taxpayer tries to hide capital in the form of income or property for which no tax has been paid.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The events of recent years show that we still have problems with tax evasion in Europe. I therefore welcome the agreement between the EU and San Marino, under which information on the financial accounts can be exchanged from 2017 on the basis of which information can be exchanged. This agreement will contribute to resolving situations where the taxpayer tries to hide capital in the form of income or property for which he has not paid tax. I supported the agreement because it will result in improved access by Member States' tax administrations to the data of the San Marino authorities. The competent authorities of the Member States will be able to correctly and unambiguously identify the taxpayers concerned and will be able to enforce the application of tax laws in cross-border situations. They will also be able to examine taxpayers' actions in cases where tax evasion is suspicion. And the agreement will also allow Member States to avoid further unnecessary investigations. It should be noted that the agreement is fully in line with OECD standards. The information exchanged will thus cover not only income such as interest and dividends, but also the status of accounts and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. I believe that this agreement will also have a positive impact on taxing profits where they are generated.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The EU and San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information on 8 December 2015 in order to improve international cooperation in the tax area and compliance. Under the agreement, from 2017, the EU and San Marino will be openly exchanged data on residents' financial accounts.  The purpose of the agreement is, however, to resolve situations where the taxpayer tries to conceal capital in the form of income or property for which it has not paid tax. As a result of that agreement, tax administrations in the Member States and in San Marino will be able to correctly and unambiguously determine the relevant taxpayers, manage and enforce national tax legislation in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and ensure that no unnecessary further investigations occur.  The agreement represents an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and builds on the 2004 agreement that made San Marino implement measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive on taxation of savings income.  For the sake of the above, I voted in plenary.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ Fair taxation and the fight against tax evasion is a topical topic not only in the Member States, but also at EU level. However, cooperation in this area with third countries is essential, especially in areas such as the exchange of information between tax authorities.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. On 8 December 2015, the European Union and San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts aimed at improving tax cooperation and the performance of tax obligations at international level. This agreement is an important step in its ongoing efforts to impose tough measures against tax fraud and evasion and improves the 2004 agreement that ensured San Marino applied measures such as those of the EU Savings Interest Taxation Directive. Under the new agreement, starting in 2017, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on their residents' financial accounts. The aim is to tackle situations where the taxpayer wishes to conceal capital representing income or assets for which no tax has been paid, and I have therefore supported the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ To ensure that San Marino applies the equivalent measures provided for in the EU Savings Interest Income Taxation Directive, back in 2004, a contract was signed between the EU and San Marino. The Commission then endorsed on 17 June 2011 a recommendation to start negotiations with San Marino, which in December 2014 resulted in an enhanced EU legal framework amending the DAC2 Administrative Cooperation Directive and promoting the exchange of information on financial accounts, which was also recommended under OECD global standards. The agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts was signed on 8 December 2015, with the aim of improving tax cooperation and the performance of tax obligations at international level. This agreement is crucial in the fight against tax fraud and evasion. The new agreement, due to come into force in 2017, will allow for the automatic exchange of information on residents' financial accounts between the EU and San Marino to prevent concealment of assets and income on which no tax has been paid. Thus, all parties involved will be able not only to establish the identity of the taxpayers concerned, but also to apply their tax legislation in cross-border situations. Therefore, I fully support and accept this report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino on measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments.  A great deal has been done in the past to combat tax fraud, and we still have a lot of work to do. In particular, in the area of data exchanges between countries. The AGREEMENT between the EU and San Marino brings about the upgrading of the 2004 agreement and will mean enhanced measures against tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it promotes more transparency in the taxation of savings income. Our support is also based on the fact that San Marino is considered an attractive destination for large-income accounts, who transfer their accounts there to avoid taxing their wealth.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Republic of San Marino is a well-known tax haven and therefore the exchange of tax information serves international tax cooperation and compliance with the relevant provisions.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the signing of an amendment to Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino. I welcome the new agreement, as it is an important step in the fight against tax avoidance and fraud by ensuring that the Republic of San Marino applies measures in accordance with the latest EU directives in the area of taxation of interest income from savings. This agreement is exemplary in that it facilitates international tax cooperation, thereby reducing the number of individuals and companies seeking to conceal capital embodying income or wealth for which the tax has not been paid. The European Parliament, including the TAXE and TAX2 committees, has made great efforts to establish a fair tax system. The above Convention contributes to this by ensuring automatic exchange of information between tax authorities.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has lately set out to effectively combat the phenomenon of tax evasion. In this respect, the EU has concluded a number of tax cooperation agreements with third countries that are usually used as 'tax havens' to avoid fair taxation of income. One of these states is San Marino, which has always had very good cooperation with the European institutions. The Commission document covered by the current report updates administrative cooperation between the two parties, allowing for the automatic exchange of account information in line with OECD global standards of 2014. That information shall cover, in addition to interest and dividends, the balances of accounts and income from the sale of financial assets. The agreement is due to enter into force from 2017, but the parties have agreed to provisional entry into force from 1 January 2016. It is therefore necessary to adopt this document without delay, which allows for the rapid ratification of the agreement and the reduction of the current transitional phase.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement, which aims to ensure that the Republic of San Marino implements enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework, updated in December 2014 (modifying the Administrative Cooperation Directive, "DCA2"), and respects the automatic exchange of financial account information recommended by the 2014 OECD Global Standards.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Equal treatment before the law is a topic I have always cared about. This is why I voted in favour of the EU-San Marino agreement to improve international tax cooperation and compliance and to fight tax fraud and tax evasion. This will allow the EU and San Marino to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents from 2017 onwards. I hope that this measure will contribute to a more equal treatment of citizens, create a culture of tax compliance, avoid unnecessary bureaucratic and time-consuming investigations, and permit tax incomes saved by these measures to be invested in job creation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. On 8 December 2015, the European Union and San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts aimed at improving tax cooperation and the performance of tax obligations at international level. The enlarged agreement will allow San Marino to apply enhanced measures equivalent to the EU legal framework that are in line with the procedures for automatically exchanging information on financial accounts promoted under the OECD's 2014 global standards.  In accordance with these standards, the aim of the additional provisions is to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income, such as interest rates and dividends, but also to account balances and revenues from the sale of financial assets. As a result of this new agreement, tax administrations in the Member States and San Marino will be able to accurately and unequivocally identify the taxpayers in question, apply and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and avoid unnecessary additional investigations. Accordingly, I fully support the complement of the agreement and Rapporteur Van Nieuwenhuizen's efforts to conclude and ratify the agreement as soon as possible to make the transition period as short as possible.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino on measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, I supported, as I believe it is right to support the transparency of capital in the form of income or assets.  Under the agreement, from 2017, the EU and San Marino will be subject to an automatic exchange of information on residents' financial accounts.  The aim is to resolve situations where the taxpayer tries to conceal capital in the form of income or property for which it has not paid tax.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which establishes an agreement between the Union and San Marino establishing a cooperation framework for the exchange of convergent tax information with which it already operates between member countries. This Agreement relates only to interest taxes received by savers as creditors. The Agreement moves forward to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion and facilitate transparency.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to validate the agreement signed on 8 December 2015 between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. The text provides that the European Union and the Republic of San Marino will automatically exchange information on the accounts of their respective residents from 2017.  However, the agreement received early application on 1 January 2016. The aim is always to deal with "ordinary" tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation. In accordance with OECD standards, the agreement provides that the information exchanged relates not only to savings income (interest and dividends), but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.  I therefore vote for this text in the logic of previous votes on tax transparency.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 December 2015, the European Union and the Republic of San Marino signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and updates the 2004 agreement to ensure that the Republic of San Marino applies measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings interest income. Under the new agreement, an automatic exchange of information between the EU and the Republic of San Marino on the financial accounts of each other's residents will be established from 2017 onwards. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive because I welcome the signature of this agreement between the European Union and San Marino. It is a step towards more cooperation on exchange of information on the financial accounts of residents.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-San Marino agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The EU and San Marino signed an agreement in December 2015 to restrict tax fraud and tax evasion by automatically exchanging information on residents’ income, such as interests and dividends, account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.  The agreement implies stricter measures to be applied by San Marino, equal to those applied within the EU since March 2014, and it complies with the 2014 Global Standard on the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the OECD.  This agreement will work in the direction of increased financial transparency with the aim of preventing EU citizens from concealing money in bank accounts from the tax services and this is the reason why I voted in favour of it.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about an Agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This Agreement represents an important step in the fight against tax evasion and evasion, as well as updating the 2004 Agreement. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts as this agreement will bring greater transparency to tax issues between the EU and San Marino.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The agreement signed this year on the automatic exchange of account and financial interest information, which aims to improve international tax cooperation and compliance, represents an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. Under the new agreement, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each's residents from 2017. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide his sources of untaxed financial income. The agreement aims to ensure that San Marino applies measures that are equivalent to the legal framework of the European Union and the OECD.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This agreement, which updates the existing 2004 agreement, is intended to provide automatic information exchange between the EU and San Marino. Cooperation in tax matters aims to apply tax law across borders, to identify tax obligations correctly and beyond doubt and to simplify the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion – on behalf of the European Union – of the protocol of amendment to the agreement between the European Community and the Republic of San Marino on rules equivalent to those of Council Directive 2003/48/EC in the field of taxation of savings income. I call for the restoration of banking and tax secrecy. There should be no suspect access to bank and tax data. This also applies to the intergovernmental exchange of tax data. However, the exchange of tax data under the agreement is intended to enable the authorities to examine the likelihood of tax evasion. This puts citizens and taxpayers under general suspicion and violates their freedoms.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – The EU and San Marino signed, at the end of last year 2015, the agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, with the aim of improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax rules at international level. I voted on the EP report on this agreement, which is an important step in the current efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion, and it updates the 2004 agreement, which ensures that the Republic of San Marino applies measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and San Marino have signed an agreement for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. This is the third in a package of five agreements, covering Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Andorra and Monaco. Although these agreements are being improved, they are still a long way from actually resolving most of the problems that exist with all these countries.  On the basis of this agreement, from 2016, the EU and San Marino will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, in order to increase efforts to combat fraud, avoidance and tax evasion, which see San Marino as one of the most sensitive countries in these respects. The agreement certainly contains improvements compared with the current situation, but it is also true that a more complete and in-depth agreement could and should have been seeking, as this still leaves a number of regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented. That is why I abstained.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the Agreement between the European Union and San Marino. On this basis, the European Union will exchange information with San Marino on the financial accounts of the population. The main purpose was not only to try to eliminate cases where people were trying to hide their income and assets, but also to bring automated exchanges into line with OECD requirements. I think both objectives are correct. On the one hand, it is necessary to prevent cases of tax avoidance by abusing another country's system, but on the other hand, by aligning requests with OECD standards, we will avoid possible problems arising from the application of two different systems. This agreement is not unique; I supported all these agreements, and I gave my vote to this one, too.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a Council decision, as I believe that the agreement will ensure that San Marino implements enhanced measures to combat tax fraud.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia's accession report to the Convention of 26 July 1995 on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities introduced a simplified method for croatia's accession to conventions and protocols concluded by Member States on the basis of Article 34 TFEI. Thanks to this agreement, the date on which the conventions will enter into force for Croatia has been set. I voted in favour of allowing croatian legislation to be harmonised within the European legal framework.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, with Croatia's accession to that Convention, the European Union's financial resources invested in the country are better protected against irregularities and potential fraud. The Convention on the Protection of the Interests of the Union provides for the inclusion in national criminal law of offences against resources and investments made by the EU in that country. This is why the accession agreement involves better use of public resources, their defence and criminal prosecution in the event of possible fraud within the borders of the State of Croatia, forcing national authorities to pursue any type of crime in this area. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote of the report on Croatia's accession to the conventions on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities. Indeed, if I support measures to protect the EU's financial interests, I am opposed to the eu's enlargement policy.  Therefore, I could not support this text.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as it is a positive fact to recommend a Council decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention for the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, but at the same time it is necessary to immediately reopen negotiations on the Directive on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities in order to effectively tackle fraud against the European Union budget.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a report by the LIBE Committee which recommends that Parliament approve a decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its Protocols. Although I and my colleagues in the National Front are opposed to the logic of permanent enlargement, I abstained considering that this is the protection of the financial interests of the European Union and therefore also of French taxpayers.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency I would like to confirm I voted against this report. I do not believe that the unelected officials of the European Union should have to power to interfere in a sovereign nation’s financial interests. The financial interests should be protected by the elected members of a country’s national parliament.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the protection of the European Communities' financial interests. The 2011 Treaty on the Accession of the Republic of Croatia established a simplified framework for croatia's accession to the conventions concluded by eu Member States. To this end, the Council will take a decision and set the date on which these Conventions will enter into force for Croatia, as well as any harmonisation of those Conventions necessary for the accession of a new Member State.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The LIBE Committee recommends that Parliament approve a Council decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its protocols: I did not object to it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this resolution which supports the Commission's proposal for the Council to set a date for Croatia to enter into force of conventions on the protection of the Union's financial interests.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Zdechovský report on Croatia's accession to the conventions on the protection of the European Communities' financial interests. This is a technical measure which merely approves a recommendation from the Commission to the Council. Although the Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia of 2011 provides for automatic accession of the Balkan State to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 4 TEU, a Council decision is necessary to establish the date of entry into force of these conventions.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission Recommendation to the Council on Croatia's accession to this international treaty.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its protocols and this accession has been recommended by Parliament's LIBE Committee. I remain strongly opposed to the permanent enlargement of the EU, but this is the protection of the EU's financial interests, so the French taxpayers are, which is why I abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report being voted on is acceptable and unbleased. It will ensure Croatia's accession to the 1995 Convention on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests, thus guaranteeing the Union from possible fraud, particularly in the use of Eu ropean funds. That is why I voted in favour of the text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduces a simplified system for Croatia's accession to conventions and protocols concluded by Member States on the basis of Article 34 OFA. The Act of Accession provides that Croatia adheres to these conventions and protocols and indicates in Annex I the list of Conventions and Protocols under consideration. This list includes the Convention of 26 July 1995 on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, its Protocol of 27 September 1996, its Protocol of 29 November 1996 and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997, which are intended to establish a common basis for the criminal protection of the EC's financial interests. That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports Croatia's accession to the Convention on the protection of the EC's financial interests. In order to achieve the objectives of the Union, Member States shall consider the fight against crimes detrimental to the financial interests of the European Communities as a matter of common interest. This Convention shall include: a Convention on the protection of the Communities' financial interests to combat, in particular, fraud affecting those interests, as well as a protocol to oppose, in particular, acts of corruption to which officials of the Member States and of the Community are concerned and which cause or threaten to harm the financial interests of the European Communities and a Protocol relating in particular to the liability, confiscation, money laundering and cooperation between Member States and the Commission with a view to protecting the financial interests of the European Communities and personal data relating thereto.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed recommendation setting out the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests, as this is necessary in order to bring it into line with the acquis. The Act of Accession of Croatia to the EU has established a simplified system of its accession to the conventions already concluded by the other Member States. The Commission therefore recommends that the Council set a date for the entry into force of the Convention on the Protection of Financial Interests and its Protocols.  And I, as a member of the European Parliament, who gives his consent in this process of accepting it, I am not opposed to it.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Act of Accession to the European Union of the Republic of Croatia introduces a simplified system of Croatia's accession to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States. The list includes the Convention of 26 July 1995 on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities, its Protocols of 27 September 1996 and 29 November 1996 and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997, all adopted on the basis of Title VI of the Treaty on European Union and aimed at creating a common basis for the criminal protection of the financial interests of the European Communities. Accession is important in order to protect the European Union's financial interests against fraud. Allowing the Member State of Croatia today to accede to this Convention and its protocols is an act due to the Croatian Republic and useful within the framework of European judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The report focuses on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests. If we are opposed in principle to any extension of the scope of accession, in this case it is the protection of the financial interests of the Union and therefore the good use of the contribution of the Member States, such as France. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the framework of the new Member States, integration into the fiscal legislative system and not only is done gradually, in order to allow for a real adaptation to the acquis communautaire and a better knowledge of the new supranational realities. The Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia of 2011 provides for a simplified system for Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States pursuant to Article 34 TEU, and it is the Council which adopts a decision on the determination of the date on which those conventions enter into force with regard to Croatia and the adaptations to be made to those conventions as a result of the accession of the new Member State. They also include the adoption of conventions in Croatian so that these versions are 'equally authentic'. The Council shall act on a recommendation from the Commission, after consulting the European Parliament. The approval of this Commission recommendation, supported by the report, is an important step for the Croatian Republic. For this very reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. With Croatia's accession to the European Union, croatia also enters into the Convention, which has been in force since 1995, which aims to protect the financial interests of the European Union and its taxpayers in cases of fraud. Croatia as a new member of the EU will now become a member of this convention, which is not controversial and is not politically problematic as it protects the EU from fraud mostly in the use of EU funds.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the recommendation for a Council decision on Croatia's accession to the conventions on the protection of the European Communities' financial interests. The 2011 Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduces a simplified system of Croatia's accession to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. The Act provides that Croatia shall accede to the Conventions and Protocols by virtue of the Act of Accession. To this end, the Council shall adopt a decision establishing the date on which these conventions will enter into force for Croatia and shall make to the conventions all the adjustments which have become necessary as a result of the accession of the new Member State (including the adoption of the Croatian language conventions, so that these versions "also authentic"). The Act of Accession lists the conventions and protocols in question aimed at creating a common basis for the criminal protection of the financial interests of the European Communities.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this procedural recommendation. Croatia joined the EU in 2013 and this recommendation concerns the date by which it is to accede to the Convention on the Protection of the European Communities’ Financial Interests. All other EU countries are parties to this Convention already and Croatia already agreed to ratify it when negotiating its membership of the EU. The recommendation is for the date to be set in the Council, where Croatia has a voice on the matter itself.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I support the Commission recommendation for Croatian accession to the Convention on the protection of the financial interests of the Union as soon as possible. Following the accession of Croatia to the European Union almost three years ago, all necessary conventions, international treaties and other laws already in place in the EU should also be adopted by Croatia as soon as possible in order to avoid a legal vacuum.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dossier recommends that the Council adopt a positive decision on Croatia's accession to the 1995 Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its Protocols. It is indeed important for Croatia to sign the Convention, and our delegation voted unanimously in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on the recommendation for a Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 July 1995, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities, in the Protocol of 27 September 1996, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union , the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, the Protocol of 29 November 1996 drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union on the interpretation of the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities by the Court of Justice of the European Communities by preliminary rulings and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997 , drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, in the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. The 2011 Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia established simplified arrangements for Croatia's accession to the Conventions (and Protocols) concluded by the Member States under Article 34 OF THE EES (ex Article K.3 EES).

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the report establishing a Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 July 1995, the Protocol of 27 September 1996, the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, the Protocol of 29 November 1996, the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997 and the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. It is understood that Croatia's accession was essential for its functioning as a Member State of the European Union. That is why I consider this to be a positive move and I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this measure because I believe it is appropriate to introduce a simplified system of Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. Such an act will be an important step forward for Croatia, which will once again be determined to espouse the EU's common principles, in particular accession to the Convention on the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia, the last country to join the EU, is slowly keeping up with all the necessary requirements. The bulk was done as early as 1 July, when the EU welcomed its 28 Member State, but there are still some details to be finaled, with which we can only agree. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of its accession procedure, Croatia, as a Member State of the Union, has become part of a set of conventions and protocols which are part of the Community legal building. These include this Convention, an integral but revised part of European instruments for the protection of their financial interests. Its entry into force, however, did not take place by the act of adentry, depending on before a Council decision, after consulting this Parliament. In this sense, Parliament is given parliament's consent to its validity also in Croatia, as proposed by the European Commission.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia's Act of Accession to the European Union in 2011 makes it possible to simplify its accession to conventions and protocols concluded between Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty. In this respect, I welcome Croatia's desire to become a contracting party to the Treaties on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of Croatia acceding to these conventions and protocols with immediate effect, marking the next step to further adherence within the European framework.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the proposal is to adopt a decision on Croatia's accession to the 1995 Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its Protocols. The conditions for Croatia's accession to the European Union have introduced a simplified method for Croatia's accession to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 TEU. I welcome the decision taken by the Council to determine the date of entry into force for Croatia of these conventions and protocols, but also to facilitate the application of amendments necessary for the accession of the new Member State.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, with Croatia's accession to that Convention, the European Union's financial resources invested in the country are better protected against irregularities and potential fraud. The Convention on the Protection of the Interests of the Union provides for the inclusion in national criminal law of offences against the resources and investments made by the EU in that country. This is why the accession agreement involves better use of public resources, their defence and criminal prosecution in the event of possible fraud within the borders of the State of Croatia, forcing national authorities to pursue any type of crime in this area. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for croatia's accession to the conventions concluded by the Member States. Annex I to the Act of Accession lists the conventions and protocols concerned. This list shall include the Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests of 26 July 1995, its Protocols of 27 September 1996 and 29 November 1996 and its second Protocol of 19 June 1997, adopted in accordance with Title VI of the EC Treaty, for the purpose of creating a common basis for the criminal protection of ec financial interests. However, in order for Croatia to actually be allowed to join this Convention, Parliament must approve the Commission's proposal. With today's vote, the EP has agreed to the Commission's proposal.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests and its Protocols aim at establishing a common legal framework for the protection of the Communities' financial interests under criminal law. Abuses affecting both expenditure and income should be subject to effective, proportionate and dissuasive criminal sanctions, including custodial sentences, which may give rise to extradition. Since I support the Position of the European Commission, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report focuses on the consultation of Parliament on a proposed recommendation for a Council Decision on Croatia’s accession to the Convention on the protection of the European Communities’ Financial Interests. I voted in favour of this report as it is a positive step forward in tackling fraud against the budget of the European Union.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report gives the European Parliament the approval of Croatia's accession to the conventions on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities. Considering that this accession follows Croatia's entry into the European Union on 1 July 2013, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By my vote, I support Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States to establish a common basis for ensuring the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities through criminal law. It is normal for the latter to join the European Union to take part in the conventions for which the European Union is a party.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In croatia's accession treaty to the EU, Member States introduced a simplified accession system for Croatia's accession to easier conventions and protocols under Article 34 TEU. In order to be effective, the Council should set the date of entry into force of these Conventions and take all necessary measures required by the Conventions for the accession of the new Member State (such as a certified translation of the Conventions into Croatian). The Council should act on a proposal from the Commission after consulting the European Parliament. The report endorses the European Commission's proposal. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. As I am opposed to a continuous enlargement of the European Union, and without wanting to target Croatia in particular, I cannot support Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its protocols. Nevertheless, the fact that the text is intended to protect the financial interests of the EU and therefore of my country France, I have decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported tomasz Zdechowski's report on Croatia's accession to the Convention for the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests. The Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests and its Protocols aim to establish a common legal basis for criminal law to protect the European Communities' financial interests. Fraud affecting both revenue and expenditure must be punishable by effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions, including imprisonment, which may lead to extradition. The Convention was adopted on 26 July 1995 and entered into force on 17 October 2002.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. It is now necessary for the Council to take a decision determining the date on which these conventions enter into force in Croatia. A recommendation that I agree with and i voted in favour of.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the EU Treaty. The Act of Accession determines Croatia's accession to those conventions and protocols. This report deals with Croatia's accession to the Convention on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union, a simple process, but which is integrated into this process of European capitalist integration. An integration that has reapersed the sovereignty of states and peoples for the benefit of the great powers and major economic groups. In counter to the reality of the vast majority of Member States, Croatia has subjected eu integration to the popular vote. An expression contradictory to the act of sovereignty that validated it, which we respect and accept. The report is essentially a consequence of the Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, which is why we abstained.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for a decision on Croatia's accession to the Conventions on the Protection of the European Commission's Financial Interests. These Conventions ensure the creation of a common legal basis for the criminal protection of the European Community's financial interests in Croatia. I believe that this is a fundamental step towards Croatia's integration into the European Union.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I had no objections.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the report on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 July 1995 on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc. I am against Croatia's accession to the Convention for the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests and I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Report relates to a consultation of Parliament on a proposed recommendation for a Council Decision on Croatia’s accession to the Convention on the protection of the European Communities’ Financial Interests (also known as ‘the PIF Convention’). As it is a consultation and the accession of Croatia to the PIF Convention is entirely without controversy, I voted in favour of the approval of the recommendation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we gave our consent to the Commission recommendation to the Council to allow Croatia to adhere to the Convention on the protection of the European Communities’ financial interests. The Act of 2011 concerning the conditions of accession of Croatia to the European Union simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States: it is no longer necessary to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols. The Council, in order to take a decision determining the date on which this Convention will enter into force in relation to Croatia and making all the adjustments required by reason of the accession of this new Member State to this Convention, will act on a recommendation by the Commission, after consulting the European Parliament. The LIBE Committee recommended that the European Parliament give its consent to the Commission recommendation. As Fidesz-EPP we therefore voted in favour.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Annex I to the Act of Accession lists the conventions and protocols concerned. This list shall include the Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests of 26 July 1995, its Protocols of 27 September 1996 and 29 November 1996 and its second Protocol of 19 June 1997, adopted in accordance with Title VI of the EC Treaty, for the purpose of creating a common basis for the criminal protection of ec financial interests. The Convention and its Protocols of 27 September 1996 and 29 November 1996 entered into force on 17 October 2002, following the strengthening of the then 15 Member States, and the Protocol of 19 June 1997 entered into force on 19 May 2009, following the strengthening of the then 27 Member States. In order to make the adjustments necessary for croatia's accession to the abovementioned Convention and its Protocols in accordance with Article 3(5) of the Act of Accession, no Commission recommendation is required. The Commission proposes that the Council take a decision setting out the date of entry into force of these Conventions for Croatia. In agreement with the rapporteur, I therefore propose that the Commission's recommendation be adopted.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this draft resolution as there is no need to make any changes to the existing Treaties due to Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the recommendation for a Council decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 July 1995, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities, the Protocol of 27 September 1996, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, of the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. , the Protocol of 29 November 1996 concluded on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union concerning the interpretation, as a preliminary ruling, by the Court of Justice of the European Communities of the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, of the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. In July 2013, the Croatian Republic was the twenty-eighth and last country, for the time being, to join the European Union, and the Act of Accession introduces a simplified system for extending conventions and protocols to Croatia. I therefore hope that the Council will quickly adopt a decision setting the time taken for croatia to enter into force of these acts, as indicated in the Commission's recommendation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests. This accession is a logical consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU and, as such, fully welcome.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. As a result of Croatia's accession to the Union, all the adjustments necessary for the new Member State as a result must be made. I welcome the fact that it protects the Union's financial interests.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report welcoming Croatia’s accession to the Convention on the protection of the financial interests of the Union (PIF). However, I also call for the immediate re-starting of negotiations on the PIF Directive to properly tackle fraud and abuse in the context of the EU budget.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Commission Recommendation to the Council on Croatia's accession to this international treaty.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia established simplified arrangements for Croatia's accession to the Conventions (and Protocols) concluded by the Member States. The report referred to shall be procedural in that it shall specify the date on which those Conventions for Croatia enter into force and shall make all adjustments to those Conventions necessary as a result of the accession of the new Member State (and which, in any event, shall include the adoption of the Conventions in croatian, so that these language versions are 'equally authentic'). We therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because the 2011 Accession Treaty of the Republic of Croatia has introduced a simplified system for the accession of Croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis that it provides for Croatia to accede to these conventions and protocols by virtue of the Act of Accession. I agree with the report and recommend approving this Commission recommendation.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. Croatia has been a member of the European Union since 2013. For the sake of consistency, it seems logical to me that it adheres to all the conventions and protocols concluded by the other Member States. In reality, this text is merely a formality that allows, in particular, the translation of conventions into the Croatian language. That is why there is no reason to object.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report regarding the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the protection of the financial interests of the Union, which will set up a common base for the criminal—law protection of the European Communities’ financial interests.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, as this accepts the recommendation of the European Commission. Accordingly, I consider that the Commission's recommendation, which calls on the Council to set through a decision the date of entry into force of the conventions for Croatia, is justified and at the same time no specific adjustments have to be made as a result of Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its protocols.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities marks a further demonstration of the logic of permanent enlargement of the European Union. Nevertheless, it turns out that this text is in line with the protection of the financial interests of the European Union, which therefore implies the fate of French taxpayers.   Hence my abstention vote on this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague To tom Zdechovsk's report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. Croatia's accession to the European Union facilitates its adherence to the conventions and protocols concluded by the other Member States. I agree with this Council decision so that these conventions will come into force for Croatia while making the necessary adjustments, such as translation into the Croatian language.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which simply endorsed the fact that Croatia, the new Member State of the European Union, adheres to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, of which all the other countries of the European Union are members.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests deals, inter alia, with the examination of fraud and irregularities in the implementation of the Union budget. Since the prosecution of such cases is of enormous importance, I agree.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report deals with some procedural aspects of the accession of Croatia to the conventions concluded by the Member States. In fact, the 2011 Accession Treaty of the Republic of Croatia provides a simplified system for the accession of this country to these conventions. Consequently, the Commission recommends that it will be for the Council to determine the date on which these conventions shall enter into force for Croatia and to make the necessary adjustments. Given this simplified system and the right of a sovereign State to accede to an international convention, I voted in favour.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – The 2011 Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduces a simplified system of Croatia's accession to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 (ex Article K.3) of the Treaty on European Union. The aim is to encourage the adoption of sanctions to combat fraud in the field of expenditure and revenue which could undermine the Community's financial interests. Member States are required to take the necessary measures to ensure that such conduct is liable to effective criminal sanctions and that the managers of undertakings are declared criminally liable for having damaged the financial interests of the Community. I believe that Croatia's accession to the conventions on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities fully reflects the spirit and commitment of the EU in this field, and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on Croatia's accession to the conventions on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities. Without wanting to specifically target Croatia, I am opposed to the logic of the systematic and permanent enlargement of the European Union. However, since this is the protection of the financial interests of the European Union (and therefore also of French taxpayers), I have chosen to abstain.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of THE EU's Financial Interests. Certainly, it is in the interests of French taxpayers. But it is based on the logic of EU enlargement that I am fighting.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, with Croatia's accession to that Convention, the European Union's financial resources invested in the country are better protected against irregularities and potential fraud. The Convention on the Protection of the Interests of the Union provides for the inclusion in national criminal law of offences against the resources and investments made by the EU in that country. This is why the accession agreement involves better use of public resources, their defence and criminal prosecution in the event of possible fraud within the borders of the State of Croatia, forcing national authorities to pursue any type of crime in this area. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of Financial Interests of the European Communities because it is part of the Accession Treaty of the Republic of Croatia in which a simplified system for Croatia's accession to all conventions (and protocols) concluded by other Member States is defined. The List of Conventions and Protocols also includes the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. Financial interests include all financial operations, loans and loans, financial elements of public procurement and all forms of passive and active corruption.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 More than four years ago Croatia became the 28th member of the European Union. Since then, a number of different agreements, protocols and conventions have required synchronise with the extended community. The 2011 Croatian Act of Accession introduced a simplified system that helps Croatia and the EU to further adapt the remaining agreements to the new numerical reality. In particular, in this case, the positive vote will help to harmonise the EU's financial mechanisms and relevant policies more closely. Croatia's accession to the conventions on the protection of the European Community's financial interests is of this very nature, so that it was logical to fully support it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia provides in a simplified manner that Croatia accedes to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 OF THE WEU, the list of which is annexed to the Accession Treaty. With this resolution, the EP endorses the Commission's recommendation that the Council adopt a decision setting a date for the entry into force of these conventions for Croatia.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Report on the recommendation for a Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 July 1995, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities, in the Protocol of 27 September 1996, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union , the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, the Protocol of 29 November 1996 drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union on the interpretation of the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities by the Court of Justice of the European Communities by preliminary rulings and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997 , drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, in the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin abstained on this vote. The LIBE Commission recommends that Parliament approve a decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its protocols. Basically, we are opposed to the logic of the permanent enlargement of the European Union. But, since this is about protecting the financial interests of the European Union (and therefore also of French taxpayers), we can abstain.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 July 1995 on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities. This Convention aims to protect the financial interests of the European Union and its taxpayers criminally, provides a harmonised legal definition of fraud and requires their signatories to adopt criminal sanctions in the event of fraud. Croatia, in accordance with Article 3(4) of the Act of Accession 12, accedes to the conventions and protocols concluded between the Member States listed in Annex I to that Act, which include the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
