text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the commission's recommendation to fix the date of entry into force of this Convention for Croatia, as well as to make any adjustments to these conventions necessary for the accession of a new Member State.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Following its accession to the EU, the aim here is to approve Croatia's participation in the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities (and related Protocols), namely the fight against fraud. However, since the Lisbon Treaty, there is no longer a process for ratification of national parliaments on these issues and Parliament is simply consulted; Council is not required to follow its decision.  I am opposed to the enlargement of the Union and the Lisbon Treaty, but I defend the sovereign choice of a State to participate in a European Convention, particularly on the fight against fraud. Under these conditions, I vote for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the logic of enlargement, but it must be acknowledged that Croatia's accession to this convention defends the financial interests of the EU, and consequently those of the French. As a result I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A Convention (and protocols which have been adopted over the years) has been in force since 1995 to protect the financial interests of the European Union in criminal law. This is the introduction of legal definitions and sanctions applicable to cases of fraud of the EU's financial interests. As Croatia is a Member State of the European Union, it is essential that you adhere to that Convention and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is important that Croatia, the newest Member State, is included in existing conventions and agreements and is an equal partner in our Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Croatia’s accession to the Convention on the protection of the European Communities’ Financial Interests (PIF) since it is important to call for the immediate re-starting of negotiations on the PIF Directive to properly tackle fraud against the budget of the European Union

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Republic of Croatia undertook in the Treaty of Accession to accede to all conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States under Article 34 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. A decision shall be adopted by the Council, after consulting Parliament, on the date of entry into force of accession and on the necessary adaptations to the Conventions. The Commission proposed to the Council the entry into force of the Convention of 26 July 1995 on the protection of the European Communities' financial interests, its Protocols of 27 September 1996 and 29 November 1996 and its second Protocol of 19 June 1997 with regard to Croatia. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that the Commission's proposal be approved by Parliament. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its protocols following the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. We abstain on this vote because we are opposed to the logic of permanent enlargement of the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The LIBE Commission recommends that Parliament approve a decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and its protocols. Without wanting to specifically target Croatia, I am opposed to the logic of the permanent enlargement of the European Union. But since this is about protecting the financial interests of the European Union (and therefore also of French taxpayers), I have favoured abstention.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduces a simplified system of Croatia's accession to conventions concluded by Member States under Article 34 (ex Article K.3) of the Treaty on European Union. I voted in favour of the Council adopting a decision establishing the date on which these conventions enter into force for Croatia and making all the necessary adjustments to the conventions as a result of the accession of the new Member State.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 1995 a convention was put into place that seeks to protect, under criminal law, the financial interests of the European Union and its taxpayers. The Accession Treaty of Croatia in 2011 brought in an easier system for the accession of Croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States, thus Croatia accedes to these conventions and protocols by virtue of the Act of Accession, just leaving the Council to adopt a decision in order to determine a date on which the conventions and protocols should enter into force. I voted for this report on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the protection of the financial interests of the Union.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a purely formal act that results in the correction of a technical error. I would therefore have voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Accession is the result of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is merely a procedural vote allowing Croatia to join the EC’s financial interests. We are against the EC creating financial interests for Member States, therefore we voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Consider that through the Act of Accession, Croatia has the opportunity to benefit from a facilitated regime for accession to conventions and protocols concluded by Member States under Article 34 TEU. In order for the scheme to become operational, the Council must adopt an act on a recommendation from the Commission and after consulting Parliament. I think that this act should be adopted as soon as possible and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the rapporteur's proposal because it allows for a faster unification of the acquis between the European Union and Croatia.  With croatian accession to the EEZ, the simplified system of accession of Croatia to the Conventions (and Protocols) concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 TEU entered into force. The proposal provides for a simpler adjustment procedure as a result of Croatia's accession to the Convention and its Protocols.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the report presented and fully support it. The report pointed out that Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of financial interests of the European Communities is based on the Treaty on Croatia's accession to the EU, and that Croatia does not need to make additional adjustments to join the Convention. I believe that the European Parliament should approve the Commission's recommendation on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. The consequence of Croatia's accession to this Convention will be greater success in the fight against expenditure and income fraud, with a clear distinction between active and passive corruption of officials. Croatia's accession to the Convention and its application in our country could greatly contribute to the fight against corruption. I am convinced that the application of the Convention in Croatia will improve the protection of the financial interests of the Republic of Croatia, and the level of security of Croatian taxpayers will increase. In this I see the great importance of Croatia joining the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, and I call on Parliament to approve the Commission's report and recommendation.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In principle, I am opposed to any enlargement of the European Union. But this text deals with the protection of the financial interests of the EU, and therefore also the financial interests of French taxpayers. In these circumstances, I do not want to give my consent or oppose myself, so I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. Since 1995 there has been a Convention to protect, in accordance with criminal law, the financial interests of the EU and its taxpayers. EU countries must impose effective, proportionate and dissuasive criminal penalties for fraud that adversely affects the EU's financial interests.  The Convention and its protocols can be signed by all countries joining the EU. Given that Croatia joined the EU on 1 July 2013 and thus gained full member status, I welcome Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities with a view to increasing transparency in the use of public funds, both at European and national level.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the EU Treaty. The Act of Accession determines Croatia's accession to these conventions and protocols. This report deals with Croatia's accession to the Convention on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union, a simple process, but which is integrated into this process of European capitalist integration. An integration that has reapersed the sovereignty of states and peoples for the benefit of the great powers and major economic groups. In counter to the reality of the vast majority of Member States, Croatia has subjected eu integration to the popular vote. An expression contradictory to the act of sovereignty that validated it, which we respect and accept. The report is essentially a consequence of the Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, which is why we abstained.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support my colleague Tomáš Zdechovski's report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. The Act on the Conditions of Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union introduced a simpler system for Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols signed by the Member States under Article 34 of the UEU (former Article K.3 of the UEU). Article 3(4) and 5 of the aforementioned Act provides for Croatia to accede to those conventions and protocols under the Accession Act.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a socialist democrat, European Union enlargement and integration with our European neighbours remains a strong and credible EU policy with the rule of law at its centre. The progression of European integration, the peace and prosperity that it has given, must not distance us from the fundamental principles on which the process is based and should not be overshadowed by the recent economic difficulties experienced by Member States. The accession of Croatia to the Convention will allow Croatia to experience full EU membership and further protect the European Communities’ financial interests.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Republic of Croatia, under the 2011 Act of Accession, will adhere to conventions and protocols concluded by Member States under Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. Article 3(5) of the Act of Accession requires the Council to adopt a decision establishing the date on which those conventions enter into force for Croatia with a view, where appropriate, to making any necessary adjustments on account of the accession of the new Member State. In view of the fact that the conventions and its protocols entered into force before 2011, it was not necessary to make adjustments. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Convention for the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities ensures that criminal law contributes effectively to the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities and combats fraud and corruption affecting Community revenue and expenditure. The protection of the European Union's financial interests is a key element of the Union's political agenda in order to consolidate and strengthen citizens' trust and ensure the proper use of their money. There is a need at Union level to investigate cases of fraud and irregularities in the implementation of the Union budget, to take measures to prevent such cases and to protect the financial interests of the Union in general. For this reason, I am in favour of the draft recommendation for the Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention for the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities of 26 July 1995, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union, the Protocol to the Convention for the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities and other documents.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests and its Protocols aim at establishing a common legal framework for the protection of the Communities' financial interests under criminal law. Abuses affecting both expenditure and income should be subject to effective, proportionate and dissuasive criminal sanctions, including custodial sentences, which may give rise to extradition. That Convention was adopted on 26 July 1995 and entered into force on 17 October 2002. Croatia has acceded to this Convention and its Protocols under the Act of Accession. The Council should take a decision with a view to setting a date within which this Convention should enter into force in respect of Croatia. In the light of the above, the Commission recommends that the Council decide on croatia's accession to the Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests and its Protocols. That is why I supported this report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. The draft resolution formalises Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests. Croatia's accession to this Convention and its Protocols is a precursor to Croatia's accession to the EU. The aim of the Convention is to create a common criminal basis that protects the Union's financial interests. Fraud must be sanctioned by effective, proportionate and therefore dissuasive penalties, which include custodial sentences up to extradition. I am therefore voting in favour of this draft.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduces a simplified system for Croatia's accession to conventions and protocols concluded by Member States on the basis of Article 34 OFA. The Act of Accession provides that Croatia adheres to these conventions and protocols by indicating in Annex I the list of Conventions and Protocols under consideration. This list includes the Convention of 26 July 1995 on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, its Protocol of 27 September 1996, its Protocol of 29 November 1996 and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997, which are intended to establish a common basis for the criminal protection of the EC's financial interests. That's why I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The accession act of the Republic of Croatia has simplified its adherence to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the EU Treaty (former Article K.3 of the EU Treaty). To this end, the Council takes a decision setting the date of entry into force of these conventions with regard to Croatia and makes all the adjustments made necessary by the accession of the new Member State (including, at a minimum, the adoption of the Croatian-language conventions, so that these versions can "also be authentic").  The Council acts on the Commission's recommendation, after consultation with the European Parliament. The report endorses the Commission's recommendation. The European Parliament gave its approval this afternoon.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, like my colleagues from the Greens/European Free Alliance, I agree that Croatia needs to accede to the Convention on the protection of the European Communities' financial interests. This step should help to combat fraud in Croatia itself, and it responds to the protection of the European Union's own financial interests. I am pleased that this vote has shown that a similar scale is being felt by the majority of other Members of the European Parliament.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty of Accession to the European Union by the Republic of Croatia in 2011 introduced a simplified system for the accession of that country to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession provides that Croatia accesses those conventions and protocols under the Act of Accession. With regard to this specific Convention, the Commission recommends that the Council determine the date on which this Convention (and its Protocols) enters into force for Croatia. In this sense, and because it is a markedly technical procedure, I voted in favour of this proposal by the European Commission.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for Croatia's accession to the Convention on the Protection of THE EU's Financial Interests. The Convention, signed in 1995 and entered into force in 2002, stipulates that EU countries must introduce effective, proportionate and deterrent criminal sanctions to combat fraud that harms the EU's financial interests. This convention therefore ensures harmonised protection of financial interests in all EU Member States.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission Recommendation to the Council on Croatia's accession to this international treaty.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, with Croatia's accession to that Convention, the European Union's financial resources invested in the country are better protected against irregularities and potential fraud. The Convention on the Protection of the Interests of the Union provides for the inclusion in national criminal law of offences against the resources and investments made by the EU in that country. This is why the accession agreement involves better use of public resources, their defence and criminal prosecution in the event of possible fraud within the borders of the State of Croatia, forcing national authorities to pursue any type of crime in this area. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union of 2011 introduces a simplified system of Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States.  The Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, which entered into force in 2002, aims to create a common legal basis for the protection of financial interests. It provides a harmonised legal definition of fraud and requires signatories to adopt effective, proportionate and dissuasive criminal sanctions to tackle fraud against the EU's financial interests.  I voted in favour of this report because it formalises Croatia's accession to the Convention, following its accession to the European Union.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am joining my Socialist colleagues in welcoming Croatia’s accession to the Convention on the Protection of the European Communities’ Financial interests (or PIF for short), but although this accession is not particularly problematic, I stress the need for negotiations on the PIF Directive to be revised so that it can properly tackle fraud when accessing the budget of the EU.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I agree with the already signed Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests, which establishes a common legal basis for criminal law in the protection of financial interests. Fraud relating to revenue and expenditure must be effectively investigated. Effective, proportionate and dissuasive sentences, including custodial sentences, must be imposed on the basis of the results of the investigation. Since Croatia joined the European Union, I voted in favour of acceding to this convention as well.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed to approve the Commission's recommendation that Croatia accede to the Convention for the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests, as this is the standard procedure that every new Member State must go through. The Convention for the Protection of The European Communities was adopted by the Member States of the European Communities as early as 1995 and is still valid for all countries which are members of the Union. The Convention also includes individual protocols which have been subsequently amended. Member States undertake by this Convention that their criminal laws will ensure the protection of the Financial Interests of the Union, since fraudulent conduct concerning Union revenue and expenditure can be organised by criminal networks operating across countries. It is therefore in the common interest of the Member States to prevent fraud by adopting legislation that discourages potential perpetrators from acting. Fraud sanctions should also not be circumvented by persons who perform management functions in large corporations, as they, too, have criminal responsibility for their decision-making. This is also one of the reasons why I support Croatia joining that basic European legal framework.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2011 Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia implements a simplified system of accession of Croatia to the Conventions (and Protocols) concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the EU Treaty (TEU).  To this end, the Council shall adopt a decision setting the date of entry into force of the Conventions for Croatia and amend them accordingly, as necessary upon accession of a new Member State. Such a decision shall be adopted by the Council on the basis of a recommendation from the Commission and after consulting the EP.  The report in question relates to the accession of Croatia to the Convention on 26 July 1995 on the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests, its Protocol of 27 September 1996 and 29 November 1996 and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997, adopted in accordance with title VI TEU, aimed at establishing a common basis for the criminal justice protection of the EC's financial interests.  In that case, it is not necessary to make the adjustments which would be necessary as a result of croatia's accession to that Convention and its Protocols. I believe that the accession of the Republic of Croatia to those conventions is necessary, which is why I voted in plenary in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The protection of the Community's financial interests by combating fraud is an EU priority. The accession of the eu's youngest Member State will strengthen the EU's capabilities in this area and further deepen European integration.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The 2011 Treaty on the Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for Croatia's accession to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by The Member States under Article 34 of the UEU (previous Article K.3 of the UEU). Article 3(4) and 5 The Act provides for Croatia's accession to these conventions and protocols on the basis of the Accession Act. Article 3(5) of the The Accession Act provides for the Council to take a decision to that end in order to set a date for the entry into force of those conventions for Croatia and for the conventions to be adapted for the accession of the new Member State (which would certainly include the adoption of conventions in The Croatian language so that those versions can be 'equally credible'. The Commission recommends that the Council take a decision to set a date for the entry into force of these conventions for Croatia, so I support the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A simplified system of accession to conventions and protocols previously concluded by Member States was made possible by the Republic of Croatia's 2011 Treaty on Accession to the EU. Article 3(5) of the The Accession Act provides that the Council determines the date of entry of the conventions of strength and the adaptation of those conventions for Croatia. This includes publishing conventions in Croatian.  Parliament accepted the Commission's position that no further adjustments had to be made for Croatia to accede to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities as of 26 July 1995. It is already necessary to determine when this Convention will enter into force in Croatia. Therefore, I accept and approve this report and the Commission's recommendation.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests.  The Act of Accession of Croatia to the Convention provides that Croatia shall accede to conventions and protocols to which the Member States have acceded in the past. It is stipulate that the Council will adopt a decision to set the date of entry into force of the Conventions for Croatia and to amended them accordingly, as necessary when the new Member State joins. The act shall also contain a list of all relevant conventions and protocols.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced simplified arrangements for Croatia's accession to the conventions concluded by the Member States. Article 3 of the Act of Accession provides that the Council shall adopt a decision to fix the date on which those Conventions for Croatia enter into force. As it is a decision by the sovereign State of Croatia to accede to the Convention, we voted in favour of the rapporteur's report which argues that the Commission's recommendation to the Council should be adopted in order to determine the date on which the conventions will enter into force for Croatia.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the Convention for the Protection of the European Communities' Financial Interests, as it is done on the basis of the Croatian Act of Accession. The purpose of the Convention is to protect the financial interests of the taxpayers of the Member States by giving a harmonised legal definition of fraud and by obliging signatories to impose criminal penalties on fraud. Effective, proportionate and dissuasive criminal penalties will in any event be in the interests of Croatian citizens.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia's accession to the European Union in 2013 was a historic moment, which gave a new dimension to the accession process of the Western Balkan countries to the EU. From a technical point of view, the Act of Accession of Croatia has introduced a simplified system for Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States, in order to allow the adoption of conventions in Croatian. These documents include the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities of 26 July 1995, together with the protocols subsequently adopted, with a view to establishing a common basis for protection within the framework of criminal law. In order for those rules to enter into force for Croatia, a Council decision is necessary, as recommended by the Commission. The current document supports this procedural step, which is why I believe that it should be adopted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with the Council's recommendation on Croatia's accession to the 26 July 1995 Convention, based on Article K.3 of the Treaty on the European Union, on the protection of the financial interests of the European Communities, to the Protocol of 27 September 1996, established on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on european Union , the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, the Protocol of 29 November 1996, drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 of the Treaty on the European Union, concerning the interpretation, as a prejudicial, by the European Court of Justice of the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997 , based on Article K.3 of the Treaty on the European Union, to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the financial interests of the Union which protects the financial interests of the EU and its taxpayers by providing a harmonised legal definition of fraud and adopting criminal penalties for fraud. I believe that this will enable the Council to determine the date on which these conventions shall enter into force for Croatia and to make all the necessary adjustments.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The legal standard in modern democracies is that state budgetary resources provide criminal justice protection, i.e. that their illegal appropriation in a certain amount qualifies as a criminal offence. The EU's most important legal instrument in the area of criminal justice protection of its budgetary resources is certainly the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities.  As a member of the Integrity - Transparency, Anticorruption and Organised Crime Intergroup, I am pleased that Croatia has formally acceded to the Convention, which is the backbone of member states' obligations to protect against fraud, corruption, money laundering or criminality of legal entities, which also damage or undermine budgetary resources.  While, like most Member States, Croatian legislation provides for specific crimes to protect the expenditure and revenues of the EU budget and all crimes relevant to anti-EU fraud are required by criminal law, I welcome this Recommendation by the Commission on Croatia's formal accession to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, as this is the only way for all of us to finally tackle all those who see the budget as a means of their personal enrichment.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported croatia's accession to the Convention for the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests, as this is the implementation of the simplified system of accession of Croatia to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 TEU.  Article 3(4) and (5) of that act provides that Croatia is to join these Conventions and Protocols of Accession on the basis of the Act of Accession.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Commission Recommendation to the Council on Croatia's accession to this international treaty.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, in another step to fully integrate Croatia inside the EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. We are generally opposed to the logic of the permanent enlargement of the European Union. But since this is the protection of the financial interests of this European Union (and therefore also of French taxpayers), I choose abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for croatia's accession to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States under Article 34 TSI. In order to make the adjustments necessary for croatia's accession to the abovementioned Convention and its Protocols in accordance with Article 3(5) of the Act of Accession, no Commission recommendation is required. The Commission proposes that the Council take a decision setting out the date of entry into force of these Conventions for Croatia. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive because I agree on the participation of Croatia in the Convention on the protection of the European Communities’ financial interests.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – the 2011 Treaty on the Accession of the Republic of Croatia established a simplified framework for croatia's accession to Article 34 TEU (formerly Article K.3 TEU) on the basis of conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States. Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession provides that Croatia shall accede to those Conventions and Protocols by this Act.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the protection of the financial interests of the Union. Article 3(4) and 3(5) of the 2011 Accession Treaty of the Republic of Croatia provides that Croatia accedes to conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union by virtue of the Act of Accession. Among the conventions and protocols concerned is the Convention on the protection of the European Communities’ financial interests of 26 July 1995, its Protocol of 27 September 1996, its Protocol of 29 November 1996 and the second Protocol of 19 June 1997, all adopted under Title VI of the EU Treaty. The Convention aims at establishing a common base for the criminal-law protection of the European Community’s financial interests. I voted in favour of determining the date on which the Convention shall enter into force for Croatia in line with a simplified system for the accession of Croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a simplified system contained in the 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia, concluded on the basis of Article 34 of the WEA. The same act specifies that the Council adopts a decision in order to determine a date of entry into force of those Conventions. Through this report, the Commission recommends that the Council take a decision to determine the date on which this Convention will enter into force for Croatia. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the Agreement on the protection of the Union's financial interests, because it is important that Croatia, as a new Member State, is fully incorporated into the existing acquis communautaire and thus become an equal partner in the European Union.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession provides that Croatia accesses those conventions and protocols under the Act of Accession. Annex I to the Act of Adeto presents the list of the conventions and protocols concerned, and this report refers in particular to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities of 26 July 1995, its Protocols of 27 September 1996 and 29 November 1996 and the Second Protocol of 19 June 1997 , all adopted under Title VI of the EU Treaty. Despite the garrote that european union's union represents for states, this is a free and sovereign decision of every people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with the report because measures must be taken to prevent and prosecute fraud and to prevent irregularities in the implementation of the Union budget.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Resolution of the European Parliament on the recommendation for a Council decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention pursuant to Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities of 26 July 1995, on the Protocol pursuant to Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities of 27 September 1996 , i have given my assent to the Protocol pursuant to Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union on the interpretation by the Court of Justice of the European Communities of the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities by reference of 29 November 1996 and the Second Protocol pursuant to Article K.3 of the Treaty on European Union to the Convention on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities of 19 June 1997. I am against the enlargement of the EU and all preparatory actions on it. Croatia, however, has already joined, so that its status can be legally completed.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on Croatia's accession to the Conventions on the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities. The Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia in 2011 introduced a simplified system for Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States under the TEU. In practice, the Council shall adopt a decision on the fixing of the date on which these Conventions enter into force with regard to Croatia and the adjustments to be made to those Conventions following the accession of the new Member State, acting on a recommendation from the Commission, after consulting the European Parliament.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that there is currently nothing to prevent Croatia from ifying the Convention for the Protection of the Financial Interests of the European Communities, which will enter into force as soon as possible. As rapporteur for this report, I strongly supported croatia's accession to the Convention as soon as possible. This Convention, together with the successive protocols, aims to protect crimes committed against the Financial Interests of the Union and has increasingly become necessary recently. It is therefore necessary for all acceding States to join it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation recommending that the Council set a date for the entry into force of those conventions for Croatia, which member states have concluded on the basis of Article 34 TEU, in order to further establish a common basis for the criminal law protection of the EU's financial interests.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: –So this is about employment services and further integration of labour markets. The first time I saw this address, I thought, Oh, that's good. Further integration of labour markets in Europe! Well, that means that doctors, German doctors, English doctors, French doctors, as well as nurses from France, England, Germany, are starting to flow into Hungary, and at last there will be no huge shortages in Hungarian health care, we will be able to care for the patients. Then I thought that the labour shortage in hospitality and trade would be over, because they would come from Western Europe to Hungary to wait, and so on. Then I realized that's probably not the case. Then I would ask you not to call it labour market integration if cheap labour only goes from one part of Europe to another, but to call it what it is: colonialism and brain drain.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Employment policy is one of the primary aspects of the European Union's substance, and therefore rationalising the mobility system in parallel with further integration of labour markets is rather welcome. I support it. It is logical that the people of our countries, working in another Member State, should receive similar remuneration and, in general, have the same working conditions as all other employees performing this type of task, regardless of nationality, irrespective of nationality. If we really live in a unified union and the well-being of every country and man depends to a large extent on the rest, there can be no discrimination at all in this regard, and it is to be welcomed that it is included in this report.  The EURES portal has continued to be increasingly active in recent years, helping hundreds of thousands of Europeans to seek work, both in their own Member States and in other Member States. However, I would agree that the existing system needs comprehensive reforms.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – The report calls for strengthening mobility within the EU and for the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment. I consider these goals to be important, but I would add that this can only be done by strengthening cohesion policy and catching up with the poorer countries of the EU. In the current situation, the labour force migrates primarily from the east and south to the richer Member States, and this is not due to the generosity of social benefits, but to the overall wage level in these countries. In Romania, the average net salary is around EUR 400 per month and the salary of a junior teacher is less than EUR 300 per month, while the price of goods and services is at the same level in the western and eastern parts of Europe. In these circumstances, it is impossible to talk about labour market integration or a European labour market. If the process of catching up with poorer Member States is halted, even greater migration could start from here, which could empty the labour market in these countries, which could lead to an unintended distorted situation.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, let us be quite clear that in the United Kingdom the migration issue is not the refugee crisis – 96% of those who come to the UK are economic migrants, whether from the EU or from outside the EU. We now have a massive over-supply of unskilled labour in the United Kingdom. The Bank of England says that, for a 10% increase in immigration, in certain sectors wages are cut by an average of 1.88%. You can bet your bottom euro that it is worse in my constituency in the north-east of England, where we have the highest unemployment in the land. So today’s vote for jobcentres to be forced to advertise across the European Union when there are vacancies for CV matching, etc, will only drive more people to the UK, when of course people are already driven to the UK because English is a global language. So we can forget the emergency brake, because in one fell swoop – in one vote – we have done more damage than that could possibly repair. Yet Labour seem perfectly content to vote in favour of this.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe. It creates a clear obligation for ‘Public Employment Services’ to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track the process of British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The ‘opt-out’ for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is ‘duly justified’. However there is no justification for this term. In any case, this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The serious problem of unemployment in certain regions of Europe makes it necessary to decisively strengthen the mobility of workers in the Union. The amendments to the Regulation, made with the help of the 5-Star Movement, ensure a number of improvements to the European Network of Employment Services (EURES) in order to facilitate usability by users. States are also committed to informing citizens about EURES and a platform performance monitoring programme is activated. I have chosen to vote in favour of making these substantial improvements to the European Network of Employment Services.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the Agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EURES platform should serve to support the fair mobility of European workers by promoting the exchange of information on offers and job demands and creating a stable structure of support and information services for migrant workers within the EU. Both the participation of social actors and the central role reserved for public employment services are a brake on possible abuses such as those recorded in the past. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed regulation on a European network of employment services, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets. Indeed, the stated system faces many problems. First, it would tend to encourage the "brain drain" which would widen the inequalities between the different European areas (East, West, North, South). Secondly, more than an obvious problem of logistics and resources, this network would trigger the uprooting of workers and the precariousness of employment. Finally, the EURES system for employment mobility would promote blackmail to mobility and would pose great difficulties with unemployment benefits. Deeply opposed to the single labour market, I opposed this text.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as its aim is to improve the existing European network of employment services, workers' access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets.  This will be done through the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, the definition for the first time of cross-border cooperation, better information for employers and employees, the obligation of network members to make available jobs and CVs public, the obligation for private employment services to perform all tasks as members of the network (unless they can demonstrate on a reasoned basis that they cannot , in which case they must perform only some of the tasks mentioned.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I have called for a further strengthening and modernisation of EURES, the European platform for occupational mobility within the EU. EURES supports jobseekers in taking advantage of freedom of movement within the European Union. AMONG other things, EURES simplifies access to job vacancies within the EU. In a border region such as Eastern Belgium, facilitating occupational mobility across borders is also of great importance. The mobility potential of the EU labour force has not yet been tapped. Opportunities are being created to get more people and especially young people into work. In the future, the portal will therefore also list apprenticeships and traineeships, among other things.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is consistent with the EU's plan to create a single labour market based on one of the EU's founding pillars, the free movement of workers. In this case, the aim here is to set up a structured cooperation network allowing all European citizens to access all job offers.  Among the measures discussed are strengthening cooperation between public employment services, integrating non-public bodies (unions, chambers of commerce), improving access to the EURES portal or creating a European coordination office (responsible for collecting information from national offices, training its employees and running surpluses and shortages in different regions).  The Programme for Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) funds this scheme. Considering that this system promotes the uprooting of workers, that it imposes the European single market on employment as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment, I voted against this report.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to thank rapporteur Heinz Becker for his excellent report. Unfortunately, unemployment in the EU still persists. This is an extremely harmful phenomenon affecting many individuals and their families. However, there are still two million job vacancies throughout the Member States. The EURES platform will help bring the unemployed and employers seeking employees across the EU together. Moreover, working abroad will be a great experience for the workers involved, as well as bringing Europe closer together.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the reform of the European Employment Service (EURES). This new regime will make it easier for the EU to find the right job and allow employers to choose workers more quickly. The aim of the reform is to provide better job and job search services across Europe, to avoid labour imbalances in Europe, where high unemployment is being observed in some countries and workers are missing or are in short supply in others. The new rules are good news for people looking for a job in the European Union. Jobseekers' CVs will automatically be linked to job vacancies. All this will be done for free. In addition, all advertisements from employment services in EU countries will become available on a single EURES web portal. It is also essential that EURES services also become available to persons with disabilities. EURES is a network of cooperation between the Employment Services of the European Commission and eu countries, as well as Switzerland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein, established in 1993. It exchanges information on job vacancies and living and working conditions. About 150,000 people are employed through this network every year.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As the free movement of workers is one of the EU's dogmas, the establishment of a structured cooperation network allowing all European citizens to access all job offers appears to be a favourable mechanism for the achievement of a single labour market. Among the many problems posed by this report, the system in question could widen the inequalities between Southern and Eastern Europe and that of the North and the West by encouraging "brain drain". Worse, EURES - the "European Employment Pole" - would promote blackmail to mobility, whereby an unemployed person would not want to work if he was not ready to take an offer in Europe, wherever it was; which could potentially pose difficulties with regard to unemployment benefits. Finally, this system leads to the uprooting of workers, imposes the European single market on employment as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which aims to improve the European Employment Services Network (EURES) in order to strengthen the information of European citizens on access to job opportunities within the Union. The aim of the network, whose portal must be easily accessible to all, must be to contribute to a high rate of quality and sustainable employment within the Union.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the global economic crisis, which has led to a massive increase in unemployment rates, it seems increasingly necessary to put in place effective initiatives to promote real integration between the labour markets of the EU Member States. In this context, strengthening the EURES network can be a great opportunity for millions of European citizens. I strongly supported the Becker report because I believe that it is essential to establish a truly accessible European platform capable of providing complete and adequate information to all job-seeking people.  Integrating apprenticeships and traineeships, which include regular employment contracts, can provide a further boost to strengthen internal mobility even for those who are completing a training course. The development of an effective network requires regular evaluation mechanisms to enable appropriate changes to be made, where necessary, to ensure the success of the European strategy.  In view of the presence of these elements in the report, I have therefore decided to support it with my vote.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative proposal which aims to facilitate workers' access to services to support the labour mobility of intra-European workers, to support fairer mobility and to increase access to employment opportunities in the Union through the review of EURES. The report ensures recognition of cross-border agreements with their own special objectives and competences, in particular for frontier workers; the social partners are included in EURES bodies at European and national level, and EURES will provide information, with specially individualised guidance for workers. The information provided to workers (on the country to which they are transferred, placement options) will generally be free, while employers may be charged for special services (EURES may offer post-treatment services but with fee payment). Workers must also give their authorization for the publication of job applications and CVs on the network and may withdraw their consent. That is why, among other things, I think it is a positive report and I voted in favour.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the adoption of this report on the proposal for a Regulation on a European employment services network, access for workers to mobility services and greater integration of labour markets. We have advocated modernizing EURES with the addition of an exhaustive Community database of job seekers and vacancies. The ultimate goal is to help reduce unemployment by better adapting labour supply to demand, and also pays special attention to cross-border regions and young people.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the establishment of a structured cooperation network that should allow all European citizens access to all job offers. This seems to support the achievement of a single labour market. Plans are being made to strengthen cooperation between public employment services (EPS), integrate non-public bodies (unions, chambers of commerce), improve access to the EURES portal and create a European coordination office. The scheme will be piloted by the Commission in partnership with the states. I voted against this report because this system promotes the uprooting of workers, imposes the European single market on employment as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment. It encourages brain drain and widens inequalities between states, and EURES tends to encourage blackmail to the mobility of the unemployed throughout Europe.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Becker's report analyses the revision of the rules governing the European Network of Employment Services (EURES). It has been noted that EURES is one of the instruments through which the principle of the free movement of workers, which was created by the Schengen Agreements, applies, and given that the schengen agreements have now lost their raison d'ion, since they no longer guarantee freedom and security within the Union, but rather are the vehicle for mass immigration and the consequent European social insecurity. , I did not intend to support this report with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the improved rules of the European Employment Service (EURES). These new rules will allow you to automatically link jobseekers' CVs to vacancies. In addition, advertisements from employment services in all EU countries will become available on a single web portal. The reform already agreed with the Council of the EU aims to provide better job and job search services across Europe, to facilitate labour mobility and to avoid situations where high unemployment rates are observed in some countries and workers are still lacking in others. The new rules will allow jobseekers' CVs to be automatically linked to job vacancies. This service will have to be free, as well as accessible to disabled people. In addition, the ads of employment services in all EU countries will become available on the EURES web portal. The European Parliament has succeeded in ensuring that private organisations are included in the EURES network and that border regions receive more information on job vacancies in different EU countries. Parliament has also succeeded in strengthening the role of the social partners within the EURES network.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 High unemployment in certain regions of Europe has led to the recognition of the need to strengthen labour mobility within the Union. We hope that this will contribute to the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment.  The purpose of this Regulation is to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for jobseekers/employers by creating the largest database of job vacancies and job seeker profiles. I support the need to including practical training and traineeship places in a Europe-wide network. I propose to introduce an appropriate exchange of general information on intra-Union mobility in the field of apprenticeships and traineeships, which should be recognised in the same way as diplomas issued by the ordinary education system of the Member States. The reform should enable public employment services to laid the foundations for closer cooperation with educational and vocational training institutions, in particular in the field of further training, extending this to the over-40s, enabling the use of information and communication technologies. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. With an ageing population in Europe and still high unemployment rates in some EU Member States or regions of them, the creation and guidance of appropriate employment flows is of paramount importance in reversing these trends.  The free choice of a job in the EU is one of the most important components of the Single European Market, one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union, and thus an essential element of EU citizenship. Increasing the mobility of workers within the EU, increasing workers' employment opportunities and helping to fill vacancies for employers, is one of the key steps towards achieving these objectives.  I therefore had no reservations in supporting that regulation or my colleague Becker's report, which aims to develop the EURES network into an effective instrument for all jobseekers and employers interested in workers within the EU. This will be achieved by providing access to a transparent and comprehensive register of job vacancies and jobseekers' profiles for the whole of the EU, and will include apprenticeships and traineeships.  In particular, I think it is good that we are involving young jobseekers in the network, who can thus take full advantage of the benefits of the EU. I think the EURES network will have a very positive impact on increasing mobility within the EU and thus an even more integrated Europe.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. Since its inception in 1993, the European Network of Employment Services (EURES) has made an important contribution to facilitating employment and mobility within the European Economic Area. Nevertheless, mobility in Europe has so far remained relatively low, without being able to achieve a real balance at European level between labour supply and demand. As the right to work based on free movement is the prerogative of all European citizens and is one of the Union's key principles, I welcome this report, which aims to make this fundamental instrument more effective. The strengthening of the EURES network, to be achieved in particular through closer cross-border cooperation between the various national employment services and the social partners, will make it possible, among other things: better information for job seekers and employers; a wider choice of employment opportunities at European level; greater correspondence between job vacancies and skills through the multilingual system of common classification of skills, qualifications and professions (ESCO), in order to facilitate the meeting between workers and employers from different countries, facilitating access to the opportunities and requirements they seek.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe. It creates a clear obligation for ‘Public Employment Services’ to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track the process of British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The ‘opt-out’ for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is ‘duly justified’. However there is no justification for this term. In any case, this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the establishment of a structured cooperation network that will allow all European citizens to access all job opportunities aimed at achieving a single labour market. Among other problems, this system tends to promote "brain drain" and thus widen inequalities within the Union, also promotes the uprooting of workers, imposes the European single market on employment as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment.  I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this report as we had some reservations about it, but did not want to block the progressive content. ‘EURES’ is a network designed to facilitate the free movement of workers within the EU-28 countries + EEA countries. The reform of EURES aims to enhance labour mobility in the EU by making it easier for workers to access information about job vacancies and information about the various Member State systems, and by making it easier for employers to recruit from all Member States. The report we voted on was an improvement on the Commission’s proposal, which focused on promoting market access for private employment services and mobility as a solution to unemployment. However, the regulation is still part of the Commission’s mobility agenda which, in my view, primarily aims to create an integrated labour market in order to increase employers’ access to cheaper labour, which is why we could not fully support the report and abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2015, every day, more than 1.1 million European citizens living in an EU country crossed borders to go to work in a neighbouring country. In addition, 7 million European citizens live and work permanently in other Member States of the Union other than their country of birth. This is good because the free choice of jobs within the EU is an integral part of freedom of movement, which is one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union as provided for in the Treaty of Rome (together with the free movement of goods, services and capital) and, consequently, a central element of EU citizenship.  Initiatives to promote the freedom of movement of citizens in the Union can be balanced with those aimed at tackling the serious problem of unemployment in certain regions of Europe: by strengthening labour mobility in the Union, workers are being given more opportunities to find the right job offer more quickly and efficiently. This will contribute to the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The mobility of European workers is an essential condition for the creation of a single labour market. Above all, in the absence of social harmonisation, this utopia increases the intensity of unfair competition between Member States. Indeed, the deepening of the EURES network will gradually lead to promoting one-way mobility from East to West. In a very degraded economic and social context, marked by the scandal of the Directive on the Detachment of Workers, such a deepening is quite unwelcome. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The free movement of workers is one of the essential elements for the development of an integrated labour market in the Union, in particular in cross-border regions, which would increase the mobility of workers and can contribute to increasing diversity and finding the right skills for vacancies and removing bottlenecks in the labour market. The objective of this Regulation is to make the EURES network an effective tool for any jobseeker or employer interested in labour mobility within the EU by creating the most comprehensive portfolio of job offers and candidate profiles that can be consulted by anyone in any EU place. Furthermore, it would be desirable for the network to include apprenticeships and traineeships, for which there must be a regular employment relationship. In order to help workers enjoying the right to work based on free movement to effectively exercise this right, I voted in favour of the initiatives of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. It is the revision of the rules governing the European Network of Employment Services (EURES), established in implementation of Regulation (EU) No 492/2011 on the free movement of workers within the Union. This review aims to give the Commission a wider role in order to achieve 'greater integration of labour markets' through increased cross-border labour mobility. In short, EURES is part of the instruments for applying the principle of free movement of labour. This principle – schengen – is one of the two pillars on which the EU is founded (the other is the free movement of capital: Maastricht). Pillars crumbling at a glance. It follows that the final vote can only be against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The freedom of movement and establishment of European citizens within the European Union is one of the pillars of the European project. This allows, for example, workers to travel to another Member State in order to work in a professional occupation. Within the single market, the mobility of workers is of considerable importance. It is therefore necessary to put everything in place in order for this mobility to be operational. The EURES network is an effective tool for job seekers and employers. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to complete the integration of labour markets.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility services and greater integration of labour markets. Being able to freely look for work within the EU is one of the EU's fundamental freedoms and a central element of EU citizenship. The serious problem of unemployment in the regions of southern Europe makes it necessary to strengthen labour mobility in the Union. This will contribute to the development of a European labour market aimed at achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which provide for an employment rate of 75% for the 20-64 age group. Labour mobility within the EU is in fact low, compared to the size of the Union's labour market and working population: the rate of mobility within the EU is only 0.29%. The objective of this Regulation is to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for job seekers or employers interested in labour mobility within the EU, making accessible and transparent a wide pool of job vacancies and profiles of job seekers across Europe.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I had some reservations about it, but did not want to block the progressive content. ‘EURES’ is a network designed to facilitate the free movement of workers within the EU-28 countries + EEA countries. The reform of EURES aims to enhance labour mobility in the EU by making it easier for workers to access information about job vacancies and information about the various Member State systems, and by making it easier for employers to recruit from all Member States. The report I voted on was an improvement on the Commission’s proposal, which focused on promoting market access for private employment services and mobility as a solution to unemployment. However, the regulation is still part of the Commission’s mobility agenda which, in my view, primarily aims to create an integrated labour market in order to increase employers’ access to cheaper labour, which is why I could not fully support the report and abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe. It creates a clear obligation for ‘Public Employment Services’ to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track the process of British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The ‘opt-out’ for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is ‘duly justified’. However there is no justification for this term. In any case, this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I fully agree that workers need to access mobility services as a means to increase access to employment opportunities. It should help to overcome labour shortages in some areas and reduce unemployment in others. The EU Member States need a common framework on labour mobility, one that would, among others, abolish any discrimination, provide adequate social services for mobile workers and generally ensure sustainable employment. Another important element is the reorganisation of the European Job Mobility Portal (EURES); this is a good way to start. Although the facility has already proven very useful for jobseekers, much more could be done in this area, like the extension of the EURES network to apprenticeships and traineeships.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The level of unemployment in some regions of the Union continues to be extremely worrying.  In addition to measures to create new jobs, action must also be taken in the area of greater market integration. The mobility of workers, which is still low in relation to potential, must therefore be strengthened, and at the same time the immediacy with which employers can satisfy the labour supply.  To this end, the European Network of Employment Services (EURES) should become more efficient, thanks to positive changes to its regulation in this report. The delegation of the 5-star Movement therefore voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EURES network has given many people the opportunity to find employment within the European Union and has been an instrument that has helped to achieve the free movement of workers, as provided for in Article 45 of the Treaty. The new needs of the labour market and the growing demand for job seekers across national borders – it is estimated that between 2007 and 2013 the number of people registered on the portal increased from 175 000 to 1 200 000 – demonstrate the explosion in demand, but this has not been followed by an increase in labour mobility. A shortcoming due to the fact that the system needed to be modified since, as it is organized, it was unable to cope with ever-increasing demand.  The extension of the local and transnational partnership network provided for in the proposal for a regulation increases the possibility of crossing labour supply and demand and at the same time increasing the mobility of workers. As a result of the ongoing demands, EURES will also be extended to trainees, a sign of how young people see the EU as a single large labour market. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that EURES offers real employment opportunities.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that the free choice of job within the EU is an integral part of freedom of movement as one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union and therefore a key element of citizenship of the European Union.  Especially in the light of the high unemployment in some regions of Europe, it is a question of strengthening labour mobility within the EU, improving employment opportunities for workers and helping employers to fill vacancies better and faster. This contributes to the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
