text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets affects a large proportion of European citizens.  It is therefore very important to ensure that such a move is governed by principles of respect for citizens' rights and does not disturb positive elements that may exist to date, while on the contrary reinforcing them. Indeed, I think it is a positive action, particularly in the light of the improvement of the EURES employment mechanism and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as I am convinced that the free choice of jobs within the EU is an integral part of freedom of movement, which is one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union and, consequently, a central element of EU citizenship.  The aim of the Regulation is to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for job seekers or employers interested in labour mobility within the EU, making a wide pool of job vacancies and profiles of job seekers across Europe accessible and transparent.  The serious problem of unemployment in some regions of Europe makes it necessary to strengthen labour mobility in the Union, to offer more opportunities to workers and to help employers to meet labour supply more quickly and efficiently. This will contribute to the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am very pleased that this proposal for a regulation has been adopted, and I am proud to have contributed with my vote in favour. In fact, measures such as this see a Europe that is not only obligations and bureaucracy, but also opportunities and work, diversification of life prospects, broadening one's horizon and increasing the chances of living happily ever after.  What's the point of moving from the countryside to the city, if you go and do a job that doesn't satisfy humanly? I will be pleased to see, when this regulation is fully implemented, young people who will make their way on the basis of their passions and not geographical boundaries.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The free movement of workers is one of the four freedoms that underpine the European internal market. The European Mobility Portal - EURES - is an important tool for such mobility, as it allows a meeting between cross-border supply and demand for employment, but also as a reliable source and aggregator of information.  However, it should be recalled that labour market policy, including all support measures, remains in the national sphere of competence. To that extent, the proper functioning of measures such as this depend on national authorities, which justifies, for example, that the public services of each Member State should be automatically designated by the Member States as members of the network responsible for the application of this Regulation. On the other hand, only 3.1% of the European workforce works in another Member State and, on average, only 700,000 people move annually. Greater use of this mobility, which allows for a greater encounter between demand and supply, contributes to more employment. Faced with unemployment that remains worrying in some countries, notably Portugal, improving instruments – such as EURES – is even more important. I support this report.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the EU should take supportive measures to promote mobility within the EU, especially for border regions, which are often weak in structural areas. The EURES network could also make a decisive contribution to reducing youth unemployment, as it will also provide traineeships and apprenticeships.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe. It creates a clear obligation for ‘Public Employment Services’ to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track the process of British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The ‘opt-out’ for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is ‘duly justified’. However there is no justification for this term. In any case, this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Work mobility within the European Union is still small in relation to the size of the Union's labour market and working population. The free choice of jobs on the market is an integral part of freedom of movement, which is one of the European Union's main fundamental freedoms and, consequently, a central element of European citizenship.  The serious problem of unemployment in some regions makes it necessary to strengthen job mobility in the Union, to provide more opportunities for workers and to help employers to meet labour supply more quickly and efficiently. The aim of this regulation is to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for job seekers or employers. The platform will be easily accessible and as easy to use as possible.  For these reasons, I am in favour of this initiative.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Intra-EU labour mobility remains relatively low when seen in the context of the size of the labour market and the active population of the EU. We still have a mobility rate in the EU-27 which is only 0.29%. The key remains that of focusing our action more on young people, who are more willing to be mobile. Minimum standards of recognition, equivalence structures as well as common rules will continue to facilitate labour mobility, thereby addressing skill gaps that are particular to different Member States.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 EURES is a network aimed at promoting collaboration between the European Commission and the public employment services (SPI) of the Member States of the European Economic Area (EEA), in order to have an exchange of information on job vacancies and to facilitate the mobility of workers within the EU.  In view of the shortcomings found in the EURES network, amendments to the Regulation have been made mainly aimed at improving the incompleteness of job vacancy information, the lack of apprenticeships and traineeships, unequal access to EURES services overcome through improved communication between job seekers and employers, limited willingness to provide assistance to job seekers and employers who have expressed interest in labour mobility , to facilitate the widest possible access and dissemination. I am voting in favour, as the aim of this regulation is to transform EURES into a more effective, transparent and accessible instrument at a time of serious labour market crisis.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EURES platform should serve to support the fair mobility of European workers by promoting the exchange of information on offers and job demands and creating a stable structure of support and information services for migrant workers within the EU. Both the participation of social actors and the central role reserved for public employment services are a brake on possible abuses such as those recorded in the past. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growing interdependence between labour markets requires closer cooperation between employment services in order to ensure greater mobility for workers and to contribute to the social inclusion and integration of people excluded from the labour market throughout the European Union.  I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution because it promotes an instrument which I believe is very useful and which aims to create a European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility services and greater integration of labour markets.  In my vote, I wanted to promote the movement of workers, eliminate all forms of discrimination between European citizens and help workers who have the right to work in another Member State to effectively exercise this right while also protecting their families.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The free choice of jobs within the Union is an integral part of the right to free movement under the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union and is therefore an important element of EU citizenship. Today, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU, and nearly one in five young people do not have a job. Some regions are more affected, while others are less so. The solution would be to increase labour mobility within the EU. This is low compared to the size of the labour market and the eu's active population, but also compared to larger competitors (USA, Japan) – the MOBILITY RATE of the EU-27 is only 0.29%. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the mobility of the workforce within the Union in order to improve workers' employment prospects and help employers fill their vacancies better and faster. The regulation aims to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for jobseekers and employers, respecting member states' competences with regard to labour market regulation, which remained a national competence. All jobseekers should be provided with comprehensive information on the employment conditions and services of the place of work. The platform should be easily accessible and as user-friendly as possible. I think it is important that, with regard to filling vacancies, the Member States and the Commission should ensure that citizens of EU Member States take precedence when filling them, so that the EU's preference is realised.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 EURES is a network of cooperation between the European Commission and member states' public employment services aimed at occupational mobility in the EU. The aim of this regulation is to make the EURES network a tool for jobseekers or employers by making available at pan-European level a pool of job vacancies and jobseeker profiles. The Regulation also aims to strengthen the institutional and organisational basis for EURES services, improve the quality of information made available to workers and employers, improve the exchange of information in order to better reflect technological developments and increase labour mobility, in particular in cross-border regions. The Regulation also covers apprenticeships and traineeships, provided that applicants are covered by an employment relationship. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that the integration of the labour markets and the entitlement of the freedom to work are an indispensable tool to address the high rates of unemployment. This regulation aims to turn the EURES network into an effective instrument for jobseekers or employers, by creating the largest framework of vacancies and jobseeker profiles, accessible EU-wide. The proposal also ensures that the labour market policy remains a Member State competence. I am in favour of this report as I believe that all jobseekers should be able to have access to all the information needed and that a user-friendly framework would be a positive step forward in tackling unemployment.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We know that the EURES network is already working, but I believe that it needs to be reorganising it in order to improve services for potential beneficiaries through better interministerial coordination, to overcome the legal obstacles that exist for workers who want to work in another country because, at present, many people are currently willing to accept job offers in another Union State because of uncertainty or lack of relevant information on social security systems , payment of taxes and other obligations in the country of residence.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to improve workers' access to vocational mobility support services within the EU by strengthening the EURES network. This instrument brings together job seekers and employers (e.g. internship and apprenticeship offers). In particular, the report proposes to create a European database to better correlate labour demand and job offers. It also provides for free support services for workers and employers and the creation of a European Coordination Office, managed by the European Commission. Finally, it implements specific partnerships for worker mobility in cross-border regions.  Considering that the current employment situation in Europe is partly due to an mismatch between demand and labour supply, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to facilitate and encourage intra-European recruitment, in particular through the revision of the EURES portal for employment mobility. The aim of this instrument is to respond more adequately to developments in the European labour market. I am particularly in favour of the development of the EURES portal to promote learning in Europe.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Network for Employment Services and Workers' Access to Mobility Services (EURES) is a network of cooperation aimed at facilitating the freedom of movement of workers in the 28 Member States of the EU, Switzerland, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway.  So I voted in favour of the EURES report. This report relates to a proposal by the European Commission for a new regulation to improve the functioning of the EURES tool. It will revitalise the network made available to workers in order to support them in their professional mobility projects, but also companies, especially SMEs, to help them fill vacancies.  I welcome the fact that this new regulation will enable the creation of cross-border partnerships capable of providing information and support to workers.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EP voted on proposals for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Network of Employment Services (EURES), access to mobility services for workers and further integration of labour markets. In particular, it is emphasised that the Regulation not only provides for the free movement of workers, but also abolishes any grounds of discrimination between workers in the Member States. EURES objectives include a coordinated employment strategy (in particular for skilled workers), an integrated labour market, increasing voluntary geographical and employment mobility in the Union and support for a smooth transition from education to work. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. As the free movement of workers is a pillar of the Union, it is understandable that the establishment of a network for all Europeans to access job offers is proposed, in order to achieve a single labour market. However, being committed to the defence of French workers, I can only oppose the uprooting of the latter, precariousness as the only hope for them and the unfair flight of the brains of some States to others. Finally, it is a project that will face logistical and resource difficulties as well as obstacles such as the barrier of European languages. In the name of pragmatism and national preference for the defence of workers, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Colleague Becker's report concerns the EU EURES platform, which aims to support labour mobility within the Union. The aim of the proposed regulation is to make EURES a tool for jobseekers as well as employers by creating a 'database' of vacancies and profiles across the EU.  In today's high unemployment situation, which is ingesting across many Member States, I believe that such an instrument would undoubtedly have a positive effect.  I support the report, but I believe that, nevertheless, it is important for Member States to be given the freedom to give employers the option of not publishing an advertisement on the platform, depending on the requirements of the specific position.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The update of the Regulation, which has already been agreed with the Council, will enable greater participation in the "social partners" (employers and trade unions) and will focus more on cross-border areas and young people. The new, "smarter" EURES portal will automatically match CVs with the appropriate jobs offered without any discrimination on the basis of nationality. All jobs published by public bodies in the Member States will be made available pan-European through the same web portal. We are voting against this report as we are against cross-border work and worker mobility. Member States should have had the option of not participating in the EURES network.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my view, the free choice of employment within the Union should be seen as an integral part of the right to free movement within the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union. This is an important element of EU citizenship, which, by the way, has been seriously threatened by the current migrant crisis. Today, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU and one in five young people have no job. I believe that, when filling vacancies, Member States and the Commission should ensure that citizens of EU Member States take precedence, thereby fulfilling the principle of EU preference. Despite rumours to the contrary, eu labour mobility in the EU is low compared to the size of the labour market and the active population of the EU, but also compared to larger competitors (e.g. USA, Japan): the EU mobility rate is only 0.29 %. I support the purpose of the regulation voted on. The EURES network should be transformed into an effective tool for jobseekers and employers, respecting member states' competences with regard to labour market regulation. It is not immigrants, mostly unskreated, but the need to meet the needs of the labour market by strengthening the free employment of EU citizens.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This proposal for a Regulation aims to improve workers' access to mobility support services within the EU by maintaining the EURES network as an effective tool for job seekers. It should be noted that it must also continue to respect the fact that labour market policies remain the competence of the Member States. Further than, the aim of the Regulation is not only to facilitate the exercise of the free movement of workers within the Union, but also to eliminate any discrimination based on nationality between workers in the Member States as regards employment, remuneration and other conditions of work and employment in the Union. In this regard, the agreed text is to lay down specific rules and provisions concerning the mobility of workers in border regions, the services provided to job seekers in order to ensure fair mobility and the effective promotion of the EURES network at Union level through intensive communication measures adopted by the Commission and , in particular, by the Member States.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EURES network was established in 1993 with the aim of helping Europeans find employment in another Member State. However, the high unemployment rates experienced in some EU Member States coexist with opportunities in other countries, but intra-Community labour mobility remains relatively low. Only 3.1% of European workers are economically active in another Member State (7.5 million out of 241 million workers). Knowledge of languages and difficulties in finding a job are pointed out as the main reasons for this. The proposal for a Regulation aims to improve the EURES network by extending the provision of employment and improving the accessibility of curricula, improving the link between available vacancies and existing curricula, increasing the exchange of information between Member States on their needs and including traineeships and other apprenticeships. Currently, the network has more than one million vacancies and 235,000 resumes available.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes amendments to the European Commission's proposal for a regulation on EURES – a European network of employment services. The original proposal referred to some issues that deserved our opposition, despite a general non-negative sense. The changes that are introduced to you, in general, are positive. A warning to the issue of compulsory mobility. The report introduces changes that ensure greater prominence for Member States and their structures (employment and training), ensures the involvement of trade unions, sees mobility as an essentially cross-border issue and ensures the gratuity of all services provided by EURES. In this sense, the regulation has gotten better. It is understood that a network facilitating voluntary mobility, such as that set out in this report, is an interesting development, so, not supporting the original proposal, we voted in favour of this report.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation, the aim of which is to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for job seekers or employers interested in labour mobility within the EU. Through this implementation, the match between supply and demand will be more accessible and transparent, maintaining labour market policy, including all support measures, of national competence.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained as it involves further integration.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against as Eures is the schengen enforcement instrument, a treaty that should be completely revised.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The update of the Regulation, which has already been agreed with the Council, will enable greater participation in the "social partners" (employers and trade unions) and will focus more on cross-border areas and young people. The new, "smarter" EURES portal will automatically match CVs with the appropriate jobs offered without any discrimination on the basis of nationality. All jobs published by public bodies in the Member States will be made available pan-European through the same web portal. I am voting against this report as I am against cross-border work and worker mobility. Member States should have had the option of not participating in the EURES network.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which will tackle a number of EURES’s shortcomings, such as an incomplete pool of job vacancies and CVs, limitations to automated matching and insufficient information for employers and mobile workers. The new EURES network should lead to a considerable improvement regarding the functioning of EURES, thereby facilitating the placement of job seekers in Europe and contributing to the reduction of unemployment and skill shortages. One major improvement is the fact that the existing EURES Web Portal is transformed into a European platform for exchange of job vacancies and CVs. Our key achievements, such as the involvement of social partners at all levels of the network, the definition of cross-border partnerships and the abolition of  fees for basic EURES services for workers, will make EURES much more effective. Hopefully, the new database will now become smarter by automatically matching the CVs with job offers. In addition, all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published EU-wide by EURES as well.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I have taken the people's party position because I see the free choice of jobs within the Union as an integral part of the right to free movement under the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union, which is an important element of EU citizenship, which, by the way, has been put at risk by the current migrant crisis. Today, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU, and nearly one in five young people do not have a job.  Despite rumours to the contrary, EU labour mobility in the EU is low compared to the size of the labour market and the EU's active population, but also compared to larger competitors (USA, Japan) – the MOBILITY rate of the EU-27 is only 0.29%.  The regulation aims to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for jobseekers and employers, respecting member states' competences with regard to labour market regulation, which remained a national competence. My position is that employment problems should be reduced not by more non-EU and explicitly unsklined immigrants, but by strengthening the free employment of EU citizens. In this context, I believe that, with regard to filling vacancies, the Member States and the Commission should ensure that citizens of EU Member States take precedence when filling them, so that the principle of EU preference is also implemented.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The free choice of jobs within the Union is an integral part of the right to free movement under the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union and is therefore an important element of EU citizenship. In my opinion, high unemployment in certain regions of Europe leads to the recognition of the need to strengthen labour mobility within the Union in order to improve workers' employment prospects and help employers fill their vacancies better and faster. This will contribute to the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment.  Accordingly, the Regulation clearly confirms that labour market policy, including all stimulus measures, remains a national competence. In addition, the principle of residence should be maintained. Furthermore, all jobseekers should be provided with comprehensive information on the employment conditions and services at the place of work.  It is crucial that the platform is easily accessible and as user-friendly as possible.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the aim of developing a better employment network at European level. This will allow us to continue to make progress in the process of European integration, while improving existing plans for the free movement of workers.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress made by the Socialist Group is the transformation of the EURES web portal into a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes. The new smart database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic cross-crossing of resumes with job openings and all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies to be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate basic service rates for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that, as a whole, the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement between the EP and the Council on the adoption of a regulation on a European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility services and greater integration of labour markets, because I strongly support the need to revitalise the EURES network through a single platform that includes job-seeking people and existing job vacancies in the Member States and at the same time improves the correspondence between supply and demand in the EU labour market. I believe that it is very useful for young job-seeking young people and in general for skilled workers, looking for better job opportunities, for job vacancies at public services in each Member State to be available on the new portal, the aim of which is to cross the needs of the market in order to bridge the current gap between the two million jobs vacant in the EU and the level of unemployment , which in some Member States achieves high percentages, particularly among young people. Extending platform member status to private organisations may further facilitate the matching of labour supply and demand from a cross-border perspective.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on a European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility-enhancing services and further integration of labour markets, as I, as a social policy expert, fully believe that it is young workers, but also entrepreneurs and small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe, who benefit from a more integrated European labour market. Basically, we need something like the 'European internal market for jobs'. A large country such as Germany, with many long-overgrown economic areas in the border area, is benefiting from a greater networking of EURES posts.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the revision of the rules on the operation of the European Jobs Network (EURES) because the existing system was flawed. The collection of available jobs and the resumes of the unemployed was incomplete. The automatic matching of resumes and offers was limited and the scope of cross-border information on available offers and competences was insufficient. Only 7.5 million people, or 3.1% of the active population, find employment in other Member States. Our aim is to tackle unemployment by better matching supply and demand in the EU labour market. I believe that the new rules will take better account of the needs of young people and the specificities of cross-border regions. The reformed EURES portal should be 'smarter', as it will automatically search for job vacancies according to the competences of the job seeker listed in the curriculum vitae and include all job vacancies published by public employment offices in Member States across the EU and, importantly, access for workers is free of charge. I consider it appropriate to prohibit discrimination on grounds of nationality in terms of employment, pay and other working conditions and to guarantee access to the services of the portal for persons with disabilities.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The EURES network makes a major contribution to the mobility of European workers. Closer cooperation between public authorities in the placement and integration of workers promotes the free movement of workers and thus one of the EU's fundamental freedoms.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe. It creates a clear obligation for ‘Public Employment Services’ to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track the process of British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The ‘opt-out’ for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is ‘duly justified’. However there is no justification for this term. In any case, this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes a regulation on a European network of employment services, workers’ access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets; all measures that are key to tackling unemployment. I particularly welcome that this proposal will make the EURES network a key tool for jobseekers and employers by creating the largest framework of vacancies and jobseeker profiles in the EU, while ensuring that labour market policy remains a Member State competence.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The idea is tempting to say that it is to reduce unemployment by linking the total supply and demand for jobs at European level. However, it does not stand up to analysis. The rapporteur notes and deplores, in the explanatory statement, that the "mobility" rate of workers in the Union is only 0.29%, a figure which obviously does not include seconded workers. But it does not analyze the basis for it. How can it reasonably be believed that this low rate is due only to a lack of information from potential workers and employers? How can one believe that the lack of appetite of an unemployed French or Swedish to go to work for 425 euros per month in Romania, where it is the average wage, is due only to his ignorance of the available job offers? Or that an unemployed Romanian is not tempted to do whatever happens the trip to France, even if he finds only a job paid at the SMIC? Your desire to artificially create a single labour market will result in the institutionalisation of social dumping, the threat of subjecting the rights of the unemployed to the acceptance of any job, anywhere in Europe, and ultimately, a social levelling down. I voted against it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative proposal which aims to facilitate access for workers to services to support the labour mobility of intra-European workers, to support fairer mobility and to increase access to employment opportunities in the Union through the review of EURES. The report ensures recognition of cross-border agreements with their own special objectives and competences, in particular for frontier workers; the social partners are included in EURES bodies at European and national level, and EURES will provide information, with specially individualised guidance for workers. The information provided to workers (on the country to which they are transferred, placement options) will generally be free, while employers may be charged for special services (EURES may offer post-treatment services but with fee payment). Workers must also give their authorization for the publication of job applications and CVs on the network and may withdraw their consent. That is why, among other things, I think it is a positive report and I voted in favour.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I want to increase the mobility of workers and ensure better integration into the labour market. It is important to respect the Treaties, especially the freedoms of movement. This will contribute to the development of a high-level European labour market. Labour mobility within the EU is relatively low compared to the size of the EU labour market and working population. The EURES network must be an effective tool to support both jobseekers and employers. This network should also include apprenticeships and traineeships. It is also important to ensure that all jobseekers can obtain information on the conditions of employment in another Member State and receive assistance.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Thursday 25 February, I voted in favour of a text to reform the European Employment Services Network (EURES), a European database of applicants and job offers in Europe.  To effectively combat unemployment, we need to better match supply and demand in the labour market. With this new EURES portal, free and accessible, we will now be able to automatically synchronize CVs with suitable job offers. In addition, all vacancies published by public employment offices in EU Member States will be available at European level on the web portal. EURES is also a great support tool for border workers, who will be able to benefit from essential information on applicable legislation across borders and will benefit from personalised support in their rights transfer processes.  To the Member States now to make good use of it!

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because free movement of workers is a fundamental freedom of European Union citizens and one of the pillars of the internal market. Moreover, worker mobility is a key element in the development of a more integrated EU labour market and an important factor to tackle unemployment, especially among young people.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our firm position is that worker mobility does not solve the problem of unemployment. Social dumping and job security are then promoted through such a practice.  We believe that the migration of workers should be their free choice, from one safe working environment to another. The report moved in the above context, but through the trilogue ensured the increased participation of government agencies in the platform, reducing the role of private job-finding enterprises, but also the introduction of the social partners as partners on this platform. We see voting as an appropriate attitude because we recognise the improvements we have had since the trilogue, but also because it is the right of anyone to move to find work.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Proposal for a regulation on a European network of employment services, workers’ access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets (EURES). The new proposal aims to update the existing European-wide job-search network to improve employee mobility and make it more user-friendly and accessible for EU citizens. Unfortunately intra-EU mobility of workers is not as high as most people think, with only 3.1% of the total labour force working in another Member State, and there is a growing shortage of labour and skills in many regions and sectors across the EU. The revised EURES will allow more targeted matching of supply and demand in the EU labour market. Although limited, it is positive to see that traineeships and apprenticeships have been included in the revised network which will have a particular significance for young people and address skills and labour shortages in certain sectors. Also positive is the inclusion of private as well as public employment services which will add extra vacancies to the network and the fact that all services for workers will be provided free of charge, while services for employers may involve costs but only in limited cases.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, due to the fact that the proposed regulation aims to enhance the access of workers to intra-EU mobility support services, maintaining the EURES network as an effective instrument for jobseekers (including traineeships and apprenticeships) and registered employers, who have a stake in labour mobility within the Union. All services for employees will be provided free of charge while services for employers could involve costs, but only in limited cases related to specific and individual services.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the People's Party position. The free choice of jobs within the Union is an integral part of the right to free movement under the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union. This is one of the most prominent entitlements of EU citizens, which has been put at risk by today's migrant crisis. Today, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU, and nearly one in five young people do not have a job.  Despite rumours to the contrary, labour mobility in the EU is low compared to the size of the labour market and the EU's active population, but also compared to larger competitors (USA, Japan). The regulation aims to transform the European network of employment services into an effective tool for jobseekers and employers. The instrument respects member states' competences with regard to labour market regulation, which remains a national competence. I believe that employment problems should be reduced not by more highly unsklined immigrants, but by strengthening the free employment of EU citizens. Therefore, with regard to filling vacancies, Member States and the Commission should ensure that citizens of EU Member States take precedence when filling them. This is how the principle of EU preference can be realised.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe. It creates a clear obligation for ‘Public Employment Services’ to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track the process of British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The ‘opt-out’ for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is ‘duly justified’. However there is no justification for this term. In any case, this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Labour market policies are a competence of the Member States and rapporteur Becker has ensured that this prerogative is respected. On the other hand, I support the idea that worker mobility can be encouraged by better European coordination of employment services. That is the whole point of the proposed regulation. The proposal aims to strengthen the EURES network by bringing together job offers, including internships and apprenticeships, as well as applications for these offers under the same label. Public employment services are members of this structure. The provision of these services will be free for applicants and may be paid for by employers when it comes to specific requests.    This proposal promotes the establishment of an instrument for mobility and employment without stripping Member States of their primary competence in employment policy. That is why I supported this text.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The freedom of movement of workers has been a great success for European economies and societies. My own country has welcomed thousands of EU citizens into its workforce just as many Scots have opted to go elsewhere to work. These opportunities are now under threat as a result of the UK referendum and it will be an outrage if Scotland is dragged out of Europe against the voters’ wishes.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on a European Network of Employment Services, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets, as I believe that the free movement of people in the EU is just as significant as the free movement of goods, services and capital, even though it is the least used of the four rights. In this regard, I believe that we need to support legislative initiatives aimed at promoting the free movement of EU workers and facilitating the protection of related social rights, as it benefits both European citizens themselves and the business and needs of the economy as a whole.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I fully support the fundamental right that represents the key development of a democratic society and the freedom of movement for European workers. The appliance of the European fundamental right will avoid the inequalities between countries with a deficit of workers; it will reduce unemployment and will generate accessibility to the integration in the labour market. The purpose of this regulation is to transform the EURES network into a European platform for exchange of job vacancies and CVs, where job-seekers or employers who have a stake in labour mobility can find job offers and job-seekers’ profiles.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the European Network of Employment Services, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of the labour market, as this is a great and much-needed idea to develop a more integrated labour market in the Union, reduce unemployment and better link supply and demand in the same.  A key feature of the EURES network is transnational and cross-border cooperation that could contribute to the creation of innovative forms of learning and cooperation between employment services, in particular in the area of quality standards for vacancies and support services.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The original text on this proposed European Employment Services Network, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets included the promotion of the single labour market and employment, through the EURES (EURopean Employment Services) scheme. It goes without saying that all my fellow Members of the ENF Group had already opposed it in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee several days ago. The free movement of workers and the linking of offers and job seekers to The European level pose a danger to French workers. This system tends to promote "brain drain" and thus widen inequalities between Southern and Eastern Europe and that of the North and West. Therefore, this is in total opposition to the national preference for employment that we have always advocated.  I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe. It creates a clear obligation for ‘Public Employment Services’ to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track the process of British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The ‘opt-out’ for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is ‘duly justified’. However there is no justification for this term. In any case, this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Heinz Becker's report on the European Employment Services Network (EURES), on workers' access to mobility services and on further integration of labour markets. The aim is to encourage and improve the professional mobility of European workers through the European EURES tool. Companies can also use it to look for job applicants. In this context of persistent unemployment, especially among young people, whose fight is a priority of my political group the EPP, I support this initiative which aims to boost the European labour market, especially in the border areas with the possibility of developing partnerships.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report is about a Commission proposal to improve the EURES network. EURES is a tool made available to workers in order to accompany them in their professional mobility. It brings together job opportunities from across the EU, thus facilitating the mobility of workers within the European Union and enabling SMEs to fill vacancies.  At this particularly difficult time in terms of employment in France and Europe, especially for young people, it was obvious to vote in favour of this text which will boost the labour market, particularly in the border area, while bearing in mind that labour market policies remain the competence of the Member States.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining on this report as he sees EURES as the solution to job shortages and transnational job placement and wants to further develop the existing platform without addressing the core issue of voluntary participation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as its aim is to help fight unemployment by better matching labour market supply and demand. Updated rules will also pay more attention to cross-border regions and young people.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The free movement of workers is one of the key elements in the development of a more integrated Union labour market, including in border regions, which allows for greater mobility of workers, thus increasing diversity and contributing across the Union to the social inclusion and integration of people excluded from the labour market. It also contributes to finding suitable skills for vacancies and removing barriers to the labour market. The approval of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Network of Employment Services, workers' access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets was therefore quite a clear matter and I am glad to be able to support it. Why, however, my colleague Mach voted against it is a complete mystery to me.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I have taken the people's party position because I see the free choice of jobs within the Union as an integral part of the right to free movement under the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union, which is an important element of EU citizenship, which, by the way, has been put at risk by the current migrant crisis. Today, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU, and nearly one in five young people do not have a job.  Despite rumours to the contrary, EU labour mobility in the EU is low compared to the size of the labour market and the EU's active population, but also compared to larger competitors (USA, Japan) – the MOBILITY rate of the EU-27 is only 0.29%.  The regulation aims to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for jobseekers and employers, respecting member states' competences with regard to labour market regulation, which remained a national competence. My position is that employment problems should be reduced not by more non-EU and explicitly unsklined immigrants, but by strengthening the free employment of EU citizens. In this context, I believe that, with regard to filling vacancies, the Member States and the Commission should ensure that citizens of EU Member States take precedence when filling them, so that the principle of EU preference is also implemented.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to underline that intra-EU labour mobility is a key element of freedom of movement and of European citizenship and represents an opportunity in order to boost economic growth. Despite high levels of unemployment, there are still vacancies in many regions within the Member States that remain, deplorably, unfilled. Steps must be taken to ensure that all jobseekers can obtain comprehensive information about employment conditions. In this context, the report deals with the proposal for a regulation that aims to update the EURES job mobility portal by extending the number of partners offering mobility services, by consolidating cooperation between public and private organisations and by focusing more on young people. This is why I voted in favour.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, one of the essential elements for the development of a more integrated labour market in the Union is the free movement of workers. More than 1.1 million European citizens living in an EU country cross national borders to work in a neighbouring country.  It is therefore necessary to offer more opportunities to workers and to help employers to meet the offer in order to strengthen labour mobility within the Community. In this context, the EURES network plays a leading role as the main channel of communication through which the service interacts with all actors, in particular workers and employers.  The text voted on today aims to improve and make this network more effective by making accessible and transparent a wide range of job vacancies and profiles of job seekers across Europe. Given the time of crisis and the levels of unemployment in the various Member States, today's vote is certainly an example of a policy of doing things, which I hope will soon produce concrete results.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on "the European network of employment services, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets" for several reasons. Visibility and access to the network remain complex, despite apparent good intentions. Linking offers and demands at a European level poses obvious logistical and resource problems. The system tends to promote brain drain and thus widen inequalities between southern and eastern Europe and that of the North and West. EURES ("European Employment Pole") promotes mobility blackmail, whereby an unemployed person would not want to work if he was not ready to take an offer elsewhere in Europe, wherever it was, which could potentially pose difficulties with unemployment benefits. This system promotes the uprooting of workers, imposes the European single market on employment as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it seeks to develop a job market at European level. However, such a market is contrary to the national priority defended by the FN. The ENF Group tabled an amendment which sought to give each Member State the right not to participate in this new integration, but this amendment was rejected by the RPS and its European allies. Ultraliberalism is progressing a little more!

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EURES platform should serve to support the fair mobility of European workers by promoting the exchange of information on offers and job demands and creating a stable structure of support and information services for migrant workers within the EU. Both the participation of social actors and the central role reserved for public employment services are a brake on possible abuses such as those recorded in the past. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I cannot support legislation introducing a mandatory euro register of job offers. State databases won't help, superstate databases won't help any more. Private servers help the unemployed and employers better.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. In the Union, although we enjoy free movement, intra-Community mobility is very low: only 0.29 %, relative to the labour market and the working population. We can and must do more for people looking for jobs and for employers in the intra-community area. We have EURES, which must also function as a database of available jobs and information that anyone can access. People can profile themselves on this network, consult local employment conditions, ask for assistance. It is a means of communicating directly with public or private employment services. Such a platform must work simply, be easy to use. It can also host trainings or trainings that increase the chances of European citizens in the labour market.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Freedom to work anywhere within the EU is one of the four freedoms on which the EU was founded. The European network of EURES employment services aims to bring together all the needs of people who want to get a job and those who provide jobs.   Currently, more than 1.1 million EU citizens cross national borders every day to work in a neighbouring country. In line with labour market needs, this report proposes to reform the EURES website, which would allow for more partnerships and consolidated cooperation between public and private employment services, so I supported it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the adoption of a regulation that will make labour mobility more private in the EU. Freedom of free movement of workers within the area of any EU Member State is one of the fundamental freedoms in the EU. The introduction of a single platform, improving and making available information on job vacancies in all Member States, together with the requirements for these posts and the profile of jobseekers, can greatly help labour mobility and thus higher employment. Such a platform can have significant positive impacts, especially in cross-border regions.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. With an unemployment rate of almost 9% in 2015, the EU needs to develop effective tools to facilitate access to employment. EURES, the European Employment Services Network, was set up to provide information, advice and recruitment services. This database has a number of shortcomings, including the automated correspondence system between CVs and job offers.   This proposed regulation aims to reshape the EURES network to improve its operation by updating the job exchange platform and THE CV database. Thus, because access to employment must be a priority for the Union and this proposed regulation provides many advances in facilitating the meeting between supply and demand for work, I am voting in favour of this text.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 Referring to my speech of 24 February 2016 to the plenary of the European Parliament, I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets, because this report is complete and documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the proposal for a regulation on a European network of employment services, mobility and labour market integration because worker mobility within the EU needs to be strengthened and requires better regulation. I believe that the EU must promote existing digital tools to increase the employment opportunities of workers throughout the EU. The EURES digital platform needs to be transformed and improved so as to include as many job offers and candidate profiles as possible and can be consulted by anyone in any eu place. The EURES network should also be extended to apprentices and trainees. The inclusion of educational and training bodies, especially in terms of continuous training, is essential. The major objective of this Regulation is to reform EURES and increase its capacity. For now, there are 150,000 contacts per month between jobseekers and employers, resulting in more than 50,000 employments per year. The Commission must come up with an emergency plan that will make the platform more visible in the Member States and inform the general public.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. We voted against it. This EURES system is another step towards an ever more inclusive single market. This "European employment hub" has obvious flaws: linking offers and demands at a European level poses obvious logistical and resource problems; this system tends to promote "brain drain" and thus to widen inequalities between Southern and Eastern Europe and that of the North and West, and eventually it will promote blackmail to mobility, according to which an unemployed person would not want to work if he is not ready to seize an offer in Europe, wherever it is , which could potentially pose difficulties with unemployment benefits.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility services and greater integration of labour markets. Among the fundamental freedoms of the European Union, a central place is held by the free choice of jobs within the European Union. This proposal aims to strengthen the EURES (European Employment Services) network, a network of services with the aim of facilitating the international mobility of Eu ropean workers, by transforming it into an effective tool for workers and employers, with a wide range of jobs and profiles of job seekers in Europe, accessible and transparent.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report on the European Commission's proposal to improve the regulation of the European Employment Services Network (EURES), which has become a very useful tool. We must work to facilitate the search for employment for workers in the outermost regions and to take account of the situation in these territories when making improvements to increase the effectiveness of the European employment services network, known as EURES.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Eures, a European network of employment services, was set up to reduce unemployment, improve employability of workers and help employers find the necessary workers more effectively and quickly. The purpose of this Regulation is to make the EURES network an effective tool for viewing as many job vacancies as possible in one place and descriptions of the jobseekers' profile.  In order for the EURES network to function successfully, it is important, on the one hand, that public and private employment services are effectively involved in the network in the Member States and, secondly, that this network is communicated to the general public through intensive communication measures by the Commission and, in particular, to the Member States. I hope that the implementation of the regulation will help Member States to tackle the opiate problems of unemployment and improve the chances of job seekers or jobseekers.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. EURES is a network of cooperation aimed at facilitating the freedom of movement of workers in the 28 Member States of the Eu, Switzerland, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway. The report before us is intended to increase the effectiveness of this scheme. Parliament's amendments aim to guarantee workers' rights. Thus, the text allows member states to "refuse or revoke the admission of EURES members or partners who violate labour standards and applicable legal requirements, particularly in terms of pay and working conditions". It also seeks to combat "any discrimination on the basis of nationality between workers in the Member States in terms of employment, remuneration and other working and employment conditions within the Union".  Nevertheless, the text sets out as a principle that increasing the mobility of workers can combat unemployment, so I abstained.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The EURES platform provides a de facto hidden major danger, that of making clear to potential economic competitors the areas of Europe's strengths and weaknesses. The holding of categorical targeted listings in the hands of public or private actors could still be acceptable at the state level, but not at the level of Europe because it would then constitute a powerful economic weapon.  Moreover, the establishment of this network is a consecration of the single labour market. It poses a risk of blackmail to mobility and opposes national preference. Of course, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on a European network of employment services, workers' access to mobility services and the development of labour market integration. The European Union must use all the necessary instruments to reverse the unemployment situation. In view of the high unemployment rate in some regions of Europe, the mobility of workers within the EU needs to be strengthened. With this Regulation, the EURES network could be an effective tool for both job seekers and employers who are interested in the mobility of workers within the EU in the near future. It will be an opportunity for a more transparent process to be established so that job seekers can obtain accurate information on working conditions and services in the workplace.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst maintaining that labour market policy is a national competence, this report seeks to promote the European employment services (EURES) network as an effective tool for jobseekers to find employment by taking advantage of the freedom of movement within the European Union. I voted in favour of this report as we should support labour mobility across the European Union.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – I come from Slovakia, a country where we have long-term very high unemployment. This forces many of our people to go abroad. It is already a kind of tradition, because our ancestors, who found a solution to poverty or deprivation in this way, went to a distant foreign country, e.g. the USA. Today, the situation is simpler, because movement on the territory of the European Union is unlimited. Workers can move freely, can look for work in another EU country and can work in that country without the need for a work permit. I consider the EURES job mobility portal in the EU to be a unique opportunity for those looking for work, as it is free of charge and offers information on living and working conditions in all participating countries. The number of people visiting it on a daily basis is huge, so I support the reform of this network in order to increase the number of partners offering mobility services through it. However, it should not be forgotten that labour policy is a competence of the Member States. State administration bodies, especially ministries, need to improve cooperation with each other to help overcome obstacles to those who want to find work abroad.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the report on the European network of employment services, workers’ access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets (EURES), because the main purpose of EURES is to provide information, advice and recruitment/placement services for the benefit of workers and employers wishing to benefit from the principle of the free movement of persons. The new database should become smarter by automatically matching the CVs with job offers. In addition, all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published EU-wide by EURES as well.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed a regulation to Parliament and the Council with the aim of strengthening labour mobility within the Union in order to improve workers' employment prospects and help employers fill vacancies better and faster. To this end, it proposes to create the largest database of job vacancies and job seeker profiles that can be viewed by anyone at EU level. In order to make the EURES network an effective tool for jobseekers and employers, the Report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs considers it important that the well-functioning public and private employment services of the Member States participate in the network and that the network is made known throughout Europe through communication measures taken by the Commission and the Member States. It also draws attention to the need for Member States and the Commission to ensure that citizens of EU Member States take precedence when filling vacancies. Moreover, the report proposes that Parliament adopt the proposal with more than 1 1 000 amendments. I voted in line with that.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The establishment of a structured cooperation network allowing all European citizens access to all job offers is part of the free movement of workers, the founding pillar of the European Union. The measures discussed are to strengthen cooperation between public employment services, to integrate non-public bodies (unions, chambers of commerce), to improve access to the EURES portal ("European employment centre") and to create a European coordination portal. This system poses serious dangers, as it further promotes the uprooting of workers, imposes the European single labour market as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment. In addition, EURES promotes mobility blackmail whereby an unemployed person would not want to work if he is not ready to take an offer in Europe, wherever it is. We are therefore vehemently opposed to the establishment of this network, which will continue to harm our sovereignty and our economy.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation raises several problems. Despite apparent good intentions, visibility and access to the network will remain complex. Linking offers and demands at a European level poses obvious logistical and resource problems. This system also tends to promote "brain drain" and thus to widen inequalities between Southern and Eastern Europe and that of the North and west.  On the other hand, it promotes the uprooting of workers, imposes the European single market on employment as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on European employment services. The agreement reached during the trialogue, together with the European Commission and the European Council, is ambitious in trying to reform an area of crucial importance for the economic recovery of European countries, namely employment.  The new form of EURES, achieved thanks to a constant commitment by the Group of Socialists and Democrats, will allow a better match between supply and demand on the labour market thanks to improvements that create a completely redesigned platform with new features. In its new structure, EURES provides for the involvement at all levels of the social partners, engaged in the protection of workers' rights. It also provides, for the first time, for the possibility of creating transnational partnerships between the countries of the European Union. Finally, for the youngest, the agreement reached will make it easier to carry out training periods in public and private bodies in other Member States, ensuring compliance with European rights regulations.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Becker's report because the aim of this regulation is to transform the EURES network into an effective tool for job seekers or employers interested in labour mobility within the EU, making accessible and transparent a wide range of job vacancies and profiles of job seekers across Europe. It is necessary to ensure that all job seekers receive full information on working conditions and services offered in the workplace.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Free movement of workers is a fundamental principle of the Treaty held as sacred in Article 45 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Based on this legislation EU citizens are entitled to look for a job in another EU country, work there without a work permit, reside there for that purpose, stay there even after employment has finished, enjoy equal treatment in access to employment, working conditions and other social and tax advantages. I voted for this report that will create a large online pool of vacancies and jobseeker profiles which can be consulted EU-wide by anyone.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The European Employment Network EURES is to be extended to include a Europe-wide database of job applications and CVs. So far, some fundamental shortcomings have been identified in EURES, including an incomplete pool of posts and CVs. I would have abstained from voting.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on a European network of employment services, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets. This report aims to improve the mobility of workers within the Union and to revise the European network of EURES employment services following the analysis of deficiencies in the current system.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is a proposal to reform EURES so that it will increase the number of partners providing mobility services and increase cooperation between the public, private sector and educational institutions.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the European network of employment services, workers' access to mobility services and greater integration of labour markets. Firstly, I am convinced that greater mobility of workers within the EU will offer them additional employment opportunities and help employers to cover their job vacancies more quickly and efficiently.  This will contribute to the development of a European labour market with a high level of employment. In addition, I believe it is necessary for the EURES network to be made an effective tool for all EU workers, job seekers or employers interested in labour mobility within the EU.
