Finally, I would like to stress that the advantages of common European rules are obvious: job seekers and employers will be in a position to better understand the profile of the other party.  A European standard of job descriptions and profiles of job seekers would be a huge step towards greater integration of the European labour market.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative proposal to modernise the European Employment Services Network (EURES), the pan-European database of jobseekers and vacancies. The free movement of workers in the EU would simply be a right if it were not accompanied by more effective legislation which contributes, first, to the integration of the common labour market and, subsequently, to facilitating access for European citizens to vacancies and available jobs. The number of people working in a Member State outside their country is 7,5 million, i.e. 3,1 % of the working population. I therefore support this initiative which will make it easier to find work throughout Europe by immediately disclosing all available jobs.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The EURES network will not only not provide relief to the unemployed, but rather constitute another elaborate mechanism for undermining the right to permanent, stable work with rights which, as the Commission has recently stated, it does not recognise. This 'network' has existed for decades, and is now being reconstituted, always in a reactionary direction, to further 'promote mobility' for the 'adaptable' workforce.  This now includes the 'private employment offices', i.e. the slave trade offices, including the notorious 'employee rental companies', but also the employers' organisations themselves. In other words, the slave trade offices are upgraded, i.e. legitimized and legitimized with the will, to provide capitalists with cheap and "flexible" labour, without rights, for temporary and underpaid jobs, as much as the boss wants.  The GUE and the MEPs of SYRIZA, as well as the other parties of the Euro-one-way (ND, PASOK, Potami) voted in favour, since they agree with the perpetuation of capitalist exploitation in order to secure the profits of capital. Unemployment is intertwined with the rotten capitalist system served by the EU and the parties of urban management. The only way out is to strengthen the working-class popular struggle to overthrow it to make the people the owner of the wealth it produces.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislation. EURES is an EU website that advertises British jobs across Europe.  It creates a clear obligation for "Public Employment Services" to post all publically advertised jobs on to EURES. In the UK this means that UK JobCentre Plus will have to advertise all its jobs across Europe. The new rules allow private employment services to apply and advertise across Europe and also create an automated job matching to CV which will fast track British jobs being taken by EU nationals. The "opt-out" for employers as written in the rules changes the current system. At the moment in the UK an employer has a voluntary opt-in to EURES. These rules say they can only exempt a vacancy if it is "duly justified". However there is no justification for this term. In any case this new legislation will increase the amount of UK jobs advertised across Europe.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is clear that one of the four fundamental freedoms is freedom of movement, which is part of the freedom to choose a job. Strengthening EURES, which would make it easier to match supply and demand, will create the conditions for greater development within the EU. Considering the need to give greater impetus to the labour sector, I consider it necessary to strengthen the EURES network. I therefore say that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The proposed regulation aims to enhance the access of workers to intra-EU mobility support services, maintaining the EURES network as an effective instrument for jobseekers (including traineeships and apprenticeships) and registered employers who have a stake in labour mobility within the Union. I believe that better job search and recruitment services across Europe are essential to fighting unemployment, especially among young people. That is why I am favour of the proposal.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the rapporteur's proposal as it establishes an even deeper and improved European Network of Employment Services. This will increase workers' access to job vacancies in other Member States, which will increase labour mobility and thus make a crucial contribution to the further integration of labour markets between the Member States of the European Union.  The European Network of Employment Services will make vacancies even more accessible in regions where workers from other regions and Member States where there is a higher unemployment rate can be recruited.  At the same time, the proposal provides assistance for workers and employers, increases the role of EURES, clearly defines cross-border cooperation, establishes minimum common criteria that all Member States will have to provide and ensures equal access to services.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome this report and fully support it. The growing trend of high unemployment, especially among young people, poses a serious problem both at national and European levels. In 2015, the EU had an unemployment rate of almost 10%, while in Croatia overall unemployment stood at a high of 17%, putting Croatia third in the EU, second only to Greece and Spain. The figures on unemployment among under-25s are devastating, reaching 45% in Croatia, while at the European level it is around 20%. Such statistics require effective action by the European institutions as well, and in this regard I welcome the Commission's efforts to improve the work of the European employment mobility portal EURES, so that it becomes more understandable and accessible to jobseekers across the Union, especially in countries most affected by high unemployment. Such measures will further boost still poorly developed work mobility within the European Union and deepen the integration of the European market.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In line with the calamitous directive on the secondment of workers, this report increasingly promotes the movement of workers, as if the European Union were a single large pool of jobs. I formally oppose this vision of things which denies the identity of peoples and the attachment of citizens to their country. Such a logic actually contributes to the increase in inequality and tension between the Member States, and it particularly harms French workers, who are in unfair competition with those of other countries.  I obviously voted against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Freedom of movement is one of the four fundamental freedoms on which the EU was founded. The freedom of citizens, including Croatian citizens, to work anywhere in the EU, is a key aspect of citizenship in the EU and includes the right of Croatian citizens to seek employment in another EU country, to work there without the need for a work permit, to stay there with their family members and to enjoy equal treatment with nationals there regarding access to employment, working conditions and all other social and tax benefits.  The aim of this regulation is to turn the EURES network into an effective instrument for job seekers or employers who share in labour mobility within the EU. This would create a pool of vacancies and jobseekers whose profile can be consulted by anyone at EU level. Given that the high unemployment rate affects some parts of Europe, including Croatia, whose unemployment rate is 18.5%, which is 8% above the level of unemployment in the EU, I support this regulation as it contributes to improving labour mobility within the EU, creating new job opportunities for workers and helping employers fill empty jobs more quickly and efficiently.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes amendments to the proposal for a Regulation on the EURES (European Employment Services) network and not its development. The commission's original text has some references which we consider to be negative, perverting the relationship between the labour market and school curricula. As elements that identify themselves as positive, we highlight the extension of the network to the promotion of internships and training. We also note the slowdown in the focus on mobility, in particular compulsory mobility. The report proposes amendments that reinforce the role of the Member States and their structures (employment and training), elements that enhance the sovereignty and decision-making capacity of the States. It values the involvement of the social partners, guides the perspective of mobility as an essentially cross-border issue and advocates the gratuity of all services provided by EURES. Some considerations and proposals which, in our view, improve the regulation. Mobility is understood not to be coercive, and should result from a voluntary decision, a situation in which a facilitating network such as that presented in this report may be useful for the workers involved. That is why we voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ 1.1 million European citizens cross the border every day for work, and in 2013 more than 7 million EU citizens lived and worked in another Member State, 78% of whom were economically active and 68% had jobs. Such mobility is possible thanks to the fact that EU citizens are able to move freely, to look for a job in another Member State without a work permit. Despite the number of people living in the Member State where they were not born, they grew by 60% after 2005, this number still accounts for only 3.1% of the total EU workforce. There are 25 million people unemployed in the EU, more than 5 million of them young people, however, there is still a shortage of skilled workers in many regions of the Member States. In 1993, in order to facilitate and simplify the employment of EU citizens in other Member States, a EURES network was launched to allow the free movement of workers within Member States and towards Switzerland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. Such a network provides free information on life and work in individual Member States and connects employers with those looking for work, but its reform is needed to adapt it to the new conditions and situation in the EU in economic and social terms. Consequently, I support the report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of this important regulation represents another step in the field of worker mobility. Our long-term objective is undoubtedly to reduce unemployment in the EU, and I believe that EURES could be one of the keys to this persistent problem. Although free movement of labour is an integral part of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union, the rate of such mobility remains relatively low, given the size of the labour market and the working age population. The purpose of EURES is therefore to create the most comprehensive Pan-European and transparent set of data on job vacancies and job seeker profiles, which will also offer opportunities for students and apprentices in the form of traineeships and job preparations. However, it will be necessary to focus on joint cooperation between Member States and EURES within the meaning of setting up coordination offices at national level to provide general support and assistance to all organisations operating within their territory within eures. In this way, it will be possible to allow all those seeking employment not only easy access to information on working and living conditions in all EU Member States, but also the possibility of facilitating contact between people looking for work and employees.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The high rate of unemployment in Europe, particularly among young people, makes it necessary to strengthen labour mobility within the Union. We need to provide more opportunities for workers and help employers to meet the labour supply more quickly and efficiently.  The objective of this Regulation is to make the EURES network a more effective tool for job seekers and employers interested in labour mobility within the EU, making a wide pool of job vacancies and profiles of job seekers across Europe accessible and transparent. Apprenticeships and traineeships should also be included in the European network.  I believe that EURES is a very important instrument and I hope that it will be able to provide practical help to European citizens seeking employment. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the adoption of this regulation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 EURES is a network of cooperation between the European Commission and Member States' public employment services aimed at occupational mobility in the EU. The aim of this regulation is to make the EURES network a tool for jobseekers or employers by making available at pan-European level a pool of job vacancies and jobseeker profiles. The aim of the proposal is to strengthen the institutional and organisational basis for EURES services, to improve the quality of information made available to workers and employers, to improve the exchange of information in order to better reflect technological developments, and to increase the mobility of workers, in particular in cross-border regions. The Regulation also covers apprenticeships and traineeships, provided that applicants are covered by an employment relationship. The new EURES network will include the European Coordination Office, national coordination offices and EURES members and partners. Public employment services enjoy preferential status in the EURES network and are automatically designated by Member States as eures members. The Regulation opens up the EURES network to various actors in the market for recruitment services (public, private, service representatives, social partners). Organisations that are unable to carry out all the tasks will be able to become EURES partners and those that will be able to provide a wider range of services will become members. I hereby supported the report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – EURES is a European vocational network for job placement. This is a cooperation between the European Commission and the employment offices of the various Member States, based on mutual exchange of information. The aim of EURES is to create a platform for workers to provide information on vacancies and job-search advice. This project is all about the free movement of persons within the Union and greatly promotes the mobility of labour. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. As a component of the freedoms of movement that are the essence of European integration, the freedom of movement of workers is essential to any strategy to combat long-term and mass unemployment in an 'optimal monetary zone'. By improving the employment prospects of workers and non-workers, and by helping employers to fill their job offers quickly, mobility ultimately makes it possible to take advantage of growth areas in Europe.  However, there is an alarming observation: the labour mobility rate in the EU is only 0.29% and only 3.1% of European workers work in a Member State of the Union different from their country of origin, even though there are large disparities in demand and employment between European regions.  While labour law is almost exclusively the prerogative of Member States, this regulatory proposal aims to strengthen the EURES network by improving the information, transparency, accessibility and visibility of a vast pool of job offers and job seeker profiles across Europe.  Presenting a positive outlook for employment, worker mobility and growth within the Union, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The free choice of the workplace within the EU is an integral part of free movement in that it is one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union and a crucial element of EU citizenship. The mobility of workers within the EU is relatively low when compared to the size of the labour market and the working population in the EU – the mobility rate in the EU at 27 is only 0.29 %. It is therefore important to strengthen the mobility of workers within the EU, improve employment opportunities and help employers to find better-qualified workers more quickly for the jobs at their disposal, thereby developing the European labour market. The aim of this Regulation is to transform the EURES (European Job Mobility Portal) network into an effective tool for both job seekers and employers who are interested in the mobility of workers within the EU, providing access, at European level and in a transparent manner, to as wide as possible of jobs and profiles of job seekers.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to strengthen and modernise EURES, the European Employment Services Network, which aims to facilitate the free movement of workers within the UNION. In particular, this network helps workers to overcome barriers to mobility and increases access to job opportunities throughout the EU. I was already recommending this in my party's European programme: we must encourage professional mobility in Europe, in particular, with the help of EURES. And I am convinced that this strengthened platform will help to promote this mobility within the European Union. I am particularly pleased with the role that the social partners will occupy in this platform. Indeed, from the beginning of the discussions in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I supported the idea of an active presence on their part, because I am convinced that their expertise will be of great use to the platform. I am therefore pleased to see that, at the end of the legislative process, we have succeeded in rallying a majority of Members to our cause.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to improve the work of the European Network of Employment Services. Importantly, the aim is to expand the EURES network by enabling employers of public, private and third-sector companies to make vacancies public on the EURES portal. Another important provision is that information on vacancies must be made available free of charge to workers, without discrimination. Thirdly, the report promotes cooperation between Member States in order to keep workers informed of all vacancies.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for a Regulation of Parliament and the Council which aims to transform the EURES network into a more effective instrument, both for job seekers and employers interested in the mobility of workers within the EU, providing access, at European level and in a transparent manner, to a wide range of job vacancies and profiles of job seekers. However, while I consider the promotion of labour mobility within the EU relevant, I note that this proposal for a regulation provides that priority should be given to nationals of EU Member States, without, however, forgetting that labour market policies remain within the competence of the Member States. I also believe that, on the basis of lessons learned from the high unemployment rate in some regions of Europe, it is important to strengthen the mobility of workers by improving employment opportunities and facilitating the recruitment process for employers.  In view of the positive contribution these measures will certainly make to the development of the European labour market, and consequently to the increase in employability rates, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on a proposed regulation to improve workers' access to mobility support services in the European Union. The regulation covers the EURES network, which is an effective instrument for job seekers and registered employers, particularly SMEs, in connection with professional mobility within the Union. The EURES network makes it possible to put online CVs and job offers, internships and apprenticeships available throughout Europe. Specialized counsellors in public employment services are also available to job seekers. Border workers will also be able to benefit from EURES which will provide them with information on applicable legislation in border countries and personalised support will be provided for transfers of their rights.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the regulation because I agree with its aim of increasing the dynamics of labour mobility by contributing to better integration of labour markets at European level. Turning the existing EURES network into an effective tool for job seekers or employers, as well as making a wide pool of job vacancies accessible and transparent, means helping our young people to create a future for themselves.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative proposal which aims to facilitate workers' access to services to support the labour mobility of intra-European workers, to support fairer mobility and to increase access to employment opportunities in the Union through the review of EURES. The report ensures recognition of cross-border agreements with their own special objectives and competences, in particular for frontier workers; the social partners are included in EURES bodies at European and national level, and EURES will provide information, with specially individualised guidance for workers. The information provided to workers (on the country to which they are transferred, placement options) will generally be free, while employers may be charged for special services (EURES may offer post-treatment services but with fee payment). Workers must also give their authorization for the publication of job applications and CVs on the network and may withdraw their consent. That is why, among other things, I think it is a positive report and I voted in favour.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. In Europe, we find both extremes: crushing unemployment and companies looking for suitable skilled workers. The low price of oil and a cheap euro – this boosts the economy and ensures well-filled order books for companies. In my country of Germany, for example, a total of 580,000 vacancies were reported to companies in January 2016. The logical consequence of this situation is therefore to bring supply and demand together. To this end, we must promote labour mobility. And there is still a lot of potential up there! At present, only 3% of Europeans live and work in another Member State. One step in this direction is the EURES network, which as a job platform also shows internships and apprenticeships throughout Europe. It is important to work closely with the employment services of the Member States and to have cross-border partnerships in border regions, in order to have closely networked labour markets, especially in the border country. It was important to me to ensure that workers always have free access to this service and that the social partners are also involved in the management of EURES. We as a Parliament have been able to ensure that this is the place to be. I believe that, by reaching an early agreement with the Council, we have found a viable solution and demonstrated rapid action in Europe.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The EURES platform should serve to support the fair mobility of European workers by promoting the exchange of information on offers and job demands and creating a stable structure of support and information services for migrant workers within the EU. Both the participation of social actors and the central role reserved for public employment services are a brake on possible abuses such as those recorded in the past. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 EURES is a very useful tool for job seekers or employers interested in labour mobility within the EU. The European network of employment services makes accessible and transparent a wide range of job vacancies and profiles required across Europe. According to statistics, more than a million European citizens cross borders every day to go to work in a neighbouring country and the number of people living in a Member State other than their country of origin has increased by almost 60% following enlargements in 2004 and 2007.  In this context, I believe that the EURES portal is a unique opportunity for job seekers within Europe. I therefore voted in favour of this report because it is aimed at making the network more accessible and user-friendly, improving transparency, the exchange of information and functionality. I hope that these measures will make it possible to provide more opportunities for workers and to help employers to meet the labour supply more quickly and efficiently.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud to have been involved in the technical trialogues between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. I do not think it would be too grandiose to suggest that this reform – which is indeed quite technical – might be a microcosm of the European Union as a whole: through collaboration, consensus and respect between everyone involved. Social partnership was easily weaved throughout the legislation and we have really created a better and more effective EURES network and portal. I believe that we have created an instrument that will improve the lives of job-seekers across Europe, and especially for job-seekers in the West Midlands. At the moment, the EURES instrument simply does not work and the distribution of jobs is far from proportionate, with the UK offering far more than most other countries, which makes for a raw deal for our job-seekers. This revision to EURES will make sure that more jobs will be available in more locations and automatically match CVs with appropriate vacancies.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 Free movement of workers is one of the key elements for the development of a more integrated Union labour market. Every day, more than 1.1 million European citizens living in one of the Countries of the European Union cross the border to work in a neighbouring country. The proposal for a regulation on the European Network of Employment Services, workers' access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets aims at reforming EURES. This reform will make it possible to increase the number of partners offering mobility services through EURES, as well as to consolidate cooperation between public and private organisations in order to fill a larger percentage of the total vacancies. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because the proposed regulation comes with new proposals that can significantly strengthen not only labour mobility within the EU, but, above all, improve employment opportunities for employees and create better conditions for employers as well. I also agree with the proposed regulation because the regulation reflects new forms of employment that allow greater mobility of workers from areas with high unemployment to areas characterised by labour shortages. I see very positively the proposed changes and extensions in the EURES (European Employment Services) network, which is a very effective tool for jobseekers or employers interested in job mobility within the EU. I agree that EURES should be extended to include apprenticeships and traineeships, but I would like to see a greater increase in the quality of the traineeship, particularly as regards the content of education and training and working conditions. I expect that, thanks also to the proposed regulation, we will be able to overcome the legal obstacles that workers who want to work in another country often face.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report amending the European Union EURES Regulation in agreement with the Council. After formal rationing by the Council, it shall take effect in a matter of months. The possibility for every citizen of the European Union to move to work in any other Member State is one of the fundamental freedoms and is one of the greatest achievements of European integration. Nevertheless, labour mobility is currently very low, at only 0.29% per year. EURES was supposed to support mobility, but it has not yet succeeded – even though it registers around 1.2 million users, which we can consider a decent number. In a situation where some EU countries – Greece, Spain, Croatia – are addressing the problem of high unemployment and there is a surplus of jobs in others, it is essential that jobseekers have an overview of offers from across the European Union. That is precisely why EURES exists, yet it has not sufficiently functioned. I therefore consider it necessary to revise it. The positive side of the proposal is that it does not represent any new costs for the European Union budget. In particular, I would like to emphasise the removal of existing administrative restrictions related to the transfer of vacancy data to EURES, and I also consider it crucial that the Commission's proposal does not interfere with the labour market policies of individual Member States, which remain entirely within their competence.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. One of the EU's four main freedoms is the freedom of free movement. The free choice of a job, which is an essential element of EU citizenship, is also an integral part of this.  The level of labour mobility within the EU is relatively low in terms of the size of the labour market and the number of active populations, i.e. 0.29%. I agree with the need to increase labour mobility in the EU, thereby increasing workers' employment opportunities and helping employers to fill vacancies better and faster.  The proposed regulation aims to develop the EURES network into an effective instrument for all jobseekers and employers interested in intra-EU labour mobility. This pan-European network would provide access to a transparent and comprehensive list of job vacancies and jobseekers' profiles. The network's performance will also be regularly assessed to enable potential improvements to be made as quickly as possible and to ensure the sustainable and successful operation of the network. I believe that the EURES network represents a unique opportunity for jobseekers in the EU, as it is free of charge, provides information on living and working conditions, and connects jobseekers with employers looking for specific skills and directs them to sectors and occupations where there is a shortage of skilled labour.  For the sake of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the free movement of labour within the common market has always been and must remain a fundamental pillar of the EU. The EU and its Member States must continue to promote worker mobility through transnational partnerships and other instruments.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA delegation supports the development of an improved European Mobility Network for Job Seekers (EURES). Combating unemployment is one of the biggest challenges in the EU. It is therefore very important that existing vacancies are filled optimally. The EURES network is therefore right to work on EU-wide awareness of vacancies and matching employers and employees in the EU. The N-VA delegation also notes with satisfaction that the principle of subsidiarity has been monitored. For example, Member States have an opt-out option for making vacancies available to the EURES portal. They thus still have room to develop their own labour market policies.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Eures aims to support labour mobility within the Union. In order to provide workers and employers with reliable and up-to-date information on different aspects of labour mobility in the Union, EURES should work with other Union bodies, services and networks facilitating mobility and informing citizens of their rights in accordance with Union legislation, such as European Youth Portals, organisations responsible for recognising professional qualifications and promotion bodies , analysis, monitoring and support for equal treatment of workers, appointed in accordance with the Directive. Freedom of movement for workers and a high level of employment are closely linked and it is therefore necessary for Member States to develop mobility policies that will contribute to a better functioning labour market in the Union. Mobility policies in the Member States should be considered as an integral part of their social and employment policies, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The aim of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the European Network of Employment Services, Workers' Access to Mobility Services and further integration of the labour market is to turn the EURES network into an effective mechanism for job search, traineeships and traineeships. EURES is a free online portal for worker mobility, offering information on living and working conditions in all Member States available in 25 languages.  The Commission is proposing amendments to the Regulation that would increase the number of EURES partners outside the EU.  The focus is on young people, offering jobs that enable learning with work such as traineeships and traineeships. The proposal underlines that labour market policies will remain the responsibility of EU Member States. According to the draft employment, Member States and the Commission will prioritise EU citizens. Freedom to work anywhere in the European Union is one of the fundamental principles of freedom of movement, one of the four freedoms on the basis of which the EU was founded.  Many member states face mass unemployment. On the other hand, there is a shortage of skilled workers in many regions within the Member States and it is necessary to invest in improving the development of the European labour market. I support this draft, as the envisaged changes will result in new opportunities for citizens in search of employment and help employers find the necessary skilled workers more quickly.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of employment services, access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets.  High unemployment in the European Union is still very much paralysing certain regions, but there are still around 2 million vacancies, and we need an intensified effort in this area.  The new rules will bring about faster coordination of supply and demand for jobs, and we will play a greater role in social partners, young people and cross-border regions.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our firm position that worker mobility is not a solution to the problem of unemployment. If seen as such, it promotes social dumping and job security.  The migration of workers must be their free choice, from one safe working environment to another. However, although the report was initiated in the above context, the trilogue ensured the increased participation of government agencies in the platform, reducing the role of private job-finding enterprises, as well as the introduction of the social partners as partners on this platform. It is also, in essence, a platform for finding work.  As an ACPL we cannot ignore this, nor can we ignore the right of anyone to move to find work. For the above reasons we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The update of the Regulation, which has already been agreed with the Council, will enable greater participation in the "social partners" (employers and trade unions) and will focus more on cross-border areas and young people. The new, "smarter" EURES portal will automatically match CVs with the appropriate jobs offered without any discrimination on the basis of nationality. All jobs published by public bodies in the Member States will be made available pan-European through the same web portal. We are voting against this report as we are against cross-border work and worker mobility. Member States should have had the option of not participating in the EURES network.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on further integration of labour markets, as I believe that all instruments to strengthen the labour market will contribute to the creation of a stronger European Union. I believe that the effective linking of public and private sector job offers in the Member States can bring significant benefits. It should be noted, however, that the willingness of workers to mobility is not equal in the different states of the Union, and in many cases we also see regional and seasonal mobility and labour shortages. I think that the fact that there are different social benefits and conditions of employment in different Member States is a cause for concern. So I believe that the new EURES instrument can be useful, but not enough alone. Regional information and incentives for employment and services are needed. All so that all information is published in all 24 languages at the same time. However, I believe that concessions to prevent the 'Brexit' that is emerging now could seriously jeopardise this important ambition. Claims for concessions may also appear in other Member States, but in this case the linking of the system may have a doubtful effect.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The free movement of workers is one of the key conditions for the development of a more integrated EU labour market, especially in cross-border regions, enabling greater labour mobility, thereby contributing to greater diversity and the finding of people with the right skills for vacancies. The last years of the financial and economic crisis have forced Member States such as the European Union to take a number of measures to increase the employability of workers and to help employers fill vacancies better and faster. Unfortunately, intra-EU labour mobility remains relatively low, which is countered by the creation of the European Network of Employment Services. This platform is intended to provide the widemest possible pool of job vacancies and jobseeker profiles at pan-European level. It also offers apprenticeships and apprenticeships. As Parliament pointed out in its report, it is necessary to ensure that the platform is easily accessible and as user-friendly as possible, while properly cooperating with existing national employment agencies. I believe that the European Commission's initiative is the right one, provided that it does not in any way limit the ability of individual Member States to pursue their own employment policies.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The latest European statistics show very low mobility rates (0.29%), which does not favour the free movement of workers within the European Union. This is determined by language barriers and difficulties in finding work. I voted in favour of the European network of employment services, as it plays an important role in providing specific information and services, which benefit both employers and frontier workers. Europe needs structures that facilitate mobility and create an integrated and balanced labour market, so as to reduce the gap between countries with high unemployment and those with labour shortages. Furthermore, we must also not forget people with disabilities, mentioned in the resolution, who require more support and easier access to services and information when they are looking for work. At M5S, we support a labour market that provides more information on working conditions and services offered in the workplace.  In our opinion, the person seeking employment abroad should have the same level of support as he or she might have in his country of origin.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to transform the EURES network into an effective instrument for any job seeker or employer interested in labour mobility within the European Union by making accessible and transparent a vast pool of job offers and profiles of job seekers throughout Europe. Apprenticeship training and internships must also be integrated into the European network, provided that a regular employment contract exists.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the introduction of the EURES network, creating the largest possible job-search platform which can be consulted by anyone in Europe, encouraging the free movement of workers and the labour market’s further integration. Helping workers to obtain information about employment opportunities where their skills are needed and ensuring their mobility inside the Union, as well as increasing cooperation between labour markets, are actions key to improving and accelerating employment inside the EU. This is particularly important for cross-border regions. In addition, freedom of movement is one of the four basic freedoms on which the EU is founded.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The free movement of workers is one of the essential elements of the development of a more integrated labour market, enabling workers to become more mobile, increasing diversity and contributing to the social inclusion and integration throughout the European Union of people excluded from the labour market. Favoring her must be our mission. Member States should be able to exclude certain categories of apprenticeships and traineeships from the correspondence of vacancies and applications for employment, in order to ensure the coherence and functioning of their education systems and to take into account the need to define their active labour policy measures according to the needs of the workers concerned by such measures.  It is essential to improve the quality of traineeships, in particular in relation to the content of learning and training and working conditions, with the aim of facilitating the transition from education, unemployment or inactivity to work.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ As an MP coming from Croatia, a member of the European Union who has faced the problem of young educated people going abroad in recent years in search of work and a better life, I do not support measures that provide additional incentives and opportunities for young people to leave their countries.  I repeat once again that such measures are not effective and beneficial for all Member States, because despite the fact that young people are largely involved in the high unemployment rate, I believe that such mobility promotions can further harm the economies of Member States such as Croatia. I believe that the focus should be on spotting differences in labour markets in the Member States and designing programmes that will enable job creation and thus provide an opportunity for young people to reach their potential in their countries. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of employment services, access to mobility services and further integration of labour markets, as the renewed EURES will make a significant contribution to reducing unemployment in the EU Member States and to speeding up the coordination of supply and demand for jobs.  They will be able to join EURES, in addition to public employment services, including private agencies and NGOs. Vacancies will thus be publicly available and accessible to all.  I believe that this will reduce unemployment even among vulnerable groups. I am convinced that EURES will also have a positive impact on increasing the employment mobility of citizens within the EU.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative proposal which aims to facilitate workers' access to services to support the labour mobility of intra-European workers, to support fairer mobility and to increase access to employment opportunities in the Union through the review of EURES. The report ensures recognition of cross-border agreements with their own special objectives and competences, in particular for frontier workers; the social partners are included in EURES bodies at European and national level, and EURES will provide information, with specially individualised guidance for workers. The information provided to workers (on the country to which they are transferred, placement options) will generally be free, while employers may be charged for special services (EURES may offer post-treatment services but with fee payment). Workers must also give their authorization for the publication of job applications and CVs on the network and may withdraw their consent. That is why, among other things, I think it is a positive report and I voted in favour.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The free movement of workers is one of the founding pillars of the Union and the establishment of a structured cooperation network allowing all European citizens access to all job offers appears to be a logical mechanism for the achievement of a single employment market to which the National Front is opposed. The issues raised are: - visibility and access to the network remain complex, despite apparent good intentions; - linking offers and demands at a European level poses obvious logistical and resource problems; - this system tends to promote "brain drain" and thus to widen inequalities between Southern and Eastern Europe and that of the North and West; - EURES ("European Employment Pole") promotes mobility blackmail, whereby an unemployed person would not want to work if he is not ready to take an offer in Europe, wherever it is, which could potentially pose difficulties, concerning unemployment benefits; - this system promotes the uprooting of workers, imposes the European single market on employment as the only alternative to unemployment and institutionalises the precariousness of employment. So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of this proposal for a regulation is to improve workers' access to services supporting labour mobility within the EU, thereby promoting fair mobility and ensuring better access to employment opportunities throughout the Union. The overall objective of the proposal is to make the EURES network an effective tool for all jobseekers and employers interested in labour mobility within the EU. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EURES network was launched a few years ago to facilitate the free movement of workers in the EU. The main aim of the platform is to provide assistance to workers to overcome barriers to mobility and increase access to employment across the EU. In recent years, a number of shortcomings have been identified in the functioning of this network, in particular with regard to unequal access to network services within the Union and the lack of exchange of information between Member States on the labour shortage and surplus. The legislative proposal debated by the European Parliament envisages correcting the shortcomings found in the functioning of the network, making the network an accessible and efficient instrument, and reorienting the services provided by EURES from general information and guidance to improving placement and recruitment. The new provisions aim to bring together all job offers, job applications and CVs available from public employment services within the Member States within the platform.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive because I am a strong supporter of the fundamental right of free movement. I therefore support this legislative piece of the labour market package, aiming at facilitating worker mobility and thus contributing to the cohesion and integration of labour markets and diversity. Even though I believe EURES advisors play a key role in providing personalised support to jobseekers to ensure they can make informed decisions when looking for or taking up a job abroad.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The free choice of a job in the EU is an integral part of freedom of movement, which is one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union and therefore an essential element of EU citizenship. Given the high unemployment rate in some regions of Europe, there is a need to increase the mobility of workers in the EU, improve workers' employability and help employers to increase the vacancies they offer more effectively and more quickly. This contributes to the creation of a European labour market with high employment.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of employment services, workers’ access to mobility services and the further integration of labour markets. The European Employment Service network (EURES) is an EU-wide database of job-seekers and vacancies, established in 1993 as a cooperation network between the Commission and the public employment services of the EU Member States (plus Switzerland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein), and partners: private job agencies, trade unions, employers’ associations. However, several important limitations such as an incomplete database of job vacancies and CVs, limited automated matching potential and insufficient cross-border labour information have prevented it from functioning efficiently and further integrating the Member States labour markets.  I voted in favour of improving the European Employment Services (EURES) network with the aim of helping fight unemployment by better matching the labour market supply and demand and paying more attention to cross-border regions and young people.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. All instruments that facilitate and improve the free movement of workers are welcome. In this sense, the European Employment Services Network, EURES, is craving a tool that will facilitate this task and balance labour markets across the Union. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the go-ahead to the agreement with the Council to launch a series of measures aimed at improving the intra-European labour mobility platform called EURES, which has been in place since 1993.  Among the progress that will be made, thanks to the push of the Socialist Group, are the fact that the EURES web portal will finally become a European platform for the exchange of job offers and resumes; that the new intelligent database, with the new IT platform, will allow automatic crossover of resumes with job offers; and that all vacancies published by public or private employment agencies will be published across the EU.  In addition, EURES will have the participation of the social partners at all levels of the network, eliminate the basic services for workers and ensure that the internship and apprenticeship contracts offered within its framework comply with EU standards and the social and employment standards of the Member States.  I believe that as a whole the agreement fulfils the objectives and priorities of the Socialist Group and is a step forward for European workers and citizens.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Draft Legislative Motion; it is important that workers are able to exercise their right of free movement across the European Union, this is to help rectify skill shortages and prevent bottle necks. However this needs to be approached in a fair way that allows people of all skill levels to apply their skills. I agree that Member States should be able ‘to exclude certain vacancies for apprenticeships and traineeships due to the differences in their educational systems and their active labour market policies.’ This should allow Member States to maintain flexibility in their education and training policies. What is vital to maintain here is the balance between the active policy that is required from the European Union to ensure that progress is made and that coordination is improved, but that this is matched by the recognition that labour market is a Member State competence beyond the specifics of the Treaty in regard to the single employment market.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'We need to better align vacancies and job seekers in the European Union. The European Parliament therefore wants to modernise the EURES database, the European VDAB. This database is a good tool for boosting labour mobility in the EU and combating unemployment.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since 1993, the EU has established a European employment database and partners (employment agencies, trade unions, employers' associations) with a European employment database as part of a network of cooperation between the European Commission. This database was intended to allow for the pooling of job offers and CVs and to provide additional opportunities for matching vacancies with unemployed people. This database quickly became obsolete and many gaps were found. This regulation purports to modernize this system. At a time when the European Union has more than 22 million unemployed people, although I have little illusions about the effectiveness of this type of tool as long as eu-employment is put in competition, I believe that no tool can be rejected by primary anti-Europeanism. The National Front has made the opposite choice, once again revealing its true social choices. Whose act.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes amendments to the EURES Regulation and not its development. The commission's original text mentions some issues that deserve opposition (the relationship between the labour market and school curricula, for example), but, in general, it presents changes that are positive, such as extending the network to the promotion of traineeships and training or, first of all, not arguing with compulsory mobility. It proposes amendments that give more prominence to Member States and their structures (employment and training), ensure the involvement of the social partners, see mobility as an essentially cross-border issue and ensure the gratuity of all services provided by EURES. In this sense, the regulation is more positive. It is understood that a network facilitating voluntary mobility, such as that presented in this report, is an interesting development

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. As the report in EURES sees the cure for the lack of jobs, the aim is to further develop the platform. There is no discussion of volunteering on the platform. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of employment services, access of workers to mobility-enhancing services and the further integration of labour markets. I am opposed to the further development of the EU's institutions until there has been a real reform of the EU. Nor do I see any persuasiveness in the plan to help more jobseekers find work through cooperation between European employment services and appropriate bureaucracy at EU level. This puts little burden on the taxpayer, as expected. What saves the project is the fact that companies can decide for themselves whether their job vacancies are advertised across the EU.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European labour market policies have a great economic potential and can also break down barriers between citizens, fostering meaningful exchange and understanding.  Such labour market policies must take into account the obstacles encountered by those facing multiple discrimination, such as women in sectors where they are underrepresented, ethnic minorities, migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, LGBTI persons, or persons with disabilities. There must be a particular effort to promote the representation of women in STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and maths). European policy on employment services must be compatible with equivalent policies in education, vocational training, and life-long learning.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the EP report on the regulation which aims to make EURES an effective tool for anyone looking for a job or employer interested in labour mobility within the EU. This regulation explicitly establishes that labour market policy, including all support measures, remains within the exclusive competence of the Member States. The EP report entitled 'European Network of Employment Services, Workers' Access to Mobility Services and The Further Integration of Labour Markets' shows that the success of the EURES network will depend on the networking of effective public and private employment services in the Member States and on targeted efforts at EU level to increase the visibility of the network , in the form of sustained communication actions by the Commission and the Member States aimed at the general public.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 One of the EU's fundamental four freedoms is the free movement of labour within the EU. Due to the high unemployment within some regions, labour mobility needs to be strengthened. I therefore support this proposal, which turns EURES into an effective tool for jobseekers or employers interested in occupational mobility within the EU. This will create as many job vacancies and profiles as possible for jobseekers, which will also include apprenticeships and traineeships. The inclusion of public and private employment services in EURES is also an important aspect.  By increasing the number of partners offering mobility services within this network, EURES will become an effective tool for reducing unemployment across the EU. An important factor in the integration of labour markets will be the remuneration system for these workers.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The EURES network will not only not provide relief to the unemployed, but instead constitutes another elaborate mechanism for undermining the right to permanent fixed work with rights which, as the Commission has recently stated, it does not recognise.  This 'network' has existed for decades, and is now always being reconstituted in a reactionary direction to further 'promote mobility', for the 'adaptable' workforce. This now includes the 'private employment offices', i.e. the slave trade offices, including the notorious 'employee rental companies', but also the employers' organisations themselves.  They are upgraded, that is to say, legitimized and with the help of the slave trade offices to provide capitalists with cheap and "flexible" labour, without rights, for temporary and underpaid jobs, as much as the boss wants. The GUE and the MEPs of SYRIZA, as well as the other parties of the Euro-one-way (ND, PASOK, Potami) voted in favour, since they agree with the perpetuation of capitalist exploitation in order to secure the profits of capital.  Unemployment is intertwined with the rotten capitalist system served by the EU and the parties of urban management. The only way out is to strengthen the working-class popular struggle to overthrow it to make the people the owner of the wealth it produces.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Free movement of labour is one of the fundamental freedoms of the European Union, and I therefore also support this report, which contains fundamental proposals for improving the EURES network. I consider it necessary for EURES to be a truly effective tool for both jobseekers and employers. Especially for young people. I therefore very much welcome the proposal to include apprenticeships and traineeships in the EURES database. Both apprenticeships and traineeships provide a better position for young people to seek employment.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EURES reform report. I was shadow rapporteur in this report and, in the course of the negotiations, we have sought to find the broadest possible consensus so that the portal is an instrument of practical and effective assistance and combines supply with demand across the European Union. I think that, now that the free movement of workers in the European Union is working, it is very important that employers and applicants have a common place where they can meet and that would make it easier for them to offer or find work. In a situation where there are large differences in the number of job vacancies between Member States, such a portal is a very desirable means. However, we must not forget that, although working abroad broadens the horizons, offers new experiences and knowledge, among them highly valued language skills, it should not be the only way for people to apply to the labour market. We should always bear in mind that a person who wants to live and work in his home country should have opportunities right there and should not be forced to go elsewhere for work. However, when he so decides, I hope that the improved EURES portal will provide him with useful help in this.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A sustained increase in employment levels in the Member States and the offset of the risk of unemployment is an objective that can only be fully achieved with close cooperation within the European Union. Freedom of movement for workers is one of the greatest advantages of Polish membership within the EU, but in order to fully exploit its potential, the exchange of information on job offers in different Member States should work much better.  Eures, which has existed since 1994, is a tool for coordinating national employment policies at European level. However, the functioning of this system needs to be adapted to new conditions, including increased labour mobility and new communication channels. The traditional structure of this network requires the addition and inclusion not only of public employment services, but also of further partners representing the private sector and non-profit organisations. Enlargement also requires the scope of EURES activities, which, in addition to information on job offers, should take into account training and traineeships, which are an essential element of vocational education. It is also right to call for new tools based on digital technologies that will quickly and efficiently associate employers with employees. I also agree with the proposal to increase the role of this platform in the process of collecting and communicating knowledge about the recruitment process, in particular the provision of this knowledge to small and medium-sized enterprises that require specific support. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this regulation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European network of employment services, access for workers to mobility services and further integration of labour markets, because I agree with the purpose of the regulation that the regulatory framework needs to be revised to reflect new types of work patterns, mobility and work life and the growing role of other labour market intermediaries who, in addition to public employment services, provide job placement services.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Tunisia has made very significant democratic progress in recent years. It is a key partner of the European Union for the development of democracy and human rights in the Maghreb, an example of validation of the Arab Spring. That is why we have to give it our strongest support on this path of overcoming and that is why I voted in favour of the introduction of emergency trade measures in Tunisia, but I do not agree to incorporate the amendments which sought to give a protectionist and physical approach to oil. As a member of this Parliament originally from Spain, I consider, of course, the need to be careful, to see the impact and to establish the measures already envisaged by this Resolution with regard to protection, but we must support anything that means its development, and that is why I would also like to reflect that I miss a permanent appeal to Tunisia to defend human rights at the highest level and , in particular, to stop harassment of the LGBTI community, because it is a scourge that does not have to be allowed on that path to democracy.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I voted against because I am sure that these measures do not serve to help the people or farmers of Tunisia: they are measures to lower the cost of olive, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in the southern countries and also in Tunisia. There is also no guarantee that this olive oil will not come to the European market below the actual costs of production and there is also no guarantee that there will be no ecological and social dumping.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Since the regime change in Tunisia more than five years ago, its economy has embarked on a long-term reform path, a restructuring process. There are, however, some sectors that remain the primary national one – olive oil production is one of those. Before the revolution, it occupied seventh place in the world. As in a number of other similar cases, a decision was taken today to support the Tunisian economy through the introduction of a temporary quota for olive oil imports to the European Union of 35000 tonnes (that is a lot!) for two years until the end of 2017. And this is to be welcomed, at least because Tunisia is not only one of the eu's most important southern partners, but also helping it to some extent to stimulate the stability of the internal state, an increase that indirectly affects us as well.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I also subscribe to the fact that I supported this report with my vote, and the reason was beyond doubt. I think it is necessary to appreciate the progress that Tunisia has made in the five years that it has already made it to, say, the Club of Democratic States. For me, it is important that this appreciation of their progress should be despite the fact that I do not deny that there is some impact on olive oil producers. On the other hand, I think we need to appreciate this country as such, even if there are some negative consequences. These are negative consequences from a looser market, and if we want to help Tunisia, I think that this price and this tax is acceptable.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sa tuarascáil seo mar a rinne 478 bhfeisire eile, agus 123 ag vótáil ina coinne. Is dóigh liom gur tuarascáil thábhachtach í seo agus caithfimid gach aon chabhair is féidir linn a thabhairt don Túinéis. I think the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia is very important and indeed critical at this particular time, particularly because of the geopolitical position there. The Commission has adopted a proposal for a regulation offering an additional temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota for Tunisia’s export of olive oil to the EU under the form of autonomous trade measures. I think this makes sense because up to a million people are employed, either directly or indirectly, in the production of olive oil. It is also sensible that we should have a mid-term impact assessment to see how it is impacting on our own suppliers here in Europe and, if it is negatively impacting, we could take corrective measures.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The EP Socialists understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. An additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia since the conviction that these measures are not to help Tunisian farmers and farmers, but are measures to reduce the cost of olives, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in southern European countries and also tunisia. Nor is there any guarantee that such oil will not enter the European Union below actual production costs or that organic or social dumping will not occur. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for the Tunisian Republic. This text aims to help Tunisia, whose economy is largely disrupted by suicide bombings in the country. However, the measures announced would affect European olive growers, as the price of olive oil has already been falling steadily over the past decade. Not taking this reality into account, the Commission is making proposals here that will jeopardise our olive growers, whereas Tunisia could have been helped through other means.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 After the Arab Spring, Tunisia is the country model in the transition process to the Republic. As part of its effort to help the country, both politically and economicly, the European Union has decided to import an additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil duty-free.  With amendments tabled - and I co-signed with other Socialist MEPs - we have tried to put some conditions under which the Tunisian economy could also be supported and not have a negative impact on Greek and European olive oil production. Unfortunately, these amendments were not voted for by Parliament's plenary and that is why I had to vote against the resolution as a whole.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The country is currently in serious economic difficulties in the face of the horrific terrorist attacks that hit Tunisia last year. Against this background, the Commission presented Parliament with a first a sensible proposal for a regulation on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. For 2016 and 2017, the text introduces a duty-free quota of 35 000 tonnes of virgin olive oil, which has been produced entirely in Tunisia. Halfway through, however, the impact of this trade measure on the Union's olive oil market will also be evaluated. If it is found that the Union market is affected, the Commission may take corrective action.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. At present, Tunisia's economy is experiencing a serious crisis due in particular to the terrorist attacks it is facing. The European Commission, in order to help it, recommends an increase of 35,000 tonnes in the import of duty-free olive oil. Currently, the amount of Tunisian olive oil exempted amounts to 56,700 tons. This measure applies for 2016. Considering that this decision will put European olive growers in difficulty, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report. This report is giving Tunisia trade preference over other countries in the misguided belief it will prevent people turning to ISIS. This notion presented here by the EU has been proved to based on fantasy and not facts. This is a dangerous precedent to set. A healthy economy will not stop people supporting terrorism; poor people do not automatically support ISIS. It is offensive to suggest so.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. 'U2012 Emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia are part of a strategy to support the young Tunisian democracy, the only successful case of the Arab Spring. Hit by terrorist attacks aimed at destabilising the country, faced with serious problems on its borders, notably in Libya, and in the face of a fragile economic and social situation, it is of great importance that Europe gives a clear signal of support to the Tunisian democratic regime.  EU countries should not regard openness to Tunisia as a circumstantial threat to specific European economic sectors, but rather as an aid to support a still very fragile democracy. Support in a number of areas should be seen as essential to preventing a serious problem in that country, with unpredictable consequences on European territory itself. At a time when the next day's lucidity experts are focusing on blaming Europe for not acting preemptively and are dedicated to taking it entirely accountable for the dramatic human rights trampling problems in the North Africa and the Middle East, it would be important that they do not oppose a proposal aimed at democraticstabilisation of a country facing serious problems.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the application of urgent autonomous trade measures to the Republic of Tunisia. The European Commission proposes the introduction of an autonomous trade instrument providing for a temporary unilateral tariff quota for Tunisia, which allows it to export 35 000 tonnes of olive oil per year duty-free to the Union. This quota will apply for two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. I agree that the EU should help revitalise the economy in Tunisia, but union solidarity should not be implemented at the expense of southern European farmers, in this particular case at the expense of olive growers. The EU is the global leader in the sector of olive oil, the production of which should be the main economic and social support in production areas. It is in large areas of EU countries, where economic crises are even more serious, that the olive oil sector provides thousands of jobs and, because of its importance, exports to third countries contribute to a positive trade balance for the EU. I agree that the Commission must carry out impact assessments of the proposed measures for the European agricultural sector and amend the measures if it appears that they are likely to harm EU olive oil producers.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 For Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the EU, the European Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes per year. This discount would be available to Tunisia by December 2017. The most important olive oil producers in the EU are mediterranean countries. These countries have also been severely affected by the crisis. Unemployment is high in all four countries above the EU average. (Portugal, Spain, Italy, Greece – unemployment above 10% in the former two and above 20% in the latter two). Solidarity with Tunisia is positive in itself, but in this case it would be more justified to worry about our own industry, our own economy. The rapporteur acknowledges this in the explanatory memorandum to the draft: "At the same time, it reiterates that EU solidarity is at the expense of farmers in southern Europe, in this case olive oil producers. The EU is a world leader in the olive oil sector, whose production is the main economic and social maintenance force in production areas. In particular, in large areas of EU countries severely affected by the economic crisis, the olive oil sector provides thousands of jobs and its significant share of exports to third countries contributes to the EU's positive trade balance." Against this all, I did not support the adoption of the referral.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
