text: In writing. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by the sharp drop in tourist traffic due to the country's terrorist risk and political instability, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 30,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. The measure is expected to last until December 31, 2017. We could have helped Tunisia in other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. Should we remind these gentlemen of the Commission that the price of olive oil has been falling steadily over the last 10 years?  That is why I voted against this false good idea.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In order to help Tunisia in the wake of the Sousse attack last June, this report proposes to offer, on an exceptional and temporary basis, a zero-duty tariff quota of 70,000 euros in 2 years for Tunisia's olive oil exports to the EU, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without increasing the overall volume of imports. A mid-term review of the impact on the EU market will be carried out. I approved this report.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis and Sousse last year made the process of consolidating democracy in Tunisia difficult. Support for the Maghreb country is one of the priorities of the Union's foreign policy in the Mediterranean area and an objective closely linked to maintaining stability in the Middle East region. In an attempt to achieve these objectives, the Commission has proposed as an autonomous, unilateral and temporary trade measure a duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, a total of 70 000 tonnes for Tunisian olive oil exports to the Union, without increasing the overall volume of imports.  Although I consider the Commission's aim to be noble and acceptable, I voted against the de Sarnez report because, since some of the key amendments proposed were rejected, I believe that this measure can have a negative impact on the European and Italian olive sector, without, however, having positive effects on the Tunisian economy. The Tunisian producers themselves, moreover, expressed through "Le Forum Tunisien pour les Droits Économiques et Sociaux" (FTDES) and "l'Union générale tunisienne du travail" (UGTT), a position of great concern about the measures.  I believe that the EU needs to find more effective and broader options to support tunisia's economy and the country's democratic institutions.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against these extraordinary trade measures because I believe that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, not by favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society but the olive oil-producing undertakings with exporting capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of Tunisian oil imported under the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement, which is currently in the negotiation phase.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work done in the report and welcome the adoption of the proposal for a Regulation on the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia. On the other hand, I must point out that I have not followed the group's line in relation to Amendments Nos 11, 12, 13 and 14, which referred to olive oil. I have supported more fee-free imports of olive oil to help Tunisia, but guarantees are needed.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU for the years 2016-2017. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. Unfortunately, this mechanism will further undermine European olive growers since the price of oil has tended to fall continuously over the past 10 years.  The Commission thus applies foreign preference and sacrifices European olive oil producers in order to support the Tunisian economy. This report is the very symbol of the failure of Europeanist logics. So I voted against it.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. Tunisia's economy is hard hit by terrorist attacks. The Commission proposes zero tariffs for imports of olives from Tunisia during the period from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017, for the already agreed levels of olive imports. Olive groves account for one fifth of Tunisia's agricultural employment and provide jobs for more than one million people. The Left Party supports increased trade in the agricultural sector for this region. However, the very central and important issue of debt cancellation was not addressed. I believe that debt cancellation for Tunisia is a better way of supporting the country's economy, both short-term and long-term, and I want to see an economic policy that goes that way.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists in the EP understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. In addition to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country, an additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the temporary application of emergency measures to facilitate trade in Tunisia. For 2015 Tunisia and in 2015 The terrorist attacks in Ssa have hit the Tunisian economy hard, but there have already been major economic difficulties in Tunisia before these events. Against this background, the European Union wishes to reaffirm its support for Tunisia and is therefore taking concrete steps to support Tunisia's economic development. The European Commission therefore proposes to introduce a unilateral temporary autonomous trade measure, which provides for a tariff quota for Tunisia, which allows this country to export duty-free to the Union 35 000 tonnes of olive oil per year, that is, a total of 70 000 tonnes, without increasing the total volume of imports. This quota shall be fixed for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 and may apply from the date on which the tariff quota of 56 700 tonnes of zero tariff currently applicable in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia is exhausted. This measure will be of great benefit to the Tunisian economy. Tunisia's olive-growing sector indirectly creates more than one million jobs, accounting for one fifth of the country's total agricultural sector jobs. In addition, olive oil is mainly exported tunisian agricultural product.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Tunisia's economy is in a bad state, especially after the terrorist attacks of less than a year ago. Therefore, the EU or The Commission is handing the hand to Tunisia and its economy by proposing to impose a duty-free quota of a total of 70 000 tonnes per year for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the EU, without increasing the total volume of imports. The measure aims to help the Tunisian economy, where the olive sector provides jobs for one million people, which is a fifth of all agricultural jobs. Olive oil is also the main agricultural product that Tunisia exports. I myself agree with the kind of solidarity that the EU expresses towards Tunisia, but we must be very careful not to hurt our own farmers, especially from southern Europe. In the countries most affected by the economic crisis, the olive oil sector is of paramount importance for maintaining jobs, exports and economic stability. Prices have been falling for a long time and farmers have been plagued by an increase in production costs for a long time.  The impact of this measure on the European agricultural sector should not be ignored, which is why I also supported the relevant amendments to the proposal, which make this partially possible.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a report on the European Parliament and Council regulations on the introduction of emergency trade measures for Tunisia. To do this, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. This will put European olive growers in difficulty, who have already seen the price of olive oil fall over the past decade. So I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's willingness to help a friendly country such as Tunisia, which is unfortunately facing an economic and political crisis today and the threats of international Islamic terrorism which is destabilising large areas of Africa and the Middle East, is certainly laudable. However, the way to help the Republic of Tunisia is wrong: real aid cannot be reduced to a trade facilitation measure. In order to really help, we need to create the conditions for a free trade area with common rules and parameters, with a view to structural cooperation on shared principles of protection of civil rights and of citizens, consumers and producers. Simply thinking of increasing oil imports and abolishing duties is a wrong measure that would only achieve the destruction of the local economies of oil and olive producers in southern European countries, with particularly negative repercussions especially on Italy, Spain and Greece.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation on the establishment of emergency autonomous trade measures for the Tunisian Republic. In concrete terms, the Commission wishes to support Tunisia, which is facing a double crisis, terrorist and economic, following the terrible attacks that hit Tunisia on 25 November 2015. To do this, the proposed regulation provides for an additional duty-free import quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil, with the current quota set at 56,700 tonnes. The granting of this new advantage will weigh seriously on the Italian and French oil industry, without addressing the fundamental problems facing Tunisia. Once again, the European Union believes that it is by punishing European producers that we will put an end to Islamist terrorism that is rampant around the Mediterranean. I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2015 terrorist attack in Sousse, Tunisia, led to the Council of the European Union asserting in its conclusions that the Union, in consultation with the Member States, will consider the possibility of taking exceptional and temporary measures to support the Tunisian economy, which was already facing great difficulties.  Further to this initiative, the European Commission proposes to unilaterally offer Tunisia, on a temporary basis, a duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes annually, a total of 70 000 tonnes, for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of an autonomous trade measure, without increasing the overall volume of imports. In order to prevent fraud and to ensure that the autonomous commercial measures envisaged will bring real benefits to the Tunisian economy, they should be conditional on Tunisia complying with the relevant Union rules on the origin of the products and the related procedures. In this difficult context that Tunisia is going through, I voted in favour to reaffirm the support of the European Union, by acting concretely to the economic development of Tunisia and, at the same time, to promote democracy in Tunisia.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure comes to life from an intervention in person by High Commissioner Mogherini to help Tunisia hit by the crisis in the tourism sector following the recent attacks. It calls for a zero-tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil to be allowed to enter the EU further.  It is clear that the price of this 'aid' would only be paid by certain Member States such as Italy, while for the most part it would be a zero-impact measure. Furthermore, this intervention would only favour the multinationals of the fake 'made in Italy', which place on the Union market huge quantities of olive oil that looks Italian, but which is such – when it is good – only in part.  To this must be added that: EU legislation on the labelling of olive oil does not allow the consumer to recognise the origin of the oil he buys; there is very little certainty about the standards of plant health controls in Tunisia; 100% Italian olive oil producers would be at a disadvantage compared to their competitors, as the measure would be reduced – de facto – to a discount on the cost of the raw material for multinationals that already have much lower production costs today. I am against granting the measures!

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists in the EP understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. In addition to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country, an additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. In September 2015, the European Commission proposed the unilateral and temporary introduction of a zero-duty tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes per year for olive oil exports from Tunisia to the European Union for a period of two years. The aim of this proposal is to help Tunisia after the attacks in Sousse in June 2015 which had a negative impact on the country's economy. Olive oil is a very important part of the Tunisian economy.  I voted in favour of this report. I believe that it is very important to help neighbouring countries, especially when they are victims of the abominations of terrorism. Tunisia is in the midst of a democratic transition and we must absolutely support it in this perilous process.  However, in a European context of agricultural crisis, we must ensure that this type of measure does not endanger the European agricultural sector. Olive oil producers are mainly located in the southern EU countries, which are also experiencing economic difficulties. I voted in favour of a text that guarantees some protection for European producers while allowing tunisia to be helped.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted against the proposal on the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures in favour of the Republic of Tunisia and in favour of rejecting the proposal. I believe that the European Union is obliged to assist the Tunisian economy. However, this aid cannot be at the expense of olive oil producers. At present, the European Commission's proposal could have a negative impact on the olive sector in the countries of southern Europe and, in particular, Italy. As a result, I voted in favour of four corrective amendments that I tabled together with my colleagues in the European Parliament's AGRI Committee.  Unfortunately, only two of the four corrective amendments have passed and I have therefore voted against the whole proposal, as announced in my speech in plenary on this point. The ball is now in the Council's way, where I hope that the governments of the Member States, particularly those in southern Europe, will be able to assert the interests of the oil companies.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which unilaterally offers Tunisia 35 000 tonnes of olive oil exports at zero duty. This decision is in light of the negative effects of terrorist attacks on the Tunisian economy. The extra tariff quotas would be in place for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. Although I do not agree that trade liberalisation is the best tool for boosting developing economies, as it can often have the effect of concentrating wealth in a few hands, olive oil is Tunisia’s biggest agricultural export and employs in the region of one million people directly and indirectly. I therefore voted in favour of this temporary measure.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of free trade, because the usual arguments we all know about efficiency, the incentive to improve, and so on. I believe, however, that an important aspect of the economic models that have led to the free trade arguments is often underestimated: that there are invalid hypotheses when it comes to agricultural goods.  My vote to close tunisian oil is not a protectionist vote, however much that effect is, but a vote to defend consumers who would find themselves on supermarket shelves two apparently identical products, but with a huge price difference, without the means to go and see if the quality is the same. I have always fought to reward the quality of agri-food products, and this case is no exception.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. I am sympathetic to Tunisia, which seeks to consolidate its democracy and recover an economy that has been further damaged by the 2015 terrorist attacks in Tunis and Sousse. I agree that the EU should provide support that favours Tunisia's economic development. This solidarity, however, must be an EU-whole effort and should not be translated mainly into a penalty for southern European countries. This proposal aims to facilitate the entry into the European market duty-free of 70,000 tonnes of olive oil, to be added to the 56,700 provided for in the Association Agreement. As the EP Committee on Agriculture recalls, the EU is the world leader in the olive oil sector, whose production represents the main economic and social support of producing regions, securing thousands of jobs in many regions of the EU countries most severely affected by the economic crisis. Moreover, the trend in olive oil developments in the last ten years has been the continuous fall in prices and the decrease in crop profitability as a result of a steady increase in production costs. For all this, I abstained in the final vote, since the amendments I have endorsed have not been adopted.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote against the proposal for a regulation because although the aims of this regulation are right, the instruments used to achieve the objectives do not consider them absolutely correct, especially if we talk about the import of more than 70 thousand tons of Tunisian duty-free oil. We cannot mortify agriculture and specifically the oil production of Southern Europe, as in the case of Italy, which boasts a heritage of 250 million olive trees and is the only country with 533 varieties of olives and 43 oils protected by the European Union, but above all a country where oil is one of the symbolic products of Made in Italy and the Mediterranean diet. It is also not right for all those Apulian olive producers who have been fighting against Xylella for months.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia since the conviction that these measures are not to help Tunisian farmers and farmers, but are measures to reduce the cost of olives, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in southern European countries and also tunisia. Nor is there any guarantee that such oil will not enter the European Union below actual production costs or that organic or social dumping will not occur. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution because, the failure to adopt part of the amendments tabled in plenary, prevented some of the doubts and uncertainties raised by the measure from being dispelled. I have chosen not to vote for the request to reject the proposal, because I believe that, as the EU, we cannot be insensitive or unsy side-of-the-way with what is happening on the other side of our sea, only to suffer the consequences helpadever.  Solidarity and help cannot be 'in words'. On the other hand, I have found and find the measure hasty and poorly analytical in predicting the consequences on our productive fabrics. That is why I signed and supported a number of amendments which, without questioning cooperation and solidarity with our neighbours, introduced important safeguard clauses, taking into account the needs of everyone, including European producers.  Unfortunately, only a few of these amendments have been accepted and this, in my opinion, has produced a report that is still stumped and deficient and which I did not feel I should support. I trust that, in the further discussions with the Council and the Commission, the spirit and the letter of the amendments can be recovered, so that we have a truly united proposal towards all the parties involved.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and in Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy. In this situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia and its economic development. Accordingly, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota in the form of autonomous trade measures for tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union of 35 000 tonnes per year, without any increase in the total import volume. The tariff quota will be available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and will become available after the tariff-free tariff quota of 56 700 tons fixed in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia and currently in force has been exhausted. If the new quota would be detrimental to the commercial interests of the Member States or would have adverse consequences for the internal market, the Union shall be entitled to take the necessary steps to eliminate it. I supported the solution.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The terrorist attack of 26 June 2015 in Sous has sparked a debate in the EU on the need to continue to support Tunisia in its political and economic transition in a concrete and targeted way, through actions that can be effective in the short term. In this context, the European Commission proposes a temporary, unilateral and duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of autonomous trade measures. Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product exported to the EU, and the olive oil sector is an important part of the national economy, providing directly and indirectly employment for more than one million people, which together accounts for one fifth of employment in the entire agricultural sector. Given the nature of the support tool, I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as I strongly believe that the European Union must support Tunisia to regain stability, particularly since it is facing a politically and economically difficult period. Terrorist attacks in Tunisia are leading to difficulties, primarily in the economy. Stronger trade relations with the European Union would be beneficial for Tunisia to be able to revive its economy. I am in favour of the legislation proposed as it is a concrete example of EU support towards stability in Tunisia, which ultimately would contribute to stability in the Mediterranean region.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures in favour of the Republic of Tunisia will allow the entry of 70 000 tonnes of Tunisian duty-free oil into the European Union over the next two years. The aim of the proposal would be to resurrect a key sector of the Tunisian economy, following the tragic terrorist attacks that sent its other key sector, tourism, into crisis. Although I therefore support the intention, the measures proposed by the European Commission do not respond effectively to the need to support Tunisia's economic recovery in a structural way. I am convinced that a strategy that integrated European cooperation and development policies with trade measures would have made it possible instead to consolidate tunisia's olive production system and make it competitive in the long term, more generally supporting the economic and political stability of the country. On the contrary, they will bring limited benefits to Tunisia, for a transitional period only. In addition, it has been decided to introduce measures that will damage our production and increase the risk of fraud in this sector, to the detriment of quality and credibility with European consumers. I therefore voted against the proposal.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to grant the Tunisian Republic a zero-tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes per year for olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU, in the form of autonomous trade measures, for a period of 2 years, from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. This additional volume would be opened as soon as the current zero-duty tariff quota of 56,700 tonnes, enshrined in the agreement, is exhausted.  While the European Commission has not provided a real impact analysis, I have positioned myself in favour of limiting the scope of the regulation and putting in place tools for monitoring and monthly monitoring of the quota for the year 2016 conditioning the renewal of the quota for 2017. Indeed, agriculture cannot always be the adjustment variable of diplomacy.  Nevertheless, given the historical ties and geopolitical issues shared with Tunisia, I am in favour of this unilateral measure really benefiting Tunisian producers, countries hard hit, especially economically by the terrorist attacks of 26 June 2015 in Sousse. For these reasons, and although my position has not been fully taken up, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of granting Tunisia emergency autonomous trade measures with a zero-right tariff quota for Olive Oil exports from Tunisia to the European Union for a period of two years. It is indeed important, through these trade measures, to support Tunisia, whose already fragile economy has been further destabilized by terrorist attacks. In order to ensure that these measures do not harm European agriculture, the European Parliament's text strengthens the regulation and establishes a mid-term review allowing the European Commission to propose corrective measures if the EU market is destabilized.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The Tunisian democracy is being put to the test three times by terrorism in 2015. Aware of the difficulties facing the country, as well as the importance of the olive oil sector in Tunisian exports to the European Union, I voted for the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures in favour of Tunisia.  Through this vote, we are introducing, on a temporary basis, a zero-tariff tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes per year for olive oil exports to the European Union, applicable from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. This volume will only be available when the current zero-duty tariff quota of 56,700 tonnes, enshrined in the Association Agreement between Tunisia and the Union, is exhausted. However, I did not agree to vote for this Report only because we have secured strong guarantees for our European producers.  Indeed, the impact of this measure on the European olive oil market will be assessed mid-term, so we leave the possibility of considering the adoption of corrective measures if the context warranted it. Finally, this tariff quota will be obtained entirely in Tunisia and transported directly from that country to the EU.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy.  In this difficult situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia, in particular its economic development.  In this spirit, with regard to Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, totalling 70 000 tonnes, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without an increase in the total import volume. The tariff quota will be available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and will become available after the tariff-free tariff quota of 56 700 tons fixed in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia and currently in force has been exhausted.  However, in the event that the new quota harms the commercial interests of the Member States or has adverse consequences for the internal market, the Union shall be entitled to take the necessary steps to eliminate it.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. March 18, 2015 - Terrorist attacks in Tunis and 26 June 2015 in Soussa have dealt a severe blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy. In this difficult situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia, in particular its economic development.  In this spirit, with regard to Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, totalling 70 000 tonnes, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without an increase in the total import volume. The tariff quota will be available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and will become available after the tariff-free tariff quota of 56 700 tons fixed in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia and currently in force has been exhausted. However, in the event that the new quota harms the commercial interests of the Member States or has adverse consequences for the internal market, the Union shall be entitled to take the necessary steps to eliminate it.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission wanted to support Tunisia, which was weakened in the wake of the terrorist attacks. It therefore proposed to exempt the country from tariffs for the export of 35,000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil to the EU from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. This proposal clearly puts European olive growers in difficulty, in a context where Spanish production has already been weakened by drought, and Italy by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa. The latter now affects France, especially in Corsica and on the French Riviera. In addition, Tunisia, the world's largest exporter of olive oil, is already benefiting greatly from the recent rise in oil prices, which stems precisely from this context. In order to defend our olive growers, especially in Corsica, I naturally voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague De Sarnez's report on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures in relations tunisia, as I believe that after the terrorist attack in Sousse in June last year, the country needs additional EU assistance on its path to political and economic transition.  The foreign ministers of EU member states agreed to a package of short-term measures that would have a positive effect on the country's transition. The Commission proposal calls for a temporary duty-free quota of 35 000 tonnes per year of olive oil exports to the EU under these emergency trade measures for a period of 2 years (from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017). However, I believe that there should be effective control and I support the idea that the EC should carry out an interim evaluation and, if necessary, propose measures against possible violations resulting from the emergency measures.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Negative and in its total. This is another action that completely ends the production of oil from Italy and Greece.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important to show solidarity with Tunisia and to use our existing instruments to help stabilise the North African country's economy and democratic political system. International terrorism poses a serious threat to the country and deters tourists without whom Tunisia's economy could collapse. Think of the aftermath of last year's horrific attack in Sousse. It is therefore appropriate to some extent to give a commercial discount to assist Tunisian olive oil producers. However, we must show solidarity with EU producers to at least the same extent. The exemption from customs duties on the additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil granted by the Commission should not become an exceptional tool into an everyday practice. Therefore, in the vote, it was a special consideration for me to have the extension of the duty-free period removed from the report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Olive oil is tunisia's main agricultural product exported to the EU. The oil sector is an important part of the country's economy, as are some regions of certain Member States, especially the South. The Regulation proposed by the Community executive provides for the granting of an annual duty-free tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes for tunisian olive oil exports to the EU in 2016 and 2017 (i.e. 70,000 tonnes in total). This quota would be opened after the depletion of the current 56 700 tonnes, also without tariff, under the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement. I doubt whether these benefits compensate for the damage and possible disruption stemming from the European olive oil sector and in Portugal in particular. Before this decision- making, there should have been a study assessing the economic, social and territorial impact of this proposal. For this reason, I abstained from the proposal.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are opposed, like M5S, to what is an ineffective form of EU solidarity at the expense of southern European farmers, in the specific case of olive oil producers. The south of Italy, which is most affected by the crisis and where the olive oil sector provides thousands of jobs, will be forced to suffer the greatest negative consequences of the measures in support of Tunisia envisaged by the European Commission.  We believe that there are other ways of providing aid, such as launching a plan to set up a development fund in all sectors of the Tunisian economy. Germany and the countries of Northern Europe must participate in the aid. With oil it is only the south of Europe, and Italy in particular, that pays.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the attacks of 26/06/2015, it is proposed to grant, for tunisian olive oil exports to the EU, a unilateral and temporary duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year in the form of an autonomous trade measure. This quota will be made available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 until 31 December 2017. The philosophy of the measure is the same as in the past that has explained identical measures, for example, in relation to the import of textiles from Pakistan. For Portugal, as well as for other Member States on the Mediterranean edge, olive oil production is of significant economic and social importance and will be hampered by this measure. It was possible to adopt other measures, genuinely and more effectively solidarity with the Tunisian people. This, however, is not the aim of this measure. Benefiting European importers (and some limited interests in Tunisia), this measure undermines them as always. The truth is that measures of this kind never harm the most powerful countries of the EU (so it was with the textiles of Pakistan, so it is now with tunisian olive oil). They are always the same to bear the costs of this false solidarity.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report increasing the amount of duty-free Tunisian oil in Europe. Yet another mistake by this Europe that has lost touch with reality. The political and economic stabilisation of Tunisia must have our support, but the European Commission has completely got the method wrong. I believe that a temporary measure in a specific area cannot consolidate the democratisation of Tunisia. All this, then, to the detriment of a sector already in trouble, due both to structural factors, such as the constant fall in sales prices and the increase in production costs, and to extraordinary events, not least the spread of the bacterium 'Xylella fastidiosa' in some Member States.  The entry into the market of further flows of duty-free olive oil would exacerbate these critical issues.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained as I did not agree with the total package.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report which constitutes a serious danger to the Italian economy.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the introduction of exceptional autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. This is another action that completely ends the production of oil from Italy and Greece.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am deeply concerned by the rising levels of unemployment and protests which have started to take place in the recent months as a result of the 2015 terrorist attacks. I would like to see Tunisia’s economic and social development continue and therefore support these temporary and exceptional measures.  It is crucial that the democratic transition in Tunisia is consolidated and supported politically and economically. However, considering the concerns of olive oil producers in certain Member States, I believe it is fundamental to have a mid-term review of the measures, which will be exceptional and for a limited period only.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy.  In this difficult situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia, in particular its economic development. In this spirit, with regard to Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, totalling 70 000 tonnes, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without an increase in the total import volume. The tariff quota will be available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and will become available after the tariff-free tariff quota of 56 700 tons fixed in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia and currently in force has been exhausted.  However, in the event that the new quota harms the commercial interests of the Member States or has adverse consequences for the internal market, the Union shall be entitled to take the necessary steps to eliminate it.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the wake of the terrorist attack in Soussa on 26 June 2015, the EU saw the need to further assist Tunisia in its political and economic transformation through concrete and targeted actions that could be effective in the short term. On the basis of the above, the European Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota for Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union of 35 000 tonnes per year in the form of autonomous trade measures. The tariff quota will be available for a two-year period from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. This excess quantity shall become available after the exhaustion of the duty-free tariff quota of 56 700 ton fixed and currently in force in the Agreement. In agreement with the rapporteur, I consider it necessary that, at this undoubtedly difficult time, the European Union should contribute to the recovery of the country's economy. At the same time, it is important to state that EU solidarity is at the expense of farmers in southern Europe, in this case olive oil producers. The EU is a world leader in the olive oil sector, whose production is the main economic and social maintenance force in production areas. In particular, in large areas of EU countries severely affected by the economic crisis, the olive oil sector provides thousands of jobs and its significant share of exports to third countries contributes to the EU's positive trade balance.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as we have found a balance in the amendment process to ensure that European oil producers are not affected by trade in this product with Tunisia, while continuing our work to help with the needs facing the country with which we have such strong ties.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists in the EP understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. In addition to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country, an additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The EP Socialists understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. An additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Parliament voted in favour of an unacceptable measure which, by giving the green light to the import of 70 thousand tonnes of Tunisian olive oil under tax exemption for two years, further damages the situation of small oil producers in several European countries, in particular Italian ones. Together with other colleagues in the Forza Italia delegation, we opposed these measures by tabling an amendment rejecting the Commission's proposal in order to state clearly our 'NO'. Although we fully support the reasons for this decision, we cannot accept that our aid should depend solely on the sacrifice of Italian and European oil producers.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Supporting a nation that is laboriously gaining the path of democracy and peace is the task of politics looking to the future. Helping a country, however, does not mean worsening the living and working conditions of those who come to terms with the fragility of a sector that can and must be one of the spearheads of Italy's agricultural economy every day. It was a difficult day of discussion but in the end the game was reopened. Having voted in favour of two amendments, it is possible to reopen the debate between the European institutions with a view to reconciling international policies in favour of the Mediterranean countries with the support and promotion of olive growing in southern Italy and Puglia. The final vote has been postponed. It is now up to the Italian Government to adopt a balanced position in support of the Italian farm system, also taking into account the employment risk in the agricultural sector. I hope that, in the coming days, we will not continue to 'dump the barrel' on those who have made every useful effort to correct the course.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Tunisian Republic, as I believe that economic cooperation is a right step in the face of the terror threats and the country's tense economic situation, while at the same time guaranteeing that the EU Commission's requirements will not harm the agricultural market in Europe.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Tunisia is an important issue for European cross-border trade. By strengthening the country's economic situation by promoting the olive oil sector, we are also making an important contribution to strengthening the economy.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the report on the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. Tunisia’s ability to consolidate the ongoing democratic transition will be key to bringing back stability to the EU neighbourhood, and economic development will be key in making this happen. Therefore it is important that the EU supports Tunisia where it can, including through the introduction of trade measures.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against these extraordinary trade measures because I believe that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, not by favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society but the olive oil-producing undertakings with exporting capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of Tunisian oil imported under the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement, which is currently in the negotiation phase.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Introduction of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia.  Tunisia's difficult political and economic situation has led the European Union to take effective action to support the country's transition. The solutions proposed by the European Commission have been supported by me. Tunisia, which is facing many difficulties, needs help that will bring benefits in the short term. The European Union's agreement to temporary unilateral customs-free exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Member States of the European Union will certainly contribute to positive developments in Tunisia, which relies heavily on the olive oil sector.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Thursday 25 February, I voted in favour of an emergency plan allowing Tunisia to import an additional 70,000 tonnes of its virgin olive oil into the European Union for the years 2016 and 2017. Tunisia has come a long way since the Arab Spring, and it is one of the few countries that has truly achieved a democratic transition. With this text, the European Union wished to support this country in its democratic process and economic stability through the development of its olive oil production, which represents many jobs.  However, in response to the concerns of European olive oil producers, additional safeguards are introduced, such as a mid-term assessment and updating of measures if they prove harmful to European olive oil producers, as well as a "follow-up clause", i.e. the obligation to ensure that all olive oil under the quota is produced entirely in the country and directly from Tunisia.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. The main goal is to improve the relationship between the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia and supporting stability in the region by supporting the Tunisian economy. I support the Commission’s proposal to offer a temporary zero-duty tariff on a 35 000 (70 000 tonnes in total) quota for exports of olive oil from Tunisia into the EU since olive oil is one of the key export products in Tunisia.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The EP Socialists understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. An additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Regulation provides for an increase in imports of raw olive oil of 35,000 tonnes per year for the years 2016 and 2017. Tunisia's economy has been hit over the years, both by the instability and by terrorist attacks. It is perhaps one of the few countries in the region where stability is currently taking place and has not descended into the chaos that plagues other countries in the region, such as neighbouring Libya.  However, the proposal to increase imports of olive oil raises problems and objections from countries, especially in the south, which believe that their own economy will be hit if imports of cheap olive oil from Tunisia increase.  Although in Cyprus we are not large producers, however this will affect Cypriot producers. That is why we consider this vote to be an appropriate stance.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia has been greatly affected by the Arab Spring and political instability of the surrounding regions. The country’s GDP has dropped significantly since 2011. Given the long history of cooperation and trade between Tunisia and the European Union, the Commission authorised the negotiation of a deep and comprehensive free trade agreement with Tunisia and sought an annual duty-free quota on Tunisian olive oil (Tunisia’s largest agricultural export). The measure may marginally interfere with olive oil production within the EU Member States, but can have a great impact on stability and security in the region. I believe that the implementation of such an agreement between the EU and Tunisia would boost trade links and mutual cooperation between the parties and for these reason I voted in favour of my colleague Marielle de Sarnez’ report and against the proposal to reject the Commission proposal.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report, as the terrorist attack of 26 June 2015 in Sousse prompted a reaction from the EU on the need to further assist Tunisia in its political and economic transition, in a concrete and targeted manner, through actions that can be effective in the short term. I agree in endorsing the need for the EU to help relaunch Tunisia’s economy in what is without doubt a difficult period.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy. In this difficult situation, the European Union wishes to stress its continued active support for Tunisia's economic development. Therefore, with regard to Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota for 35 000 tonnes of olive oil exports to the Union each year, without any increase in the total import volume. The tariff quota will be available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and will become available after the tariff-free tariff quota of 56 700 tons fixed in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia and currently in force has been exhausted.  However, in the event that the new quota harms the commercial interests of the Member States or has adverse consequences for the internal market, the Union shall be entitled to take the necessary steps to eliminate it.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the collapse of tourism in Tunisia, the European Commission has decided to support this partner by offering, from 1 January 2016 and for two years, a zero-duty unilateral tariff quota for a volume of 35,000 tonnes per year of olive oil exported to the EU.  This support for the Tunisian economy is essential to combat the spread of radical Islamism that feeds on poverty and misery. Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural export to the EU.  For my part, I supported this proposal because I think it provides sufficient guarantees to prevent European producers from facing unfair competition. For example, the measures are temporary and exceptional and enforcement measures can be taken if the situation in Europe deteriorates. Therefore, while remaining vigilant about the effects of these measures on European producers, who must also be supported by the EU to maintain their activities and fight the olive-killing bacteria, I believe that we have an interest in helping our partners when they are affected by the waves of terrorism as we have been recently.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which seeks to maintain tariff-free olive oil imports to the EU. This proposal has raised objections from certain players in the European olive oil industry. The quantities of Tunisian oil involved however should not have a major impact on EU producers and it is in our own interests to give backing to the Tunisian economy.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted according to the Commission’s proposal to Parliament and the Council. The Tunisian economy has been hit following the terrorist attacks from 2015. Thus, it is crucial for the EU to support Tunisia through exceptional measures in order to boost its economy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council to introduce urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, as I support efforts to help tunisia's economy, which has been significantly weakened by terrorist attacks and political developments.  In this context, I support the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures, which is also the position of the ALDE Group. However, it is necessary to establish whether olive oil will be imported directly from Tunisia and that possible attempts at smuggling or origin fraud must be prevented. I therefore believe that the proposed measures should take into account the protection of European olive oil producers and prevent market distortions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. We have decided to table an amendment to reject the Commission's proposal on these emergency autonomous trade measures in favour of Tunisia. Beyond this desire to refuse a proposal, I believe that the latter does not overly improve the original text. This report proposes zero tariffs for 35,000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil, which I consider to be an aberration for the interests of the European Union. We could have helped Tunisia in other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall trendly over the past 10 years, affecting European producers.  So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marielle de Sarnez's report on the introduction of autonomous and urgent trade measures for Tunisia. The aim is to exempt from tariffs a quota of exports of Tunisian olive oil. These measures are temporary and exceptional and an impact assessment on European producers will take place mid-term. Olive oil is one of Tunisia's only sources of agricultural exports to the European Union, with more than one million people living in the sector. It is important to support Tunisia and thus its democratic process, which, while one of the most advanced in the region, is threatened by significant security challenges, making support for the stability of the Tunisian economy paramount. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. After the Arab revolutions, Tunisia is the only country to turn to a true democratic transition. The recent attacks on Tunisian soil have severely weakened the country's economy, which is highly dependent on tourism, and it is important to support the country. The measures proposed here will help it sell its olive oil production and create jobs in order to regain economic growth and political stability. Indeed, the olive oil sector in Tunisia is economically important and represents many jobs. This regulation grants Tunisia an additional tariff quota for duty-free olive oil (35,000 tonnes per year) for two years. The exceptional and temporary nature of these measures means that they will not have an impact on our producers. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution to support our Tunisian friends in their democratic transition.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. In the report on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for Tunisia, the regulations of the European Parliament and the Council put the European olive oil industry and its producers at a significant disadvantage. Although the vote has been postponed, I would like to say that I am opposed to this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In recent months I have noted with concern the rising levels of unemployment and protests which have started to take place as a result. I want to see Tunisia’s economic and social development continue and therefore I supported these temporary and exceptional measures.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy.  In this difficult situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia, in particular its economic development.  In this spirit, with regard to Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, totalling 70 000 tonnes, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without an increase in the total import volume. The tariff quota will be available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and will become available after the tariff-free tariff quota of 56 700 tons fixed in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia and currently in force has been exhausted.  However, in the event that the new quota harms the commercial interests of the Member States or has adverse consequences for the internal market, the Union shall be entitled to take the necessary steps to eliminate it.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report since I believe that these emergency measures will harm the European olive economy, especially after the terrorist attacks. However we should try to find another way, which will not affect our European economy and European producers of olive oil, especially in the south.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal to open an extra quota of 35,000 tonnes of duty-free Tunisian olive oil for the year 2016 and 2017 of the Commission, is a serious detriment to us and, at the same time, will not bring any benefit to the Tunisian people. The opening up of the market is happening in the wrong way, because I think it is unthinkable to give Tunisia practical help by cutting import duties.  Fortunately, with our work, we have managed to amend part of the proposal, in order to limit some negative effects, removing the possibility of extending these extraordinary measures, which will then end in 2017, and demanding that the oil be fully obtained in Tunisia and directly transported to the EU. The adoption of these amendments, which have already been supported in the Committee on Agriculture, is essential because it blocks the initial proposal and brings the debate back to the Council for the opening of negotiations with the Member States.  I did, however, vote against it, because the aim of solidarity is certainly to be supported, but the instrument chosen is wrong. We cannot continue to trade, as has been done so far, agriculture in southern Europe with aid to the people of North Africa.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. To help the Tunisian economy, the Commission proposed to grant 35,000 tonnes of tariff-free import quotas for Tunisian olive oil for the years 2016 and 2017. However, these quotas have been strongly criticised by farmers in the south of the European Union. They have just suffered a sharp drop in production due to a bacterium attacking olive trees, and are worried that Tunisian olive oil will take the market share they have lost. As these doubts have not received clear answers from the Commission, and the amendments I tabled calling for safeguards for producers have not been taken up, I decided to abstain because I also did not want to block a measure that could help the Tunisian economy. I note, however, that there are many other ways to help the Tunisian economy, starting with the revision of its debt, or the conditions we put on our financial aid, rather than carrying out measures that threaten European producers and oppose them to Tunisians.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures in favour of the Tunisian Republic. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by the terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the European Union. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. The measure will be implemented from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2017. Tunisia could have been helped in many other ways, without putting European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall trendly over the past 10 years, affecting European producers. The Commission does not care about that.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, in line with my plenary speech on this subject. The Commission assumes that Tunisia, whose economy has suffered badly since the terrorist attacks in Sousse in June 2015, must be helped. To this end, it proposes to introduce an additional duty-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of Tunisian olive oil for export to the EU. The current quota is already 56,700 tonnes. The Commission could have helped Tunisia in many ways. But it chose by this decision to support Tunisian trade while putting European olive growers (including the French) in difficulty. It is impossible for me to accept this decision, which penalizes a sector already in difficulty, given the trend price declines observed over the past 10 years.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The EP Socialists understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. An additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The EP Socialists understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. An additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for Tunisia since the conviction that these measures are not to help Tunisian farmers and farmers, but are measures to reduce the cost of olives, which will harm small and medium-sized producers in southern European countries and also tunisia. Nor is there any guarantee that such oil will not enter the European Union below actual production costs or that organic or social dumping will not occur. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am for free trade, not for restrictions and exceptions.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The terrorist attacks in March 2015 in Tunisia and June 2015 in Sousse were a severe blow to Tunisia's economy. Tunisia's olive oil sector currently employs around 1 million workers, representing one fifth of tunisia's agricultural workers. To support Tunisia's economic growth and development, the EU is unilaterally and temporarily abolishing the tariff quota for olive oil this year, amounting to 35,000 tonnes of oil annually. Quotas will apply from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. I think it is important to provide support and solidarity to Tunisia following the terrorist attacks that have harmed the economy, and this measure to lift olive oil quotas is one way of helping, so I supported the report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The deteriorated security situation in Tunisia caused by terrorist attacks has been negatively reflected in the country's economy. In order to boost the economy, the European Union will provide Tunisia with assistance in the form of a single zero rate of duty for the export of olive oil per 35 000 tonnes per year from Tunisia to the EU in 2016-2017. The olive oil sector employs a million people, one fifth of the jobs in Tunisian agriculture.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. A wave of terrorist attacks hit Tunisia in 2015, putting this young democracy to the test. This violence has had extremely painful economic consequences, particularly in the tourism sector, which has been particularly targeted.  This legislative proposal aims to allow the Tunisian economy to regain some hope, temporarily facilitating the export of Tunisian olive oil to the European market. In doing so, the Union once again marks the strength of its European commitment alongside this country.  Aware of the difficulties facing Tunisia, a country which is a priority of the European Union's policy towards its neighbourhood, I therefore support this legislative proposal.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24 February 2016.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against it. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by the terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU, with the current quota being 56,700 tonnes. Tunisia could have been helped in other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall trendly over the past 10 years, affecting European producers.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures in favour of Tunisia is not supported. It is important, however, to protect domestic products and to support those facing crises, such as the current one affecting the oil production sector. In this case, the vote is due precisely to a need for protection.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the draft report on Tunisia. I am fully aware of the difficulty of the economic situation there, which worsened after the attacks of 18 March 2015 in Tunis and 26 June 2015 in Sousse. With this report, the EU expresses its support for the Republic of Tunisia and its determination to help with Tunisia's economic development. That is why the Commission is propositioning a temporary unilateral tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, i.e. a total of 70 000 tonnes, for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without increasing the total volume of imports. This quota should be granted for a period of 2 years, with effect from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. I consider this measure to be particularly important because it will bring about a recovery for a large part of the Tunisian economy. The Tunisian olive sector indirectly provides jobs for more than one million people and accounts for a fifth of the country's total agricultural employment. Moreover, olive oil is the main agricultural product exported by Tunisia. I therefore supported the report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Since the EPP, we have supported the proposal for tunisia to grant Tunisia a new quota of olive oil imports, in order to help Tunisia's economy, which is having such a hard time following the latest terrorist attacks. But we believe that it was important to include a number of measures to prevent this decision from harming Spanish producers, so we appreciate the support received for the amendments tabled to ensure that this agreement will be beneficial to all.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of Tunisia's difficult economic situation and the terrorist attacks in spring 2015, which have further depressed the country's economy, the European Union is taking concrete steps to support Tunisia's economic development.  The Regulation provides for a temporary, i.e. two-year duty-free export of 35 000 tonnes of olive oil to the EU. This measure is projected to benefit the Tunisian economy, as it indirectly creates more than one million jobs in the olive-growing sector.  By committing itself to such action, the European Union supports tunisia's economic development while promoting tunisia's democratic process.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Terrorist attacks on Tunisia's young democracy have dealt a severe blow to its economy. In order to support the country, the European Union is proposing an exceptional and temporary measure to increase import quotas for olive oil without tariffs. It is coupled with a mechanism to compensate for possible adverse effects on European productions, or even to suspend the measure. This form of aid is not without interest for EU oil exporters - who process Tunisian oil on our soil before exporting it. Therefore, it is regrettable that the EU does not choose to give the country the means to improve its own oil processing infrastructure. If the reason presented is to support the democratic transition, the erasure of Tunisia's debt, largely held by European states, would have been a much better economic as well as political solution for a debt, let us remember, contracted by dictator Ben Ali and his corrupt gang. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union, under the guise of "humanism", intends to come and defend Tunisia's interests against those of producers in southern Europe; Italy in particular. The Commission wants to impose additional quotas without tariffs: (35,000 tonnes of olive oil, while its import is currently 56,700 tonnes). This will create unfair competition for this sector in crisis. Prices have generally fallen over the past decade, so it is unwelcome to make this worse. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the report introducing emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia, the meaning of my vote was abstention. After the attacks in Tunisia, it is important that the European Union show solidarity with tunisia. However, I have many reservations when I see the European Union using trade policy as a bargaining chip in situations of this nature.
