In this case, the olive oil sector of southern European countries will suffer greatly. The olive oil sector is extremely important for Portugal, which has promoted national production with support for investment and internationalization, having tripled production between 2007 and 2014. I express some concern about the damage that the sector may suffer, so I abstained.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these trade measures as it is important that the European Union sends the message that we are ready to assist Tunisia’s economic recovery and tackle the level of unemployment amongst its youth whilst at the same time preserving the stability of the European Union’s olive oil market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Tunisia is an ancient partner of the EU, as the first trade cooperation agreement between the two partners dates back to 1969. The negotiations that began in 2015 between the EU and Tunisia on free trade are a kind of result of this long-standing cooperation. Agreements of this type contribute not only to improving the economy of both contractors, but also to strengthening other relations between them, so they are always very welcome. I very much appreciate the political situation in Tunisia, which is a model for all the surrounding countries. Despite the positive situation in politics, Tunisia faces many challenges, mainly based on regional differences and conflicts in neighbouring countries. In this area, the EU-Tunisia agreement could also contribute to the stability and consolidation of democracy. Despite the positives that the agreement will bring, I would once again like to appeal to compliance with European standards, especially when adjusting those areas that have an impact on the food industry and human health.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Commission’s proposal of granting emergency autonomous trade preferences to Tunisia. I believe that after the terrorist attacks of last year Tunisia’s economy needs further assistance. The olive oil sector is crucial as it indirectly employs more than a million people in Tunisia, representing one fifth of the jobs in the agricultural industry. Therefore these measures will bring concrete benefits to Tunisian citizens in the short run. I am painfully aware of the sensitives of certain of our Member States producing olive oil. For this reason it is important to stress that the measures will be temporary and that an impact assessment should be carried out after one year as of their application.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a regulation of parliament and the Council in order to support the Tunisian economy in serious difficulties and, at the same time, the process of democratisation in Tunisia. To this end, it proposes to open for Tunisia a temporary unilateral tariff quota for duty-free exports of 35 000 tonnes per year for a period of two years, i.e. 70 000 tonnes in total, without an increase in the total import volume. Given that olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural export product to the EU and that the Tunisian olive oil sector indirectly employs more than one million people, one fifth of the total Tunisian agricultural sector, the measure is a major help to Tunisia. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament support the adoption of the regulation with a few amendments. I voted in line with that.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We are voting against these measures, which are to allow the additional import of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil from Tunisia to the European Union without tariffs. There are other measures to help the Tunisian economy disrupted by terrorist attacks than to continue to bully European olive growers.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. Tunisia could have been helped in many other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall trendly over the past 10 years, affecting European producers. The Commission does not care about that. That is why I voted against it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has taken steps to support Tunisia’s economy after the terrorist attacks in 2015 by taking practical measures that should boost the country’s economic development. The Commission is proposing to offer a zero-duty tariff quota of 70 000 tonnes for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the EU, in the form of an autonomous trade measure. I voted for this report that will benefit a large portion of the Tunisian economy taking into consideration that the olive oil sector indirectly employs more than one million people.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – European agriculture is facing a crisis. Although olive oil was not included in the goods prohibited for import into Russia, the embargo imposed by the Federation has brought a wide response throughout the sector and, as a consequence, European agriculture continues the alarming trend of losing its attractiveness. The uncertainties in the sector make this livelihood less attractive as the scissor of the knee gap dissolves more and more.  Illiberal free trade policies and the abolition of safeguards for European farmers only contribute to the promotion of these trends.  The European Union must treat neighbourhood countries responsibly, but without being detrimental to the European farmer, who is becoming an increasingly frequent victim of political decisions.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report aims to grant Tunisia 35,000 tonnes of import quotas for olive oil to the EU for the years 2016 and 2017. As European oil production has fallen, this measure allows Tunisian producers to be supported without significantly upsetting European producers.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The economic and political support of Tunisia is essential for the country to be able to function and move forward after the terrorist attacks there. Given that olive oil is Tunisia's largest agricultural export item, the EU's short-term measure is reasonable.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU-Tunisia agreement on duty-free import into the EU of 75,000 tonnes of olive oil for 2016 - 2017 is another painful blow by the EU to Greece's poor olive growers. The agreement comes as the CFP has taken a crushing hit on small and medium-sized farmers and the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government along with the EU and IMF is seeking a free shot with barbaric unpopular measures. It coincides with the attempt to strike the fair fight of the poor farm because it fights the roadblocks for survival.  The lies that the agreement is being made to "confront terrorism" and "promote the democratisation" of Tunisia do not mislead anyone. The main objective is to lower the producer price on olive oil so that middlemen and large traders can continue to buy cheaply and sell expensively. Workers will buy oil very expensively, while poor producers will be captive to the farm.  The agreement serves exclusively the profits of large business groups in the chain of transport, export, import, disposal and marketing. Poor farming can draw its own conclusions from this. Her path is to fight in alliance with the working class and the other poor people against their monopolies and power, and their imperialist associations that serve them.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations, especially when it inaccurately claims that such preferences will prevent terrorism. We find the claim that poverty drives terrorism to be insulting to the millions of poor but peaceful people in the world. Therefore we voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently at a very difficult time, as its economy has been hit hard by the 2015 Sousse terrorist attack. The Commission has therefore considered helping this State by giving it the opportunity to trade in oil on favourable economic terms.  I reiterate my absolute disapproval of these decisions, which risk undermining the economies of the Countries of the Mediterranean basin. Although I believe it is right to help countries in difficulty, such as Tunisia, I do not think it is appropriate to adopt decisions which will lead to a very serious economic fallout for the agricultural sectors of the countries of Southern Europe.  Another way could and should have been found to help Tunisia humanitarianly and economically, without undermining the economy of some European countries and their citizens.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ To express solidarity with Tunisia and support the democratic regime, the European Commission has proposed the introduction of temporary unilateral duty-free quotas of 35 000 tonnes per year for Tunisian olive oil exports to the European Union, with an already existing quota of 57 000 tonnes. Such a quota would be available for a period of two years, from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product for export to the EU, and the olive oil industry is an important part of the country's economy, directly and indirectly employing more than 1 million people. Shortly after the adoption of the proposal for the introduction of autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, MEPs called on the Commission to reconsider this legislative proposal and not allow additional access to the European market by Tunisian olive oil and to identify other measures to support Tunisia's political and economic transition. Europe's olive growing sector has already been hit hard by the economic crisis. Olive oil is not only the most important agricultural product exported from Tunisia to the EU, but the olive oil market is primarily one of the strategic markets for the economy of the Mediterranean EU Member States, which produce top quality olive oil, so I ask for the protection of the interests of our farmers.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. The measure will be in place from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2017. Tunisia could have been helped in other ways without putting European olive growers in difficulty, already very affected by the outbreak of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa. I believe that the European Commission should first be concerned with finding solutions to the economic problems of the European Union, including those it has created itself, before pretending to help others. So I voted for that report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product for export to the Union, and the olive oil industry is an important part of the country's economy, which has suffered significant financial consequences in recent years. In anticipation of concluding negotiations on establishing a deep and comprehensive free trade area and in response to tunisia's economic crisis and supporting the implementation of the necessary political reforms, the European Union has approved a €300 million increase in macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. This measure is another proposal to help Tunisia, which I do not necessarily consider to be the most adequate. The price of oil in Tunisia is incomparably lower than in the EU. I am of the opinion that a more concrete aid measure would be to raise the price in the Tunisian market. In this way, we risk that only oil resellers will make the extra profit. On the other hand, we must also take into account the olive growing sector in Europe, which has already been hit by an unprecedented crisis and record low yields over the past two years. Oil stocks are lower than average which opens up additional oil space from Tunisia. However, it is necessary to define safeguards if the yield of olives in Europe is higher this year. For these reasons, I support all 4 amendments tabled specifying the conditions and improving the proposal to assist Tunisia.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the unfortunate attacks of 26 June 2015, a unilateral and temporary duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year in the form of an autonomous trade measure is proposed for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the European Union. A quota to be made available for a period of two years, starting on 1 January 2016. Olive oil production has significant economic and social relevance, not only for Portugal but also for other Mediterranean Member States. We believe that there is a need to assist Tunisia, particularly in the wake of the criminal attacks. We do not accept, however, that they are systematically the same to bear the costs of this solidarity, burdening countries such as Portugal, which have their economies depressed by the austerity policies imposed by the Troika, in this case by means of solidarity that is in direct conflict with their national production interests. The European Union must activate other solidarity mechanisms to provide proper support to Tunisia. From the express, we voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support Marielle de Sarnez's report on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia.  Tunisia is in a difficult situation undergoing a political and economic transition in which Tunisia needs EU assistance. In order to provide this assistance, the Commission proposes to offer Tunisia a temporary, unilateral duty-free tariff rate of 35 000 tonnes per year for olive oil exports to the EU, in the form of an autonomous trade measure. This quota will be available for a period of two years from January 2016 to January 2017. This measure would greatly help Tunisia rebuild its economy, which is in a very difficult state. However, we must be aware of the fact that the solidarity of the European Union in this case was developed at the expense of olive oil producers in southern Europe. It is therefore very important that the impact this measure will have on the European agricultural sector is determined and that the measure is limited in temporal and quantitative terms. Negative effects on the olive oil market must be minimised to prevent European olive oil prices from falling in the coming months.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The terrorist attack of 26 June 2015 in Sous has sparked a debate in the EU on the need to continue to support Tunisia in its political and economic transition in a concrete and targeted way, through actions that can be effective in the short term. The Council identified actions to be taken to support the political transition and economy in Tunisia. In this context, the European Commission proposes a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of autonomous trade measures. This quota will be available for two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. An additional quantity will be opened once the current duty-free tariff quota of 56 700 tonnes has been exhausted. Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product exported to the EU, and the olive oil sector is an important part of the national economy, providing directly and indirectly employment for more than one million people, which together accounts for one fifth of employment in the entire agricultural sector. It should be noted that this concession should not prejudge the outcome of the negotiations on agriculture under the FTA, which began in October 2015. I hereby supported the report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March and 26 June 2015 in Sousse have hit the Tunisian economy hard. Against this background, the European Commission is proposing a temporary, unilateral and duty-free quota for Tunisia of 35 000 tonnes of olive oil per year, which will contribute to the economic stabilisation of the country. This quota will apply for a period of two years, from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017, and will be opened as soon as the current duty-free quota of 56 700 tonnes enshrined in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia is exhausted. I am voting in favour of the proposal because, particularly with regard to the current migration of peoples to Germany, I believe that it is necessary to promote the internal stability of the Maghreb states. This regulation will play a part in this.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The EP Socialists understand that Tunisia's geopolitical situation deserves all the support and solidarity on the part of the EU. However, we do not support the burden of it on farmers in southern Europe and without minimal guarantees for the European olive oil sector, on which the economy of large EU territories depends. An additional 35 000 tonnes of olive oil is added to the tariff-free quota enjoyed by this country during 2016 and 2017. We are concerned that such measures will be taken without prior impact studies and by eting the monthly certificates that stagger the arrival on the EU oil market. We have secured support for two amendments affecting the exclusively Tunisian origin of oil and strengthening the temporary nature of the increase in tonnes, detaching this emergency measure from the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement.  The final vote has been postponed to negotiate with the Council the two new texts promoted by the Spanish socialist delegation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. To help strengthen Tunisia's economy, which was hit by terrorist attacks in 2015, the European Parliament today voted on an emergency plan, which I supported, allowing the import of an additional 70,000 tonnes of its virgin olive oil into the EU in 2016-2017. Tunisia has come a long way since the Arab Spring and has been the target of terrorist attacks precisely because it is on the road to consolidating its democracy. These attacks had a huge impact on the tourism sector and the economy in general at a time when Tunisians were already facing a difficult economic crisis, with high unemployment. That is why it is crucial that Europe expresses its solidarity with the Tunisian people and helps with concrete measures, such as the one voted this lunchtime, which immediately and directly stimulate its economy.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that assistance should be provided to Tunisia, which is in an unenviable economic situation, as soon as possible. I understand that allowing Tunisia to export olive oil duty-free to the European Union threatens southern European farmers. However, I believe that oil from Tunisia is already reaching the EU , but this is not always seen on product labels. On the other hand, I hope that if export preferences have negative consequences for Europe, we will be able to return to this issue and adjust our strategy.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia following the terrorist attack on 26 June 2015 in Sousse. In particular, it is a question of the granting of an annual tariff quota, duty-free, of 35,000 tonnes for tunisian olive oil exports to the EU in 2016 and 2017, giving a total value of 70,000 tonnes, after the exhaustion of the current 56 700 tonnes provided for in the EU-Tunisia Association Agreement, which are also duty-free. In plenary, I had the opportunity to say that I am fully in favour of political and economic aid to this country, although I disagree with the way it intends to be exercised, since it would be possible to use other instruments, for example in the context of the Neighbourhood Policy or Humanitarian Aid, without undermining the olive oil sector, which is so important for the agricultural economy of some Member States. The principle of solidarity should not only apply outside the EU, but also within the EU, and for that reason I have decided to abstain.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the Commission's proposal for a regulation to grant a two-year tariff-free unilateral tariff quota of 35,000 tonnes for Olive Oil exports from Tunisia to the European Union. Tunisia has recently seen several waves of attacks in which the tourism sector, an important economic resource for the country, has collapsed. The olive oil sector plays an important role in the Tunisian economy and these exceptional and temporary measures will help Tunisia stabilize its economic situation and continue its democratic process.  In addition, the text calls for that there should be no abuse or circumvention of this additional quota and that it benefit all Tunisian producers, including small producers.  I would also like to stress that, given the situation of agricultural crisis and in order not to penalise our farmers, the text voted includes a mid-term review of the effects of this regulation and allows corrective measures to be taken to restore the situation on the European market should it become destabilised.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against these trade measures in favour of Tunisia because I consider them to be affected by the internal markets of Europe, especially those of the Mediterranean. I do not question the idea itself, which is to help Tunisia, which is too important for us also in terms of migratory flows, but I am critical of the means chosen by the European Commission to help them. Unilateral tariff concessions on 35 thousand tonnes of oil in two years mean undermining our market, especially the Italian market, and destroying all SMEs that produce quality oil.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against these extraordinary trade measures because I believe that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, not by favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society but the olive oil-producing undertakings with exporting capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of Tunisian oil imported under the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement, which is currently in the negotiation phase.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to introduce urgent autonomous trade measures for Tunisia in the form of an additional, temporary, unilateral and duty-free quota of 35 000 tonnes of olive oil, because we are granting trade preferences in order to send a political signal in favour of the country affected by terrorism in 2015. It should be noted that olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural exports to the EU and that the sector creates one million direct and indirect jobs. I think we have found a good compromise in the form of carrying out an impact assessment halfway through, by allowing us to take concrete corrective measures if there are negative effects on olive oil exports from the European Union.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. Repeated terrorist attacks have hit Tunisia's already weak economy hard. That is why the European Commission has proposed temporary measures to support Tunisia. I am convinced that an annual duty-free import quota of 35 000 tonnes of olive oil will have a major impact on Tunisia, as olive oil is the country's largest export commodity and the sector employs around one million people. I do not share the view that the proposal has harmful effects on the EU market, as the EU's own production has recently, for various reasons, fallen by around 48%, and Tunisian olive oil accounts for around 1.7% of European consumption. These temporary measures are not sufficient, but I nonetheless choose to support the proposal with regret that protectionism managed to sneak into the final resolution.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the terrorist attacks of 26 June 2015 in Sousse, Tunisia, the European Union decided to introduce some autonomous emergency trade measures in favour of the Republic of Tunisia. These measures authorise duty-free imports of 35 thousand tonnes of olive oil for two years, in addition to the 56 700 tonnes already entered in the Association Agreement concluded between the EU and Tunisia.  This agreement, which authorises additional temporary access for Tunisian olive oil to the European market, risks inevitably undermining italy's olive sector, which has only recently been marking a good level of growth after a major crisis in 2014. Tunisian olive oil, in fact, will certainly be placed on the market at lower prices than that of domestic production, affecting the consumption and sales of quality Italian olive hateful.  Considering that the oil industry is certainly one of the excellences of the Italian agricultural sector, I believe that it must be defended and protected. I have therefore chosen to vote against the report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have long supported any measure to aid Tunisia in its transition to democracy. It has been a success story for the region, in my view. The vote today represents a concrete measure to deliver on these promises, which help the Tunisian economy and boost jobs and growth.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission offering a temporary unilateral tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year over the next two years for the export of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union. At the same time, with this particular commitment to promoting economic development in cooperation with the Tunisian people, we also support the process of democratic change in Tunisia.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. A terrorist attack took place in Sus, which led the EU to offer Tunisia more assistance in its political and economic transition. It will do so through concrete and targeted measures, which can also be effective in the short term. The Commission has thus proposed to introduce a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the EU in the form of autonomous trade measures. Such a quota will be available for a period of two years (January 2016 to December 2017).  I agree that the EU should contribute to the recovery of Tunisia's economy during this difficult period, but I do not think that EU solidarity should be implemented to the detriment of southern European farmers, who are, in this case, olive oil producers.  In the olive oil sector, the EU is a world leader. In the vast areas of the EU countries most affected by the financial and economic crisis, this sector provides thousands of jobs and contributes to a positive EU trade balance.  The report contains certain amendments aimed primarily at encouraging the Commission to assess, at the same time as determining the feasibility of the proposal, the impact of such measures on the European agricultural sector. I believe that the proposals are appropriate, which is why I supported the report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Following the terrorist attack on 26 June 2015 in Sousse, Tunisia, the Council of the European Union stated in its Conclusions of 20 July 2015 that the Union, after consulting its Member States, would explore the possibility of taking extraordinary and temporary measures to support the Tunisian economy. Olive oil is Tunisia's main agricultural product for export to the Union, and the olive oil industry is an important part of the country's economy, as well as those of some Member States. Therefore, for the year 2016, a duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes is opened for imports into the Union of virgin olive oil classified in CN code 1509 10 10 and 1509 10 90 which is fully produced in Tunisia and brought directly from Tunisia to the Union. Those measures should be limited in time and shall be without question the negotiations between the Union and Tunisia on the establishment of a deepened and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA), and I therefore supported the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the imposition of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia proposes measures to improve the difficult economic situation Tunisia has found itself in following the recent terrorist attacks. The regulation passed a non-taxable annual quota for the export of 35 000 tonnes of virgin olive oil fully produced in Tunisia to the European Union. Licenses have been introduced, which will be issued from January to October 2016 and 2017, without which it will not be possible to export olive oil. These exceptional measures will be in force for a period of 2 years. The voted amendments to the adopted regulations will provide protection to the member countries engaged in industry and export of olive products. It is considered that the amount of quota of imported oil envisaged will not harm EU citizens engaged in the olive industry. Furthermore, if the Commission finds evidence that Tunisia does not comply with the conditions or finds that there is an imbalance of the European market, it may adopt an act partially or completely suspending preferential agreements with Tunisia. I voted for a postponement to further agree on some of the items in this report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council imposing urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia.  I support the amendments, which include the Commission's mid-term review of the impact this regulation has had since its entry into force on the union olive oil market. However, if the review establishes that the provisions of the Regulation have a negative impact on the Union market, the Commission shall be empowered to adopt an implementing act which would enable the Commission to propose remedia tone the situation on the Union market.  In doing so, we express our support for economic development in Tunisia.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia. In doing so, the EU seeks to help Tunisia in its difficult economic situation, which is caused, inter alia, by recent terrorist attacks, in order to prevent a slowdown in the transformation of the Tunisian economy and possible political fluctuations that could have a negative impact on the stability of the country. By specifically standing alongside Tunisians to promote their economic development, the European Union is also acting in favour of the Tunisian democratic process.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Regulation provides for an increase in imports of raw olive oil of 35,000 tonnes per year for the years 2016 and 2017. Tunisia's economy has been hit over the years by both the instability and the terrorist attacks. It is, perhaps, one of the few countries in the region where stability is currently observed and has not descended into the chaos that plagues other countries in the region, such as neighbouring Libya.  However, the proposal to increase imports of olive oil raises problems and objections from countries, especially in the south, which believe that their own economy will be affected if imports of cheap olive oil from Tunisia increase.  Although in Cyprus we are not large producers, however this will affect Cypriot producers. That is why we voted against the report.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy. In this difficult situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia, in particular its economic development.  In this spirit, with regard to Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, totalling 70 000 tonnes, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without an increase in the total import volume. The tariff quota will be available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017 and will become available after the tariff-free tariff quota of 56 700 tons fixed in the Association Agreement between the Union and Tunisia and currently in force has been exhausted.  However, in the event that the new quota harms the commercial interests of the Member States or has adverse consequences for the internal market, the Union shall be entitled to take the necessary steps to eliminate it.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the European Parliament to have its voice heard on one of the worst humanitarian disasters in the world at present and to give its international weight to Saudi Arabia and other parties to the conflict in order to improve the situation. I consider it urgent that the naval blockade be lifted and that combat activities throughout Yemen be lifted in order to bring humanitarian aid to an unhindered end. A particularly worrying a feature of the situation is the high number of children among the victims and the serious threats to the safety of international aid workers. Agreeing that international efforts to resolve the situation in Yemen should be conducted under un-direction, I also took into account the fact that there is even a specific responsibility of EU Member States on this issue, in particular with regard to compliance with and enforcement of the requirements relating to restrictions on arms shipments to the region. I believe that this aspect must continue to be closely monitored by the European Parliament's instruments in the future.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Commission's proposal to allow 35 000 tonnes of Tunisian oil per year to enter the EU duty-free for two years. I agree with the need to help Tunisia, but this is not the right way to go, since Tunisian oil, according to the Commission's analysis, will probably replace the current inward processing traffic: it means that it will remain in the EU and drive down the price of oil, damaging producers in Italy and the other Mediterranean countries, which are already damaged by EU austerity policies. I voted in favour of the amendments, which at least impose restrictive conditions: the first prevents tunisian oil from entering the EU duty-free, the second allows Tunisian oil to enter the EU only on condition that it comes exclusively from Tunisian olives. This will reopen the discussion on the import of Tunisian oil into the EU Council.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following last year's terrorist attacks in Tunisia, the economy of tunisia suffered, as it was already facing great difficulties. The European Union supported the young Tunisian democracy, which emerged from the Arab Spring, including from an economic point of view. One of the very important products of the Tunisian economy is olive oil, representing a sector that directly and indirectly employs more than one million people, a fifth of all agricultural jobs. In order to encourage the maintenance and development of this sector, the European Commission has proposed to offer a duty-free tariff quota unilaterally on a temporary basis without increasing the total volume of imports. This measure is intended to support economic development and the promotion of the democratic regime in Tunisia, although it marginally affects the similar sector of the EU economy. This is a strategic measure aimed at strengthening the Tunisian state, as well as combating terrorism and immigration in an area bordering the EU. The measure is to apply until the completion of the Free Trade Agreement between the two parties, on which negotiations began in October 2015. I think it is a salutary measure that deserves to be supported.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text.  The European Union would like to reaffirm its support, taking concrete action to support Tunisia's economic development.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this emergency measure to boost Tunisia’s economy, which is currently facing serious economic difficulties as a result of a series of terrorist attacks in 2015, in addition to an economy already suffering from the unstable post-revolutionary context. I hope that this measure, which will offer a temporary, unilateral duty-free tariff rate quota of 35 000 tonnes annually for Tunisia’s exports of olive oil to the European Union, Tunisia’s main agricultural export, can bring temporary relief to the Tunisian people.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council to introduce urgent autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, as I believe these measures will have a positive impact on facilitating the difficult economic situation facing Tunisia as a result of terrorist attacks. I would like to point out that specific trade measures can be suspended in the event of a market imbalance at European Union level and if the introduction of quotas under this Regulation leads to severe distortions of the European Union market. As this suspension may last until normal conditions are in place on the market, I do not think this will adversely affect EU producers.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council imposing the necessary autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia, as it is important that, in the context of the difficult circumstances caused by the summer terrorist attacks, the EU expresses its support through concrete actions, in particular because of the economic development of Tunisia.  The European Commission therefore proposes to introduce a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, i.i. a total of 70 000 tonnes, for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union.  The measure will benefit a large part of the Tunisian economy. The Tunisian olive sector indirectly provides jobs for more than one million people and accounts for a fifth of all agricultural jobs in that country. Olive oil is, inter alia, the main agricultural product exported by Tunisia.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against these extraordinary trade measures because I believe that, first of all, they do not respond to the original meaning of the Council's mandate, not by favouring the whole of the Tunisian economy and society but the olive oil-producing undertakings with exporting capacity. Further note, the report does not provide for sufficiently guaranteed clearing mechanisms in the event of a fall in olive oil prices in Europe, which could adversely affect European oil producers, in particular Italians and Spaniards. Finally, these extraordinary measures seem to open the door to a permanent increase in the quota of Tunisian oil imported under the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement, which is currently in the negotiation phase.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU. The current quota is 56,700 tonnes. The measure will be in place from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2017. We could have helped Tunisia in other ways without putting European olive growers in trouble. I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March 2015 and Soussa on 26 June 2015 dealt a serious blow to the already struggling Tunisian economy. In this difficult situation, the European Union would like to stress its continued active support for Tunisia, in particular its economic development. In this spirit, with regard to Tunisia's exports of olive oil to the Union, the Commission proposes to open a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, totalling 70 000 tonnes, in the form of autonomous trade measures, without an increase in the total import volume. This measure will have a positive impact on much of the Tunisian economy. I voted in favour.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The terrorist attack that took place in Sousse, Tunisia, in June 2015 not only resulted in significant human losses, but also had a significant impact on the Tunisian economy. The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia envisages the granting, through a series of specific autonomous trade measures, for a period of two years, of a duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes annually for exports of olive oil to the Union. These trade measures are intended to help improve the difficult economic situation facing Tunisia. The European Parliament supports the adoption of this regulation, however, asking the European Commission to carry out an impact assessment on the Union olive oil market, halfway through the period laid down in the legislative proposal. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to ensure that urgent measures are taken to improve Tunisia's economic situation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the introduction of emergency autonomous trade measures for Tunisia. After the terrorist attacks in Tunis and Sousse in 2015, tourist arrivals in Tunisia have decreased considerably, negatively affecting the already struggling economy. In order to help the Tunisian economy, an emergency short-term trade measure is announced in the form of a two-year temporary zero-duty tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year for EU olive oil imports from Tunisia for 2016 and 2017. The measure will not increase the overall volume of imports from Tunisia as the EU will only discount duties on the current Tunisian olive oil exports to the EU. In order to further protect the EU olive producers, additional precautions will be undertaken such as a mid-term assessment and updates of the measures if they turn out harmful for EU olive oil producers, as well as a ‘tracking clause’ obligation ensuring that the olive oil truly comes from Tunisia. I voted in favour of this emergency measure in order to help the damaged Tunisian economy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposes, following the attacks of 26/6/2015, the granting, for tunisian olive oil exports to the European Union, a unilateral and temporary tariff quota with duty-free of 35 000 tonnes per year in the form of an autonomous trade measure. This quota will be made available for a period of two years from 1 January 2016 until 31 December 2017. For Portugal, as well as other Member States on the Mediterranean edge, olive oil production has significant economic and social importance.  We do not understand that they are systematically the same as always, bear the costs of this solidarity, which stems even from the imperial policies of interference of the most powerful countries. We therefore call for other forms of solidarity to be found that do not only pity countries and economies in difficulty.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. A temporary, unilateral quota for duty-free imports of 35 000 tonnes of olive oil per year from Tunisia would inevitably put the European olive oil industry at a significant disadvantage. I am therefore voting against this motion for a resolution.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for the Tunisian Republic. This is about genuine trade facilitation for Tunisia, which the EU also assumes unilaterally. In doing so, we are helping the people of Tunisia and the EU by enabling improved economic cooperation. In the spirit of my free-trade convictions, I am happy to support this request.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the EP report on the introduction of autonomous emergency trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia. Tunisia is going through an extremely difficult time, with its economy affected by last year's terrorist attacks. In this context, the EU wishes to reaffirm its support by acting specifically to support The economic development of Tunisia, and the European Commission has proposed to provide the country for two years with a duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes annually, a total of 70 000 tonnes, for olive oil exports. This temporary provision does not affect the outcome of the agricultural negotiations to be held in the context of the Free Trade Agreement, which has been discussed since October 2015.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ in the context of the terrorist attacks in Tunis on 18 March last year, which have substantially damaged the Tunisian economy, I have decided to support the report on the proposal for a unilateral zero-rate tariff quota for the export of olive oil from Tunisia to the European Union of 70 000 tonnes over a period of two years. Olive oil is Tunisia's most exported agricultural item, and so this particular measure will make a major contribution to boosting economic development in the country. This is a positive boost for tunisia's economy, where the olive oil sector provides work to more than one million people, which is one/five of the total number of jobs in the agricultural sector. At the same time, this provision is also of a political nature, which will support the process of democratic change in the country.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU-Tunisia agreement on duty-free import into the EU of 75,000 tonnes of olive oil for 2016 - 2017 is another painful blow by the EU to Greece's poor olive growers. The agreement comes as the CFP has taken a crushing hit on small and medium-sized farmers and the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government along with the EU and IMF is seeking a free shot with barbaric unpopular measures.  It coincides with the attempt to strike the fair fight of the poor farm because it fights the roadblocks for survival. The lies that the agreement is being made to "confront terrorism" and "promote the democratisation" of Tunisia do not mislead anyone.  The main objective is to lower the producer price on olive oil so that middlemen and large traders can continue to buy cheaply and sell expensively. Workers will buy oil very expensively, while poor producers will be captive to the farm.  The agreement serves exclusively the profits of large business groups in the chain of transport, export-import, disposal and marketing. Poor farming can draw its own conclusions from this. Her path is to fight in alliance with the working class and the other poor grass roots against their monopolies and power, their imperialist associations that serve them.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I have given my vote to this temporary emergency trade measure in relation to Tunisia. Tunisia is the only country in the MENA region that has successfully mastered the process of democratic and political transition. It therefore serves as an example to other countries. As tourism has suffered greatly as a result of the terrorist attack in Sousse in June 2015, assistance from the European Union is needed. I believe that the new temporary duty-free quotas for olive oil are the right instrument, as olive oil is Tunisia's main export item to the EU. The European Union has thus shown that it appreciates the political breakthrough that has occurred in Tunisia and that it is willing to provide rapid assistance in maintaining the economy and employment, as this sector creates more than a million jobs. I therefore supported the report.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Building a sustainable and stable state requires a solid economic basis. This economic success is the driving force behind the rule of law and a modern state that effectively meets the needs of its citizens. The situation in Tunisia is far from the standard of a democratic state, and the recent years of internal destabilisation in tunisia have also had a negative impact on our continent. As in the case of Ukraine, in the case of Tunisia, we must make an effort to open up our market to products that, on the one hand, will enrich the offer for European consumers and, on the other hand, strengthen the weak foundations of our North African partner's economic development. Tourism, which is the main sector generating GDP growth in Tunisia, has fallen victim to terrorism and political instability in the region as a whole, and its role must be balanced by other sectors of the economy, including agriculture in particular. Of course, the steps taken are temporary and limited in nature, as such action must not cause lasting damage to European oil producers and destabilise the internal market. I believe that this decision is the right one and will bring more benefits to the stability of the region than any other political or military action. Given the important role played by the North African states in the fight against the migration crisis affecting Europe, the steps taken by the European Parliament and the Council are fully justified.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of amendments to the proposal temporarily offering Tunisian olive oil additional access to the EU market to support the country's economic recovery following the terrorist attacks in Tunis and Sousse, as these measures aim to address possible disruption in the European olive oil sector, which is an important part of the economy of some Member States, especially in the South , as is the case in Portugal. In order to address possible disruptions in the European olive oil sector, the Commission is obliged to carry out a mid-term assessment of the impact on the Union olive market from the entry into force of these provisions and, if the European market is found to be affected, the EC is also obliged to propose corrective measures to restore the situation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. In the event of the terrorist attack in Sus on 26 June 2015, the EU decided to offer Tunisia more assistance in its political and economic transition, through concrete and targeted measures that can be effective in the short term.  I support these measures, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation which will allow for the introduction of a temporary unilateral duty-free tariff quota of 35 000 tonnes per year, i.e. a total of 70 000 tonnes, for exports of olive oil from Tunisia to the Union, in the form of autonomous trade measures and without increasing the total volume of imports.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The globalization of markets puts industrial sectors around the world in competition. The European glass production sector has paid the cost of global competition and, in particular, in Wallonia, there has been a decline in net production for more than fifteen years now. I voted in favour of mobilising part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds in favour of 412 workers made redundant and in favour of the training of 100 young people from the Belgian region of Hainaut.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 following the dismissal of 412 workers following the closure of a production plant in Roux (Hainaut), owned by AGC Europe SA, and another 268 after the closure of the Auvelais production plant (Namur region), owned by Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux , both plants located in Belgium.  This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these Belgian workers, given the high unemployment rates in the region, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of globalisation.  It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers as well as training to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market.  I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving the application EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass, for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 412 workers who became unemployed following the closure of two production sites of AGC EUROPE SA and Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux. The amount of aid that the European Union is providing to support these people in the labour market is more than EUR 1 million.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to adopt a motion for a resolution authorising the mobilization of the European Mobilisation Fund to the tune of 1.96 million euros to promote the reintegration into the labour market of 412 workers made redundant in Belgium in the glass manufacturing sector as well as assistance in training 100 young people without a diploma. As a result of China's overcapacity and overproduction in the glass sector, putting downward pressure on prices. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to confirm I voted against this report. The report wanted to approve giving EUR 1 095 544 (60% of the match funding) through the Global Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs. The Belgian Government submitted the request in 2015 when two production plants in Wallonia were shut down. The main reasons for the closures were as a result of strong competition and overcapacity in Asia.  That’s EUR 2 659 per person!! Job-seeker allowances should be a national government expenditure. United Kingdom taxpayers should not be contributing to this.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF to help Belgium support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from 2 companies active in the production of non-metallic mineral products. A total of EUR 1 095 544 is intended to be allocated from the EGF for Belgium.  The application was submitted to the Commission on 19 August 2015 and additional information was submitted by 28 October 2015. The Walloon Region, which has a deep tradition of glass production, is currently experiencing serious difficulties in the Union's trade in glass products and, moreover, there is overcapacity in Asia, while Europe has higher production costs and stricter environmental standards. Tailored services will include support, advice, job search facilitation, training, and support for setting up businesses.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Opposed to this hypocritical system of the 'Globalisation Adjustment Fund', emblematic of a European Union that behaves like an arsonist, I nevertheless voted in favour of this report which proposes to release EUR 1.96 million to promote the reintegration into the labour market of 412 workers made redundant in Belgium in the glass manufacturing sector. These layoffs are mainly due to Chinese overproduction: once again, by refusing to protect our industries from unfair competition outside Europe, the European Union is reduced to minimizing the disastrous consequences of its irresponsibility.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I obviously supported this decision to grant more than ONE million euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the socio-professional reintegration of workers who have been made redundant at AGC Roux and Saint Gobain Glass. The conversion cells implemented in the Hainaut are achieving very positive results in the actions carried out with the trade union partners. The EGF's assistance further amplifies their capacity to act. The WEF funding will also help the socio-professional integration of 100 young people under the age of 25 who are not in school, have no job and are not trained (NEETS). This will, in particular, amplify our efforts in Charleroi to promote the employment, and therefore the future, of all.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a means of providing additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. With the outbreak of the economic crisis, European glass trade suffered numerous disturbances, which combined with the loss of 32% of jobs in the sector in the decade 2000-2010. Wallonia, a region with a historical tradition in glass making, has seen a number of large companies encounter considerable difficulties, including Hainaut-Namur Glass.  I voted in favour of the Zdechovský report because I agree with the need to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide assistance to the company's 412 former workers. The mobilisation of the EGF will help to provide a coordinated package of tools for training, job search, support for the creation of new businesses and support for collective projects.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers and help young people without education or employment, in two regions of Belgium (Haianut and Namur), by closing two factories in the glass sector. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I have supported, as on other occasions, the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, this time aimed at Hainaut-Namur Glass in Belgium, where beneficiaries would be 412 laid-off workers in the manufacturing sector of other non-metallic mineral products. The dismissals have been due, according to the Belgian authorities, to the transformation that has taken place in the European glass sector and especially in that country in recent years. I hope that the mobilisation of this Fund will help to alleviate the situation of those affected.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is intended to mobilize the EGF following a request from Belgium for a financial contribution following layoffs in the economic sector of the manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products in Hainaut and Namur. The event behind these layoffs is the closure of two production sites located in Wallonia and owned respectively by the two companies, AGC Europe SA and Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux. The reported redundancies relate to the figure of 412 units for a contribution to the coordinated set of personalised services to the tune of EUR 1,095,544. I have therefore decided to vote in order to support employees in this sector who are victims of globalisation and the rise of Asian imports. This sector has seen a 32% decline in employment in the EU since 2000.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, with my vote, the mobilisation of the EGF to the value of EUR 1 095 544 in favour of 512 Belgian workers employed in the glass production sector.  I am convinced that the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a fundamental instrument for supporting citizens at this time of crisis, but I am equally firm in my belief that the EU must work to resolve the malfunctions underlying the internal market as a whole rather than simply providing economic support to try to support its victims.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so because, in the present case, workers should be given financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped.   Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed not only in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 412 workers who have lost their jobs in Hainaut-Namur Glass, which operates in the glass production sector, in the Wallonia region. These redundancies are due to the transformations produced in the European glass sector, and especially Belgian, in recent years, which have greatly affected the glass production sector in Wallonia. The long historical tradition of glass manufacturing in Wallonia is currently confronted with serious disruptions in trade in glass products in the Union and over-production capacity in Asia, adding higher production costs and stricter environmental standards in Europe. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include targeting actions, job search support, integrated training, experience transfer and support for the creation of companies and collective projects. Personalized services will also be provided to 100 young people under the age of 25 in the Hainaut region who do not work or follow studies or training.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supported the Commission's decision to mobilise the EGF to assist Belgium in supporting the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from 2 companies operating in the glass-making sector in the Belgian regions of Heno and Namur. This is the first application to be considered under the 2016 budget and which is intended to provide a total of EUR 1 095 544 from the EGF for Belgium.: It concerns 412 redundancies and up to 100 targeted young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs). In accordance with all applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission has concluded that the application fulfils the conditions for granting a financial contribution from the EGF. According to the Belgian authorities, the redundancies have been caused by developments in Europe and, in particular, in the Belgian glass industry, which have had a significant impact on the Walloon glass sector in Belgium. The Walloon Region, which has a deep tradition of glass production, is currently experiencing serious difficulties in the Union's trade in glass products and, moreover, there is overcapacity in Asia, while Europe has higher production costs and stricter environmental standards.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 19 August 2015, Belgium submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass' following redundancies in the Hainaut and Namur regions of Belgium. The request complies with the requirements of the relevant Regulation, according to the committee's examination, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report on the use of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the first of its kind in 2016, as this is at least in some symbolic way to help laid-off workers in companies engaged in glass business in the Belgian region of Wallonia.  Thus, less than EUR 1.1 million in funding is allocated from the EU budget. This will be used to help 412 redundant workers with retraining and education and 100 unemployed young people not in education. The Belgian and european glass industry as a whole is facing a number of problems due to competition from the Far East, high production costs and strict environmental legislation. As a result, there is a contraction in production and, consequently, redundancies. Services to be provided by, inter alia, laid-off workers include, but are not limited to, counselling and job-search promotion, support for start-ups, training allowances, etc. Unemployed young people will have various training programmes and career guidance programmes with european adaptation funds. The Slovenian glass industry is also facing similar problems, and there have been redundancies in slovenia. I expect that, even from the Slovenian Government, there will be a request to the Commission for the use of the funds of that fund, which would help many individuals.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which approves the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for 412 laid-off workers from Hainaut Namur Glass in Belgium. Member States can make applications for the mobilisation of the EGF if at least 500 workers are made redundant in a single company over four months or in a sector of the economy over nine months. The EGF assistance provided can include active labour policies such as job-searching, training, upskilling, outplacement, education and business start-ups. In this case I supported the derogation from the 500 worker threshold – because it was not significant, and because I am in favour reducing the threshold to 200 laid-off workers. One hundred young people not in education or training will have access to the fund, and the use of the fund for allowances is only 5% of the maximum 35% allowed.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is useful for providing support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation either because of the continuing global financial and economic crisis or because of new economic and financial crises of a supra-regional nature. The Fund must be used to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market, updating their training and giving them financial support at the same time. It is therefore appropriate to mobilise the EGF in order to make a financial contribution to workers in companies that have suffered serious problems as a result of these phenomena.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In this case, the FEAM instrument is being sought following the dismissal of 412 employees, including 144 at the Roux production site and 268 following the closure of the Auvelais production site in Namur province. This report points out that trade in glass products in the EU is in decline, partly because of China's production overcapacity, which is leading to drastic pressure on prices. The implementation of this Fund therefore demonstrates that the destruction of hundreds of jobs is primarily the result of unfair competition that directly threatens our industrial flagships and throws hundreds of workers out of work. It then only deals with the consequences by mobilising EUR 1.96 million to promote the reintegration of these laid-off workers into the labour market. Aware, however, of the usefulness of paying this sum to finance return-to-work plans, I voted in favour of the text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union has created legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade or as a result of financial and economic crises in order to help them reintegrate into the labour market. This financial assistance, in order to also support the quality standards of European products, must be implemented and streamlined, in line with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission of 17 July 2008 by mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in places where there will be increases in unemployment. In the situation set out in the report, the Union is to contribute 60% of the cost of the total measures estimated for the reintegration of workers, including the introduction of assistance for small entrepreneurs, young people wishing to open businesses, educational opportunities and training. All of these are intended to support the affected industries in Belgium, with the regions concerned being Hainaut and Namur. I voted in favour of these financing measures, seeing them as a real solution to the problem of workers in Belgium whose activity has ceased as a result of increasing globalisation.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The measures concern 412 redundancies at two glass production plants in the Walloon provinces of Hainaut and Namur, as well as 100 NEET under-25s from Hainaut. The amount allocated is € 1 095 544 (60 % of total costs). Between 2000 and 2010, employment in the glass sector in Europe fell by 32 %; Wallonia, with a strong tradition in glass production, is suffering the consequences in a particular way. This measure follows the one already approved following the closure of Saint-Gobain Sekurit in 2013 (257 redundancies).

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of two companies, AGS Europe SA and Saint-Gobain, located in Belgium's Hainaut province. The amount of aid amounts to 1,095,544 euros. 412 laid-off employees will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. The mobilization of the fund was justified and necessary given the difficulties faced by the glass production sector. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (the EGF, set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) which refers to belgium's application following the redundancies of 412 workers in the manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products.  The Belgian authorities say that the redundancies are due to developments in the glass sector in Europe, and especially in Belgium, in recent years, which have had a significant impact on glass production in Wallonia. The established tradition in the glass-making sector in Wallonia is confronted with the overcapacity of Asia and has to cope with the highest production costs and the strictest environmental standards in Europe. Redundancies therefore appear to be linked to changes in the structure of world trade. I therefore voted in favour of this measure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which approves the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for 412 laid-off workers from Hainaut Namur Glass in Belgium. Members States can make applications for the mobilisation of the EGF if at least 500 workers are made redundant in a single company over four months or in a sector of the economy over nine months. The EGF assistance provided can include active labour policies such as job-searching, training, upskilling, outplacement, education and business start-ups. In this case I supported the derogation from the 500 worker threshold – because it was not significant, and because I am in favour reducing the threshold to 200 laid-off workers. One hundred young people not in education or training will have access to the fund, and the use of the fund for allowances is only 5% of the maximum 35% allowed.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and its application to the glass sector in the Wallonia Region, especially in the areas of Namur and Hainaut which have experienced great economic hardships in recent years. Too many jobs have been lost and too many people remain in unemployment since August 2014 when the redundancies began. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to support such workers and help them find new jobs and I agree that it should be mobilised to help the glass sector in Wallonia.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The M5S delegation is in favour, as a general rule, of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. We are aware that it is probably not the tool that can best help workers, but in the absence of alternatives it must be supported nonetheless. The delegation therefore voted in favour of mobilising in support of the 412 redundant workers affected by the glass industry crisis in Wallonia.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in 2 companies operating in the Hainaut and Nambour regions in Belgium. The Belgian authorities state that the root cause of the redundancies is developments affecting the European, and in particular the Belgian glass industry in recent years, which have had a significant impact on the glass production sector in Wallonia.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at belgium's request is a positive move and is essentially a certification of the usefulness of the Adjustment Fund, for the benefit of European citizens' workers. In this light it is obviously a positive move and I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I recognise the importance of the role of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in assisting workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, due to the persistence of the global economic and financial crisis or because of a new global economic and financial crisis , so that they can be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Bad story, this crisis! I am very sorry for workers in difficulty because of unfavourable economic conditions, while I feel strong responsibility when the economic turbulence is due to policies that are not properly calibrated. I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision because I believe that the public sector must compensate when it creates damage, and in this case poorly governed globalisation has created redundancies in Belgium that are finally compensated.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Zdechovský Report, which allows the use of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to reintegrate into the labour market of 410 workers from two laid-off Belgian companies and 100 targeted young people who do not work, study or train. The economic and financial crisis we are experiencing has also had consequences in the glass sector, which has affected the Walloon region in particular.
