Through the use of this Fund, created to provide additional support to workers for major structural changes in world trade, it will be possible to support these workers through measures ranging from guidance/interpretation and facilitating job search to support for business creation or personalised professional requalification.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that Belgium has submitted an application to mobilise the European Fund in order to help 412 redundant workers and up to 100 NEETs (young unemployed and not enrolled in education or training courses), I can only vote in favour because, according to the latest estimates published by Eurostat, which show a still too high level of unemployment , it is necessary to welcome any action taken to help European citizens in difficulty.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with an efficient mobilisation criterion to increase efficiency for the treatment of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) applications in the Commission and by Parliament and the Council by shortening the time for assessment and approval. The use of the Globalisation Fund will focus on more personalised services facilitating job-search, integrating a training component even through transfer of experience, and inducing support for enterprise creation.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to Belgium's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for financial support for redundant workers, it should be remembered that the aim of this fund is to make available, quickly and efficiently, a financial contribution to the economic sector and to support workers who have lost their jobs. Following the closure of the Auvelais production plant in the Namur region, an application was submitted showing that a difficult labour market situation is being highlighted. The Belgian authorities have decided to initiate the provision of personalised services for the workers affected, with actions aimed at supporting, guidaing and integrating redundant staff and through the support and creation of collective enterprises and projects. I welcome the direct and targeted action of the Belgian Government in support of workers, and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 following the dismissal of 412 workers following the closure of a production plant in Roux (Hainaut), owned by AGC Europe SA, and another 268 after the closure of the Auvelais production plant (Namur region), owned by Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux , both plants located in Belgium.  This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these Belgian workers, given the high unemployment rates in the region, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade.  This is the first request to be examined in the framework of the 2016 budget and is in favour of Belgium for a total of EUR 1 095 544 from the EGF. The application concerns 412 redundant workers and approximately 100 young people not in employment, education or training. According to the Belgian authorities, the redundancies were made as a result of developments affecting the European glass industry, and in particular the Belgian glass industry, which have had a major hit to the Glass industry in Wallonia in recent years. Taking into account the opinions of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Regional Development, the EP's Committee on Budgets concluded, on the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application and that the submission was therefore eligible.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills after losing their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. when a large company closes, the factory moves out of the EU or in the wake of the global financial and economic crisis. Hainaut-Namur Glass's request from Belgium concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of just over EUR 1 million. The total estimated number of beneficiaries supported, including NEETs, is 512. The personalised services to be provided to redundant NEETs and young people include the following activities: guidance and support, job search, training, business creation support, allowances and personalised upskilling.  I fully support the measures that put in place policies to boost growth and jobs, which is why I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that European workers should be provided with solutions in cases of redundancies as a result of serious disruptions in the European Union. I voted in favour of this report as it gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Belgium which relates to the application in respect of 412 redundancies in Hainaut- Namur Glass which were caused by a serious disruption of Union trade in glass products.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, for the first time in 2016, at the EGF company in Hainaut-Namur (Belgium) manufacturing glass, following the dismissal of 412 workers between 31 August 2014 and 31 May 2015. The EU provides an envelope of EUR 1,095,544 to the EGF company. The envelope will also benefit 100 young people without jobs, diplomas and training. The Region of Wallonia, with a long tradition in the production of glass, has been affected for several years by a recession and a sharp rise in unemployment: 19% between 2007 and 2012. Supporting the objectives of this report, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support Belgium, which is facing massive layoffs in the glass sector. The mobilization of this fund to the tune of EUR 1,095,544 should be used to reintegrate these workers into the world of work who have suffered the consequences of globalisation.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. I supported the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium to facilitate the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant at Hainaut-Namur Glass. At the root of the redundancies are the major changes in world trade which have affected the glass sector in Europe in recent years.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 19 August 2015, Belgium submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass' following redundancies in the Hainaut and Namur regions of Belgium.  Egf-funded measures are expected to include 412 redundant workers and 100 unemployed, unskewed or unedithed young people under the age of 25 (NEETs) living in the Hainaut region. The application was made on the basis of the intervention criterion, which allows for derogations in exceptional cases within the meaning of Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation for redundant workers and Article 6(2) of the EGF Regulation for NEETs. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 1 095 544 to be granted on the basis of a request submitted by Belgium. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a fund that helps workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changing patterns of global trade to find new or new skills. Once again, I am voting against mobilising this fund because I believe it is not effective and the funds should be used differently by fully supporting measures that contribute to stimulating the economy so as to create new jobs, but I believe that giving €1 million to 400 people who have lost their jobs is frivolous and certainly poorly efficient.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. It is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures, and so I voted in favour of this application. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application following redundancies in the manufacturing sector of other non-metallic mineral products; estimates that the 412 workers made redundant, as well as 100 young people from Hainaut province who do not work, study or follow any training (NEET) under 25 years of age, participate in the proposed measures. I therefore agree that a financial contribution of EUR 1 095 544 should be mobilised to satisfy belgium's request.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Another proposal to mobilise this Fund, i.e. a few hundred more redundancies in the EU. The proposal concerns 412 workers made redundant from two companies operating in the glass sector in Hainaut and Namur. This is the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will serve assistance for individual assistance in job search, individual case management and general information services, training and retraining, grants and incentives. The conversation is always the same. The application is justified by the significant drop in glass production in Europe, which, for the first time since the 1960s, fell to less than one million tonnes in 2009, a trend that continued in 2011 and 2012, with many of the remaining producers transferring production to Asia, resulting in a 12% drop in employment in this sector since 2010 and 27% since 2000. If this aid is needed swiftly to support the laid-off workers, we reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of these neoliberal policies that have once again led to this outcome. Palliative stooes are not enough, nor can they legitimise these policies.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it benefits ordinary workers.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on aid to glass workers in Wallonia.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We do not need skilled unemployed people, which is why I am voting against the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass - Belgium.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium. The application relates to 412 redundancies in Hainaut-Namur Glass, operating in the manufacture of glass products, within the period 31 August 2014 - 31 May 2015. The EGAF funding of EUR 1 095 544 will contribute to helping 412 former workers through a coordinated package of integrated training, facilitating job-search, support/guidance/integration, transfer of experience, support for enterprise creation, support for collective projects and allowances.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 1 095 544 to be granted on the basis of a request submitted by Belgium. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of this Fund because Belgium's glass industry and therefore the EU glass industry has suffered serious disruption and is currently in a very precarious situation. The mobilization of this Fund will allow workers in this sector to access feasible labour alternatives outside the sector.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for an EP and Council decision mobilising a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 095 544 requested by Belgium to deal with the redundancies of two companies in the Hainaut and Namur regions, because I believe it is important to urge the European Commission to intervene in support of European glass companies. I believe it is right for the EU to adopt new policies to support this sector in all Member States given the severe crisis in European industry due to the contraction of sales and international competition from third countries, as I have already had the opportunity to ask the Commission by tabling a written question on an EU glass strategy. In this particular case, the closure of the plants has resulted in the redundancies of 412 workers, plus more than 100 young people who do not study or work and who will benefit from retraining measures. It is time for Europe to adopt a comprehensive strategy for a sector that has lost around 32% of its jobs in a decade and has seen historic and fundamentally important plants and businesses close for individual regions and local communities.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today, with fundamental reservations, against the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund , Amendment EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass. I consider the fund itself to be an extremely inappropriate instrument.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The problem of structural changes within an industry as a result of globalisation is an important issue. The Belgian workers affected in the glass industry should be supported by the personalised services provided under the EGF.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers and help young people without education or employment, in two regions of Belgium (Haianut and Namur), by closing two factories in the glass sector. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the memorandum on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass because following its assessment of this application, the Commission has concluded, in accordance with all applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the conditions for awarding a financial contribution from the EGF are met.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade.  We voted in favour of the report after proposing to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in two companies active in the production of other non-metallic mineral products in the Hainaut and Namur regions in Belgium.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application to mobilise EUR 1 095 544 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for 412 glass workers made redundant following the closure of production plants in the Hainaut and Namur regions. Glass production has been seriously disrupted and in a ten-year period employment in the glass sector as a whole in Europe decreased by 32%. In Wallonia, with its strong tradition of glass-making, the number of jobs in the sector in the Namur and Hainaut regions decreased by 19% between 2007 and 2012 with further large job losses in 2013 and 2014.  I was very pleased to see that the application will support a further 100 young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs) with measures specifically aimed at providing them with assistance such as mobilisation and guidance either for further education/training or to follow induction sessions and personalised upskilling, and I particularly welcome the fact that the Belgian authorities started providing the personalised services for the workers affected on 10 September 2015, well ahead of the decision on granting EGF support for the proposed coordinated package. It is also very positive that allowances and incentives to be provided amongst the proposed measures are limited to 5.52% of total estimated costs.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it concerns mobilising the Fund for 412 workers who were made redundant during the period 31 August 2014 to 31 May 2015 and up to 100 targeted young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs). In the Wallonia region, which has a strong tradition of glass-making, several large enterprises have faced difficulties in recent years, with the number of jobs in the regions of Namur and Hainaut decreasing by 19% between 2007 and 2012 and 1 236 job losses in 2013 and 1 878 in 2014 in Wallonia.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this document relating to the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns) in response to the proposal for a decision mobilizing the EGF for Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers dismissed in two companies operating in division 23 of NACE Revision 2 ( Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products) in the NUTS level regions 2(11) of Hainaut (BE32) and Namur (BE35) in Belgium.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Hainaut-Namur Glass application refers to 412 workers made redundant and will mobilise a total amount of EUR 1 095 544 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for Belgium. I voted in favour of this report regarding mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund that will offer support for the reintegration of workers made redundant in the Hainaut and Namur regions of Belgium.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. Interinstitutional agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, as the conditions of the EGF Regulation referred to in Article 4(2) are fulfilled, and belgium is harmoniously entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 095 544, in order to support 412 workers made redundant in the Hainaut and Namur regions and 100 young people from the Hainaut region who are not employed , do not go to school or train.  In recent years, the entire glass sector in the Union, and in particular Wallonia, has faced difficulties in employment, causing 1,236 jobs lost in Wallonia in 2013 and 1,878 in 2014, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text highlights the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 1.96 million euros in order to promote the reintegration into the labour market of 412 workers made redundant in Belgium in the glass manufacturing sector as well as to help train 100 young people without a diploma. It should be remembered that these layoffs are mainly due to overcapacity due to China's overproduction in the glass sector, thus exerting downward pressure on prices. Hence the positive aspect of this text. This text then responds to this situation, which we can only blame. I voted for this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague To-Zdechovsk's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at the request of Belgium for sacked employees of AGC Europe SA and Saint-Gobain. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs. This fund will release an envelope of 1,095,544 euros for 412 sacked employees. This amount will be used to finance training, counselling and support to encourage the recruitment of these laid-off workers.    This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which mobilises the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 400 Belgian workers laid off in 2014 in a glass production company. This fund will promote the reintegration of these workers made redundant by training, counselling and support. The Wallonia region, specifically Namur and Hainaut, lost more than 1,800 jobs in 2014 in this sector. It was therefore necessary to mobilize this fund in a region historically producing glass.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Workers and employees who have lost their jobs as a result of the adjustment of the economic environment due to the pressures of globalisation must be supported in their reintegration and requalification. I therefore support the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate in the labour market workers made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 19 August 2015, Belgium submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass' following redundancies in the Hainaut and Namur regions of Belgium. Egf-funded measures are expected to include 412 redundant workers and 100 unemployed, unskewed or unedithed young people under the age of 25 (NEETs) living in the Hainaut region. The application was made on the basis of the intervention criterion, which allows for derogations in exceptional cases within the meaning of Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation for redundant workers and Article 6(2) of the EGF Regulation for NEETs. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 1 095 544 to be granted on the basis of a request submitted by Belgium. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by the crisis and the effects of major structural changes in world trade.  At the root of the redundancies we are discussing are certain events that have affected the glass sector in Europe, and especially in Belgium, in recent years. In addition to the effects of globalisation, the Belgian authorities note that Asia's overcapacity in this sector certainly plays a major role. This application concerns 412 workers made redundant and up to 100 young people unemployed. I therefore decided to vote in favour and support these workers in difficulty.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the provinces of Namur and Hainaut in Belgium. The aim is to reintegrate 412 workers into the labour market and to help about 100 young people without a diploma to receive training. Layoffs are mainly related to China's overcapacity and overproduction in the glass sector, putting downward pressure on prices.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it mobilises 1.96 million euros mainly to promote the reintegration of 412 laid-off workers in Belgium in the glass manufacturing sector. These layoffs are due to competition from China, which has broken prices in this sector because of the reckless opening of European borders decided by the EU.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 following the dismissal of 412 workers following the closure of a production plant in Roux (Hainaut), owned by AGC Europe SA, and another 268 after the closure of the Auvelais production plant (Namur region), owned by Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux , both plants located in Belgium.  This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these Belgian workers, given the high unemployment rates in the region, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am fundamentally opposed to this redistribution of money. What makes this redistribution even worse is that it is a consequence of normal activity on the free market, where some sectors have to move to countries with more efficient production, and also that money goes to Belgium – a wealthy Member with a very generous social network.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to provide additional assistance to employees who are feeling the effects of major structural changes in the world economy. In order to initiate the mobilisation of the European Fund, it is necessary to agree the opinions of parliament, the Council and the Commission on the management of funds and amounts. The Commission accepted a proposal to mobilise funds for Belgium to support the reintegration of the labour market, where glassworkers were technologically redundant in two large corporations, at NUTS2 level in the Hainaut (BE32) and Namur (BE35) regions of Belgium.  1m euros will be mobilised for 412 workers and 100 targeted young professionals. The Commission concluded that Belgium and its regions had met all the preconditions for the use of these funds, so I supported the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up almost a decade ago to financially support workers made redundant or otherwise unemployed by the process of liberalising trade. In the present case, this concerned the 412 employees of two Belgian glass companies, together with a further 100 young people who are not employed. The total cost will be EUR 1095544. Human capital is the most important resource of any country, so every effort must be made to avoid losing it and continuing to be productive. A positive vote today was necessary so that more than half a thousand people could integrate or reintegrate into the labour market as quickly as possible and continue to apply (as well as receive) and spread experience among colleagues for years, thereby positively affecting both themselves and their surroundings and the European Union economy as a whole.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The belgian company concerned in the production of other non-metallic mineral products applied for support aimed at reintegrating 412 redundancies into the labour market. The applicant fulfilled the conditions for granting the aid. This is the first request to mobilise the EFG in 2016.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary, budgetary cooperation and sound budgetary discipline, because it is comprehensive and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/007 BE7Hainaut-Namur Glass i am in favour. There must be EU financial support for redundant workers, which must be made available effectively and in a way that meets what is needed. Belgium, having applied and met the requirements, will indeed have a figure at its disposal to deal with the situation. Finally, it should be stressed that there is a forecast for NEETs, i.e. those who are not undergoing training, working or actively seeking work, which contributes to reducing the productivity of the European Union and is a reason for slowing down.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report that was supported across the political spectrum. In it, we approve the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for the Namur and Hainaut regions in Belgium, where the number of jobs decreased by 19% between 2007 and 2012. The EGF was created to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of significant structural changes in world trade. Thanks to the crisis of the glass industry, several businesses in the regions have been closed and, most recently, more than 250 employees of the glass business have been laid off. The money provided will be spent on further education or training and finding a new job. In the final vote, I supported the report

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I have supported the proposal for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help laid-off workers from two companies in Belgium engaged in glass manufacturing in the Hainaut and Namur regions. We will help with just over one million euros those affected by the consequences of the transformations that have taken place in the European glass sector, and especially the Belgian, in recent years, which have greatly affected the glass production sector in Wallonia.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because I welcome the Commission's decision to grant financial support to the Regions of Namur and Hen in Belgium from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. These funds will be used to train, retrain and return workers who have lost their jobs, after two glass industry plants were forced to lay off more than 500 workers without compreising competitive pressure.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This "European Globalization Adjustment Fund" involves nearly 500 redundancies in two companies in the deindustrialized Belgian regions of Wallonia, including the company Saint-Gobain. It is not at its first misdeed locally but also in France with a major plan to lay off 400 jobs in 2008. The company, despite a 114% increase in net profit to 671 million euros, sold its glass subsidiary to a U.S. investment fund this summer and is also trying to establish itself in Indonesia. All of this is not unrelated. And the EU continues to look elsewhere and ask licensees to do self-entrepreneurship. This Fund once again contributes to corporate irresponsibility and social dumping. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In Belgium, 412 workers were laid off in the glass production sector. This is mainly due to Chinese overproduction and overcapacity in this area, which is putting downward pressure on prices. The goal of mobilizing the EGF to the tune of 1.96 million aims to promote the reintegration of these workers as well as to help the training of about 100 young people without a diploma.  So I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund Mobilisation report: application EGF/2015/007 BE/ Hainut-Namur Glass. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The application submitted meets the necessary conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF and the Belgian authorities have provided all the necessary guarantees and I have so i have put forward my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the tools at the European Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising the EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 412 workers in the glass sector in Belgium due to global financial issues.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass, which gives the green light for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Belgium. The application relates to 412 redundancies in Hainaut-Namur Glass, operating in the manufacture of glass products, within the period 31 August 2014 – 31 May 2015. The EGF funding of EUR 1 095 544 will contribute to helping 412 former workers through a coordinated package of integrated training, facilitating job-search, support/guidance/integration, transfer of experience, support for enterprise creation, support for collective projects and allowances.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. At 2011 prices, the Fund shall not exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million. Belgium submitted an application on 19 August 2015 to use the Fund for EUR 1 095 544 to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from two companies in the Provinces of Hainaut and Namur. The Commission found that the request fulfils the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF and that the measures envisaged by the Belgian authorities constitute active labour market measures under the EGF Regulation and therefore submitted a proposal to Parliament and the Council to approve the use of EUR 1 095 544 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In its report, the Committee on Budgets proposes that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal and contribute eur 1 095 544 to the EGF on the basis of a request submitted by Belgium. I supported the proposal.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. We are in favour of the principle of mobilising European funds to compensate for the disastrous effects of the savage globalisation imposed by the Euroligarchy. That is why I voted for it.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF to the sum of around EUR 1 million for Belgium, involving 412 workers made redundant and up to 100 young people out of work.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) provides support for people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes in the world trade patterns due to globalisation. I voted for this report that will bring a contribution of EUR 1 095 544 for personalised services from the 2016 EGF budget to a total of 512 workers made redundant.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. With the Globalisation Fund, the European Union has a budgetary instrument that provides financial support to workers affected by the far-reaching global structural changes in world trade patterns. This fund starts exactly where society needs it most, which is why I would have voted in favour of this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report concerns assistance for the training of 412 laid-off workers as well as for 100 neET youth (neither student, employee, nor trainee) in the Hainaut and Namur regions. Some of these workers were laid off following the closure of the production plants in Roux and Auvelais, victims of increased competition from the Asian glass market and relocations. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. People who have lost their jobs as a result of developments in Belgium, including many young people, need to be supported so that they can retrain and find work again if necessary.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against approving giving EUR 1 095 544 (60 % of the match funding) of British taxpayers money through the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EU dole money) to 412 workers in Belgium who have lost their jobs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in world trade.  In view of the serious employment consequences of the economic crisis, Belgium submitted its EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass application for a financial contribution from the EGF to support the sector that has fallen into a deep crisis. I think we should welcome belgium's support for the proposal.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Hainaut-Namur Glass.  Wallonia has a long tradition of the glass industry, which makes its population particularly dependent on this industry. The growing impact of globalisation on the local economy has increased competition, and conditions for the glass industry in the region have been greatly tightened. Poorer competitiveness has caused problems for regional glass companies - the number of jobs has fallen by 19% in recent years.  The allocation of mitigation funds is justified, but the Commission must examine all the circumstances and take into account any future applications for funds.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the decision to mobilise a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at Belgium's request within the eu's general budget for 2016, in order to assist laid-off glassworks workers. The Belgian region of Wallonia, especially the namur and hainaut cities, are known for the tradition of glass production, which employs a small number of workers of this region. This sector of industry has found itself in serious crisis, both due to the global financial crisis and the fact that most of the European market has been occupied by foreign producers. Unfortunately, the price of crisis and globalization this time is paid by workers from Wallonia, 412 of them. In my view, this measure will allow redundant workers to find another job, start their own businesses or retrain, which will also help reduce the unemployment rate in Wallonia. I therefore call on Parliament to respond to Belgium's request and approve this decision.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This request relates to assistance for employees of glass manufacturing licensed in Belgium. Chinese overproduction in the sector is leading to an overall drop in prices affecting factories in Europe. I deplore the aberrant policy of the European Union, which is always ready to open up even more to global competition without ever paying attention to the consequences on jobs and growth in the Member States. Once again, the Globalization Adjustment Fund is used to alleviate very partially the distress caused by stupid decisions. I do not, of course, want to refuse aid to workers who have been abused by the European Union, and I therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation, e.g. closing large companies or moving production outside the EU or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. For the period 2014-2020, the Fund has a maximum annual budget of EUR 150 million and can finance up to 60% of the cost of projects designed to help workers who have become redundant to find new employment or set up their own business.  The strong historical tradition of glassmaking in Wallonia faces major challenges today, including overcapacity in production in Asia combined with higher production costs and stricter environmental standards in Europe, which ultimately resulted in the redundancies of 412 Belgian Hainaut-Hamur Glass workers who were made redundant. For this reason, I support this measure, which allocates EUR 1 095 544, which will have a positive impact on 412 former workers and up to 100 targeted young people who are not in employment, education or training in order to provide them with integrated training and facilitate job search.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The proposal is the result of the dismissal of 412 workers from two companies operating in the glass ware sector in Hainaut and Namur. This is the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will serve as individual assistance in job search, individual case management and general information services, training and retraining, grants and incentives. This application is justified by the significant drop in glass production in Europe, which, for the first time since the 1960s, fell to less than one million tonnes in 2009, a trend that continued in 2011 and 2012. A depression resulting from the relocation of companies to Asia, which has also resulted in a fall in employment in this sector on European soil of 12% since 2010 and 27% since 2000. We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising to support the laid-off workers, the main victims of political decisions that reflect the deepening of the capitalist system and the pursuit of neoliberal policies, which we condemn.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ On 19 August 2015, Belgium submitted an EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut- Namur Glass application concerning 412 workers made redundant in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev Section 23. 2 (Production of other non-metallic mineral products).  Redundancies occurred in the companies in question in the Belgian regions of Hainaut (BE32) and Namur (BE35) which are part of NUTS 2. In order to establish a correlation between redundancies and major structural alterations in world trade flows resulting from globalisation, Belgium argued that trade in glass products in the EU has been significantly undermined in recent years. Between 2000 and 2013, demand in Europe stagnated, imports increased dramatically and foreign producers occupied an increasing part of the European market, as explained by the fact that surplus production capacity in Asia, particularly China, put pressure on price reductions that European producers find difficult to cope with due to higher production costs and stricter environmental standards, in particular CO2 emission quotas. Although demand has grown in development economies, Europe has unfortunately failed to increase its market share in export markets.  In order to assist redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs, I support the report of my colleague rapporteur Tomáš Zdechovski.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. – I am pleased with the vote of support that Parliament has given this report today and thus contributed to the better situation of workers in southern Belgium. The fund is generally used to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The measures should improve job security in positions that are susceptible to trade patterns and lessen unemployment in these sectors. I would like to note the improved procedure put in place by the Commission, following Parliament’s request for the accelerated release of grant. The pressure that the new timetable has given will most likely increase the potential impact on the effectiveness of case instruction and rapid implementation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to the EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass application submitted by Belgium. This application was made following the redundancy of 412 workers. The glass production sector has experienced serious difficulties in recent years, due in particular to imports, which have increased dramatically, and to foreign producers, which have gained an increasing share of the European market. Some companies have been forced to close their production plants and restructure their workforces, resulting in a large number of redundancies. I hope that the mobilisation of the EGF, amounting to EUR 1 095 544, will prove to be a decisive instrument for supporting these workers and their families, as well as valuable aid for the societies affected by the crisis.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills after losing their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. when a large company closes, the factory moves out of the EU or in the wake of the global financial and economic crisis. Assistance to Belgian workers is part of solidarity with the Belgians, who are members of our group and are in a government coalition in Belgium. In addition, the Saint-Gobain Group is a leader in glass production on the European market. In Poland, it has production facilities in Strzemieszyce Wielki (Dabrowa Górnicza district), Żary and Kole. I hereby supported the report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to help employees find new jobs after losing their jobs, so that the period of unemployment is as short as possible. To this end, the EGF offers further training to train one's own skills and to develop skills that meet the demands of globalisation. In principle, I support the implementation of policies that create work and growth. However, with regard to the EGF, I have concerns as to whether this is an effective instrument for achieving these objectives and whether the result justifies the financial expenditure for it. I am therefore voting against this decision.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, I voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund's intervention to help the 412 workers laid off following the closures of two glass production plants in Belgium owned by AGC EUROPE SA and Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux. The amount provided by the European Union to help these people find a job is more than 1 million euros. While I welcome the European Parliament's decision to give Belgian workers the means to help them get back on their feet professionally, I can only deplore these new factory closures in a historic sector in Wallonia. I cannot say it enough, industry must be at the heart of our concerns. A strong industrial base is, in my view, a necessary condition to strengthen the entire economic fabric and allow the creation of many jobs in Europe. I am also pleased to see that the intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will enable 100 unemployed, out-of-school and untrained young people to be better prepared to enter the labour market.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in favour of Belgium, amounting to a total of EUR 1 095 544, to deal with 412 redundancies in Hainaut-Namur Glass, which operates in the economic sector of manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products in the Hainaut and Namur regions and which closed their production units. From the analysis to the report, the EUSF mobilisation criteria are met and, being aware of the difficulties that the glass sector has faced in recent years and the profound impact this situation has had on communities and their local economies, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides that the EU contributes up to one million euros to help workers who are made redundant in the glass sector in Belgium. The mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is responding to the dismissal of 412 employees; and accompanies these laid-off workers in their search for work. I supported this report, which also reminds us of the importance of improving the employability of all workers through appropriate training and recognition of the skills acquired throughout their professional careers. It is crucial that the EU has instruments and financial resources such as the EGF to respond quickly and effectively to such large-scale economic situations.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is the instrument promoted by the European Union to provide support in the face of the challenges posed by the globalisation of markets.  This application, the first under the 2016 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 1 095 544 in favour of Belgium. It covers 412 workers made redundant and up to 100 young people who are unemployed and not enrolled in education or training courses (NEETs) to promote their placement. The two plants involved, which are part of the AGC Europe SA and Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux groups, have been forced to close in particular because of strong competition from Asian countries, which they can produce without having to comply with the environmental and social constraints to which our companies are subjected.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers and help young people without education or employment, in two regions of Belgium (Haianut and Namur), by closing two factories in the glass sector. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the disbursement of retraining aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because Wallonia in Belgium is already affected by many restructurings following the loss of the coal and steel industries. It was important for me to note that whenever we give a region such as Wallonia renewed aid to retrain unemployed people through a company closure, we examine exactly what we have been able to learn from previous grants for that region and, if necessary, make adjustments to help them to move them back to another profession more effectively.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Free trade is a continuation to economic prosperity and in turn individual freedom. That is why I have strong objections to the European Globalisation Fund, which is an expression of protectionism. In view of this, I believe that the fund should be phased out in an orderly manner.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 following the dismissal of 412 workers following the closure of a production plant in Roux (Hainaut), owned by AGC Europe SA, and another 268 after the closure of the Auvelais production plant (Namur region), owned by Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux , both plants located in Belgium.  This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these Belgian workers, given the high unemployment rates in the region, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Tories fail to apply for the fund where it is desperately needed – such as with the closure of the steel industry in the UK. Belgium’s application will show to the UK Government the positive effects that this fund has and how solidarity with our brothers and sisters across the EU is the best course of action.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ in the case of the European Parliament resolution on the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in a request from the Belgian company Hainaut-Namur Glass, I voted in line with the EKR's position against this resolution. I consider it important to create a policy that helps to grow employment and create jobs. At the same time, however, I share the position of the EKR faction, which does not consider the European Globalisation Fund to be an administrative and adequate instrument for this purpose.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The release of funds from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help 412 redundancies in the glass industry in Belgium. I agree that these financial resources should be used to retrain and retrain these workers, as they find themselves in a situation that is the result of global economic pressures. The European glass industry has had to cope in recent years with strong competition from Chinese and Japanese products. Overcapacity in Asia has contributed to price reductions in Europe, leading to a 32 % decrease in glass industry employment in Europe between 2000 and 2010. Two Belgian production plants, AGS Glass and Sainte-Gobaine Glass, which closed in 2014, also found themselves in trouble. The vast majority of workers made redundant are men, and up to a quarter of them are over 55 years old. I therefore welcome the fact that the Belgian Government is also trying to contribute in this way to the future application of these people in the labour market. More than EUR 1 million is earmarked from the Fund for various personalised services to help them acquire skills that they would also use outside the endangered glass industry.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 As additional support for workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis, the EU has established legislative and budgetary instruments. The so-called European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is also used to help reintegrate those redundant workers into the labour market.  On this basis, Belgium submitted an application EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of redundancies in the economic sector. These measures are expected to include 412 redundancies, as well as 100 young people from the Hainaut region who are not in employment, education or training and under the age of 25.  Although the application does not meet the normal eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, it has been submitted in accordance with the aid criterion, which allows for a derogation in exceptional circumstances in the case of redundancies and in the case of young people who are not in employment, education or training.  In order to mobilise the Fund, the Commission submitted to the budgetary authority a request for transfers totalling EUR 1 095 544 from the EGF reserve to the EGF budget line.  I agree that EU financial assistance for redundant workers should be dynamic and available as quickly and efficiently as possible, which is why I supported the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \u2012 Globalisation is a phenomenon that has been going on for several decades. We can all benefit from more open world trade and better use of comparative benefits. The EU should also focus on the areas where it is comparatively best. At the same time, however, it is important for the EU to continue to support sectors and workers in Member States that have lost competitiveness as a result of globalisation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 Belgium applied to EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies in the economic sector classified in Section 23 Rev. 2 NACE (Production of other non-metallic mineral products) in nuts level regions 2 Hainaut (BE32) and Namur (BE35) in Belgium, and the measures are projected to cover 412 displaced workers, as well as 100 young people from the Hainaut region who are not in employment, education or training (NEETs) and are under the age of 25. Of these workers, 144 were made redundant due to the closure of a production facility in Roux (Hainaut) owned by AGC Europe SA and 268 due to the closure of a production facility in Auvelais (Namur region) owned by Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux. I support the Commission's proposal, since the conditions referred to in Article 4(2) of the The EGF Regulation has been fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 095 544 under that Regulation, amounting to 60 % of the total cost of EUR 1 825 907.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Workers and employers across the European Union have been hit by the global financial and economic crisis. In order to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the closure or reduction of the number of employees of large companies or by moving production to countries outside the EU, a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been established. The report on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund proposes the introduction of personalised measures to assist the glass production sector in Belgium.  The Belgian region of Wallonia has a strong and long-standing tradition of glass production, and companies have faced great difficulties in the sector in recent years. Due to strong competition from Japanese and Chinese manufacturers, two production facilities have already closed in Wallonia. Belgium plans, using the Fund, to implement seven measures to help citizens who have lost their jobs, including helping them seek new employment, train and support. I support the decision to mobilise the Fund to help this sector tackle the emerging conditions and help the affected workforce find new job opportunities.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds - the role of Hainaut-Namur Glass.  This is the first report this year and represents a typical example of the impact of globalisation on the European market. This will help 412 redundant workers and 100 young people who are not in employment, education and training and are under the age of 25.  The report is in line with the European Commission's position and the EU decision on the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Unless there are suspicions of corporate misconduct, we always vote in favour of the Globalisation Fund. Our disagreement with the Union's economic policies and unbridled market freedom are recorded many years ago.  However, the Fund's money ends up in retraining and/or compensation programmes for redundant workers, which we support. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 19 August 2015, Belgium submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass' following redundancies in the Hainaut and Namur regions of Belgium. Egf-funded measures are expected to include 412 redundant workers and 100 unemployed, unskewed or unedithed young people under the age of 25 (NEETs) living in the Hainaut region. The application was made on the basis of the intervention criterion, which allows for derogations in exceptional cases within the meaning of Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation for redundant workers and Article 6(2) of the EGF Regulation for NEETs. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 1 095 544 to be granted on the basis of a request submitted by Belgium. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the instruments by which the European Union provides assistance to the labour force affected by the structural changes in world trade. The Fund may not use more than the maximum total amount of EUR 150 million from the consolidated union budget. Assistance shall be provided in cases where Member States report a situation of extreme necessity and only following the interinstitutional agreement between the Commission, the Council and Parliament.  In the present case, the Belgian State requested EU intervention to reintegrate workers made redundant as a result of the closure of two glass-producing companies in the Hainaut-Namur region. The proposed intervention amounts to around EUR 1 million to be transferred to Belgium. The Commission's response to this request was positive as those events were considered to have occurred due to unfavourable developments on the world glass industry market. The funds will be mainly used for advice, job fairs, vocational training, support for free initiative and collective projects.  As this is about supporting the reintegration into the labour market of a large quota, I express my support for this measure.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. It is only natural that Europe has made its contribution to helping workers. In recent years, trade in glass products in the EU has been severely disrupted. Between 2000 and 2010, employment in the glass sector as a whole in Europe fell by 32%. In Wallonia, with a strong experience in glass manufacturing, several large companies have experienced difficulties in recent years: the number of jobs in the glass sector fell by 19% between 2007 and 2012 in the provinces of Hainaut and Namur and the number of job losses throughout the region was 1,236 in 2013 and 1,878 in 2014.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this measure which enables workers and self-employed people who have lost their jobs due to the rapid changes induced by globalisation to rapidly reintegrate the labour market. Through this fund, workers will be provided with training, guidance, job-search facilitation, transfer of experience, support for enterprise creation and collective projects, as well as job-search and training allowances. I believe that this measure is vital to reduce unemployment periods to their maximum, encourage labour flexibility and thus increase the competitiveness and sustainability of the European market.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against Belgium's request for financial support to adapt to globalisation in the glass production sector with a total amount of EUR 1 825 907, of which EUR 1 095 544 should be from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. While in principle I support measures that boost economic growth and job creation, I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not the right tool to introduce such a policy and that the money offered will not reintegrate redundancy.  The surplus production capacity in Asia, in particular china, has led to price reductions that european producers find difficult to cope with and demand in Europe has stagnated while imports have increased drastically. From all of the above, it is clear that the proposed measures cannot return 412 workers in the Belgian regions of Hainaut and Namur to the labour market or help the recovery of the sector in the long term, but represent only short-term assistance.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 May 1999 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and common line I supported the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (role EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur-Namur Glass, Belgium) as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows.  This time, the funds will go to Belgium to support the reintegration of workers made redundant into the labour market by two companies in the Belgian regions of Hainaut (BE32) and Namur (BE35) at NUTS level 2(11).

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers and help young people without education or employment, in two regions of Belgium (Haianut and Namur), by closing two factories in the glass sector. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 20 January 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from two companies in the Hainaut and Namur regions of Belgium. The application concerns 412 redundant workers and approximately 100 young people not in employment, education or training. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing this fund dedicated to alleviating the economic effects of globalization and, in particular, the loss of jobs resulting from relocations.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome support for collective projects; I call on the Commission to assess the results of this type of measure in other applications in order to identify the benefits for participants.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the application EGF/2015/007 BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass. The grant of EUR 1 095 544 in EU aid is directed to Belgium to help 412 Benelux workers find new jobs. The workers were made redundant by two glass manufacturers – AGC Europe and Saint-Gobain Glass – which are unable to compete with very strong competition from Asian producers. Belgium has also decided to include 100 young people who are not in employment, education or training (NEETs) in the plans. Redundant workers are usually helped by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund with measures such as support for business start-ups, job-search assistance, occupational guidance and various kinds of training. In order to help the laid-off workers find new employment after losing their jobs due to harsh competition in the market I voted in favour of granting this aid.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay compensation for maximum redundancies for the cessation of different business activities of the Member States. In this case we are talking about a transfer which somewhat dampens a 19% fall in employment in the period 2007-2012 and 1 236 jobs lost in 2013 in the Valona Region of Belgium. It is therefore appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this decision. In order to adapt to globalisation, the Belgian glass industry needs additional resources to retrain and guide the often young people working in this sector in their search for a new job.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has overwhelmingly adopted the report by Tozechovsk calling for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 1 million for 412 workers laid off in factories owned by Saint-Gobain Glass. Saint-Gobain Glass is not at its best when it comes to obtaining the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, since its laid-off workers have already benefited in 2015.  This follows a plan to lay off 4,000 workers in France in 2008.  The report highlights the declining situation of the glass and employment industry in Wallonia in the face of Asian competition. But at no time are the shareholders' overwhelming responsibility for these layoffs mentioned in the report! European public funds should not replace the responsibilities of large companies. So I have, as usual, when it comes to large companies, voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The proposal concerns 412 workers made redundant from two companies operating in the glass sector in Hainaut and Namur. This is the mobilisation of EUR 1 095 544 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will serve as individual assistance in job search, individual case management and general information services, training and retraining, grants and incentives. This application is justified by the significant drop in glass production in Europe, which, for the first time since the 1960s, fell to less than one million tonnes in 2009, a trend that continued in 2011 and 2012, with many of the remaining producers moving production to Asia, resulting in a fall in employment in this sector of 12% since 2010 and 27% since 2000. We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising to support those targeted by the consequences of political decisions, and further reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of these neoliberal policies which have once again led to this outcome.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In the years 2000-2010, companies in Wallonia in particular had difficulties and had to cut down workers. Hainaut in particular is a difficult labour market. The high unemployment rate must be effectively tackled. The report proposes effective financial assistance and is therefore worthy of support.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 May 2012. I did not agree between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management (application EGF/2015/007 - BE/Hainaut-Namur Glass, Belgium). I reject all aid from this fund on principle.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today approved Belgium's request for the mobilisation of the EGF, which has applied for around EUR 1 million in support of 412 redundant workers affected by the crisis in the glass industry. In addition, the Belgian authorities will offer tailored services co-financed by the EGF to up to 100 young people from the Hainaut region who are not in work and who do not participate in any education or training. The event behind the redundancies was the closure, in 2014, of two production plants in Wallonia belonging to two companies, AGC Europe SA and Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux. It should be pointed out that, between 2000 and 2010, with regard to the glass sector as a whole, employment fell by 32% in Europe (particularly in Germany, Poland, France and Belgium) and for the first time since the mid-1960s glass production in Belgium fell below 1 million tonnes in 2009 , continuing to decline by 5% in both 2011 and 2012. It should also be added that this is the fifth case of a request for EGF assistance in this sector, the crisis of which stems mainly from very strong competition from the Far East.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the absorption of EUR 1 095 544 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as this is one of the typical examples of the impact of globalisation on the European labour market. The glass industry is one of the sectors that has suffered from production cuts in the past, and this is no different at present. I firmly believe that this financial support will help 412 redundant workers as well as young people in these affected Belgian regions to find work, further education, start a business or work collective projects.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted against the report on the application to mobilise the Globalisation Adjustment Fund by the Belgian company Hainaut Namur Glass. Although I support measures to create growth and jobs, as well as measures to help people who have lost their jobs, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not, in my opinion, the right means. While the Fund itself provides funding for active measures to help redundant workers to be employed, there are no thorough analyses of the impact of the aid granted from the Fund to give sufficient comparative results.
