I therefore believe that it has not yet been demonstrated that the fund generates sufficient added value, and with the help of the funds currently being spent on the fund, we would be able to find more effective solutions for redundant workers.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help workers made redundant in Belgium.  The glass industry is an economic sector with a long tradition, facing higher production costs and stricter environmental standards in Europe and overproduction in Asia.  Egf assistance will be given to redundant workers (many under the age of 25) for training, support for joint projects and support for business creation.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: Madam President, actually there is very little change in terms of people speaking loudly in this Chamber. I am one of those who cannot speak simultaneously with other people speaking loudly, so yet again I would like to ask you to kindly request people who just want to talk to each other to leave the room, leave the Chamber and let others who want to give speeches do so. I will now switch to Hungarian and, with regard to the 2016 Growth Survey, I would like to say that I did not vote for it. And be nice to stop the clock, which you're supposed to do, and I asked you to do it, so don't count on my speaking time, okay? So I heard an interview with a Hungarian family entrepreneur in Sopron on the radio back home, who was moved to say that he considered it a blessing of God to be a family entrepreneur and to run the family business with his wife, adult sons and daughters-in-laws. He said he was confident that his grandchildren would continue this family business and that they would obviously not leave Hungary because they would have something to stay for. This is the way of the future, not the constant growth that you are pushing for. That is why I did not vote for this report, because I do not believe in this continuous, far-fetched, neoliberal, globalist growth at all.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The economic growth, development of the European Union are the cornerstone of the Community's existence, so it is precisely this report, which follows the Commission's annual growth survey in question, that is to be welcomed. Promoting economic reforms, exchanging views and promoting debate between all parties involved (including national parliaments, social partners, with civil society) is necessary for a successful and productive long-term economic recovery in the Union and further progress. I share the rapporteur's view that investment, fiscal policy and structural reforms must also be accompanied by close respect for domestic demand. While the idea of a free market is highly logical in itself, it must be said that the specificity of the existing demand, which clearly affects all other areas, must not be ignored. Support.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé arís le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir sa tuarascáil seo agus tá áthas orm gur éirigh leis an tuarascáil le móramh mór; dhá thrian de na feisirí ina fabhar i.e. 395, agus 203 ina coinne. I think the Commission deserves praise for the ambitious initiatives it has brought out in its first year in operation, particularly supporting jobs and growth and trying to reinforce economic convergence and strengthen social fairness. Their three priorities for 2016 are commendable: relaunching investment, which is crucial; pursuing structural reforms to modernise our economies; and, of course, responsible rather than populist fiscal policies. I also welcome their commitment to try to reduce long-term unemployment and especially the unacceptably high levels of youth unemployment. Má éiríonn leo é seo a dhéanamh, fásfaidh geilleagar na hEorpa go tapa.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP objects to the powers of the EU to oversee and instruct national parliaments as to their economic policy, as by doing so the EU in effect overrides the democratic will of the peoples of its Member States. Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's contribution to the annual growth survey for 2016 identified priorities for promoting growth and employment in Europe. The analysis lacks a critical view of the European policies adopted so far. Consequently, there is a flattening along the Lines of the Commission. References to policies to support public investment, employment and social equality are empty and insufficient. The text is also in favour of the failed policy pursued so far and of further strengthening the current structures of economic governance and monetary union. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that in the context of the slowdown in the world economy, the Union must strengthen its domestic demand more than ever in order to achieve greater economic growth, reduce inequalities, create more quality jobs and improve social cohesion.  Less competitive countries should invest more in improving their productivity, rather than competing with lower wages and reducing public services. At the same time, the Member States of the Union with stronger economies must increase their efforts to support domestic demand through increased public and private investment and a rise in wages.  The euro area is a major economy that must be treated as such and must work towards upward convergence, with employment and social indicators at the same level as existing indicators. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the need for more reforms, yes, but for reforms to improve the quality of education systems, invest in innovation, modernise public administration and make more efficient use of natural resources.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Because of the growing resistance to the economic governance framework and its dire effects on the popular classes, several proposals insist on maquillaring the European Semester by increasing it with redistributive social policies or elements of democratic oversight while maintaining the "deepening" (in jargon of the Union) of its economic policies. Since the neoliberal key to the neoliberal vault — the individualisation of industrial relations and the orientation of public policies for the private benefit — is not called into question, I voted against this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which represents the European Parliament's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the first half of 2016. This text proposes to strengthen domestic demand through public and private investment higher than those of the Juncker Plan, and low rates. However, it is these same measures that are causing the economic destruction of France and many other European countries.  In addition, this text reflects the EU's objective of standardising national economies around a federalised and liberalised system. I cannot therefore support this text.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the European Parliament expresses its views on the Recommendations of the European Commission on economic policy by the Member States of the European Union and the Eurozone.  Unfortunately, Greece, as part of a programme, is not included in the Process of the European Semester and the recommendations of the European Commission.  I voted in favour of the report as several of the key points of our group's proposals were included although, due to the reaction of the Conservative forces in Parliament, important points were left out.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report represents the EP's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 semester and follows the Commission's annual Growth Study. The topics covered in this report are investment, structural reforms, fiscal responsibility, eurozone issues, the democratic legitimacy of the European Semester and fiscal policies, the environment and public health, and regional development policies. The report proposes to strengthen domestic demand through public and private investment that is greater than the Juncker plan. An ideological tool aimed at standardising national economies around a federalised and liberalised system and making illusory proposals to boost the economies of EU countries, I voted against the report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency I would like to confirm I voted against this report. This report outlines the European Union’s economic priorities for 2016. The Commission has carried out surveillance on Member States and this is its report card.  It is an affront to the sovereignty of the democratically elected national governments who should decide their own country’s economic policies. The Commission should not be able to force Member States to change their financial processes and policies. The Eurozone crisis has only proven that one size does not fit all.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of this report with the active support of the main European political families is of great political significance.  The European Parliament explicitly signals a willingness to link to budgetary rigour concerns the ambition to promote economic growth and job creation. This programmatic option has marked the action of the current European Commission and has already led to the emergence of interesting initiatives to encourage investment, such as the Juncker plan. It would be good for the different European governments to understand the need for a clear choice on this path, which is, moreover, very well sining in this text which has merited the adoption of a large majority of MEPs.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, by which the European Parliament endorsed the EU's economic, social and single market priorities for 2016. This report is Parliament's contribution to setting economic policy priorities for 2016. the European Semester policy coordination process in response to the Commission's Annual Growth Survey. Reports have also been drawn up on the employment and social aspects of the European Semester and aspects of the Single Market. The resolution notes that the Stability and Growth Pact must be fully implemented and that its flexibility must be exploited for investment and structural reforms and in dealing with refugee and security challenges. It calls for further reductions in labour taxation and the sustainability of social security systems, improved tax collection, the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, measures against aggressive tax planning and tax havens. It is important to reduce the severe domestic investment gap and the risk of a rise in the euro rate. It is also necessary to improve the implementation of country-specific recommendations at national level.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report represents Parliament's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 semester and follows the Commission's annual growth study. The topics covered in this report are investment, structural reforms, fiscal responsibility, eurozone issues, the democratic legitimacy of the European Semester and fiscal policies, the environment and public health, and the so-called "regional development policies". In general, this report proposes to strengthen domestic demand through public and private investments that are higher than those of the Juncker Plan, especially with low rates. But these investments must remain sustainable given the very high levels of debt. It is also concerned about macroeconomic and social disparities that are narrowing only very slowly. However, this report is above all an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around an increasingly federalized and liberalized system. I cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States, so I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European semester which, for the first time, sets out the policy guidelines for the year calling for more investment and a balanced tax policy in parallel with austerity measures. It also takes social problems into account and provides solutions to them. Since the economic crisis of 2008, the European right has imposed drastic austerity measures on us. These measures have been in place for almost 8 years now and nothing is moving! State debt continues to rise, the unemployment rate remains at a historically high ceiling and the gap between rich and poor is growing by the day. However, since the beginning of this year, we have seen encouraging signs of change and this report is once again proof of this. Investment is beginning to be a priority and we can only be satisfied with that. I can only welcome this change of course in Europe and I hope that it will help to revive the European economy and with it growth and jobs.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is witnessing a weak and uneven economic recovery between the different Member States. In this context, the problems of growth are inextricably linked to the persistence of tax avoidance and evasion which, together with aggressive tax planning, continue to cause billions of potential losses for the public finances of different countries.  The Rodrigues report on the annual growth survey under the European Semester for economic policy coordination, which I supported with my vote, effectively underlines the strategy that the EU must adopt to address the problems generated by the 2008 structural crisis. The 2016 Annual Growth Survey package is accompanied by a timely proposal that includes a combination of investment policies, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility. I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that the objective of promoting stronger levels of growth and strengthening recovery in Europe will be through expansionary policies that also allow countries in deficit to use space for flexibility to increase investment.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by Parliament. The European Semester is the mechanism by which the Union is currently trying to implement compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact — deficit and debt control, as well as other meters. I am opposed to these objectives of stringing up the economies of individual States on the basis of neoliberal criteria. The European Semester consists of a procedure by which the Commission reviews national budgets before their approval in Parliaments and issues country-specific recommendations to be implemented in next year's budgets. I am also opposed to this method which clearly infringes the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the adoption of this report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies. Unlike my group, I have supported this report and supported certain amendments which I believe have improved the text. I agree that the combination of the proposed policies will not adequately address the problem of rising poverty, inequalities and social exclusion in the Union. On the other hand, I abstained in an amendment which referred to the request for the suspension of the ongoing negotiations of TTE and the ACS. Not because it disagrees with this, but because the second part of the amendment talked about granting market economy status to China. This would have dire effects, for example, on the European steel sector and more accurately for the Basque sector.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report represents Parliament's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 semester and follows the Commission's annual Growth Study. The report covers topics ranging from investment to the environment and, more generally, it proposes to strengthen domestic demand through strong private and public investment (see low rates). Nevertheless, it remains a highly ideologically oriented report since it aims to standardize the national economies of states for a federalized and liberalized system. I can only fight this report and these hopes which are only illusory, since it is these European policies that have led to the destruction of our economies, our jobs and growth in Europe. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I find the report analysing the governance of the single market within the 2016 European Semester unbalanced and not acceptable. I believe that the text contains too many insensitive statements, and there is also a total lack of reference to the very high costs to our businesses and local authorities caused by european over-production and the rules imposed on the internal market. For these reasons, I did not support this text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against all three reports. The keynote of all three reports is to support the economic policies that set the framework for the European Semester. I am opposed to europe's market-liberal approach, austerity policies, privatisations and deregulation.  Opposition to this policy is growing throughout the EU. I note that the reports, particularly Mr Rodrigues, contain attempts to criticise the policy pursued and some arguments in favour of incentives. However, it is not clear enough for me to be able to vote in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that in the context of the slowdown in the world economy, the Union must strengthen its domestic demand more than ever in order to achieve greater economic growth, reduce inequalities, create more quality jobs and improve social cohesion.  Less competitive countries should invest more in improving their productivity, rather than competing with lower wages and reducing public services. At the same time, the Member States of the Union with stronger economies must increase their efforts to support domestic demand through increased public and private investment and a rise in wages.  The euro area is a major economy that must be treated as such and must work towards upward convergence, with employment and social indicators at the same level as existing indicators. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the need for more reforms, yes, but for reforms to improve the quality of education systems, invest in innovation, modernise public administration and make more efficient use of natural resources.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report as it is the European Parliament's contribution to the definition of economic policy priorities for 2016. In the european semester policy coordination process, in response to the Commission's Annual Growth Survey and related documents, including the draft economic policy recommendation for the euro area. At the same time, reports are being prepared on the employment and social aspects of the European Semester and on aspects of the Single Market. All three reports will be discussed with the Commission and the Council in preparation for the Spring European Council. The Committee's report aims to stimulate debate at European level, including involving national parliaments, social partners and civil society, on three key issues: what combination of fiscal, monetary and structural policies should the European Union implement within 12 to 18 months? How should policy coordination at euro area level be improved? How can the priorities and recommendations of the European Semester be made more democratic and how can recommendations be better implemented?

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to promote effective economic growth, I would like to highlight the need to invest more seriously in human capital in the context of labour market reforms. This means, in particular, investment in education and innovation. Improve national education, vocational training and lifelong learning systems. In doing so, they should be adapted to the new skills and knowledge needs of the EU labour market. This enables innovation, which is a key engine for growth, productivity and competitiveness. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament has identified its economic policy priorities in the context of the 2016 policy coordination process, called the European Semester, with the support of the report.  The combination of investment, structural investment and fiscal responsibility is the basis for budgetary planning, with a particular focus on the euro area. At the time, nor are environmental, public health and food safety and regional policies irrelevant.  In the report, Parliament also called for democratic accountability towards budgets and encouraged active debates in the Member States on its own reports and recommendations and national reform and stabilisation programmes for public finances.  It must be acknowledged that countries are all too concerned with 'closing' their annual budgets, forgetting that there is also a European budget, which is an important component of the country's financial picture, and so does my support for this report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of weak and fluctuating economic growth, which is struggling to accelerate, the economic governance priorities set out in the Annual Growth Survey for 2016 remain to consolidate the recovery and promote upward convergence between Member States, coordinating action around a combination of structural reforms, increased investment momentum and responsible fiscal policies.  I welcome the fact that the report voted on today, which I support, departs from the austerity mantra, with particular emphasis on sustainable economic growth, based primarily on reviving investment. In order to achieve this, and thus to recover our growth potential, we all need to make decisive efforts in this direction. In particular, countries with an excessive budget surplus should contribute more to supporting investment in Europe and restoring domestic demand, while those currently in deficit should have the flexibility to carry out the reforms and investments that can breathe new life into our economies. Without coordinated and geared action in this direction, we risk achieving downward convergence, with a recovery that will never materialise completely.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative non-binding report. UKIP objects to the powers of the EU to oversee and instruct national parliaments as to their economic policy, as by doing so the EU in effect overrides the democratic will of the peoples of its Member States. Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report represents the EP's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 semester and follows the Commission's annual Growth Study. This report is above all an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around a federalized and liberalized system. I cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States. I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European growth is still substantially weak, with a trend – although better than in previous years – still too uncertain and that does not free European citizens from the fear of new recessionary spirals and from the risks due to the consequences of major global criticalities (instability and unreliability of the Chinese market and the economic and financial policies adopted by Beijing, critical issues in the supply of gas and raw materials from non-European countries , insecurity and migration issues arising from the ongoing war events in the Middle East and Africa). It is time to overcome the logic of austerity alone as a way out of the crisis and realise that Europe now needs structural reforms and extraordinary measures such as a real EU investment plan to enable economic recovery.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the very principle of the definition of a European semester, which is only a tool of coercion in the service of the Commission and against the Member States. As a reminder, the European semester sets out specific country-specific recommendations and requires Member States to implement them. In addition to the usual platitudes about unemployment and the deepening of public debts of states, the report still advocates continuing to flee forward the austerity policies contained in the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Resolutely opposed to this economically absurd and suicidal strategy, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has been through a long economic crisis, which has caused serious social difficulties and eroded the potential for economic growth. The European Union is also facing a number of difficulties, in particular terrorist attacks, geopolitical instability in neighbouring regions, but also because of the arrival of a very large number of refugees. With regard to the mix of economic policies to be implemented in 2016, the euro area and the Member States must be able to strengthen the recent economic recovery, address structural challenges and contribute to a long-term strategy. In the overall assessment of the draft budget plans for 2016 we are shown that the orientation of the euro area's fiscal policy at aggregate level, largely neutral, expected, appears to be broadly appropriate, taking into account also the unprecedentedly low level of interest rates and the high external surplus, which could indicate that some support for demand is needed. I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination and the Annual Growth Survey for 2016 because I argue that the European Union needs a number of well-established economic policies in order to be able to achieve economic growth for the 2016 European Semester.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The report highlights important points, such as the 'fault' of surplus countries that do not put the surplus back into circulation by increasing divergences, and points out that there are countries that gain from the euro. However, the text in no way highlights 'how' to resolve these issues. We are, of course, in favour of the dissolution of the euro, but as long as we are inside, if we want to maintain a non-optimal currency area, we need internal transfers and therefore, given that they are told that surpluses must be put back into circulation, that there must be redistribution and that there are differences, why do we not make the surplus countries pay for transfers to the poor regions? The historical surplus must be considered. If they have noticed that the surplus of some states balanced by the deficits of others is 'ugly', then let us look at the thousands of billions of surpluses accumulated thanks to the euro by Germany and put them back into circulation. If we look only today we are also in surplus, domestic demand is at zero, and we certainly export more than we import.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that in the context of the slowdown in the world economy, the Union must strengthen its domestic demand more than ever in order to achieve greater economic growth, reduce inequalities, create more quality jobs and improve social cohesion.  Less competitive countries should invest more in improving their productivity, rather than competing with lower wages and reducing public services. At the same time, the Member States of the Union with stronger economies must increase their efforts to support domestic demand through increased public and private investment and a rise in wages.  The euro area is a major economy that must be treated as such and must work towards upward convergence, with employment and social indicators at the same level as existing indicators. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the need for more reforms, yes, but for reforms to improve the quality of education systems, invest in innovation, modernise public administration and make more efficient use of natural resources.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The annual growth review is the first step in the European semester. This review by the European Commission highlights the additional measures that member states should take to support their growth and achieve the social and economic targets of Europe 2020. The European Parliament's report is a response to the Commission's work in this area. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the importance for Member States to respect their European commitments enshrined in the Stability and Growth Pact by implementing the necessary structural reforms. I have been able to reiterate my positions in favour of simplifying the regulatory framework on work in some Member States and for the urgent need to adapt our pension systems to the reality of demographic ageing.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. The European Semester for economic policy coordination is a key element in coordinating the individual efforts of all Member States to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. However, I believe that, in addition to the short-term fiscal implications of structural reforms, the long-term environmental, economic and social effects must also be taken into account. We must not forget that the transition to a green economy and investment in more efficient health systems will increase the security of energy supply, improve the health and well-being of European citizens and create quality jobs, thereby helping to restore the competitive advantage of the European economy. In the priorities of the Annual Growth Survey and in the country-specific recommendations, the Commission should also take into account the move towards a new economic model based on a circular economy involving the development of a fiscal framework that values the development of sustainable policies that comply with the 'polluter pays' principle, which provides the right signals in favour of investment in resource efficiency.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which forms part of a wider agenda to deepen Europe’s economic and monetary union (EMU). The overall aim is to bind Member States to economic and fiscal policies at an EU level. In effect, the report represents a well-coordinated effort to institutionalise austerity. Moreover, the report offers no way out of the prevailing austerity narrative. In fact, it proposes the intensification of austerity policies. The immediate priorities are on boosting competitiveness and structural convergence, imposing fiscal policies and gradually making the convergence process ever more binding and therefore impacting directly on Ireland’s ability to implement our own legislation. Although this report contained some elements which sought to give more involvement to national parliaments in the Semester process, Sinn Féin generally opposes the European Semester, which works to deny citizens real political choices when electing their governments. Since I also oppose the austerity agenda of the overall report, I voted against.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP objects to the powers of the EU to oversee and instruct national parliaments as to their economic policy, as by doing so the EU in effect overrides the democratic will of the peoples of its Member States. Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I fully support the inclusion of a single market pillar under the European Semester. This should allow for better cohesion and coordination of our policies, enhanced competitiveness, and creation of growth and jobs. It is worrying, however, that some Member States have still not fully implemented the Services Directive, whose aim is to further reduce barriers to trade and thereby encourage growth.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report supports the failed strategy proposed by the Commission, insisting on the need to continue with fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, private investment, full implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact.  There are many issues that, in my opinion, are lacking in this text: an adequate analysis of the role of the euro, macroeconomic imbalances, budgetary constraints and the impact of the Commission's recipes on the economy, as well as any critical reflection on the need for a real change of course. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that the European Union is now called upon to exit a long economic crisis, which has had significant social consequences.  At the same time, it faces a number of challenges, including the threat of terrorist attacks, geopolitical instability in the Neighbourhood and the unprecedented increase in asylum seekers. In order to ensure its political legitimacy, the European Union must develop the means to meet these challenges.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the European Semester on economic policy coordination and the Annual Growth Survey for 2016. This effort is part of the generalised trends in the intensity of strict austerity policies that lead to further deterioration than to a response to the economic crisis. I have therefore decided not to support the report.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I consider it appropriate to strengthen the democratic nature of European economic governance. The European Parliament intends to contribute to the definition of economic policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester process of policy coordination, responding to the Commission's annual growth survey and related documents.  The European Union is emerging from a long economic crisis which has caused serious social difficulties and eroded the potential for economic growth. At the same time, it faces new challenges, in particular the threat of terrorist attacks, geopolitical instability in the neighbourhood and the unprecedented large arrivals of asylum seekers. In order to guarantee its political legitimacy, it is necessary to develop the means to meet these challenges.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report has been rather controversial given the attitude of the political side opposed to mine, aimed at discourating good practice and putting everyone in the same cauldron.  In a European Union that covers 16 of its 28 countries with the common monetary umbrella, it is normal for economic policies to be coordinated. What is not normal is that, thanks to a monetary policy that blows on national sails, some Member States are giving up on the reforms through which the boat can return to its own sail.  On these very issues, the two main groups have split up and, thanks to well-settled amendments, we have managed to improve the text so that we can vote in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester is one of the instruments for the economic coordination of Member States. Its main objectives are the pursuit of structural reforms that promote jobs and growth, sustainable fiscal policies and the prevention of macroeconomic imbalances.  Sustainable growth can only be achieved with a combination of these three elements. National budgets need to be balanced and, especially in cases such as Portuguese, the work of re-honoring the future needs to be continued through a consistent deficit reduction. On the other hand, European funding programmes, such as Horizon 2010 or the so-called "Juncker plan", should be used to stimulate "smart" investment, i.e. with lasting effects on job creation and wealth production. Finally, it is clear that each country cannot be regarded only in its individuality, but also in the broader context of the whole monetary and economic union. We therefore need coordinated action by the Union. I welcome the democratic scrutiny of the policies of economic coordination that constitutes this report, and i hope, however, that this exercise of scrutiny can be improved, in the way of the proposed by the report of the five Presidents in June 2015.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non legislative non—binding report. UKIP objects to the powers of the EU to oversee and instruct national parliaments as to their economic policy, as by doing so the EU in effect overrides the democratic will of the peoples of its Member States. Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report proposed by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs as it is the report on the priorities of the European Semester to improve the growth of the European Union in 2016. The proposals included in the document are aimed at creating a stronger economic recovery by creating quality jobs and restoring equal opportunities, without putting in the background the major challenges, such as climate change, which need constant monitoring. I support the initiative that will enable Member States to meet structural challenges and contribute to a long-term strategy to undertake new investments to support sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a gradually declining debt-to-GDP ratio for the EU and euro area. This progress needs to be sustained and complemented through more involvement of local and regional authorities through the European Fund for Structural Investments (EFSI) vehicle by developing project pipelines and investment platforms laying out synergies between European Structural and Investment Funds Improvements in national education, vocational training and lifelong learning systems are needed for learners to adapt to the new skills and knowledge demanded by the EU labour market. Investment is also another key driver of growth as it will continue to stimulate job creation.  Furthermore, removing unnecessary obstacles to speed up the implementation of Cohesion Fund roll-out through simplification, adhering squarely to the principle of subsidiarity and widening more the pool of beneficiaries, can render beneficial spill-over effects in our societies.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual growth survey report 2016 and the proposed combination of investment policies, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility aim to promote stronger levels of growth and strengthen recovery in Europe. Macroeconomic imbalances must be addressed through a coordinated effort involving all Member States, on the basis of relevant reforms and investments. The report identifies priorities for promoting growth and employment, but I believe that there is no proper policy with regard to a genuine energy Union based on solidarity, and it is also important that measures are taken to stimulate job creation, highlighting the importance of social protection systems.  I am voting against these problems.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Because of the growing resistance to the economic governance framework and its dire effects on the popular classes, several proposals insist on maquillaring the European Semester by increasing it with redistributive social policies or elements of democratic oversight while maintaining the "deepening" (in jargon of the Union) of its economic policies. Since the neoliberal key to the neoliberal vault — the individualisation of industrial relations and the orientation of public policies for the private benefit — is not called into question, I voted against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester for 2016 shows a slowdown in growth prospects in EU countries due to a number of both external factors, such as economic and financial turbulence in many emerging economies, and within the EU, such as low growth potential and public debt. I therefore believe that it is important to take measures to promote economic growth and reduce macroeconomic imbalances.  With my vote, I wanted to support the proposals contained in the European Parliament's recommendation, which aim to improve policy coordination at European level through investment policies, structural reforms, better quality of public spending and fiscal responsibility.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the crisis, the number of private and public investments has differed between Member States. During the negotiation of the semester dossiers, it has been shown that investments continue to be hampered by regulatory and non-regulatory challenges. I would consider it important that the identification and elimination of the challenges hindering investment should be part of efforts to improve framework conditions, reduce administrative barriers and remove regulatory bottlenecks. It is positive that the European Commission has once again started to explore policy areas and instruments during this semester cycle that can provide an overview of the key challenges hampering investment at national level. However, the analysis of the main challenges summarised in the country-specific fact sheets should continue in the framework of the European Semester, in particular in the country reports. It is time to re-engage in dialogue with the Member States, including in the form of thematic discussions within the Council and council committees, with a view to identifying these challenges and possible steps and measures to overcome them, otherwise the European Semester process will not be able to fulfil the role that we intended for it when it was created. I supported the report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report calls for stronger coordination at European level and deeper coordination of tax policy in the EU. The text of the report refers several times to previously adopted documents that our Delegation has never supported, namely the five Presidents' report calling for the strengthening and swift completion of the Banking Union. There has also been a demand for labour taxation to be transferred to pollution taxes. With this in mind, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Economic policy coordination is fundamental in ensuring economic growth. Growth is an important step forward to ensure an economy which is stable and prosperous. Economic growth leads to a reduction in poverty, a decrease in unemployment rates, less deficits and higher living standards, which are all areas of concern for the Union.  We need stronger safeguards to our economy and this is why I voted in favour of this report as it addresses and develops the means to address these challenges. This report also contributes to the fundamental important basis of having a more effective European Semester Report. I believe that it is important to address the quality of jobs and to have a more inclusive labour market. The Union needs to rely much more on internal demand and to increase private and public investment. Economic growth must be based on a differentiated approach on a country-by-country basis.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union does not have an economic policy, but a number of national economic policies, and in this context I believe that the lack of a common strategic vision must give us a thought, so as to act towards defining a common economic policy, given that there are enormous differences between Member States at economic, social and political level.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report defends the European Parliament's position following the European Commission's first annual review of 2016 growth, as part of the European Semester. The latter aims to strengthen the coordination of Member States' economic policies. MEPs identify three priorities for the coming year, focusing on boosting investment, pursuing structural reforms and adopting responsible tax measures. We also call for the full implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact, while being flexible, particularly in addressing the challenges of refugees and security. Considering that the tax relief on labour must be one of the priority reforms in Europe, I supported this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Investment policies, greater attention to domestic demand dynamics and integration of the Central Bank's expansionary monetary policies are the three points of greatest innovation in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey package.  This new approach, which is more focused on growth, needs to be read in a complementary way to policies to contain public spending. In addition, worsening international economic and financial conditions must prompt European policymakers to review export-oriented growth strategies for domestic demand support policies. The latter would not only ensure greater internal redistribution of wealth, but above all would put the European economy safer from uncontrollable macroeconomic imbalances.  In the report, it is essential to highlight the link between promoting those structural reforms that can strengthen the potential for growth and, above all, supporting fair and sustainable social protection systems. In fact, in recent years we have learned that the two must go hand in hand in order to ensure an improvement in the living conditions of the weakest sections of society. I consider this report to be a fundamental element in supporting the progressive policies that the S&D Group in Parliament and the Italian Government in the Council have promoted in recent years.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Since the crisis, the figures for both private and public investment have shown a different picture for the different Member States. Unfortunately, the negotiation of the semester dossiers has shown that investments continue to be hampered by regulatory and non-regulatory challenges. That is why I would consider it of the utmost importance that the identification and elimination of the challenges hindering investment be part of efforts to improve framework conditions, reduce administrative barriers and remove regulatory bottlenecks. I welcome the fact that, during this semester cycle, the European Commission has once again begun to explore policy areas and instruments that can provide an overview of the key challenges hampering investment at national level. I also believe that the analysis of the main challenges summarised in the country-specific fact sheets should, however, continue in the framework of the European Semester, in particular in the country reports. I believe that it is time to re-initiate a dialogue with the Member States, including in the form of thematic discussions within the Council and the Council committees, with a view to identifying these challenges and possible steps and measures to overcome them, otherwise the European Semester process will not be able to fulfil the role that we intended for it when it was created.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The economic recommendations supported by this report are in line with the federalist and ultra-liberal ideology of the European Union. It would like to further integrate the policies of the States, even though they are already deprived of the monetary tool and their customs policy, which are European competences. As is often the case, this text makes a fairly realistic observation of the situation, for example when it highlights persistent macroeconomic and social disparities. Unfortunately, the proposed solutions are not in the best interests of the states. Being attached to the sovereignty of them, and not wishing to endorse solutions that have already demonstrated their inefficiency, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to abstain from this report because I believe that the report relates in part to issues that are outside the EU's remit. At the same time, the report does not contain a clear message. It is impossible to make an opinion about something so vague. While the report calls for improvement and structural reforms, it calls for significant political change at the same time. This implies a debate on redeployment and definition of responsibilities that need to go from national parliamentary level to plenary level in the EP. The euro area, which at the same time may be formally referred to as a macroeconomic person, certainly cannot be called "one whole". There are too many specific factors for each country that make the proposed approach illogical, because the original hypothesis is simply false. There is no comprehensive approach to in-depth policy coordination within the EU.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Aligning Member States' fiscal and economic policies with EU requirements imposes a continuous and deep recession on weak economic countries, while promoting the interests of powerful states.  The operation of the European Semester leads to the absolute financial control of Greece so that it cannot implement a national economic policy for its exit from the crisis, but is constantly under the control of Germany and the other economically powerful countries.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the crisis, the number of both private and public investments has differed between Member States. Unfortunately, the negotiation of the semester dossiers has shown that investments continue to be hampered by regulatory and non-regulatory challenges. That is why I would consider it of the utmost importance that the identification and elimination of the challenges hindering investment be part of efforts to improve framework conditions, reduce administrative barriers and remove regulatory bottlenecks. name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report supports the failed strategy proposed by the Commission, insisting on the need to continue with fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, private investment, full application of the Stability and Growth Pact. The report lacks an adequate analysis of the role of the euro, macroeconomic imbalances, budgetary constraints and the impact of the Commission's recipes on the economy, and there is therefore no critical reflection on the need for a real change of course. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by Maria João Rodrigues recognizes that the effort made and structural reforms have had positive results in employment and the reduction of public debt. Furthermore, it reaffirms what we have adopted in this Parliament over the last few years: 1- Fiscal policy must strengthen competitiveness, growth and, at the same time, be responsible respecting the limits of public debt in order to preserve our social rights. It is that, in fact, more deficit and more debt result in the decrease of the social state. And they bring more poverty and unemployment; 2- It is clear that the ECB's role in low interest rates is fundamental in stabilising and managing public debt; 3- The strengthening of domestic demand, especially in countries with surplus, is positive. Everyone must aspire to this goal; 4- Structural reforms are fundamental; 5- The EFSI and structural investment funds should be well used. I congratulate the rapporteur and hope that all Member States will act in accordance with what is advocated in this report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Annual Growth Survey for 2016 (AAC2016) represents the starting point of a process to which we firmly oppose. The European Semester and Economic Governance are at the heart of a neoliberal strategy of fiscal policies, and many others by drag, of national states. The guidelines contained in the report, which should be respected by governments under penalty of sanctions, insist on the same revenue that has sown poverty and unemployment across Europe, preventing in practice any alternative strategy to deal with the crisis, making it impossible to stimulate growth based on public investment and an increase in aggregate demand, for example. There are no cosmetic maneuvers, whether from a social point of view or aimed at a supposed democratic legitimacy, that erase the deeply undemocratic character of economic and monetary union, which imposes in the interest of the populations and workers their neoliberal policies of concentration of wealth. The dissolution of EMU is a necessary step towards the implementation of development policies in the countries of the periphery, of breaking relations of dependence and submission, of improving living conditions and levels of well-being of workers and peoples.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Amendment 12 as I wish to see the negotiations on TTIP suspended.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the report does not highlight at all how to resolve some issues.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: annual growth survey for 2016. The operation of the European Semester leads to the absolute financial control of Greece so that it cannot implement a national economic policy for its exit from the crisis, but is constantly under the control of Germany and the other economically powerful countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support that the EU needs to rely much more on internal demand and more private and public investment. Surplus countries need to expand their budgets in order to support investment and growth everywhere in the EU while deficit countries need to be allowed more fiscal space through the flexibility instrument to invest more. I believe that the euro-area aggregate fiscal stance also needs to be considered and not only individual Member States with an exclusive focus on deficit countries, as is the case today. Surplus countries need to make a greater effort in increasing wages and internal demand.  And finally, I would like to underline that the economic policy mix to be implemented by the EU, the euro area and by the individual Member States in 2016 needs to strengthen the recent economic recovery while addressing structural challenges and contributing to a long-term strategy for sustainable growth.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the Commission's Annual Growth Survey also highlights the need to pay greater attention to social equity in the framework of the new national stability and reform programmes, and therefore to add three employment indicators (activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment) to the macroeconomic imbalances procedure; it is urgent that these indicators are indeed weighted in the same way as existing indicators in order to carry out in-depth analyses in the relevant Member States and to ensure that internal inequalities are further analysed and that economic and social reforms can be proposed and monitored.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is strictly necessary to open the debate on the three fundamental axes of this report: the Union's fiscal, monetary and structural policy over the next eighteen months, the political coordination of the euro area and the implementation of the recommendations of the European Semester.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that in the context of the slowdown in the world economy, the Union must strengthen its domestic demand more than ever in order to achieve greater economic growth, reduce inequalities, create more quality jobs and improve social cohesion.  Less competitive countries should invest more in improving their productivity, rather than competing with lower wages and reducing public services. At the same time, the Member States of the Union with stronger economies must increase their efforts to support domestic demand through increased public and private investment and a rise in wages.  The euro area is a major economy that must be treated as such and must work towards upward convergence, with employment and social indicators at the same level as existing indicators. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the need for more reforms, yes, but for reforms to improve the quality of education systems, invest in innovation, modernise public administration and make more efficient use of natural resources.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2016, because with it the EP wanted to open a real and democratic debate in the EU on the economic policies to be implemented in the coming months and on how to deepen political coordination at eurozone level. The European Semester can become a virtuous and democratic process if it is aimed at becoming an exercise open to stakeholders, and especially if in the current economic circumstances the "virtuous triangle" (investments, budgetary responsibilities and structural reforms), with domestic demand as the fourth component, will become a "solid square". The necessary deepening of EMU must promote economic stability and convergence, giving countries with low growth, high unemployment and inadequate levels of investment, and therefore with a limited budgetary margin, the opportunity to converge and achieve the Treaty's objectives of balanced and sustainable growth.  I strongly supported the call for Member States to coordinate their efforts to achieve greater growth, create new quality jobs by investing in strategic sectors of the economy (innovation, education, training), carry out reforms that are useful to society, complete the Banking Union and develop instruments for complementary budgetary capacity.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained today on the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2016. The report adequately reflects the current situation in Europe, but in some parts targets the wrong political conclusions.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The Annual Growth Survey is an important contribution by the European Parliament to the targeted definition of the Union's economic priorities. Along with this, the balance of the policy mix, as well as the stabilisation of EMU and the strengthening of democracy, are important issues that I welcome.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given it now clearly states that due to the slowdown in the world economy, the EU should increase internal demand in order to increase the growth potential. The euro-area aggregate fiscal stance also needs to be considered and not only individual Member States with an exclusive focus on deficit countries, as is the case today. Surplus countries need to make a greater effort in increasing wages and internal demand. For the UK, it is of paramount importance that the euro area, the most important trade partner for the UK, undertakes proper structural economic reforms.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative non—binding report. UKIP objects to the powers of the EU to oversee and instruct national parliaments as to their economic policy, as by doing so the EU in effect overrides the democratic will of the peoples of its Member States. Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by Parliament. The European Semester is the mechanism by which the Union is currently trying to implement compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact — deficit and debt control, as well as other meters. I am opposed to these objectives of stringing up the economies of individual States on the basis of neoliberal criteria. The European Semester consists of a procedure by which the Commission reviews national budgets before their approval in Parliaments and issues country-specific recommendations to be implemented in next year's budgets. I am also opposed to this method which clearly infringes the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because it represents the European Parliament's contribution to the elaboration of economic policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester policy coordination process. The European Union needs a more vigorous economic recovery that generates quality jobs and restores equality of opportunity. The mix of economic policies that the EU, the euro area and individual Member States must implement in 2016 must be able to strengthen the recent economic recovery, address structural challenges and contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable growth. The Europe 2020 strategy was reviewed mid-term and reconfirmed by the European Parliament and the Commission as the overall framework that can ensure smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the EU. For this strategy to be effective and realistic, it is essential that the agreed priorities and recommendations made within the European Semester are fully consistent with the strategy and focus on its implementation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, even though the employment and social situation has slowly improved in the EU and the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has overall stabilised in 2013 and 2014. However, further boosting employment will require new measures such as addressing rigidities in the labour market, skills mismatches, modernising social protection and pension systems, as well as having social partners actively contributing to domestic reform.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Our firm position on overturning the European Semester and austerity policies has led us to vote against this report as well, which "welcomes the 2016 Annual Growth Survey package and the proposed mix of investment policy, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility," but also calls for greater economic coordination, the correction of macroeconomic imbalances through the well-known unpopular neoliberal policies of harsh austerity and memoranda and "major national efforts in the effective implementation of reforms.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I approve of the three policy priorities for 2016: re-launching investment, pursuing structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies. The annual growth survey highlights the importance of the European Fund for Structural Investments (EFSI) and the use of funds under Horizon 2020, the Connecting Europe Facility and the European Structural and Investment funds, the need to address macroeconomic imbalances, convergence towards the best performers, tackling long-term unemployment, improving the business environment, respect for common fiscal rules, reduction of public debt and growth-friendly expenditure.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Ribeiro report covers social and labour market policy aspects in the context of the Annual Growth Survey of the European Semester. The fundamental problem is that the EU is still unwilling to recognise the adjustment difficulties caused by the euro and continues to focus on combating symptoms. But also in the fight against symptoms, one could make helpful policy. In some parts, the ECR has succeeded in counteracting the request for the centralisation of policy and responsibilities, but it has not succeeded sufficiently. As an example, the report proposes that 20% of the European Social Fund's resources for social concerns and the fight against poverty should be set up, thus giving Member States room for manoeuvre, developing a concept of 'social fairness' at EU level, or calling on the Commission to launch an initiative on minimum wages.  In the interests of subsidiarity and self-responsibility, I have decided to reject the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 We have voted in favour of the European Parliament's annual growth survey report. However, we are opposed to the proposals that the EU budget could, through its own resources, relieve national budgets. It ignores both the different responsibilities and the competences at national and common level as well as the scope of the common budget in relation to the national ones. Increased expenditure on fisheries, regional policy or research obviously does not relieve the costs of school, education, police, justice, defence or social security. Rather, it is important that the common budget focuses on the common tasks at European level and on the major future investments that are required instead of subsidising agriculture and old business structures, while, through responsible budgetary policies and structural reforms, Member States safeguard important commitments and the conditions for economic growth. That is how we can face the economic problems that many Member States have to deal with.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights the importance of social and environmental indicators being taken seriously in the correction of economic balances. I consider that annual growth should not be looked at in economic terms alone; it is vital that social factors are also included in the equation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2016 A year, because I think more effective structural reforms need to be initiated, in particular in terms of modernising economies and sustaining public finances.  It is also necessary to improve the current business environment in order to attract investment and raise trust in the EU and ensure that public spending is efficient and economically sustainable. Such a thing represents the position of the ALDE Group, and therefore I was AGAINST this proposal for a resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report promotes the European Semester, which considers the free movement of people, goods, services and capital to be the cornerstone of sustainable economic growth within the European Union's single market. The European Semester therefore preaches for a federalised and ultra-liberal economy, which I strongly oppose, in accordance with the spirit of sovereignty that we have always defended. It exists only to enable the objectives of Strategy 2020, a strategy of the European Union to which I am hostile. We cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States. I voted against this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)

Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Maria Joo Rodrigues' report on the 2016 Annual Growth Review as part of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. The report stresses the need for EU economies to undertake structural reforms and fiscal accountability. Returning to the paths of growth is crucial in the EU today and for this the annual growth review 2016 calls for a relaunch of investment and underlines the importance of European funds which must be used in their full potential. I support this report which sets out the necessary directions for strengthening European growth. This report has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The annual growth review outlines the three priorities that need to be taken at EU level for Member States to return to growth. For 2016, the priorities will be to boost investment, pursue structural reforms and finally responsible fiscal policies. The report does not forget to stress the need to use European funds. These proposals are essential if the Union is to return to stable and sustainable growth. So I voted in favour of those priorities.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The Annual Growth Survey serves as a stimulus for a debate at European level involving national parliaments, social partners and society to analyse the combination of monetary and structural measures the European Union should implement in the coming months and how this can be better coordinated at eurozone level. We are critical of various aspects of this policy. I am therefore abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. At a time of several crises, we need to reinforce the EU’s internal cohesion with a stronger and more balanced economic recovery. What Europe needs today is a stronger focus on investment and domestic demand. At the same time, a second generation of reforms needs to take place, improving education, innovation, public administration, tax collection and ensuring sustainable and fair welfare systems which reduce social inequalities.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the Annual Growth Survey published by the Commission in the autumn of last year. It lists growth priorities for the coming years. The text adopted by Parliament calls for wider state efforts to create growth. In my view, however, the mix of instruments proposed to achieve this objective is only very suitable for this purpose.  Public demand is sold in a classic Keynesian manner as an all-purpose weapon, and it is given an abstract, totally inflated and unrealistic status. The report also calls for further exemptions from the Stability and Growth Pact and seeks to further weaken it for politically opportune objectives. ALFA believes that rules must also be followed by politics in particular and must not be interpreted and watered down arbitrarily. We are strongly opposed to further exemptions from the Stability and Growth Pact (SWP). That is why I voted against the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 European Parliament resolution of 25 February 2016 on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: the 2016 Annual Growth Survey was not entirely bad, but unfortunately I could not support it. I take the view that the European Semester is generally poorly set up and this resolution could not change the fact that it focuses primarily on competitiveness, a single fiscal policy, the euro area and largely ignores social issues. Moreover, I do not believe that the Spring European Council should remain the main moment during which the EU's political priorities are defined. The European Parliament can only give an opinion on this event, which I do not consider sufficient.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report deals with the Commission’s Communication on the Annual Growth Survey (AGS) as part of the European Semester. Unemployment undoubtedly negatively affects economic growth as well as social convergence. An important improvement is that the AGS underlines the need to pay more attention to social fairness and, for this purpose, to reform programmes by adding three employment indicators: activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment. I recognise that the report presents an interesting analysis of the goals of this Communication, for instance the eradication of poverty or of the gender pay gap in order to tackle unemployment. Nevertheless, there are aspects that need to be reviewed: the aforementioned indicators remain lacunar, the concept of ‘social fairness’ needs to be clarified, the enhanced simplification of employment legislation that could reduce employee protection. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. –The European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies brings with it challenges, both in the short and medium term, which we face. My attention is primarily focused on the citizens of Europe, who are clas calling for investment and new jobs. It is therefore vital to make full use of the Structural Funds, the European budget and the EFSI, in order to strengthen cohesion and mitigate divergences in the single market, enabling all regions to develop their competitive advantages and promoting further private investment. There are three main objectives that we must achieve: relaunching investment, continuing structural reforms and implementing responsible budgetary policies. Where responsible does not mean austere.  I have chosen to vote in favour because I believe that the combination of economic policies that the EU, the euro area and the individual Member States will have to implement in 2016 must be strengthened. At the same time, a long-term strategy for sustainable growth must be put in place.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the European semester for economic policy coordination (annual growth review 2016). In general, this report proposes to strengthen domestic demand through public and private investment that is higher than the Juncker plan, especially with low rates. But these investments must remain sustainable given the very high levels of debt. It is also concerned about macroeconomic and social disparities that are narrowing only very slowly. However, this report is primarily an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around a federalized and liberalized system. The hope presented in this report that the recommendations will be able to revive the European economy is one of the technocratic illusions of Brussels. I cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it promotes the European Semester, which preaches for the establishment of a federalised and ultra-liberal economy. The ENL Group supported an amendment tabled by The EFDD group of English Nigel Farage which called for an end to the TAFTA negotiations and to prevent China from becoming a "market economy" (which will open our borders even more!), but this amendment was rejected by the RPS and its European allies.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. 'Unfortunately, the report on the annual growth analysis within the European Semester 2016 calls for budget deficits to increase, a budget for the euro area and to increase the EU budget. Since there are also good elements in the report, such as the recognition that large public and private debt makes us particularly vulnerable and the focus on structural reforms, the N-VA delegation has decided to abstain.

Public demand is sold in a classic Keynesian manner as an all-purpose weapon, and it is given an abstract, totally inflated and unrealistic status. The report also calls for further exemptions from the Stability and Growth Pact and seeks to further weaken it for political expedient objectives. ALFA believes that rules must also be followed by politics in particular and must not be interpreted and watered down arbitrarily. We are strongly opposed to further exemptions from the SGP. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Last November, the European Commission published an annual growth survey for 2016 and called on Member States to take even more effective action in the new Cycle of the European Semester to stimulate investment, implement structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies that, combined with unconventional monetary policy measures by the European Central Bank, will result in the growth of the European economy. The report calls for coordination between the different policies and instruments of the European Union and linking local, regional and national objectives with those at EU level. The aim is to use the European Semester mechanism effectively to boost economic growth, development and employment between Member States. I therefore supported the European Parliament's resolution on the European Semester and the annual growth survey for 2016.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: annual growth survey for 2016, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/2/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. In general, this report proposes to strengthen domestic demand through public and private investment that is greater than those of the Juncker Plan. He is concerned about macroeconomic and social disparities that are only slowly narrowing. Above all, this report is an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around a federalized and liberalized system. The hope presented in this report that the recommendations will be able to revive the European economy is one of the technocratic illusions of Brussels. We cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to respond to the Annual Growth Survey for 2016 on the Coordination of Economic Policies in the framework of the European Semester. While this report has made some improvements over previous ones, seeking a greater combination of investment policies, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, stressing the need for increased domestic demand and flexible monetary policies, the focus on the need for structural reforms and more competitive and flexible labour markets, always result in greater job insecurity and a continuation of austerity policies , not leading to sustainable and quality growth. I voted against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe must continue to improve economic governance and reforms at the national level must continue to ensure growth. This is why the European Parliament is betting on the report on the European Semester for Growth for 2016, so I support the motion for a resolution which I hope will help to move towards improved stability in the Union.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
