text: Writing. \u2012 Report on 2016 The European Semester for economic policy coordination highlights the major challenges facing competitiveness, financial stability, growth and employment.  The report stresses the importance of structural reforms, investment in research and development, resource efficiency, productivity-enhancing innovation and the reduction of macroeconomic imbalances, in order to achieve economic policy objectives.  In my opinion, it is equally important to improve national education, vocational training and lifelong learning systems and to adapt them to new needs in the labour market. Among other things, I agree with the report's position that economic growth is inseparable from a citizen-friendly public administration system at all levels of government, as well as effective and transparent rules on public procurement.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report is anchored in the logic of the implementation of the European semester. Although it makes some criticisms of the recommendations by country, it is no less imbued with liberal dogma: it thus promotes structural reforms and fiscal consolidation, the completion of the banking union, the reduction of employer contributions, the reform of social protection and pension systems, the adaptation of education and research systems to the needs of the market... While calling for an increased role of the European Parliament, supposedly for democratic reasons and more surely to legitimise the policies implemented. I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. While the state of play undertaken is quite obvious in this report, the recommendations are just as simple as being. This is a long complaint about our current economic anxieties, which unfortunately cannot be eliminated by the intercession of European ideology. This report leaves no doubt as to its futility. I am opposed to the principle of this European semester, which has reason only to achieve the objectives of the 'Europe 2020' programme.  I have, therefore, voted against this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary that some of those who appeal to the solidarity of those who comply with rules do not make austerity as it happened in Portugal inevitable, poorly ruling the Socialists by 2009. A country that spends more than it can afford, condemns itself intolerably and indebted to future generations. Therefore, the absurd spending options until 2009 meant, in Portugal, necessary deficit condition, debt, unemployment, recession, inability to finance the markets and the troika.  I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination because I share the position that greater coordination at European level is needed to achieve a stronger and more sustained economic recovery.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it represents Parliament’s commitment to building upon the recent economic recovery in the European Union and also implementing a long-term strategy for sustainable growth.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2016 because the EU can no longer rely on exports with the slowdown of the world economy. It needs to rely much more on internal demand and more private and public investment. Surplus countries need to expand their budgets in order to support investment and growth everywhere in the EU while deficit countries need to be allowed more fiscal space through the flexibility instrument to invest more. However, there are some sensitive points and I believe should remain an issue of the national competences.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission published its 2016 growth report on 26 November 2015. The Report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs notes that although the European Union is experiencing an economic recovery, this is rather uneven and some Member States are constantly struggling with low growth rates and global economic growth is slowing. It states that Europe continues to suffer from a significant investment deficit, which significantly weakens the longer-term growth potential and that the employment rate is improving, but not sufficiently, to significantly reduce unemployment and poverty. Finally, it points out that although the euro area's current account surplus is growing and the current account deficit and specific labour costs have decreased significantly in several Member States, private and public sector debt remains high in many countries and net external debt as a share of GDP has not been lower in most Member States. In the face of these problems, the report seeks to contribute proposals to the definition of economic policy priorities for 2016. It calls for measures to be put in place for a stronger recovery, for the governance of EMU to be deepened for stability and convergence, and for increased accountability, relevance and effectiveness to strengthen democracy. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report represents the EP's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 semester and follows the Commission's annual Growth Study. The topics covered in this report are investment, structural reforms, fiscal responsibility, eurozone issues, the democratic legitimacy of the European Semester and fiscal policies, the environment and public health, and regional development policies. However, this report is primarily an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around a federalized and liberalized system. The hope presented in this report that the recommendations will be able to revive the European economy is one of the technocratic illusions of Brussels. We cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is primarily an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around a federalized and liberalized system. I cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States of the European Union. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have given strong support to the adoption of this report setting out the EP's contribution to setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester process of policy coordination. The aim is to strengthen the democratic character of European economic governance, in the spirit of the interinstitutional agreement called for in the report of the five Presidents.  We are, in fact, emerging from a long economic crisis that has caused serious social difficulties and eroded growth potential. The combination of economic policies to be implemented by the EU, the euro area and individual Member States in 2016 must undoubtedly aim to strengthen the recent economic recovery and, at the same time, meet structural challenges.  In the current economic circumstances, the 'virtuous triangle' of investment, budgetary responsibility and structural reform promoted by the Commission will have to be broadened. Boosting growth potential by reducing inequalities is an objective compatible with the principle of fiscal responsibility.  We hope that all actors will actively participate in the European Semester in order to achieve a stronger economic recovery, a greater resilience of the European social market economy to structural shocks and challenges, thereby demonstrating that European democracy works and can ensure sustainable and widely shared prosperity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Annual Growth Survey sets out goals at EU level to help Member States support growth, reinforce economic convergence, create jobs and strengthen social fairness. I voted for this report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs that shows Parliament’s input to the definition of policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester. This report should stimulate debates at European level on the priorities for the next 12 months of EU economic policy.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which I consider to be an important contribution to ensuring effective coordination of member states' economic policies. I voted in favour of the amendment calling for the use of EFSI to be defined not only for strategic but also economically viable projects, because I believe that the aspect of economic viability should also be decisive. I also supported highlighting the need to remove barriers to entry into the labour market, especially for young people. This is one of the problems largely hindering successful economic development and should therefore be given increased attention.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have opposed this report because the original purpose of the European semester, to ensure the euro stability criteria, is no longer in the foreground. Instead, we are now talking about a centralised governing body of the planned economy. This then interferes with the budgeting of the Member States.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report concerns the implementation of the European Semester. Although he is quite critical of the country-by-country recommendations, he mentions the employment imperatives and a better budget for the Union; the report does not highlight the role of institutions in the liberal measures taken in recent years that have led to a deterioration in socio-economic conditions in many Member States. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. In order to improve the economic environment in Europe, structural reforms need to be carried out, to make the economy more competitive and to create a credible environment that attracts investment. However, the current report suggests focusing on increasing public spending rather than on economic modernisation or labour market reforms.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's reports on the 'European Semester', the mechanism for imposing 'permanent memoranda' on all EU Member States, demonstrate the commitment of the political staff of monopolies to its objectives: measures to continuously reduce the price of labour everywhere in order to recover the profitability of business groups, to come capitalist growth that so far seems anemic, uncertain and fragile.  That is why they require urban governments to implement the 'country-by-country recommendations', i.e. the unpopular measures drawn up by the EU institutions. In order to counter popular indignation, they attempt to dress up the whole process of six months and "enhanced economic governance" supposedly with "social aspects" and "social sensitivity", but they do not even manage to express wishful words, betraying their hostility to labour-popular rights.  The six-month period and all the procedures of the EU's 'permanent memorandums' cannot have a trace of a 'social aspect', because they were simply designed, implemented and serve a single plan to strike at every working, wage, social right of the working class and the poor working classes. There can be no euro-six months better, pro-populist, as various opportunists and new-cut social democrats are trying to deceive the people. The EU and the monopolies it serves only get worse. They're getting better than tipping.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP objects to the powers of the EU to oversee and instruct national parliaments as to their economic policy, as by doing so the EU in effect overrides the democratic will of the peoples of its Member States. Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the economic recovery in the EU, despite being in progress for some time, remains weak and uneven among and within Member States. In view of the fact that some of these states are faced with the persistent problem of very low growth rates and bearing in mind that, despite significant reductions in current account deficits and a reduction in unit labour costs, net foreign debt as a percentage of GDP has not decreased, I support the issues dealt with in that report.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Annual Growth Survey (AGS) identified three policy priorities for 2016: re-launching investment, pursuing structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies. The use of funds under Horizon 2020 and the European Structural and Investment Funds is essential for supporting growth and innovation across Europe. This Annual Growth Survey thus sets out what more can be done at EU level to help Member States support growth, reinforce economic convergence, create jobs and strengthen social fairness. Hence, I supported the resolution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Commission's Growth Review Report for this year has affected three main areas: investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility. I think it is essential that a thorough debate on three important issues should be launched at European level following this report: the issue of deepening coordination at eurozone level, on the further direction of the EU's fiscal, monetary and structural policy, and on the issue of democratising the decision-making process on the Recommendations of the European Semester. I agree with the rapporteur that it is essential for Europe to find responsible solutions to the new challenges it faces, in which these are primarily threats of terrorist attacks and the migrant crisis, in order to confirm its political legitimacy. I believe that by supporting this report, Parliament is contributing substantially to defining priorities in the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination 2016 and sends an important message to all actors to actively engage in the European Semester so that we can all together encourage a stronger economic recovery of the European economy.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report praises the European Semester, a system to which I am opposed and to which reality also tends to be wrong. He advocates an ever more federal and ever more liberal European economic package, which I cannot accept in any way. So of course I voted against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that in order to be able to combine monetary, structural and budgetary policies that open up high levels of employment, productivity and social cohesion in Europe, it is necessary to strengthen the integration of the euro area and deepen political coordination between Member States, to strengthen the key role played by the European Semester and to give it greater democratic responsibility, which will result in a more intensive dialogue between national parliaments. , European Parliament and Commission.  Progress towards a European democracy means at the same time having an interdependent, stable and inclusive economy. Above all, this process implies greater convergence of national economic policies which, although they are significantly interconnected as the economic crisis has revealed to us, must simultaneously implement the structural reforms required to relaunch the growth and competitiveness of the euro area.  The European Semester marks a very important moment in this regard, as it opens the period when Member States work together on their macroeconomic policy programmes and review their commitment to support the Europe2020 strategy. The main challenge to be expected is to reduce indebtedness combined with the revival of investment and the strengthening of domestic demand in an efficient regulatory environment.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Annual Growth Survey sets out what more can be done at EU level to help Member States support growth, boost economic convergence, create jobs and strengthen social fairness. It therefore underlines the importance of an integrated approach to economic policy based on three main areas of action that must work together: boosting investment, accelerating structural reforms and implementing responsible and growth-positive fiscal consolidation.  Only working together can restore trust and boost the regrowth of the entire EU, and this requires a resolute commitment from Member States to operate at national level. For this reason, I welcome the 2016 Annual Growth Review package and the proposed policy mix consisting of investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility, which aims to promote higher levels of growth and strengthen European recovery and upward convergence.  I would like to point out that due to the slowdown in the world economy, the EU cannot rely on exports, but should increase internal demand in order to increase the possibility of growth. For this reason, private and public investments need to be increased. Surplus countries need to expand their budgets to support investment, while deficit countries should be allowed more fiscal space through flexibility so they can set aside more on investment and structural reforms.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report reinforces and deepens a political vision that we firmly reject. The European Semester and economic governance are at the heart of the supranational neoliberal policy strategy on member states' fiscal policies, amputating their economic sovereignty. The guidelines in the report insist on the same revenue that sown poverty and unemployment across Europe, in practice preventing any development strategies and economic growth based on growth-stimulating policies and supported by public investment and promoting jobs with decent rights and wages. Any social cosmetic maneuvers or attempts to legitimise policies of austerity and impoverishment that are promoted do not erase the deeply undemocratic nature of economic and monetary union, which imposes, in the interests of the people and workers, its neoliberal policies of concentration of wealth. Only the break with these policies can pave the way for alternative development policies focused on asserting the sovereignty of states and defending the interests and longings of peoples and workers.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU is rising from a long economic crisis that has caused serious social hardship and jeopardised the potential for economic growth. At the same time, the EU faces new challenges, notably the threat of terrorist attacks, geopolitical instability in the neighbourhood and the unprecedented number of asylum seekers. It is important that the EU develops the means to address these challenges in this situation to ensure its political legitimacy. It is also important that economic reconstruction is stepped up and quality jobs created. In addition to the economic problems that have arisen in the midst of the development of the digital revolution and technological innovation, it is also important to address long-term challenges such as climate change, robotization, demographic change and the shift towards a multipolarn world. There is always a correlation between these challenges and the economic situation and it is very important that the priorities and proposals for the European Semester framework are accepted in line with the Europe 2020 strategy. Any structural reforms that will result must reflect and be based on the experiences of the past and the challenges that are yet to come. Despite the fact that the concept of structural reforms is generally understood as a concept that involves reducing the state role in the economy, thereby creating more flexible markets, such an approach has not always led to improved productivity, but has even increased inequalities and deflationary pressures. Consequently, I support the report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester ensures that Member States follow economic and budgetary policies consistent with their commitments to the EU. This 2016 growth analysis outlines the additional measures to be taken at EU level to help Member States support growth, strengthen economic convergence, create jobs and foster greater social equity.  The text proposes to pursue an integrated approach to economic policy based on three main pillars: relaunching investment, speeding up structural reforms and pursuing responsible and growth-friendly budgetary consolidation. In addition, the 2016 Annual Growth Survey is accompanied by a number of recommendations for the euro area.  I hope that all Member States will actively participate in the 2016 European Semester, in order to achieve a stronger economic recovery and greater resilience of the European social market economy to structural challenges. Only in this way will we be able to demonstrate that European democracy works and is able to ensure sustainable and widely shared prosperity. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report calls for stronger coordination at European level and deeper coordination of tax policy in the EU. The report also stresses the need for the EU's own resources and calls for steps to be taken towards fiscal consolidation and closer integration in the euro area in order to complete the EMU process quickly. Furthermore, the text of the report refers several times to previously adopted documents that our delegation has never supported, namely the five Presidents' report calling for the strengthening and swift completion of the Banking Union. One paragraph also calls for the transfer of labour taxation to taxes related to environmental pollution. I therefore could not support the report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. This report is the European Parliament's contribution to the definition of economic policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester for the coordination of economic policy in response to the Annual Growth Survey and related Commission documents. In my opinion, the report focuses too much on measures of demand-oriented policies and on harmonisation measures; it also claims that the euro area is a macroeconomic entity which is a single entity. In order to strengthen democracy, the report calls for a redefinition of a number of responsibilities of national parliaments and for the practice of national parliaments to discuss and vote on national reform programmes and stability and convergence programmes to be extended. I am abstaining because I cannot support too many points in this report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a particularly difficult time in Europe, with multiple European crises, the European Parliament sends a message in the defence of internal cohesion, betting on an economic recovery that will reduce unemployment and social inequalities. We need not only fiscal consolidation and reforms, but also a significant increase in investment and domestic demand. A growth and jobs strategy needs to be the first goal of this semester. I would like the message to be stronger and clearer. It is still a step in that direction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that in the context of the slowdown in the world economy, the Union must strengthen its domestic demand more than ever in order to achieve greater economic growth, reduce inequalities, create more quality jobs and improve social cohesion.  Less competitive countries should invest more in improving their productivity, rather than competing with lower wages and reducing public services. At the same time, the Member States of the Union with stronger economies must increase their efforts to support domestic demand through increased public and private investment and a rise in wages.  The euro area is a major economy that must be treated as such and must work towards upward convergence, with employment and social indicators at the same level as existing indicators. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it sets out the need for more reforms, yes, but for reforms to improve the quality of education systems, invest in innovation, modernise public administration and make more efficient use of natural resources.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted this resolution this afternoon by 395 votes in person, 203 against and 50 abstentions. The voted text specifies that the Stability and Growth Pact should be fully implemented but, with flexibility in investment and structural reforms, as well as in addressing the challenges of refugees and security. In addition, the text calls for a reduction in labour tax burdens, for better national monitoring of country-specific recommendations, for more national investment in countries with large current account surpluses, and for measures against aggressive corporate tax planning. In a context of multiple crises, it is necessary to strengthen the internal cohesion of the European Union through a stronger and more balanced economic recovery (not to mention the social, which was now the subject of another report).

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because I believe that it contains positive aspects. In particular, the text stresses that macroeconomic imbalances should be reduced by coordinated action by all Member States on the basis of relevant reforms and investments. Another important aspect is the aim of giving employment rates (labour force participation rates, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment) the same status as existing indicators, in order to ensure that there is no two-level approach and that these indicators should be duly taken into account when formulating EU policies and drawing up guidelines for Member States.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. As Europe struggles to emerge from an economic crisis and is facing a serious migration crisis, Maria Joel Rodrigues' report sets economic policy priorities for the European Union as part of the European Semester coordination process. The report stresses the importance of bringing economic policies into line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. It calls for a correction of macroeconomic imbalances, through a coordinated effort by Member States. Above all, the European Parliament calls for greater support for domestic demand, particularly through increased investment. These will have to be particularly geared towards training and innovation. The report highlights the need to improve tax collection and the fight against fraud and tax evasion. Finally, it recalls the usefulness of the European semester and encourages the improvement of its effectiveness in order to better coordinate economic policies, increase its democratic character and include new objectives such as those related to the environment. For all these reasons, I voted for this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of this resolution, and as I have already said in relation to the report on employment and social affairs, I would like to reaffirm the importance of the 3 priorities identified by the Commission in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey: relaunching investment, need for structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies. In an ideologically difficult report, it was possible to build bridges between the EPP and S&D, and the document, among other ideas, stressed the need for structural reforms and fiscal consolidation, while avoiding politicisation of the European Central Bank, and the need to make wage increases, obviously dependent on productivity increases by member states' economies, was also highlighted. I would also stress that, despite the overall improvements in public finances in the EU, including the gradual decline in debt-to-GDP ratios, government debt ratios continue to grow in several Member States, which requires close and close monitoring of these situations. I also consider it important to point out the resolution which states that "effective implementation of structural reforms, as well as greater coordination at European level, in order to achieve a stronger economic recovery and a sustainable and widely shared prosperity", and I therefore voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which expresses the European Parliament's positions on the European semester, particularly with regard to economic policies. At a time when we are seeking to boost growth and create jobs, this resolution underlines the need to strengthen European coordination between Member States for economic policies, and to adopt a comprehensive approach combining investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility policies. The first is to highlight national efforts to implement structural reforms; but also to advocate European coordination for fiscal consolidation without harming growth. Strengthening domestic demand, addressing macroeconomic imbalances and rapidly implementing the Banking Union is crucial. I have supported this text which calls for the European Fund for Strategic Investments to be made to the maximum of its possibilities in order to pursue a coherent and coordinated industrial policy. Finally, in order to confirm the economic recovery within the EU, it is necessary, particularly in the euro area, to encourage genuine economic and social convergence and better European coordination of social and fiscal standards.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by Parliament. The European Semester is the mechanism by which the Union is currently trying to implement compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact — deficit and debt control, as well as other meters. I am opposed to these objectives of stringing up the economies of individual States on the basis of neoliberal criteria. The European Semester consists of a procedure by which the Commission reviews national budgets before their approval in Parliaments and issues country-specific recommendations to be implemented in next year's budgets. I am also opposed to this method which clearly infringes the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Because of the growing resistance to the economic governance framework and its dire effects on the popular classes, several proposals insist on maquillaring the European Semester by increasing it with redistributive social policies or elements of democratic oversight while maintaining the "deepening" (in jargon of the Union) of its economic policies. Since the neoliberal key to the neoliberal vault — the individualisation of industrial relations and the orientation of public policies for the private benefit — is not called into question, I voted against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to congratulate Ms. Rodrigues on the sterling work that she has done on this text that was adopted today. The EU, in my view, and the view of many Socialists across this chamber, cannot rely on exports any longer, especially with the slowdown of the global economy in the last decade. There is a need for surplus countries to expand their budgets so as to support investment and growth elsewhere and everywhere in the EU, while at the same time allowing for more fiscal wriggle room for countries with large deficits so that more and better investment can be made to encourage growth and put these states on the road to recovery.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in line with the EKR's position against this resolution when voting on the European Semester resolution for the coordination of economic employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. The Annual Growth Survey sets out the Commission's priorities for action at national and European level to promote economic growth and employment later this year. I consider it important that adequate attention be paid and support for reform efforts in the field of employment and social policy. At the same time, however, the principle of subsidiarity must be respected, so I could not agree with the requirements for the further transfer of competences in this area from the Member States to the EU level.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: I supported the report on the European Semester in writing ‒ because I believe that, in the current situation of economic recession, we need to ask ourselves some fundamental questions on how to improve the coordination of the economic policies of individual Member States. In the near future, Europe will be facing important decisions on fiscal, monetary and structural policy. We will have to decide how to better coordinate the policies of the euro area countries and how to make decisions about the future of the euro more democratically. If citizens expect there to be a stronger economic recovery and the creation of quality jobs enabling equal opportunities, we need to address the structural challenges of our economies, particularly at European level. Europe is facing global economic impacts to which it could respond more flexibly if there were greater agreement between Member States on the Direction of the Union. The recovery between countries is still uneven and is often influenced by external factors such as the low price of oil. In addition, we have a lack of investment in Europe, even though the current account surplus is increasing. As the 2008 crisis has proved to be not only cyclical but largely structural in nature, fundamental structural reforms will have to be carried out, but this requires greater willingness of Member States to seek common solutions to economic challenges.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Although the economic recovery in the EU is ongoing, this is still weak and uneven among Member States and partly dependent on temporary and external factors. Europe is still facing a significant investment deficit that significantly weakens the EU's longer-term growth potential. In the face of economic and financial turmoil in many emerging economies, economic growth is slowing and leading to new strategic challenges to which the EU will have to respond appropriately.  Europe is an economic area that relies heavily on imported resources compared to competitors. I agree that this is precisely why building a real circular economy is a prerequisite for future economic growth.  The report refers to the 2016 Annual Growth Survey package and the proposed policy mix. These include investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility and are intended to further promote higher growth rates and strengthen the European recovery.  The report also touches on the problem of the euro area and stresses that, due to its high degree of interdependence and unity, this represents an economic unit in which convergence of the most prospecious countries must be promoted and supported through greater coordination of national policies.  I believe that paying attention to increased competitiveness, growth and employment, taking into account the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, is extremely important, which is why I supported the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the Annual Growth Survey published by the Commission in the autumn of last year. It lists growth priorities for the coming years. The text adopted by Parliament calls for wider state efforts to create growth. In my view, however, the mix of instruments proposed to achieve this objective is only very suitable for this purpose.  Public demand is sold in a classic Keynesian manner as an all-purpose weapon, and it is given an abstract, totally inflated and unrealistic status. The report also calls for further exemptions from the Stability and Growth Pact and seeks to further weaken it for political expedient objectives. ALFA believes that rules must also be followed by politics in particular and must not be interpreted and watered down arbitrarily. We are strongly opposed to further exemptions from the SGP. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Despite the gradual resumption of economic growth in the EU, some Member States continue to deal with the impact of the recession. Europe still faces a number of challenges, including a lack of investment and unemployment. The sustainability of public finances or investments in science and research are fundamental to economic stability and create a preconditions for further growth.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The economic recovery in the European Union is ongoing, but remains weak and uneven between and within Member States and is partly driven by temporary and external factors, including low oil prices. World economic growth is slowing due to economic and financial turmoil in several emerging economies, leading to new strategic challenges that must be adequately adapted by the European Union. Europe still faces a severe investment short supply, significantly weakening the EU's potential for longer-term growth, while the current account surplus of the euro area balance of payments is growing. I therefore welcome the 2016 Annual Growth Review package and the proposed policy mix consisting of investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility, which aims to promote higher levels of growth and strengthen European recovery and upward convergence. I would also stress that achieving a stronger economic recovery and sustainable, widespread prosperity requires significant national efforts to effectively implement structural reforms as well as stronger European coordination.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Annual Growth Research Report names three priorities for 2016: implementing structural reforms, responsible fiscal policies and starting investments. It emphasises the need to address macro-economic disproportion, improve the business environment, respect common fiscal rules, reduce public debt and combat long-term unemployment.  Global competitiveness remains an important objective. Member States must develop new strategic approaches and structural reforms to strengthen the long-term growth potential of EU countries and to successfully combat long-term unemployment, especially in young people and poverty. Many member states have limited fiscal opportunities to deal with new economic shocks. While economic recovery is evident in some Countries of the European Union, progress is still uneven and weak in many countries.  Investments in skills development, a more inclusive labour market at EU level and the creation and maintenance of equal job opportunities are needed. I support the report because it highlights the need to invest in structural reforms, productivity and reducing macro-economic inequalities and the importance of the possibility of free movement of people, goods, services and capital, which is the basis for sustainable economic growth of the European Union market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: the Annual Growth Survey 2016.  Following the economic crisis engulfing the entire European Union, the economic recovery is different from that of the Member States. In some Member States they see a high growth rate, while some Member States still face low growth rates. Despite the slightly improved indicators, in some regions the unemployment rate is still too high.  I support the proposed policy mix, which includes investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, aimed at further promoting higher growth rates and strengthening The European recovery and upward convergence.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our firm position on overturning the European Semester and austerity policies has led us to vote against this report as well, which "welcomes the 2016 Annual Growth Survey package and the proposed mix of investment policy, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility," but also calls for greater economic coordination, the correction of macroeconomic imbalances through the well-known unpopular neoliberal policies of harsh austerity and memoranda and "major national efforts in the effective implementation of reforms".

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Aligning Member States' fiscal and economic policies with EU requirements imposes a continuous and deep recession on weak economic countries, while promoting the interests of powerful states. The operation of the European Semester leads to total economic control of Greece, so that it cannot implement a national economic policy for its exit from the crisis, but is constantly under the control of Germany and the other economically powerful countries.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. In my view, it is too eurozone-centric and completely ignores the role of non-eurozone countries in the context of the European Semester. Although the report notes that the implementation of the CSRs is inadequate, it does not include the fact that compliance with the recommendations varies greatly between eurozone and non-euro area countries. (In 2014, eurozone countries made some progress on 61% of the recommendations, while non-eurozone countries made at least some progress in only 33% of the recommendations.) Although the rapporteur encourages the initiation of a public debate in this regard, I miss the proposal to establish a mechanism through which the Commission can better encourage Member States to implement CSR. Furthermore, I also miss the mention of social equity, which is also at the heart of economic recovery policies. Overall, despite the fact that the report touches on a number of important issues, it lacks specific details on them and thus does not sufficiently emphasise the EP's expectations.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Annual Growth Study presented by the European Commission launches an annual cycle of economic governance, called the European Semester. There is no doubt that the economic and social priorities set out in the 2015 growth analysis, namely investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, remain valid. One of the most important challenges facing Member States is the still unsatisfactory outcome of the implementation of the country-specific recommendations. Without political will and commitment at national level, it is not possible to implement the recommended reforms, which aim, after all, to boost competitiveness, create new and stable jobs and achieve sustainable growth.  There is no doubt that the European Commission also has an important role to play in this process. It should seek to make better use of the European Structural and Investment Funds so that they support the implementation of the key priorities identified in the country-specific recommendations, including through measures combining the effectiveness of these funds with sound economic governance and the strengthening of the European single market, which is a prerequisite for economic growth in Europe.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this text and hope that all actors will actively commit to the 2016 European semester with the aim of achieving a stronger economic recovery and a better resilience of the European social market economy in the face of shocks and structural difficulties, proving that European democracy works and is able to ensure sustainable and widely shared prosperity.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ If recovery in the EU is progressively gaining ground in the EU, Member States need to continue to pursue structural reforms to make their economies more competitive and build confidence in their economic and business environment to incentivise investors to invest. However, this report calls past efforts into question by recommending an increase in public spending, being hesitant on modernising economies and shielding against labour market reforms, which would lower the barriers to entry into the labour market, particularly for the young. These are the reasons why I voted against it. Indeed, it does not strike the right balance between demand and supply side reforms. It falls short of requesting barriers to entry into the labour market be removed, of more explicitly prescribing reforms such as modernising economies, making social security systems more sustainable and promoting innovation and entrepreneurship. Moreover it does not recommend European Fund for Structural Investments (EFSI) projects to be economically viable. In this context, I could not support it.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is undoubtedly the best outcome of the Process of European Integration. The current market is still growing weakly and there is still ample untapped potential. At this difficult time for European unity, we must consider the high potential that the single market can have to revive growth and innovation in order to make Europe more competitive. Member States need to use the European Fund for Strategic Investments to maximise national strategies and boost growth and competitiveness through projects that could not have been financed from other funds.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report by Mrs Rodrigues on the grounds that the European Union is still experiencing the effects of the economic crisis, which have caused serious social problems and damaged the potential for economic growth. The people of Europe expect a greater economic recovery, creating quality jobs and restoring economic stability. We are facing serious, long-term challenges, such as shredding work organisation, demographic change, and we are at a turn around in the face of a multipolar global. For this reason, we need to develop a long-term strategy for sustainable economic growth. The time has come to move towards concrete structural reforms, the main objective of which should be to strengthen the growth potential of the economy by increasing employment and productivity, promoting fair and balanced action to increase social protection, as well as reducing social inequalities in order to restore a level playing field in the European labour market. This should also be taken into account in the newly proposed programme to promote structural reforms.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While I agree that further efforts are needed to recover European Union economies and correct macroeconomic imbalances, I consider that the measures proposed in this report do not represent an effective or correct way to achieve the objectives of poverty reduction, social exclusion and rising inequality.  In fact, despite the fact that I believe that Member States need to exploit the full potential of the ESI Funds, I consider this to be an overly prescriptive text which also seeks to reduce the role and meaning of national parliaments as major players in matters of economic governance. As I do not support the proposal to redistribute and redefine responsibilities within the European Semester through the transfer of debates from the level of national parliaments to the Plenary Session of the European Parliament, I voted with abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: I supported the 2016 Annual Growth Survey, as it is a defining economic policy priority in the context of the 2016 policy coordination process.  The purpose of this report is to stimulate debate at European level, including by involving national Members, social partners and civil society, on three main issues, namely on what combination of fiscal, monetary and structural policies the European Union should implement over the next 12-18 months, how to deepen policy coordination at euro area level and how to achieve that decision-making on the priorities and recommendations of the European Semester is more democratic and how to ensure a more comprehensive implementation of the recommendations.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by Parliament. The European Semester is the mechanism by which the Union is currently trying to implement compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact — deficit and debt control, as well as other meters. I am opposed to these objectives of stringing up the economies of individual States on the basis of neoliberal criteria. The European Semester consists of a procedure by which the Commission reviews national budgets before their approval in Parliaments and issues country-specific recommendations to be implemented in next year's budgets. I am also opposed to this method which clearly infringes the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the Annual Growth Survey published by the Commission in the autumn of last year. It lists growth priorities for the coming years. The text adopted by Parliament calls for wider state efforts to create growth. In my view, however, the mix of instruments proposed to achieve this objective is only very suitable for this purpose.  Public demand is sold in a classic Keynesian manner as an all-purpose weapon, and it is given an abstract, totally inflated and unrealistic status. The report also calls for further exemptions from the Stability and Growth Pact and seeks to further weaken it for political expedient objectives. ALFA believes that rules must also be followed by politics in particular and must not be interpreted and watered down arbitrarily. We are firmly opposed to allowing further exemptions from the Stability and Growth Pact. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this report as it is quite biased against surplus countries without taking into account that most of their surplus exports are outside the EU. With China’s slowdown and the arrival of 1 million refugees, the surplus will go down by itself. Moreover it includes a mention in the Commission communication that enables Member States to get fiscal flexibility just by announcing reforms (not approving/implementing them as would be logical) and lastly, it misrepresents the objectives of EFSI and does not clarify that only economically viable projects should receive its financing to avoid having more airports without planes, motorways without traffic and high speed trains without passengers.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report represents the European Parliament's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 semester and follows the Commission's annual Growth Study. The topics covered in this report are investment, structural reforms, fiscal responsibility, eurozone issues, the democratic legitimacy of the European Semester and fiscal policies, the environment and public health, and regional development policies. In general, this report proposes to strengthen domestic demand through public and private investment that is higher than the Juncker Plan, especially with low rates. But these investments must remain sustainable given the very high levels of debt. It is also concerned about macroeconomic and social disparities that are narrowing only very slowly. However, this report is primarily an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around a federalized and liberalized system. The hope presented in this report that the recommendations will be able to revive the European economy is one of the technocratic illusions of Brussels. We cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States. I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2016 Annual Growth Survey underlines the need for greater national efforts for a stronger economic recovery and sustainable broad prosperity, as well as stronger European coordination and instruments for the effective implementation of structural reforms. I voted in favour of the final document.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it imposes a vision of economic governance based on austerity and structural reforms which represent a massive loss of social rights.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Citizens look forward to a stronger economic recovery, quality jobs and new equal opportunities. We also want to live in a cleaner environment and take advantage of the opportunities offered by the digital revolution and other technological innovations. Increasing domestic demand requires more investment in both the private and public sectors in excess of 2014. investment plan for Europe presented by the Commission. Attention should therefore be paid to ways in which the reduction in indebtedness could be encouraged and new investments to support sustainable and inclusive growth should be encouraged.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2016. This report represents Parliament’s contribution to the definition of economic policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester process of policy coordination, responding to the Commission’s Annual Growth Survey and related documents, including a draft recommendation for the economic policy of the euro area. The report stresses that the stability and growth pact should be implemented in full and that its flexibility should be reflected upon investment and structural reforms and in dealing with refugee and security challenges. We need a more solid and well balanced economic recovery while facing the consequences of the financial crisis and this is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The 2016 Annual Growth Survey proposes to relaunch investment through the Investment Plan for Europe, boosting investment projects, completing the banking union and accelerating work on the Capital Markets Union, boosting investment in human capital, and reforming education and training systems to boost employment and sustainable growth , continue with the implementation of structural reforms to modernize the economy and implement responsible fiscal policies. In short, we are talking about a number of proposals which seek to recover a path of long-term sustainable growth to generate jobs in Europe, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against yet another report which should identify the strategic priorities for growth and jobs in Europe by analysing what has not worked so far, but which once again ends up blindly insisting on the usual failed recipes advocated for more than five years by the European Commission with no other result than to produce record levels of unemployment, poverty and inequality. I find it unacceptable that the parties of the establishment continue without hesitation to defend a toxic strategy that preaches austerity, structural reforms, strict application of budgetary constraints and centrality of private investment in the financing of public goods, consciously denying the indisputable role of the single currency in condemning most eurozone countries to recession, in blocking any economic recovery and in exacerbating inequalities and imbalances between countries. We insisted on the need to change course, immediately introducing democratic mechanisms to exit the euro and preparing a plan for the controlled and coordinated dissolution of the eurozone. At the moment, however, although it is becoming increasingly clear that there can be no growth within the euro, there is a lack of a fundamental element of intellectual honesty in the institutions: the will and the political courage to admit that the euro was a serious mistake and to start working as soon as possible on Plan B.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted against this report. In order to improve the economic climate in Europe, structural changes are needed to make our economy competitive again and attract investment. In my opinion, this report places too much emphasis on public expenditure rather than on economic modernisation and social reform.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the adoption of the European Parliament's report on the European Semester for the 2016 Growth Survey.  I voted against the report mainly because it took a positive view of the five Presidents' plan for the development of the euro area. I cannot agree with that. The five Presidents' plan aims, among other things, at a bank union of solidarity, a common euro area budget with permanent transfer systems and a common Ministry of Finance.  The deeper integration of the euro area, as requested in the report, will take decision-making power away from the governments of the euro area countries to a supranational level, far away from the Member States and their citizens. I do not agree with this trend.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Under the guise of European coordination of economic and budgetary policies, the European semester, set up after the 2008 financial crisis, must, we are told, be able to monitor the implementation of so-called structural reforms and the reduction of budget deficits, we know what this means. And the least that can be said is that the dramatic consequences of the austerity policies deployed on the European continent are once again largely overshadowed by parliament's annual report on the European semester. Symptomatic of this hypocrisy, several paragraphs recognise that Member States, whose budgets are being cut by austerity, are no longer able to protect and promote key sectors such as education, health, research or innovation, but without questioning the causes of these distressing findings. It is high time to stop these deadly austere policies and to promote alternative policies based on a different distribution of wealth and other priorities that meet the needs of the people and not those of money and finance.  I voted against the various reports on this subject as well as all members of my group.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The growth outlook for 2016 represents the starting point of a process to which we firmly oppose it. The European Semester and economic governance are at the heart of a neoliberal strategy for national states' fiscal policies.  The guidelines contained in the report, which should be respected by governments, insist on the same revenue that soed poverty and unemployment across Europe, in practice preventing any alternative strategies to address the crisis, with growth-stimulating policies based on public investment and increased aggregate demand. There are no cosmetic maneuvers, whether from a social point of view or through the greater involvement of this House, which erase the deeply undemocratic nature of economic and monetary union, which imposes, in the interests of the people and workers, its neoliberal policies of concentration of wealth. We remain convinced that only the end of EMU and the euro can pave the way for alternative development policies, focusing on people's well-being rather than the accumulation of profits.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Annual Growth Survey serves as a stimulus for a debate at European level, involving national parliaments, social partners and society, to analyse the combination of monetary and structural measures the European Union should implement in the coming months and how this should be better coordinated at eurozone level. I am very critical of various aspects of this European policy. I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because it discriminates against nationals. Instead of constantly expanding, more should be helped and invested at home.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policy – employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. I have accompanied this report as shadow rapporteur for my group. I am not satisfied with the result. My concerns have not been taken into account.  Firstly, I am fundamentally opposed to the economic governance of the EU and the euro area through the European Semester. On the contrary, the Member States should pursue their own economic policies and thereby enter into competition with each other. A coordinated economic policy is only needed if the intention is to establish or maintain transfer mechanisms between Member States. Secondly, the report erroneously maintains the illusion that the euro is a one-way street and that the members of the euro area are irrevocably linked. I have tabled and supported amendments calling for an exit mechanism. However, they did not receive a majority.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to continuously reiterate the call for a strong social dimension to the European Semester and country-specific recommendations, in order to arrive at growth which is truly inclusive and sustainable. Terms like ‘structural reforms’, ‘fiscal consolidation’, and ‘budgetary responsibility’ cannot remain coded jargon for harmful austerity policies, which hurt the most vulnerable in society and strangle economic growth. Instead, structural reforms must entail meaningful change towards delivering a higher quality of social services to those who need them most, and enabling effective social investment and financing to stimulate inclusive and sustainable growth.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 This report represents the European Parliament's contribution to defining economic policy priorities while encouraging the strengthening of the democratic nature of European economic governance. It is also intended to spark debate at European level with the involvement of national parliaments and civil society on three main themes: the combination of fiscal, monetary and structural policies; policy coordination at euro area level; ensure better implementation of the recommendations. As a result of the long-term economic crisis, citizens are eager for stronger economic recovery, quality jobs and a return to equal opportunities. However, a strengthening of domestic demand is needed to boost economic growth, which of course requires greater investment by both the private and public sectors.  However, support for potential growth must be achieved by eliminating inequalities, making efficient use of public spending and more effective tax collection linked to the prevention of tax evasion.  At national level, in-depth parliamentary discussions with Members of the Commission and national governments will be key, based on the euro area recommendation, the European Council conclusions, the European Commission's country reports and country-specific recommendations. I supported this report because it emphasises the strengthening of democracy for greater accountability and the need for higher investment in view of their low interest rates, which is extremely important in view of the high level of public and private debt.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this annual growth survey for 2016 in which the Commission opened the European Semester by identifying priorities to promote growth and employment in Europe.  The report basically supports the failed strategy proposed by the Commission, insisting on the need to continue with fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, private investment, full implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact. The report lacks an adequate analysis of the role of the euro, macroeconomic imbalances, budgetary constraints and the impact of the Commission's recipes on the economy, and there is therefore no critical reflection on the need for a real change of course.  There are, however, a number of points that we can support, such as the importance of stimulating domestic demand and increasing public investment, and a greater focus on environmental issues, unemployment and growing inequalities. These are, however, references which, if not accompanied by proposals for alternative policies and revision of the rules and mechanisms of economic governance, are empty and insufficient, and therefore do not change the text's basic message in favour of the bankruptcy policy pursued so far and a further strengthening of the current structures of economic governance and monetary union.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's reports on the 'European Semester', the mechanism for imposing 'permanent memoranda' on all EU Member States, demonstrate the commitment of the political staff of monopolies to its objectives: measures to continuously reduce the price of labour everywhere in order to recover the profitability of business groups, to come the capitalist growth that has so far seemed anemic, uncertain and fragile.  That is why they require urban governments to implement the 'country-by-country recommendations', i.e. the unpopular measures drawn up by the EU institutions. In order to counter popular indignation, they attempt to dress up the whole process of six months and "enhanced economic governance" supposedly with "social aspects" and "social sensitivity", but they do not even manage to express wishful words, betraying their hostility to labour-popular rights.  The six-month period and all the procedures of the EU's 'permanent memorandums' cannot have a trace of a 'social aspect', because they were simply designed, implemented and serve a single plan to strike at every working, wage, social right of the working class and the poor working classes. There can be no euro-six months better, pro-populist, as various opportunists and new-cut social democrats are trying to deceive the people. The EU and the monopolies it serves only get worse. They're getting better than tipping.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies: Annual Growth Survey for 2016, from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and whose rapporteur is Mrs João Rodrigues, because it marks a turning point in the prevailing thinking in the European forum for the representation of European citizens. The report rejects the austerity model and is committed to coordination of economic and social policies, which refers to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Jobs. It advocates strengthening investment and domestic demand. It advocates "second generation" structural reforms to strengthen growth potential, focusing on education and innovation, sustainability of the social model, modernisation of public administration and a tax system for fair and equitable. It also supports a new eurozone management model, bringing it closer to an optimal monetary area, by easing it with its own instruments within the framework of economic and monetary union. It is a historical report, the recommendations of which need to be made.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The achievement of the European Union's sustainable prosperity and global competitiveness is the objectives pursued, inter alia, by the Report on the Annual Growth Survey 2016, which I supported.  I agree that achieving the objectives set requires stronger European coordination and investment in investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility for member states.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – Unfortunately, I must say that this report on the growth of the European Union is pure schizophrenia, which is why I voted against it. The report criticises black work while proposing steps that make legal employment more difficult and more expensive. The report calls for a policy of real growth, while at the same time proposing to increase the redistribution rate. The report criticises the level of debt, while proposing many measures that increase that debt even further. And the report notes that there is high unemployment in the European Union, while at the same time proposing to raise the minimum wage. This is simply not how economic policy works. We can write a lot and different reports here for a long time, but the real economy works by getting more freedom, less redistribution and less low taxes.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – In view of the fact that we are deciding the real lives and fates of real people here in the European Parliament, I will once again return to my real person, who recently stated how good it is to be a family entrepreneur, not in a huge multinational company, mostly, right, as a vulnerable worker , because that is what we Hungarians get most. So, for our part, we would like to push family businesses, so to speak, and to force their support, and the occupational and social aspects of these, which this second report is about, are very important. Here, on the basis of family solidarity, employment is solved, there is no unemployment, because they go to the very end to keep the work of the relative, the family member. They're not going to put him out on the street, they're going to try to do it on more legs or some other way to keep the job going. They don't put a mother, a woman with a small child, or an elderly employee on the street because she's a family member.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Housing sector support, continuation of renovation, health, children's and youth policies, senior policy... Although this report mentions this only in part, this set of measures of fundamental importance is absolutely vital for the entire European Union, especially in my country, Latvia. Once again, I would like to emphasise the particular emphasis on children's and young people's policies. Because, figuratively speaking, if you do not pay attention to the development of fruit trees or, say, strawberry beds, there is a possibility that nothing good will grow or grow, but will not be particularly consumable. But children are "flowers" of our lives, and everything must be done to make them grow up happily, socially, spiritually, morally developed. This is very important. This is Task No 1.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, despite the slowly-diminishing unemployment rate and the persistent positive trend of economic growth, behind the overall figures there are still strong differences between Member States as well as structural problems on the employment market. Besides the lower-than-desired percentage of economically-active women and youth unemployment above 20% , most worrying is the number of long-term unemployed, which has doubled in recent years, translating into a serious risk of poverty and social exclusion in our societies and the regrettable waste of human capital. This is why I welcome the report’s call for more responsible structural reforms and for more investment in human capital in order to develop resilient economies. An inclusive labour market can then also withstand the challenges posed by population ageing and increasing economic dependency.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE)
text: . Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Anyone who portrays the economic and social situation in the EU as bleak is spreading a picture of disarray. The economy will grow by two percent this year and next. Unemployment will, at last, fall. So our policies are slow but safe. The Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative are being vigorously implemented, as the Member States have finally abandoned their hesitation. 4.8 million young people seeking training or a job must not be left alone. The Ribeiro report also includes social indicators. They must be given the same status as the economic indicators, and they must be accompanied by in-depth analyses of the specific problems in the Member States. Let us prove that we are taking effective action against unemployment, hopelessness and exclusion. In so doing, the EU is demonstrating the importance of solidarity and humanity in our Community.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called on the unelected EU Commission to initiate new legislation monitoring the spending of taxpayers’ money. The report calls for things like interfering with Member States’ social protection, tax policies and tax rules, welcomes the EU Commission’s initiative on the long-term unemployed, calls to enhance the Youth Guarantee Scheme, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together on removing the obstacles to fair labour mobility and calls for better coordination of the European Semester , specifically for the Eurozone.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The biannual report on the coordination of economic policies highlights the need to implement uniform industrial policies throughout the EU and the need to facilitate SMEs in accessing European funds. The report also highlights the social dimension of EU action, with particular reference to unemployment and cuts in public spending. However, the text focuses too much on strengthening economic and monetary union. That is why I have chosen to vote against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that economic recovery should be fair, create quality jobs, reduce inequalities and combat poverty and social exclusion. We need upward social European convergence, with socially responsible reforms based on solidarity, social integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth. Investment in social development should not simply be a means of improving economic growth, but an end in itself. We need greater investments in social protection systems to combat poverty and combat growing inequalities.  In addition, the euro area is treated as a single economy that needs deeper integration, with a strengthened social dimension, better social protection floors and minimum wages, and a strong pillar of social rights.  Finally, I supported this report because it shows us the reality of the data and forgets the Commission's complacency. Employment is being created, but this is precarious, with indecent wages, unfair working conditions and precarious positions. There is no greater betrayal of the social model than the fact that labour poverty is now one of Europe's main problems.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The timid social reforms proposed in this report are, in practice, incompatible with an economic framework whose guiding principles will remain neoliberal economic policies, which they serve as a mechanism for legitimization. That's why I voted against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the European semester for the coordination of economic policies. This text, as every year, welcomes the Commission's assessments. It does not propose any concrete recommendations other than the fight against the ills known for years: unemployment, unreported work, low fertility rates, ageing... Furthermore, I am fundamentally opposed to this European semester, which is only a tool for the Commission to assess the work of Member States and to interfere more in the affairs of countries.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. We are in favour of raising the lowest wages in the EU in order to reduce poverty and combat wage dumping. In Sweden, unlike in most countries, there is no statutory minimum wage, but wages are set by collective agreements between the social partners without direct political interference. We therefore believe that minimum wages should not be regulated by law, but that account must be taken of each member country's national practices in order to strengthen collective agreements and workers' rights in the different wage-setting systems.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: employment growth survey for 2016, because it sets economic priorities and economic targets for the coming year. It also includes an assessment of the social situation and employment in the EU and is the first year that specific recommendations for the euro area are included. High-level work, equal opportunities and fair mobility are key principles of European social convergence.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The recommendations developed in this report are grossly useless, such as developing skills and skills with training, combating undeveloped work, modernising social systems to cope with ageing, etc. Being opposed in principle to the existence of this semester: it is only a tool for the Commission to assess and judge the work of the Member States. As for the country-specific recommendations, they are only one more way for the Commission to interfere in the functioning of countries. Finally, this semester exists only to enable the objectives of Strategy 2020, an EU strategy which we strongly oppose, to be achieved. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency I would like to confirm I voted against this report.  It is another example of the European Union interfering in the sovereignty of Member States. Unemployment in my constituency is the highest in the UK. This report will not reduce unemployment in my constituency. It will not increase wages in my constituency. It will not create jobs in the North East.  The EU will not reduce the levels of unemployment in the North East; it is a job for the UK Government.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, by which the European Parliament endorsed the EU's economic, social and single market priorities for 2016. This report is Parliament's contribution to setting economic policy priorities for 2016. the European Semester policy coordination process in response to the Commission's Annual Growth Survey.
