The report on the employment and social aspects of the European Semester and the single market highlights the need to step up efforts to encourage investment in skills, to ensure that labour markets are more inclusive, to create quality jobs and to reduce poverty, social exclusion and increasing income and wealth inequalities while maintaining budgetary discipline. I agree that employment indicators should be given the same status as existing indicators and that these indicators should be duly taken into account when formulating EU policies and drawing up guidelines for Member States. There is also a call for further reductions in labour taxation and for the sustainability of social protection systems.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report represents Parliament's participation in setting economic policy priorities for the 2016 semester and follows the Commission's annual growth study. The topics covered in this report are investment, structural reforms, fiscal responsibility, eurozone issues, the democratic legitimacy of the European Semester and fiscal policies, the environment and public health, and the so-called "regional development policies". In general, this report proposes to strengthen domestic demand through public and private investments that are higher than those of the Juncker Plan, especially with low rates. But these investments must remain sustainable given the very high levels of debt. It is also concerned about macroeconomic and social disparities that are narrowing only very slowly. However, this report is above all an ideological tool aimed at standardizing national economies around an increasingly federalized and liberalized system. I cannot support recommendations for economic reforms that have destroyed the economy of France and many other Member States, so I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the employment report on the European semester, which reminds us that the priority of national and European policies must be the creation of quality jobs and must generate growth. Here, too, the emphasis is on a balance between structural reforms, fiscal consolidation and sustainable investments, made in parallel with an analysis of social and economic impacts.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. Unemployment now affects 23 million European citizens, half of them are long-term unemployed. This is a serious phenomenon which, in addition to causing a loss of human capital, undermines the foundations of possible future sustainable economic growth.  I voted in favour of the Ribeiro report because I fully agree with the central objective of the report, investing in people. Placing new resources in the areas of health care, housing and children, without neglecting rehabilitation services, is a fundamental step towards promoting integration and social cohesion. All EU countries need to work to develop strategies to ensure that more and more people become and remain active within society. The inclusion of refugees, migrants and asylum seekers must, to this end, be a priority.  Europe must provide all the necessary funds to ensure an effective global approach to meet the great challenges of our time. Equal opportunities, quality jobs and the right mobility are the only way to achieve upward social convergence.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this report on the Commission's Annual Growth Prospective Study as part of the European Semester on Social and Employment Aspects mentions three positive social indicators from my point of view — activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment in the 2016 Alert Mechanism Report — continues to follow the 'economicist' logic of the European Semester and to influence neoliberal prescriptions for the dramatic employment problem and poverty. That's why I voted against it.  There are recurring concepts that put economic benefits before quantity, quality and dignity in employment such as: competitiveness, productivity, entrepreneurship, flexisecurity, legislation on the system of labour law, deregulation of the labour market, reduction of taxes and wage costs, skills to boost innovation and competitiveness, segmentation of the labour market and simplification of labour protection legislation (which would affect, inter alia, unfair redundancies) Etc. In commitments, both the most critical aspects of the Annual Growth Study process globally and the most progressive amendments in specific aspects have not been incorporated, emphasizing my refusal to support it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report, unlike my group, as it seems to me to be going in the right direction and reflecting well the social and employment aspects that need to be reflected in the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies. Wage dispersion increases inequalities and harms the productivity and competitiveness of enterprises and I believe it is necessary for the Commission and the Member States to implement measures to improve the quality of employment and increase minimum wages to an appropriate level in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. In addition, it is requested that current social protection systems be assessed and that efforts to tackle social and wage dumping in the Union be reassessed.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which only confirms the fact that national governments have placed national governments under the tutelage of national governments in their economic policy. This is also the stated project of this famous European semester since the Commission makes "recommendations" for the Member States every year, like a doctor to his patient. The same applies to employment and social aspects. Although it recognises the glaring social dysfunctions that persist, such as too high unemployment among young people or a European workforce lacking qualifications, Parliament, with this report, merely congratulates its master, the European Commission, for its recommendations. However, the latter are only once again meaningless declarations of intent; the fight against undclared work or the development of skills are good promises but, in fact, no concrete proposals are present in the text to achieve these objectives. Finally, the Commission's interference in the social and economic life of the Member States is clearly from an ultra-liberal perspective of austerity, which has been murdering the peoples of Europe since 2008.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we are voting on is unbalanced and presents many critical issues, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against all three reports. The keynote of all three reports is to support the economic policies that set the framework for the European Semester. I am opposed to europe's market-liberal approach, austerity policies, privatisations and deregulation.  Opposition to this policy is growing throughout the EU. I note that the reports, particularly Mr Rodrigues, contain attempts to criticise the policy pursued and some arguments in favour of incentives. However, it is not clear enough for me to be able to vote in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that economic recovery should be fair, create quality jobs, reduce inequalities and combat poverty and social exclusion. We need upward social European convergence, with socially responsible reforms based on solidarity, social integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth. Investment in social development should not simply be a means of improving economic growth, but an end in itself. We need greater investments in social protection systems to combat poverty and combat growing inequalities.  In addition, the euro area is treated as a single economy that needs deeper integration, with a strengthened social dimension, better social protection floors and minimum wages, and a strong pillar of social rights.  Finally, I supported this report because it shows us the reality of the data and forgets the Commission's complacency. Employment is being created, but this is precarious, with indecent wages, unfair working conditions and precarious positions. There is no greater betrayal of the social model than the fact that labour poverty is now one of Europe's main problems.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because there are still differences between and within Member States in the field of employment and social inclusion, and social change shows that disparities in the EU continue to widen, with negative impacts on growth, employment and cohesion; whereas societies with more equality and more investment in people are more resilient in terms of growth and employment. Parliament welcomes the Commission's call for investment in services such as housing assistance, healthcare, childcare and rehabilitation services. It should also be noted that quality and inclusive jobs are a necessary pillar of social justice that promotes the human dignity of all citizens. In this respect, quality employment and economic growth should be at the heart of Member States' and EU policies, especially measures for young people and people over 55, as a way of building a more sustainable social economy in the EU. Parliament urges the Member States to implement and further develop policies to promote youth employment, in combining these policies with specific labour market needs. Parliament also calls on the Commission to promote, at Member State level, various forms of cooperation, including governments, enterprises, including social economy enterprises, educational institutions, personalised support services, civil society and social partners based on the exchange of best practices.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is known that education efforts are generally focused primarily on the younger part of the workforce, while in many Member States a wider part of the workforce should be targeted with educational efforts, including adult education and vocational training opportunities. I would like to underline that insufficient investment in education, in particular digital skills, poses a threat to Europe's competitiveness and the employability of the European workforce. I would therefore like to encourage member states to prioritise a wide range of digital skills education. I call on the Commission to support a broader investment strategy at Member State level for the entire cycle of education and training, which includes all sectors of lifelong learning, work-based and on-the-job training, dual training, formal and informal learning. I would like to recall that skills and competences acquired in non-formal and informal learning environments play an important role in improving the employability of young people and those who have been left out of the labour market for a long time due to the performance of care responsibilities. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The unemployment rate is decreasing within the EU, but too slowly, and action needs to be taken. MePs, including me, have also pointed to this by supporting the report on the European Semester in the context of employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey.  Parliament therefore proposes to continue the isation of structural reforms in this area, but also in a social and responsible way, by promoting sustainable growth and by reviving investment. Increasing investment in human resources is becoming one of the most important challenges of modern times, with the EU able to help Member States considerably through means of promoting social and economic cohesion.  It is also an interesting call for Members to develop policies that will strengthen entrepreneurship among young people from an early age by providing opportunities for work placements and business visits.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The upward convergence to which Europe is aiming, and which seeks to promote the European Semester, must not only be economic convergence, but also social convergence.  Relaunching investment and employment, supporting the creation of quality jobs and ensuring social justice, together with appropriate welfare systems, must also be priorities of the European Semester, and I welcome the fact that this report has aimed to address these issues, focusing, among other things, on the need to integrate the social dimension of the eurozone more closely.  In order to ensure socially responsible recovery and sustainable economic growth, it is therefore important to continue to focus on structural reforms and investment geared to supporting employment, education and human capital, social development and reducing inequalities not only within individual countries, but throughout the Union.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called on the unelected EU Commission to initiate new legislation monitoring the spending of taxpayers’ money. The report calls for things like interfering with Member States’ social protection, tax policies and tax rules, welcomes the EU Commission’s initiative on the long-term unemployed, calls to enhance the Youth Guarantee Scheme, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together on removing the obstacles to fair labour mobility and calls for better coordination of the European Semester , specifically for the Eurozone.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Basically, in addition to the blatant futility of this report, I object to the very existence of this semester: it is only a tool for the Commission to assess and judge the work of the Member States. The country-specific recommendations are only one more way to find the Commission to interfere in the functioning of countries. I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report because I am opposed to the European Semester, the EU’s annual cycle of economic governance and surveillance. This report attempts to make some socially progressive statements regarding workers’ rights and combating poverty – however, these proposals are within the framework of the European Semester, which is fundamentally conservative and pro—business at the expense of citizens, communities, economic sovereignty and democracy in the EU. The report also welcomes the Commission recommendation on the euro area under the Economic and Monetary Union of the EU, which is another reason why I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The modest economic recovery that seems to be beginning to take place in the European Union is certainly to be welcomed, but the high level of unemployment that still characterises several regions of Europe can only give cause for concern. It also seems that the crisis has not affected all the social classes and all the regions of Europe equally: the weaker social classes and the more peripheral regions have paid the highest price of the recession, and even today they often do not see their exit.  It is therefore necessary for the EU as a whole to act with greater solidarity and foresight, overcoming the narrow logic of rigour as the only way to overcome the economic crisis and instead implementing a broad plan for sustainable and inclusive development that puts the recovery of the economy at the centre in the most disadvantaged areas of Europe.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the very principle of the definition of a European semester, which is only a tool of coercion in the service of the Commission and against the Member States. As a reminder, the European semester sets out specific country-specific recommendations and requires Member States to implement them. In addition to the usual platitudes about unemployment and the deepening of public debts of states, the report still advocates continuing to flee forward the austerity policies contained in the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Resolutely opposed to this economically absurd and suicidal strategy, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 2016 is the third year of economic recovery and with a further growth forecast of 2% in the European Union and 1.8% in the euro area, but the recovery is uneven between Member States. This is driven by positive factors, such as the ever-decreasing price of energy, which contributes to increased purchasing power if it has an impact on the real economy. Since 2013, there has been a slow decline in the unemployment rate, but not significant enough to limit unemployment and poverty, despite macroeconomic policies of structural and stimulative reform. Unemployment currently affects 9.9% of active citizens among Europeans, and half of them face long-term unemployment. The sector is the most affected sector of youth, which currently amounts to 22.6% of the population of the European Union. I voted in favour of this report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: employment and social issues in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey because I believe that a reduction in unemployment is needed throughout the European Union, and this can only be achieved through an improvement in economic policies.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The report emphasises the need to 'humanise' economic and monetary union, adding a 'social dimension'. We could reduce it to a famous Fantozzian exclamation: 'How human, the euro!' It is nothing more than a smokescreen, mainly for the use of the PSE. The "humanisation" measures already adopted by the Commission (see § 3) have obviously not in the least slowed down the process of dismantling social rights and wage depression, but allow the piddini to persevere in deception: they will cut survivor's pensions by vaping "responsible", "fairer" and "flexible" austerity. A 'other' euro is not possible. Point.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that economic recovery should be fair, create quality jobs, reduce inequalities and combat poverty and social exclusion. We need upward social European convergence, with socially responsible reforms based on solidarity, social integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth. Investment in social development should not simply be a means of improving economic growth, but an end in itself. We need greater investments in social protection systems to combat poverty and combat growing inequalities.  In addition, the euro area is treated as a single economy that needs deeper integration, with a strengthened social dimension, better social protection floors and minimum wages, and a strong pillar of social rights.  Finally, I supported this report because it shows us the reality of the data and forgets the Commission's complacency. Employment is being created, but this is precarious, with indecent wages, unfair working conditions and precarious positions. There is no greater betrayal of the social model than the fact that labour poverty is now one of Europe's main problems.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the European semester, the annual growth review is a first step in highlighting the additional steps Member States can take to achieve Europe 2020's economic and social objectives. This report is a response by the European Parliament to this review. In this report, Parliament focuses on the social indicators present in the European semester. This year three new indicators were taken into account: long-term unemployment, youth unemployment and the participation rate. Member States must implement the structural reforms necessary to create growth and jobs. I voted in favour of this report. This was an opportunity for me to reiterate my positions in favour of the fight against social dumping within the Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. The European Semester for economic policy coordination is a key element in coordinating the individual efforts of all Member States to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. However, I believe that, in addition to the short-term fiscal implications of structural reforms, the long-term environmental, economic and social effects must also be taken into account. We must not forget that the transition to a green economy and investment in more efficient health systems will increase the security of energy supply, improve the health and well-being of European citizens and create quality jobs, thereby helping to restore the competitive advantage of the European economy. In the priorities of the Annual Growth Survey and in the country-specific recommendations, the Commission should also take into account the move towards a new economic model based on a circular economy involving the development of a fiscal framework that values the development of sustainable policies that comply with the 'polluter pays' principle, which provides the right signals in favour of investment in resource efficiency.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called on the unelected EU Commission to initiate new legislation monitoring the spending of taxpayers’ money. The report calls for things like interfering with Member States’ social protection, tax policies and tax rules, welcomes the EU Commission’s initiative on the long-term unemployed, calls to enhance the Youth Guarantee Scheme, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together on removing the obstacles to fair labour mobility and calls for better coordination of the European Semester , specifically for the Eurozone.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the priorities of the Commission: investment, structural reforms and modernisation, and the fact that the Annual Growth Survey 2016 will pay much more attention to social aspects and investment in people. Although the unemployment rate is falling, thanks to reforms, many initiatives and investment, there is still a lot more that can be done with youth and long-term unemployment being particularly worrying. The objectives outlined in this year’s survey, such as upward social convergence, broader investment in education and training as well as more focus on the digital economy, are very promising.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses as every year on the employment and social aspects of the Annual Growth Survey as part of the so-called European Semester.  We have tried to remove all the economic references to which we are opposed (fiscal consolidation, improved economic governance, strengthening economic and monetary union) and we voted against to express our opposition.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I agree with the principles set out in the report, I could not support it as a whole, as its final version includes several paragraphs asking for an alignment of minimal wages, which I find highly problematic. In order to attack the issue of wage dispersion we need to address first the obstacles and rigidities of the EU’s labour market which exist in its Member States and to push administratively the level of income. Only a truly open and competitive labour market can enhance economic convergence within the European Union.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress the need to invest in social development, which is not only an instrument to ensure sustainable and inclusive economic growth and convergence, but must also be an individual objective in itself.  Economic and social cohesion must remain the primary objective of all EU policies and more efforts should be made to carry out a more complex and objective assessment based on the diversity of the Member States and their specific characteristics.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the European Semester on the coordination of economic policies on employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey.  This effort is part of the generalised trends in integration and the intensity of labour market deregulation policies that lead to a weakening of labour rights.  I have therefore decided not to support the report.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Ribeiro's report because I agree that, although the unemployment rate has been falling since 2013 thanks to favourable macroeconomic policies and the impact of structural reforms, it remains very high involving more than 23 million European citizens. In this context, the phenomenon of so-called 'undeclared work' is proliferating, which has a significant negative impact on budgets, with a huge loss of tax revenues and pension contributions.  For these reasons, the report aims to pay more attention to social equity, stressing the need for responsible structural reforms and continuing to give priority to investment with the need to promote and protect the social market economy. The great challenge for European society is that of social inclusion, and better coordination of the European Semester is needed to achieve the objectives.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because political documents like this make me particularly proud to serve the citizens in this institution: the Europe of bureaucrats that certain rulers want to paint, an EU that is attentive to the employment and social aspects of data, in other words to the people who make those economic data move on which so often, wrongly, too much is concentrated.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Throughout its first year of work, the European Commission presented ambitious initiatives to support jobs and growth, strengthen economic convergence and strengthen social justice. The economic priorities of the Annual Growth Survey remain valid, but political efforts should be strengthened for 2016. I support the excellent report by Mrs Ribeiro, which stresses the need to articulate the economic and social dimension and sets out concrete measures to boost sustainable social development, across all Union policies, and propose their monitoring. I underline the need to invest in people as soon as possible in order to reduce inequalities and promote social inclusion, and I applaud the Commission's proposal to strengthen the Youth Guarantee and the individualised approach to long-term unemployment. I believe that socially responsible reforms should be based on solidarity, integration and social justice, protecting the most vulnerable groups. This desiderato cannot be dissociated from promoting sustainable growth leading to the creation of more jobs, stimulating entrepreneurship. In this sense, better use of European funds in promoting social, economic and territorial cohesion is desired.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called on the unelected EU Commission to initiate new legislation monitoring the spending of taxpayers’ money. The report calls for things like interfering with Member States’ social protection, tax policies and tax rules, welcomes the EU Commission’s initiative on the long-term unemployed, calls to enhance the Youth Guarantee Scheme, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together on removing the obstacles to fair labour mobility and calls for better coordination of the European Semester , specifically for the Eurozone.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposed by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs deals with analysing the social aspects on which action can be taken to make economic recovery even more real. In particular, the modest results of the increase in employment are presented and the fact that some categories, such as women, still remain at a disadvantage in the world of work. The report stresses the need to promote sustainable and inclusive growth involving the creation of more quality jobs and real prospects for everyone, including young people. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report focuses as every year on the employment and social aspects of the AGS as part of the European Semester. The report highlights the things that have not worked so far (unemployment still too high, EU 2020 targets not met, Youth Guarantee not effective in many Member States, increase in atypical contracts and precarious employment, cuts in public spending) and, above all, underlines the importance of the social dimension in the European Union.  Although the need to assess the social impact of structural reforms before they are implemented and the need to implement global and homogeneous industrial policies at EU level to meet the challenges posed by non-European competitors, as well as the need to facilitate SMEs and micro-enterprises by reducing bureaucracy and facilitating access to funds, the report provides for the usual economic references to which we are opposed (fiscal consolidation) , improvement of economic governance, strengthening of economic and monetary union). That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The timid social reforms proposed in this report are, in practice, incompatible with an economic framework whose guiding principles will remain neoliberal economic policies, which they serve as a mechanism for legitimization. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission's analyses under the European Semester highlight the persistence of employment and social divergences both within and between Member States. These divergences create disparities in the European Union, hamper growth, employment and cohesion.  The European Parliament resolution, on which I voted in favour, supports strengthening the social dimension through the revival of investment in human capital, the implementation of structural reforms and better use of European funds both to carry out infrastructure projects and to stimulate entrepreneurship among young people.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Ribeiro report underlines that 90% of global economic growth will occur outside the EU in the next 10-15 years. New solutions and approaches will therefore be needed. Today, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU, with nearly 40% of businesses unable to find properly qualified workers, while few countries can say that they have made meaningful and effective efforts to change all this. The report welcomes the fact that the European Commission's Annual Growth Survey highlights the need to pay greater attention to social equity in the framework of the new national, stability and reform programmes, and therefore to add three employment indicators (activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment) to the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. The report also welcomes the renewal of the Europe 2020 Integrated Guidelines; stresses that the Europe 2020 strategy is more up-to-date than when it was set up, and calls on the Member States to pay more attention to its practical implementation, and calls on the Commission and the Council to monitor more closely the implementation of this strategy at comprehensive and Member State level. I think it is important to include the part of the report that calls on the European Commission, in close cooperation with the Member States, to seek to provide more detailed information on EU funds and programmes that can increase entrepreneurship, boost investment and improve access to funding instruments.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The annual growth survey 2016 is the first important step in the annual cycle. I positively believe that the introduction of specific recommendations for the euro area is significant and important progress. I strongly believe in the need for further inclusion in the employment sector as well as a solid framework inducing more social protection systems. The introduction of the minimum income is a crucial and fundamental step forward in the labour market. We need to further address youth unemployment, as well as re-enforcing measures on labour safeguards to promote social inclusion. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I firmly believe that in order to strengthen the role of the Europe 2020 strategy on smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, measures must be taken to ensure that its objectives, particularly social ones, are equally reflected in all the instruments of the semester, including the country-specific recommendations.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's position on social and employment issues, following the European Commission's first review of 2016 growth. During the year, the Commission presented ambitious proposals to support jobs and growth, strengthen economic convergence and social equality. Supporting these same priorities for 2016, the European Commission proposes to intensify its efforts on boosting investment, deepening structural reforms to modernise the economy and adopting responsible fiscal policies. Considering the urgent need to address macroeconomic imbalances, particularly in employment, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report discusses a number of key issues for defining a Europe in a contemporary and progressive way.  Public finance policies cannot be an exercise in abstract finance but must take into account the dramatic contingency surrounding the lives of many European citizens. The refugee crisis clearly shows the crisis of a European solidarity system, and that is why states must be able to guarantee appropriate measures to deal with these emergencies. Emergencies that do not end with the process of identifying migrants, indeed begin at that very moment.  Therefore, the Commission should recognise a broader definition of migration policies which, starting with reception centres, will continue to support families in difficulty in the suburbs of our cities and our society. These policies must necessarily be coordinated with those of incentives for entrepreneurship and the competitiveness and internationalisation of European small and medium-sized enterprises, which can reopen the links of social integration.  I therefore support this dual demand for greater attention to social policies in public finance and at the same time for greater coordination between national and European institutions in order to build a virtuous path of growth.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following the people's party's position, I voted in favour of the Ribeiro report. The report highlights that in the next 10-15 years, 90% of global economic growth will occur outside the EU. New solutions and approaches will therefore be needed, in my view. In order to combat black employment and increase economic growth, a number of amendments have been adopted in the Commission's work, which are also based on the good practices followed so far in Hungary.  As is well known, there are 23 million unemployed people in the EU today, with nearly 40% of businesses unable to find properly qualified workers, while public and private indrecurities are still high in EU countries – and few countries can say that they have made meaningful and effective efforts to change them. Hungary has done much in recent years to whiten the economy. Breaking previous trends, significant progress has also been made in the fight against government debt and retail foreign exchange debt. Effective measures have also been taken to improve work-based and workplace (dual) training, to raise employment levels, to expand childhood education and care and meal programmes, and to improve the employment of different target groups (young people, older people, women), in particular with regard to the application of tax incentives in labour market measures, in line with the report's recommendations.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination is an important tool for prioritising the EU in promoting job creation and growth by promoting convergence and following examples of good practice in EU Member States. Employment and social performance are now one of the key challenges in Europe and are also being targeted by the European Semester. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur, Sofia Ribeir, for the excellent work she has done on this subject and this report. The report covers all the key issues and the recommendations are close to me – in particular, promoting entrepreneurship among young people or initiatives to promote new innovative projects and start-ups. However, I have decided to vote against this report. This is due to the call for intervention in national wage systems, which appears on several points in this report and which I cannot agree with.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text for several reasons. On the one hand, it merely recalls evidence relating to unemployment rates and labour qualifications or concealed work and public debt. On the other hand, the solutions that are supposed to address these problems are paltry and are part of a series of recommendations that have demonstrated their limitations. For example, flexi-security only exacerbates precariousness and training policies do not prevent states from moving away from full employment in a sustainable way. Finally, I do not wish to endorse the European semester, an instrument of the European Union which reduces the room for manoeuvre of States, in order to continue to endorse a failing system and a Strategy 2020 which we dispute.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support further initiatives to improve economic growth and employment, but nevertheless, I have decided not to support this report primarily because of its overly obligatory nature. This report contains some important priority issues, but despite the fact that it is mainly a comprehensive balanced one, calling for a number of initiatives at EU level that would not only undermine subsidiarity but also undermine national regulatory policy.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In its first year in office, the Commission presented ambitious initiatives to support employment and growth, strengthen economic convergence and strengthen social justice. Unfortunately, however, there has been no progress.  Today, with the 2016 Annual Growth Survey, it sets priorities for the coming year. Sofia Ribeiro's resolution (EPP, Portugal) adopted by the Employment Committee on 17 February defends the inclusion of recent employment indicators in the Annual Growth Survey in order to monitor social developments in the Member States.  However, the report does not agree with us on many points. There is, for example, a reference to the refugee and migration issue that it can have a positive impact on labour supply and development, "with conditions".

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2015 Annual Growth Report sets out a number of economic priorities that remain valid in 2016. However, the EU's objective for this new year focuses on three new priorities: relaunch of investment, structural policies to modernise our economies and responsible fiscal policies. We need to invest in social progress, stressing the importance of indicators of employment, poverty and quality inequality and will work by paying more attention to social justice in the context of new national stability and reform programmes, adding three employment indicators (activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment). We are aware that inclusive and quality employment is a fundamental pillar of social justice in promoting human dignity for all. That is why Member States and the EU must carry out policies aimed, in particular, at creating measures aimed at young people and the generation of more than 55 years, in order to build more socially sustainable economies in the EU.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The six-monthly report on the coordination of economic policies highlights the social dimension of Union action, with particular reference to still too high unemployment, cuts in public spending and measures such as the Youth Guarantee, which have proved ineffective in many Member States, such as Italy. However, references to the strengthening of economic and monetary union and fiscal consolidation remain in the final text. That is why I have chosen to vote against.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The report calls for further efforts to ensure a balance between the social and market economy so that the convergence of European policies is accompanied by an effective increase in employment, prosperity and improved living conditions for citizens. I also congratulate the rapporteur Sofia Ribeiro on the excellent work done. I highlight the defence in the report that social indicators should be taken into account in the evaluation of the European semester. This is an important innovation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report points to the consolidation of policies shaped by the so-called Economic Governance, of which the European Semester is an instrument, complying with the Annual Growth Survey, its neoliberal prescription and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, specifically with regard to employment and social affairs issues. The rapporteur, the Portuguese member of the right, values the country-specific recommendations and the need for their implementation, when we know them unacceptable and undemocratic – in Portugal, they consisted of the attack on social and labour rights, measures of "fiscal consolidation", privatizations, deepening inequalities, theft of wages and crushing of consumption. The European Semester is another mechanism for attacking the sovereignty of peoples, on the organs of sovereignty of states, deepening the concentration of power at EU level to better implement policies contrary to the will, needs and aspirations of peoples – a process that we reject in the first place. In the shudder of this report, we confirm the need to break with the neoliberal policies imposed by the EU as an indispensable step towards achieving economic growth, development, job creation and broad social and labour rights, as well as decent wages. We voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as the semester process is an intrusion into our sovereignty.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because it emphasises the need to humanise economic and monetary union.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In its first year in office, the Commission presented ambitious initiatives to support employment and growth, strengthen economic convergence and strengthen social justice. First of all, reference is made to the refugee and migration issues that can have a positive impact on labour supply and development, "with conditions". It also argues that Member States should make full use of the possibility of using the EFSI in conjunction with other EU funds under Horizon 2020, the Connecting Europe Facility and the European Structural and Investment Funds. Finally, it supports intra-Union labour mobility across the Union (EURES). For these reasons, I am voting against this report in its entirety.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Quality jobs, equal opportunities and fair mobility are the basis for European upward social convergence. I believe that socially responsible reforms must be based on solidarity, integration, social justice and fair wealth distribution. Therefore, I support the need for European upward social convergence, the need for quality and inclusive employment and promotion of stability in employment and security in transitions between jobs. More investment in social protection systems is also requested to prevent poverty and inequalities, together with a strong first pension pillar, introduction of minimum incomes, investment in education to fight youth unemployment and support for unemployed people, especially the long-term unemployed.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the priorities highlighted in the report, according to which investments in this field should not only be invested in social development in order to ensure sustainable and integration-enhancing economic development and convergence, but should also be treated as an explicit objective; underlines, therefore, the importance of indicators relating to quality of employment, poverty and inequality; welcomes the Commission's call for investment in services such as housing benefit, healthcare, childcare and rehabilitation services; stresses that economic and social cohesion should continue to be the primary objective of EU policies and that more efforts should be made to achieve a more complex and objective assessment based on the differences and characteristics of the Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report in order for there to be definitive coordination of economic policies with regard to the social aspects of employment. Greater coordination between the public and private sectors is important, encouraging curriculums to correlate with the labour market. The collaboration of all those involved is therefore very important.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that economic recovery should be fair, create quality jobs, reduce inequalities and combat poverty and social exclusion. We need upward social European convergence, with socially responsible reforms based on solidarity, social integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth. Investment in social development should not simply be a means of improving economic growth, but an end in itself. We need greater investments in social protection systems to combat poverty and combat growing inequalities.  In addition, the euro area is treated as a single economy that needs deeper integration, with a strengthened social dimension, better social protection floors and minimum wages, and a strong pillar of social rights.  Finally, I supported this report because it shows us the reality of the data and forgets the Commission's complacency. Employment is being created, but this is precarious, with indecent wages, unfair working conditions and precarious positions. There is no greater betrayal of the social model than the fact that labour poverty is now one of Europe's main problems.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's report on the social and employment aspects of the European Semester because I strongly supported the position taken within my own EMPL Committee to put a decisive end to economic policies based on austerity and conservative reforms. The EP's message to the European Commission focuses on a new paradigm: the EU must adopt economic policies to support demand through substantial investment in innovation, training and efficient natural resources, which can restart growth, and ensure better and efficient use of existing European funds (Social Fund and Cohesion Fund). I strongly supported the need for inclusive social policies because access to education and training for workers is an opportunity for society. I also supported the call for Member States to implement and monitor more effective and inclusive forms of social protection and income support systems, in order to ensure an adequate standard of living for the unemployed and people at risk of poverty and social exclusion, and to exchange best practices on the effectiveness of a minimum income in terms of reducing inequalities.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. The report looks at the current social situation in Europe very comprehensively, but draws some false and unprofitable conclusions.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I consider the social development of people, socially responsible structural reforms and the promotion of social, economic and territorial cohesion to be useful from an employment point of view.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as quality jobs, equal opportunities and fair mobility are the basis for European upward social convergence. Socially responsible reforms must be based on solidarity, integration, social justice and fair wealth distribution.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called on the unelected EU Commission to initiate new legislation monitoring the spending of taxpayers’ money. The report calls for things like interfering with Member States’ social protection, tax policies and tax rules, welcomes the EU Commission’s initiative on the long-term unemployed, calls to enhance the Youth Guarantee Scheme, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together on removing the obstacles to fair labour mobility and calls for better coordination of the European Semester , specifically for the Eurozone.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this report on the Commission's Annual Growth Prospective Study as part of the European Semester on Social and Employment Aspects mentions three positive social indicators from my point of view — activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment in the 2016 Alert Mechanism Report — continues to follow the 'economicist' logic of the European Semester and to influence neoliberal prescriptions for the dramatic employment problem and poverty. That's why I voted against it.  There are recurring concepts that put economic benefits before quantity, quality and dignity in employment such as: competitiveness, productivity, entrepreneurship, flexisecurity, legislation on the system of labour law, deregulation of the labour market, reduction of taxes and wage costs, skills to boost innovation and competitiveness, segmentation of the labour market and simplification of labour protection legislation (which would affect, inter alia, unfair redundancies) Etc. In commitments, both the most critical aspects of the Annual Growth Study process globally and the most progressive amendments in specific aspects have not been incorporated, emphasizing my refusal to support it.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report supports from the beginning to the end the austerity policies promoted by the Commission and the sovereign circles of Brussels. He says unemployment is falling, the post-crisis situation has stabilised and that what is needed now is to continue the policies that already exist.  We voted against, as is the standing line of the Group when it comes to reports on the budget and the European Semester.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on employment and social aspects of the AGS 2016. While the unemployment rate has been decreasing since the end of 2013 it is still too high in many Member States, affecting 23 million Europeans, about half of whom are long-term unemployed and with youth unemployment even higher still at 22.6%. According to the Commission, employment and social divergences within and between Member States persist and social developments point to further divergence across the EU, hindering growth, employment and cohesion. In this context it is crucial that further structural reforms are socially just and it is positive that the Commission has emphasised social fairness in the new national stability and reform programmes, adding three employment indicators. In particular I supported the call on the Commission and Member States to implement measures to improve job quality along with measures raising minimum wages to an adequate level in line with the principle of subsidiarity to reduce wage dispersion and on Member States to assess and increase investment in their current social protection systems, in order to tackle and prevent poverty and inequality while also ensuring their sustainability in the face of expected demographic , economic and new social challenges.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report due to the fact that despite the economic priorities of the 2015 Annual Growth Survey remaining valid, policy efforts need to be strengthened and the Commission needs to focus efforts on three priorities for 2016, namely re-launching investment, pursuing structural reforms to modernise economies, and responsible fiscal policies. In 2016 three employment indicators have been added to the main scoreboard: the activity rate, long-term unemployment and youth unemployment.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the Annual Growth Survey published by the Commission in the autumn of last year. It lists growth priorities for the coming years. The text adopted by Parliament calls for wider state efforts to create growth. In my view, however, the mix of instruments proposed to achieve this objective is only partially suitable for this purpose.  Public demand is sold in a classic Keynesian manner as an all-purpose weapon, and it is given an abstract, totally inflated and unrealistic status. The report also calls for further exemptions from the Stability and Growth Pact and seeks to further weaken it for political expedient objectives. ALFA believes that rules must also be followed by politics in particular and must not be interpreted and watered down arbitrarily. We are strongly opposed to further exemptions from the SGP. That is why I voted against the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report specifically calls for more access to affordable childcare. Just yesterday the Scottish Parliament approved the coming year’s Scottish budget which includes a commitment to 1 140 hours free childcare for three and four year olds. The Scottish Government is working to keep Scotland in the European mainstream and I welcome today’s report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The annual growth survey launches the European Semester by setting out the EU’s economic priorities for the year to come. This is actually the first step in the annual cycle. In this report, specific recommendations for the euro area are included for the first time. I believe that reforms must be based on solidarity, social justice and fair wealth distribution. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination: Aspects of Employment and Social Policy in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey, because I believe that greater investment in social development is needed in the form of strengthening convergence.  More investment in education and education, in particular in digital skills, is needed, while increasing long-term unemployment across Europe needs to be addressed through concrete and targeted measures. I followed the position of the ALDE Group which was to vote against this motion of resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report's recommendations are disconcerting: it calls for the development of skills and skills with training, it supports a fight against unreported work and promotes flexicurity (which generally translates into precariousness), it intends to modernise social systems in order to cope with ageing and does not fail to question the low fertility rates in Europe. In addition to these considerations, we strongly oppose the very existence of this European Semester because it is only a tool for the European Commission to assess and judge the work of member states. As for the country-specific recommendations, they are only one more way for the European Commission to interfere in the functioning of countries.  I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called on the unelected EU Commission to initiate new legislation monitoring the spending of taxpayers’ money. The report calls for things like interfering with Member States’ social protection, tax policies and tax rules, welcomes the EU Commission’s initiative on the long-term unemployed, calls to enhance the Youth Guarantee Scheme, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together on removing the obstacles to fair labour mobility and calls for better coordination of the European Semester , specifically for the Eurozone.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sofia Ribeiro's report on employment and social aspects as part of the 2016 Annual Growth Review. Since this year, the Commission has incorporated three new indicators to more accurately measure macroeconomic imbalances in order to better combat unemployment. The Commission has thus formulated substantial ambitions for jobs and growth which need to be further consolidated and reinforced by political actions. I have supported this report, which is abounding in that regard.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the annual growth review, the Commission has proposed a number of priorities on employment and social issues as part of the annual growth review for 2016. As the level of unemployment is still very high in the European Union and particularly among young people, it is important that Member States invest in training and education and fulfil the commitments they have made in the framework of Europe 2020. The fact that the Commission has a strong social equity and employment objective is a good thing. I have therefore voted in favour of this report, which is in line with the Commission's proposals.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining on this proposal. Although it provides for a differentiation between the areas of responsibility which fall within European and national levels of responsibility, it calls for greater influence on the part of the officials of the European Semester, which is in direct contradiction to important measures such as the call for more democratic participation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Quality jobs, equal opportunities and fair mobility are the basis for European upward social convergence. Socially responsible reforms must be based on solidarity, integration, social justice and fair wealth distribution.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Ribeiro report covers social and labour market policy aspects in the context of the Annual Growth Survey of the European Semester. The fundamental problem is that the EU is still unwilling to recognise the adjustment difficulties caused by the euro; it therefore continues to focus on combating symptoms. But also in the fight against symptoms, one could make helpful policy. In some parts, the ECR has succeeded in counteracting the need to centralise policy and responsibilities, but this is not enough. As an example, the report proposes that 20% of the European Social Fund's resources for social concerns and the fight against poverty should be fixed, thereby giving Member States room for manoeuvre; a concept of 'social fairness' will also be developed at EU level; finally, the Commission is invited to launch an initiative on minimum wages.  In the interests of subsidiarity and self-responsibility, I have decided to reject the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Semester is generally set poorly and even this resolution could not change the fact that it focuses primarily on competitiveness, a single fiscal policy, the euro area and largely ignores social issues. European Parliament resolution of 25 February 2016 on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: the employment and social aspect in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey is primarily about social issues, but it is simply not in its power to transform the European Semester to become social.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is economy policy coordination. This means deepening of EMU governance for more stability and convergence, and improving Parliament’s role in decision-making on the European Semester’s priorities and recommendations. However, I voted against the report since the proposed policy mix does not take into consideration the issue of rising poverty, inequalities and social exclusion in the EU.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. As can be seen from statistical data, the unemployment rate has been falling slightly since the second half of 2013, but not sufficiently to reduce unemployment and poverty. The figures tell us of an uneven economic recovery, accompanied by differences in employment and social stability within the Member States.  Reducing unemployment is our first objective today and, together with economic growth, the policies implemented at European and national level are targeted. The report also addresses the problem of undeclared work, which deprives workers of their social and employment rights. This is unacceptable to me.  I believe that the policies implemented to date will bear fruit, and among them the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) must allow for major investments with the participation of some 71 000 SMEs. Investing in people, implementing structural reforms and reviving sustainable growth are excellent starting points, with which I fully agree, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this report. Of course we need to do more, but we want to move in that direction.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the European semester for the coordination of economic policies on employment and social aspects as part of the 2016 Annual Growth Review. The report's recommendations are of a platitude to cry: it calls for the development of skills and skills with training, that we fight against undclared work, that flexicurity is promoted (which generally translates into precariousness), that social systems be modernised to cope with ageing, that we question the low fertility rates in Europe... Fundamentally, in addition to the blatant futility of this report, I object to the very existence of this semester: it is only a tool for the Commission to assess and judge the work of the Member States. As for the country-specific recommendations, they are only an additional way for the Commission to interfere in the functioning of countries.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it merely lists the obvious (it is necessary to fight against undclared work, etc.), on the other hand to sing the praises of the European Semester, which is nothing more than an instrument designed to facilitate the Commission's interference in national policies.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that economic recovery should be fair, create quality jobs, reduce inequalities and combat poverty and social exclusion. We need upward social European convergence, with socially responsible reforms based on solidarity, social integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth. Investment in social development should not simply be a means of improving economic growth, but an end in itself. We need greater investments in social protection systems to combat poverty and combat growing inequalities.  In addition, the euro area is treated as a single economy that needs deeper integration, with a strengthened social dimension, better social protection floors and minimum wages, and a strong pillar of social rights.  Finally, I supported this report because it shows us the reality of the data and forgets the Commission's complacency. Employment is being created, but this is precarious, with indecent wages, unfair working conditions and precarious positions. There is no greater betrayal of the social model than the fact that labour poverty is now one of Europe's main problems.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that economic recovery should be fair, create quality jobs, reduce inequalities and combat poverty and social exclusion. We need upward social European convergence, with socially responsible reforms based on solidarity, social integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth. Investment in social development should not simply be a means of improving economic growth, but an end in itself. We need greater investments in social protection systems to combat poverty and combat growing inequalities.  In addition, the euro area is treated as a single economy that needs deeper integration, with a strengthened social dimension, better social protection floors and minimum wages, and a strong pillar of social rights.  Finally, I supported this report because it shows us the reality of the data and forgets the Commission's complacency. Employment is being created, but this is precarious, with indecent wages, unfair working conditions and precarious positions. There is no greater betrayal of the social model than the fact that labour poverty is now one of Europe's main problems.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The timid social reforms proposed in this report are, in practice, incompatible with an economic framework whose guiding principles will remain neoliberal economic policies, which they serve as a mechanism for legitimization. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Ribeiro report covers social and labour market policy aspects in the context of the Annual Growth Survey of the European Semester. The fundamental problem is that the EU is still unwilling to recognise the adjustment difficulties caused by the euro and continues to focus on combating symptoms. But also in the fight against symptoms, one could make helpful policy. In some parts, the ECR has succeeded in counteracting the request for the centralisation of policy and responsibilities, but it has not succeeded sufficiently. As an example, the report proposes that 20% of the European Social Fund's resources for social concerns and the fight against poverty should be set up, thus giving Member States room for manoeuvre, developing a concept of 'social fairness' at EU level, or calling on the Commission to launch an initiative on minimum wages.  In the interests of subsidiarity and self-responsibility, I have decided to reject the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, in particular paragraph 19: "The European Parliament considers that wage dispersion increases inequality and harms the productivity and competitiveness of businesses; calls on the Commission and the Member States to implement measures to improve the quality of jobs in order to limit labour market segmentation in combination with measures to raise minimum wages to an appropriate level in line with the principle of subsidiarity and to strengthen collective bargaining and the position of workers in wage-setting systems, in order to reduce wage dispersion; believes that all this should be done in order to support overall demand and economic recovery, reduce wage inequalities and combat in-work poverty." None of this is a matter for the European Parliament or the European Commission. Government intervention can only make the situation on the free market worse.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to the Commission's latest economic forecasts, the level of unemployment in 2015 was 9.5 percent, the lowest rate in the European Union since the beginning of the crisis. However, the long-term unemployment rate and youth unemployment remain high and we need more decisive and effective action at Member State level to address these problems. Effective structural reforms in the fields of labour market, education and financially foster lifelong learning, new skills and innovation need to be implemented. In addition, we need to make better use of the instruments at our disposal, such as the Youth Guarantee. I believe these are key steps to reduce long-term unemployment rates, especially young people, so I supported the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the European Semester to harmonise economic policy and aspects of employment and social policy in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The annual growth review kicks off the European semester by setting out the EU's overall economic priorities for the coming year. It is the first step in the annual cycle. The joint report on employment attached to it assesses the social and employment situation in the Union.  This initiative report contains many important progressive proposals such as the fight against essential social dumping in Europe, including the introduction of a minimum wage in all EU Member States. The text also calls on Member States to invest more in social protection systems to prevent poverty and inequality. It also focuses on investing in education and strengthening the youth guarantee to combat youth unemployment. This initiative report clearly promotes employment reforms based on solidarity, integration, social justice and an equitable distribution of wealth; I therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Semester on the coordination of economic policies: employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/2/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies - Employment. Member States urgently need to develop youth employment policies, adapting them to real labour market requirements.  The Commission must come up with a concrete plan for the coordination of businesses, educational institutions, civil society and social partners, with a view to adapting Member States' education and training systems and linking skills at EU level. There are almost 2 million unfilled posts in the EU, half of which are in the digital sector and 40% of companies are having difficulty finding staff with the necessary skills. On the other hand, the EU unemployment rate is 23% among young people. Europe must find solutions to use these young people in the labour market. The Commission should encourage education and training programmes in order to avoid the serious situation in which these young people are excluded from the labour market in the long term. The Youth Guarantee is a good proposal, especially because it facilitates the transition between school and work. Uniform application and efficiency in all Member States are imperative.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This report is of a platitude to cry: it calls for the development of skills and skills through training, that we fight against undclared work, that flexisecurity is promoted (which generally translates into precariousness), that social systems are modernised to cope with ageing, that we question the low fertility rates in Europe... Apart from the blatant futility of this report, we oppose the very existence of this semester: it is only a tool for the Commission to assess and judge the work of the Member States. As for the country-specific recommendations, they are only an additional means of interfering in the functioning of countries. Finally, this Semester exists only to enable the objectives of Strategy 2020, an EU strategy which we strongly oppose, to be achieved.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2016. The strategic priorities to which reference is made are varied and important: a still weak and uneven economic recovery, growth rates that remain low, unemployment, crisis as well as cyclical but also structural, tax avoidance and evasion. The package that is being proposed is a good one and underlines the importance of synergistic efforts.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on the European Semester for economic policy co-ed and the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. In the long term, we are against how the European Semester project is currently set up. It focuses only on competitiveness and single fiscal policies, neglecting priorities such as poverty reduction, combating unemployment and social exclusion. While there are a number of positive elements for me in the document presented, such as the need for structural reforms, respect for budgetary discipline and increased investment in the EU, I remain convinced that a single fiscal policy, as required by the draft document, does not represent a long-term positive solution in view of the specificities of individual Member States in the economic field. That is why I voted against the report in the final vote.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to respond to the Commission's proposal on the 2016 Annual Growth Survey on social and employment aspects.  Neither the Commission's proposal nor the rapporteur's proposal really seeks the creation of quality jobs and their sustainable growth. Basing job creation on reducing labour costs, including through taxes, labour market segmentation and simplification of labour law – i.e. simplification of redundancies – will only increase job instability and precariousness and increase poverty levels. We need a policy of strategic investment in education and research, measures that support young employment and combat their exclusion, secure social protection systems and investment strategies that foster quality job creation. Only then can we enter a sustainable growth path.  I voted against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. In the European Union, we must continue to invest in social progress to ensure that sustainable and inclusive economic development is achieved. In this regard, we have influenced the report which we have approved, with my support, in the European Parliament on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: social and employment aspects of the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. I hope that the recommendations and requests we are aiming for here will be taken into account when promoting measures that will help to grow more equally in Europe, without leaving anyone on the road.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report discusses the most pressing employment and social challenges currently facing Member States. Attention is drawn to the measures to be improved or strengthened to address the problems of poverty and social exclusion, an ageing population, a high unemployment rate among young people, underperforming health and long-term care systems.  I agree with the report's stated that Member States should develop their social protection policies more consistently and responsibly in order to be able to meet the expected demographic, economic challenges and improve the resilience of their economies in times of crisis.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This Parliament's initiative report amends the Commission's communication on the "Annual Growth Review 2016: Consolidating Recovery and Convergence". As always, the Commission's text stresses competitiveness, entrepreneurship and the reduction of the tax burden. It also aims to defend policies undertaken, arguing, for example, that "unemployment has been falling since 2013 thanks to favourable macroeconomic policies and the impact of structural reforms." Or by "rejoicing in the results achieved by the EFSI in its first year of implementation." While Parliament proposes to take into account new social indicators such as the labour participation rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment, the text remains a liberal and dogmatic litany. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. While the state of play undertaken is quite obvious in this report, the recommendations are just as simple as being. This is a long complaint about our current economic anxieties, which unfortunately cannot be eliminated by the intercession of European ideology. This report leaves no doubt as to its futility. I am opposed to the principle of this European semester, which has reason only to achieve the objectives of the 'Europe 2020' programme.  I have, therefore, voted against this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the Report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination from a perspective of analysis focused on social and employment aspects. Better and more options that invest and promote employment growth in a sustained and responsible way are key.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution which is in sync with the Commission’s priorities for 2016: investment in citizens and using structural reforms to modernise our economies in a fiscally sound manner.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2016, because I believe that the EU can no longer rely on exports with the slowdown of the world economy and it needs to rely much more on internal demand and more private and public investment. However, there are some sensitive points and I believe should remain an issue of the national competences.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The priorities set out by the Commission in the Annual Growth Survey 2016 address openly the shortcomings of the European economy and bring out a fresh policy mix fostering investment in the single market and reducing inequalities.
