Given the tensions between Member States nurtured by people’s mobility within EU and the huge immigration waves coming from war zones, I fully support the focus laid out this year on employment and social performance.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the Commission communication referred to in the previous paragraph also states that the economy is growing, but rather unevenly, and that unemployment is falling, albeit not rapidly enough, to curb unemployment and poverty. It urges that member states' education and training systems be better aligned with the fight against structural labour shortages, particularly as regards the widespread education of digital skills. It points out that the Youth Guarantee is not implemented in many Member States and considers it necessary to strengthen it at Member State, regional and local level. It is concerned about the situation of more than 12 million long-term unemployed people in Europe and considers a personalised approach to solving their problems to be essential. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report follows the Commission's annual Growth Study. It focuses on the "employment and social" part of the European Semester and takes stock.  Clearly, this report welcomes the European Commission's assessments and its recommendations. Secondly, the report lists a set of obvious findings: a mini drop in unemployment is observed in Europe but the unemployment rates of young people and the elderly remain too high, the European workforce is sorely lacking in skills, there is too much un-reported work, the public debts of the Member States continue to increase... And the recommendations that follow these findings are: the development of skills and skills with training, the fight against undclared work, the promotion of flexicurity (which generally translates into precariousness), the modernisation of social systems to cope with ageing, and a study on low fertility rates in Europe... We therefore oppose this report, which is very useless and is merely a tool for the Commission to interfere in the functioning of the Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the very existence of this semester: it is only a tool for the Commission to assess and judge the work of the Member States. As for the country-specific recommendations, they are only one more way for the Commission to interfere in the functioning of countries. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, we would like to highlight the fact that the Commission, in its annual growth survey, has placed the issue of social equity at the heart of Europe's economic recovery. Quality and inclusive employment are an essential pillar of this, capable of promoting human dignity for all.  We are deeply concerned about the social impact of budgetary adjustment policies that focus on spending cuts. Socially responsible reforms must instead be based on solidarity, integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth – a model that guarantees equality and social protection, protects vulnerable groups and raises the standard of living of all citizens.  We therefore encourage The Member States to step up their efforts to close the gender pay gap, to take more active measures to strengthen women's participation in the labour market. We call on the Member States and the Commission, in line with the principle of subsidiarity and with the help of the social partners, to promote family policies, appropriate provisions on maternity and paternity leave, and new provisions to facilitate access to childcare. Only in this way will we be able to achieve a better work-life balance.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Riberio report dealing with the social and employment aspects of the 2016 European Semester. The key aspects of the report are social and responsible structural reforms, the strengthening of sustainable growth through investment, better use of European funds to promote social and geographical cohesion, social inclusion as a challenge for society.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Annual Growth Survey sets out goals at EU level to help Member States support growth, reinforce economic convergence, create jobs and strengthen social fairness. I voted for this report by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs that shows Parliament’s input to the definition of policy priorities for the 2016 European Semester. This report should stimulate debates at European level on the priorities for the next 12 months of European economic policy.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the final vote, inter alia because a passage remained in the text calling on the Commission and the Member States to implement measures to raise minimum wages. I am afraid that this is directed against competition in the internal market and could result in the unification of Member States' legislation in the wage area, which I do not consider economically desirable. Given that Member States have different economic levels, we should also respect different wage levels. I am also annoyed by the call on the Commission and the Member States to step up efforts to tackle social and wage dumping in the EU. In this call, I again see a hidden effort to restrict competition in the internal market and eliminate the competitive advantages of the new Member States through artificial legislative interventions.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have abstained from voting on this proposal. Although it distinguishes tasks which are shared between European and national levels of responsibility, there is also a call for greater influence on the part of the officials of the European Semester.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report concerns the Commission's communication of 26 November 2015 entitled "Annual Growth Review 2016: Consolidating Recovery and Convergence", which includes competitiveness, productivity, entrepreneurship, flexicurity, wage tax cuts, and legislation on the labour law system. The report aims to address the unemployment rate in the EU and the gender pay gap, which is still far too large. However, despite the many statements contained in this text, no concrete solution has been made, so I voted against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. While the employment and social situation in Europe has slowly improved, more measures are needed to reduce labour market rigidity and to renew social protection and pension systems.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies: Employment and Social Aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey, as I consider the issue of social development to be a priority, an issue that brings European citizens back to the centre of our political agenda. In fact, our economic policies cannot ignore common considerations on employment, social equity, the problem of poverty and other fundamental social aspects.  Given the current economic conditions, the European Union needs social and responsible structural reforms because, at the moment, the social impact of budgetary adjustment policies, mainly made up of spending cuts, is on the edge of sustainable. The new reforms must therefore start from the social level in order to create a model that guarantees, through increased investment and better use of funds, sustainable growth, equality, protection for vulnerable groups and, in general, well-being for citizens. Finally, giving concrete answers on these issues is also crucial in order to guarantee greater political legitimacy for the European institutions and, specifically, for the European Parliament.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's reports on the 'European Semester', the mechanism for imposing 'permanent memoranda' on all EU Member States, demonstrate the commitment of the political staff of monopolies to its objectives: measures to continuously reduce the price of labour everywhere in order to recover the profitability of business groups, to come capitalist growth that so far seems anemic, uncertain and fragile.  That is why they require urban governments to implement the 'country-by-country recommendations', i.e. the unpopular measures drawn up by the EU institutions. In order to counter popular indignation, they attempt to dress up the whole process of six months and "enhanced economic governance" supposedly with "social aspects" and "social sensitivity", but they do not even manage to express wishful words, betraying their hostility to labour-popular rights.  The six-month period and all the procedures of the EU's 'permanent memorandums' cannot have a trace of a 'social aspect', because they were simply designed, implemented and serve a single plan to strike at every working, wage, social right of the working class and the poor working classes. There can be no euro-six months better, pro-populist, as various opportunists and new-cut social democrats are trying to deceive the people. The EU and the monopolies it serves only get worse. They're getting better than tipping.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called on the unelected EU Commission to initiate new legislation monitoring the spending of taxpayers’ money. The report calls for things like interfering with Member States’ social protection, tax policies and tax rules, welcomes the EU Commission’s initiative on the long-term unemployed, calls to enhance the Youth Guarantee Scheme, calls on the Commission and the Member States to work together on removing the obstacles to fair labour mobility and calls for better coordination of the European Semester , specifically for the Eurozone.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas the unemployment rate has been falling slightly since the second half of 2013 but not sufficiently to reduce unemployment and poverty in several Member States, which is still too high; that the employment rate of women (63.5% in May 2015) remains well below the main objective of the Europe 2020 strategy and that the loss of human capital due to unemployment is enormous, I express my full support.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Following the publication of the Annual Growth Survey 2016, which set out the priorities at European level, this report shifts the attention of the European Semester to the national dimension. As discussed in the report, the Bulgarian economy has been gradually emerging from the crisis, but a broad-based recovery is yet to be achieved. Therefore, I welcome the resolution and I look forward to the country-specific recommendations to be presented in May 2016 by the Commission based on the analysis presented in the country reports and the dialogue held with Member States.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ We are witnessing a situation of increasing youth unemployment, undeclared work, which threatens workers' access to social protection systems, as well as the risks of sustainability of social security especially with regard to people at risk of social exclusion (e.g. older age, persons with disabilities, refugees, etc.). I believe that good and quality jobs are particularly in terms of youth, a cornerstone of social fairness and securing the future and promoting human dignity. In this regard, employment and social growth must be at the heart of EU policies as a way of achieving a more sustainable social European Union as well as guaranteed sustainability of social protection in relation to the expected ageing of the population and the promotion of family-friendly policies that can increase parents' ability to ensure well-being and contribute to rising birthrates. I encourage Member States to modernise existing social protection systems so that this can be achieved before. I welcome the Commission's call on Member States to increase social investment, in particular in the context of health care, childcare, housing support and rehabilitation services.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. There is a lot of evidence in this report: there is a mini drop in unemployment in Europe but unemployment rates for young people and the elderly remain too high, the European workforce is sorely lacking in skills, there is too much un-reported work, the public debts of the Member States continue to rise... The report's recommendations are also platitude to cry: it calls for the development of skills and skills with training, that we fight against undclared work, that flexicurity is promoted (which generally translates into precariousness), that social systems be modernised to cope with ageing, that we question the low fertility rates in Europe... Fundamentally, in addition to the blatant futility of this report, I object to the very existence of this semester: it is only a tool for the Commission to assess and judge the work of the Member States. As for the country-specific recommendations, they are just another way that the Commission has found to interfere in the functioning of countries. Finally, this semester exists only to enable the objectives of Strategy 2020, an EU strategy to which I am opposed, to be achieved. I therefore vote logically against this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unemployment in Europe has fallen slightly over the past three years due to the combination of macroeconomic policies and structural reforms, but fluctuations have not been such as to lead to a narrowing of the poverty gap. These changes are also linked to impromptu factors linked to the unknowns of the world economy, which sometimes produces favourable situations for the real economy, leading to lower inflation and a temporary increase in purchasing power.  Indeed, there are many factors in Europe that prevent us from eliminating employment differences and achieving a fair and resilient society. The protracted unemployment, especially youth unemployment, has disastrous consequences in terms of loss of human capital and a reduction in social integration. Similarly, female unemployment and the gender pay and pension gap remain factors of exclusion and serious imbalance. We need forward-looking public policies, for an inclusive, fair and dynamic labour market within a sound regulatory framework and in accordance with the renewed objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.  I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the European Semester can take up this challenge and encourage The Member States to step up their efforts by investing in services aimed at positive social and economic development.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Unemployment remains too high in many Member States, currently comprising 9.9% of working citizens, or 23 million Europeans, about half of whom are long-term unemployed. In the euro area, this unemployment covers 10% of citizens. At EU level, the youth unemployment rate is 22.6% and in 2014 the share of young people who were not involved in the education or training process, nor were employed, was 12.3%. This group is threatened with exclusion from the labour market, which leads to a loss of skills and human capital.  One of the five objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of poor and socially excluded people. 123 million people in the EU are poor and socially excluded. I welcome the Commission's call for investment in services such as housing support, health, childcare and rehabilitation services. Quality and inclusive employment is a cornerstone of social fairness, as it promotes the human dignity of all. It is necessary to invest in people as early as possible in the lifecycle in order to reduce inequality and encourage social inclusion at an early age. I believe that sustainable and inclusive growth needs to be promoted, resulting in more and better jobs and concrete prospects for all, especially for young people, in order to respond to the internal and external challenges facing the European Union.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In essence, the report seeks to strengthen the consolidation of EU economic governance policies, in particular the European Semester, by complying with the Annual Growth Plan, the europe 2020 objectives or the specific recommendations for each Member State, in particular with regard to employment and social issues. The Rapporteur, by the way, values the country-specific recommendations and the need for their implementation, when we know them unacceptable and undemocratic, and which in Portugal have imposed the achievement of the deficit targets set by the Troika and so-called permanent measures of "fiscal consolidation" - privatizations, deepening inequalities, wage thefts and reducing consumption. The European Semester is just another mechanism for attacking the sovereignty of states and their organs of sovereignty, deepening the concentration of powers to better implement policies contrary to the will, needs and aspirations of peoples, processes which we reject in the first place. This reality confirms the need to break with the neoliberal policies imposed by the EU and the imperative need to support economic and sustainable growth in decent wages, work with rights, training and qualification of workers, including through public control of strategic sectors. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Sofia Ribeiro's report. The EU's high unemployment rate has slowly started to decline, but despite macroeconomic measures and structural reforms, unemployment and poverty have failed. It is particularly important to take into account certain microeconomic conditions and the need for further socio-fair structural reforms, the impact of which must be assessed before they enter into force. The employment rate for women is 63.5% according to the May 2015 figures, which is much lower than the 75% Europe 2020 target. Increasing women's participation in the labour market can greatly help reduce the noticeable economic disparities between women and men and have a positive impact on women's higher risk of poverty and exclusion from society. The loss of human capital in the midst of unemployment is huge, with the total cost of youth unemployment estimated at €153 billion a year. In addition to financial and social consequences, unemployment, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment have a negative impact on social harmonisation and ultimately hamper sustainable economic growth. It is therefore of utmost importance to invest in social development that guarantees sustainable and inclusive economic development and also has a positive impact on social and economic cohesion, which should be the primary objective of EU policy.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2016 Annual Growth Survey is accompanied by the publication of the Commission's draft joint employment report, which is adopted jointly with the Council (on the basis of Article 148 TFET) and which analyses the employment and social situation in Europe and the policy responses implemented by the Member States. This report analyses the possibilities for improving the employment and social situation in the EU as a whole. I welcome the Commission's efforts to relaunch the social dialogue. For all this, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I did not support the report because its provisions are an attempt by the EU to enter into the competences of the Member States. These are provisions on the EU's intention to control and monitor employment contracts in the Member States. Furthermore, there is a desire to introduce an EU-wide social policy. I have hereby abstained.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. The Annual Growth Survey outlines the European Commission's action plan for the next 12 months at national and EU level. The objective is economic growth and the highest possible employment rate. The Annual Growth Survey is seconded by a joint employment report that directly influences structural reforms in member states. The Joint Employment Report examines the stock of structural reforms in the Member States and, if necessary, extends them in accordance with the Annual Growth Survey. These regulations are in serious breach of the principle of subsidiarity within the EU. An example of this is the demand that the European Commission should make a push for a Union-wide minimum wage. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. Almost 9% of europe's labour force is unemployed. In 2014, almost 5% had been for more than a year and about 3% for more than two years.  It's dramatic.  This resolution provides interesting proposals to address this. That is why I supported her. We need to invest in human resources. We call on states to develop policies for youth employment. These policies must be consistent with the real needs of the labour market. For example, instruments such as the Youth Guarantee must be fully utilised and strengthened.  In addition, the Commission must promote, at Member State level, an investment strategy covering the entire education and training cycle, to ensure that the entire labour force benefits. In particular, a rapid response must be made to the situation of the unemployed over the age of 55. Similarly, sustainable growth must be enabled, including a revival of investment. European funds and programmes are an appropriate lever to stimulate entrepreneurship, investment and access to finance. There is a need to increase information on these information. Improvements are being seen at EU and euro area level. Let's continue and redouble our efforts.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Many socialist measures were incorporated into this report: responsible social reforms based on solidarity, integration, social justice and the fair distribution of health care; quality and inclusive employment; promoting job stability; more investment in social protection systems to prevent poverty and inequalities; introduction of a minimum wage; investment in education to combat unemployment; support for the unemployed, in particular long-term ones; increased social dialogue; reducing wage inequalities and equal treatment among national workers and other Member States; the inclusion of refugees and the strengthening of the social dimension of the euro area, among many others.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that economic recovery should be fair, create quality jobs, reduce inequalities and combat poverty and social exclusion. We need upward social European convergence, with socially responsible reforms based on solidarity, social integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth. Investment in social development should not simply be a means of improving economic growth, but an end in itself. We need greater investments in social protection systems to combat poverty and combat growing inequalities.  In addition, the euro area is treated as a single economy that needs deeper integration, with a strengthened social dimension, better social protection floors and minimum wages, and a strong pillar of social rights.  Finally, I supported this report because it shows us the reality of the data and forgets the Commission's complacency. Employment is being created, but this is precarious, with indecent wages, unfair working conditions and precarious positions. There is no greater betrayal of the social model than the fact that labour poverty is now one of Europe's main problems.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination, which focused on employment and social aspects as part of the 2016 Annual Growth Review. While the economic forecasts for 2016 are encouraging, it is clear that unemployment levels are still very high in the European Union, especially among young people. If I am in favour of coordinating economic policies in Europe, I support the idea that the social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy are better integrated into the European semester. It is on this basis that we must coordinate economic policies in Europe. I am therefore pleased to see that a majority of my European colleagues have joined me on this point in calling via this report for 'strengthening the role of the Europe 2020 strategy' and calling for 'social objectives to be reflected equally in all instruments of the European semester, including country recommendations'. More than ever, we must coordinate our economic policies in order to improve the social conditions of all European citizens.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it emphasises, even more clearly than maria João Rodrigues, the need to focus more on social justice under the new national, stability and reform programmes, adding three employment indicators (activity levels, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment) to the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. The report also stresses the importance of social investment in order to promote Economic, Territorial and Social Cohesion in Europe. Attention is drawn to the importance of investment in health and long-term care, social services, childcare, housing support and rehabilitation services.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. First of all, I would like to greet my Party colleague Sofia Ribeiro for the excellent report subject to the vote and who, moreover, has received substantial support (about two thirds) from the different political groups of the European Parliament. From today's resolution, I would like to stress the importance of the 3 priorities of the 2016 Annual Growth Survey identified by the Commission: the relaunch of investment, an analysis of structural reforms for the modernisation of our economies and the need for responsible fiscal policies. I would also stress the inclusion of 3 indicators in the main scoreboard for analysing the situation of member states on activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment, which, as the rapporteur rightly pointed out, makes this annual review report closer to "the real life of Europeans", and represents a commitment by the Commission to strengthen the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 Mr President, these are the keys to our country. Please, Brussels, take it. Drive carefully. This is the feeling I got when I read these suggestions. A Europe-wide minimum wage? Are we really asking the Commission to take such an initiative? It is not a small leap for Europe, but a giant leap for federalism.  I understand that Mr Ribeiro has had good intentions. However, I believe that we should leave social policy to the Member States.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the European semester for the coordination of economic policies in terms of employment and social policies. In order to create jobs, it is necessary to stress that social and economic cohesion must remain the objective of all EU policies. This is to encourage upward European social convergence, to adapt education and training systems, but also to establish a genuine investment strategy covering the whole cycle of education and training. Balanced structural reforms that are more attentive to social equity are crucial. I supported this text which calls for stimulating growth by sustaining investment. Finally, this resolution calls for the optimal use of European funds, such as the European Social Fund, which enable greater social inclusion.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this report on the Commission's Annual Growth Prospective Study as part of the European Semester on Social and Employment Aspects mentions three positive social indicators from my point of view — activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment in the 2016 Alert Mechanism Report — continues to follow the 'economicist' logic of the European Semester and to influence neoliberal prescriptions for the dramatic employment problem and poverty. That's why I voted against it.  There are recurring concepts that put economic benefits before quantity, quality and dignity in employment such as: competitiveness, productivity, entrepreneurship, flexisecurity, legislation on the system of labour law, deregulation of the labour market, reduction of taxes and wage costs, skills to boost innovation and competitiveness, segmentation of the labour market and simplification of labour protection legislation (which would affect, inter alia, unfair redundancies) Etc. In commitments, both the most critical aspects of the Annual Growth Study process globally and the most progressive amendments in specific aspects have not been incorporated, emphasizing my refusal to support it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The timid social reforms proposed in this report are, in practice, incompatible with an economic framework whose guiding principles will remain neoliberal economic policies, which they serve as a mechanism for legitimization. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to create stable and progressive social convergence, there must be jobs available for people. We must aim to make these quality jobs, without the precariousness that the Tory Government is dead set on making commonplace. Opportunities to work must be made more equal, tearing down unsettling and ridiculous forms of discrimination based on gender, race, ethnicity, sexuality, religion and disability. Socially responsible reforms must promote fair mobility and be based on solidarity, integration, social justice and fair wealth distribution.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in line with the EKR's position against this resolution when voting on the European Semester resolution for the coordination of economic employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. The Annual Growth Survey sets out the Commission's priorities for action at national and European level to promote economic growth and employment later this year. I consider it important that adequate attention be paid and support for reform efforts in the field of employment and social policy. At the same time, however, the principle of subsidiarity must be respected, so I could not agree with the requirements for the further transfer of competences in this area from the Member States to the EU level.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution because I consider the need to invest in social development as an opportunity to achieve sustainable and inclusive economic development. The European Union as a whole and many EU Member States continue to suffer from structural problems, which urgently need to be addressed in order to reduce poverty, eliminate regional disparities and create favourable conditions for the growth of new jobs. The report calls on the Member States to do their utmost to close the gender pay gap and to take more active measures to promote women's participation in the labour market, which has not been met in the long term, despite the many measures taken both at EU level and in individual Member States. In future, the Commission and the Member States should focus on micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, which are a key element in ensuring sustainable and inclusive development and job creation and in closing the gender pay gap in terms of self-employment.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The unemployment rate has been decreasing slowly since the second half of 2013. Despite the support of some macroeconomic policies and structural reforms, this is not happening fast enough to curb unemployment and poverty.  Unemployment currently affects 9.9% of active citizens, which is 23 million Europeans. Of these, about half are long-term unemployed.  The third year of economic recovery has now begun, with growth expected to be 2% in the EU-28 in 2016 and 1.8% in the euro area. However, the recovery takes place differently between Member States and depends on temporary factors.  According to the Commission, there are still differences in employment and social differences within and between Member States. Social development still points to a further divergences across the EU that prevents growth, employment and cohesion.  The report refers to the Employment and Social Aspects Scoresheet for 2016. This highlights, in particular, the continued investment in people and social development, structural reforms in a social and responsible way, the promotion of sustainable growth through investment recovery, better use of European funds to promote social, economic and territorial cohesion and better coordination of the European Semester.  I agree that taking into account the specific microeconomic situation and implementing additional fair social structural reform is essential, which is why I supported the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Ribeiro report covers social and labour market policy aspects in the context of the Annual Growth Survey of the European Semester. The fundamental problem is that the EU is still unwilling to recognise the adjustment difficulties caused by the euro and continues to focus on combating symptoms. But also in the fight against symptoms, one could make helpful policy. In some parts, the ECR has succeeded in counteracting the request for the centralisation of policy and responsibilities, but it has not succeeded sufficiently. As an example, the report proposes that 20% of the European Social Fund's resources for social concerns and the fight against poverty should be set up, thus giving Member States room for manoeuvre, developing a concept of 'social fairness' at EU level, or calling on the Commission to launch an initiative on minimum wages.  In the interests of subsidiarity and self-responsibility, I have decided to reject the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ unemployment in the EU is slowly in decline. However, significant social and employment disparities remain between Member States. Investment in education is essential for Europe's future competitiveness. However, in addition to investing in youth education, specific labour groups such as women or generation 55+ should not be forgotten either.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. A strong economy is the best basis for social prosperity. Unfortunately, this is not sufficiently taken into account in the report before us. Although the final text adopted by the plenary refers to the importance of subsidiarity, it remains unfortunately very prescriptive in certain passages. It also calls for a number of initiatives at EU level that the N-VA cannot support. The N-VA is in favour of European social objectives but relies not so much on the European Commission but on the Member States themselves to achieve them. That does not mean that there would be no role for the European Commission, which can indeed act in support.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The unemployment rate has been decreasing slowly since the second half of 2013, but not enough to curb unemployment and poverty despite some stimulus macroeconomic policies and structural reforms. Unemployment remains too high in many Member States and currently covers 9.9% of working citizens, or 23 million Europeans, about half of whom are long-term unemployed, while in the euro area this unemployment covers 10% of citizens, all of which are unfavourable than those in 2008. I therefore welcome the Commission's call for investment in services such as housing support, health, childcare and rehabilitation services, and would stress that economic and social cohesion should remain the primary objective of all EU policies and that more efforts should be made to carry out a more complex and objective assessment based on the diversity and characteristics of Member States. I welcome the fact that the Commission's Annual Growth Survey underlines the need to pay greater attention to social fairness in the context of new national stability programmes and reform programmes by bringing three employment-related indicators (activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment) to the macroeconomic imbalance process.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination in the annual growth research report also looks at social aspects and employment. The topics of this year's report were social policy, social charter and protocol, employment policy, actions to combat unemployment and economic growth. The economic priorities of last year's report remain, but in 2016 the priorities of restarting investments, responsible fiscal policy and structural reforms needed to modernise the economy are highlighted.  To allow for a better analysis of macroeconomic inequalities, new variables such as long-term unemployment, activity rate and youth unemployment are included. I support this report because it highlights the need to invest in social development. This is not only a means to guarantee sustainable and inclusive economic development, but also an independent priority. Particular attention was also paid to the exchange of best practices between Member States and investment in lifelong education and training.  Underinvestment in education, especially in the digital age, poses a threat to European competitiveness. In order to meet labour market needs and provide eu citizens with the necessary employment, these priorities should not be ignored. I welcome the recommendations of the childcare investment report, rehabilitation services and healthcare in general. Economic and social cohesion should remain the primary objectives of all EU policies.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey.  I support the report's emphasis that the need to invest in social development is not only a means of ensuring sustainable and inclusive economic development and convergence, but must also constitute a specific objective in itself. We need investment in housing support, healthcare, childcare and rehabilitation services.  As the report rightly covers, quality and inclusive jobs are an essential pillar of social justice that promotes human dignity for all.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report supports from the beginning to the end the austerity policies promoted by the Commission and the sovereign circles of Brussels. He says unemployment is falling, the post-crisis situation has stabilised and that what is needed now is to continue the policies that already exist.  As acpel, we voted against, as is the settled line between the ACPL and the Group when it comes to reports on the budget and the European Semester.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In its first year in office, the Commission presented ambitious initiatives to support employment and growth, strengthen economic convergence and strengthen social justice, but unfortunately no progress has been made.  Today, with the 2016 Annual Growth Survey, it sets priorities for the coming year. Sofia Ribeiro's resolution (EPP, Portugal), adopted by the Employment Committee on 17 February, defends the inclusion of recent employment indicators in the Annual Growth Survey in order to monitor social developments in the Member States.  However, the report does not agree with us on many points. First of all, reference is made to the refugee and migration issues that can have a positive impact on labour supply and development, "with conditions". It also argues that Member States should make full use of the possibility of using the EFSI in conjunction with other EU funds under Horizon 2020, the Connecting Europe Facility and the European Structural and Investment Funds. Finally, it supports intra-Union labour mobility throughout the Union.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which summarised in detail the employment and social aspects of the 2016 Growth Survey. Indeed, the signs of economic growth have already been shown in the employment figures, but only in a small way and to a very different extent from one Member State to another. Unemployment and worker poverty remain serious problems within the EU. The report rightly highlights the worrying level of youth unemployment. Like the rapporteur, I also welcome the Commission's wish to extend the Youth Guarantee programme, but it is regrettable that many Member States have not been able to implement it successfully so far. I support the rapporteur's proposal that, as poverty, social exclusion and homelessness are serious and growing problems for most Member States, the Europe 2020 strategy needs to be revised to see how the objectives set out there can nevertheless be achieved. I also agree with the recommendation in the report that the Commission should promote cooperation between governments, companies, educational institutions, NGOs and social economy enterprises, creating an opportunity to share best practices and develop a clearer picture of the needs of the labour market. Finally, I fully agree with the call for the EU to guarantee the proper use of funds from European funds, which requires even stricter supervision by the Commission.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Although unemployment in the European Union is slowly falling, it remains relatively high, especially among young people, almost a quarter of whom are out of work. The community-wide cost of such high youth unemployment is estimated at more than €150 billion per year. Member States must overcome barriers to job creation and improve the functioning of labour markets. I am therefore pleased that the European Semester, based on three main pillars, namely boosting investment, structural reforms and increasing fiscal responsibility, has been complemented by a new pillar in the Framework of the European Semester 2016: employment and social affairs. I hope that this will not only place greater emphasis on analysing the social situation and employment in the European Union, but will also facilitate the monitoring of any distortions in the Member States that undermine growth and the creation of new and stable jobs.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the report because I do not believe that initiatives on minimum wages should be taken at European Union level. The report also contained other problematic points where the EU goes into the area of nationalcompensation on labour market issues.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unemployment remains the EU's main economic challenge. Economic growth is stable in most regions of the EU, budget deficits are getting smaller, but this positive ratio does not include reducing unemployment. Of the 23 million Europeans facing unemployment, more than half remain stranded in this situation in the long term. We need to connect the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the Labour Market much better. At the moment, we do not have a social evaluation of the projects financed by this programme. Moreover, there are states with poverty-stricken regions that do not yet have a draft adopted in the EFSI. We can also think about expanding programmes to reduce youth unemployment. Both in terms of the age of the beneficiaries and the amounts allocated, I believe that we can support an increase. Last but not least, I expect a clearer connection of the European Semester with the social aspects of the EU. The social economy remains far from reality, with only 10% of all European companies falling into this category. We can get more in the next period!

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. In order to align European and national growth policies and ensure their relevance on the ground, it is crucial to strengthen the role of social partners at both European and national level. In order to move towards upward convergence and achieve a balance between competitiveness and equity, social dialogue must be pursued in all phases of the European semester. In this regard, I welcome the Commission's efforts to relaunch the social dialogue and the simplified approach presented by EAC 2015. However, it should still be remembered that, in many Member States, the situation remains weak at the national level.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it does not address the right issues. Indeed, the report adopted calls for increasing flexibility in public deficit spending and it does not recommend that European Fund for Structural Investments (EFSI) projects be economically viable and moreover it introduces bureaucracy and does not intend to remove barriers to entry to the labour market and modernise the economy. It also addresses the migration crisis and I do not believe this is the right place for that.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because it raises important concerns for young Europeans. The unemployment rate for young people in the EU is 22% and 12% of young people are uneducated, not employed or educated, which puts this group at risk of exclusion from the labour market, which affects the increase in social spending. Given that, first of all, Member States have a responsibility to tackle unemployment among young people, we should create a larger EU support system. Common labour market regulation needs to be put in place for education, training and active policies towards the unemployed. This aid should cover particularly new EU countries such as Lithuania. Because only in this way will we be able to equalise living standards in the old and new parts of Europe in the future, by implementing a subsidiarity policy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the report on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination: Employment and Social Policy Aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey, as I believe that Member States should try to address social policy bottlenecks in a flexible manner and reduce the number of poor and socially excluded people or those at risk of such a situation.   Given that I believe that a common analysis and definition of member states' social and economic dimension strategies cannot be consolidated within the European Union, I believe that structural reforms will not strengthen the business-friendly environment in order to create more quality jobs and strike a balance between the social and economic dimensions. In fact, I believe that good jobs are the cornerstone of social fairness, as they promote human dignity and must be the centre of EUROPEAN Union policy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey was a way of defining social policy priorities in the context of the 2016 policy coordination process.  The report stresses the importance of investing in people, the need for structural reforms and sustainable growth, better use of European funds and social inclusion. All aspects are mentioned, which currently present a major challenge to European society and the social policies of the Member States.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this report on the Commission's Annual Growth Prospective Study as part of the European Semester on Social and Employment Aspects mentions three positive social indicators from my point of view — activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment in the 2016 Alert Mechanism Report — continues to follow the 'economicist' logic of the European Semester and to influence neoliberal prescriptions for the dramatic employment problem and poverty. That's why I voted against it.  There are recurring concepts that put economic benefits before quantity, quality and dignity in employment such as: competitiveness, productivity, entrepreneurship, flexisecurity, legislation on the system of labour law, deregulation of the labour market, reduction of taxes and wage costs, skills to boost innovation and competitiveness, segmentation of the labour market and simplification of labour protection legislation (which would affect, inter alia, unfair redundancies) Etc. In commitments, both the most critical aspects of the Annual Growth Study process globally and the most progressive amendments in specific aspects have not been incorporated, emphasizing my refusal to support it.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The Ribeiro report covers social and labour market policy aspects in the context of the Annual Growth Survey of the European Semester. The fundamental problem is that the EU is still unwilling to recognise the adjustment difficulties caused by the euro and continues to focus on combating symptoms. But also in the fight against symptoms, one could make helpful policy. In some parts, the ECR has succeeded in counteracting the request for the centralisation of policy and responsibilities, but it has not succeeded sufficiently. As an example, the report proposes that 20% of the European Social Fund's resources for social concerns and the fight against poverty should be set up, thus giving Member States room for manoeuvre, developing a concept of 'social fairness' at EU level, or calling on the Commission to launch an initiative on minimum wages.  In the interests of subsidiarity and self-responsibility, I have decided to reject the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, as I believe it includes a fair amount of measures and reforms that are worth considering in order to improve the situation in our labour markets.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. There is a lot of evidence in this report: there is a mini drop in unemployment in Europe but youth and senior unemployment rates remain too high, the European workforce is sorely lacking in skills, there is too much undised work, the public debts of member states continue to rise... The report's recommendations are also very platitude: it calls for the development of skills and skills with training, that we fight against undclared work, that flexicurity is promoted (which generally translates into precariousness), that social systems are modernised to cope with ageing, that we question the low fertility rates in Europe... Fundamentally, in addition to the blatant futility of the report, we object to the very existence of the semester: it is only a tool for the Commission to assess and judge the work of the Member States. As for the country-specific recommendations, they are only an additional means for the Commission to interfere in the functioning of countries. Finally, this semester exists only to enable the objectives of Strategy 2020, an EU strategy which we strongly oppose, to be achieved. So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The unemployment rate has been falling slowly since the second half of 2013, but not significantly enough to curb unemployment and poverty, despite supportive macro-economic policies and structural reforms. Nevertheless, it is still too high in many Member States, currently affecting 9.9 percent of active citizens, which means 23 million Europeans, about half of whom are long-term unemployed, and more than 10 percent of the euro area is still well above the 2008 figures. I supported the report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted favourably on this report because it represents a critique of the labour elements of the specific recommendations and the European Semester process as a whole.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2016 report. The report suggests the importance of the employment indicators such as activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment, which were recently included in the Annual Growth Survey, being employed for monitoring social developments in Member States as well. The indicators will enable the assessment of internal imbalances in Member States and eventually allow for redesigning their economic and social reforms if necessary. The report stresses the importance of ‘social fairness’, which should be crucial when designing employment and social policies, particularly when applying structural reforms that significantly harm vulnerable groups in society. I voted in favour of this report because it is directed towards ensuring sustainable and fair welfare systems and reducing social inequalities.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2012 Annual Growth Survey for 2016 identifies as specific priorities, in the social and employment aspects, investment in people, the development of structural reforms in a sustainable and social way, the promotion of sustainable growth, relaunching investment, making better use to promote geographical and social cohesion, considering social inclusion as a challenge for society or better coordination of the European Semester. In short, we are talking about a number of positive priorities, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. We are in favour of raising the lowest wages in the EU in order to reduce poverty and combat wage dumping. In Sweden, unlike in most countries, there is no statutory minimum wage, but wages are set by collective agreements between the social partners without direct political interference. We therefore believe that minimum wages should not be regulated by law, but that account must be taken of each member country's national practices in order to strengthen collective agreements and workers' rights in the different wage-setting systems.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution for a motion. It is vital that the recent overemphasis on fiscal correction is at least slowed and where possible reversed. There has not, in recent times, been enough emphasis on the social and long-term economic costs of this form of reform. It is vital that we properly invest in young people and their skills. Any fiscal correction needs to be based on solidarity, integration, social justice and a fair distribution of wealth; otherwise it only ends up denying people the chance for gainful employment and fuels social inequality. There needs to a rapid and effective response at both ends of the age scale, both for young people, particularly the 12.3% of young people who are not in education or training, but also those aged 55+ who are finding it very difficult to re-enter the labour market. Both of these groups represent human resources that are being wasted by overzealous fiscal correction which is undermining programmes that can provide them with the skills that they need. We need to recognise the importance of investing in people to improve growth.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Parliament often takes a position on matters that do not necessarily belong to it. It is desirable to improve the employment situation in the Member States, but the employment policies of economies that differ greatly cannot be steered from the EU. In accordance with this principle, I could not support the adoption of the report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Under the guise of European coordination of economic and budgetary policies, the European semester, set up after the 2008 financial crisis, must, we are told, be able to monitor the implementation of so-called structural reforms and the reduction of budget deficits, we know what this means. And the least that can be said is that the dramatic consequences of the austerity policies deployed on the European continent are once again largely overshadowed by parliament's annual report on the European semester. Symptomatic of this hypocrisy, several paragraphs recognise that Member States, whose budgets are being cut by austerity, are no longer able to protect and promote key sectors such as education, health, research or innovation, but without questioning the causes of these distressing findings. It is high time to stop these deadly austere policies and to promote alternative policies based on a different distribution of wealth and other priorities that meet the needs of the people and not those of money and finance.  I voted against the various reports on this subject as well as all members of my group.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In essence, the report seeks to strengthen the themes referred to in the proposals made under the European Semester and economic governance, the Europe 2020 Objectives, or in the recommendations specific to each Member State. Here's the problem: it doesn't call into question the legitimacy of national sovereignty and development policies, which have effectively only contributed to social degradation, masking them with socializing makeup, in the manner of social washing, but not altering their principles. We recognise that the text presents some reasons for support, including objective information on the numbers of poverty and extreme poverty, unemployment, the objectives that have not been met, without statistical manipulation, the strengthening of industrial relations and collective agreements and the fight against precariousness and insecurity. As has already been said, all the positive aspects of the report do not change the essence of the European Semester and the policies of the European Union. In this sense, it is proposed to vote against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report clearly separates the tasks of the Commission and MS without requiring additional competences at EU level. On the other hand, he is in favour of programmes which I am rather critical of, such as .B Youth Guarantee, strengthening the influence of the officials of the European semester. This is in direct contradiction to more democratic responsibility. That is why I abstained.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because it is important to combat poverty despite a permanent job. It is also important that women are no longer disadvantaged and that wages are also adjusted to the living standards of today's economy.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policy – employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. I am opposed to the economic governance of the EU and the euro area through the European Semester. On the contrary, the Member States should pursue their own economic policies and thereby enter into competition with each other. A coordinated economic policy is only needed if the intention is to establish or maintain transfer mechanisms between Member States. There is really no reason for a report on employment and social aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey. Reports of this kind are the beginning of the communitarisation of social policy. This also entails the desire of the EU federalists for a European employment agency or for the communitarisation of risks due to the cost of unemployment. I reject all this.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to reiterate that serious political commitment is required in order to meet the Europe 2020 anti-poverty targets, and such a commitment would require tackling gender inequalities.  As such, I echo this report’s concerns about the social impacts of structural reform policies that have been implemented across the EU so far, and highlight that they have had a disproportionate negative impact on women, thereby also affecting children and other dependents. Likewise I support the report’s mention of the importance of the social economy, and reiterate the role that cooperatives, mutuals and similar alternative business models can play in stimulating inclusive and sustainable growth.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 One of the objectives of economic policy coordination is also social inclusion as an opportunity for society. As such, work has never been a guarantee that one will be out of poverty, nor the best tool for ensuring social inclusion, as 12.7% of working-age workers suffered from poverty in 2014, an increase of 1.7% since 2009. This is also due to the fact that work is not fairly valued, and I therefore also support the introduction of a minimum income for families as a tool for combating poverty and social exclusion. However, it should not be forgotten that, in view of the ageing of the European population, it is necessary to move in the direction of pro-family policy and, therefore, by promoting the birth rate. At the same time, we must not forget the adequate financial evaluation of mothers' work in caring for their children and solidarity between generations.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's reports on the 'European Semester', the mechanism for imposing 'permanent memoranda' on all EU Member States, demonstrate the commitment of the political staff of monopolies to its objectives: measures to continuously reduce the price of labour everywhere in order to recover the profitability of business groups, to come capitalist growth that so far seems anemic, uncertain and fragile.  That is why they require urban governments to implement the 'country-by-country recommendations', i.e. the unpopular measures drawn up by the EU institutions. In order to counter popular indignation, they attempt to dress up the whole process of six months and "enhanced economic governance" supposedly with "social aspects" and "social sensitivity", but they do not even manage to express wishful words, betraying their hostility to labour-popular rights.  The six-month period and all the procedures of the EU's 'permanent memorandums' cannot have a trace of a 'social aspect', because they were simply designed, implemented and serve a single plan to strike at every working, wage, social right of the working class and the poor working classes. There can be no euro-six months better, pro-populist, as various opportunists and new-cut social democrats are trying to deceive the people. The EU and the monopolies it serves only get worse. They're getting better than tipping.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I consider it necessary to continue to cooperate between governments, society, social partners and educational institutions on the transfer of good practice, which leads to a greater link between the education system and the requirements of the current labour market. I also agree with the need to invest in young people's entrepreneurship. However, I consider it equally important to find the most effective solution to unemployment among people in the 55 years and over category. These people can offer businesses their long-term and considerable experience in their fields of activity.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the report covering the European Commission's priorities for the next 12 months, with a focus on promoting economic growth and employment. Although the report was particularly positive for action at both national and European levels, with a focus on increasing employment, including employment for young people and persons with disabilities, on the other hand, it contained many elements that I could not support. First of all, it was references to wage fragmentation across Member States. I believe that the effect of possible harmonisation of the minimum wage in the European Union is not sufficiently examined and could ultimately have undesirable consequences. Secondly, it was too thin an ice on which the report was moving in the context of the challenges of the teaching process and the curriculum, and I think that some of the proposals have interfered with the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of education. Last but not least, they were references to migration policy and an expression of support for the European Commission's migration agenda. My opinion on this issue has not changed. Although I believe that the migration and refugee crisis needs to be tackled together, I do not support the system of proposed quotas and I believe that solutions should be brought about on the principle of voluntary solidarity between Member States. Unfortunately, all these aspects outweighed the positives of the report, as a result of which I voted against it in the end.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Understanding and accepting the reasons for strengthening economic policy coordination in the European Union as part of the European Semester, a rational approach to the proposed action must be maintained for the Member States. It is difficult to agree to the demands to limit the freedom to shape the rules and conditions of employment in Poland with the help of European regulations. Creating economic growth requires appropriate tools, including the possibility of influencing the labour market. While forms of cooperation at European level that are conducive to increasing employment in the form of, for example, eures networks are needed, the possibility of direct interference by the European Commission in the social policies of the Member States or in the employment relationship between employer and employee, based on national law, is a bad proposal, which I cannot support. This is an example of an unjustified expansion of the EC's competences, which will increase the level of bureaucracy in the EU and weaken the ability of Member States to respond rapidly to employment crises. Of course, the merits of this report must be emphasised, including the call for increased investment in human capital, the need to protect a market economy or the role of infrastructure investment in creating growth. Unfortunately, given the overly far-reaching proposals to restrict member states' freedom in the field of employment policy and the rejection of many favourable amendments, I abstained.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: social and employment aspects in the 2016 Annual Growth Survey from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, whose draftsman was Mrs Sofia Ribeiro, as it underlines the need for more attention to be paid to social equity in the context of the new national stability and reform programmes , adding three employment indicators (activity rate, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment) to the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. On the other hand, the report states that these indicators are truly placed on an equal footing with existing indicators, which will make it possible to carry out in-depth analyses in the Member States concerned and ensure that their internal imbalances are better assessed. In addition, I would also stress the focus on creating quality jobs and creating conditions for generating growth, which should be placed at the heart of Member States' and EU policies, in particular for young people and generation over 55, as a way of building more sustainable social economies.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I plan, dear colleagues, to create a dictionary entitled 'Language of the European Union with central and eastern European eyes'. For example, the single market, what does it mean from our point of view? The fact that we had to give western companies, so-called investors, all our factories, so to speak, at the time of the regime change, had to be planted there, that we had to give the French or the Germans the same chance, as the European Court of Justice has ruled now, the possibility of a cafeteria, the possibility of an Elisabeth voucher. It is not by chance possible for the Hungarian state or the Hungarian company to benefit from an advantage. I believe that this should be called the single market when the Hungarian entrepreneur will have the same chance of buying French or English or German land, factories and services as vice versa. In the meantime, I'm going to ask you again to call it what it is, colonialism.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr What is important in this report? To have transparency, so there is transparence. That is the most important thing. For the European Standardisation System to be restored and to make more active use of information communication technologies. The principle of mutual recognition and its maximum respect and fairer administration of public procurement are of fundamental importance, because without effective reforms in these areas, the full functioning of the single market is simply not possible. The same thing you have to say is that the same thing is to be said that the same thing applies to a clearer division of competences between different levels of management structures so that they do not duplicate their functions. In general, support.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I supported this report on the single market within the EU. Personally, I consider the single market to be one of the main advantages of European integration, with the political aspects of the 28 countries working together.  I think that even those who may not be in support of further building a federal Europe should see that uniting the internal market is a clear advantage for citizens and businesses, and i therefore also hope that in the future we will be able to remove the obstacles that are still in the single market.  Personally, I would consider it a great success if, in this parliamentary term, we were to promote certain aspects of the digital single market, to adjust the sale of goods over the Internet across national borders, to resolve the issue of geoblocking, etc.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I also supported this draft report. The reason for this is that the single internal market is a fundamental value that European integration has developed over several decades. Undoubtedly, this is the motivation why businesses, citizens and, of course, the state should insist on further deepening integration today. I would also like to stress that the report that has been presented to us very rightly understands terms such as competitiveness, increasing competitiveness, investment and innovation. I would also like to say that cohesion policy, which eliminates disadvantages, is part of the internal market in a way. It is also the engine of employment growth, competitiveness and innovation.  These are all the values why it makes sense, in my opinion, to further deepen the single internal market, because if the market operates unhindered, it undoubtedly brings economic and employment growth.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an initiative report and is not legislative. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Each economic parameter indicates declining performance for the States of the Union. The 'single market' is an instrument that we have at our disposal to promote growth and stability. Although the text refers to bureaucratic simplification and cooperation, the benefits of this strategy are treated superficially without taking into account the possible side effects. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that, in order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and act as a stabilising instrument for economies, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its full realization.  The single market is the cornerstone of the economies of the Member States and the European integration project, providing economic benefits such as greater competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in the EU, in particular greater opportunities for choice of quality products and services and lower prices.   As a socialist I believe that the key to unlocking the full potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion, lies in the observance and implementation of existing Union legislation in our Member States, and I believe that better governance and greater transparency of its integration process are vital for job creation, sustainable growth and competitiveness in our influential single market.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The deepening of the single market at the stroke of recommendations in the European Semester will mean continuing the regression in social and democratic rights experienced in recent years by placing market pseudo-freedoms against labour rights and the sovereignty of European peoples. That's why I voted against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text on the governance of the single market in the context of the 2016 European semester. Indeed, this text presents the single market as the great solution to the current European ills. The main features of this text are the harmonisation of national policies, the sharing of unlimited data, the free global circulation and the establishment of a supra-state control body to verify the proper implementation of European directives and decisions. Without any questioning of these European dogmas, this text praises them, the latter having jeopardized our economies. So I objected.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on single market governance in the context of the European Semester 2016, because it includes the area of growth and the creation of additional jobs through assistance provided by effective competition. The inclusion of the single market as a pillar of the European Semester should also include benchmarks and specific indicators referring to the single market as a whole.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Condensed from the EU's poncifs, this report provides an overview of the threats to the single market, the first of which is of course "national selfishness", the resurgence of nationalism/populism/protectionism... your choice! The solution? the single market, of course, through its digital component and through a supra-state governance body. In addition, the text recommends: unlimited data sharing, increased overall free movement of workers, capital, etc. It stresses the need for the creation of a body to monitor the docile implementation of European directives and regulations as recommendations made to countries in the context of successive European semesters with sanctions at the key for recalcitrants.  Protectionism is presented roughly as a brake and a hindrance to the productivity and competitiveness of the single market.  Finally, the integration of illegal immigrants and minorities and their access to the single market is high on the agenda in the report. Therefore, as long as the European Union does not get rid of the dogmas that parasitize the intelligence of its representatives, I can only vote against this text.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, by which the European Parliament endorsed the EU's economic, social and single market priorities for 2016. This report is Parliament's contribution to setting economic policy priorities for 2016. the European Semester policy coordination process in response to the Commission's Annual Growth Survey. The report on single market governance reiterates its call for the inclusion of the Single Market pillar in the European Semester by creating a framework for continuous monitoring and identification of single market barriers in specific countries, assessing the integration and competitiveness of the Single Market and focusing on certain priorities in areas where action would have the greatest impact on growth and jobs, including sustainable business development.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on the insertion of the single market into the framework of the 2016 European Semester. The report underlines the importance of further developing the single market and is concerned that the level of implementation of the European Semester recommendations for the period 2011-2014 was weaker than expected. It therefore invites the Commission to propose a mechanism to encourage countries to implement country-specific recommendations and to include this monitoring in the European Semester. I do not agree with the report because it is essentially a continuation of the flawed economic policy and philosophy so far, which does not take into account the huge differences between member states (e.g. five times different wages, significantly different economic structures, the breakdown of the Union into opposing debtor and creditor countries, etc.) and further pushes for a policy that has long been found to have failed. The Union could develop much faster than the United States, among other non-neoliberal policies, because catching up with less developed countries could provide significant dynamics. On this basis, I rejected the report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The report purports to take stock of the threats to the single market, the first of which is national selfishness with the resurgence of nationalism/populism/protectionism, etc. For Eurocrats, the only viable solution to Europe's woes is the single market, through its digital component and through a supra-state governance body.
