This means harmonising "regional policies" - that is, national - within the EU and increasing the overall free movement (!) of data, workers, capital etc.  I obviously voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European semester in the single market to consider as the pillar of the European economy. It is essential to further develop the European single market in order to help create jobs in the European Union. Indeed, the completion of the single market would produce economic gains ranging from EUR 651 billion to EUR 1,100 billion per year, equivalent to 5% to 8.63% of the UNION's GDP. Competition is also an essential element of the report and all forms of competition, including digital competition, are examined.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is one of the main achievements of the integration process and one of the fundamental pillars of the European Union. I voted in favour of the Stihler report on the governance of the single market within the framework of the 2016 European Semester, because I firmly believe in the need to reaffirm the importance of including this issue in the debate on the European Semester. The growth and economic stabilisation of the Member States are objectives that can only be achieved by completing the single market and strengthening democratic accountability processes. The creation of new jobs, Europe's growth and competitiveness are not unrelated to the improvement of governance systems and the increased transparency of decision-making processes. I supported this report because I believe that the provision for a system of regular monitoring and evaluation of the single market and competitiveness is moving in this direction. Setting a set of priorities and providing for the creation of a robust database of quantitative and qualitative information to effectively assess progress in the Member States can be an excellent way of further improving integration mechanisms.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, since the report understands the single market as the only way to create work, growth and competitiveness and can also be done only under the framework of the European Semester. The European Semester and the report of the five presidents are a frontal attack on national and economic sovereignty — any tax reform or wage policy measure must be approved by national competitiveness committees, tools created for budgetary union — and represent an oligarchic and authoritarian institutional architecture with an absence of absolute democracy. I therefore reject any action within the framework of the European Semester and the report of the five presidents.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I am grateful for the work of the rapporteur and the other Members who have worked for the adoption of this report on the governance of the single market within the framework of the 2016 European Semester. The single market is one of the foundations of the EU and for the European Semester to successfully promote growth it is necessary to include the single market and policies for its full implementation. Needless to say, accountability at all levels of effective governance of the single market could be achieved by improving regulation on the one hand and expanding the culture of compliance on the other.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have strongly rejected this report which proves once again that most MEPs in the major political groups are only the priests of the European Federalist Church. Psalmodizing their incantations to the so-called benefits of a federal and ultra-liberal Europe, they say most seriously that if the singing tomorrows have not yet affected Europe in terms of prosperity and security, it is simply because integration has not been completed. We therefore need more and more single market, more liberalisation of workers, capital and above all not to loosen the cabal against the populist monster who seems to want to extend its grip on the wonderful European paradise by proposing protectionist measures in terms of economy and employment. This report on the governance of the single market is a true credo of European dogma, hammering abrasive figures on the so-called cost of "non-Schengen" and on the so-called economic and social gains made by the single market, a true "notorious success" as this report dares to say. But the peoples of Europe no longer have the faith of the coal miner about this European Union and are increasingly aware of the need to be protected.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against all three reports. The keynote of all three reports is to support the economic policies that set the framework for the European Semester. I am opposed to europe's market-liberal approach, austerity policies, privatisations and deregulation.  Opposition to this policy is growing throughout the EU. I note that the reports, particularly Mr Rodrigues, contain attempts to criticise the policy pursued and some arguments in favour of incentives. However, it is not clear enough for me to be able to vote in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that, in order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and act as a stabilising instrument for economies, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its full realization.  The single market is the cornerstone of the economies of the Member States and the European integration project, providing economic benefits such as greater competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in the EU, in particular greater opportunities for choice of quality products and services and lower prices.   As a socialist I believe that the key to unlocking the full potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion, lies in the observance and implementation of existing Union legislation in our Member States, and I believe that better governance and greater transparency of its integration process are vital for job creation, sustainable growth and competitiveness in our influential single market.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market Governance Report is one of three parliamentary reports on the 2016 European Semester. The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of the single market is not expanding. I believe that the Union should support Member States in significantly increasing cross-border trade and urgently to make better use of digital technologies. In my opinion, the governance of the single market needs to be strengthened in order for the Union to be an engine for growth and jobs. This requires re-ingesting the highest level of political supervision, standardise the transposition and implementation of EU rules, and at the same time develop more effective tools to ensure that the single market really benefits citizens and businesses.  In the context of the Europe 2020 strategy, we are reviewing the functioning of the single market. It is necessary to look precisely at where progress has been made and to try to limit where difficulties remain. These should be the basis for identifying policy priorities.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The single market, as a cornerstone of the EU's existence, is also a major challenge. Progress and globalisation, the development of modern technologies, its power is further increased, but at the same time the possibility of abuse, unfair practices, exploitation and the like.  With the rest of the majority of Members, I supported the strategy for managing the single market because I am aware of its strengths and that, together with its development, it also requires an update of general practices.  By supporting the report, we have also made clear the rapporteur's desire for the single market to be included in the European Semester, as it is an essential component that, unfortunately, is taken for granted too often.  What the single market means has recently been felt by economists in the face of the migrant crisis, when they have begun to face problems with the free movement of goods. It is therefore right that the single market should be constantly upgraded, while at the same time requiring Member States to strictly respect its rules. Indeed, those who wish to benefit from this must also adhere to commitments, obligations and agreements.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is not only one of the pillars of the Union but also one of its greatest achievements. Its potential for growth, competitiveness and employment is enormous, but it is not yet fully exploited. As stated in the report voted on today, which I supported, the European Semester should focus more on the opportunities offered by this fundamental instrument and enable them to fully deploy. This is only possible if the internal market is effectively deepened, to be achieved through better governance and transparency, the reduction of existing non-tariff barriers and the full implementation of existing regulations on public services and procurement, in accordance with a multi-level and more coordinated approach. The opportunities that the single market offers us, like those of the digital single market, are indeed many, but it is up to us to act and coordinate to derive the greatest benefits from them.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an initiative report and is not legislative. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The total lack of questioning as a pragmatic analysis of the overall balance sheet of the single market renders this text abstruse. It must be rejected in its entirety. I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The market is a large, complex multi-level system, which is one of the pillars of European well-being and the integration process that Member States are pursuing. It is a valuable resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the European Union depends.  The unused potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 000 billion, is both an opportunity and a wake-up call to ensure that the single market benefits everyone. There are currently excessive barriers to trade across the EU and many Member States do not implement the decisions they sign, especially on inclusiveness and transparency, which is why the EU's influence is not yet expressed in its full potential. It must be realised that the market needs macroeconomic and micro-economic policy coordination combined with the governance of budgetary policies in order to contribute to the structural economic growth desired in the EU Member States.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the governance of the single market in the framework of the European Semester 2016 extols European federalism as the only bulwark against the current economic crisis and against the rise of so-called populist parties. The text therefore calls for the creation of a monitoring body in charge of complying with European directives as well as the Commission's recommendations in the Member States. The rapporteur also stresses the need to encourage and promote european mobility in order to reduce regional disparities.  This report is a series of generalities on how the European Union contributes to the individual well-being and prosperity of our societies. While most EU Member States have been going through an unprecedented economic crisis since 2008, leading to an increase in the number of job seekers and a dramatic increase in social inequalities, it is absolutely indecent to witness the complacency of those responsible for this economic slump, determined never to question themselves. So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. Our opposition to the very concept of the 'European Semester' is political but also of substance. In the case of this report, which touches on the aspects relating to the management of the internal market, we are faced with a number of unseeded statements. In our opinion – once again – the IMCO Committee makes too optimistic assumptions about the contribution that greater development of the internal market and the digital single market can make to the growth of the union's economy as a whole.  There are too many references in the text to tasks that Member States would not complete, including with regard to the application of EU rules. Our delegation maintains, in fact, that the regulatory over-production of the European institutions is the problem, and certainly not the difficulties encountered by the Member States in inserting rules that are unsuited to their own production reality within their own legal systems. On the contrary, there are no references to the costs that this Europe and its rules, including many of those relating to the internal market, impose on our companies and local authorities.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that, in order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and act as a stabilising instrument for economies, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its full realization.  The single market is the cornerstone of the economies of the Member States and the European integration project, providing economic benefits such as greater competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in the EU, in particular greater opportunities for choice of quality products and services and lower prices.   As a socialist I believe that the key to unlocking the full potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion, lies in the observance and implementation of existing Union legislation in our Member States, and I believe that better governance and greater transparency of its integration process are vital for job creation, sustainable growth and competitiveness in our influential single market.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The annual growth review, the first step of the European semester, highlights the additional measures that should be taken by Member States to support their growth and achieve the social and economic objectives of Europe 2020. This allows us to examine the state of the European economy and the single market. This report highlights the importance of the single market in the Process of the European Semester. The European Parliament reiterates the need to complement the single market in order to improve the competitiveness of the European economy. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the governance of the single market within the framework of the 2016 European Semester, on the basis of the following reasons: – the EU faces several challenges both globally and nationally, slow growth, high levels of unemployment and above all intense international competition; - the European Semester aims to increase the coordination of economic and budgetary policies across the EU to 28 Member States; - the priority is to increase stability, promote growth and employment and strengthen competitiveness. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that the single market is one of the founding elements of the Union and is the backbone of the economies of the Member States. I agree with the Commission's intention to continue its analysis of the country-specific investment challenges, within the framework of the European Semester.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which takes as its premise that the single market is the only way to deliver effectively on jobs, growth and competitiveness, in the framework of the European Semester. The report proposed creating a new ‘Single Market’ pillar in the European Semester to evaluate integration. As I am against the European Semester as a matter of political principle, I voted against this report to strengthen it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an initiative report and is not legislative. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I welcome the recommendations of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer protection for this year’s European Semester. I agree that the single market strategy should be included as one of the pillars of the European Semester. It is a very promising strategy aiming to fully explore the potential of the single market, and if properly implemented and focused on, it could be very beneficial, resulting in job creation and growth. Again, I express my regrets that the Services Directive has not been fully implemented by all Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are against economic governance so we voted against it.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I voted in favour of this report, I regret the adoption of paragraph 35 on the sharing economy in its current form. It should not be our role to try to force new industries to fit into the frameworks and rules of the traditional industries they replace. They have completely different business models, based on two different technological eras. As history has shown, it is futile to try to hold back progress with protectionism measures. Technological revolutions lead to more jobs and growth than they ever destroy. The times they are a-changing and the sooner we as legislators understand this, the better.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress that the single market is one of the foundations of the EU. In order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and stabilise the economies of the Member States, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its completion.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this report because I have always argued that the single market is a valuable resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the European Union depends and that its untapped potential represents both an opportunity and a wake-up call to ensure that the single market benefits everyone. I am convinced that macroeconomic and micro-economic policy coordination combined with the coordination of budgetary policies is needed to contribute to the desired structural economic growth in the EU Member States.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important for the European Parliament to act as the voice of the people even when it is not necessarily a question of legislating: for example, reports such as this one, in which Parliament fleas the European Commission with regard to decisions, reports and working hypotheses, which then have an impact on the lives of citizens. I welcome the work done by Mrs Stihler and voted in favour, agreeing with the approach and almost all the points that have been made.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Semester aims to coordinate the European Union's economic and budgetary policies in order to increase stability, promote economic growth and employment and strengthen competitiveness. It is impossible to decouple the Single Market from this exercise as it represents the backbone of the Member States and is a key tool for fostering growth, employment and competitiveness. I support the Stihler Report because it considers it vital to include the Single Market as a Pillar in the European Semester, notably through a system of regular monitoring and evaluation of single market integration and competitiveness. I would like to stress the particular attention that the implementation of existing legislation which is not complied with by Member States should be given to the removal of non-tariff barriers still in place in the market, as well as to the challenge of digitisation of the market, which creates a whole new paradigm for investors, businesses and consumers. Investment in the ICT sector is crucial if we want to have a competitive advantage. Creating a digital single market will change our lives and the way we interact by changing the behaviour patterns of consumers and economic operators. We must therefore unlock the untapped potential of the Single Market in this area.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the coordination of our macro- and micro-economic policies, together with the coordination of fiscal policy, in order to achieve better structural economic growth in the EU Member States. I also welcome the inclusion of an internal market pillar in the European Semester.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative non—binding report. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is a valuable resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the European Union depends. The untapped potential of the single market, worth an estimated eur 100 billion, is an opportunity to ensure that the single market benefits everyone. At present, there are excessive barriers to trade across the EU and many Member States do not implement the decisions they sign. The measures that have been taken so far to promote growth and job creation have yet to demonstrate their full potential. For this reason, I agree with the rapporteur and believe that better governance and greater transparency of processes, speeding up the path towards an efficient and integrated single market.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A greater choice of high-quality products and services and lower prices for consumers can be further enhanced through systematic monitoring of the implementation and enforcement of the single market rules by country-specific recommendations (CSRs). The issue of research and development (R&D) raised in this report indicates that only 17% of firm investment goes towards scientific R&D. Clearly we still lack the necessary drive by our policymakers to work on removing regulatory barriers as well as to facilitate increased investment in R&D.  I agree with the resolution seeking a speedy delivery and implementation of the digital strategy to ensure the EU regains lost ground in relation to the previously slow adoption and use of digital technologies.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is one of the pillars of the European Union and is one of its main achievements. During the European Semester, the main objective will be to concern the single market and the policies aimed at its completion, through the coordination of economic policies, the improvement of stability, the promotion of growth and employment. The resolution therefore aims at the immediate lifting of unjustified territorial restrictions known as geoblocks, as well as updating the European Standardisation System in order to support EU policies in favour of digital innovation, modernising public administration through the provision of better and more accessible digital services to citizens and businesses, and finally facilitating cross-border cooperation and interoperability of public administrations. I am voting in favour, as I consider the implementation and subsequent compliance with the rules of the single market to be fundamental.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The deepening of the single market at the stroke of recommendations in the European Semester will mean continuing the regression in social and democratic rights experienced in recent years by placing market pseudo-freedoms against labour rights and the sovereignty of European peoples. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is an important tool for promoting the EU's competitiveness and ensuring job creation and economic growth, and it is important to remove all obstacles to its achievement. The European Parliament resolution, which I voted in favour of, calls on the Commission to integrate the single market pillar into the European Semester. jobs.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market Governance Report is one of three parliamentary reports on the 2016 European Semester. The crisis has highlighted the need for Europe to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of the single market is not expanding. The UNION should support Member States in significantly increasing cross-border trade and take urgent action to make better use of digital technologies.  In order for the EU to be an engine for growth and jobs, the governance of the single market needs to be strengthened. This requires re-ingesting the highest level of political supervision, standardise the transposition and implementation of EU rules, and at the same time develop more effective tools to ensure that the single market really benefits citizens and businesses.  The most important thing to do now is to review the functioning of the single market in the context of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is necessary to look at where progress has been made and to map out the difficulties and to identify policy priorities on this basis. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In order to ensure the effective impact of EU tools on economic growth, job creation and competitiveness, progress in single market integration in Member States is regularly measured. This report highlights the better management and transparency of this process, as well as the strengthening of member states' ownership. In view of the effective implementation, application and enforcement of single market rules, more opportunities could be created for consumers in the long term, quality standards could be established and competition could be stimulated. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it restates the importance of the inclusion of a single market pillar in the European Semester process highlighting the significant contribution for jobs and growth that could derive from the effective completion of the Single Market. Such inclusion should encompass, among others, specific indicators and benchmarks related to the Single Market.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, and believe that many of the conclusions contained within it would improve the governance of the single market, which is in all Member States’ economic interest. The proposals for improvements to the way in which the Commission identifies and addresses gaps in the single market, and better enforcement to help ensure a level playing field are positive steps forward. I also welcome the references in the report to improving public procurement, and the efforts to address non-tariff barriers in a general sense – the subject of detailed scrutiny in my own report currently in progress. Deepening the single market will have enormous economic benefits to all our economies, but especially for SMEs and innovative start-ups. So, in conclusion, I hope the Commission will take on board the pro-competitiveness agenda and many of the positive ideas for improving the functioning of the single market contained within this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European model is, above all, a market-based social and economic system, in the sense that no computer in the world can process information better than the market, I believe that the Commission must draw up an annual report on existing barriers to the single market in different Member States and the European Union as a whole and issue recommendations , within the country-specific recommendations aimed at removing them, stressing that the Single Market should play a greater role in the country-specific recommendations.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's recommendations to the single market in the 2016 European Semester process, ahead of the European Council on 17-18 March. In this report, we call for further integration of the internal market, in order to remove non-tariff barriers to trade. The European semester, which aims to strengthen coordination between Member States' economic policies, should ensure better monitoring of the single market, so that it serves more growth, jobs and SMEs. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The single market is one of the cornerstones of European integration, the full potential of which must be harnessed in order to boost competitiveness but also to create jobs and growth within the European Union. That is why I supported this report, which highlights recommendations in the context of the European semester for better governance and greater transparency within the single market.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis of recent years has made it clear that the European institutions need to make a renewed effort to promote economic policies that can effectively summarise macroeconomic budgetary policies, such as those of the European Semester, and at the same time micro-economic policies to promote the single market.  In fact, it is clear to Europeans, but not yet to many in the European institutions, the direct link between macroeconomic deficit-surplus policies in the balance of payments in the Member States and competition policies between the Member States themselves. Therefore, the Commission's renewed focus on promoting investment policies to increase support for domestic demand will also have a positive effect on strengthening the European single market. At the same time, however, a stronger single market also means legislating intelligently so as to guarantee maximum consumer protection by promoting transparency in production processes.  Therefore, it is necessary to develop a regulatory framework around made-in in order to protect not only businesses and their value chain of excellence but also consumers so that they can be more aware in their purchasing decisions.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Single Market Governance Report is one of three parliamentary reports on the 2016 European Semester. The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of the single market is not expanding. The UNION should support Member States in significantly increasing cross-border trade and take urgent action to make better use of digital technologies. In my opinion, the governance of the single market needs to be strengthened in order for it to be an engine for growth and jobs in the Union. This requires re-ingesting the highest level of political supervision, standardise the transposition and implementation of EU rules, and at the same time develop more effective tools to ensure that the single market really benefits citizens and businesses.  The most important thing to do now is to review the functioning of the single market in the context of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is therefore necessary to look precisely at where progress has been made and to try to limit where difficulties remain. These should be the basis for identifying policy priorities.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report denounces protectionism as a threat to Europe, while a reasoned return to Europe would be more of a solution to our problems. In addition, the report calls for the creation of a body to monitor the enforcement of regulations, directives and recommendations by States, with sanctions in hand, as if Europe were all that was all that. Far from questioning the failures of the single market, the report echoes the usual argument that European economic integration is not sufficiently successful, particularly in terms of liberalisation of labour, capital or data. The report also discusses the integration of illegal immigrants and minorities and their access to the single market. In view of the weight of ideology in this report, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the Single Market Report under the European Semester 2016, as I believe that efforts should be made to improve the functioning of the single market. Better governance and more transparency are among the main outlined positives of this report.  Speaking of the Single Market, it should also be emphasised that the European Semester respects the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, one of the important areas for Member States.  However, there is also a need to strengthen existing mechanisms and tools to improve governance.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is one of the cornerstones of the European Union and forms the backbone of the economies of the Member States and the European integration project as a whole. There are a number of economic benefits of the single market, such as the integration of products and markets, economies of scale, increased competition and the level playing field enjoyed by 500 million citizens in the 28 Member States. However, I agree that a favourable framework for economic initiative and business development needs to be facilitated by encouraging competitiveness and cooperation between SMEs and thereby exploiting the industrial potential of innovation, research and technology. On the other hand, adapted and fair economic and social reforms need to be carried out and bureaucracy and protectionism to be tackled in order to improve the productivity and competitiveness of the European economy.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are facing another uncritical and simple exaltation of the Single Market, to which considerations are added on some of the most recent developments at the level of the said European Semester. The National Competitiveness Councils are one of the recent changes introduced in the European Semester. The Commission states that they should monitor competitiveness performance and policies in order to monitor and correct competitiveness differentials between Member States and thereby avoid "distortions" of the single market. Its real objective is to contain or force an even greater reduction in unit costs of wages, transferring productivity gains to capital, lowering the weight of wages in national income, that is, increasing the exploitation. They're one more piece in a structurally undemocratic building. The weak economic recovery – the result of so-called austerity policies – will be the excuse to impose even more austerity and the attack on rights. The Single Market has increased the dismantling of sovereign regulation instruments for economies, economic dominance, divergence and development asymmetries, promoted tax avoidance and profit transfer, privatisations, deregulation of trade relations and capital concentration. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States and the European Union have been facing periods of low growth, high levels of unemployment and increasingly aggressive global competition for some years. This European Semester must create opportunities for the single market, which is one of the pillars on which the EU is founded, to become an instrument of growth and competitiveness for the whole Union. I agree with the need for a series of actions aimed at improving governance and transparency processes, favouring the application and improvement of the current rules of the single market. Finally, I believe that the proposal to achieve the digital single market in the age of technological development is to be welcomed. Infrastructure, interoperability and standards at EU level are essential to enable a fair implementation of digital transformation across Europe, for the economic and social development of EU countries.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because the report makes no concrete statements.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the governance of the single market in the context of the European Semester 2016 as I do not agree with the new model of investment behaviour it presents. Everything about money, not about citizens, not about nations, not even about countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the importance of the inclusion of a single market pillar in the European Semester process highlighting the significant contribution for jobs and growth that could derive from the effective completion of the single market. I believe that such inclusion should encompass, among others, specific indicators and benchmarks related to the single market. A more coherent policy mix, focused on investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, along with stronger democratic accountability, are deemed essential within the European Semester.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the aim of enthusing the European Union to continue to work and improve on the integration and competitiveness of the single market, increasingly advancing and harnessing the full potential offered by the common market, and avoiding efficiency losses to the fullest.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that, in order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and act as a stabilising instrument for economies, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its full realization.  The single market is the cornerstone of the economies of the Member States and the European integration project, providing economic benefits such as greater competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in the EU, in particular greater opportunities for choice of quality products and services and lower prices.   As a socialist I believe that the key to unlocking the full potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion, lies in the observance and implementation of existing Union legislation in our Member States, and I believe that better governance and greater transparency of its integration process are vital for job creation, sustainable growth and competitiveness in our influential single market.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that, in order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and act as a stabilising instrument for economies, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its full realization. name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the governance of the single market under the 2016 European Semester, because I am convinced that the single market is a valuable resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the EU depends. The integration of the single market into the European Semester, as an instrument of coordination and monitoring, can promote job creation, growth and competition. However, these processes must be accompanied by better governance and greater transparency in the process. In order to exploit the untapped potential of the single market, estimated at 1,000 billion, and to enable it to benefit everyone, it is necessary to remove the many barriers to trade across the EU, increase the transparency of decision-making processes, improve governance and force Member States to implement the decisions they take. This will make it possible to avoid distortions which undermine free competition. Overcoming current weaknesses and creating new jobs requires a new paradigm in investment models, with increased investment in strategic sectors and business spending on intangible assets and appropriate implementation of the Services, Public Procurement and Concession Directives.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on Single Market Governance in the context of the 2016 European Semester. The aspect highlighted here is of central importance when we talk about a positive development of the European Semester and its guiding role for the further development of Europe.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Today's vote aims to strengthen The governance, transparency and accountability of Member States with regard to the Internal Market. The free internal market, as the Union's primary objective, is closely linked to the economic prosperity of the Union.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it succeeded in restating the importance of the inclusion of a single market pillar in the European Semester process highlighting the significant contribution for jobs and growth that could derive from the effective completion of the single market. A more coherent policy mix, focused on investments, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, along with stronger democratic accountability, are deemed essential within the European Semester.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an initiative report and is not legislative. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, since the report understands the single market as the only way to create work, growth and competitiveness and can also be done only under the framework of the European Semester. The European Semester and the report of the five presidents are a frontal attack on national and economic sovereignty — any tax reform or wage policy measure must be approved by national competitiveness committees, tools created for budgetary union — and represent an oligarchic and authoritarian institutional architecture with an absence of absolute democracy. I therefore reject any action within the framework of the European Semester and the report of the five presidents.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report in view of the importance of the Single Market and its impact on the current and future economic prosperity of the EU. The untapped potential of the Single Market is estimated at EUR 1 trillion, while being an opportunity and a wake-up call to ensure its functioning for the benefit of all. There is a need for cross-border development and job development in rural and poor areas, as well as the development of common competitiveness policies. The network of national competitiveness councils needs to increase its role with the common policies in this area. Public procurement and the public sector are important drivers, but we need transparency and ethical competition. SMEs must be at the attention of the governance of the Single Market within the European Semester and resources must be allocated at national and European level, particularly in rural areas. The European Parliament regulates, but the Commission and the Member States have an obligation to find the smartest methods of implementation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because the single market is key to growth and job creation in Europe. I and my colleagues from the ALDE Group are working intensively for a deeper single market within all policy areas.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As a group we voted against the whole package of the European Semester, since our opposition to it is a common position of the parties in our group. We also have a clear position on the reasons why the common market is being promoted by the dominant circles of the Union. These reasons are no more than market opening for large multinational groups, and their competition on a global scale. This, however, is to the detriment of workers and the interests of the people.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Single Market Governance Report within the European Semester. This report is one of two annual contributions from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection to the European Semester process. It focuses, in particular, on the Commission’s ‘Single Market for growth and jobs’ report accompanying the Annual Growth Survey and dealing with the state of the integration of the single market. The single market has brought tremendous benefits for European citizens and businesses, the free movement of goods, services and capital and is crucial to stimulating competition. However, in some areas there is no truly integrated European market as missing legislation, administrative obstacles, and a lack of enforcement leaves the full potential of the single market unexploited. This report outlines several proposals that reiterate the need for strong leadership from all the EU institutions and clear political ownership on the part of the Member States in order to achieve tangible improvements and a more stringent governance for the single market.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report due to the fact that it stresses that despite the lack of straightforward tariff barriers in the single market, a vast number of various non-tariff barriers do exist. The report also encourages the EU institutions, the Member States and all relevant stakeholders to launch a constructive debate on this issue in order to overcome the non-tariff obstacles within the EU. The single market is a precious resource which the European Union’s current and future economic prosperity depends upon.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative non-binding report. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report argues that the European Semester should also include the Single Market as a cornerstone of the EU and measures to complete it.  On the basis of highlighting the single market as the backbone of the economies of the Member States and the whole project of European integration, it is pointed out that its further development can unlock potential swaying investment and creating jobs. The Commission is therefore invited to implement systematic monitoring of the implementation and implementation of internal market rules through the country-specific recommendations. In order to improve productivity, competitiveness and entrepreneurial growth prospects, it also emphasises the need to tackle administrative burdens and protectionism more decisively, to improve the European standard system and to create improved interoperability. The new business models of the sharing economy are also to be welcomed, given their innovation potential. One danger, for example, is the proposal to include "all relevant stakeholders, including employers' and trade union organisations" in any procedures for reviewing the European Semester. The European Semester must meet objectively reasonable criteria and must not be charged ideologically. In view of the largely positive content from an economic point of view, I voted in favour of the report, but I will continue to pay attention to purely economic regulatory content. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative non—binding report. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft report was encouraging and I recognise that the rapporteur made an effort to include some input from my political group but, unfortunately, the right wing of Parliament forced a series of changes with unacceptable wording. I favoured amendments focused on the need to make the single market compatible with the localisation of economic activities, investments in the green economy, public authorities’ right to regulate in the public interest, and high social and environmental standards in public procurement. Whilst there are many elements in this report which I can support, on balance I consider that the right of this House has had too much influence and I could accordingly not endorse the final resolution.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Opinion with which I share the rapporteur's view that the coordination of micro and macroeconomic policies, together with that of fiscal policies, is necessary to generate the desired structural economic growth in the EU Member States.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The single market accounts for 500 million people and an estimated 23 million SMEs. I agree with the rapporteur that the slow pace of investment in the EU and the difficulties that SMEs encounter in accessing capital are critical barriers to growth and job creation in the European Union. The Commission’s Investment Plan for Europe and the European Fund for Strategic Investments are most welcome and ease access to funding for SMEs. Moreover, a wider range of financing options for SMEs is a priority of the capital markets union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the management of the single market in the European Semester in 2016, because I think the single market is essential for comprehensive growth and job creation across the European Union. The process of further integration of the single market must be accompanied by better governance and greater transparency.  It is also important to stress that the EU faces the challenge of digitalisation, and therefore it is important to direct investments towards the IT, research and development sectors in order to contribute to the competitiveness of the single market through concrete measures. There are still some barriers and barriers that need to be bridged in order to deepen the integration of the EU single market.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The total lack of questioning as a pragmatic analysis of the overall balance sheet of the single market renders the text abstruse. It must be rejected in its entirety and our position will hardly change as long as the European Union does not get rid of the dogmas parasitising the intelligence of its representatives. We are naturally opposed to the establishment of a single market governance body. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative non-binding report. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Catherine Stihler's report on the governance of the single market in the context of the 2016 European Semester. This report addresses issues such as micro-economic coordination and non-tariff barriers in the single market. It also recommends that the single market be addressed as a particular axis within the framework of the European Semester. The European Semester consists of coordinating the economic policies of states in order to converge more effectively towards growth objectives. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the European Semester, this report examines the needs and recommendations related to the single market. Particular attention is paid in this report to the improvement that could be made to non-tariff barriers and the obstacles they represent to the integration of the single market, or to the deepening of the Digital Single Market, for which I am particularly committed. The single market is an important source of prosperity, jobs and growth for our countries. It is therefore needed to be improved, as this report for which I voted for us proposes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to this report because it provides for more bureaucracy and administration in the context of the European Semester.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. To deliver effectively on jobs, growth and competitiveness, the progress of integration of the Member States in the single market must be accompanied by better governance and greater transparency, including the enforcement and implementation of existing EU legislation.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur argues that the European Semester should also include the Single Market as a cornerstone of the EU and measures to complete it.  The rapporteur emphasises the single market as the main pillar of the economies of the Member States and of the whole project of European integration. Its further development is intended to unlock potentials for attracting investment and job creation. The Commission is therefore invited to introduce systematic monitoring of the implementation and implementation of internal market rules through the country-specific recommendations. Excessive administrative burdens and protectionism should be tackled more decisively, the European standard system optimised and improved interoperability created.  In view of the largely positive content from an economic point of view, I voted in favour of the report, but I will continue to pay attention to purely economic lyrise.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The single market is a valuable resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the European Union depends. It is undeniable that job creation, growth and competitiveness are all objectives that must be accompanied by better governance. The report highlights the transformational effects of digitalisation on businesses and consumers. Only by understanding that the single market of the twenty-first century is very different from that of the past will we be able to find the right solutions to the current problems. This difference is due to the digital revolution which, if managed with foresight, will facilitate SMEs, contributing to an increase in employment and an increase in GDP. The digital single market is a point in the report with which I fully agree. There are still obstacles to its full completion, but we are ready to do everything in our power to remove them. In agreement with what has been said in this report, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the single market governance report in the context of the 2016 European Semester. This report is a summary of the European Union's poncifs. The subject falls within the religious domain: it refers to the threats to the single market, the first of which is "national selfishness" and the resurgence of nationalisms/populism/protectionism, etc. The only viable solution to Europe's suffering is, of course, the single market, through its digital component and through a supra-state governance body.  The text calls for harmonisation of national policies within the EU, with unlimited data sharing combined with a strengthening of the global free flow of data, workers, capital etc. The report stresses the need for the creation of a body to monitor the docile implementation of European directives and regulations as recommendations made to countries in the context of successive European semesters, with sanctions at the key in case of reluctance or slowness or even blocking the process.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report for two reasons. Firstly, because it calls for greater liberalisation of the workforce, which means that it would like to turn workers into stateless nomads who can be struck at mercy. Secondly, because he denounces the "national selfishness" and the rise of "populism" which may hinder the deepening of the sacrosanct single market, which he describes (it is believed to be!) a "notorious success".

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that, in order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and act as a stabilising instrument for economies, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its full realization.  The single market is the cornerstone of the economies of the Member States and the European integration project, providing economic benefits such as greater competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in the EU, in particular greater opportunities for choice of quality products and services and lower prices.   As a socialist I believe that the key to unlocking the full potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion, lies in the observance and implementation of existing Union legislation in our Member States, and I believe that better governance and greater transparency of its integration process are vital for job creation, sustainable growth and competitiveness in our influential single market.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it stresses that, in order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and act as a stabilising instrument for economies, it must also include the single market and policies aimed at its full realization.  The single market is the cornerstone of the economies of the Member States and the European integration project, providing economic benefits such as greater competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in the EU, in particular greater opportunities for choice of quality products and services and lower prices.   As a socialist I believe that the key to unlocking the full potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion, lies in the observance and implementation of existing Union legislation in our Member States, and I believe that better governance and greater transparency of its integration process are vital for job creation, sustainable growth and competitiveness in our influential single market.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The deepening of the single market at the stroke of recommendations in the European Semester will mean continuing the regression in social and democratic rights experienced in recent years by placing market 'freedoms' against labour rights and the sovereignty of European peoples. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur argues that the European Semester should also include the Single Market as a cornerstone of the EU and measures to complete it.  On the basis of highlighting the single market as the backbone of the economies of the Member States and the whole project of European integration, it is pointed out that its further development can unlock potential swaying investment and creating jobs. The Commission is therefore invited to implement systematic monitoring of the implementation and implementation of internal market rules through the country-specific recommendations. In order to improve productivity, competitiveness and entrepreneurial growth prospects, it also emphasises the need to tackle administrative burdens and protectionism more decisively, to improve the European standard system and to create improved interoperability. The new business models of the sharing economy are also to be welcomed, given their innovation potential. One danger, for example, is the proposal to include "all relevant stakeholders, including employers' and trade union organisations" in any procedures for reviewing the European Semester. The European Semester must meet objectively reasonable criteria and must not be charged ideologically. In view of the largely positive content from an economic point of view, I voted in favour of the report, but I will continue to pay attention to purely economic regulatory content.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The biggest challenges for managing the single market in the European Semester for 2016 are the coordination of different policies as well as the transposition of regulations into national legislation. Achieving a full single market will make it easier to address the many barriers faced by SMEs, especially in the segment of red tape at state and interstate level, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The single internal market without borders, ensuring the free movement of goods, services, capital and persons, is one of the strongest aspects of the Union with a positive impact on the economy of the Member States. Its effective functioning requires continuous monitoring and the adoption of measures to ensure its flexibility and high efficiency. I appreciate that the report also focuses on the untapped potential of the Single Market, which, in financial terms, amounts to more than EUR 1000 billion. Remedying this requires all 28 Member States to respect their commitments and coordinate their policies.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the governance of the single market in the context of the European Semester 2016, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/2/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. As with the two previous votes, this is one of the components of the European semester, an ideological tool in favour of ever more Europe and ever more uniform European policies. As with previous reports, the total lack of questioning and pragmatic analysis of the overall balance sheet of the single market gives an abstruse text that is conspicuous by its futility.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The IMCO report of which I am a member deals with the governance of the single market in the framework of the 2016 European Semester. In the long term, we are against how the European Semester project is currently set up. It focuses only on the competitiveness and benefits of the single market for economic growth and competition policy. Other important priorities, such as poverty reduction, combating unemployment and social exclusion, come second, if not completely ignored. The report also highlights the importance of developing e-government and highlights its shortcomings, such as the lack of protection of personal data, the problems that older citizens will experience with the system, etc. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Including the pillar of the Single Market in the European Semester Package will only legitimise, once again, measures promoting competitiveness in the labour market, low wages, easing redundancies, weak social protection and lowering tax rates for a more competitive and "productive" Single Market. This is not the path to sustainable and socially responsible growth – market freedoms cannot be ahead of labour and social rights.  I voted against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The single market is a key tool to boost EU competitiveness and generate jobs and growth. We must support this opportunity for all European citizens to benefit from the advantages of this unity. I support the report on the governance of the single market within the framework of the European Semester 2016, which contains important and very appropriate proposals to ensure that this objective is met.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite some progress made by Member States in simplifying national legislation in various areas to make them more consumer and business-friendly, there remain a series of obstacles to the integration and strengthening of the single market. The report on single market governance gives an overview of the most important challenges and measures facing them in this area.  Despite repeated calls in the European Council conclusions, the Annual Growth Surveys and the country-specific recommendations for strengthening the Single Market, little progress has been made so far on this issue. I agree with the provisions contained in the Report that, in order to make the single market more effective, Member States need to implement single market legislation more responsibly, ensure compliance and enforce the rules.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report proposes to include the single market and policies to complete it within the framework of the European semester, so that it can promote economic growth and stabilise the economies of the Member States. It would therefore be "the addition of a single market pillar in the European semester" allowing regular monitoring and evaluation of the integration and competitiveness of the single market. It thus lists the advantages that the single market is supposed to offer such as "product standardization" or "increased competition" which should allow for "lower prices". I remain opposed to both the European semester and the single market, which are only aimed at increasing the deregulation of the economy to the detriment of both workers and consumers. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU, true to itself, completely lacks pragmatism and questioning, one not going without the other. Until she decides to leave her oripeaux as a Manichaean preacher, our positions will have a hard time evolving. I disapprove of Europe's ideological policies that do not meet the needs of nations. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is a key instrument for promoting competitiveness, employment and growth in the European Union. The measures adopted within the single market have a privileged potential for promoting economic growth and should be widely considered in the discussion of the European Semester. I have presented my vote in agreement with this report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that increased transparency and better governance are necessary to ensure that the single market continues to increase employment within the European Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on single market governance within the European Semester 2016, because the EU can no longer rely on exports with the slowdown of the world economy. It needs to rely much more on internal demand and more private and public investment. Surplus countries need to expand their budgets in order to support investment and growth everywhere in the EU while deficit countries need to be allowed more fiscal space through the flexibility instrument to invest more.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection points out that the Single Market is a valuable resource with an untapped potential estimated at EUR 1 billion and therefore advocates the inclusion of the Single Market Pillar in the European Semester. It pays particular attention to the creation of a single digital market. Referring to the Commission's report referred to in point 7, it highlights the challenges of digital competition: emerging economies can now leave behind more advanced economies by using the latest technologies and purchasing products and services globally. It therefore urges an increase in investment in ICT, digital technologies and R&D. It also considers it essential to replace the necessary digital skills and training that are currently lacking as soon as possible, without which the Digital Single Market will never be fully created and which will enable EU citizens to adapt to the increasing digitisation of companies and industries. I supported the report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the governance of the single market within the framework of the European Semester is a set of technocratic and ideological recommendations. Firstly, the first threat to the single market presented in the report is national protectionism and the only solution is the strengthening of the single market. Secondly, the report states that it is essential to continue harmonizing national policies with the strengthening of free trade and the introduction of sanctions for reluctant countries. The report also calls for greater liberalisation of the workforce, whether interoperable, nomadic and calls for general recognition of skills. All this to complete the uniqueness of the market and the reduction of national disparities. We therefore reject this text, which is merely a dogmatic profession of faith in favour of the single market, the devastation of which is no longer to be demonstrated.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The total lack of questioning as a pragmatic analysis of the overall balance sheet of the single market makes the text futile. It must be rejected in its entirety, which is why I voted against it.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is a valuable resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the European Union depends. There are currently excessive barriers to trade across the EU and many Member States do not implement the decisions they sign. The influence of the European Union corresponds only to that of its constituent parts of the 28 Member States. I voted in favour of this report so that progress on the integration of the single market in the Member States is accompanied by better governance and greater transparency in the process, and this can be achieved by integrating the single market into the European Semester.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The single market refers to the European Union as one territory without any internal borders or other regulatory obstacles to the free movement of goods and services. It stimulates competition and trade, improves efficiency, raises quality and helps cut prices. I voted for this report that will include the single market in the 2016 European Semester, the European Union’s annual cycle of economic policy guidance and surveillance.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported a report highlighting the importance of a functioning internal market within the framework of responsible public finance management in the Member States. The report rightly points out that the Commission should present an annual report on barriers to the single market in individual Member States and in the EU as a whole and make recommendations aimed at removing these barriers as part of the country-specific recommendations. I also agree with the emphasis that closer cooperation and exchange of information and best practices should take place between national market surveillance authorities in order to effectively address the various forms of unfair competition in the single market, including the high number of illegal and non-compliant products, which cause high costs to law-adjouling undertakings and pose a high risk to consumers. In this context, I believe that the Council of the EU should speed up the adoption of a package of measures to ensure market safety and market surveillance, which threatens product safety in the EU.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report criticises the fact that there is a gap between the financing approaches for SMEs and the financing approaches for large enterprises and therefore a disadvantage. In addition to polite references, however, the report has no revealing nature, which is why I would have opposed it.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report on the European semester is oriented in a liberal way, giving as the final objective the only completion of the single market as the only guarantee of growth and employment in the EU. The text proposes coordination of micro-economic and macroeconomic policies, together with coordination of fiscal policies in order to achieve growth in Europe.  I voted against this report, which calls for the implementation of macroeconomic sanctions mechanisms, and the placing under the tutelage of Member States via the supervisory authorities and country-by-country recommendations.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. A larger single market is essential for Europe to promote economic growth and accelerate job creation.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's reports on the 'European Semester', the mechanism for imposing 'permanent memoranda' on all EU Member States, demonstrate the commitment of the political staff of monopolies to its objectives: measures to continuously reduce the price of labour everywhere in order to recover the profitability of business groups, to come the capitalist growth that has so far seemed anemic, uncertain and fragile.  That is why they require urban governments to implement the 'country-by-country recommendations', i.e. the unpopular measures drawn up by the EU institutions. In order to counter popular indignation, they attempt to dress up the whole process of six months and "enhanced economic governance" supposedly with "social aspects" and "social sensitivity", but they do not even manage to express wishful words, betraying their hostility to labour-popular rights.  The six-month period and all the procedures of the EU's 'permanent memorandums' cannot have a trace of a 'social aspect', because they were simply designed, implemented and serve a single plan to strike at every working, wage, social right of the working class and the poor working classes. There can be no euro-six months better, pro-populist, as various opportunists and new-cut social democrats are trying to deceive the people. The EU and the monopolies it serves only get worse. They're getting better than tipping.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an initiative report and is not legislative. UKIP has voted against this report as we are against further EU governance. We particularly oppose statements in this report that criticise national governments’ transposition of EU legislation. We have, however, voted in favour of Amendment 1 which, although far from perfect, removes the criticism that national regulations create barriers in the Single Market. Moreover, this amendment also removes calling on the Commission to do anything, which we fully support.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently facing a number of challenges both globally and nationally, such as slow growth, high levels of unemployment and, above all, intense international competition. That is why it is absolutely necessary to take all possible steps to promote its economy and its competitiveness.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – At the heart of Europe’s competitiveness, and its biggest economic strength, is the single market, which with 500 million persons gives the EU the opportunity to be a global economic force. The report on single market governance within the European Semester 2016 emphasises that Europe now faces a different kind of competition – a digital one. Instead of developing powerful industrial sectors locally, advanced economies could be established by adopting the latest technologies and sourcing products and services globally. During my mandate as an MEP I am fully supporting the digitalisation process of European industry and the opportunities a fully operational digital single market (DSM) could bring to the EU. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The report highlighted that the introduction of the single market hides huge potential, but unfortunately this potential has not yet been fully realised. I welcome the measures proposed in this report, which relate to the system of monitoring and regularly assessing progress in the field of single market integration, which should encourage Member States to implement single market laws more efficiently.
