I am convinced, and I agree with the rapporteur, that through a more successful integration of the single market, we will reach the desired structural economic growth more quickly, which is of particular importance for those Member States, such as Croatia, which are still struggling with the consequences of the economic crisis. I hope that by supporting the measures outlined in this report, we will send a clear message to the national authorities of all Member States how important it is to work more efficiently in connection with the integration of the single market for the future economic prosperity of the entire Union.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the governance of the single market is a summary of the European Union, I would even say dogmas as the subject has become a matter of religious belief among its promoters. He advocates an ever more uniform system, an ever-increasing disappearance of nations, and ever more savage liberalisation. It seems that reality no longer matters to the strong Europeanists. The single market is even described as a 'notorious success', which is sure to amaze the millions of poor and unemployed who are desperate to see growth return to Europe one day. It is obviously not possible for me to approve such an irrational text and I therefore vote against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is one of the eu's founding pillars and an opportunity for growth, employment and a level playing field for consumers in all Member States. The construction of the single market requires a continuous commitment and unanimous awareness of the significant benefits of its development. With a view to structural economic growth based on the coordination of macroeconomic and microeconomic policies associated with the coordination of budgetary policies, the integration of the Single Market Pillar into the European Semester would open up the opportunity for inclusive and strengthened governance. One of the most promising areas is the digital single market, which highlights new areas in which to operate, creates new investment opportunities and additional jobs, particularly for young people. I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the need to remove the remaining obstacles to the full implementation of the single market, the integration of which into the European Semester would encourage Member States to implement the decisions already signed and progressively simplify their national legislation, within the framework of an inclusive and non-discriminatory approach involving the full participation of the European Parliament. , which has always been a driving force in the relaunch of the single market.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Single Market is one of the cornerstones of the EU, forming the backbone of Member States' economies and the European integration project as a whole. I point out that it is the economic benefit that creates the single market, such as product standardisation and market integration, economies of scale, stronger competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in 28 Member States, which brings consumers primarily a greater choice of high-quality products and services and lower prices.  I welcome the fact that the Commission has simplified the new European Semester process and understands that the number of country-specific recommendations has decreased to adopt recommendations that focus more on country priorities. I regret the fact that there are serious shortcomings in several Member States as regards the implementation of the Services Directive, which covers activities accounting for more than 45 % of GDP and jobs in the EU, including due to a number of national rules and regulations that are not always in line with the public interest.  I emphasise that the public procurement market represents a large part of the entire single market and contributes significantly to the growth of entrepreneurship, employment and competitiveness in the Member States. I therefore welcome the Single Market Strategy, stating that various Actions of the Commission (Capital Markets Union, Digital Single Market, Energy Union, etc.) are focused on the main objective of harnessing the potential of the EU Single Market.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 As regards the single market, while prohibiting/limiting public control of strategic sectors of the economy, National Competitiveness Councils are established, deepening the institutionalisation of EU neoliberal policies. The National Competitiveness Councils are one of the recent changes introduced in the European Semester. The Commission states that they should monitor competitiveness performance and policies in order to monitor and correct the competitiveness misalignment between Member States and thereby avoid "distortions" of the single market. We know well, however, that its real objective is to control and impose fiscal measures and precariousness of work and wage devaluation. The weak economic recovery will be the excuse to impose more austerity and the attack on the rights of workers and peoples. They are simply intended to monitor the performance of budgetary executions and labour policies, deepening the undemocratic nature of economic governance. We are well known that mechanisms such as the single market have accentuated the dismantling of sovereign regulation instruments for economies, economic dominance, divergence and development asymmetries, and promoted tax avoidance and profit-sharing, privatisation, deregulation of trade relations and capital concentration. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I fully support my colleague Catherine Stihler's report on single market management in the European Semester 2016, the EU faces a number of challenges such as high unemployment rates, slow economic growth and strong international competition. In order to minimise the negative effects of these challenges, the EU is trying to increase stability, promote growth and jobs and strengthen competitiveness through the European Semester, which aims to better coordinate fiscal and economic policies in the 28 Member States, and strengthen competitiveness and the economy is of great importance for the future of the EU. When managing the single market, one of the cornerstones of the EU and the Union's greatest achievement, the importance of developing human capital must be mentioned by ensuring the availability of information and appropriate education in order to raise awareness and level of knowledge. Worryingly, information on public consultations is only available in one language in the vast majority of cases, resulting in not all interested parties being able to comment on important proposals and issues. Furthermore, the efficient management of the single market depends, inter alia, on incentives and clear responsibility for the implementation and application of laws related to the single market, and also favors competition and better regulation, which can lead to strengthening economic growth, increasing employment and competitiveness.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is a valuable resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the European Union depends. However, little progress has been made at the moment despite repeated calls for the single market to be strengthened in the Conclusions of the European Council. A report estimates that the completion of the single market would bring economic benefits of between €651 billion and €1,100 billion a year, or between 5% and 8.63% of EU GDP. Greater progress on the integration of the single market in the Member States should be accompanied by better governance and greater transparency in the process. This would allow the creation of jobs, growth and the competitiveness of the European single market. I believe, and i voted in favour of this, that this can be achieved by integrating the single market into the European Semester.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Progress in single market integration in Member States is measured regularly to ensure that it is effectively translated into growth, job creation and competitiveness. The report highlights the better management and transparency of this process, as well as the strengthening of member states' ownership My aim is to highlight the potential benefits of the single market, while drawing attention to unjustified barriers at national level. The report draws attention to the following points: the Single Market Pillar in the European Semester, which fully respects the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, and a set of analytical tools to better measure the economic and regulatory performance of the Single Market; the effective implementation, application and enforcement of single market rules and the need to further develop and strengthen existing mechanisms, tools and instruments to improve governance; action should be taken to ensure effective problem-solving at national level and, where possible, through informal measures, which could create more opportunities for consumers, lead to the establishment of quality standards and stimulate competition; coordination of single market priorities in the context of the European Semester should be rooted in a deeper democratic process involving the parliaments of the Member States. That is why I supported this report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – In order for the common market to effectively promote growth, employment and competitiveness, the degree of economic integration of the individual Member States is regularly recorded. In this context, the report calls for progress in the integration of the internal market in the Member States to be accompanied by better governance and greater transparency of the process in order to effectively boost job creation and achieve growth and competitiveness. A so-called internal market pillar should therefore be included in the European Semester, which, among other things, fully respects and does not violate the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, and creates a set of analytical tools that measure the economic performance of the common market in an appropriate manner. It also aims to strengthen the implementation of common market legislation and to address problems at national level as far as possible. By coordinating the measures implemented by the European Semester, national parliaments should be more involved, which would make implementation more democratic. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. This resolution, to which I have supported, is one of the three texts of the package adopted on the European semester. It focuses on the governance of the single market within the framework of the European Semester 2016. The European Semester, which aims, among other things, to contribute to convergence and stability in the Union but also to promote economic growth, should include within it the single market and policies to deepen it. Through which intermediary? We call for a single market pillar to be added to the European Semester. This pillar should include a regular monitoring system, identify the specific obstacles for each Member State, and assess the integration of the single market and its competitiveness. This system would be based on a solid database, performance comparison, peer review and best practice exchange. I would like to underline the economic and symbolic importance of the single market for the Union. Its full potential must be used, which will require improved governance and the assurance that the single market will integrate perfectly into the 21st century economy to become one of its drivers.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is a precious resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the EU depends.  The untapped potential of the single market, estimated at EUR 1 trillion, is an opportunity and a warning signal to ensure that the single market works for our benefit. There are currently too many barriers to trade in the EU and many Member States do not apply the decisions taken.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, adopted by 462 votes in support, 166 against and 7 abstentions, the European Parliament once again called for the inclusion of the single market pillar in the European semester, with a regular monitoring system, identification of country-specific single market barriers, and an assessment of its integration and competitiveness, with emphasis on the particular importance that should be given to growth and employment. , especially smes. Let us not forget that the single market is an indispensable resource on which Europe's economic prosperity depends. Its untapped potential is estimated at 1000 billion euros. In order to achieve real results in terms of employment, growth and competitiveness, progress in the area of single market integration within Member States must be accompanied by better governance and greater transparency, including the implementation and application of existing EU legislation.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support this report because it is weak enough and does not, in principle, propose measures that are actually working. The Greens' proposals for market surveillance, circular economy and fiscal coordination have not been taken into account and are not reflected in the final text. So to vote for a weak and incomplete report, in my opinion, it did not make sense.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Semester aims to effectively promote the coordination of economic and fiscal policies in the European Union and stimulate economic growth and employment, while intending to stabilise member states' economies. To do so, we must keep in mind the objective of achieving the single market – we must not forget that the single market is one of the cornerstones of the European Union.  The economic benefits of this are numerous, including the integration of products and markets, as well as the level playing field enjoyed by 500 million citizens in the 28 Member States, which provide more competitive prices, greater choice of products, a higher quality offer and therefore more beneficial conditions for consumers.  It therefore seems essential to me that it is essential to achieve the single market without delay in order to achieve structural and sustainable economic growth that captures and fosters investment, based on standards of transparency and efficiency, which stimulate job creation and increase the well-being of the citizens of the Member States.  In turn, through job creation it will also be possible to promote the development of the most disadvantaged regions, contributing to territorial cohesion.  In mind the points listed, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which points out that the single market is one of the EU's main successes and is, moreover, an essential means of creating jobs, boosting European growth and competitiveness. This resolution commits to the addition of a single market pillar in the European semester in order to establish regular monitoring of the integration of the single market and European competitiveness, but also to identify obstacles to the single market.  The text underlines the untapped potential of the single market, suggesting addressing the non-tariff barriers that remain within the EU. The aim is to ensure better application of the principle of mutual recognition, to modernise public administrations and to promote transparency. Finally, I supported this report because it calls for better governance of the single market and offers recommendations to develop its potential.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, since the report understands the single market as the only way to create work, growth and competitiveness and can also be done only under the framework of the European Semester. The European Semester and the report of the five presidents are a frontal attack on national and economic sovereignty — any tax reform or wage policy measure must be approved by national competitiveness committees, tools created for budgetary union — and represent an oligarchic and authoritarian institutional architecture with an absence of absolute democracy. I therefore reject any action within the framework of the European Semester and the report of the five presidents.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported My colleague Stihler's report on single market governance in the framework of the 2016 European Semester, as it is an important contribution to the debate on how to improve the functioning of the internal market. The report not only deals with the issue of the inclusion of the internal market in the European Semester and how to achieve better policy coordination, but also names a number of obstacles that consumers still face in the internal market – including geo-blocking, different delivery rules or the lack of harmonised rules on contracts and consumer protection, in particular for online shopping. I particularly welcome the fact that the report calls for the immediate abolition of unjustified territorial restrictions known as geo-blocking and thus an end to unjustified discrimination in access to goods and services, but also price discrimination based on geographical location or nationality. Any form of discrimination in the internal market is completely unacceptable to me.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The deepening of the single market at the stroke of recommendations in the European Semester will mean continuing the regression in social and democratic rights experienced in recent years by placing market pseudo-freedoms against labour rights and the sovereignty of European peoples. That's why I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the economic benefits of the single market and recognises the many barriers, including bureaucratic barriers, that hinder both domestic and international growth.  The report stresses the importance of integrating the single market into the European Semester in order to promote the EU's competitiveness, ensure job creation and economic growth, while respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. From this point of view, I believe that the proper participation of the national parliaments of the Member States is of fundamental importance in order to ensure not only transparency but also more democratic governance of the european semester review process.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The untapped potential of the single market is estimated at over EUR 1 trillion, and is an opportunity and a wake-up call to ensure that the single market can benefit us all. The single market has the potential to create jobs and growth for all, and this prospect has been identified at EU level. Despite all the work on this at national level, there has been little progress in the integration and exploitation of this potential resource. My colleague, Catherine Stihler, has done a tremendous job in addressing a lot of the major barriers to realising one of the EU’s biggest and valuable resources.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I support the idea of a single market, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution. I consider it necessary to help create an appropriate environment for economic initiative and business development. It is also important to promote competitiveness and cooperation between SMEs. The European Union must exploit the potential of industries in the fields of innovation, research and technology.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the Single Market to be the skeleton of the economies of the EU Member States and I am convinced that not only the eu's current but also future economic prosperity will depend on the single market. I am glad that the Single Market is currently one of the greatest achievements in Europe, but at the same time I regret that we are still not making use of the progress that has been made over the last 20 years, especially in view of increasing international competition. I appreciate that some progress has been made by the Member States in various areas, but I regret that there are still many outstanding issues that are taking further deepening and integrating the single market. This is evidenced by the statistical indicator, on the basis of which the untapped potential of the single market is estimated at EUR 1 trillion. I think that this is reason enough to look for ways to achieve even more effective results, especially in terms of jobs, growth and the EU's competitiveness. I supported the resolution because I believe that the proposed single market measures in the framework of the 2016 European Semester will help mobilise all possible means to improve the EU's economy and competitiveness.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Home to 500 million consumers and 21 million SMEs, the single market is not just one of the foundations of the EU, but in its current phase of development, one of the greatest achievements of our European Union. This is why I most welcome the adoption of this report identifying both improvements to its governance and avenues through which it could be better adapted to the realities and challenges of the 21st century. Seeing that today over 70% of all economic activity in the EU and a similar proportion of its employment are in services, I believe that this is the area which we should most concentrate on by establishing and better implementing and enforcing rules on fair and healthy competition. It is essential that these start with the freedom to provide services across borders, non-discrimination and territorial limitations, such as geo-blocking.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Semester aims to increase economic and fiscal policy coordination in all EU Member States with the aim of ensuring greater stability, promoting growth and employment and strengthening competitiveness. I believe that the single market is one of the cornerstones of the EU and is an essential instrument for improving growth, employment and competitiveness.  Current technological, social and behavioural changes have a significant impact on the behaviour of businesses and consumers and create a number of economic opportunities and challenges that need to be addressed within the single market.  The report highlights the role of the single market as an important tool in promoting the EU's competitiveness and job creation and growth. It also recalls the need to implement appropriate and fair economic reforms and to properly address bureaucracy and protectionism with a view to improving the productivity and competitiveness of the European economy.  I agree that in order to manage the single market more strongly at all levels and to be more accountable, the division of tasks at individual levels must be clearly defined. This would provide greater incentive and clearly defined responsibilities for the implementation and enforcement of single market legislation, thereby giving the single market a new impetus.  I believe that it is absolutely necessary to make use of all potential opportunities to stimulate the EU's economy and competitiveness. In view of the above, I supported the report on the implementation of the single market in the context of the 2016 European Semester.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur argues that the European Semester should also include the Single Market as a cornerstone of the EU and measures to complete it.  On the basis of highlighting the single market as the backbone of the economies of the Member States and the whole project of European integration, it is pointed out that its further development can unlock potential swaying investment and creating jobs. The Commission is therefore invited to implement systematic monitoring of the implementation and implementation of internal market rules through the country-specific recommendations. In order to improve productivity, competitiveness and entrepreneurial growth prospects, it also emphasises the need to tackle administrative burdens and protectionism more decisively, to improve the European standard system and to create improved interoperability. The new business models of the sharing economy are also to be welcomed, given their innovation potential. One danger, for example, is the proposal to include "all relevant stakeholders, including employers' and trade union organisations" in any procedures for reviewing the European Semester. The European Semester must meet objectively reasonable criteria and must not be charged ideologically. In view of the largely positive content from an economic point of view, I voted in favour of the report, but I will continue to pay attention to purely economic regulatory content.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the Single Market is the basic idea and pillar of the EU, which brings the most visible benefits to businesses and European citizens in European cooperation. However, despite the progress, work still needs to be done to improve it by removing existing barriers. A properly functioning single market is key to strengthening the EU's competitiveness.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Semester aims to better coordinate economic and fiscal policies in all 28 EU Member States in order to increase stability, promote growth and jobs and strengthen competitiveness. The Single Market is one of the cornerstones of the EU and one of the greatest achievements. For the European Semester to successfully boost economic growth and lead to the stabilisation of economies, it must equally cover the single market and policies aimed at its final establishment. The Single Market is the backbone of Member States' economies and european integration projects as a whole, including the economic benefits generated by the single market, such as product standardisation and market integration, economies of scale, stronger competition and a level playing field for 500 million consumers in the 28 Member States, which brings consumers primarily a greater choice of high-quality products and services and lower prices. I therefore support the fact that the Commission has simplified the new European Semester process and that the number of country-specific recommendations has decreased to adopt recommendations that focus more on country priorities. I welcome the Single Market Strategy, as various Actions of the Commission (Capital Markets Union, Digital Single Market, Energy Union, etc.) focus on the main objective of harnessing the potential of the EU Single Market.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Single Market Report is submitted annually as part of the European Semester. This is a report on initiatives necessary to create a single market, an important instrument for strengthening the competitiveness of the European Union, achieving growth and creating jobs. Stronger competitiveness, a level playing field, product standardisation and market integration are just some of the economic benefits generated by achieving the single market.  This gives consumers more choice and lower prices for high-quality products and services, allowing for cooperation between SMEs. Improving the single market will achieve structural and sustainable economic growth and increase investment in new jobs. I support the report and the instructions put out there, considering it necessary to create a favourable environment for the development of entrepreneurship, foster cooperation and competitiveness among SMEs and thus exploit the industrial potential of technological innovation and research.  I support the modernisement of the Professional Qualifications Recognition Directive, as the changes will facilitate the recognition of qualifications and facilitate the easier mobility of EU citizens. In particular, I welcome the call for the lifting of unjustified territorial restrictions, denial of access based on geographical location, which will prevent discrimination in access to goods and services and discrimination on grounds of nationality and geographical location.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report on single market governance in the context of the 2016 European Semester.  Following the financial and economic crisis, which has affected the Member States differently, we are facing low growth rates, high unemployment rates in some regions and strong international competition. The Aim of the European Semester is to ensure greater stability, promote growth and employment and strengthen competitiveness.  I support the report, which reiterates that the single market is one of the cornerstones of the EU, and stresses that, in order to successfully promote economic growth and stabilise the economies of the Member States, the European Semester must equally cover the single market and policies for the completion of the single market.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As an ESA/BPA, but also as an ACPL we voted against the whole package of the European Semester, since our opposition to it is a common position of the parties in our group. Also as ACPL we have a clear position on the reasons why the common market is being promoted by the dominant circles of the Union. These reasons are no more than market opening for large multinational groups, and their competition on a global scale. This, however, is to the detriment of workers and the interests of the people.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Aligning Member States' fiscal and economic policies with EU requirements imposes a continuous and deep recession on weak economic countries, while promoting the interests of powerful states. The operation of the European Semester leads to the absolute financial control of Greece so that it cannot implement a national economic policy for its exit from the crisis, but is constantly under the control of Germany and the other economically powerful countries.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the governance of the single market in the framework of the 2016 European Semester. I agree with the report's finding that the current and future economic recovery of the European Union depends on how we can exploit the untapped potential of the single market. The rapporteur rightly pointed out that these untapped opportunities also indicate that there are further problems ahead of the smooth functioning of the single market. I support the proposal that the Commission carry out regular monitoring of the implementation and enforcement of single market rules in the framework of country-specific recommendations. It is indeed worrying that the level of implementation of the European Semester recommendations for the period 2011-2014 did not meet expectations, so there is a need for a mechanism to encourage countries to implement country-specific recommendations. In addition, I welcome the fact that the report also addressed the importance of the digital single market and the sharing economy. Indeed, investment in digital technologies, R&D and digital readiness development is essential if the European Union is to maintain its competitiveness.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The European Semester, a procedure in which The Member States of the European Union coordinate their economic and budgetary policies, is based on three main pillars: boosting investment, structural reforms and increasing fiscal responsibility, which have been complemented by a new pillar – employment and social affairs. In my opinion, however, the European Semester cannot be judged in abstraction from the assessment of the state of governance of the European Single Market, which is a prerequisite for economic growth in Europe.  As rapporteur for the PPE Group report on the governance of the Single Market within the framework of the European Semester, I am pleased that the document adopted by the European Parliament includes proposals I supported, in particular on deregulation of business conditions, empowerment of SMEs, development of innovation, technological progress, the uptake of e-government, as well as the removal of non-tariff barriers and national protectionism.  These are just some of the conditions that must be met in order to unleash the entrepreneurial energy of the citizens of the Union. This, on the other hand, is needed in order to maintain the competitiveness of the European economy on the global market. This will also depend on the number of stable new jobs created and the future wealth of Community citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We firmly believe that easy access to information for businesses and consumers is a prerequisite for good governance of the single market. The work of the Commission and the Member States on a number of information portals for different users is recognised: businesses, citizens and consumers. We believe that a simple, user-friendly and accessible umbrella portal, such as the single digital portal, is necessary to streamline and simplify access to information and promote existing platforms for users, provided that national and regional governments make the portal accessible and publicly inform citizens about its use.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses on growth opportunities within the single market and calls for the single market to take a more prominent role in the European Semester. Indeed, the Single market governance report is one of two annual contributions from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) to the European Semester process. It focuses on growth opportunities within the single market and calls for the single market to take a more prominent role in the European Semester. The rapporteur managed to draft compromise amendments that covered most of the contentious issues, e.g. on implementation of country-specific recommendations, infringement procedures, professional qualifications, the sharing economy and public procurement. As a consequence, I decided to support it . The single market is key to growth and job creation in Europe and ALDE is committed to a deeper single market within all policy areas.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report highlighting the need for better governance and greater transparency of the single market integration process into Member States, as I believe it respects the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. I also agree with the recognised need to effectively implement, implement and strengthen single market laws, and I believe that further development and strengthening of existing mechanisms, tools and instruments is necessary to strengthen governance.  Given the demonstrated willingness to take all the steps necessary to effectively address possible problems primarily at Member State levels and to involve national parliaments in coordinating single market priorities, I voted to adopt a single market management report in the European Semester in 2016.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on single market governance in the context of the 2016 European Semester, as the inclusion of the Single Market Pillar in the European Semester could make visible progress in job creation, growth and competitiveness.  The Single Market is a valuable asset on which the current and future economic prosperity of the European Union depends. Its untapped potential, which is estimated to be EUR 1 trillion, is both an opportunity and an incentive for the single market to work for the benefit of all of us.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against it, since the report understands the single market as the only way to create work, growth and competitiveness and can also be done only under the framework of the European Semester. The European Semester and the report of the five presidents are a frontal attack on national and economic sovereignty — any tax reform or wage policy measure must be approved by national competitiveness committees, tools created for budgetary union — and represent an oligarchic and authoritarian institutional architecture with an absence of absolute democracy. I therefore reject any action within the framework of the European Semester and the report of the five presidents.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur argues that the European Semester should also include the Single Market as a cornerstone of the EU and measures to complete it.  On the basis of highlighting the single market as the backbone of the economies of the Member States and the whole project of European integration, it is pointed out that its further development can unlock potential swaying investment and creating jobs. The Commission is therefore invited to implement systematic monitoring of the implementation and implementation of internal market rules through the country-specific recommendations. In order to improve productivity, competitiveness and entrepreneurial growth prospects, it also emphasises the need to tackle administrative burdens and protectionism more decisively, to improve the European standard system and to create improved interoperability. The new business models of the sharing economy are also to be welcomed, given their innovation potential. One danger, for example, is the proposal to include "all relevant stakeholders, including employers' and trade union organisations" in any procedures for reviewing the European Semester. The European Semester must meet objectively reasonable criteria and must not be charged ideologically. In view of the largely positive content from an economic point of view, I voted in favour of the report, but I will continue to pay attention to purely economic regulatory content.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report. It is fundamental that Europe keeps deepening the single market in order to achieve a higher level of private investment that can create more sustainable economic growth in the medium term.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the governance of the single market is a summary of the European Union's poncifs. The subject falls within the religious domain: - The state of the situation of threats to the single market, the first of which is national selfishness; - The need for harmonisation of national policies within the EU with unlimited data sharing combined with increased global free movement. The report also calls for greater liberalisation of the workforce, whether interoperable, nomadic and calls for general recognition of skills. Completing the single market would therefore make a profit of 1 trillion euros, a nugget that emerged from the lenient study on the "cost of non-Europe". The total lack of questioning as a pragmatic analysis of the overall balance sheet of the single market makes the text abstruse. It must be rejected in its entirety and our position will hardly change as long as the European Union does not get rid of the dogmas parasitizing the intelligence of its representatives. I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The single market is one of the foundations of the EU. In order for the European Semester to successfully promote economic growth and stabilise member states' economies, it must equally embrace the single market and policies that are trying to achieve its full implementation. In our view, the final form of the report still does not sufficiently represent left-wing expectations and does not always carry forward the results that our group has already achieved successfully. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because important elements on market surveillance, the circular economy and fiscal coordination are not properly reflected or even absent. Even worse, one of the paragraphs calls for deregulation as a means to successfully achieve effective single market governance.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I believe that the single market needs to be strengthened, more interconnected and sufficient staff to provide market surveillance authorities to meet today's challenges, especially those arising from global competition; urges national market surveillance authorities to cooperate more closely and exchange information and best practices in order to effectively address various forms of unfair competition in the Single Market, including the large number of illegal and non-compliant products, which incur high costs for qualifying companies and face significant risks for consumers, especially the most vulnerable.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the single market governance within the European Semester 2016 report. The report highlights the need for the integration of European markets into a single market, with a system for regular monitoring, identification of country-specific barriers to such a market, and an evaluation of its integration and competitiveness. It also stresses the unexploited potential of an EU single market, which will effectively deliver jobs, growth and competitiveness, widely recognised as priorities at EU level. The report equally suggests that the process of integration must be accompanied by improved governance, greater transparency and easier access to information, and systematic implementation of existing EU legislation. I voted in favour of the report as it puts as priorities higher employment and growth and a special focus on SMEs, stating that these can be achieved through further market integration, while specifying the procedural mechanisms that need to accompany the process.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a document that highlights a number of initiatives aimed at improving the functioning of the internal market in goods and services. The Commission's proposal has been the subject of amendments which have been to clarify certain microeconomic coordinations and to strengthen the text. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted in favour of the report on the policy of the internal market within the European semester 2016. The report focuses on key benefits of the single market for both consumers and businesses. The single market contributes to job creation and growth. Consumers can enjoy a wider choice of quality products and services at lower prices, and businesses benefit from access to a larger market. The N-VA believes that strong efforts should be made to address existing barriers in the Member States, which hinder the efficient functioning of the internal market. This is sufficiently reflected in the report, with special attention also paid to SMEs. Finally, we are very pleased with the emphasis in the report on better regulation, first and foremost looking at the effective application and enforcement of existing rules and instruments, before creating new rules.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. Although employment in Europe has improved slightly, it is necessary to implement more reforms in the labour market if we are to see a greater fall in unemployment in the long term. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The growth outlook for 2016 represents the starting point of a process to which we firmly oppose it. The European Semester and economic governance are at the heart of a neoliberal strategy for national states' fiscal policies.  The guidelines contained in the report, which should be respected by governments, insist on the same revenue that soed poverty and unemployment across Europe, in practice preventing any alternative strategies to address the crisis, with growth-stimulating policies based on public investment and increased aggregate demand. There are no cosmetic maneuvers, whether from a social point of view or through the greater involvement of this House, which erase the deeply undemocratic nature of economic and monetary union, which imposes, in the interests of the people and workers, its neoliberal policies of concentration of wealth. We remain convinced that only the end of EMU and the euro can pave the way for alternative development policies, focusing on people's well-being rather than the accumulation of profits.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The development of the internal market is to be supported, but the European Semester is included in all matters. Furthermore, the report supports the Commission's various actions on the internal market strategy, such as the Energy Union, The Capital Union, etc., which I cannot support, which is why I voted against.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained on the European Parliament's resolution on single market governance within the European Semester 2016. I am fundamentally opposed to the economic governance of the EU and the euro area through the European Semester. On the contrary, the Member States should pursue their own economic policies and thereby enter into competition with each other. A coordinated economic policy is only needed if the intention is to establish or maintain transfer mechanisms between Member States. The rapporteur has made every effort to limit her report to actual measures that really promote the internal market and competition, without too often expressing the desire for centralised coordination. I would like to support this approach by abstaining rather than rejecting the report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The single market remains a central element and a major driver of the European Union's economy. I agree with the rapporteur's position that, despite the progress made since the single market was created, its growth potential has not yet been fully exploited. One of the key needs in managing the Single Market is to carry out tailored economic and social reforms, to address excessive bureaucracy and protectionism in order to improve the productivity and competitiveness of the EU economy. It would therefore be justified to include the Single Market Pillar as the next pillar of the European Semester.  This pillar would be seen as a system responsible for regularly monitoring and evaluating single market integration and competitiveness. The single market of the 21st century is radically different from that of the 20th century. These changes are largely due to the digital revolution. To this end, appropriate measures should be taken to bridge the gaps. In line with the rapporteur's opinion, I am convinced that easy access to information for businesses and consumers is a prerequisite for good governance of the Single Market. I appreciate both the work of the Commission and the Member States on a number of information portals for different users. A simple, user-friendly portal is needed to improve and simplify access to information and to promote an existing platform, provided that national and local authorities make such a gateway available and publicly inform citizens about their use of it.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise the enormous importance of the European single market in the 21st century, particularly in the field of digital and ICT technologies. As the digital single market is expanded, the EU must also ensure inclusive access to the internet and other technologies, and promote a high degree of digital literacy, ICT education and life-long learning. Particularly, it must strive for the inclusion of women and girls in fields of ICT, STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and maths) and entrepreneurship. Likewise, the EU must ensure that internet rights and freedoms are upheld, with a balance between freedom of expression, privacy and online safety.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on the governance of the single market in the 2016 European Semester. According to the rapporteur, the Single Market is a precious resource on which the current and future economic prosperity of the EU depends, with the untapped potential of the Single Market estimated at EUR 1 trillion. I agree with her opinion that there are too many trade barriers within the EU, and many Member States do not implement the decisions to which there are signatories. The report also states that coordination of macro and microeconomic policies, accompanied by coordination of fiscal policies, is needed to ensure the desired structural economic growth in EU Member States.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's reports on the 'European Semester', the mechanism for imposing 'permanent memoranda' on all EU Member States, demonstrate the commitment of the political staff of monopolies to its objectives: measures to continuously reduce the price of labour everywhere in order to recover the profitability of business groups, to come the capitalist growth that has so far seemed anemic, uncertain and fragile.  That is why they require urban governments to implement the 'country-by-country recommendations', i.e. the unpopular measures drawn up by the EU institutions. In order to counter popular indignation, they attempt to dress up the whole process of six months and "enhanced economic governance" supposedly with "social aspects" and "social sensitivity", but they do not even manage to express wishful words, betraying their hostility to labour-popular rights.  The six-month period and all the procedures of the EU's 'permanent memorandums' cannot have a trace of a 'social aspect', because they were simply designed, implemented and serve a single plan to strike at every working, wage, social right of the working class and the poor working classes. There can be no euro-six months better, pro-populist, as various opportunists and new-cut social democrats are trying to deceive the people. The EU and the monopolies it serves only get worse. They're getting better than tipping.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, if the European Semester is to promote economic growth and stabilise the EU's economies, it must also include the single market and policies supporting its completion. It is the European Semester that aims to increase the coordination of member states' fiscal and economic policies, which will boost employment growth and boost competitiveness. It is more than desirable that trade barriers be removed while ensuring that all 28 EU Member States comply with existing legislation. Furthermore, there is a need for regular monitoring and evaluation of progress on single market integration.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is difficult to disagree with the report's statement that the single market is one of the pillars of the European Union. In addition to the free movement of persons, it is in this area that the success of European integration is most evident, although there are still shortcomings and the use of non-tariff barriers. The idea of the European Semester seems to be an ideal tool to address these problems and to better coordinate national policies in order to strengthen the principle of free movement of goods. The fact that the potential of this tool has not yet been exploited to strengthen the foundations of the single market is a major omission on the part of the Commission, and I support the call in this report to change this. We face many challenges that are linked to the effects of the digital revolution on the European economy. Today, the single market is not only a traditional trade in goods, but also a question of free access to the services market, with great potential for e-commerce or the emergence of new business models, such as the model of the collaborative economy. All these challenges of the present day have not had their counterparts in the past at the design stage of the current shape of the single market, and we must find a place for them within all four freedoms. I believe that the potential of the European Semester can be effectively exploited in overcoming barriers to europe's further economic integration, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the governance of the Single Market in the framework of the 2016 European Semester from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, whose rapporteur was MEP Catherine Stihler, mainly because it is stated that the digital single market strategy should be rapidly presented and implemented to ensure that the EU regains the ground lost in relation to the slow adoption and use of , in the past, of digital technologies; also agrees with the reference to the allocation of EU and national funds in order to provide the necessary infrastructure, in particular in rural areas; and finally, noting that it is equally important to support digital innovation and improved interoperability and that particular attention needs to be paid to cybersecurity issues.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The proper functioning of the single market and the effective implementation of single market legislation are important in achieving structural and sustainable economic growth.  I supported the report on the governance of the single market in the context of the European Semester because it recognises the current challenges and proposes, in my opinion, reasoned recommendations to maintain the competitiveness of the European internal market on a global scale.  Decisive action must be taken to ensure that the European Union's future single market policy delivers tangible results and responds to the needs of citizens.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Another section in my dictionary, free trade. What does free trade mean? This means that, in the spirit of free competition, wages in both countries concerned are pushed down and down so that prices, such as agricultural buying-in prices, are lower and lower. Let the little ones, the smallholders, the family farmers, the family entrepreneurs, the small business owners, the micro-entrepreneurs go broke. It also means, for example, what is completely illogical for a 5-year-old child is that we transport food and food from one end of the world to the other, instead of providing locally produced food there, locally, in that country, both to provide a livelihood for rural people and, on the other hand, to provide healthy, high-quality food to the local population, without chemical treatments related to various transport-related treatments.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr It has been a purely historic Europe and Tunisia: their relations have always been a very active regime, and in recent years it has only intensified because of the changed regime in this North African country. And our European Union is Tunisia's primary economic partner, especially in the trade in agricultural products, and this cooperation will only strengthen every year. So it is time to take another step in our relations, to intensify negotiations on the potential conclusion of a free trade agreement. This is particularly logical given that a meeting of the EU-Tunisia Association Council was held on 17 March last year and an action plan on the creation of a privileged partnership was adopted. And our community's efforts to develop relations with the EU-Mediterranean partnership region, I hope, will culminate in success. So I support it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna moltaí go léir anseo agus d’éirigh leis le móramh mór: 479 i bhfabhar agus 123 i gcoinne. Dar ndóigh, le blianta beaga anuas tá a lán margaí mar seo, comhréitigh leis na tíortha éagsúla á bplé againn agus á gcur ar an bhfód againn. Dar ndóigh, is ceart go ndéanfaimid ceann leis an Túinéis comh maith.  Ní dóigh liom go mbeidh an ceann seo chomh conspóideach le cuid de na cinn eile, go háirithe TTIP, mar a bhfuil a lán gearán agus conspóide faoi; ach cífimid cad a tharlóidh. Maidir leis an Túinéis, is ceart bualadh ar aghaidh leis. Ach mar a dúirt an Feisire Morvai, caithfimid a bheith cúramach freisin nach gcuirfimid isteach ar ár bhfeirmeoirí anseo san Eoraip chun comhréiteach a dhéanamh le haon tír eile.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the recommendation in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia since the conviction that such agreements entail liberalization not only of trade in agricultural products, but also of services, affecting basic social rights. The European Union has also refused to promote an international audit of the odious debt acquired by Ben Ali's regime, which the Tunisian people continue to assume today. Moreover, the negotiation of this agreement does not take into account asymmetry and does not have the participation of Tunisian social organizations and trade unions. Therefore, since the conviction that such an agreement only favours large companies, with a negative impact on workers and small producers on both sides, both Tunisian olive oil producers and those in southern European countries, I voted against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution on the negotiations of an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement, which welcomes the opening of the negotiations.  The text defends the idea that Tunisia should be helped in order to ensure stability and economic dynamism. Although he says that we must be careful about the sensitive agricultural sectors, promises never kept, this agreement puts our farmers in difficulty with strong unfair competition but also the employees and industrialists who will have to deal with the relocation of industrial and service companies.  These negotiations for a free trade agreement with Tunisia represent the jeopardy of European workers.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 In October 2015 the European Commission opened negotiations with Tunisia on the signing of a Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement. The agreement could create opportunities for both sides.  As a Socialist Group we are asking the Commission to ensure transitional periods, transparency during the negotiations and to improve social conditions in the country.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this resolution, Parliament is in favour of opening negotiations on an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement. Even though I am not against free trade per se, it is difficult for me to form an informed opinion on the opening of negotiations without having seen a mandate from the Council of the European Union in this regard. Although Parliament is not involved in the drafting of such a mandate – which I very much regret – and these negotiating mandates have so far only been made freely available under public pressure, I believe that it is only possible to express an opinion on the appropriateness of free trade agreements if these negotiating guidelines have been examined. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the opening in October 2015 of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement. The text repeatedly returns to the fact that Tunisia, which is an example for the region, must be helped, that it is necessary to ensure its stability and the dynamism of its economy. This resolution calls on the Commission to facilitate the granting of "Move IV" visas, calls for a chapter on investment, calls for the opening of public procurement and to be cautious on sensitive agricultural sectors. This text forgets that such a free trade agreement risks endangering our economy, for example by causing a situation of unfair competition for European farmers, employees and industrialists and relocations of industrial and service companies. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to confirm in the interest of transparency that I voted against this report as a whole. I believe in free trade but I do not trust the European Union to negotiate this trade agreement in the best interests of the United Kingdom. The UK taxpayer has already contributed towards a EUR 300 million loan to Tunisia to help keep its economy afloat. In a few weeks’ time, when the UK votes to leave the European Union, the UK Government will be able to start its own negotiations for free trade with Tunisia.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the opening of negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement. Relations between the EU and Tunisia are close and very old, as the EU is Tunisia's largest trading partner and Tunisia is the EU's 34th partner. This new partnership will open up opportunities for growth and economic convergence between Tunisia and the EU. This partnership should also contribute to tunisia's political and democratic stabilisation, its economic recovery, while also having a positive impact on consumer prices and employment. I support the calls for negotiators to conclude an agreement that takes into account important economic differences between the two countries, be flexible in these negotiations, demonstrate the ability to react quickly, and bear in mind that this agreement should benefit the economy and society of Tunisia and the European Union. The Commission should ensure that these negotiations bring concrete benefits quickly to key sectors of the EU and Tunisia economies, as well as to relevant stakeholders, in particular micro, small and medium-sized enterprises. At the same time, the agreement should contribute to the development and diversification of tunisia's economy, which currently focuses on agriculture, reduce regional disparities and must bring concrete benefits to all tunisian and European citizens.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution welcomes the opening of free trade negotiations between the European Union and Tunisia on 13 October 2015. The aim is to help Tunisia, which is seen as an example for the region: stability must be ensured by encouraging the dynamism of its economy. In particular, this resolution calls on the Commission to facilitate the granting of "Move IV" visas, but seems unserious about the negative consequences that this free trade agreement would have on our economies, which are already in great difficulty. That is why I opposed it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report which endorses the opening of negotiations to conclude a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. The latter has been hit hard by the terrorist attacks that have taken place on its soil in recent months. It is therefore more than necessary to stabilize the country politically and economically and to consolidate its democracy. This free trade agreement must contribute to this by being both progressive and asymmetrical and aiming to have a positive impact on consumer prices, employment, wages and the reduction of inequality.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is Tunisia's main trading partner and has had trade relations with the country on the southern shore of the Mediterranean since 1969. The cradle of the Arab Spring, Tunisia is also the only country that, after the 2011 protests, embarked on a stable path of democratic transition, manifested in the approval of the new constitution of 26 January 2014. The opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement is, in this context, an attempt to strengthen ties between Europe and Tunisia, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution. Political stability and economic development are two inseparable elements which, by mutually reinforcing each other, can guarantee Tunisia resistance to the instability that characterises the entire regional context, be it the complex situation in Libya or the Algerian case. The agreement must commit itself to promoting growth, employment and lower prices, taking due account of the existence of agricultural sectors requiring special protection and in respect of which action will also have to be taken by providing for transitional mechanisms, quotas and exclusions in order to protect producers on both sides.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. Empirical experience shows that there is a good chance of promoting social imbalances in a country whose situation is already sensitive.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this motion for a Resolution on the opening of negotiations on the EU-Tunisia free trade agreement. It begins by strongly condemning the terrorist attacks in that country in recent months and referencing that the Tunisian economy faces significant difficulties. There is also an obvious demographic and economic imbalance between the Union and Tunisia justifying the adoption of an asymmetrical and progressive strategy in the negotiations.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have taken a stand against this resolution on the opening of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement. While I believe that Tunisia should be a strategic partner, especially for France because of the historical ties between our two countries, I do not consider free trade agreements to be an adequate tool for economic prosperity. All the more so since this kind of agreement risks jeopardizing our industries, and in particular our agricultural sector, which is already in very bad shape and which could be subject to unfair competition from Tunisian production at a lower cost. The resolution highlights the economic and social benefits that Tunisia could derive from such an agreement but what do the Member States get out of it? It is not certain that opening our public markets to Tunisian companies is beneficial to our own economies. Finally, I consider that using visa liberalisation for Tunisians as a carrot to supposedly advance human rights is a real economic and political blackmail against a partner who deserves more respect than that.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with this report calling for free trade negotiations between Europe and Tunisia. I believe that such a negotiation would do enormous damage both to the Italian agricultural production system, which would be fighting against competition not burdened by expensive European standards, and to European citizens who would find products on the market that do not comply with the same phytosanitary standards as those grown in the EU. For all these reasons, I did not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement. The motion for a resolution deals with the opening of negotiations on a comprehensive trade agreement with Tunisia. The country is in serious economic trouble following the terrorist attacks in Sousse, which basically stopped all tourism. Trade with Tunisia is therefore positive. However, the proposed agreement will cover, inter alia, services, public procurement and agriculture, and may benefit EU businesses rather than tunisia's economy. That is the wrong direction of economic policy. I want to see an economic policy that focuses on debt cancellation for Tunisia, because it is a better way to support the country's economy, both short-term and long-term – an economy based on solidarity and not on free trade.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution, in which the European Parliament strongly condemns the terrorist attacks in Tunisia in recent months that have resulted in a huge number of casualties. Parliament notes that Tunisia's democratic transition process has been the most successful in the region and that it has chosen a unique political and economic model among the Southern Mediterranean countries, and asks the European Commission to take this fully into account in the negotiations. In addition, the European Parliament considers that this agreement covers not only the trade dimension, but also that it must necessarily aim to contribute to stability in Tunisia, to strengthening its democracy and to revitalise its economy, while having a positive impact on both consumer prices and employment, and on the wages of skilled and unskilled workers, and by reducing disparities. Parliament actively calls on the Commission and the Tunisian Government to establish a clear and precise process for the participation of Tunisian and EU civil society at all stages of the negotiations and to use innovative ways. Welcomes also the role of Tunisian civil society in the first phase of the negotiations and calls for consultations to be open, transparent and to take greater account of the different sections of Tunisian civil society, in line with best practices identified in other similar negotiations.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-Tunisia free trade negotiations began in autumn 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. At the same time, I stressed the need to pay particular attention to the interests of the European Union in the Member States, in particular agricultural products, during the negotiations. There cannot be a situation where the competitiveness of producers within the UNION is disadvantaged. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report by expressing my final opinion in the light of the text of the negotiated treaty.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Tunisia's economy has been in serious trouble, politically unstable surroundings and refugees from neighbouring, war zones have been hit hard by this otherwise prosperous African country, which has long been a model for a successful transition to democratisation in the region.  For Tunisia, the EU is the most important trading partner, trying to reform the economic sector, opening up their economy to the West. The possibility of signing a free trade agreement in the future would allow Tunisia to reduce the huge disparities between the urban environment and the countryside. At the same time, it will be an opportunity for all their micro and small businesses to access new markets.  By supporting the opening of negotiations, MEPs have also set out an example that developing countries that play by economic rules are trying to make a breakthrough and actively reform their economies, and consequently they have better opportunities and conditions for cooperation and trade with EU countries.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This text echoes the idea that we must help our Tunisian neighbour, an example for the region, but forgets that we must not create economic difficulties for our peoples. Other methods of aid that deep free trade treaties could have been explored. This agreement risks creating unfair competition for European farmers, employees and industrialists with relocations of industrial and service companies (e.g. the European Union automotive sector). I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The provision of economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with third countries. This has often produced positive results for citizens on both sides and increased the range of influence of soft power in the European Union.  Tunisia is today one of the few (or perhaps the only) Arab country in which the so-called 'Arab Spring' has landed in a modern democracy, which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law. A friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop under appropriate conditions, gradually, and gradually to become part of the common free trade area.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution welcomes the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. This agreement aims to help Tunisia to ensure its political stability by contributing to its economic dynamism. The Commission is therefore asked to facilitate the granting of visas and to open public procurement to Tunisian companies, in return for respect for human rights. While it is essential to ensure political stability in North Africa as well as in the Near and Middle East, notably by fighting against the rise of Islamic fundamentalism, we challenge the idea of achieving this through trade liberalization. This agreement poses a danger to our economies, especially our agriculture, which is already severely weakened by falling commodity prices.  That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since October 2015, the European Union and Tunisia have started negotiations for a new, more ambitious free trade agreement, an agreement based on the mandate adopted on 14 December 2011 unanimously by the European Union states, and the first rounds of negotiations began between 19 and 22 October 2015. The main arguments for the implementation of the new contract are the history of cooperation between the European Union and Tunisia, which dates back to 1969, with Tunisia being the first country on the southern shoreof of the Mediterranean to sign an association agreement with the European Union in 1995. The establishment of a new trade treaty between the European Union and Tunisia should open up prospects for economic growth and, last but not least, for rapprochement for the economies of both parties, as this partnership must come to Tunisia's aid in achieving both political and demographic stability. I voted and I support this report on the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia because I believe that this agreement is beneficial for both the European Union and Tunisia, economically, politically and demographically.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. This resolution is based on the same theme as the measure granting trade preferences to Tunisian oil.  The problems are well known and very similar to those for which we opposed the agreement with Morocco. Italian agricultural products, especially those in the South, would be subject to competition from producers who are not bound by expensive European standards and are unable to guarantee the same phytosanitary standards. Not only that, several observers of the North African reality say that, by now, many of Tunisia's great agricultural producers are nothing more than foreign investors, often European.
