Furthermore, our delegation does not agree that the issue of tunisia's economic crisis can be dealt with by means of trade concessions, which would only be paid for by certain producers in certain Member States and which would not, in return, see opportunities for access to the market for Italian companies of a certain interest. Finally, it is dangerous to combine trade with more sensitive issues such as the call for greater visa liberalisation. That would be an absolutely wrong and dangerous approach.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Tunisia and the European Union have a privileged political and economic relationship within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. With this in mind, an association agreement was put in place in 1995. He called for the gradual establishment of a free trade area between the EU and Tunisia. In October 2015, negotiations for a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement with Tunisia began.  In this resolution, Parliament shares its recommendations with the European Commission negotiators. Parliament supports the opening of these negotiations. It recalls that the provisions of the agreement must not endanger the economy of either party. Some sectors will need special attention, such as services, public procurement and agriculture.  The agreement reached in agricultural matters must not jeopardy the interests of certain regions in the south of the Union, which are competitors to Tunisian exports. I voted in favour of this resolution, which sends a signal of support for a young democracy that is Tunisia.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution today because I believe it is necessary to accompany the Tunisian economy, which has been severely weakened by terrorist attacks, with aid measures. The Tunisian economy is in fact at a time of considerable economic difficulty. The tourism industry is collapsing, the unemployment rate in 2015 was 15% of the working population, 28.6% of graduates out of work and unemployment among young people is rising sharply. All this at a time when the country's democratic transition process is proving to be the most advanced in the region as a result of the adoption of a single political and economic model among the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean. In addition, Tunisia has taken in more than one million and eight hundred thousand Libyan refugees, a number equal to almost 16% of the country's total population. I believe it is essential for Tunisia to receive substantial financial, technical and trade negotiating assistance from the EU in order to properly implement the various provisions of the Free Trade Agreement. It is important that financial aid is provided transparently and that we ensure that it brings real benefits to the recipients.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution which would build on the existing free trade area covered by the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement signed some 20 years ago. The now proposed ‘Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement’ would widen the scope to cover technical barriers to trade, investment protection, public procurement and competition policy, liberalisation of trade in services and trade in agriculture. Specifically I am disappointed that the resolution does not make any reference to re-discussing Tunisia’s debt or the real participation of Tunisian civil society and trade unions in the negotiation process. For these reasons I voted against the resolution.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully welcome the launch of negotiations for modernisation of our current Association Agreement with Tunisia in October 2015, however difficult they turn out to be. If successful, the outcomes will have many economic benefits to both parties as well as political importance for Tunisia. I am hoping that the negotiations will involve many partners, not only Tunisian authorities but also social partners and greater civil society so that the final agreement can be of benefit to all.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution expresses the European Parliament's recommendations on the negotiation of the FREE TRADE Agreement between the EU and Tunisia, the negotiations of which were launched in October 2015. It is an agreement on the liberalisation of goods and services between Tunisia and the EU and the preparation of common measures on labour mobility on the defence of intellectual property. The text of the resolution recommends that the Commission proceed to a gradual and asymmetrical agreement, with a gradual opening up to tunisia's economic sectors. The resolution also calls for the liberalisation of certain goods considered sensitive to our companies, such as olive oil, to be excluded from the negotiations. There are also some weaknesses in the text. However, considering that many of the compromise amendments proposed by the 5 Star Movement were accepted, I decided to vote in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The trade relations between the EU and Tunisia are one the key elements for Tunisian political and economic stability. The negotiations on an ambitious free trade agreement that has been launched last year aim to further strengthen the relationship between both parties. Both sides need such a close trade relationship. It will help, among others things, Tunisia to promote stability, democratic reforms and peace not only in the country but in the entire Maghreb region. For that reason I was in favour of the INTA report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, considering that deepening Euro-Tunisian trade relations through the conclusion of an ambitious trade partnership should open up growth and rapprochement prospects for the economies of Tunisia and the European Union.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia concerns the economic sector, but also at political level.  Tunisia is a country closely linked to Europe and with particular economic transactions. Although these discussions have lasted a long time, I believe that not only have not many issues relating to such an agreement been resolved, but above all the form of this agreement is not appropriate and does not protect the interests of European citizens and Member States. That is why I decided to vote against.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After seeing the outcome of the vote on the Tunisian oil report, which was the aspect that interested me most within the broader agreement, I voted in favour of this resolution in the hope that these further negotiations will result in a more reasonable text that is more favourable to our consumers. Let us never let our guard down!

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU must continue with its aid to Tunisia and provide the country with appropriate financial and technical assistance, during the negotiations and, subsequently, during the implementation of the agreement’s provisions, by developing a genuine partnership in which the interests of people on both shores of the Mediterranean can be taken into account. I hope that this agreement promotes further scientific cooperation, particularly between universities and research centres in Europe and Tunisia towards the development of new technologies and, more generally, culture and education.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations for free trade agreements between the European Union and Tunisia began on 19 October 2015. The resolution highlights a number of points to be taken into account: the agreement must be gradual and asymmetrical; the opening-up of Tunisia's economic sectors must be gradual, gradual and must provide for transitional periods for sensitive sectors, excluding from the negotiations certain products considered sensitive by the parties (we have obviously called for the exclusion of the olive oil sector). Substantial financial, technical and trade negotiating assistance must be provided in order to properly implement the various provisions of the Free Trade Agreement, by demanding that this aid be provided transparently and bring real benefits to the recipients. The text is not a bad one, but since, unfortunately, some of our amendments, which are of fundamental importance, have not been included in the text, such as the one concerning the exclusion of the olive oil sector, I cannot support it. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the recommendation in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia since the conviction that such agreements entail liberalization not only of trade in agricultural products, but also of services, affecting basic social rights. The European Union has also refused to promote an international audit of the odious debt acquired by Ben Ali's regime, which the Tunisian people continue to assume today. Moreover, the negotiation of this agreement does not take into account asymmetry and does not have the participation of Tunisian social organizations and trade unions. Therefore, since the conviction that such an agreement only favours large companies, with a negative impact on workers and small producers on both sides, both Tunisian olive oil producers and those in southern European countries, I voted against it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first agreement on trade cooperation between the two partners was reached in 1969 and Tunisia was the first country on the southern Mediterranean coast to sign an Association Agreement with the European Union in 1995. On 13 October 2015, the European Union and Tunisia opened negotiations on an ambitious free trade agreement. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms and is expected to contribute to the political and democratic stabilisation of Tunisia. The parliamentary report adopted today mentions the issues on which, in your opinion, the European Commission should focus during the negotiations. Against this background, particular attention should also be paid to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products, in the negotiations.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The text of the resolution supports the opening of negotiations, recognising that Tunisia is an exception among the countries of the region which, after the events of the Arab Spring, has successfully succeeded in moving towards a democratic country. Furthermore, it calls on the European Union and its Member States to continue the assistance needed to consolidate democratic change. The resolution calls on the Commission to negotiate a mutually beneficial agreement that will allow a balanced, asymmetric and gradual opening up of the Tunisian market, giving Tunisia's exports greater and better access to the EU market. That being said, I voted 'in favour'.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The negotiations initiated for an EU-Tunisia Free trade agreement aim at improving market access and investment opportunities, and supporting ongoing reforms in Tunisia, in order to integrate further Tunisia, which is currently faced with economic and political disturbances, into the EU and world economy. I believe that negotiations should be based on a staged process including transition periods and specific monitoring and attention to sensitive sectors and public services. It is important to have transparent negotiations and also to reform specific situations such as corruption. Nevertheless, I voted against a paragraph relating to tax since I believe that tax matters are dealt with in a Council body which is vested with such competences. Overall, I strongly agree that we need to help Tunisia to reform and to induce inclusive growth.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As a strong proponent of free trade, I voted in favour of supporting the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement resolution. Whilst this will have economic benefits for both sides, this move will also help support an important ally in North Africa, help modernise the Tunisian economy and create the growth and jobs needed to help stabilise the Tunisian economy. It will also help support Tunisia’s transition into a vibrant, modern democracy – something strategically vital for British interests in a region experiencing political instability.  This resolution is ambitious in scope and includes the main economic sectors which are beneficial for both sides. The resolution also gives Tunisia enough time to adapt to the new market conditions which it will be required to uphold.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament underlines the importance that this free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia goes beyond its mere commercial dimension. I consider it particularly essential that this agreement contribute to the stabilisation of Tunisia, which is affected not only by terrorism but also by great economic difficulties. This free trade agreement should help promote the growth of the European Union while accompanying Tunisia in revitalising its economy. It is therefore essential that this agreement can benefit the European and Tunisian economies, and in particular SMEs.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-Tunisia negotiations started on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. The negotiations should also pay particular attention to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support the process of opening negotiations for a free trade agreement with Tunisia. The European Union is Tunisia's largest economic partner. The signing of a comprehensive free trade agreement should allow for further convergence and integration between the Tunisian and European markets. The agreement is also expected to extend EU standards to the areas of the environment, consumer defence and workers' rights in Tunisia. However, I believe that this agreement must take place in prudent steps, with the utmost transparency but also with the utmost respect for the situation in Tunisia, the only state that has courageously managed to stay on the path of democracy in the wake of the Arab Spring wave and which we see is struggling to get its economy back on track. The support of the Union, at this difficult stage, and the strengthening of democratic reforms in Tunisia are essential, especially since the region remains very unstable. I am convinced that Tunis today needs comprehensive European assistance to revive and diversify its economy, but also and above all to strengthen its democratic process and fragile political institutions.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Eu-Tunisia negotiations started on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. The negotiations should also pay particular attention to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text defends the idea that we must help our Tunisian "neighbour". Since 13 October 2015, negotiations for a free trade agreement have been opened with Tunisia. But the agreement in question risks creating unfair competition, especially for European farmers, employees and industrialists, with relocations of companies in industry and services, for example in the automotive sector. There is therefore no question of harming the European economy in order to satisfy a country like Tunisia. It would have been possible to cooperate, without systematically resorting to greater trade liberalization. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations were launched in October last year to sign a free trade agreement with Tunisia. I supported this resolution as it outlines the priority areas for these negotiations to be addressed by the European Commission, drawing up its position.  I believe that Tunisia is one of the few countries in the region that has succeeded most in becoming a democratic state as a result of the events of the Arab Spring.  The Commission should work towards an agreement that is beneficial for both parties, paying attention to the fact that exports of food and agriculture products produced in Tunisia must meet high EU quality standards.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative as a whole for the simple reason that the EU should first deal with its internal problems of unemployment and the economy and then solve those of African countries. Greece goes out and the EU finances and imports low-cost Tunisian products.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-Tunisia negotiations started on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. The negotiations should also pay particular attention to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between Europe and Tunisia are close and very old, with the European Union being Tunisia's main trading partner and the creation of a free trade area and the establishment of provisions on agriculture and services. Tunisia, the birthplace of events known as the 'Arab Spring', is the only country in the Near and Middle East and North Africa region where a process of democratic and political transition has been carried out, and is an example for the whole region. I therefore agree with the need to deepen ties between the European Union and Tunisia and to the promotion and strengthening of the south-south regional integration processes between Tunisia and neighbouring countries, in particular through the Agadir Agreement.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution focuses on the establishment of a Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Tunisia, which falls within the wider scope of neighbourhood relations, and is governed by the Association Agreement of 1995 (which for years considered as an estimateable democracy the regime that the Tunisian people overturned by the fight), which provides for the creation of a free trade area and the establishment of provisions on agriculture and services. The opening of negotiations on this agreement is (supreme cynicism, supreme hypocrisy) as a measure of aid to Tunisia following the June 2015 attacks in Sousse. It also states that Tunisia has taken in more than 1.8 million refugees from Libya as a result of the EU-sponsored and supported aggression there, and that this figure accounts for 16 % of Tunisia's total population. The solidarity façade that is intended to be attributed to Free Trade does not stand the evidence of the facts, which denote its neocolonial nature, because in order to impose economic and social policies that will not benefit the Tunisian people, but rather aim to make way for European multinationals wishing to colonize the market of this country, focusing particular attention on the agriculture sector and the service sector of that country. We voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as I am not in favour of the terms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the open of free trade negotiations with Tunisia as they would cause economic damage to our country.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the opening of negotiations on an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement for the simple reason that the EU should first deal with its internal problems of unemployment and the economy and then solve those of African countries. Greece goes out and the EU finances and imports low-cost Tunisian products.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Concerning the negotiations for a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement with Tunisia, I believe it will improve market access and investment opportunities, and support ongoing reforms in Tunisia, to ultimately integrate Tunisia into the EU and world economy. However it is important to ensure that Tunisia’s economy is opened in a gradual asymmetric manner, with transition periods and special attention given to sensitive sectors and public services.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-Tunisia negotiations started on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. The negotiations should also pay particular attention to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal convinced that the trade agreement with Tunisia will be beneficial for all. Tunisia has been a neighbouring state of great importance to the EU, a trade cooperator since 1969 and a trading partner since 1995. That is why I believe that this new framework of relations will benefit both sides.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia because I believe it is important to support a democratic transition and a process of liberalisation of the country that can put Tunisia on the path of modern democracies. I believe that trade relations between the EU and Tunisia are an integral part of a neighbourhood policy that values Tunisia as a free and democratic country, a model for the entire North African area. In this sense, the development of the economy and the increase in trade with the EU are the key to a stable and plural society at a time of exposure to fundamentalism and terrorism: reducing inequalities and promoting well-being, employment and rights are the appropriate tools against these threats. I believe, however, that the agreement must be gradual and flexible, given the high sensitivity of certain sectors for both parties. I therefore support Parliament's call for impact studies on the effects of the agreement in certain areas such as agri-food and public procurement, the sectoral approach to negotiation, the provision of transitional periods and quotas, the call for product traceability and the provision of compensatory measures in the event of adverse effects on the economies of both parties.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the opening of negotiations on an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement, as the underlying procedure fulfils many of the indicators of a new 'fair trade agreement' that I have called for and it is precisely respect for human rights and social standards that play a role.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU's sectoral relationship with Tunisia and the country's democratic process can be promoted through close trade relations. I am therefore in favour of a free trade area in order to strengthen the Tunisian economy, the country's democratic process and Tunisia's relations with the EU.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. Empirical experience shows that there is a good chance of promoting social imbalances in a country whose situation is already sensitive.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A resolution that takes into account the Priorities of the European Union in its negotiations with Tunisia on free trade is undoubtedly progress in relations between the two sides. Tunisia is an example of a country that consistently strives for democracy in such extraordinary conditions. The European Union's cooperation with Tunisia will allow for the gradual opening up of the Tunisian market, the improvement of exports to the European Union and the development of a high level in this field.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because the free trade agreement between the EU and Tunisia will be beneficial for both parties and builds on the stability in the Maghreb region.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia sets out a framework with which we disagree. It promotes neoliberal policies, like all free trade negotiations, which help big business and not the ordinary citizen in Tunisia. Tunisia needs support, but not with the policies promoted by this report which adversely affects the people in Tunisia. It seeks to put workers in the EU and Tunisia in a framework of "competition" between them, resulting in wage restraint and the backsliding of the labour rights of those workers who enjoy them. We therefore consider voting against it to be an appropriate position.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I along with ALDE fully supported this free-trade agreement between the EU and Tunisia. In October of 2015, the EU and Tunisia launched negotiations on an ambitious free-trade agreement on the basis of a mandate adopted in December 2011. This free-trade agreement is part of a broader framework to strengthen that relationship. This resolution by the Committee on Internal Trade emphasises that sensitive markets in the EU need to be protected but in general outlines how both markets will benefit from the agreement. It also highlights the fact that Tunisia is currently hosting over 8 million refugees and such an agreement helps to build and maintain the stability and peace in the Maghreb countries.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution because the deepening of EU-Tunisia trade relations through the conclusion of an ambitious trade partnership represents an opportunity for growth and closer ties between the economies of Tunisia and the EU. This partnership must also contribute to the political and democratic stabilisation of Tunisia. The Tunisian economy faces the major difficulties that GDP grew by 2.3% in 2014 and the unemployment rate in 2015 was 15% of the active population, that 28.6% of graduates have no jobs and that unemployment among young Tunisians is rising.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is committed to free trade. Free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win for consumers in particular. These effects are particularly evident in developing and emerging countries. Z.B. the tiger states show that opening up to free trade is beneficial. ALFA therefore considers this free trade agreement, which is now to be negotiated, to be an important aid to Tunisia's further development, while at the same time benefiting Europe. This sign is all the more important because Tunisia is currently taking important steps towards stable democracy. I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-Tunisia negotiations started on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. The negotiations should also pay particular attention to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Tunisia has faced many challenges in the last few years and we must continue to encourage those who support stability and democracy. The EU should enter trade negotiations with Tunisia and in due course any final package will come back before this House.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia has been left in a delicate state economically, politically and socially following the terrorist attacks that took place in recent months. However, this has not stopped the Tunisian authorities taking in more than 1.8 million Libyan refugees. This action should be applauded greatly in the current context. I consider that it is the European Union’s job to support Tunisia through its difficult times and I welcome the opening of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution to start negotiations on a Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, as it strengthens trade relations with Tunisia, helps its damaged economy and contributes to the stability of the region. This Agreement is also an essential part of the eu-Tunisia cooperation already in place and is particularly important due to the current instability of the regional environment.  The financial and technical assistance provided by the European Union to Tunisia will be crucial for trade negotiations and for the social and economic reforms that need to be initiated as soon as possible. I consider, however, that it is of particular importance to take into account the interests of the European economy and European businessmen and businesses, in particular SMEs, in order to protect their interests and the European single market.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text echoes the idea that we must help our Tunisian neighbour, an example for the region, but forgets that we must not create economic difficulties for our peoples. Other methods of aid that deep free trade treaties could have been explored. This agreement creates a high risk of unfair competition for European farmers, employees and industrialists with relocations of industrial and service companies. We are obviously against a free trade agreement with Tunisia. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the opening of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement. This resolution notes the importance of negotiations on an EU free trade agreement with Tunisia to replace the current Association Agreement. One of the objectives is to support Tunisian democracy and thus to send a strong political signal. This agreement will have to be balanced and cover broad areas. However, the European Parliament is aware that the forces involved are likely to be asymmetrical and therefore calls for active participation of Tunisian civil society as well as technical assistance from the Union. I therefore support these negotiations on a new agreement which will be a factor of stability in order to support the democratic process in Tunisia. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to send a strong political signal of support to our Tunisian friends. By opening these negotiations on the signing of a free trade agreement with Tunis, the European Union wishes to participate in a definitive stabilisation and vitality of the country's economy. The participation of civil society is particularly highlighted in this negotiation process. I welcome the fact that this resolution was adopted by a large majority.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I cannot agree with the resolution on the agreement. As it stands, it provides not only for a desirable deepening of trade relations, but also for points relating to migration, which I reject in part.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as I want to help Tunisia on its path to reform, further inclusive growth and the creation of high—quality jobs.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is fundamentally committed to free trade. With appropriately smart design, free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win, especially for consumers. These effects are particularly evident in developing and emerging countries. Z.B. the tiger states show that opening up to free trade is beneficial. ALFA therefore considers this free trade agreement, which is now to be negotiated, to be an important aid to Tunisia's further development, while at the same time benefiting Europe. This sign is all the more important as Tunisia is currently taking important steps towards stable democracy. I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the proposal. Tunisia may be a country with major economic problems, but this form of support is not appropriately chosen. Liberalising trade between the EU and Tunisia would most favour companies engaged in exporting olive oil from Tunisia to the EU. Temporarily, there could be an increase in the number of jobs in Tunisia as a result of a closer trade partnership with the EU based on olive oil exports to EU countries. In the long run, however, such cooperation would be detrimental to Tunisia, as there would be a real risk of plundering the country in order to obtain as much benefit as possible without any sign of investment in local infrastructure, etc. The impact of such measures on EU olive oil producers, in particular southern EU countries, would also have to be assessed. In particular, Tunisia should focus on addressing internal political and social problems.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-Tunisia negotiations started on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. The negotiations should also pay particular attention to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ It is essential to establish a trade agreement between European Union and Tunisia. However, this trade agreement should focus also on a debt restructuration. As a GUE/GNL group, we would like also to see the Tunisian civil society involved in the negotiations for the trade agreement. At this stage of the process, the trade agreement does not help the Tunisian economy. since it is focusing on market liberalisation. I voted against for the abovementioned reasons.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA) will benefit both sides (the EU and Tunisia). In the case of Tunisia, it will help support economic reforms and further consolidate young democracy in that country. Whereas, in the case of the EU, the deal will not only facilitate trade and economic growth but also will provide an opportunity to the Union to promote democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms in a neighbouring country, which is located in a very unstable North-African region characterised by extensive human rights violations, irregular migration and the presence of Islamic State. Namely, in this context, I supported the DCFTA with Tunisia because above all it will be a stepping stone for further economic and political integration of the Euro-Mediterranean region that will bring in long—term economic growth, stability, security, peace and prosperity.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU-Tunisia Partnership Agreement represents an opportunity for growth for both the Tunisian and European economies. It must be understood, however, that this agreement is not just a matter of trade, since its aim is to stabilise Tunisia's political reality, accompanying it in its process of democratic transition. Financial support is needed to achieve this. In any case, I believe that we must proceed with caution, taking into account the considerable disparities between the two parties, their specific characteristics, and maintaining a sectoral approach during the negotiation. I also believe that the opening up of specific Tunisian economic sectors must take place gradually and gradually. The free trade agreement must be beneficial to both parties and must therefore not harm European economic sectors. In view of the fact that the main purpose of this partnership is to contribute to the political and democratic stabilisation of Tunisia, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. De Sarnez's report makes the right observation on the need to support Tunisia. It was in this country that the Arab Spring began; it was in Tunisia that his call for freedom and democracy came to fruition. Tunisia, however, is subject to strong social and economic tensions, the emancipation of its society takes place in an extremely heavy political context, an unstable environment, and it is therefore very important to help it. A hastily negotiated trade agreement risks adding harmful economic instability to political instability. Moreover, without listening to Tunisian civil society, which has demonstrated its maturity more than once, and without acceding to its demands to be involved or for a real impact study to be carried out before starting negotiations. We need to have access to these requests first and foremost; that is why I have opposed this report which calls for the continuation of negotiations without taking these necessary precautions. These are new avenues of cooperation that we need to explore with the Tunisians; and not agreements that promote the logic of competition or financial aid conditioned on imf dictates.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the opening of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement. This proposal welcomes the opening of free trade negotiations between the European Union and Tunisia. One of the points in this text is that Tunisia must be helped, an example for the region, that it must ensure its stability and the dynamism of its economy. This text forgets that we must not create economic difficulties for the peoples of Europe.  Other methods of aid that deep free trade treaties could have been explored. This agreement creates a high risk of unfair competition for French and European farmers, employees and industrialists, with relocations of industrial and service companies.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I am opposed to the free trade agreement with Tunisia that it wants to promote.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution opens negotiations for yet another free trade agreement, this time between the European Union and Tunisia. This very (too?) liberal-inspired text extols the Tunisian model and tries to convince it that it must be helped, by setting up a number of Euro-Tunisian facilities: granting visas, opening public procurement... This agreement will certainly backfire on European producers, creating new unfair competition for farmers, wage earners and industrialists. Indeed, there are fears, in the light of similar agreements made in recent months (particularly with Ukraine), of social dumping and a movement of relocations of companies and services that would be strongly harmful to European actors. I have spoken out against this text.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 As an N-VA delegation, we support the resolution for the opening of negotiations on an EU free trade agreement with Tunisia. At the beginning of 2011, Tunisia was the birthplace of the Arab Spring. The Jasmine Revolution then marked the beginning of a difficult process for the country to build a democratic system. The resolution recognises the democratic steps that Tunisia has taken in the meantime. The negotiations on a free trade agreement with the EU are a key element in further Tunisian development. A trade agreement can be a catalyst for political stability and economic development. This is very important for a country that is going through a process of democratisation by trial and error. Deep economic reforms in areas such as trade in services, effective investment protection and better trade access to European markets will ensure growth and jobs. Moreover, we would also like to point out the possible impact that extensive trade relations can have in order to hopefully better control the flow of migrants towards Europe. The conclusion of a trade agreement and the implementation of economic reforms can offer Tunisians a better prospect of the future to build a good life at home.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the recommendation in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia since the conviction that such agreements entail liberalization not only of trade in agricultural products, but also of services, affecting basic social rights. The European Union has also refused to promote an international audit of the odious debt acquired by Ben Ali's regime, which the Tunisian people continue to assume today. Moreover, the negotiation of this agreement does not take into account asymmetry and does not have the participation of Tunisian social organizations and trade unions. Therefore, since the conviction that such an agreement only favours large companies, with a negative impact on workers and small producers on both sides, both Tunisian olive oil producers and those in southern European countries, I voted against it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is committed to free trade. Free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win for consumers in particular. These effects are particularly evident in developing and emerging countries. Z.B. the tiger states show that opening up to free trade is beneficial. ALFA therefore considers this free trade agreement, which is now to be negotiated, to be an important aid to Tunisia's further development, while at the same time benefiting Europe. This sign is all the more important because Tunisia is currently taking important steps towards stable democracy. I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. I am in support of free trade, not in terms of restricting imports, such as in paragraphs 47 and 48, where the Commission is called upon, 'to discuss the implementation of high standards and high quality in the sanitary and phytosanitary field, and to address veterinary and meat, fruit and vegetable control problems'. Studies show that strict European rules are too expensive for importers, and the price that Europeans pay for them because of more expensive goods does not correspond to risk.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. Since 2011, Tunisia has strengthened its democratic transition by proclaiming a new Constitution on 26 January 2014 and holding parliamentary and presidential elections in November 2014. An EU-Tunisia trade agreement would not only contribute to economic stability, but also to strengthening democracy and reducing inequality. The agreement should take into account economic differences between the two parties and take into account local specificities, culture and socio-economic characteristics.  Tunisia's democratic transition is the most successful in the region and the Union in this way provides support for the further development of the stability of the political system, so I supported the report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement will undoubtedly help the economies and economies of both parties. The security situation in Tunisia has deteriorated in recent months as a result of terrorist attacks. This agreement will therefore have not only a commercial but also a significant political dimension, which will be reflected not only in the security of the country, but also in its democratisation, in economic and social relations. That is why the Commission must also take this fact into account in the negotiations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/2/2016, as well as because the free trade agreement to be passed will allow the long-term import of Tunisian oil and other agricultural products into the EU and in particular into Greece, which will economically harm the poor Greek farmers from the Memorandum and create serious problems for the smooth development of the primary sectors of our country.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report! To help Tunisia, whose economy is severely affected by the terrorist attacks, the Commission is proposing an additional tariff-free quota of 35,000 tonnes of olive oil exports from Tunisia to the EU, with the current quota being 56,700 tonnes. We could have helped Tunisia in other ways, without putting European olive growers in trouble. The price of olive oil has tended to fall over the last 10 years, which affects European producers, and this agreement represents a real shortfall for our producers. But, as always, the Commission is generous to others, not its citizens.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the opening of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement is in my favour. Relations between Tunisia and Europe are long-standing and the European Union remains Tunisia's main trading partner. It is important to work on deepening trade relations, and that is what this report is about, which offers tangible opportunities for the Tunisian and European economies. Together with these negotiations, however, the European Union will provide financial and technical assistance by working on an effective partnership.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Tunisia is a country that has suffered greatly in recent years and has been affected by terrible terrorist attacks, which is causing a very difficult economic and social situation in that country. Therefore, from the EU we must work to support Tunisia and welcome the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement to increase the relationship between the two sides.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. I believe that this partnership will benefit the business of both Tunisia and the EU Member States. Moreover, this agreement will undoubtedly contribute to ensuring political and democratic stability in Tunisia.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Union agrees on the need to support Tunisia's young democracy, which is also struggling with a particularly unstable regional context. But the EU only considers its external relations from the point of view of economic annexation, so Brussels wants to initiate its first South Mediterranean free trade agreement with the country. The result is a total abolition of customs duties, regulations and state aid, which will take a toll on a fragile economy in the face of this imperialist juggernaut.  As in the case of TAFTA, the negotiating mandate granted by the Council to the European Commission is not public. The report underlines this but does not require at least consultation with national parliaments for the final agreement. I am opposed to all these free trade agreements, let alone in this case.  I join my comrades in the Tunisian Popular Front in voting against this agreement.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text does not take into account the economic interests of the Member States, and subordinates them. It would have been appropriate to exclude the importation of olive oil from the negotiations, for example. This agreement risks unfair competition with our farmers and relocations. As a result I voted against.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the opening of negotiations on an EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement. As the European Union is Tunisia's main trading partner, it is important to strengthen trade relations between the EU and Tunisia. It is also important to have a more ambitious trade partnership, which is an opportunity for growth and rapprochement for both economies. This partnership should contribute to tunisia's political and democratic stabilisation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because improving trade relations with Tunisia will not only help the economies of EU Member States, but will help boost the Tunisian economy and help support its political transition process.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the opening of negotiations for a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement between the EU and Tunisia in October 2015. The agreement must contribute to the development and diversification of Tunisian economy which is currently highly dependent on agriculture. It must also bring concrete benefits to its citizens in terms of consumer prices, employment and wages. Apart from provisions in areas such as services, public procurement and intellectual property rights, the agreement will provide in particular for the approximation of Tunisian legislation to EU legislation in trade-related areas. This should lead to a progressive integration of the Tunisian economy into the EU single market. I believe that the effects of the agreement will also contribute to the consolidation of democracy in Tunisia and to the political stability of the country. I therefore support this resolution.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is the cradle of the Arab Spring and the only country in the Middle East and North Africa to have implemented a process of democratic and political transformation: the new constitution adopted on 26 January 2014 is exemplary in the protection of rights and freedoms, and free, pluralistic and transparent elections were held at the end of 2014. As a result, Tunisia serves as an example of a democratic transition for the other countries in the region. In addition, relations between the European Union and Tunisia are close and old: the first agreement on trade cooperation was reached in 1969 and Tunisia was the first country on the southern Mediterranean coast to sign an Association Agreement with the European Union in 1995.  For these reasons, the Committee on International Trade proposes that the European Parliament welcome the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement between the EU and Tunisia on 13 October 2015 and take a position on the swift conclusion of the negotiations. To this end, it considers it important that the agreement take into account the significant economic differences between the two parties, provide for a progressive, gradual and asymmetric opening up of Tunisian economic sectors and that the EU provide significant financial and technical support to Tunisia for the proper implementation of the various provisions of the FTA. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution welcomes the free trade negotiations between Tunisia and the European Union that opened on 13 October 2015. Tunisia is being asked to help by ensuring stability and boosting its economy. We are therefore voting against this proposal, which is a threat to our farmers, our employees and our industrialists who will be at great risk of unfair competition.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text echoes the idea that we must help our Tunisian neighbour but forgets that we must not create economic difficulties for our peoples. This agreement creates a high risk of unfair competition for European farmers, employees and industrialists. Other methods of aid that free trade treaties can be explored, which is why I voted against.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the courageous process of democratic transition initiated in Tunisia and the constant attempts at destabilisation, we warmly welcome the opening of negotiations between the European Union and Tunisia on the creation of a comprehensive and in-depth free trade area. Indeed, confident that European trade policy can be an effective instrument for promoting sustainable development and economic growth, we trust that the agreement will contribute to the complete stabilisation of the country through a higher level of employment and a plan of reforms that can be achieved within a framework of regulatory cooperation. Indeed, the country is facing a difficult economic slowdown, caused by the collapse of tourist presences, the country's main source of livelihood, strongly linked to terrorist attacks and Libyan turbulence. We therefore recognise the enormous institutional effort to increase the inclusiveness of Tunisian society, as well as the admirable humanitarian support for the approximately two million Libyan refugees in the country. Convinced that a safer and more prosperous Tunisia is of primary interest to the European Union, we hope that the agreement will be of an asymmetric nature and that the negotiations will be conducted with the utmost transparency and with the highest involvement of Tunisian civil society, which is a worthy protagonist of the democratic path taken.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the next 10 to 15 years almost 90% of the world’s demand will be generated outside the European Union. This is why through its agreements the EU should boost its growth potential by opening up market opportunities for European businesses abroad. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that should open the negotiations for an EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement and seek to contribute to the stability of Tunisia to the consolidation of its democracy and economy.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Union is founded on ideas of solidarity and mutual assistance aimed at mutual integration of the housekeepers of its member countries. However, European producers from all sectors are becoming increasingly subject to a number of transformations and transitions, such as the process of accession to the Community. For this reason, I believe that the European Union must seek and ensure the proper and smooth functioning of the European single market as a matter of priority.  Tunisia is a country with traditional ties to the European Union, and it is the country's first and most economically important partner. Due to its geographical and climatic proximity to southern Europe, a large proportion of agricultural goods produced in Tunisia are similar to European ones and constitute direct competition for the European producer.  Free trade agreements are an instrument which, I believe, has counter-reticent effects for the European producer. There are still many mechanisms supporting inequalities between European farmers in order to open up this single market freely. I therefore believe that another free trade agreement will only create even more uncertainty among European producers and therefore I did not give my support to open the negotiations for a free trade agreement between the EU and Tunisia.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The regulations set out in the report on the introduction of urgent autonomous trade measures for Tunisia are significantly discriminating against the European olive oil industry. I would have opposed this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Although it mentions the need for Tunisia to be supported by the EU following the democratic transition, this motion for a resolution calls, despite a very unstable environment, for further negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement, over the other hand, the need for consultation with civil society and a possible impact study of such an agreement. I voted against this resolution.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. A free trade agreement could not only contribute to the stability of Tunisia, to the stability of Tunisia, to strengthening democracy and to giving new impetus to the country's economy.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is a key strategic partner for Europe in the Mediterranean geopolitical landscape. A country which is going through a process of democratic transition to a pluralist society and which aims to strengthen this new and still fragile democracy. The recent terrorist attacks in Tunisia are clearly an attempt to hinder this process of democratic consolidation that is taking place; an ongoing political transition which is therefore in danger of being seriously threatened by the action of these terrorist groups and which has further weakened tunisia's tourism sector, the main lever of the country's economic revenues.  In this sensitive context, the resolution I voted on today proposes the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement. This is an opportunity for the European Union, the country's main trading partner, to give practical help to the Tunisian economy, which is suffering from over-labour and a very high rate of youth unemployment. I believe that this commitment must be made through an accompanying process at the negotiating stage, both through economic and technical aid and through regular dialogue between MEMBERS of the European Parliament and Tunisians, as provided for in the newly formed Joint Parliamentary Committee. I therefore supported this resolution because the EU's opening up of trade to Tunisia is a necessary step in supporting the democratic transition and the country's economy.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not oppose the concept of trade with all countries. However, we feel that the EU has no right to conduct our trade negotiations. Therefore, we voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is Tunisia's main trading partner and the first cooperation agreement between the two partners dates back to 1969. The EU points out that in Tunisia the labour market is unequal between the different sectors covered by the trade agreement which, if not filled, are likely to lead to over-labour in the agricultural sector and the elimination of other sectors important for economic diversification in their country. Support for this country cannot and must not be to the detriment of the economies of the Mediterranean countries. I therefore hope that there will also be greater protection for the agricultural and manufacturing sectors of that European airline, so as not to worsen a situation already widening in deficit with the crisis of recent years.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The signing of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Tunisia will contribute to strengthening already very active economic cooperation with Tunisia. I note that the European Union is one of Tunisia's most important trading partners and the signing of this agreement will allow greater access to the Tunisian market for European products. The signing of the FtA is important not only on the economic side, it is also a clear political message. With this agreement, the Union will send a message that it supports democratic reforms in this North African state. Tunisia is one of the few states where the removal of power as part of the Arab Spring did not lead to bloodshed, but the country has made significant progress in democratisation. I am therefore confident that the signing of this Agreement will encourage Tunisian authorities to further implement economic and political reforms. I call for the realisation of the Agreement to take into account the protection of the interests of EU farmers, in particular olive oil producers.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text defends the idea that we must help our Tunisian neighbour, an example for the region, but forgets that we must not create economic difficulties for the peoples of Europe. Other methods of aid that deep free trade treaties could have been explored, especially since free trade is far from enriching everyone in the European Union (in reality, it is a system that tends to enrich only those who were already rich). This agreement creates a high risk of unfair competition for Farmers in the Member States, employees and industrialists with relocations of companies and services. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The first trade cooperation agreement between the two sides was concluded in 1969 and Tunisia was the first country on the southern mediterranean coast to sign an association agreement with the European Union in 1995. Also, the European Union is Tunisia's first trading partner and Tunisia is the Union's 34th trading partner. In line with the objectives set out in the European Neighbourhood Policy and the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, the best way for the Union to help tunisia's economy is to provide an attractive and reliable market for Tunisian exports, which is why I support the opening of negotiations with Tunisia last October. In anticipation of concluding negotiations on the establishment of a deep and comprehensive free trade area (DCFTA) and in response to the economic crisis in Tunisia and to support the implementation of the necessary political reforms, the European Union has approved a €300 million increase in macro-financial assistance to Tunisia to be paid in three instalments of €100 million in 2015. In parallel with the negotiations, the European Union must continue to assist Tunisia and intensify it. It must also provide adequate and adequate financial and technical assistance during negotiations and later in the implementation phase of the provisions of the Agreement and develop a real partnership that can take into account the interests of the population on both sides of the Mediterranean.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes the establishment of a Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. The opening of negotiations on this agreement seeks to be justified. From the prospect of being another aid measure to Tunisia in the wake of the barbaric attacks of June 2015, to the hypocritical mention that tunisia has taken in more than 1.8 million refugees from Libya, accounting for 16 % of its total population. The latter is a direct criminal political consequence of interference and aggression that the US, NATO and the European Union have imposed in the Middle East and North Africa as part of their strategy of destabilising the Arab world and economic exploitation of the wealth of these regions.  The façade of solidarity with which this Free Trade Agreement is intended hides its true neo-colonialist aspect, which will impose economic policies and structural reforms on Tunisia contrary to the interests of its people, opening doors to European multinationals and the exploitation of the agricultural and services sectors of that country.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is one of the closest neighbours on our Mediterranean border and one of the Long-Term Trading Partners of the European Union. I voted in favour of opening free trade negotiations with this country, whose economy has been very negatively affected by terrorist attacks over the past year. I firmly believe that this free trade agreement will help Tunisia gradually create new, quality jobs and promote inclusive growth. I voted in favour of the free trade negotiations, which will be gradual. Tunisia's economy should be opened up asymmetrically to European and world trade, ensuring the protection of the most sensitive sectors and boosting employment in problem areas and inland regions. I supported this agreement because I believe it will help stabilise the country and consolidate democracy. In this respect, it is important that civil society is involved in the negotiations and that transparent financial and technical assistance is provided to Tunisia. I hope that the opening of negotiations and the subsequent conclusion of a free trade agreement will lead to deeper cooperation in other areas, including education and scientific cooperation, beneficial to both sides. Furthermore, I believe that an agreement with the Union will lead to the introduction of higher social and labour standards in which Tunisia is lagging behind, and that the European Commission will not only focus on current account balance values, but will not neglect the issue of respect for human rights.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in favour of adopting the EU-Tunisia trade agreement, not least in view of the long-term and close relationship between Tunisia and the European Union, which began back in 1969. I believe that this ambitious agreement will not only bring the EU and Tunisia's economies closer, but will also contribute to the political and democratic stabilisation of the country. Tunisia is the only country in the Middle East and North Africa that has become successful in transitioning to a democratic regime after an event known as the "Arab Spring." After adopting a new constitution protecting human rights and freedoms on 26 January 2014, the country set an example for other countries in the region. For this reason, it is important to continue to support Tunisia in its efforts to become a full-fledged democracy. Tunisia is facing insufficient growth and rising unemployment, the agreement should contribute to addressing the greatest pains of its economy, in particular the diversification of tunisia's economy, which is now mainly focused on agriculture.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The resolution supports the opening of negotiations, recognising that Tunisia is an exception among the countries of the region which, after the events of the Arab Spring, has successfully succeeded in moving towards a democratic country. Furthermore, it calls on the EU and its Member States to continue to provide Tunisia with the necessary assistance in order to consolidate democratic change. As regards the fta, the resolution calls on the Commission to negotiate a mutually beneficial agreement that will allow a balanced, asymmetric and gradual opening up of the Tunisian market, giving Tunisia greater and better access to the EU market for Tunisia's exports. Furthermore, the resolution calls for further action to support Tunisian exports in order to meet high European standards, in particular as regards food safety rules for agricultural products, which is particularly important for smaller producers. That is why I supported this report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution is a recommendation by Parliament to the Commission to attach particular importance to certain points in the negotiations for a free trade agreement with Tunisia. Negotiations with Tunisia are supported and Tunisia's special position as the most democratic partner in the region is recognised. Tunisia has therefore asked the EU and its member states for this free trade agreement in order to contribute to the stability of the current situation and to act in a supportive manner. The motion for a resolution calls for the Tunisian market to be open to the EU in a balanced, asymmetrical and gradual manner, while at the same time giving Tunisian exports better access to EU markets. The aim is to ensure that Tunisian exports comply with European standards, especially in terms of food safety in agricultural products. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This agreement goes beyond the mere commercial dimension and must be intended to contribute to tunisia's stability with a view to consolidating its democracy and reinstatement of its economy, with a positive impact on consumer and employment prices, the wages of skilled and unqualified workers, as well as the reduction of inequalities. The stability and development of the third countries that are close to us must be one of our priorities.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing.
