In 2012 The Socialists support the launch of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as a sign of support and solidarity for a neighbouring country that has made tremendous progress since the Arab Spring and is engaged in a difficult transition process. In principle, we demand that trade negotiations be used as a tool to regulate sustainable development goals and respect for human rights at the international level, promoting the highest standards of labour, social, health and environmental protection. With regard to the economic conditions of the agreement, we demand particular and differentiated attention to the circumstances of Tunisia, with progressive and asymmetric clauses allowing it to open up internationally, in stages and sectors. We want a progressive trade agreement, which brings clear benefits to all Tunisian and European societies. That is why, once again, we demand maximum transparency, link the agreement to the fight against corruption and fully include Tunisian and European civil societies in the negotiation process. We will continue to defend the debt relief incurred by the old regime and the creation of a joint civil forum that allows citizens to assess and monitor compliance with human rights and sustainability clauses.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Tunisia has come a long way since the Arab Spring and has been the target of terrorist attacks precisely because it is on the road to consolidating its democracy. These attacks had a huge impact on the tourism sector and the economy in general, at a time when Tunisians were already facing a difficult economic crisis, with high unemployment. That is why it is crucial that Europe expresses its solidarity with the Tunisian people and helps them with concrete measures that immediately and directly stimulate its economy. The resolution passed this afternoon contributes to this by encouraging the free trade negotiations with Tunisia launched last October.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the negotiations between the EU and Tunisia on a free trade agreement are an excellent way to help this country. Tunisia's democratic transition has been the most successful in the region and the EU should therefore support Tunisia in its knowledge, sharing experience and, at the same time, promoting the necessary reforms. It is equally important that some of them have already started and cannot stop. The text also notes that financial support and assistance granted by the EU must be provided in a transparent manner and that it would actually benefit its intended beneficiaries. This is one of the main objectives of ensuring that taxpayers' money is used in a targeted manner.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which paves the way for an agreement that must be exemplary to accompany Tunisia's democratic transition and contribute to Tunisia's stability. This agreement will therefore have to be made on a partnership-based model, closely involving Tunisian civil society. The European Parliament also wants the most fragile sectors of the Tunisian economy (agriculture, public procurement, etc.) to be protected through an asymmetrical agreement. Once again, MEPs signalled to the Committee their vision of international trade, based on respect for the ability to legislate for the parties. Anxious to see the Tunisian economy diversify, the European Parliament wants this agreement to be balanced in order to support a fair exchange.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The current framework for trade relations between the EU and Tunisia is governed by the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement signed in 1995, which entered into force in 1998 and laid the foundations for the establishment of a Free Trade Area. On 13 October 2015, the EU and Tunisia resumed negotiations to consolidate a comprehensive and ambitious Free Trade Agreement. As a country in our southern neighbourhood in the Mediterranean basin, it seems clear to us that a Free Trade Agreement is to us. In addition, Tunisia is currently facing serious internal, economic and social security problems, and the implementation of a free trade agreement is therefore a mechanism to facilitate the country's economic reinvigoration and an important contribution to its political and social stabilisation and the consolidation of its democracy. In view of the assumptions underlying the conclusion of the agreement, I believe that it will bring tangible gains for both the European and Tunisian economies.  However, I would like to draw attention to the need for rigorous sectoral assessments and monitoring, especially at agricultural level, to avoid any unexpected negative impacts on the economies of both parties.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the negotiations for a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia that were launched on 13 October. Through these negotiations, the European Union wishes to strengthen its ties with Tunisia and provide additional support. The current environment is difficult given the terrorist strikes the country has suffered, the collapse of the tourism sector - which was an economic engine - and the security instability of the region. At the same time, Tunisia continues to carry out its democratic process and I would like to remind you that the Tunisian dialogue has just received the Nobel Peace Prize. The objective of these negotiations is multiple; there is also a desire to improve market access and investment conditions, as well as to boost growth and employment, especially for young people. Given the country's current economic structure and the sensitivity of certain sectors, the agreement will have to be progressive and asymmetrical. I will be attentive to the progress of trade negotiations, notably through the EU-Tunisia Joint Parliamentary Committee of which I am a member and which allows for regular dialogue with Tunisian parliamentarians.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. Empirical experience shows that there is a good chance of promoting social imbalances in a country whose situation is already sensitive.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade agreements can provide opportunities for European producers while encouraging democratic reforms and economic prosperity in third countries. I welcome the opening of trade negotiations with Tunisia, as this will support the country in its efforts to overcome political and economic challenges and contribute to regional stability. The potential for the EU’s trade agreements to deliver improvements in human rights and environmental standards must be fully realised.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the opening of negotiations on a deep and comprehensive free trade agreement between the EU and Tunisia, because such an agreement is of great political importance from a political point of view, both for stabilisation and for a more socially and economically dynamic Tunisia. We must continue to support the democratisation process in Tunisia. I am in favour of the involvement of the national parliament and civil society, which are essential in this process and will lead to both its facilitation and speeding up. The agreement should be all-encompassing and should therefore include the sectors of agricultural products, services, public procurement, intellectual property rights, public procurement and sustainable development.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. I welcome the opening of negotiations on an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement and hope that the agreement will be ambitious, create great opportunities for growth and jobs, not only for Tunisia but also for the EU. I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal, despite the fact that the measures for a time-limited duty-free import quota for olive oil from Tunisia, which Parliament has just approved, were watered down. My hope is that these temporary measures will become part of the forthcoming free trade agreement.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the recommendation in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia since the conviction that such agreements entail liberalization not only of trade in agricultural products, but also of services, affecting basic social rights. The European Union has also refused to promote an international audit of the odious debt acquired by Ben Ali's regime, which the Tunisian people continue to assume today. Moreover, the negotiation of this agreement does not take into account asymmetry and does not have the participation of Tunisian social organizations and trade unions. Therefore, since the conviction that such an agreement only favours large companies, with a negative impact on workers and small producers on both sides, both Tunisian olive oil producers and those in southern European countries, I voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As I have said in the past, Tunisia remains a priority not only for me but for the rest of the Socialist Group in the Parliament. This vote represents two things: how far Tunisia has come since its political upheaval at the end of 2010 and the preparedness of the EU to reach out to this new democracy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. I am in favour of opening negotiations with Tunisia on the free trade area. I believe that the agreement should contribute to deepening economic cooperation between the EU and Tunisia, which is already at an advanced level thanks to the abolition of tariffs on industrial products, in line with the Association Agreement.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 on 13 October 2015, the European Union and Tunisia started to negotiate an ambitious free trade agreement on the basis of a mandate unanimously approved by the Member States of the Union back in 2011. Trade relations between the EU and Tunisia should provide an opportunity for the growth and convergence of the economies of Tunisia and the European Union, while at the same time contributing to political and democratic stabilisation in Tunisia. The two parties to the negotiations should conclude a gradual and asymmetrical agreement that takes into account the significant economic differences between the two parties in order to demonstrate flexibility, ability to react, innovativeness, transparency and adaptability, and to remember that this agreement, which is beneficial to both parties, should first benefit the tunisian and European economies and should, of course, respect the specificity, sensitivity, culture and local socio-economic spheres without abusing Tunisia's intra-regional trade with the countries of the region.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is committed to free trade. Free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win for consumers in particular. These effects are particularly evident in developing and emerging countries. Z.B. the tiger states show that opening up to free trade is beneficial. ALFA therefore considers this free trade agreement, which is now to be negotiated, to be an important aid to Tunisia's further development, while at the same time benefiting Europe. This sign is all the more important because Tunisia is currently taking important steps towards stable democracy. I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the destabilisation of many Arab countries located in the EU's neighbourhood poses a significant security risk. The rapid stabilisation of these areas is therefore a priority and in the interest of the Union. The EU has always excelled at its soft power, and free trade agreements are one of its instruments. Economic development is an important part of restoring stability in countries that have been through crisis or armed conflict.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Trade Partnership is only part of a larger project under the neighbourly relations between the European Union and Tunisia, set out in the 1995 Mediterranean Association Agreement, which governs the implementation of free trade and agricultural and service provisions. On 17 March 2015, the EU-Tunisia Association Council adopted a new action plan, establishing a privileged partnership to achieve a greater degree of economic integration. It is in the interests of both Tunisia and the European Union to promote and strengthen the regional integration process at level between Tunisia and its neighbouring states, in particular under the Agadir Agreement, and these efforts must be complemented by free trade negotiations between Tunisia and the EU. I therefore welcome the start of negotiations in autumn 2015 with a view to concluding the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Tunisia on the basis of the mandate adopted by the Council in 2011 following the Arab Spring. I believe that this Agreement is not only important because of its trading dimension and that its objective should certainly be to contribute to tunisia's stability, strengthen its democracy and boost its economy, while also having a positive impact on consumer prices and employment, the wages of skilled and unskilled workers and reducing inequalities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ International relations between Tunisia and the European Union go back a long way. The first trade cooperation agreement was concluded in 1969. Negotiations on the EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement began on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of great political importance for the stabilisation and social and economic betterment of Tunisia, which has suffered major losses in the democratisation process.  Last March, the Council of Europe adopted a new action plan that established a privileged partnership to achieve the goal of a greater degree of economic integration. Tunisia is one of the priority countries in neighbourhood policy in relation to southern Mediterranean countries to the European Union. The agreement will benefit both the populations of Europe and Tunisia.  Tunisia has already initiated significant social and economic reforms, and this Agreement will contribute to reducing regional inequalities and developing and diversifying the current agricultural economy. Tunisia, implementing a democratic and political transition, is an example for the entire Middle East and North Africa region.  Economic development is closely linked to political stability, so I support the opening of negotiations believing that this trade agreement can provide additional support to Tunisia in a democratic transition towards a stable pluralistic society.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the resolution opening negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement.  I support the upgrading of EU-Tunisia relations, which have been close and fruitful for many decades. The first trade cooperation agreement was signed by the partners back in 1969. I support close contacts with Tunisia, which is the only country in the Middle East where a process of democratic and political transition is taking place, which can lead to a role model for the whole region. I also welcome that the report encourages the Union to take all possible measures to support Tunisia in its democratic transition to a stable and pluralistic society.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia sets out a framework with which we disagree. It promotes neoliberal policies, like all free trade negotiations, which help large businesses on the rich side, not the ordinary citizen in Tunisia.  Tunisia needs support, but not with the policies promoted by this report that negatively affects both the people in Tunisia and the EU, trying to put EU and Tunisian workers in a framework of "competition" with each other, resulting in wage restraint and the backsliding of the labour rights of those workers who enjoy them. We voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU should first deal with its internal problems of unemployment and the economy and then solve those of African countries. Greece goes out and the EU finances and imports low-cost Tunisian products.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-Tunisia negotiations started on 13 October 2015. These negotiations are of extraordinary political and economic importance for Tunisia, both in terms of democratic stabilisation and market opening processes. Tunisia has taken a significant step on the path of democratic state development, which forms the basis of reforms. The negotiations should also pay particular attention to the interests of the Member States of the European Union, in particular agricultural products.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to establish a comprehensive free trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Tunisia, and welcomes the start of negotiations on this last autumn. The importance of this is also clear to me from a political point of view, given the traditions of relations between European countries and Tunisia, the fact that the EU first concluded an ASSOCIATION agreement with Tunisia from the southern Mediterranean, and the pioneering role that this country played in launching the process of democratisation in the region during the Arab Spring. The EU is Tunisia's largest trading partner, but I agree with the EU approach indicated in the negotiating mandate to take into account the country's difficult economic situation, political and regional characteristics. This justifies the adoption by the EU of gradual market opening, asymmetrical negotiations and agreement as objectives. At the same time, I consider it important and in my work as a Member, I will monitor that the future EU-Tunisia free trade agreement does not disproportionately harm the interests of European farmers and that eu health and environmental standards are properly enforced.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the FREE TRADE AGREEMENT between the EU and Tunisia supports the stable development of Tunisia. This free trade agreement can create a peace-promoting balance for the whole of North Africa by developing eu-Tunisia cooperation.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement between the EU and Tunisia is intended to highlight those points that must be taken into account during the negotiations. We of the 5 Star Movement have expressed our vote in order to protect the sectors that are dearest to us, as Italians, such as the agricultural sector and specifically that of olive oil. In order to represent the interests of small European producers, we have tabled a number of amendments to exclude Tunisian olive oil from further liberalisation. On Thursday, we voted to have a less asymmetrical agreement, which would protect the most sensitive sectors (such as olive oil) and which would provide for a gradual and progressive opening up to tunisia's economic sectors in order to protect small and medium-sized producers throughout southern Europe, italians in the first place. The resolution in general is not negative, but since the amendments proposed by us to protect Italian olive oil have not passed, we have decided not to support it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. This is of course a resolution, but it must be considered that the deepening of Euro-Tunisian trade relations with the conclusion of an ambitious trade partnership must open up prospects for growth and rapprochement for the economies of Tunisia and the European Union. It is desirable that this partnership contribute to tunisia's political and democratic stabilization.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement, as an operational economy bringing about job creation for young people and opportunities for foreign investment is now of utmost importance for the broached democratic transition to succeed. This trade partnership represents not only an opportunity for growth and closer ties between the economies of Tunisia and the EU, but it can also become a stepping stone to facilitate the development of the MENA region as a whole, and set an example for the entire region.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the opening of negotiations for a Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia, as I consider Tunisia to be one of the European Union's priority countries in neighbourhood policy when it comes to southern Mediterranean countries. As Tunisia achieves the most successful democratic transition in the region and has chosen a single political model of economic development among the countries on the southern mediterranean coast, I believe that the Union must take all possible measures to support Tunisia's further transition.  In fact, I believe that this Agreement will contribute to setting high quality standards in terms of sustainable development, in particular in the area of social standards, and that the Government of Tunisia and the European institutions will draw up appropriate provisions to clearly identify the source, origin and traceability of products imported from Tunisia. I believe this Treaty is mutually beneficial.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia free trade agreement, as I believe that the agreement has more than a purely trade dimension.  Tunisia has consolidated its democratic transition since 2011 by declaring a new constitution on 26 January 2014 and holding parliamentary and presidential elections on 26 October and 23 November 2014 respectively.  The free trade agreement will certainly contribute to tunisia's stability, the strengthening of its democracy and the recovery of its economy, with a positive impact on both consumer prices, employment, the wages of skilled and unskilled workers and the reduction of inequalities.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. Empirical experience shows that there is a good chance of promoting social imbalances in a country whose situation is already sensitive.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the opening of negotiations with this important partner. I consider that this agreement has more than just a trade dimension, and that it should seek to contribute to the stability of Tunisia, to the consolidation of its democracy. I want however that the EC and EU continue to monitor the olive oil imports and their effects on European producers in order to find the right economic balance.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement presents a significant risk of unfair competition for European farmers, employees and industrialists with relocations of companies (e.g. the European car industry). I'm voting AGAINST.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and Tunisia are very close and go back a long way, as the European Union is Tunisia's number one trading partner and Tunisia is the 34th trading partner of the European Union. Deepening eu-Tunisia trade relations through an ambitious trade partnership is expected to open up growth and ediers perspectives for both Tunisia and the European Union economy. The partnership is also expected to contribute to the political and democratic stabilisation of Tunisia. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. Tunisia urgently needs support for its economy in order to recuperate from the recession and stabilize the young democracy. The opening of FTA negotiations is the wrong medicine in such a moment, because it hinders rapid progress for Tunisian goods to enter the EU market tariff-free and makes such market access conditional to all kinds of reciprocities which are not on the agenda of urgencies in Tunis and could cost the country a lot in the long run, such as intellectual property rules increasing the price of medicines.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I hope that this agreement will help to ensure a long-term favourable environment in Tunisia, encouraging long-term investment in key, dynamic and value-added sectors of the economy, such as tourism, energy, including renewable energy sources, high-tech services, the digital economy and data exchange; I call on the Commission to include a chapter on investments in order to facilitate mutual foreign direct investment between the EU and Tunisia and to speed up the establishment of a european-Mediterranean investment and trade facilitation procedure.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on opening of negotiations for an EU-Tunisia Free Trade Agreement. The aim of the agreement is to improve market access opportunities and the investment climate, and to support ongoing economic reforms in Tunisia. This agreement builds on the existing free trade arrangement established 20 years ago by the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement, which focuses mainly on trade in goods. The new agreement facilities numerous areas of mutual interest such as trade in different sectors of goods and services, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, investment protection, public procurement and competition policy. The agreement seeks to contribute to the stability of Tunisia, to the strengthening of its democracy and modernisation of its economy by having a positive impact on consumer prices, employment and wages and this is the reason why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. On 13 October 2015, the EU and Tunisia decided to launch a major redevelopment of the current Association Agreement. We are talking about a future agreement that will be of key political importance, since it can lay the groundwork for the institutional stabilization and social and economic dynamization of the country. That is why I believe it is necessary to vote in favour of opening these negotiations.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'As the leader of the Liberal Group in the European Parliament for the follow-up to the political situation in Tunisia, I felt it was very important to support the Commission's proposal, as my liberal colleague de Sarnez put it in her report. Tunisia is one of the few countries in the region that evolved positively after the Arab Spring. That is why Tunisia deserves all possible support, including as an ally against IS.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution contains Parliament's recommendations to the Commission on the recently begun negotiations with Tunisia for a "comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement". While this text contains some good elements (asymmetry of the agreement, publication of the negotiating mandate, better civil society association, sectoral impact studies), it remains in an economic and neoliberal logic. Tunisia occupies a special place in the countries of the Middle East. At the origin of the so-called "Arab Spring", hard hit by terrorists, everything must be done to ensure that its democratic transition succeeds. However, while the social question has not been answered, the EU and its member states offer only poisoned gifts. After the toxic loans that have contributed to the increase in its debt, Tunisia should therefore liberalize its economy, sacrifice its traditional agriculture and its environment, all for the benefit of large European companies. I voted against it and I still call for a real partnership putting the interests of people on both sides of the Mediterranean above the profits of companies and investors. There is an urgent need to take into account the real issues in order to give Tunisian democracy a chance.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution deals with the establishment of a Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, which falls within the wider scope of neighbourhood relations and is governed by the Mediterranean Association Agreement of 1995, which provides for the establishment of a free trade area and the establishment of provisions on agriculture and services.  The opening of negotiations on this agreement is a measure of aid to Tunisia following the barbaric attacks on 26 June 2015 in Sousse. And it does not hide, even if making a hypocritical mention in paragraph 8, that Tunisia has taken in more than 1.8 million refugees from Libya, and that this figure accounts for 16 % of Tunisia's total population. The latter, a direct consequence of the continued interference of the European Union in the Middle East and North Africa. But this solidarity-fronted Free Trade Agreement is, in essence, neo-colonialist, because it wants to impose economic and social policies on Tunisia, which will not benefit the people – on the contrary and once again, this proposal aims to pave the way for European multinationals, which want to reach the agriculture sector and the services sector of that country.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. A further deepening of the Association Agreement with Tunisia would strengthen economic cooperation, especially in the areas of knowledge and freight transport, but would also lead to increased migration, so I voted against the report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted 'in favour' of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the introduction of exceptional autonomous trade measures for the Republic of Tunisia. The economy of the Republic of Tunisia is mainly based on agriculture and mining. Agricultural area accounts for 48% of the country's area. More than 60,000 olive trees are growing across the country, producing more than 150,000 tonnes of oil. Tunisia thus becomes the second exporter of olive oil and the fourth producer of olive oil in the world. Their cultivation has become the main source of livelihood of the inhabitants there, so for good reason olives are called the green treasure of Tunisia. Unfortunately, the Republic of Tunisia was the site of the terrorist attacks (2015), resulting in temporary economic failure of the state. To mention, it is the European Union that remains Tunisia's first trading partner (currently 72% and 75% of Tunisian exports). It is one of the European Union's most recognised trading partners in the Mediterranean, which signed an association agreement with the European Union in July 1995. However, in order to prevent abuses, it is also important to ensure that the autonomous measures envisaged actually benefit the Tunisian economy, which must be conditional on Tunisia complying with the relevant EU rules on the origin of products and related procedures, as well as on tunisia's effective administrative cooperation with the Union.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade policy must always put people and planet before narrow profit-making, as per the Alternative Trade Mandate. Strengthening economic ties and stimulating business in the EU’s relationship with Tunisia is hugely important, but it must also be accompanied with a human element. The economic benefit from a trade deal with Tunisia should be shown to benefit Tunisian citizens and consumers, as well as those most vulnerable in society. Cultural exchange must also follow, creating true dialogue between EU Member States and Tunisia, strengthening civil society engagement and paving the way for collaboration in a number of fields such as cultural and social entrepreneurship.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the motion for this resolution. The conclusion of a trade partnership that will allow for the deepening of trade relations between Tunisia and the Union will not only support the growth of the economy, but can also contribute to the democratic and political stabilisation of the country. Tunisia is the only country in the Middle East and North Africa where the transition to democracy has taken place. The Constitution that was created is a very good example. However, it still needs to be intensively implemented. Tunisia, therefore, with its political transformation and reforms, is a good example for other countries in the region they can be inspired by.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution opening negotiations with Tunisia on a free trade agreement. Tunisia is the cradle of the so-called Islamic State. the Arab Spring and, at the same time, the only country in the MENA region where the process of democratic and political transition has been successfully completed. Deepening trade relations between the European Union and Tunisia by concluding a free trade agreement will hopefully provide an opportunity for growth and convergence of our economies and contribute to stabilisation in Tunisia. We can also see the opening of negotiations as a signal by which the European Union appreciates the successful transition to democracy and the view that Tunisia can serve as an example to other countries in the region in this.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Political and economic instability in the European Union's immediate neighbourhood is causing many threats to our security, including terrorism and uncontrolled immigration. In order to tackle these phenomena at the source of the problem, we need reliable and reliable partners in the North African region; partners who, through strong institutions and a stable economic situation, will be able to provide their citizens with an alternative to fleeing poverty and violence to Europe.  Tunisia fulfils many conditions to become such a reliable partner for Europe, but it needs our support. The negative experiences of recent years, including the disillusionment with the effects of the political transition triggered by the Arab Spring, the disastrous consequences of terrorist attacks on the tourism industry and the pressure from radical Islam, have significantly delayed the process of building a modern Tunisian state. The opening of free trade negotiations with the EU has the opportunity to become a pro-development impulse that will significantly speed up the process. Of course, I am aware of the unequal position of our economies and all the potential problems that may arise during these negotiations, but I believe that both sides will be able to properly identify the areas of contention and find a mutually beneficial compromise. I am convinced that only this kind of cooperation, and as a result, the restoration of a politically and economically stable immediate NEIGHBOURHOOD of the EU, will help to resolve the immigration crisis that has been going on for months. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the negotiations for the conclusion of a free trade agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, as they will bring concrete benefits to the European and Tunisian economies and, consequently, contribute to maintaining the process of democratic and political transition in Tunisia. Political stability and economic development are crucial in establishing prosperity and peace for the Tunisian population.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: "I ask my dear colleagues to imagine a lakeside and a man walking by that lake. You'll see five people drowning in the water. She decides to rescue one because it happens to be her own child. Is what you did morally acceptable? I think I am. In the vicinity of another person there are 10 poor, miserable elderly people in need of care and care. She decides to take care of two of them, because they happen to be her own parents. Is your decision moral? I think so, yes. Migration. We Hungarians, and I think several European countries, believe that we sympathize with the people who have come to escape the various sufferings, but we still believe that we know and want to support our own citizens from our scarce resources. Is it moral? I believe that it is, and that is what the whole EU system should be minded of, starting with the Ombudsman.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I supported this report, which describes in great detail the ombudsman's work. I must say that I welcome the fact that the Ombudsman's activities are increasing.  Furthermore, I also welcome the fact that, in principle, the EU institutions respond positively to the Ombudsman's suggestions, because the Ombudsman is 'useless' if his recommendations and his views are not taken seriously by the competent authorities concerned by his recommendations. Here I think it is good news that 80% of the Ombudsman's initiatives have been taken into account by the European institutions. There is still a reserve of 20%, and I think that is what we need to work on, and hopefully that number of 20% will decrease in the future.  What I think is important is that citizens can contact the Ombudsman electronically via a website, because simple access to the Ombudsman is the basis for the success of this institution, and I welcome the fact that incentives are therefore increasing and that the Ombudsman communicates electronically with EU citizens.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr In general, the ombudsman's primary task is to promote citizens' rights. If there is such an item in each Member State of the European Union, there is such an Ombudsman or ombudsman, then the duties of the European Ombudsman are much broader. For example, in 2014, issues such as fundamental rights, lobbying systems, transparency of authorities, European Union institutes, etc. was the Ombudsman's focus, which is very good because, for example, between 20% and 30% of all complaints were directly related to the principle of transparency and non-compliance with it.  For example, to some extent, it is clear why access to different documents is restricted, but still our citizens have a right to know what is happening in the European Union. For example, the EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement, which has already been mentioned several times. Why are conversations secret? There is an urgent need to be as open as possible to our citizens.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm cúpla focal a rá faoin ábhar seo mar is Éireannach í Emily O’Reilly agus is cara liom í agus dar ndóigh tá jab iontach déanta aici ó toghadh í don phost tábhachtach seo. Fiú i mbliain amháin 2014, tháinig 2 163 gearán trasna a binse agus chuaigh sí trí gach ceann de na gearáin sin go mion agus d’éirigh léi teacht ar réiteach ar a lán díobh. Dhún sí cuid de na cásanna agus thug sí an míniú go raibh uirthi é sin a dhéanamh, agus i gcásanna eile thug sí moladh nó breith. Fáiltím freisin roimh an bplean go mbeadh straitéis cúig bliana ag an Ombudsman agus freisin go mbeadh sí, as a meon féin, in ann iniúchadh a oscailt ar ábhar áirithe. Dá bhrí sin, tá jab iontach á dhéanamh aici agus molaim í agus táim bródúil aisti.  Mar fhocal scoir, ba mhaith liom tú féin a mholadh as an dea-jab a rinne tú sa chathaoir inniu. Lean ar aghaidh leis an dea-obair, a Uachtaráin!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman launched 342 inquiries into maladministration in the European Union during 2014. The annual report highlights the Ombudsman's increased focus on issues such as conflict of interest, whistleblowing, transparency of lobbying and the problem of revolving doors. These issues are of major importance in raising awareness of good administrative practices. The 5-Star Movement has always fought for transparency within the institutions, which is why I voted in favour of the European Ombudsman's annual report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution is made on the annual report submitted by the Ombudsman. Specifically, it refers to its work during 2014. The motion for a Resolution accentuates several positive elements of the Ombudsman's work, within a general context of growing citizen distrust of the European Union. This is the case, for example, in the case of the investigation into 'revolving doors' within the European Commission, the infringement of access to information by the European institutions or the recommendation made to create a mechanism against The infringement of individual rights by Frontex. It also highlights the need to increase resources for the Ombudsman's Office and that 20% of cases of non-compliance with the recommendations still persist. However, I have decided to abstain as our amendments on such sensitive issues as the dual-use (civilian and military) fate of European funds to third countries participating in the Horizon 2020 programme (such as Israel) or the end of Frontex's joint deportation policies have not been included. I also understand it wrong to congratulate the European Commission on its transparency in the TCI negotiations, for obvious reasons.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. The aim of this text is to congratulate the European Mediator Emily O'Reilly for her activities in 2014. While the European Ombudsman has promoted greater transparency, particularly in the areas of lobbying and clinical trials, it remains insufficient. In addition, the mediator called on Frontex to set up a complaint system for migrants when they are presumed to be victims of human rights abuses.  Finally, MEP Sylvie Goddyn tabled an amendment in committee to remove the provision of the report which congratulates the European Ombudsman on obtaining this new avenue of appeal. As this amendment has not been adopted, I cannot support this text.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014, because it deals with complaints from EU citizens, associations and businesses about possible mismanagement by EU agencies or other institutions.  The activities of the European Ombudsman help European institutions to become more efficient, better run and more friendly to citizens.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Ombudsman (or European Ombudsman) investigates complaints about maladministration in the institutions and bodies (with the exception of the European Court of Justice) of the European Union. These include, for example, administrative irregularities, discrimination, abuse of power or even non-response to letters. Any EU citizen, as well as any company, association or association or other body established in the EU, can lodge a complaint. Since 1 October 2013, the post of EU Ombudsman has been carried out by Emily O'Reilly, who was re-elected by the European Parliament on 16 December 2014. For 2014, 23 072 citizens used the Ombudsman's services. It dealt with 2079 complaints, launched 342 investigations and completed 400 investigations. Most of the complaints or investigations concerned the European Commission, followed by EU agencies. I welcome the 2014 annual report and Mrs O'Reilly's work and congratulate her not only on the achievement, but also on the good cooperation with Parliament. Your recent efforts on the transparency of the authorisation of plant protection products by the European Commission are commendable.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution in question here gives satisfaction to the activities of the European Ombudsman (Emily O'Reilly) for 2014. The latter conducted an investigation into the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership which led to the publication by the Council of the directives the EU uses to negotiate TTIP and the announcement by the European Commission that it would increase the transparency of lobbying activities and expand access to documents. However, this is still very inadequate. In addition, the Ombudsman has created a transparency register, in which more than 7,000 lobbying organisations have voluntarily registered. In addition, the Ombudsman has promoted greater transparency in clinical trials. Finally, the Ombudsman called on Frontex to set up a complaint procedure for migrants when they are presumed to be victims of human rights abuses. In committee, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn had called for the withdrawal of the passage which, in the report, refers to this procedure and welcomes it. Since the amendment was not adopted, I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency I would like to confirm that I voted against this report. I approve of the investigations into revolving-door activities and corruption among senior bureaucrats, but I feel more could be done to combat this. I cannot overlook the lack of transparency with regard to the negotiations on TTIP or the suggested increase in the Ombudsman’s budget.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I want to thank European Ombudsman Mrs O’Reilly for her excellent work. Her office does its job extremely well, even though they are only 67 people. I think her work has been very significant, especially with regard to Frontex and the transparency of TTIP negotiations. I hope she will continue her excellent work, not only on the basis of complaints by EU citizens, but of her own accord as well. There is still a lot of work to be done and my expectations – as well as those of the European citizens – are high.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. In 2014, the Ombudsman opened 325 inquiries on the basis of complaints and 17 own-initiative inquiries, closed 387 inquiries based on complaints and 13 own-initiative inquiries. The majority of complaints were made by individual citizens, companies, associations and other legal entities. The Ombudsman identified 39 cases of maladministration in the closed cases and made 12 draft recommendations. The draft recommendation shall be drafted in cases where the contested authority may remedy maladministration or where maladministration is serious or has a global impact. The European Ombudsman works closely with his colleagues in the Member States. This cooperation takes place within the European Network of Ombudsmen, which brings together national and regional ombudsmen. In many cases, complaints that are not falling within the Ombudsman's remit are best dealt with by the members of this network, i.e. ombudsmen from member states or regions.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution gives a satisfaction to the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2014, Emily O'Reilly. But I do not forget that it was this "European Ombudsman" who asked Frontex to set up a procedure for filing complaints in favour of migrants when they are presumed to be "victims of violations of their fundamental rights". In committee, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn tabled an amendment to remove the provision of the report which congratulates the European Ombudsman for obtaining this new avenue of appeal. As this amendment has not been adopted, I have opposed this text by which Parliament gives its satisfaction to the 'European Ombudsman'.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved the European Ombudsman's 2014 annual report. In particular, it highlights the investigations it has opened into transparency within the EU institutions, transparency of lobbying activities, fundamental rights, ethical issues, trade negotiations, etc.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the great work and enormous effort made by the Ombudsman's institution in 2014. This is a work which has highlighted the need for further progress and improvement in the functioning of the European public administration, on such sensitive issues as revolving doors, the improvement of transparency in the negotiations (including that of TTE) and the critical and constructive view of Frontex's work, as well as the permanent defence of the fundamental rights of Europeans. Through this report I would also like to thank and acknowledge the Ombudsman for her work on the issue of migration and asylum, where she has highlighted the defence of European values and the need to give a common answer from the outset.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman is a figure provided for in Article 228 TFEI which is responsible for receiving complaints about maladministration in the activities of the Institutions of the European Union. On 16 December 2014, at the Strasbourg plenary session, the European Parliament re-elected Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman. The Cabezón Ruiz report, which I supported with my vote, presented a positive picture of the activities carried out by this institutional figure in 2014. Of the more than 2 000 complaints received, more than a thousand of the Ombudsman provided advice and, in a further 325 cases, launched a related inquiry. The strategic investigations, carried out on their own initiative and made possible also thanks to the appointment of a special coordinator, were important. In general, the Ombudsman's work has been positively marked by a particular focus on respect for citizens' right to participate in EU decision-making and, in particular, on the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI). I therefore decided to support the report presented to Parliament.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. The report on the Ombudsman's activities is quite positive, and we also welcome the Ombudsman's action during 2014. But we disagree with certain views contained in this report as "the celebration" of "the progress made on transparency" in the TIC negotiations, or the warmness with which frontex is concerned, hot returns and the lack of refugee rights in this context of crisis. Our group tabled amendments to this text on these issues, but they did not succeed, so we are forced not to give full support to the report. However, we welcome the Ombudsman's actions to defend citizens' rights and her work to create a network between different EU levels.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I welcome the adoption of the Ombudsman's 2014 activity report congratulating Mrs O'Reilly on her election and work, and welcoming and supporting the Ombudsman's greater use of her powers to launch strategic investigations on her own initiative. I also support the re reminding myself that the Ombudsman has the capacity and obligation to control Parliament as part of his task of ensuring good administration for EU citizens.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I had to vote against this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014, Mrs Emily O'Reilly. I certainly recognize some of Ms. O'Reilly's accomplishments. In particular, it sought to improve transparency in the transatlantic trade and investment partnership negotiations. However, I was forced to reject this report in the sense that, while it knows how to highlight the progress made by the Ombudsman, he remains very blind to his failures and mistakes. I cannot the forthment that Mrs O'Reilly has asked Frontex to set up a complaint procedure for migrants. We walk on our heads giving a blank cheque to illegal immigrants who would have a weapon against our own authorities. This means that, even when the Union claims to give itself a role as protector of our borders and our citizens, it apologises directly and leaves it possible for anyone to sue its own representatives! Such an aberration could not receive my approval. That is why I rejected this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman is one of the few existing forms of control that European citizens have at their disposal vis-à-vis the European institutions. I believe that the European Ombudsman cooperates positively with other bodies working in the Member States to protect citizens, such as the European Network of Ombudsmen and the Committees on Petitions, and that its activities have so far produced good results. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. Parliament welcomes the inquiry launched at the Ombudsman's initiative in 2014 on the following key topics: transparency of the EU institutions, transparency in lobbying and clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues, citizens' participation in eu decision-making, EU-funded projects and programmes and EU competition policy. The European Parliament also appreciates the fact that the Ombudsman pays more attention to transparency in lobbying and her efforts to create a mandatory Transparency Register so that citizens can know who is trying to influence EU decision-makers. Parliament also congratulates the Ombudsman on her inquiry into citizens' right to participate in the EU decision-making process, in particular in the context of the functioning of the ECI; notes that in 2014 it invited organisers of the European Citizens' Initiative, civil society organisations and other stakeholders to comment on the European Citizens' Initiative with a view to improving it. Parliament notes with concern that the representatives of petitioning organisations are asking for better harmonisation and better administration of methods for collecting and registering signatures. He hopes that proposals will be made for improvements, in particular with regard to the current technical and data protection barriers in the signature collection process.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the information available, the European Ombudsman works closely with his colleagues in the Member States. This cooperation is carried out within the framework of the European Network of Ombudsmen, which includes national and regional ombudsmen, petitions committees and similar bodies from the Member States of the European Union, candidate countries and the European Economic Area and other countries in the Schengen area. Parliament's Committee on Petitions is a full member of the Network. In addition, the Ombudsman meets regularly with members and officials of the Institutions of the Union to discuss ways of improving the quality of administration, to stress the importance of proper complaint handling for them and to ensure that his recommendations and reports are properly used. Of course, it is possible to further improve the Ombudsman's activities, but his work so far has met basic expectations, so I voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 At the last plenary session, I also supported the report on the Work of the European Ombudsman for 2014.  The maximum number of complaints received by the Ombudsman relates to (non)transparency in the EU institutions, and I see the biggest problem there. It is such a large European apparatus, which of course does a lot of good things, but all too many things are true behind closed doors or very lackive communication with the public. Not only transparency of the work of the institutions, but also transparent work by lobbyists is essential in such a range of content and in view of the importance of decisions taken within the institutions.  More than 23 000 citizens who asked the Ombudsman for assistance in 2014 are seeing that people have also perceived someone at European level who can help or protect them, and we must also give the European Ombudsman greater power.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The role of the European Ombudsman is essential to bring to light, following complaints from private citizens or at the end of own-initiative inquiries, cases of maladministration by the European institutions. Through its work, it makes it possible to identify and remove certain behaviours that are harmful to the rights of European citizens, restoring confidence in the role of the institutions and making their work more transparent and effective. In the light of this, I welcome the work carried out by the Ombudsman and set out in his annual report for 2014 and I particularly welcome the fact that the Ombudsman has taken a more active and dynamic role in initiating strategic inquiries on his own initiative, not only to ensure good administration and greater transparency in the day-to-day work of the institutions but also in the management of EU-funded projects and programmes. , such as Horizon 2020, in international negotiations, such as those relating to TTIP, or in the protection of human rights, with particular regard to frontex's mandate.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Ombudsman has asked Frontex to set up a complaint procedure for migrants when they are presumed to be victims of human rights abuses. In committee, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn tabled an amendment to remove the provision of the report which congratulates the European Ombudsman for obtaining this new avenue of appeal. As this amendment was not adopted, I objected to this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman plays an essential role within the European Union, which is to help the EU institutions become more transparent, effective and close to citizens, thereby strengthening their confidence in the Union.  Yours is a guarantee figure for the protection of European citizens and has the task of ensuring that citizens' rights are fully respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards, as is expected of the Union's institutions, bodies or bodies. 2014 was an extremely productive year for the establishment of the European Ombudsman, as it began to implement the new 'Towards 2019' strategy, which places particular emphasis on the strategic issues of public administration in the European Union affecting millions of Europeans. The European Parliament must continue to support the current European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, as she did an excellent job in 2014 in her task of assisting the INSTITUTIONS of the European Union in order to provide European citizens and residents with the best possible service, using transparency as a guarantee of better administration.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is satisfied with the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2014. It takes up the main issues on which the Ombudsman has intervened. Firstly, his investigation into the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) would have led to the publication of the guidelines used in the negotiation of the agreement. The Ombudsman is also the originator of a register that lists no less than 7000 lobbies.  However, it is important to remember that the European Ombudsman has asked Frontex to facilitate the filing of complaints by illegal migrants if they feel they are victims of human rights abuses, which will limit the expulsions of individuals who are present illegally on our territory. That is why I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ombudsman is responsible for receiving complaints about cases of maladministration arising in the activities of the institutions of the European Union. For 2014, the Ombudsman initiated 325 complaints and 17 own-initiative inquiries and concluded 387 complaint-based investigations, as well as 13 own-initiative inquiries. In 2014, the Ombudsman acted on 2,163 complaints received. In 1,217 cases, the Ombudsman's services consisted of advice or case transfer, in 621 cases the complainants were informed that they could no longer receive additional advice, and in 325 cases investigations were initiated. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Mrs Emily O'Reilly has successfully fulfilled her work as european Ombudsman, given her report for 2014, and I believe that she is the right person to continue working within the institutions of the European Union in the coming year.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The European Ombudsman represents, albeit without any real powers of influence, a form of control given to European citizens. In the year under review, the Ombudsman opened 325 complaint-based inquiries and 17 own-initiative inquiries. The main sources of complaint were individual citizens (335) and businesses, associations and other legal entities (52). These controls mainly concerned the European Commission. Where possible, the Ombudsman seeks to achieve a positive result by working towards a friendly conciliation satisfactory to both complainants and the institution concerned. In 2014, friendly conciliations were found in 133 cases and in 163 cases the Ombudsman considered that no further inquiry was justified. Finally, it is right to point out that the European Ombudsman works closely with his counterparts in the Member States, such as the European Network of Ombudsmen, which includes national and regional ombudsmen, committees on petitions and the corresponding bodies of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Every year, the European Parliament reports on the activity of the European Ombudsman. Since October 2013, The Irish Emily O'Reilly has held this position. The European Ombudsman is the bridge between citizens and the European institutions. Its mission is to strengthen the rights of European citizens by investigating cases of maladministration in European institutions and bodies. It is therefore an essential element of democratic control within the European Union. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the Ombudsman's investigations which aim to improve transparency within the European institutions.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the Annual Report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. With regard to the issues of complaints in the Ombudsman's annual report, it appears that the issue of public access to documents of the EU institutions is clearly predominant and has triggered a large number of complaints. Of all closed inquiries in 2014, 20-30% of complaints concerned transparency and in particular the institutions' refusal to allow access to documents and/or information. This shows that the EU institutions need to carry out their work in a more transparent way in order to promote good governance and ensure the participation of civil society. I believe that openness and access to documents, in particular by the Commission, in accordance with Article 15 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 42 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, are an essential part of the system of institutional checks and balances. In particular, there is a need for greater openness in the ongoing negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). The report highlighted these elements and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman, Emily O’Reilly. The work of the Ombudsman has been instrumental in holding EU processes and officials to account in many ways. Of note are recent own-initiative investigations which sought to expose the lack of transparency within TTIP and investigations into ‘revolving doors’ between lobbyists and EU officials. The report also notes how as a result of this office’s inquiries that the European Central Bank has disclosed a letter to the Irish Government on the financial crisis, and that the Commission has followed the Ombudsman’s recommendation to release documents on the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy. For these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a good analysis of activities of the European Ombudsman for the year 2014. I particularly welcome the own initiative investigations regarding transparency of the European institutions as well as fundamental rights and lobbying and the fact that full powers of the Ombudsman are used to make our Union better. I greatly appreciate the work of the European Ombudsman as it contributes to legitimacy, transparency and the overall functioning of the European institutions and brings them closer to the citizens of the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report starts with an analysis of the European Ombudsman's work in 2014, but contains, beyond that, several interesting ideas. For example, the Ombudsman is encouraged to make a more active contribution, within the limits of his mandate, to the prevention of conflicts of interest; it is also generally encouraged to make greater use of the power to launch own-initiative investigations, in particular with regard to the financing of projects aimed at reducing disparities in development. I voted without hesitation in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it gives a realistic feedback of activities of the European Ombudsman’s office. I was concerned, however, by the quite negative tone of the original report with regards to the TTIP negotiations. The text, as adopted now, is fairly balanced, commending the openness of the TTIP talks as promoted by the European Commission. It has to said that no negotiations ever before had this level of transparency allowing close public scrutiny during the process.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Enabled to receive complaints from any citizen or company resides in the European Union, the Meditator is an important reference to be used in cases of maladministration by a European institution or agency or violation of fundamental rights. In 2014 alone, the Ombudsman dealt with more than 2 000 complaints and 23 072 citizens sought assistance from his services. Important figures denote the growing role it has played over the twenty years since its inception.  Access to information and the institutions' demand for transparency account for 20-30% of complaints. Thanks to the Ombudsman's role, it has been possible to improve access to EU documents by ensuring greater transparency and also to enable a very wide audience to receive information on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. I welcome the new organisational structure and the appointment of an inquiry coordinator, as well as the fact that the Ombudsman has the power to launch strategic inquiries on his own initiative. These are all elements that increase its function and role and, at the same time, the confidence of citizens in the European institutions.  I voted in favour of this report and I share the positive assessment made by the European Parliament of the seriousness and professionalism of the european Ombudsman's action.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and congratulate Emily O'Reilly on her re-election as European Ombudsman, as well as on her excellent work.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014 concerns an important part of the European reality.  Efforts are being made to speed up and improve judicial procedures in Europe to a large extent concern the activities of the European Ombudsman and in this sense his role is important. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure relating to the work of the European Ombudsman which, like all the institutions, is linked to the greatest possible transparency, thus ensuring good administration while ensuring the participation of civil society. All the requests submitted to that body are relied on by one of the institutions on which the citizens of Europe rely most and, from this point of view, it must be ensured that it is as efficient as possible, while respecting the necessary public access to it. In this respect, I welcome the excellent work done by the European Ombudsman in the role of Emily O'Reilly.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a MEMBER of the PETI Commission, I can see quite closely the work to which the European Ombudsman is subjected, to which I would be happy, if I could, to give more resources in the face of greater public awareness. I can assure you that it is not easy to extricate one another among the bushes of Overlapping European standards that make even the most ligi stumble upon duty, and between officials who are sometimes very cooperative while at other times deserve a wash of their heads to remind them that they work FOR the citizens. I voted in favour of this report, which takes a rather faithful picture of the tasks carried out annually by the European Ombudsman's office and which adequately underlines that this figure must be publicised in order to make it available to more and more citizens who may need it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2012, the European Ombudsman promoted a strategic own-initiative inquiry into Frontex, which resulted in the proposal for a complaints mechanism open to all. In 2015, this recommendation was supported by the European Parliament and is reflected today in the proposal put forward by the European Commission for the establishment of a European Border and Coast Guard Agency. This is one of the most successful examples of such surveys, which remain a priority for the re-elected Ombudsman. It is also notelike the emphasis placed during 2014 on transparency as a guarantee of good administration, essential for the proper functioning of the State. During that year, in this and other topics, such as competition and concursais procedures, more than 2,000 complaints were lodged, which resulted in some kind of action by the Ombudsman.  I support this report and welcome the work done by the Ombudsman in 2014.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the report by the European Ombudsman, who has done an excellent job in taking numerous initiatives to increase the efficiency of the institution he represents. Some of these initiatives concern the appointment of an investigation coordinator and the introduction of new internal rules on reports of wrongdoing by employees, thus bringing the first positive results. I would also like to congratulate the Ombudsman on his inquiries into transparency within the EU institutions, the transparency of lobbying and clinical trials, as well as all those relating to the protection of fundamental rights, as well as those on EU-funded projects and programmes and its competition policy.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Ensuring citizens’ rights are fully respected and the right to good administration is constantly pursued reflect the highest standards expected of the institutions, bodies, offices and agencies of the Union. In this sense there is no doubt that the European Ombudsman plays a vital role in helping EU institutions become more open, effective and citizen-friendly with the aim of strengthening citizens’ confidence in the Union. The results of the Eurobarometer survey of May 2015 are nonetheless worrying: 40% of citizens trust in the European Union and 46% do not. It is commendable that the institutions have complied with 80% of the Ombudsman’s proposals but this needs to be increased.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2015, Ombudsman Emily O' Reilly presented her annual report following inquiries based on complaints from individuals, businesses and associations, totalling 325, in addition to a further 17 inquiries conducted on her own initiative. The legal basis for the European Ombudsman's mandate is Article 228 TFEI, under which the Ombudsman is empowered to receive complaints about maladministration in the activities of the Institutions of the European Union. The key themes of the Ombudsman's inquiries were: transparency within the EU institutions, lobbying and clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues, citizen participation in EU decision-making, EU-funded projects and programmes and EU competition policy. I am in favour of the work carried out by the European Ombudsman in the hope that he will continue to contribute and develop mechanisms for preventing conflicts of interest at all levels of the EU institutions, bodies and agencies.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution is made on the annual report submitted by the Ombudsman. Specifically, it refers to its work during 2014. The motion for a Resolution accentuates several positive elements of the Ombudsman's work, within a general context of growing citizen distrust of the European Union. This is the case, for example, in the case of the investigation into 'revolving doors' within the European Commission, the infringement of access to information by the European institutions or the recommendation made to create a mechanism against The infringement of individual rights by Frontex.
