It also highlights the need to increase resources for the Ombudsman's Office and that 20% of cases of non-compliance with the recommendations still persist. However, I have decided to abstain as our amendments on such sensitive issues as the dual-use (civilian and military) fate of European funds to third countries participating in the Horizon 2020 programme (such as Israel) or the end of Frontex's joint deportation policies have not been included. I also understand it wrong to congratulate the European Commission on its transparency in the TCI negotiations, for obvious reasons.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Eurobarometer estimates as of May 2015, 40% of citizens have confidence in the European Union, while 46% are distrustful. A good deal of this dissatisfaction stems from the institutions' lack of capacity to respond concretely and in a reasonable time to the needs of citizens and the limited ability to make individual rights feel protected. In this context, the role of the European Ombudsman is essential, first and foremost as an instrument for monitoring the transparency and correctness of administrations, which must reflect the highest standards expected of the Union's bodies and agencies. Making the institutions feel closest to the citizens increases confidence: on this we must work, in line with the ability to implement incisive policies that respond to the most widespread needs and needs. In this, the Ombudsman has demonstrated positive activism, in particular by using the power to launch strategic investigations on his own initiative, for example on the transparency of lobbying activities, clinical trials, ethical issues, citizen participation in decision-making, EU-funded programmes and competition policy. I believe that the road is right and must be pursued, with the full support and contribution of the European Parliament.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman was re-elected by Parliament in December 2014. The Ombudsman's activities are communicated annually, and the parliamentary report welcomed the report. The Ombudsman's activities contribute to making the institutions more citizen-like. Parliament welcomes the ombudsman's focus on transparency as a guarantee of good administration. The Ombudsman deals with complaints and remediations of maladministration in the EU institutions.  Its activities cover transparency, fundamental rights, ethical issues, citizens' participation in EU decision-making and EU programmes. I would stress that intervention in the process of EU legislation is not within the ombudsman's remit. Twice as many complaints outside his resicing came to his office as complaints that actually affected him; this shows that citizens need to be informed of their rights in as many languages as possible. In 2014, the Ombudsman launched a consultation and made recommendations to the institutions concerned in order to make the ECI easier and more transparent. The Ombudsman examined of his initiative the respect for fundamental rights in the implementation of cohesion policy in the Member States. In 2014, most ombudsman inquiry (204) was launched against the European Commission. Most of the complaints received concerned access to information and documents. Proposals to improve EU administration have been met by 80% of the institutions. I supported the report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The activities of the European Ombudsman require particular attention in view of the scope of his activities. Following her re-election as European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly continued to conduct courageous inquiries and make useful recommendations, in particular with regard to issues such as insufficient transparency of the EU institutions, lobbying activities, clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues, certain European expenditure, competition policy or the position of citizens. The report accepts and supports initiatives taken at the Ombudsman's request: the procedure for refugees to lodge complaints in the event of violations of their fundamental rights, the improvement of the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative, the interactive Wish List for Europe programme launched before the European elections, better access for people with disabilities to the institutions. In view of the positive assessment of the Ombudsman's work, I voted 'in favour'.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Ombusdman investigates complaints about poor administration by EU institutions or other EU bodies on the basis of complaints which are lodged by citizens or residents of the EU or by EU-based associations or businesses. I voted in favour of this report as the work of the Ombudsman induces further transparency. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the European Ombudsman should have greater power to launch investigations in order to have a transparent Union.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report welcomes the European Ombudsman's efforts in 2014 to increase transparency within EU institutions, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations and lobby groups. He also reviews several investigations by the Ombudsman, relating to the protection of fundamental rights in EU cohesion policy, for example. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which takes stock of the European Ombudsman's investigations for 2014, and thus helps to identify its main areas of action. The European Ombudsman, which investigates cases of maladministration against the European institutions, plays an important role in promoting greater transparency and governance as well as ensuring respect for the rights of European citizens.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Ombudsman had expressed the wish that migrants could file a complaint when they felt that their fundamental rights were not being respected. In committee, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn had tabled an amendment against the provision of the report congratulating the Ombudsman for obtaining this new avenue of appeal. Unfortunately, this amendment has not been adopted, and I will vote against this report, in line with our position on this scheme.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report received my full support, not only because it welcomes and encourages initiatives such as better access to institutions for people with disabilities, but also because it supports efforts such as the creation of mandatory transparency of lobbying registers in the composition of so-called 'expert groups', drug research and, in particular, the use of Horizon 2020 funds. In particular, the use of funds is at the heart of a number of institutional issues, which in turn affect Member States directly. Above all, clarity when it comes to how funds are allocated is essential to ensure trust in the Member States themselves and between Member States throughout the European Union.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 While the role of the Ombudsman is essentially a task, we consider that this resolution is trying to derail it. The priority should be the fight against corruption within the institutions, not the targeting of FRONTEX officials, nor the alleged fight against non-existent discrimination.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament intends to continue to support and promote the figure of the Ombudsman and his actions. The aim we have from Europe is to ensure that the Union institutions provide the best possible public service to citizens and to ensure that their rights are respected. The Ombudsman contributes to this being an effective reality by being empowered, as established by the TFEU, to receive complaints concerning cases of maladministrating in the activities of the European institutions. The entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty extends these powers and includes requests for possible mismanagement under the Common Foreign and Security Policy, including the Common Security and Defence Policy. When we talk about maladministrating we mean cases where a public body does not comply with the rules that have been established or when it does not comply with the principles of the European Union. In this regard, cases such as the blocking in the Council of the Directive against discrimination or non-ratification of the Marrakesh Treaty could fall within the scope of the Ombudsman's functions.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, presented to the Committee on Petitions the activity report of 2014, when she opened 342 inquiries into maladministration in the European Union. Key issues in the Ombudsman's inquiries concern transparency within the EU institutions, transparency of lobbying and clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues, citizen participation in EU decision-making, EU-funded projects and programmes and EU competition policy. In particular, the Ombudsman opened own-initiative inquiries and made recommendations to call on the Council and the Commission to be more transparent in the TTIP negotiations. The 5 Star Movement has always fought to bring transparency within the institutions, which is why I voted in favour of the European Ombudsman's annual report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2014, the Ombudsman opened 325 complaints and 17 own-initiative inquiries. The complaints came mainly from individual citizens (335) and from undertakings, associations and other legal entities. As regards the origin of complaints by country, Spain topped the list (309), followed by Germany (219), Poland (208) and Belgium (147). Of the 342 surveys opened by the European Ombudsman, 204 (59.6%) european commission, 47 (13.7%) eu agencies, 29 (8.5%) to other organs, 32 (9.4%) European Personnel Selection Service (EPSO), 12 (3.8 %) European Parliament, 13 (3.8%) European External Action Service and 11 (3.2%) European Anti-Fraud Office. In 2014, the Ombudsman followed up on 2163 complaints received. In 1217 cases, his services provided advice or transferred the case in 621 cases, the complainant was informed that no further action could be taken and, in 325 cases, an investigation was opened. The Ombudsman's budget is an independent section of the EU budget. The Ombudsman's 2014 budget was EUR 9 857 002 and the institution's establishment plan contained 67 jobs. I voted in favour.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman plays a sensitive and significant role in bringing to light cases of maladministration, at EU level, reported by citizens. The Ombudsman therefore makes it possible, in some way, to reduce the distance between citizens and institutions, giving the former the opportunity to denounce the disservices and misdeeds of the Union's institutions and bodies and thus to demand respect for the right to good administration enshrined in Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. We welcome the ombudsman's work in 2014, especially with regard to the investigations launched into transparency within the EU institutions, transparency of lobbying and clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues, EU-funded projects and programmes and, not least, the participation of citizens in EU decision-making. I therefore declare my vote in favour of this report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ombudsman opened 342 inquiries, of which 325 were based on complaints and 17 were own-initiative inquiries. The vast majority (59.6%) the European Commission. The rapporteur proposes the adoption of the 2014 annual report and welcomes the inquiries initiated by the Ombudsman, in particular on transparency in the EU institutions and transparency in the activities of interest groups. This is a usual procedure. Each year, the European Parliament assses and approves a report on the activities of the European Ombudsman. Its intervention is limited to the relationship between the EU institutions and legislation and the citizens of their Member States. Generally speaking, we agree with the above in the report. However, we do not follow and cannot accept the indirect support it gives to frontex's code of conduct for joint return operations and repatriation flights.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly in 2014. The final budget has made it possible to note the tireless work of my colleague, who has used all the instruments within her competence in favour of greater transparency of the European institutions, ensuring a close fight against maladministration. I consider the Ombudsman's intention to encourage initiatives to help minorities, such as refugees and people with disabilities, to be noble. Furthermore, your initiative to host the 'Your wish list for Europe' event is a very good example of respect for subsidiarity.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained as I was not completely satisfied with report.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the European Ombudsman, which is a useful means of monitoring citizens.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. Mrs O Reilly's effort is commendable, given the short time since her election. Her role as European Ombudsman in helping the EU institutions become more open, effective and citizen-friendly, with a view to strengthening citizens' confidence in the Union, is very difficult. The idea of European integration must be consistent with more transparency and control of its institutions. In view of last May's Eurobarometer, public confidence in the EU is only 40%, but the lack of this is close to 46%. In addition, there is 20% of the Ombudsman's proposals, with which the institutions have not complied.  There is still a long way to go in areas such as transparency, the rule of law, ethics, the fight against corruption, the management of conflicts of interest in the public sector, transparency in clinical trials and, above all, openness in TTIP negotiations.  For these reasons I am voting in favour of the report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to welcome the Ombudsman’s greater use of her power to launch investigations on her own initiative such as on transparency in the TTIP negotiations, how Frontex ensures the respect of fundamental rights of migrants who are subject to forced returns, and composition of the Commission’s expert groups, clinical trials and lobby activities as well as her work towards a mandatory Transparency Register. Key investigations for 2014 have been carried on, such as the ones on the participation of citizens in EU decision-making, on EU funded projects and programmes, and on EU competition policy. The Ombudsman plays a vital role in helping EU institutions become more open, effective and citizen-friendly with the aim of strengthening citizens’ confidence in the Union, and I believe this report will help the Ombudsman in ensuring that these objectives are met.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman works closely with his colleagues in the Member States. This cooperation is carried out within the framework of the European Network of Ombudsmen, which includes national and regional ombudsmen, petitions committees and similar bodies from the Member States of the European Union, candidate countries and the European Economic Area and other countries in the Schengen area. Parliament's Committee on Petitions is a full member of the Network. The Ombudsman also meets regularly with members and officials of the Institutions of the Union to discuss ways to improve the quality of administration, to stress the importance of proper complaint handling for them and to ensure that his recommendations and reports are properly exploited.  The Ombudsman's budget is an autonomous section of the European Union budget. The Ombudsman's budget for 2014 was EUR 9 857 002 and the institution has 67 posts in its establishment plan.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with very bearing in mind the role that the European Union must play in the misconduct of some public servants. From the EU and very specifically from the figure of the European Ombudsman, these wrongdoings must be fought for the ethics and founding principles of the EU.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Annual Report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014, the work of which I believe is of fundamental importance in order to ensure a more transparent, effective and participatory European Union for citizens.  The European institutions are undoubtedly going through the most difficult phase in their history. The political crisis in the Union is putting the very idea of Europe at risk, and the values at the foundation of its construction are at the same time as the growing and widespread distrust of European citizens.  In this climate of uncertainty and general disappointment with regard to the EU institutions, the European Ombudsman has been an important point of reference for the bodies of European citizens, who have approached this institution mainly to denounce issues related to the transparency of the EU institutions and access to the documentation they produce.  Finally, I would like to congratulate Emily O'Reilly on her re-election as European Ombudsman, who has done an excellent job in recent years by giving a voice to thousands of European citizens and providing them with assistance, in the name of transparency and the principle of good administration that have certainly characterised her tenure.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. Emily O'Reilly is doing an excellent job. Her experience as a national ombudsman has been extremely helpful in developing a new, positive profile and increased public perception of the Ombudsman.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Ombudsman investigates complaints about maladministration in EU institutions and bodies. Complaints can be made by EU citizens or residents of the EU and by companies and institutions established in the EU. Complaints of maladministration may m.in cases such as unfair conduct, discrimination, abuse of powers or improper procedures. It is also the European Ombudsman's job to protect the rights of persons with disabilities. In 2014, The Ombudsman closed 325 complaints and 17 on his own initiative and closed 387 complaints and 13 on his own initiative. The main sources of complaints were citizens (335) and businesses, associations and other legal entities (52). As regards the country of origin of the complaints, Spain comes first (309), followed by Germany (219), Poland (208) and Belgium (147). The Ombudsman's annual report shows that the main subject of complaints is public access to documents of the EU institutions. In 2014, of all completed proceedings, 86 (21.5%) access to documents. I welcome the fact that the EU institutions have 80% complied with the Ombudsman's recommendations. However, I am concerned that the percentage of non-complying with its recommendations remains at 20%. Although the Ombudsman's suggestions are not legally binding, it should be required that institutions, bodies, offices and bodies respond quickly and effectively to his critical comments and draft recommendations.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Citizens must be able to participate in the work of the Union. This is achieved through the mandate of the Ombudsman, who handles complaints in cases of maladministration in the activities of the EU institutions. I also see this as an opportunity to improve the quality of administration.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. The report on the Ombudsman's activities is quite positive, and we also welcome the Ombudsman's action during 2014. But we disagree with certain views contained in this report as "the celebration" of "the progress made on transparency" in the TIC negotiations, or the warmness with which frontex is concerned, hot returns and the lack of refugee rights in this context of crisis. Our group tabled amendments to this text on these issues, but they did not succeed, so we are forced not to give full support to the report. However, we welcome the Ombudsman's actions to defend citizens' rights and her work to create a network between different EU levels.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Ombudsman, and particularly his actions, deserve exceptional attention. Emily O'Reilly has put a lot of effort into ensuring transparency about the composition of expert groups and drug research, among other things. I also enthusiastically supported the Ombudsman's initiatives on better access for people with disabilities to institutions or improving the functioning of the European citizens' initiative.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. With 23,072 requests from citizens for 2014 and the handling of 2,163 complaints, the European Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, has worked perfectly to ensure full respect for the rights of European citizens, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.  In particular, I would like to point out the investigations into transparency within the Union's institutions, the transparency of lobbying and clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues, citizens' participation in EU decision-making, EU-funded projects and programmes and EU competition policy. I therefore welcomed Frontex's request for the Agency to set up a procedure for filing individual complaints in the event of alleged human rights violations.  I also share the idea that it is essential to guarantee the existence of European institutions free of conflicts of interest if we are to focus precisely on preserving the confidence of European citizens. It is in this sense that codes of ethics have emerged in recent years and a public register of representatives of interests has been created. However, to be credible, these practices must be shared by all institutions, including the Council.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report and encourage the ombudsman to keep up the good work. I compliment the European Ombudsman on the successes achieved, especially in difficult TTIP negotiations, and encourage promoting the European Network of Ombudsmen.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our group has tabled a number of amendments which have been voted on. However, two specific amendments referring to key issues on which we are strongly opposed (namely the reference to TTIP and FRONTEX) were voted down. We have therefore voted to abstain.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The main priority of the European Ombudsman is to ensure that citizens’ rights are fully respected and the right to good administration reflects the highest standards as expected of the institutions, bodies, offices and agencies of the Union. I welcome the re-election of Emily O’Reilly to the position of European Ombudsman and anticipate her continued good work. I also welcome the fact that there is greater openness in the ongoing TTIP negotiations following the Ombudsman’s inquiries. I support the Ombudsman’s increased cooperation with the European Institutions, and particularly the European Parliament, and therefore I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because it fully supports the fact that the Ombudsman is making greater use of the power to open strategic investigations on its own initiative. In 2014 the Ombudsman opened 325 inquiries on the basis of complaints as well as 17 own-initiative inquiries and it closed 387 complaints-based inquiries as well as 13 own-initiative inquiries. The main sources of complaints were individual citizens (335) and companies, associations and other legal entities (52).

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights the importance of transparency in the ongoing TTIP negotiations. The EU’s negotiators must pay heed to this as this House will not accept any attempts to have our voice silenced on this issue.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Transparency is a paramount European value. Transparency is also crucial in all EU negotiations. I would like to salute the Ombudsman’s inquiries towards the transparency of the TTIP negotiations. Furthermore, I would like to ask for a comprehensive approach from the Member States towards mandatory collaboration with the Ombudsman.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Ombudsman's annual action report report in 2014, as I believe that this institution, led by European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly, has really done a good job in the areas of transparency in the EU institutions, transparency of lobbying and clinical trials, fundamental rights and ethical issues, and EU competition policy. That same year, 23,072 citizens sought help from the Ombudsperson, in the form of a complaint or request for information, which had been successfully completed. In 2014, the Ombudsperson opened 342 investigations, 325 of which were opened on the basis of a complaint, and the other 17 were own-initiative investigations, which is certainly particularly appreciated and supported. Transparency is essential for good governance, so I approve this report and vote FOR it.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Progress on transparency remains limited and the report welcomes the fact that the European Ombudsman has asked Frontex for a refugee complaint procedure. In committee, my colleague Sylvie Godyn tabled an amendment to remove the provision of the report which congratulates the European Ombudsman for obtaining this new avenue of appeal. As this amendment has not been adopted, I and my colleagues oppose the vote on this report. So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Soledad Cabezon Ruiz's report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014, which receives complaints about maladministration in the European institutions. Most of the investigations opened, 325 in 2014, concern access to documents, selection procedures or the execution of contracts. This report encourages the Ombudsman to open more investigations on her own initiative. Similarly, in view of the registration of 7,000 structures in the European Transparency Register, Parliament encourages transparency on the meetings of expert groups and in European agencies. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report discusses the European Ombudsman's activity in 2014. This mediator, in charge of investigations and complaints against the European institutions, does a remarkable job of investigation and transparency to act as an intermediary between European citizens and the institutions. Ms. O'Reilly, the current mediator, opened more than 325 complaints investigations in 2014 and the report encourages the Ombudsman to open more investigations on her own initiative. I naturally voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The European Ombudsman is doing a great job with a focus on transparency in administration. The Ombudsman's office is self-sufficient in investigations, has introduced new rules on whistleblowing and calls for greater transparency in institutions and international negotiations, clinical trials or influence by stakeholders. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I have great respect for the European Ombudsman, I decided to abstain when voting on her 2014 activity report. I was annoyed by the mention that the report welcomes progress in the openness of the ongoing TTIP negotiations, as I am not personally aware of any. It's still behind closed doors, and then there's parties paid for by multinational corporations. However, I appreciate the Ombudsman for the inquiry into the right of citizens to participate in the EU decision-making process, in particular the inquiry into how the European Citizens' Initiative (ECI) works. I also welcome the increased and necessary attention paid by the Ombudsman to transparency in lobbying and her efforts to establish a mandatory transparency register to enable citizens to find out who is trying to influence EU decision-makers.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The rapporteur presents the traditional annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman, in this case regarding the activities undertaken in 2014, which was a particular year since the European Ombudsman began to implement the new strategy ‘Towards 2019’. The Ombudsman is empowered to receive complaints concerning maladministration in the activities of EU institutions. In this context, the report welcomes the key inquiries initiated by the Ombudsman, notably the transparency in lobbying activities and within the European institutions, the ‘revolving door’ cases concerning high-ranking EU officials’ activities, as well as fundamental rights and ethical issues. Additionally, there are subjects of particular interest in which the Ombudsman is invited to pursue investigations, particularly the lack of transparency in the TTIP negotiations and the respect for the welfare of returnees during return flights in Frontex procedures. Given these facts, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Ombudsman was established by the Maastricht Treaty as a body functional to EU citizenship. Its task is to combat maladministration within the institutions and bodies of the European Union. At the same time, it has a duty to strengthen the instruments for protecting the rights of citizens of the Union and to improve the efficiency of Community administration. With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Ombudsman's mandate has been extended to include the common foreign and security policy. From a more general point of view, it can be said that the Ombudsman seeks to improve the quality of administration through the receipt of complaints. In order to do this, an annual study of its activities is published in order to inform the public of what has been done. Considering that the report comprehensively illustrates the role of the European Ombudsman and the work carried out in 2014, I have decided to give a positive opinion.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. In particular, the Ombudsman carried out an investigation into the TTIP (Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership) which resulted in the Council's publication of the EU guidelines used to negotiate TTIP and the announcement by the European Commission that it would increase transparency in lobbying activities and expand access to TTIP-related documents. However, transparency is still insufficient. The Ombudsman has created a transparency register, in which more than 7,000 lobbying organisations have voluntarily registered. So there are some pretty positive things.  On the other hand, the Ombudsman has asked Frontex to set up a complaint procedure for migrants when they are presumed to be victims of human rights abuses. In committee, Sylvie Goddyn tabled an amendment to remove the provision congratulating the European Ombudsman on having obtained this new avenue of appeal. As this amendment has not been adopted, I am opposed to the vote on this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it welcomes the progress made by the European Ombudsman on transparency, although this progress remains very limited. He is also wrong to congratulate the Ombudsman for asking Frontex for filing complaints for migrants!

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution is made on the annual report submitted by the Ombudsman. Specifically, it refers to its work during 2014. The motion for a Resolution accentuates several positive elements of the Ombudsman's work, within a general context of growing citizen distrust of the European Union. This is the case, for example, in the case of the investigation into 'revolving doors' within the European Commission, the infringement of access to information by the European institutions or the recommendation made to create a mechanism against The infringement of individual rights by Frontex. It also highlights the need to increase resources for the Ombudsman's Office and that 20% of cases of non-compliance with the recommendations still persist. However, I have decided to abstain as our amendments on such sensitive issues as the dual-use (civilian and military) fate of European funds to third countries participating in the Horizon 2020 programme (such as Israel) or the end of Frontex's joint deportation policies have not been included. I also understand it wrong to congratulate the European Commission on its transparency in the TCI negotiations, for obvious reasons.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Ombudsman is in charge of receiving complaints in cases of ineffective, poor or slow administration at EU level. Over the years, 20-30% of complaints related to the issue of transparency and were most often related to the refusal of institutions to approve access to documents and/or information. In 2014, The Ombudsman initiated 325 procedures based on complaints received, 17 procedures on its own initiative and 387 procedures closed. In the run-up to the European elections, the Ombudsman organised an interactive event "Your Wish list for Europe" with the aim of bringing citizens to the very heart of the decision-making process. I supported the Ombudsman's work report for 2014.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Institute of the European Ombudsman is a means of protecting entities residing or having their registered office in the Territory of the Union from maladministration by EU institutions and bodies. In 2014, the current Ombudsman found maladministration in 39 closed cases and issued 12 draft recommendations. As a lasting means of negotiating redress in disregarding previous recommendations by the EU institutions and bodies, the Ombudsman may draw up and submit a special report to the EP. In 2014, the EP Ombudsman did not submit any such special report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Report on the European Ombudsman's annual activity report in 2014, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/2/2016, and because this Report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this activity report. We recognise that the European Ombudsman is the author of some good decisions on 2014, such as the creation of a register of transparency of lobbyists or the promotion of transparency in clinical trials. On the other hand, we condemn its request to Frontex to set up a complaint procedure for migrants when they are presumed to be victims of human rights violations.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the report assessing the work of the European Ombudsman for 2014, there are a number of positive elements and it is clear that the Ombudsman takes her office very responsibly and seriously, as evidenced by the increase in the number of investigations launched, including on her own initiative. The Ombudsman has thus addressed one of the key areas for me, namely transparency in the conduct of the European institutions or, for example, the issue of the so-called 'revolving door' of senior EU officials. However, given that the report highlights significantly the progress made in making the TTIP negotiations more transparent, of which I am certainly not convinced, as I have not seen any greater openness, I abstained in the final vote on the report

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the Ombudsman's activity in 2014 highlights the importance of this institution and that we must continue to support it from the European Parliament. I am voting in favour of the motion for a Resolution on this activity in which the large number of complaints made from Spain, which is the European country that tops the list of people who appeal to this institution, is once again highlighted the need to initiate investigations by the Ombudsman.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on the response to the 2014 activities presented by the European Ombudsman. I believe that the investigations carried out by this institution in relation to the transparency of the activities of eu institutions, high-ranking officials, lobbyists are significant and help to prevent conflicts of interest at any level within the EU institutions, bodies and agencies.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Every year, the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions presents a report on the assessment of the activities of the European Ombudsman over the past year. The Ombudsman in this case investigates complaints against EU institutions in cases of mismanagement or non-compliance with citizens' rights. During 2014, it carried out in-depth investigations, particularly on the lack of transparency of the transatlantic TAFTA agreement, the slippage of former European Commissioners and the opaque actions of the lobby. As such, although his mandate is limited, his work is to be commended.  Parliament's report should have called on him to continue this work when, for example, he confines himself on the TAFTA to welcome the Commission's "greater openness" even though its negotiating mandate on behalf of the European peoples is still not officially made public. In addition, on the Frontex agency in charge of external borders, the report is limited to asking to "ensure the welfare of returnees during return flights" while human rights violations in its treatment of migrants are multiple. In these circumstances, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Ombudsman has promoted greater transparency in clinical trials, which has led to limited improvements. The Ombudsman also called for a complaint procedure for migrants to be set up. Ms Goddyn was denied the removal of the amendment which congratulates the Ombudsman on obtaining this new remedy. As a result, I have spoken out against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. Established by the Maastricht Treaty, the European Ombudsman has a key role to play in investigating cases of maladministration by the European institutions, enhancing the efficiency of public administration by the European Union.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which recognises the important work done by Emily O’Reilly as the EU Ombudsman in 2014, which has seen good results for the Union’s work.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – I read with interest the Annual Report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman for 2014. The role of the Ombudsman is extremely important and I consider this function to be an expression of freedom and legal certainty in a democracy. One of the Tasks of the European Ombudsman is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected, but it also helps the EU institutions to become more open to citizens. This work is very demanding today, as up to 46% of citizens do not have confidence in the EU institutions. For this reason, congratulations to the Ombudsman, because she is doing her job really well. It shall use its power to open a strategic investigation on its own initiative. I add to the positive resonance with the fact that, within her office, she appointed an own-initiative investigative coordinator and introduced new internal rules on informatics. I also very much appreciate the progress that has been made in transparency in the TTIP negotiations. The Ombudsman has taken fundamental steps in this matter. I call on the Ombudsman to continue to support efforts for greater transparency also in the area of research and development in order to guarantee access to healthcare.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the European Ombudsman, that welcomes the Ombudsman’s greater use of her power to launch investigations on her own initiative such as on transparency in the TTIP negotiations, how Frontex ensures the respect of fundamental rights of migrants who are subject to forced returns; the composition of the Commission’s expert groups, clinical trials, and lobby activities, as well as her work towards a mandatory Transparency Register. Other key investigations for 2014 include participation of citizens in EU decision-making (in particular into the functioning of the ECI); EU funded projects and programmes; and EU competition policy.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman presented his report on his activities in 2014 to the President of the European Parliament on 26 May 2015.  The Committee on Petitions proposes that the European Parliament: congratulate Emily O'Reilly on her re-election as European Ombudsman on 16 December 2014 and the excellent work she has done; to support the eu institutions' objective of providing the best possible service to Europe's citizens and citizens; agree that the Ombudsman focused on transparency as a guarantee of good administration; take a position in favour of increasing the ombudsman's office's annual budget; approve the annual report on the European Ombudsman's activities in 2014. I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is a satisfaction of the European Parliament to the European Ombudsman for its 2014 activities. These included the establishment of a transparency register in which more than 7,000 lobbying organizations were registered; promote greater transparency in clinical trials that has resulted in the publication of information on the added value of products and their actual research costs; to increase the transparency of lobbying activities within the framework of TTIP, but which is still very inadequate. However, the Ombudsman has also called for a complaint procedure for migrants to be set up so that they can attack Frontex in the event of a violation of their fundamental rights, which means that we are very opposed to this satisfaction proposed in the text tabled.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Progress on transparency remains limited, but the report welcomes the fact that the European Ombudsman has asked Frontex for a procedure for filing complaints in favour of migrants. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. The Ombudsman opened 325 complaint-based inquiries and 17 inquiries on his own initiative and closed 387 complaint-based inquiries and 13 inquiries on his own initiative. The main sources of complaint were individual citizens (335) and businesses, associations and other legal entities (52). I believe that Emily O'Reilly has done an excellent job and that the focus on transparency as a guarantee of good administration has been a key element in the performance of her mandate.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Ombudsman can, at the request of any EU citizen, investigate an EU institution on the grounds of administrative irregularities, discrimination, abuse of power, unfairness, failure to reply and refusal of information. I have voted for this report that summarises the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of this report because the Ombudsman's work is very commendable and is characterised by new rules on whistleblowing and the call for greater transparency.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is an overview of the European Ombudsman's activities in 2014, the complaints received from him and their resolution. Given that a very large percentage of complaints were made up of access to documents from the institutions and a lack of openness, this is clearly an area that needs to be addressed more and solutions for greater openness are found.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report (which was an ‘own initiative report’ and therefore not legislative) because it contained a call for an increase in the budget of the Ombudsman. UKIP is opposed in principle to any increases in expenditure and thus the burden on the UK taxpayer arising from membership of the EU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the European Ombudsman's main priorities is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards expected of the Union institutions, bodies and agencies. At present, the ombudsman has a very important role to play and one of his tasks is to help the EU institutions to become more transparent, effective and close to the citizens, thereby strengthening citizens' confidence in the Union. In view of its successes, I too have my confidence in this body.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Ombudsman is committed to ensuring that citizens, NGOs, associations and companies are aware of their right to complain about maladministration in the EU institutions. I welcome the Ombudsman’s investigation into whether the EU institutions are living up to their obligations and I believe that the Ombudsman should continue urging for better transparency on the members and meetings of all experts groups expert groups, technology platforms and agencies.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which clearly expresses its support for the European Ombudsman and leads to greater transparency of public registers accessible on the Internet, and supports further inquiries by the Ombudsman.  The report welcomes the implementation of the transparency register, which makes an important contribution to greater transparency in the work of the European Parliament.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome european Ombudsperson O'Reilly's report on the work of her office for 2014. In particular, I would like to give a high assessment of the relations the Ombudsperson has with parliament and the Commission, and to commend the importance she attaches to those relations in her work. I am pleased to commend the Ombudsperson's efforts in shedding light on a number of transparency-related cases, not least in the field of work of the Institutions of the European Union. Transparency in the work of the Union institutions, in particular the Commission and the Council, is one of the key preconditions for growing citizens' trust in the European institutions.  I call on Parliament to support this report and I hope that the successful cooperation of European Ombudsperson O'Reilly so far will continue this year, and that the resolution of complaints regarding the transparency of the EU institutions will contribute to the gradual strengthening of the trust of so-called "ordinary" citizens throughout the Union in its institutions.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Ombudsman conducted an investigation into the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) which resulted in the Council's publication of the EU guidelines used to negotiate TTIP and the Announcement by the European Commission that it would increase transparency of lobbying activities and expand access to TTIP documents. However, transparency is still insufficient. In addition, the European Ombudsman has asked Frontex to set up a complaint procedure for migrants when they are presumed to be victims of human rights abuses. This measure seems unacceptable to me because it can only further slow down the resolution of the migrant crisis. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Ombudsman's main priority is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards, the application of which is expected to be applied by union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. According to a Eurobarometer survey of May 2015, 40% of citizens trust the European Union and 46% do not.  Any Citizen of the Union and any natural or legal person resident or based in a Member State shall have the right to contact the European Ombudsman in relation to irregularities in the activities of the institutions, bodies, offices or agencies of the Union, with the exception of the Court of Justice of the European Union in exercising its judicial powers. Close cooperation between the Ombudsperson and the Committee on Petitions has contributed to achieving a higher level of democratic scrutiny of the activities of the European institutions. I welcome and support the fact that the Ombudsperson is serving more of her powers to open strategic investigations on her own initiative. I welcome the 80% harmonisity rate of the EU institutions with the Ombudsperson's proposals and express concern that a 20% non-compliance rate remains.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the legislation, 'any citizen of the Union, as well as any natural or legal person resident or established in a Member State, shall have the right to petition the European Ombudsman concerning cases of maladministration in the performance of the institutions, bodies or bodies of the Union, with the exception of the Court of Justice of the European Union in the exercise of their judicial functions'. The European Ombudsman shall have jurisdiction to carry out investigations into cases of maladministration in the performance of the institutions, bodies or bodies of the Union, with the exception of the Court of Justice of the European Union in the exercise of its judicial functions. Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights states that 'all persons have the right to have their affairs dealt with by the institutions, bodies and bodies of the Union impartially, fairly and within a reasonable time'. The rapporteur proposes the adoption of the 2014 annual report and welcomes the inquiries initiated by the Ombudsman, in particular on transparency in the EU institutions and transparency in the activities of interest groups. Generally speaking, we agree with the above in the report. However, we do not follow and cannot accept the indirect support it gives to frontex's code of conduct for joint return operations and repatriation flights.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 annual report submitted by the European Ombudsman and I am very glad that she has been re-elected. The current protector has proved that, unlike her predecessor, she is not afraid to make more use of own-initiative and proactive investigations in introducing new internal rules. As one of the representatives of European citizens, I am very happy that this helps to break down the opacity of the Institutions of the European Union and its activities. I consider it very important that conflicts of interest are avoided and possible cases are thoroughly investigated. It is clear that, otherwise, european citizens' trust in the European Union will only have a decreasing tendency. Citizens' trust is currently affected, inter alia, by the European Commission's negotiations with the United States of America on TTIP. A large number of people complain about the lack of transparency. I therefore hope that the Ombudsman will take appropriate action shortly to increase understanding of the chapters under discussion. I supported the Ombudsman continuing to monitor the work of advisory groups in the European Commission advising her on the implementation of budgetary-large policies, including agricultural policies, and to work with the European Court of Auditors in the future. Any gaps in transparency must no longer appear in the implementation of the budget, and the Union institutions and the Member States must undoubtedly accommodate this ombudsman.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to receive the report on the European Ombudsman's work, which confirms the importance of this office. As a social democrat, it is very important to me that citizens' rights are fully respected, especially at EU level. For this reason, I greatly appreciate and appreciate the work of Emily O'Reilly, who was re-elected European Ombudsman on the basis of her efforts. Thanks to its excellent performance, this could, for example, lead to greater openness in the ongoing TTIP negotiations, but also to the policy of the European Medicines Agency, which plays a key role in the transparency of clinical trial data. The results of the Eurobarometer show us that citizens' trust in the EU is gradually declining, so it is important to continue to support the function of the European Ombudsman, which advocates transparency and good governance of the EU institutions. Thanks to the incentives coming directly from citizens, there may be important changes in the openness and friendliness of the European institutions, which will retroactively strengthen their confidence in the work of the European Union. Access to information on the conduct of negotiations or on the activities of individual Union institutions must remain a fundamental right for all citizens of the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Emily O'Reilly, re-elected European Ombudsman by the European Parliament at the Strasbourg plenary session on 16 December 2014, presented her annual report on 26 May 2015. In 2014, it launched 325 complaint-based inquiries and 17 own-initiative inquiries. The main sources of complaint were individual citizens (335) and businesses, associations and other legal entities (52). The Ombudsman found cases of maladministration in 39 of the cases closed and drew up 12 draft recommendations. As far as complaints are concerned, it appears that public access to documents of the EU institutions is predominant and has triggered a large number of complaints. Of all the investigations closed in 2014, 86 cases (21.5%) concerned access to documents. I hope that the Ombudsman will be able to continue to work with the utmost independence and transparency to combat cases of maladministration by community institutions and bodies and, consequently, to strengthen the instruments for protecting the rights of CITIZENS of the Union and to improve the efficiency of the Community administration. I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – The 2014 annual report of the European Ombudsmen focuses on the collection of complaints from Member States relating to fundamental rights in the EU and maladministration in the EU. A "maladministration" is defined as follows: "An maladministration arises when a public body does not act in accordance with rules or principles that are binding on it." The report records the number and origin of the complaints and reports on their outcome. In my opinion, the financial resources spent on this are not in proportion to the real added value generated by the Ombudsman. However, I believe that the provision of a contact point for complaints in principle is the right one. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. With this resolution, which I fully support, the European Parliament congratulates Emily O'Reilly's decisive action as the European Ombudsman. Its role is essential to ensure that the rights of European citizens are respected and that they are confidence in the Union. A trust that requires more transparent and open European institutions, accessible to all, but also free of any conflict of interest. This is an indispensable condition for fostering closeness between Europeans and their rulers. The role of the Ombudsman is thereby very important in ensuring that the European administration respects its obligations, particularly with regard to the rule of law, democratic principles and the values of the Union. In particular, I welcome his commitment to the fundamental rights of refugees and migrants. Frontex must strive to fully comply with the Ombudsman's recommendations to this effect, in the context of its joint return operations, particularly in the case of the most vulnerable. It is also time for the Agency to respond to the many calls of Emily O'Reilly, relayed by the European Parliament, for the establishment of its own mechanism for filing individual complaints in case of violations of fundamental rights.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I have supported this resolution, in which we approve the European Ombudsman's activity report for 2014 and congratulate her on her re-election and the excellent work she has done, with certain results. At a time when the proportion of citizens who do not trust the Union is greater than the proportion of citizens who trust it, the Ombudsman's action to ensure full respect for citizens' rights and to ensure the right to good administration can help to reverse this problematic trend.  We therefore fully support the Ombudsman's increasing use of her power to open investigations on her own initiative and call for an increase in the annual budget allocated to her. 342 investigations were opened and 400 were closed. These open investigations include the themes of fundamental rights, issues of ethics or citizen participation in the decision-making process, but also transparency within EU institutions as well as in lobbying activities and clinical trials. We must ensure that the Ombudsman has strong support in her work. With this resolution, this House testifies to this intention.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this report, which I voted on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014, Parliament welcomes the investigations opened by the Ombudsman, stating that the main themes emerging from these surveys were transparency within the EU institutions, transparency of lobbying and clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues. , citizens' participation in EU decision-making, EU-funded projects and programmes and EU competition policy. The text of the report states that it is essential for the Ombudsman to focus on transparency to ensure good administration. It has been asked to investigate transparency concerns over Parliament's rapid access to relevant Commission documents on infringements and the EU's pilot procedure, particularly when they are linked to existing petitions. Parliament also welcomed and supported the Ombudsman's greater use of her power to open strategic investigations on her own initiative.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it perfectly reflects the active activities of The Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly. One of the biggest achievements is the Ombudsman's desire to create a mandatory Transparency Register, which registers lobbyists. More than 7 000 institutions have already voluntarily registered in the Transparency Register.  Another important work is the effort to ensure openness in the TTIP negotiations. It was as a result of the ombudsman's inquiry that the Council published the guidelines used by the EU as negotiating directives in the TTIP negotiations. Meanwhile, the Commission has announced plans to increase transparency through lobbying and has promised to provide greater access to TTIP documents.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the European Parliament Resolution of 25 February 2016 on the European Ombudsman's Annual Report for 2014. I agree with the adoption of the report and I congratulate Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly on the excellent work done throughout 2014, in particular her pro-activity, in terms of research and decisions taken on transparency of the European institutions, fundamental rights and citizens' participation, as well as her efforts to improve the functioning of the body to which it chairs.  For these reasons, my vote was in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. Mr President, 42.54%. So few EU citizens voted in the European elections in 2014; the share is at an all-time low.  There are many reasons for the low level of interest, of which I would now like to highlight transparency. There's not enough of that. How can a citizen get an idea of TTIP negotiations if the papers are classified? How can a citizen trust lobbyists not to dictate policy if meetings are not accurately recorded and published conscientiously? The European Ombudsman has called for and gained more transparency. This is a work that we should all support and respect.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes stock of the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. Re-elected in December 2014 by the European Parliament, the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, opened 325 investigations in 2014 on the basis of complaints. It should be recalled that the Ombudsman's mission is to investigate complaints of maladministration in the actions of the European institutions. It also has the power to initiate investigations. I have therefore supported this resolution, which welcomes the adoption by the European Ombudsman of a five-year strategy that allows for a more focused approach to addressing recurring problems and promoting good administration. It should also be noted that 80% of the Ombudsman's recommendations are followed and implemented by EU institutions. The European Ombudsman has an essential role in ensuring respect for fundamental rights and the principles of the rule of law in the action of the European institutions.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Emily O'Reilly is once again the European Ombudsman and in the report we have adopted today we have congratulated her on the work she has done to date. The Ombudsman's task is to be a meeting point between citizens and the institutions, and you have exercised this delicate role in a competent and transparent manner.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. The report on the Ombudsman's activities is quite positive, and we also welcome the Ombudsman's action during 2014. But we disagree with certain views contained in this report as "the celebration" of "the progress made on transparency" in the TIC negotiations, or the warmness with which frontex is concerned, hot returns and the lack of refugee rights in this context of crisis. Our group tabled amendments to this text on these issues, but they did not succeed, so we are forced not to give full support to the report. However, we welcome the Ombudsman's actions to defend citizens' rights and her work to create a network between different EU levels.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Committee on Petitions' report on the annual report of the activities of the European Ombudsmen in 2014, because it is important to uncover the possible errors in the EU's administration, to get to the bottom of people's complaints and thus to avoid them in the future as well as to find solutions for them. In addition to complaints from companies, associations and other legal persons, the Ombudsman mainly deals with individual EU citizens, many of whom also come from Germany. Complaints often relate to requests for information and access to documents, administrative and staff information, tendering or procurement procedures, the Commission as guardian of the contracts and the performance of contracts. I believe that we must give the Ombudsman more powers to open investigations on his own initiative in order to create greater transparency.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution is made on the annual report submitted by the Ombudsman. Specifically, it refers to its work during 2014. The motion for a Resolution accentuates several positive elements of the Ombudsman's work, within a general context of growing citizen distrust of the European Union. This is the case, for example, in the case of the investigation into 'revolving doors' within the European Commission, the infringement of access to information by the European institutions or the recommendation made to create a mechanism against The infringement of individual rights by Frontex. It also highlights the need to increase resources for the Ombudsman's Office and that 20% of cases of non-compliance with the recommendations still persist. However, I have decided to abstain as our amendments on such sensitive issues as the dual-use (civilian and military) fate of European funds to third countries participating in the Horizon 2020 programme (such as Israel) or the end of Frontex's joint deportation policies have not been included. I also understand it wrong to congratulate the European Commission on its transparency in the TCI negotiations, for obvious reasons.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution concerns the report on the activities of European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly in 2014. The European Ombudsman's main priority is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards expected of the Union institutions, bodies and agencies.  In 2014, the Ombudsman opened 342 inquiries, 325 on the basis of complaints and 17 on his own initiative, 59.6% of which concerned the Commission. It also provided recommendations on the lack of transparency within the EU institutions and lobbying activities, clinical trials, fundamental rights, ethical issues, competition policy spending and citizen participation in EU decision-making.  I believe that the Ombudsman plays an essential role in helping the EU institutions to become more transparent, effective and close to the citizens, thereby strengthening their confidence in the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of adopting this resolution when voting on the European Parliament resolution on the Annual Report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman for 2014. In fact, a fundamental priority of the European Ombudsman should be to guarantee respect for the rights of EU citizens, which entitles him to investigate cases of maladministration by the institutions, bodies, offices and agencies at EU level. In 2014, the European Ombudsman took action on 2 163 complaints received and initiated 342 inquiries herself. I therefore support efforts to provide the best possible services in this area.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main priority of the European Ombudsman is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected. The Ombudsman plays an essential role in helping the EU institutions become more open, effective and citizen-friendly in order to strengthen their trust in the Union. In 2014, 23 072 citizens asked the Ombudsman for help, of which 19 170 received advice through an interactive escort on its website. In the same year, the Ombudsman recorded 2 079 complaints and received 1 823 requests for information. I supported the report because I believe that the Ombudsman has taken up her post very well after her re-election. Thanks to her work, the work of the European institutions has become more transparent, with great appreciation for her initiative in the run-up to the European elections, when, in an effort to put citizens at the heart of decision-making, she organised an interactive event called Your Wish List for Europe, which was greatly appreciated by the electorate.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman's main priority is to ensure that citizens' rights are strictly respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards expected of EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies.  The Ombudsman's essential role in cooperating with the EU institutions is to help achieve greater openness and efficiency. It also plays an important role in ensuring that the EU institutions are citizen-friendly and that their trust in the EU is strengthened.  The Annual Report on the European Ombudsman's activities in 2014 was presented in May 2015. In 2014, 23,072 citizens asked 23,072 citizens for help from the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly. Its office recorded 2,079 complaints and 1,823 requests for information. The report said the Ombudsman had launched 342 inquiries, of which 325 complaints inquiries and 17 on her own initiatives. In total, it completed 400 investigations. Over the years, 20-30% of complaints concerned transparency, mainly because the institutions did not provide access to documents and/or information.  The report assesses the work of the European Ombudsman and congratulates her on her good performance of her duties. As I support its efforts to provide the best possible services to the citizens and the people of Europe, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ The position of European Ombudsman is an important part of democracy within the EU. Its supervision of the transparency and quality of services provided to citizens by the EU institutions is a necessity that strengthens citizens' rights and their trust in the EU. Despite advances in transparency in certain areas, such as TTIP, there is still much room for improvement.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. The European Ombudsman's Annual Report on Action in 2014 was formally submitted to the President of the European Parliament on 26 May 2015 and presented the report to the Committee on Petitions on 23 June 2015 in Brussels. Parliament re-elected Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman at its plenary session in Strasbourg on 16 December 2014.
