The Ombudsman's top priority is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards, the application of which is expected of union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. The Ombudsman plays a key role in helping the EU institutions become more open, efficient and citizen-friendly in order to strengthen citizens' trust in the Union, and I therefore supported the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Ombudsman's top priority is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected and plays a key role in helping the Union institutions become more open, efficient and citizen-friendly. According to a May 2015 survey, 40% of EU citizens trust the Union, 46% do not. In 2014, 23,072 citizens sought the help of the Ombudsperson and 342 investigations were opened.  The conclusion of a particular investigation took an average of 11 months. Parliament welcomes the investigations opened by the Ombudsperson in 2014 that detect the main topics: transparency in the Union institutions, fundamental rights, ethical issues, citizens' participation in the Union decision-making process. Parliament also encourages the Ombudsperson to continue supporting initiatives aimed at achieving greater transparency, and calls on Member States to be more enterprising in their mandatory cooperation with the Ombudsperson. I support this report because I believe that European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly has achieved excellent results in her work. I also support its objective of assisting the Union institutions in their efforts to provide the best possible service to European citizens. I believe that the Ombudsperson's emphasis on transparency as a guarantee of good governance is essential.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Annual Report on the European Ombudsman's activities for 2014.  According to numerous studies, confidence in the Institutions of the European Union among citizens is low. In order to strengthen citizens' trust, we need transparency and mutual control between the institutions, which is the task of the European Ombudsman.  The institutions of the European Union must strive to provide the best possible services to the citizens and the people of Europe. If we want to strengthen citizens' trust, we must support the Ombudsman's activities in 2014, which included transparency in the EU institutions, transparency in lobbying, fundamental rights, ethical issues and citizens' participation in decision-making in the EU.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's Report of the European Parliament on the Annual Report on the Work of the European Ombudsman for 2014, as I believe that it is possible to agree with the overall conclusion that expresses satisfaction with the work of the European Ombudsman. In the system of the Union institutions, the Ombudsman plays an important role, since even against the institutions of the European Union, its citizens have the right to the proper exercise of administration. The European Ombudsman contributes to improving the performance of governance at Union level not only through its action to respond to citizens' complaints, but also through own-initiative inquiries that respond to some of the most important issues in the area of so-called good governance, such as access to documents, conflicts of interest or the transparency register. The usefulness of the European Ombudsman can be documented in the example of the European Citizens' Initiative, where the Ombudsman's Office has highlighted the need to amend certain rules to make the initiative an effective and accessible and understandable tool to the public.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman carried out important investigations during 2014, such as an investigation into the lack of transparency in the ongoing negotiations on the TTP agreement. In addition, during 2014, the European Ombudsman investigated key issues such as transparency in procedures within the EU institutions, fundamental rights, citizens' participation in EU decision-making and EU-funded projects.  Although we welcome the work that has been done, the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman contains some problematic reports that we cannot accept. For example, it notes that progress has been made on transparency in the negotiations on the TIMP agreement. Indirect support for FRONTEX, in particular for operations to deport refugees, is also problematic. For the above reasons we have abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. Mrs O Reilly's effort is commendable, given the short time since her election. Her role as European Ombudsman in helping the EU institutions become more open, effective and citizen-friendly, with a view to strengthening citizens' confidence in the Union, is very difficult. The idea of European integration must be consistent with more transparency and control of its institutions. In view of last May's Eurobarometer, public confidence in the EU is only 40%, but the lack of this is close to 46%. In addition, there is 20% of the Ombudsman's proposals, with which the institutions have not complied. There is still a long way to go in areas such as transparency, the rule of law, ethics, the fight against corruption, the management of conflicts of interest in the public sector, transparency in clinical trials and, above all, openness in TTIP negotiations.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I unreservedly supported the adoption of the report on the European Ombudsman's activities in 2014, because it reflects the valuable contribution of the Ombudsman re-elected that year to a more open, citizen-friendly European Union. The European Ombudsman's activities have clearly become more active during the reporting period, particularly in the area of own-initiative inquiries. As a Member, I consider it particularly important and will monitor your work recently and in the future on the issues of protecting the rights of migrants, introducing operating conditions and mandatory registers of EU lobbyists, and managing EU-funded funds and projects.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Any citizen of the Union and any natural or legal person residing or having its registered office in a Member State of the European Union shall have the right to address the European Ombudsman in cases of maladministration in the activities of the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. In its report, the European Parliament expressed its support for the key issues examined by The Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, concerning the m.in. transparency of the work of the institutions and expert groups advising them, as well as conflicts of interest and access to documents and information. In terms of transparency of the functioning of the EU institutions and greater involvement of citizens, it is particularly important that the EU Transparency Register, which was set up in 2012, a platform for recording and sharing information on the interests of numerous organisations active in the EU institutions, is particularly important. In conclusion, I believe that the Ombudsman's action and close cooperation with the European Parliament are extremely important. I appreciate Emily O'Reilly's commitment, which is why I decided to vote in favour of the report that gave a positive assessment of her work in 2014.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text.  The Ombudsman's main priority is to ensure full respect for the rights of citizens and to ensure that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards expected of the Union's institutions, bodies and bodies. It must play a vital role in helping the European institutions to improve their openness, efficiency and closeness to citizens in order to strengthen their confidence in the Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of approving the annual report for 2014 on the Activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. The Ombudsman plays a vital role in helping EU institutions become more open, effective and citizen-friendly, thus strengthening citizens’ confidence in the Union. I particularly welcome the Ombudsman’s push in 2014 for more transparency within the EU institutions, in lobbying and clinical trials, and for more citizen participation in EU decision-making. Finally, I am also pleased that the Ombudsman achieved concrete results in 2014, opening 325 inquiries on the basis of complaints as well as 17 own-initiative inquiries and closing 387 complaints-based inquiries as well as 13 own-initiative inquiries.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that the Tasks of the European Ombudsman are among the most important in the European Union. It is the Ombudsman who is the guardian of civil rights and freedoms and, as the report shows, they have been and are being violated. I support the report in question because it contains an important publication affecting people with disabilities. The European Ombudsman must in the future promote measures to better protect the rights of people with disabilities and to ensure that eu administrative authorities are aware of their obligations in relation to the protection of the rights of this group. Those who believe that an EU institution is not functioning in accordance with the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will have easier access to exercise their rights. It is also worth supporting the continuation of the idea of the beginning of 2014, on the basis of which seconded national experts were included in the Ombudsman's team. Their task is to support the Ombudsman in the preparation of a work programme on disability and to find ways to reach EU citizens in order to inform them of their rights under the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the European Ombudsman's activities in 2014.  I believe that the European Ombudsman has done a good job of closedinging many important complaints. At the same time, I believe that this is a necessary institution that could be more helpful to EU citizens.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Institutional respect for citizens’ rights is a key element for democracy. The work of the European Ombudsman ensures that the rights of European Union citizens are respected by the European institutions by answering their concerns and resolving their conflicts. Her efforts, however, do not stop there as she increasingly launches investigations on her own initiative and advocates for greater transparency. Not unlike the Committee of Petitions, the European Ombudsman is bringing the European Union closer to its citizens and therefore her efforts must be supported. The amount of work done by the European Ombudsman is astonishing, especially bearing the limited budget in mind. As the rights of European citizens are at stake here, we have not only called for a closer cooperation with the Committee on Petitions, but also for an increase in the budget.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. The report on the Ombudsman's activities is quite positive, and we also welcome the Ombudsman's action during 2014. But we disagree with certain views contained in this report as "the celebration" of "the progress made on transparency" in the TIC negotiations, or the warmness with which frontex is concerned, hot returns and the lack of refugee rights in this context of crisis. Our group tabled amendments to this text on these issues, but they did not succeed, so we are forced not to give full support to the report. However, we welcome the Ombudsman's actions to defend citizens' rights and her work to create a network between different EU levels.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution gives satisfaction to the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2014, Emily O'Reilly, and presents her initiative to ask Frontex to set up a complaint procedure for migrants when they are presumed to be victims of human rights abuses. I obviously voted against this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament re-elected Emily O'Reilly as European Ombudsman at its plenary session in Strasbourg on 16 December 2014. On 26 May 2015, Emily O'Reilly presented her 2014 annual report to Martin Schulz, President of the European Parliament. In 2014, the Ombudsman acted on 2 163 complaints received. In 1 217 cases, the Ombudsman's office advised or referred the case (e.g. to a member of the European Network of Ombudsmen or parliament's Committee on Petitions), in 621 cases the complainant was informed that the Office was not in a position to provide further advice and 325 cases were investigated. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive, as implicit endorsement of the Ombudsman’s approach with regard to her own-initiative inquiries.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The European Ombudsman's task is to protect the rights of persons with disabilities and to ensure that the EU administration is aware of its responsibilities in respect of compliance with these rights. Persons who believe that an EU institution does not comply with the provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities have the right to lodge complaints with the Ombudsman. At the beginning of 2014, a seconded national expert joined the Ombudsman's team to help develop a work programme on disability issues and to find ways to better reach citizens and staff of the EU institutions and inform them of their rights and obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Annual Report of the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. 2014 was productive year for the European Ombudsman as she began the implementation of the new strategy – Towards 2019 – with a greater focus on the strategic issues of EU public administration affecting a great number of Europeans. The office equally continued to resolve significant numbers of complaints from individuals, members of civil society organisations, businesses and other interests, and assisted many more in seeking solutions to their difficulties. In addition, joint efforts were made towards increasing lobbying transparency in the EU. Conclusively, the European Ombudsman office worked successfully in 2014 towards providing the best possible service to the citizens and residents of Europe and this is the reason why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the Ombudsman's Office since the activity carried out by Mrs O'Reilly in 2014 deserves recognition for modernizing the institutions and bringing them closer to citizens at the moment of political-social conflict. I would like to highlight the Ombudsman's use of her ability to conduct ex officio investigations as it has been in revolving door cases, transparency in clinical trials and in TTE negotiations. Special mention deserves the impetus given in 2014 by both the Ombudsman and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermmans to the register of interest groups, where more than 7000 organisations have already been registered. This register provides transparency to the work of the European Parliament and to all European institutions. The work of the Ombudsman's Office has helped in this period to improve the functioning of all institutions by focusing on possible cases of maladministration and recommending solutions, solutions that have been 80% assumed by the investigated bodies.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of this motion for resolution on the activities of the European Ombudsman, Emily O’Reilly. While acknowledging that transparency is an ongoing process, where there is almost always room for improvement in any institution or organisation, I feel that the Ombudsman made excellent progress in many areas in 2014. Due to the Ombudsman’s inquiries, the Commission has released a variety of documents that have proved invaluable to improving transparency, including on the Greek entry into the eurozone. Also the European Central Bank has disclosed the contents of a letter to the Irish Government on the financial crisis, and the Commission has followed the Ombudsman’s recommendation to release documents on the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, although this was after reform had been agreed. I was therefore happy to vote positively in regards to the Ombudsman’s activities in 2014. It is vital that the Ombudsman is congratulated for her proactive work and encouraged to go further in the future. This can only be an advantage to European Union and its institutions.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. Mrs O'Reilly has performed her role as Ombudsman superbly, especially with regard to the transparency of the TTIP negotiations. It is my hope that she will continue its work in this way in order to support the European institutions in order to become more effective, transparent and responsible.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report, as every year, covers the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. While the function of the European Ombudsman is to strengthen the democratic process within the European Union, its legislative resources have so far been relatively limited. Since her election in 2013, Emilie O'Reilly has strengthened the Ombudsman's remit and seems to want to remind Member States and the Commission of their obligations to respect the rule of law and democracy.  Transparency of TTIP negotiations, transparency of lobbyists, conflicts of interest or respect for fundamental rights: the mediator has taken the initiative to open a number of investigations into possible breaches of the rule of law and the results of her investigations are interesting.  However, this report does not follow its recommendations to the end and welcomes, among other things, greater openness in the TTIP negotiations or Frontex's activities on expulsions and returns. The GUE/NGL tabled several amendments to repeat its recommendations, all of which were rejected. To say the least, Emilie O'Reilly still has a long way to go to be heard; I support it and so I voted for this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman shall have jurisdiction to carry out investigations into cases of maladministration in the performance of the institutions, bodies or bodies of the Union, with the exception of the Court of Justice of the European Union in the exercise of its judicial functions. Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights states that 'all persons have the right to have their affairs dealt with by the institutions, bodies and bodies of the Union impartially, fairly and within a reasonable time'.  According to the legislation, 'any citizen of the Union, as well as any natural or legal person resident or established in a Member State, shall have the right to petition the European Ombudsman in cases of maladministration in the performance of the institutions, bodies or bodies of the Union, with the exception of the Court of Justice of the European Union in the exercise of their judicial functions'. We understand the process, but we cannot but consider that it is only part of a propaganda manoeuvre aimed at selling a very democratic and concerned European Union for citizens, when, in the concrete reality of its policies, it oppresses entire populations in complete disregard for their sovereign will.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the work of the European Ombudsman is in our interests. For .B, it has focused on transparency (especially in administration), is self-initiative in investigations, has introduced new rules on whistleblowing, wants more transparency in EU institutions/lobbying/clinical trials and conducts investigations into transparency in the TTIP agreement.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the motion because it favours the TTIP agreement and migrants. From a national point of view, this request is completely indisputable. It would also be an increasing burden on the German economy in the longer term.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the 2014 Annual Report on the activities of the European Ombudsman. The report is essentially a statistical diligent task and reflects the Ombudsman's work in figures and percentages. The report, in which it praises the Ombudsman's work and calls for greater transparency of the EU, is becoming political, for example in the area of lobby registers and the use of EU funds.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014. I support the rapporteur's assessment of the work of Emily O'Reilly, who was re-elected by Parliament as European Ombudsman at the plenary meeting in Strasbourg on 16 December 2014. It is to be appreciated that the EP report welcomes the Ombudsman's determination in his efforts to launch strategic investigations on his own initiative, as well as the fact that he is effective in assisting the EU institutions in their efforts to provide citizens and residents of Europe with the highest possible service, with a focus on transparency, in order to guarantee good administration.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ In 2014, the European Ombudsman's work was characterised by 325 inquiries launched following complaints. It closed 387 complaints investigations this year and closed 13 own-initiative investigations. The addressees of the complaint were mainly individual citizens, in up to 335 cases. The Ombudsman's role is to seek conciliatory solutions that would satisfy both sides. As regards the theme of complaints, up to 21.5% of cases concerned public access to documents to the EU institution. It is also the role of the European Ombudsman to protect the rights of persons with disabilities, but in my opinion this role should be taken up by more national ombudsmen. This is also one of the reasons why I have chosen not to support the report, because I am not intrinsially convinced that this function is justified at EU level.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the 2014 Report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman. I think that Ombudsman O'Reilly has done an excellent job of promoting transparency during this period. Thanks to its investigation, a number of important documents have been published, and I believe that it was its intervention in the transatlantic trade partnership negotiations that allayed citizens' greatest concerns, which stemed mainly from the opaque closed-door negotiations. The introduction of a so-called transparency register was also very important, which I believe is a useful tool for public awareness and gaining citizens' trust. I also appreciate the Ombudsman's trying to encourage the European institutions to provide accessible services for persons with disabilities.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the resolution approved by the European Ombudsman's annual report for 2014.  I support the intention to take complaints in cases of maladministration in the functioning of the Institutions of the European Union and all the successful work to be done so far.  However, at this point, I believe that we should consider a European Ombudsman within the EU, which will have wider powers and stricter powers to react when even the most klatant violations of the rights and freedoms of citizens of the European Union, enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, before the national authorities of the Member States.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – I voted against this annual report by the European Central Bank because I consider it an insult to this House that the 2014 annual report is not presented to Parliament until February 2016. However, I consider it much more serious that the head of the European Central Bank, Mr Draghi, is liquidating our common currency, the euro, with its monetary policy. Firstly, it is the release of a huge amount of money, and this cannot be called anything other than printing money without some real cover. And secondly, it's a knock-on of the base rate to almost zero. This devastating policy at the European Central Bank is only possible because, on the basis of the absurd voting mechanism in the ECB's board, debtors decide on creditors.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr In 2008, there was a financial crisis in 2009, and its consequences are still being felt, although it has been over for how many years, but due to the new, always developing international reality, the European Union's economy often continues to shake fever periodically. The european central bank's policy as a whole in this respect helps to overcome the consequences of this crisis effectively enough. Of course, there are clearly different types of shortcomings in its policies, such as different financial and credit policies for the different Member States. However, it cannot be accepted that the European Central Bank is trying to regulate inflation rates and stimulate economic growth.  It is imperative to say that in my country, Latvia, one Prime Minister called the years of the pre-crisis fat years, and in order for us to return to the fat years, it is imperative that we stimulate investment in business.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Central Bank, an institution of the highest economic importance, implemented anti-conventional monetary policies under the Draghi Presidency that were supposed to rebalance europe's financial situation. This has not been the case: the real economy is still suffering. The 2014 Annual Report on the ECB's work does not refer, or does so weakly, to essential economic factors: the inefficiency of the single currency, the supervisory mechanism (SSM) and the general role of the European Central Bank in the Europe system. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote against the ECB's annual report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this annual report on the activity of the European Central Bank (ECB) because it supports the expansion monetary policy it has been developing, including the Member States' public debt purchase programme, as well as the priority set in August 2012 to do everything necessary to ensure the financial stability of the euro area and the irreversibility of the single currency.  I regret, however, that a negative coalition, made up of the far-right, Eurosceptics, the radical left and most of the European People's Party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, has blocked Amendment No 12, promoted by a pro-European coalition made up of Members from four political groups, including the writer, and who asked the ECB to consider turning its profits (of the order of one billion euros a year) into a new resource of its own.  It is to be appreciated in any case that the amendment was supported by my group (Socialists and Democrats), so I will continue to work on the objective of increasing the European Union's own resources and, in particular, for constituting a fiscal capacity in the euro area.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the final result has diluted the important criticisms that the rapporteur made in the first version under discussion. The initial version of this report contained an express condemnation of the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, for the role played in the financial extortion to which this institution is subjecting the Member States to the periphery of the European Union. However, this initial text has been amended by most groups in this Parliament, leaving an idyllic, acrytic and decaffeinated vision of the activity carried out by this institution during the 2014 financial year. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the opinion of the ECON Committee on the ECB's annual report. Indeed, this text, which is supposed to comment on the ECB's policy two years ago, is actually focusing on current economic events and European policies. The lack of a critical view of the text on the deterioration of the macroeconomic situation and the adverse effects of the addictive drug QE is widely questionable. The destabilizing effects on asset prices associated with massive monetary creation, as well as the effects of low oil on inflation levels in relation to the ECB's objectives, are therefore insufficiently addressed.  Moreover, we find no questioning of the major European monetary pillars which have, let us remember, destroyed the economies of our countries. On the contrary, these are glorified in the text.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a welcome resolution on the latest Annual Report from the European Central Bank, especially the European Parliament’s call for further efforts to improve the financing of the real economy, and the emphasis on continuing to increase the democratic accountability of the ECB as a priority. It is positive that the ECB acknowledges the importance of helping small businesses to access finance, for example as a result of the credit-easing package of June 2014. However, I particularly endorse the comments made by Socialists and Democrats and other colleagues in the debate on failure of the ECB sufficiently to address the negative jobs impact of its actions generally and through its involvement in programmes in particular Member States. As an EU institution, the ECB is bound under Article 9 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union to take into account the requirement to promote employment and social protection and to combat social exclusion in defining and implementing its policies and activities.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 In this annual report of the European Central Bank, the European Parliament expresses its opinion on its work during 2014.  The ECB has a positive and key role in setting out unconventional monetary policy operations. However, it is clear that there are also certain limits to what a monetary policy can achieve on its own, and it is therefore clear in the final report that it is necessary to have more targeted investment and structured and socially balanced reforms with a positive sign.  Finally, as a group of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, we have managed, in cooperation with other political groups, to make it clear in the report, which I voted for, that there should also be a comprehensive assessment of the ECB's participation in the Troika and the Quartet and that the responsibilities it assumes should be clear, so as to ensure the democratic accountability of each institution in the adoption and implementation of the rescue programmes.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Central Bank's 2014 Annual Report. Despite the independence of the Central Bank, a debate on the correctness of its policies remains important. The forecasts for growth within the EU are currently 1.7 percent. Nevertheless, high unemployment rates remain a concern. In my view, therefore, it remains particularly important to support small and medium-sized enterprises, which are important job engines within the EU. The tactic of low interest rates also remains controversial, especially as regards pension savers and savings account holders. However, the objectives pursued are the right ones: to promote the way out of the debt crisis and to strengthen the single currency.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report presents the opinion of the ECON Committee on the ECB's annual report for 2014. While there is criticism and concern, for example about the difficulties of financing SMEs or the impact of securities purchases on the ECB's balance sheet, the fact remains that this text sins by its lack of a critical view on the deterioration of the macroeconomic situation and, even if it is mentioned, on the undesirable effects of the addictive drug that is "quantitative easing" and exit scenarios. Moreover, the report does not call into question, or even praise: banking union, capital markets union, budgetary governance, independence of the Central Bank, etc. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to confirm I voted against this report. The report calls for the European Central Bank (ECB) to initialise legislation which it is allowed to do under the Lisbon Treaty. I do not support further European legislation. The ECB makes profits from the loans it gives to Member States such as Greece. This report calls for the profits made from the financial suffering of Member States to be given to the European Union as ‘own resources’. The EU does not have its ‘own’ resources; it makes money out of European taxpayers and this case is no different.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report. I agree with the need to improve conditions for both public and private investment aimed at boosting growth and jobs and to continue efforts to ensure real-world financing. Member States need to implement sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms. The ECB must continue to strive to maintain favourable financing conditions, and public and private investment in the euro area remains significantly lower than it was before the current crisis. The important establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), as well as the Commission's plan to create a Genuine Capital Markets Union (CRS), which should diversify sources of funding in the EU economy, increase cross-border investment and improve access to finance for businesses, especially SMEs. The ECB must continue to contribute to efforts to increase cheap lending to the real economy and facilitate economic recovery, job creation, growth and stability.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report essentially provides commentary on the European Central Bank's 2014 report. It is a rather dry, professional material, and the real economic problems, such as the huge German export surplus, which has led to an increase in external indebtedship in the periphery countries, are not discussed. The report before the European Parliament set out a number of general and already well-known principles for the ECB, while acknowledging that the ECB's policy has not been particularly effective in boosting the euro area economy. Let us add that monetary governance instruments, such as cheap loans, cannot solve problems that arise from a lack of overall demand. The solution would have been strong public investment, which is prohibited by the Treaty of Lisbon. The report's recommendations are nothing more than confirmations of the neoliberal economic policy principles already applied. For this reason, I do not consider the report useful and have rejected it.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As every year, the ECON Committee presents its opinion on the ECB's annual report, with a one-year lag.  The exercise is therefore somewhat delicate since it is a question of commenting on the policy pursued by the ECB two years ago, while the news of 2015 and early 2016 has been very rich: resumption of banking supervision of systemic banks, launch and gradual extension of quantitative easing, management of the Greek crisis with Mario Draghi's reaffirmation of the commitment to support the euro at all costs. ,... It is in fact a report of self-satisfaction from Eurobeats and I logically voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is an annual report to assess the ECB's action. The ECB plays a key role in unconventional monetary policy operations. However, these are the limits of what monetary policy can achieve and we need more positive and targeted investment and socially balanced structural reforms. The report focuses on the economic outlook for the euro area and the ECB's role in macroeconomic adjustment programmes. There is also a questioning of the role of the troika and unconventional monetary policies.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Central Bank led by Mario Draghi launched in 2014, with the aim of supporting loans to the real economy, a series of long-term refinancing operations and several programmes for the purchase of selected financial assets in the private sector. In 2015 he then promoted an activity purchase program for 1100 billion euros. These and other operations, which involved unconventional measures, were a positive, if not a decisive, response to the Union's economic problems. I have decided to give my wholehearted support to the Marias report because I believe that the ECB's contribution to increasing low-interest loans to SMEs and, above all, to promoting an effective economic recovery in terms of employment, growth and stability is fundamental; The defence of the single currency, the supervisory role of the banking system and the commitment to price stability are essential contributions to ensuring that the European project moves towards greater integration.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by the European Parliament on the ECB's activity in 2014. The report contains some progressive elements, pointing out the negative role the ECB has played in Greece and the ECB's democratic deficit, and emphasizing the austerity policies that the ECB has pushed. However, I voted against the report as a whole because it contains implicit validation of the ECB's current structure.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the European Central Bank's 2014 Annual Report. It itself talks that the modest, geographically unbalanced recovery planned for the coming euro area years must be strengthened and that potential economic growth will need to be increased to reduce high unemployment rates in many euro area Member States and alleviate the burden of debt. I differed from my group in the vote on Amendment No 12, which called on the ECB to consider using its power of initiative in order to transform part of its net profits into a new Resource of the Union, so as to ensure that only Member States which had adopted the single currency benefited from the ECB's net profits. I regret that this amendment has not been adopted.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I rejected this report which proves once again that many Members prefer to hide their eyes rather than face the reality and consequences of the ECB's policies. If the rapporteur dares to criticise the ECB's gendarme, in particular on the difficulties of financing SMEs, the structural causes of the economic and monetary crisis we are going through are still not addressed: no questioning of the Banking Union, the Union of Capital Markets, the independence of the central bank... Worse, the rapporteur also does not dare to take head-on the ECB's desperate attempts to save the euro ("whatever the price", according to Mario Draghi) which lead to further desiring of the market with massive monetary creation. A report of such naivety or irresponsibility could therefore not receive my support.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the ineffectiveness of the economic policies put in place by the ECB to deal with the market crisis, given the banking crisis that is sinking Italians' savings due to measures such as the Bail In and the economic forecasts of another year of recession at European level, I did not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this annual report on the activity of the European Central Bank (ECB) because it supports the expansion monetary policy it has been developing, including the Member States' public debt purchase programme, as well as the priority set in August 2012 to do everything necessary to ensure the financial stability of the euro area and the irreversibility of the single currency.  I regret, however, that a negative coalition, made up of the far-right, Eurosceptics, the radical left and the majority of the European People's Party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, has blocked Amendment No 12, promoted by a pro-European coalition composed of Members from four political groups, including the writer, and who asked the ECB to consider turning its profits (of the order of one billion euros a year) into a new resource of its own.  It is to be appreciated in any case that the amendment was supported by my group (Socialists and Democrats), so I will continue to work on the objective of increasing the European Union's own resources and, in particular, for constituting a fiscal capacity in the euro area.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the annual report on the activities of the European Central Bank (ECB) in 2014. The European Parliament stresses that, while the ECB continues to seek to maintain favourable financing conditions, public and private investment in the euro area remains significantly lower than it was before the current crisis, and therefore welcomes the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), as well as the Commission's plan to create a genuine Capital Markets Union (CRS), which should diversify sources of finance in the EU economy, increase cross-border investment and improve the quality of investment by businesses, especially SMEs access to finance. Parliament calls on the Commission to come forward with proposals to improve macro-prudential supervision and policies to reduce the risk of shadow banking, taking into account the warning given in the ECB's annual report that, in view of the ever-expanding credit intermediation provided by banks over the past decade, further initiatives are needed to monitor and assess the vulnerability of the growing shadow banking sector. Parliament recalls its call for the ECB's annual report to include information on the insights identified in Parliament's annual report. He believes that it would be useful if the ECB, together with an assessment of monetary and financial conditions, presented an assessment of the gap in the volume of results in the euro area in its report following the monthly meeting of the Board of Governors.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported Parliament's resolution on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank, although it is also relatively critical of some of the actions of this joint financial institution within EMU.  Of course, it is not just criticism but also warnings and recommendations. Thus, Parliament pointed to significant increases in risk associated with the programme for the purchase of different government bonds, the imbalance between the conditions and the level of interest rates for SMEs compared to large, insufficient cooperation with Parliament and the like.  However, Members are aware that the situation in the financial markets is challenging and that the ECB is making great efforts to help ensure financial stability in some countries and that, as a result, it must also occasionally take advantage of measures which until recently were considered unconventional.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The role that the ECB has played and continues to play in providing support to the real economy through targeted longer-term refinancing operations and private sector financial activity purchase programmes, together with its attempt to bring inflation closer to the 2% threshold, and therefore in a more balanced position, is important to enable the full economic recovery of the euro area. Nevertheless, the development of growth and investment in the eurozone has so far been slow, and this is clear because, as we have been advocating for a long time, monetary policy cannot be the only solution to Europe's economic problems, but we need more coordinated and courageous political action, based on the implementation of structural reforms and the revival of investment, both public and private. The contribution made by the ECB therefore deserves, of course, to be recognised, but we must remember that monetary policy is still a limited instrument and that we need an all-encompassing policy mix, including the completion of the Banking Union and fiscal policy.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative non-binding report. The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ECB led by Mario Draghi had the courage and took considerable risks in doing everything in its power to save the euro: it lowered its main refinancing rates to the effective lower limit and reduced the deposit rate to -0.20% and, at the same time, implemented constant diplomatic action aimed at reassuring stakeholders and melting market tensions by contributing to the stability of the eurozone and preventing the emergence of new financial critical issues.  However, we must reiterate that the economic line of the eurozone cannot be taken by a technical body – however qualified it may be – but must depend on the political will of the European citizens. , and we will not change the EU's economic line by overcoming the logic of austerity alone as a way out of the crisis and instead implementing a genuine supranational public investment policy.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The ECON Committee presents its opinion on the 2014 Annual Report of the European Central Bank (ECB). The rapporteur expresses serious concerns about the ECB's inability to revive private investment and remains very sceptical about the effectiveness of quantitative easing in the recovery of activity in the euro area.  While we can share the many criticisms leveled against the ECB, we criticise the rapporteur for his lack of lucidity when it comes to studying the causes of the current economic slump. The single currency prevents us from freely using monetary leverage to finance investments that will contribute to tomorrow's growth. Monetary sovereignty is, in fact, essential when fiscal room for manoeuvre is extremely limited. Finally, this text makes no reference to the Banking Union, the Capital Markets Union and the independence of the ECB, which are at the root of the economic difficulties that the Euro Area Member States are currently facing. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report of the European Central Bank for 2014 captures the main aspects of the ECB's work during the period concerned, marking the important points of the European Central Bank's action, following which certain recommendations were drawn up. The European Central Bank acted promptly on the difficult situation characterised by falling inflation, the downward trend in lending activity, the slow pace of economic growth, and the ECB resorting to unconventional monetary policy instruments. However, further sustained efforts are needed to strengthen potential economic growth and to reduce high unemployment rates in many euro area Member States and, at the same time, to reduce debt. It is also necessary to improve the conditions for public and private investments aimed at stimulating economic growth and job creation. I was in favour of this report because I believe that there is a need for the European Central Bank to continue its contribution to the Union's general economic policies and to the achievement of the related objectives, in order to overcome economic obstacles and ensure economic growth in all Member States.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. A banking crisis is exploding in Italy because of bail-in in Europe's general disinterest. QE did not stop deflation and was supposed to be done in 2011 instead of starting the spread. The discourse of the "risk" of sovereign debt must be ELIMINATED and even the minimum spread that exists today must be zeroed. No sovereign debt in its own currency in the rest of the world is risky while the very existence of the spread certifies this risk. QE should be used to buy securities in such a way as to reset spreads, not proportionally. Then the economic forecasts seem too optimistic: objective analyses foreshadow another year of recession.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this annual report on the activity of the European Central Bank (ECB) because it supports the expansion monetary policy it has been developing, including the Member States' public debt purchase programme, as well as the priority set in August 2012 to do everything necessary to ensure the financial stability of the euro area and the irreversibility of the single currency.  I regret, however, that a negative coalition, made up of the far-right, Eurosceptics, the radical left and most of the European People's Party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, has blocked Amendment No 12, promoted by a pro-European coalition made up of Members from four political groups, including the writer, and who asked the ECB to consider turning its profits (of the order of one billion euros a year) into a new resource of its own.  It is to be appreciated in any case that the amendment was supported by my group (Socialists and Democrats), so I will continue to work on the objective of increasing the European Union's own resources and, in particular, for constituting a fiscal capacity in the euro area.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Every year, the European Parliament prepares an initiative report on the activities of the European Central Bank (ECB). In these difficult economic times and with low inflation, the ECB has put in place exceptional measures such as lower interest rates and quantitative easing in order to refinance the European economy. I voted in favour of this report, which provides an overview of the ECB's European monetary policy in 2014.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I gave my positive vote on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2014 on the basis of the following considerations: the crisis has painfully highlighted the economic difficulties that European citizens face when structural rigidities are not promptly and incisively corrected by the Member States; it follows that the ECB must be credited with defending the euro and price stability; an obligatory step to correct macroeconomic imbalances and make effective use of the Stability Pact in any case involves strengthening governance and coordinating economic policies; the great fragility of the euro economy leaves ample room for action on the political commitment of states and institutions to the implementation of sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. Aside from some worrisome elements within the text, I also strongly object to the manner in which this text came to be voted upon. Compromise amendments, which had included the input from all political parties, were discarded at the last minute in favour of ‘Alternative Compromises’ from a few select groupings. Although there were some good elements in the report, which highlighted the detrimental and negative role the ECB played in Greece, I strongly object to the undemocratic architecture of the ECB as a whole and therefore these elements were not strong enough for me to endorse the entire text. It goes without saying that rather than developing further steps towards pooling sovereignty, there is a need to reject austerity policies, prioritise public investment, democratise the governance structure and to redefine the European Monetary Union. In any event, the ECB is based on the idea of deepening the power of supranational bodies which will move the political power further away from the people. This is fundamentally undemocratic and an agenda which I strongly oppose.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the very difficult negotiations, I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Central Bank in the year 2014, which, despite an improved situation, was still an economically challenging year, with the ECB having to lower its key refinancing rates and reduce its deposit facility rate. I agree with the recommendations that the ECB should put greater effort into the creation of more favourable financing conditions – private and public investment are crucial for economic growth and the subsequent creation of jobs and wealth. I welcome the attempts by the European Central Bank to boost inflation to around 2% and the steps taken to improve transparency of the Bank to make it more accountable and visible to the citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is about the European Parliament's assessment of the work of the European Central Bank in 2014. The initial text was well aligned with the position of the Five Star Movement, as it contained a harsh criticism of the inefficiency of the unconventional policies adopted by the ECB to rebalance the European financial situation. Indeed, these measures have not achieved the desired result: the real economy is still suffering and the management of the supervisory mechanism within the ECB does not meet the necessary transparency requirements. The text of the report, as amended as a result of compromises between the different political parties, is, however, purged of these aspects of criticism. No reference is made to essential elements such as the inefficiency of the single currency and the supervisory mechanism. I have therefore chosen to vote against.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and recognise that the ECB, in response to a complex environment characterised by a sovereign debt crisis, falling inflation, credit contraction and sluggish economic growth, and with its interest rates approaching the lower zero threshold, has unfortunately also taken erroneous decisions on key issues. The report also contains positive elements and we therefore support it.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report can only concern and affect millions of European citizens.  As it is the Central Bank of Europe, we understand that the decisions taken and the policies taken play a particular role within the Member States. Because I believe that the ECB's policy during the crisis that led to the poverty of thousands of Europeans was not appropriate, and because there are not enough critical references in the report, I find myself in the unfortunate position of voting against it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I recognise the european Central Bank's great contribution as a supervisory authority on the European banking system. The ECB's contribution includes efforts to increase low-interest loans for the benefit of the real economy and to foster economic recovery in terms of employment, growth and stability. In particular, in 2014, the European Central Bank implemented a series of targeted longer-term refinancing operations and programmes for the purchase of selected private sector financial assets, with the aim of supporting loans to the real economy. Parliament stressed that the ECB's supervisory role and its monetary policy function must be clearly distinguished and that the combination of the two functions should not give rise to conflicts of interest for the ECB. The legislative body stresses the need for democratic accountability in view of the new supervisory functions conferred on the ECB, as well as its advisory role for the Troika and Quadriga programmes.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Let me be clear: I believe that the euro has been managed in a questionable way and I do not want to be a nationalist, but it cannot be denied that Mario Draghi makes us proud every day, as Italians, of the way in which he fulfills his institutional duties. The criticisms initially made in this report have rightly been reduced with the fundamental contribution of my political group, and it is right that this should be the case because without its credibility on the markets and without its ability to deliver on its promises today, Europe would probably already be in pieces, and with it its States and its citizens. Congratulations to my compatriot Mr Draghi, and to the shadow rapporteur, who has been able to add a report that has been somewhat distorted.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the fact that the European Central Bank is guiding its action to maintain favourable financing conditions, private and public investment in the euro area remains considerably below pre-global crisis levels. Given this complex context of the sovereign debt crisis, rising inflation, credit contraction and stagnant economic growth, the ECB has resorted to unconventional monetary policy instruments. I support the Marias Report as a result, as it registers the positive effect of some measures, such as the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as well as the European Commission's plan to establish a genuine Capital Market Union, which should diversify sources of funding in the EU economy, boost cross-border investment and increase business access , in particular SMEs, to finance. I agree that the ecb's supervisory role and monetary policy function should be clearly distinguished and should not lead to conflicts of interest for the ECB, and that institution should be subject to democratic scrutiny in view of the new responsibilities conferred.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non legislative non-binding report. The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's usual annual report on the ecb's activities.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Findings show that real GDP is predicted to rise by 1.4% in 2015, 1.7% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017 however, it is becoming more evident that the foundations for growth are fragile hence requiring a stronger dose of political commitment. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are fundamental in this respect as they represent 99% of all businesses and account for 80% of jobs in the Union, thus having a key role in generating economic growth, creating jobs and narrowing social disparities. Banks have an important role to play by making access to funding more efficient and less bureaucratic.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament was called upon to present its assessment of the work of the European Central Bank in 2015. The ECB's policies have proved to be ineffective in supporting the real economy and boosting growth, and hard-hit efforts have also been made in relation to the Troika and the functioning of the single currency. In order to reach a compromise between the political parties, we have arrived at a document that is far from sustainable. My criticism is mainly directed at the role of monetary policy, which does not seem to be suitable for resolving the emergency and crisis situation that Europe is facing, and I also believe that the supervision mechanism (SSM) managed within the ECB is not adequate. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the final result has diluted the important criticisms that the rapporteur made in the first version under discussion. The initial version of this report contained an express condemnation of the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, for the role played in the financial extortion to which this institution is subjecting the Member States to the periphery of the European Union. However, this initial text has been amended by most groups in this Parliament, leaving an idyllic, acrytic and decaffeinated vision of the activity carried out by this institution during the 2014 financial year. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The ECB's 2014 annual report submitted had a great deal of key information in both the European Union's finances and policy areas. Unfortunately, in many cases, the report tabled did not convince me to take a clear decision, so I decided to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Central Bank has played an important and crucial role during the economic crises faced by the Union. However, I believe that we need to create a common basis framework to increase investments and to have balanced structural reforms. I voted in favour of this report, as the European Central Bank is playing a positive role by the implementation of a non-conventional monetary policy operations. We need to address the limitations of monetary policy. I also strongly agree that the ECB needs to provide an assessment and clarify its scope about the involvement in the Troika and Quadriga framework. I voted against an amendment which was presented by over 40 MEPs which called for the possibility to use ECB profits for creating an EU own resource.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's position in the European Central Bank's (ECB) 2014 annual report. The report points to the limited effects and risks associated with the Bank's asset buyback program ("quantitative easing"). This programme has not yet resulted in the desired inflation rate of almost 2%, still below, nor has it reduced the gap between the borrowing rates granted to SMEs and those granted to larger companies. MEPs remind us that monetary policy cannot solve fiscal and economic problems and should not replace the necessary structural reforms. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament makes its recommendations in light of the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report. The European Central Bank plays a key role in improving the conditions for public and private investment in the euro area to stimulate growth and job creation. In particular, I wanted to stress once again the need to allow access to finance for SMEs.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Admittedly, this report, which deals with the ECB's report, rightly mentions the financing problems of small and medium-sized enterprises or the consequences of buying securities on the balance sheet of the European Central Bank. It is regrettable that the report does not challenge asset acquisitions in the context of quantitative easing. While the news of bubbles and excesses resulting from massive monetary creation is not sufficiently addressed, the consequences of "low oil" on the inflation targets set by the ECB are not discussed any more. In view of the lack of questioning of the dogmas relating to budgetary governance, the functioning of the European Central Bank, the banking union or the capital markets union, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Annual Activity Report of the European Central Bank for 2014 reflects the real state of the Bank, as well as several criticisms about unconventional monetary policy. According to my political group, the report contains several paragraphs that are too positive in its assessment of the central bank's activities.  For this reason, I decided to abstain.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 A single sentence of the report illustrates the essence of the existence of the European Central Bank, but also the economic policy of Germany and, by extension, of the European Union. Paragraph 11: 'welcomes the unequivocal commitment of the European Central Bank to make every effort to protect the euro which it undertook in August 2012'. Everything about money, not about citizens, not about nations, not even about countries. It is clear that the so-called stability of the euro is simply a means of enforcing Germany's financial interests, so part of the problem. In order to become part of the solution, the European Union must change direction. And this can only be done with nationalist governments that energize the citizen, the family and the nation against money.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The economic recovery in the euro area is expected to progress, with GDP growth of 1.4 % expected in 2015, 1.7% in 2016 and 1.8 % in 2017, but a strong political commitment to sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms essential to stimulating economic growth is needed. Unemployment in the euro area itself is expected to slow ly decline from 11.6% at the end of 2014 to 10.5% at the end of 2016 with wide disparities between unemployment rates in the different Member States, with figures ranging from 6.4 % in Germany to 26.6 % in Greece. The average inflation rate in the euro area, after remaining close to zero in the first half of 2015, is expected to rise again, rising to 1.1% in 2016 and 1.7% in 2017, although the ECB continues its action to maintain favourable financing conditions. The truth is that private investment and public investment in the euro area remain considerably below the levels before the current crisis and the European institutions must continue in constant dialogue so that Europe's economic, social and political objectives are well off.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this annual report on the activity of the European Central Bank (ECB) because it supports the expansion monetary policy it has been developing, including the Member States' public debt purchase programme, as well as the priority set in August 2012 to do everything necessary to ensure the financial stability of the euro area and the irreversibility of the single currency.  I regret, however, that a negative coalition, made up of the far-right, Eurosceptics, the radical left and the majority of the European People's Party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, has blocked Amendment No 12, promoted by a pro-European coalition composed of Members from four political groups, including the writer, and who asked the ECB to consider turning its profits (of the order of one billion euros a year) into a new resource of its own.  It is to be appreciated in any case that the amendment was supported by my group (Socialists and Democrats), so I will continue to work on the objective of increasing the European Union's own resources and, in particular, for constituting a fiscal capacity in the euro area.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The austerity policies promoted by the ECB and the European institutions are the cause of rising unemployment, especially among young people, and are undermining the social systems in the field of education, health and welfare, which should be the pillars of European society. We continue to hide the harshest criticism of the single currency, the ineffectiveness of European monetary policies and the lack of transparency of the ECB's bodies. The eurozone Member States, by surrendering sovereignty over their own currency and banking system, have allowed heavy interference over the fundamental right to self-determination democratically. I am voting against.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report criticises some aspects of the ECB's monetary policy as well as the rules for its functioning. However, their content and overall sense are overall negative. It welcomes the Banking Union, the UMC and the EFSI. It advocates that the so-called "fiscal consolidation" should continue. It advocates "structural reforms", sweetening them with (pasme-se) a so-called "social balance". Forget the need for separation between investment banking and commercial banking. It opposes the renegotiation and consequent restructuring of debts. It states that the rules of economic governance must be respected and strengthened. It requests that all stability pact tools be applied. The report does not call into question the ecb's deeply undemocratic nature, nor does it far exceed the area of its statutory powers, and is inlerable in the economic policies of national states. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. I believe Ireland should leave eurozone.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against as there is no interest in the Italian banking crisis and the economic forecasts seem too optimistic.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative. A single sentence in the report illustrates the essence of the existence of the European Central Bank, but also the economic policy of Germany and, by extension, of the European Union. name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the ECB's annual report considering that I support monetary policy carried out by the European Central Bank to ensure price stability. However, we must be aware that its effect will not last without structural reforms, budgetary discipline and productive investment in the Member States.
