name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the ECB's 2014 annual report because I believe that the European Central Bank has ensured in these years of crisis, within the limits of the Treaty, the stability of the eurozone, through the use of unconventional monetary policy instruments, culminating in quantitative easing (purchase by the ESCB of government bonds, covered bonds, mostly banking and securities issued by development banks) in operation since March 2015 , together with traditional monetary policy instruments such as the management of official rates, gradually reduced, to the point of being brought close to zero or even negative, to avoid deposits with the ECB. Expectations of a strengthening of quantitative easing at the next meeting of the ECB's Board of Governors are desirable as necessary in order to allow for a better transmission of monetary policy and an increase in the inflow of liquidity to the real economy. However, deepening and strengthening the eurozone will depend on the completion of the Banking Union. Failure to complete is the cause of distortions within the eurozone between Member States and ultimately between savers. In order to deal with systemic risks, it is essential to create a European deposit guarantee scheme. That is the message from the EP to the Council.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Central Bank's 2014 Annual Report, which at the right points recognises the performance of the Central Bank in the debt crisis of individual EU Member States, while at the same time openly mentioning the lack of transparance.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. – The ECB contribution covers economic development in the areas of employment, growth and monetary stability. I consider it an important contribution to supporting the real economy and securing private financial assets.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this annual ECB report as it is a positive but still critical report recognising the important role the ECB plays in the recovery of the European economy, in the special programmes it has set up and as European banking supervisor.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative non-binding report. The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by the European Parliament on the ECB's activity in 2014. The report contains some progressive elements, pointing out the negative role the ECB has played in Greece and the ECB's democratic deficit, and emphasizing the austerity policies that the ECB has pushed. However, I voted against the report as a whole because it contains implicit validation of the ECB's current structure.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The Annual Report 2014 addresses among other things the TLTROs, the negative interest rate on deposits, ABSs, covered bond and government securities purchase programmes and the setting up of the SSM.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this annual report on the activity of the European Central Bank (ECB) because it supports the expansion monetary policy it has been developing, including the Member States' public debt purchase programme, as well as the priority set in August 2012 to do everything necessary to ensure the financial stability of the euro area and the irreversibility of the single currency.  I regret, however, that a negative coalition, made up of the far-right, Eurosceptics, the radical left and the majority of the European People's Party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, has blocked Amendment No 12, promoted by a pro-European coalition composed of Members from four political groups, including the writer, and who asked the ECB to consider turning its profits (of the order of one billion euros a year) into a new resource of its own.  It is to be appreciated in any case that the amendment was supported by my group (Socialists and Democrats), so I will continue to work on the objective of increasing the European Union's own resources and, in particular, for constituting a fiscal capacity in the euro area.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our position that the neoliberal austerity policies implemented in the euro area are inextricably linked to the democratic deficits of the construction of the euro. The ECB is participating in the Troika, and the banking union is getting more and more supervisory rights from national central banks, thus promoting the interests of huge banks rather than co-operation and small banks that finance small and medium-sized enterprises.  The report also prevents state debt restructuring processes and supports macroeconomic adjustment programmes. We voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Central Bank Annual Report 2014. This annual report describes the previous year’s activities of the European Central Bank and reports on the eurozone’s monetary policy. It correctly highlights our modest recovery and current low growth environment. Its outlines some clear causes and obstacles of the Union’s slow growth such as poor financing conditions for SMEs, the modest impact of the asset purchase programme on money and credit dynamics, and the effect of negative interest rates on deposits. It also correctly voices concerns about possible unintended consequences and long-term effects of unconventional monetary policy measures. I was particularly pleased to see the report also states that the ECB’s involvement in the troika was illegal and calls for an assessment of the role the ECB played within troika.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which is the Parliament’s annual own initiative report on the activities of the European Central Bank. It covers the interesting period of the ECB’s unconventional measures destined to combat very low levels of inflation. This occurred during the time when most of the Member States that had been through a sovereign debt crisis were exiting their programmes, while the economic recovery in the euro area was still developing.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the ECB's 2014 Annual Report. The report addresses, among other things, the ECB's non-conventional monetary policies. The report calls for a review of the ECB's actions and its role in the troika and calls for political independence of the ECB, which also supports ALFA.  However, the report lacks a thorough and critical analysis of the possible far-reaching negative consequences of the current ECB programme of ultra-loose monetary policy (quantitative easing). In the light of several actions pending before the Federal Constitutional Court, in particular against the ECB's OMT programme and its ultra-loose monetary policy, it is an absolute must to raise the ECB's potential mandate overruns. Parliament's report does not fulfil this obligation and subsequently failed to obtain my vote. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non legislative non-binding report. The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the annual report on the European Central Bank, in which the European Parliament expresses its views on the work carried out in 2014. The ECB lunched a new phase of non-standard measures in 2014 which came after the decline in inflation rates since 2013 and tenuous euro area growth prospects. However, we all know that there are limits to what monetary policy can achieve. We need more investment and socially—balanced structural reforms.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to adopt the European Central Bank's annual report for 2014, taking into account the contribution to solving the economic crisis, achieving macroeconomic stability, boosting investment, consumption and economic growth measures. Measures still need to be continued for a modest and geographically uneven economic recovery and still high unemployment rates.  In particular, a more favourable funding rate should be provided for SMEs. Private and public investment is still at a much lower level than before the crisis. The impact of the asset purchase programme on monetary and credit policy is positive but still modest. In this sense, inflation expectations have started to rise and the risk of a deflationary spiral has decreased.  Monetary policy measures that bring attractiveness to investment in the euro area should be continued. The independence of the ECB should be respected and its role in safeguarding financial stability and fostering transparency of central banks is important. It is important that the ECB's supervisory function and monetary policy functions are clearly separated. I welcome President Draghi's willingness to inform the EP of the ECB's positions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Criticism of the European Central Bank's balance sheet is insufficient. The macroeconomic balance sheet is too optimistic and there are many formulas that welcome the policies pursued by the European Union. The destabilizing effects on asset prices (bubbles, market instability) associated with massive monetary creation, as well as the effects of low oil on inflation levels in relation to ECB objectives, are insufficiently addressed. The main pillars of the EU's economic policies are not questioned, or even praised: Banking Union, Capital Markets Union, fiscal governance of the 6 and 2 Packs, independence of the central bank, ban on the direct monetisation of public debts... So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non legislative non-binding report. The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Notis Marias' report on the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report. This report examines the ECB's unconventional measures against low inflation in the European Union. These exceptional measures were implemented by the European Central Bank because most Member States faced significant difficulties with their sovereign debt. I support this balanced report, which is a european Parliament's control over the activities of the European Central Bank.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report examines the unconventional measures used by the European Central Bank (ECB) during the sovereign debt crisis. These measures have mainly focused on combating the very low level of inflation in the euro area. The stability of the area is an essential element that the Central Bank managed to preserve in 2014.  I voted in favour of this clear and balanced report on the ECB's activities.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. In terms of content, it takes up the right criticisms, but I am opposed to the concept of a transfer union.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the ECB's 2014 Annual Report. The report addresses, among other things, the ECB's non-conventional monetary policy measures. The report calls for a review of the ECB's actions and its role in the troika and calls for political independence of the ECB. ALFA also supports these demands.  However, the report lacks a thorough and critical analysis of the possible far-reaching negative consequences of the current ECB programme. With this program called "quantitative easing," the ECB is expanding its monetary base to reduce real interest rates. This is justified by exceptional circumstances.  In the light of several lawsuits pending before the Federal Constitutional Court against the ECB and its ultra-loose monetary policy, it is an absolute must to raise the ECB's potential mandate overruns. Parliament's report does not fulfil this obligation and subsequently failed to obtain my vote.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Central Bank's 2014 Annual Report was one of the documents for which I believe it is not possible to raise my hand in good conscience. I therefore voted against it because I believe that this institution does not work on democratic foundations and has contributed to the economic destabilisation of several EU countries. While the report stresses that democratic accountability is needed in view of the new supervisory responsibilities entrusted to the ECB, as well as its advisory role in the Troika and Four programmes, it does not set out what this democratic responsibility should look like, and I therefore consider this report to be worthless and potentially harmful.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – A strong political commitment to the implementation of sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms is crucial to strengthening economic growth. Public and private investment in the euro area continues to be lower than before the current crisis. The creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI or EFSI) will help to promote cross-border investment and improve access to credit for businesses, in particular SMEs. I recognise the ECB's efforts to increase low-interest loans for the benefit of the real economy, and measures to promote economic recovery through growth and stability. I would remind you that the primary objective of the ECB is to maintain price stability and has tried by all means to comply with this obligation. I have decided to give a positive opinion to the report because the work carried out by the ECB in the year under review shows that it has done everything in its power to protect the financial stability of the EU.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report because of its lack of a critical view on the deterioration of the macroeconomic situation and, even if mentioned, on the adverse effects of the addictive drug "Quantitative easing".  The destabilizing effects on asset prices (bubbles, market instability) associated with massive monetary creation, as well as the effects of low oil on inflation levels in relation to the ECB's objectives, are therefore insufficiently addressed. Of course, the main pillars of the EU's economic policies are not questioned, or even praised: Banking Union, Capital Markets Union, fiscal governance of the 6 and 2 Packs, independence of the central bank, ban on direct monetisation of public debts, etc.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it gives an overly optimistic assessment of the ECB's activities.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 This annual report is the best in years, although it can always be better. The report contains some particularly critical paragraphs concerning the ECB's irresponsible monetary policy. Unfortunately, the "grand coalition" of PPE, S&D and ALDE was not prepared to question whether the ECB is not over-mandated. That is one of the reason why the N-VA delegation opted for abstention.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the final result has diluted the important criticisms that the rapporteur made in the first version under discussion. The initial version of this report contained an express condemnation of the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, for the role played in the financial extortion to which this institution is subjecting the Member States to the periphery of the European Union. However, this initial text has been amended by most groups in this Parliament, leaving an idyllic, acrytic and decaffeinated vision of the activity carried out by this institution during the 2014 financial year. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the ECB's 2014 Annual Report. The report addresses, among other things, the ECB's non-conventional monetary policies. The report calls for a review of the ECB's actions and its role in the troika and calls for political independence of the ECB, which also supports ALFA.  However, the report lacks a thorough and critical analysis of the possible far-reaching negative consequences of the ECB's countervalued programme of ultra-loose monetary policy (quantitative easing). In the light of several actions pending before the Federal Constitutional Court, in particular against the ECB's OMT programme and its ultra-loose monetary policy, it is an absolute must to raise the ECB's potential mandate overruns. Parliament's report does not fulfil this obligation and subsequently failed to obtain my vote.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against Amendment 12, tabled by a group of more than 40 Members, which proposed that the ECB use its powers under Article 129(1) of the Treaty. 3 TFEU and its profit was used as the EU's own source of revenue. The ECB should be abolished and Member States should return to their own currency.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In 2014, the European Central Bank (ECB) lowered interest rates to an effective lower limit and interest rate on cash deposits to -0.20%. In 2014, the ECB launched a series of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO) and purchase programmes for selected private sector securities to boost lending to the real economy.  The report notes that market fragmentation and the debt burden of SMEs need to be reduced. Furthermore, conditions for public and private investment need to be improved to boost growth and job creation. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and the banking system is crucial in lending them to give them the opportunity to increase competitiveness and growth.  I supported the ECB report for 2014, as I believe the ECB has taken important measures to stimulate investment and growth.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the maintenance of the euro to be the most fundamental role of the European Central Bank, as the institution responsible for monetary policy. It is necessary for the ECB to closely monitor and analyse monetary, financial and economic developments and to take the necessary measures flexibly in order to protect the euro internally and externally.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report for the reasons I mentioned in my speeches as rapporteur in the debate held in the Plenary of the European Parliament on 1/2/2016, also pointing out the following: The report I prepared on the ECB's 2014 annual report, as tabled in August 2015, was complete and particularly harsh on the ECB's activities. The post-vote report maintains several points of criticism of the ECB's neoliberal policy. Paragraphs 13 and 30 of the report, referring to judgment C-62/14 of the Court of Justice of the EU, on the one hand pave the way for the haircut of ECB bonds and, on the other hand, call for the ECB to be evicted from the troika. Paragraphs 30,31,32 harshly criticise the role of the troika and initiate its control by the European Parliament. Paragraphs 19, 22, 25 and the arrangements of the first part of paragraph 15 referred to in the debt audit are important.  Of course, there are aspects in the final report with which I do not agree, such as the controversial remaining part of paragraph 15, which could nevertheless be understood to accept debt restructuring provided that it is not done ad hoc, but on the basis of the provisions in force and as long as it does not rekindle the debt crisis.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This visionless report merely comments on current economic events and European policies, as well as the ECB's action.  As last year, there are some criticisms and concerns, for example about the difficulties of financing SMEs or the impact of securities purchases on the ECB's balance sheet. However, it can be blamed for its lack of a critical view on the deterioration of the macroeconomic situation and, even if mentioned, on the adverse effects of the addictive drug "Quantitative Easing".  And, of course, it should be noted that the main pillars of the EU's economic policies are not questioned, or even praised: Banking Union, Capital Markets Union, fiscal governance of the 6 and 2 Packs, independence of the Central Bank, prohibition of the direct monetisation of public debts... Pillars that we strongly oppose.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the 2014 annual report on the European Central Bank, in which we from the European Parliament show our support for some of the main measures taken that year to facilitate economic growth and employment in Europe, as well as the roundness with which the ECB is working to defend the euro.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank 2014. I welcome the decisions taken by the ECB to promote public and private investment and to ensure price stability. I also share the view in the resolution that monetary policy cannot solve all the fiscal and economic problems faced by many Member States and therefore require appropriate structural reforms and fiscal consolidation measures.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report welcomes the calamitous action of the European Central Bank (ECB).  He welcomes the fact that "the ECB made it clear in August 2012 that it will "do everything possible" to protect the euro", i.e. to maintain its monetary action solely for the benefit of the Germans. It reaffirms "its commitment to respect the independence of the ECB in the conduct of monetary policy". He welcomed the "creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI)" which, however, is of little use. Finally, the report recalls the ban on the "direct purchase by national central banks or by the ECB of debt issued by the European Union" at the origin of the public debt crisis. I am voting against this report, which does not propose any reorientation of the role of the ECB.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report expresses concern and contains noteworthy remarks. However, overall, criticism of the ECB is insufficient and considerations on the macroeconomic balance sheet are too optimistic. Moreover, the many congratulations made to the Union's policies, which mark the text, are illegitimate in my view.  As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. In compliance with the obligation laid down in Article 113(3) of the Treaty, the European Central Bank publishes a report on monetary policy and the activities of the ESCB each year. I believe that Member States must continue to carry out sustainable structural reforms that are essential to promote economic growth. I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal. The European Central Bank has a role to play in reducing unemployment rates and debt burdens across Europe.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the annual report of the European Central Bank, because it is playing a positive, key, role with its non-conventional monetary policy operations. The report calls for better targeted investments and positive, socially balanced, structural reforms. However, I have voted against amendment 12, which calls for the possibility to use ECB profits for creating an EU own resource because I am not in agreement with this particular amendment.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The President of the ECB submitted a report on the bank's activities in 2014.  The Motion for a Resolution of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs stresses that: according to the Commission's autumn forecast, economic recovery in the euro area is expected to expand, but this growth is not on a stable footing; unemployment in the euro area will slowly fall, but unemployment in many Member States remains at alarming levels; the euro area is expected to reduce the budget deficit and public debt; low energy prices can help the economic recovery. It therefore proposes that the EP take a position in favour of strengthening the geographically unequal and modest recovery in order to reduce the high unemployment rate and the debt burden. It also proposes that Parliament expect the ECB to contribute to the overall economic policy within the Union within the meaning of Article 282 TSI, provided that the success of its main mission of price stability is not jeopardised and reaffirms its commitment to respecting the ECB's independence in the management of monetary policy, as enrined in the Treaty. Finally, it recommends that national governments and authorities refrain from asking the ECB to take specific measures.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. As every year, the ECON Committee presents its opinion on the ECB's annual report, with a year of lag, in a report that actually comments on current economic and European policies, as well as the ECB's action.  On a recurring basis, there are some criticisms and concerns, for example about the difficulties of financing SMEs or the impact of securities purchases on the ECB's balance sheet. However, it can be blamed for its lack of a critical view on the deterioration of the macroeconomic situation and, even if mentioned, on the adverse effects of the addictive drug EQ and exit scenarios.  Of course, the main pillars of the Union's economic policies are not questioned, or even praised: Banking Union, Capital Markets Union, six-pack and two-pack budgetary governance, central bank independence, ban on direct monetisation of public debt, etc. We therefore vote against this report, which goes against our positions on these issues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. It is easy to criticise this report for its lack of a critical view of the deteriorating macroeconomic situation, which affects all European countries. The destabilizing effects on asset prices (bubbles, market instability) associated with massive monetary creation, as well as the effects of low oil on inflation levels in relation to ECB objectives, are insufficiently addressed. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the european Central Bank's annual report for 2014. The ECB's monetary policy is a fundamental pillar of Europe's economic recovery. The work that the bank has undertaken in recent years is important and courageous, especially thanks to the launch of the quantitative easing operation, which is giving European countries a favourable period to discuss and approve structural reforms, which can add competitiveness to economies and reduce the burden of high unemployment that still weighs on some Member States. The report also recognises the key role played by the ECB during the economic and financial crisis. In the context of this report, I would like to stress the importance of an approved amendment, proposed by a coalition of more than forty MEPs, calling on the European Central Bank to transform the profits generated by the bank's actions into European Union resources, instead of redistributing them to the national central banks.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Central Bank is the central bank of the 19 European Union Member States that have adopted the euro. Its main task is to maintain price stability in the euro area and preserve the purchasing power of the single currency. I have voted for this report on the European Central Bank’s annual activity report for 2014 that highlights the steps needed for a stronger monetary union, amongst which we can identify the Commission’s plan to establish a Capital Markets Union that should diversify sources of financing in the EU economy, boost cross-border investment and increase access to financing for business, especially SMEs.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the ECB's 2014 Annual Activity Report and appreciate that it remained focused on this subject and did not contain elements unrelated to this subject. An example is the call for the ECB to consider using its power to initiate legislation and to convert part of the bank's net profit into a new Union own resource, in addition to doing so to ensure that only Member States that have adopted the single currency benefit from the ECB's net profit. I am not in favour of taking serious political initiatives without prior in-depth discussion and clarification of what they are being pursued and what their impact will be. Not to mention that controversial and divisive rather than unifying policy initiatives do not even belong in the annual report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains defensible and important criticisms, but does not address the shortcomings of the Transfer Union. Therefore, since not all the critical points were mentioned, I would have abstained from voting.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report in question unsted the ECB's monetary policy for 2014. The text is consistent with the eu's austere economic policy in the EU over the past few years and calls on Member States to implement structural reforms to comply with macroeconomic criteria, particularly those countries that have been under a fiscal consolidation programme, and opposes the idea of restructuring public debt. These elements led me to vote against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. According to the report, the euro area is expected to recover easily from the recession, the fall in unemployment and the improvement in the fiscal forecast. However, it is important to work further to strengthen the economy, inter alia by increasing access to finance for SMEs and keeping inflation below or close to 2%.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The report includes a call for the ECB to initiate legislation to permit the EU to take as its ‘own resources’ the profits of the ECB – profits which currently are distributed to eurozone Member States. UKIP objects to the activities of the ECB and, as the UK is a shareholder in the ECB, UKIP accordingly voted against the report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Central Bank committed itself in August 2012 to make all the necessary efforts to defend the euro, and in fact, according to the Commission's latest autumn forecasts, the economic recovery in the euro area is expected to increase. Considering that in 2014 the ECB implemented a number of targeted longer-term refinancing operations and programmes for the purchase of selected private sector financial assets, in order to support loans to the real economy, I am confident that future progress will be made taking into account the objectives set.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The publication of the Annual Report complements ECB efforts towards greater transparency by describing the actions that the ECB undertook in 2014. From a monetary policy perspective, the environment we faced in 2014 was very complex and demanding, for the year as a whole, we saw GDP growing by 0.9% in the euro area. The policy measures introduced by the ECB have contributed to lower interest rates in capital markets. Even though Bulgaria is not yet part of the euro area, I believe a strong euro area is an essential element of a strong and competitive European Union. Therefore, I support the report and the measures taken by the ECB.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Central Bank's Annual Report is an important document because in addition to giving an overview of monetary policy implementation, it also provides forecasts that can act as guidance and incentives to reach higher economic growth, reduce unemployment and public debt and increase investment in the coming period. I agree with the view that low energy prices, if they remain at current levels for at least a few months, with inflation up to 2%, will be a significant factor in boosting competitiveness and creating new jobs in 2016. The ECB's 2014 Annual Report recognised the problems holding back economic progress. These are certainly differences between financing rates for SMEs, interest rates on small and large loans, and lending conditions for SMEs in different euro area countries, and we can say the same for the EU-wide area. We must all work together to reduce the existing discrepancy. I also support the Commission's efforts to facilitate access to finance for SMEs and increase cross-border investment. I, as well as the members of the committee responsible, are concerned about the high level of public and private debt in some Member States, including Croatia, and therefore we need to find mechanisms to bring it to acceptable borders.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report actually comments on current economic and European policies as well as the ECB's action. As last year, there are some concerns, for example about the difficulties of financing SMEs or the impact of securities purchases on the ECB's balance sheet. However, there is no critical view of the deterioration of the macroeconomic situation or the adverse effects of EQ. The destabilizing effects on asset prices associated with massive monetary creation, as well as the effects of low oil on inflation levels in relation to the ECB's objectives, are therefore insufficiently addressed. Of course, the main pillars of the Union's economic policies are not questioned, or even praised: Banking Union, Capital Markets Union, six-pack and two-pack budgetary governance, central bank independence, ban on direct monetisation of public debt, etc. Eager for a radical questioning of all these points, I am logically against this Eurobeat and unrealistic report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ According to the Commission's latest autumn forecast, the euro area expects the economic recovery to strengthen and is projected to grow real GDP by 1.4% in 2015, 1.7% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017. A resolute political commitment to implementing sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms is essential to boost economic growth.  I therefore support the work of the European Central Bank and emphasise its importance during crisis situations. The central bank plays a positive and crucial role and contributes to its unconventional monetary policy operations. Monetary policy, however, does not operate in a vacuum. I would like to stress that there are limits to what monetary policy can achieve. We therefore need more targeted investments and positive, socially balanced, structural reforms to ensure optimal results.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some criticism that it promotes elements of the ECB's monetary policy, or the rules of its functioning, the content and general meaning of the report are overall negative. It welcomes the Banking Union, the UMC and the EFSI. It reinforces the idea of so-called "fiscal consolidation". It values "structural reforms", seeking to paint them with "social balance". Forget the need for separation between investment banking and commercial banking. It objects to the renegotiation and consequent restructuring of debts. It states that the rules of Economic Governance must be respected and strengthened and calls for all the tools of the Stability Pact to be implemented. The report does not call into question the ecb's deeply undemocratic nature, nor does it far exceed the area of its statutory powers, and is inlerable in the economic policies of national states. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to the Commission's latest autumn forecast in the Euro area, the economic recovery is expected to strengthen and real GDP to grow by 1.4% in 2015, 1.7% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017. However, the foundations for growth are not the most stable. A resolute political commitment to implementing sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms is essential to boost economic growth. SMEs are known to be the backbone of the European economy and that the banking system is essential in enabling competitiveness and growth. Furthermore, it is important to mention the importance of facilitating credit flows to microenter enterprises and SMEs, as they represent 99% of all businesses and account for 80% of jobs in the EU. Therefore, SMEs play a key role in creating economic growth, creating jobs and reducing social inequalities, and bank lending volumes are slowly increasing. Private and public investment in the Euro area remains at a much lower level than before the current crisis, despite the ECB taking the necessary measures to maintain favourable financing conditions. Therefore, the establishment of the EFSI and the Commission's plan to establish a genuine Capital Markets Union are of significant importance. Such initiatives should lead to the diversification of sources of funding in the Union economy, increase cross-border investment and access to finance for businesses, in particular SMEs. Consequently, I support the report of my colleague Notis Marias.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Central Bank's annual report for 2014, as in that year it demonstrated that it was able to act actively when it was needed. However, I would like to point out that the European economy has shown itself and shows that the use of this policy only is insufficient to restore the performance of the European Union economy to the level it was at before the crisis. The measures taken by the European Central Bank need to be accompanied by an active policy involving positive, socially balanced structural reforms and sustainable investment. I voted in favour of the proposal for the European Central Bank to communicate more with MEMBERS of the European Parliament, as we are the only directly elected representatives of European citizens. It should therefore be self-evident to set up feedback on the annual reports that Parliament approves. I also supported the proposal to transform part of the institution's profits into the union budget's own resources. Indeed, the European Central Bank reports annual profits of up to EUR 1 billion, which are returning to central banks, even if the EU budget is in long-term tension. I did so because of my conviction that it is wrong to prevent deeper integration of euro area countries if they wish to do so, but also because of the hope that the Czech Republic will soon belong to this grouping.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. – I would like to commend the European Central Bank in its efforts to help European countries recover after a very serious economic crisis. It pleases me to hear that the ECB has made some important strides to help us progress to full economic recovery. According to the Commission’s latest economic forecast, recovery in the euro area is expected to expand, with real GDP predicted to rise, and unemployment will slowly but surely decrease. However, I do agree that Europe still has a long road of recovery ahead of us. We cannot only rely on the monetary policy conducted by the European Central Bank. The position of European social democrats is clear: we need to be more future-oriented and create more investments and greater domestic demand. With these aims, we can hope to not only recover from this crisis but come out stronger than before.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The efforts undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) in 2014 were important. I welcome the work done by the ECB, its Executive Board, its staff and the Eurosystem Committees, which have responded to the challenges and enabled the Governing Council to fulfil its mandate and responsibilities. In 2014, several strands of work, started in previous years, merged into a coherent policy response. Inflation seems to be returning to levels below but close to 2% over the medium term, in line with the ECB's target. From a monetary policy perspective, the ECB faced a complex picture in 2014. The weak recovery in 2013 did not accelerate as initially expected. Monetary growth remained subdued and credit continued to contract, albeit at a gradually slower pace. By voting in favour of this report, I hope that the ECB will continue its tough task of improving the conditions for investment, both public and private, aimed at reviving growth and job creation.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – This report outlines the work of the European Central Bank for 2014. The report's complete lack of criticism of the ECB's monetary policy, which has repeatedly exceeded the competences of its mandate and thus called into question the budgetary sovereignty of the national parliaments in the long term, is incomprehensible. This blatant maladministration is not sufficiently addressed in the report and therefore makes it compulsory for me to vote against this report.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. In addition to optimistic forecasts of the economic recovery, unemployment and fiscal outlooks of euro area member countries, the report highlights three recommendations. Firstly, on the need to improve the environment for the creation of SMEs and therefore of jobs, it calls for increased public and private investment. The establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and efforts to establish a Capital Markets Union (CMU) are welcomed. With regard to financial stability in the euro area, the text supports differences, if not contradictions, in national fiscal policies that hinder joint monetary stimulus (quantitative easing) - with MEPs in the European Parliament urging Member States to carry out a full audit of their public finances. Finally, efforts to make the ECB more transparent, although some progress remains to be made, as is the case with the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM).  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This report notes that the expected recovery in the euro area, which is geographically uneven and modest, is expected to be stronger and that potential economic growth should increase in order to reduce the high unemployment rates recorded in many euro area Member States and lower the debt burden. It also stresses the need to improve the conditions for both public and private investment to boost growth and job creation, and calls for a redouble of efforts to ensure the financing of the real economy. Structural reforms must be sustainable and socially balanced. I am just sorry that no amendment has been adopted which provided that part of the European Central Bank's profits (an average of EUR 1 trillion annually) could be transformed into the Union's own resource for investment and progress of the European project, rather than going back to the national central banks.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this annual report on the activity of the European Central Bank (ECB) because it supports the expansion monetary policy it has been developing, including the Member States' public debt purchase programme, as well as the priority set in August 2012 to do everything necessary to ensure the financial stability of the euro area and the irreversibility of the single currency.  I regret, however, that a negative coalition, made up of the far-right, Eurosceptics, the radical left and most of the European People's Party and the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, has blocked Amendment No 12, promoted by a pro-European coalition made up of Members from four political groups, including the writer, and who asked the ECB to consider turning its profits (of the order of one billion euros a year) into a new resource of its own.  It is to be appreciated in any case that the amendment was supported by my group (Socialists and Democrats), so I will continue to work on the objective of increasing the European Union's own resources and, in particular, for constituting a fiscal capacity in the euro area.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report and in particular supported an amendment which calls on the ECB to consider using its power of legislative initiative in accordance with Article 129, paragraph 3 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union in order to reform, by ordinary legislative procedure, Article 33, paragraph 1, point a), of the ECB's statutes, with a view to converting a share of the net profit of that institution into a new own resource of the Union. According to this amendment, this should be done in such a way as to ensure that the ECB's net profit benefits only the Member States that have adopted the single currency.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Central Bank has developed an action to ensure financing conditions favourable to companies, especially SMEs. However, private and public investment in the euro area remains considerably below pre-global crisis levels. In this follow-up, the ECB found itself in the need to adopt unconventional monetary policy instruments in order to mitigate the effects of the sovereign debt crisis, inflation with decreasing signs, credit contraction or stagnant economic growth. This report not only takes account of the positive effect of some measures, such as the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, but also supports the European Commission's plan to establish a genuine Capital Market Union, which will focus on diversifying sources of funding in the EU economy, stimulating cross-border investment and increasing access to finance for businesses , and in particular SMEs. Because I consider it essential that the ECB continues to play the role assigned to it by the Treaties, and because it considers it essential to be subject to democratic scrutiny of its work in view of its new responsibilities, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the activities of the European Central Bank for 2014 but also makes recommendations from Parliament. First of all, it is important to stress that, according to the Commission's latest forecasts, the economic recovery in the euro area is expected to intensify, while remaining fragile. That is why the ECB needs to improve, in monetary terms, the conditions for this recovery; guaranteeing, in particular, a low inflation rate of around 1%, as is forecast for 2016. As this resolution calls for, there is a need to improve the conditions for public and private investment to stimulate growth and create jobs. As such, I supported this report, which reminds us that monetary policy must enable a higher rate of financing for European companies, particularly SMEs, one of the engines of the European economy. Monetary policy must accompany the recovery of economic growth by promoting investment.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report not only ratifies or comments on the work of the European Central Bank in 2014, but also serves to make proposals to relaunch and improve the ECB's activities for the future. In particular, the report talks about eurozone financial indicators and the ECB's quantitative easing initiative to revive the economy. In today's vote, the European Parliament approved and supported the monetary policy pursued by the ECB to ensure price stability, but at the same time wishes to point out that these measures will not be effective unless accompanied by the necessary structural reforms, budgetary discipline and productive investment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by the European Parliament on the ECB's activity in 2014. The report contains some progressive elements, pointing out the negative role the ECB has played in Greece and the ECB's democratic deficit, and emphasizing the austerity policies that the ECB has pushed. However, I voted against the report as a whole because it contains implicit validation of the ECB's current structure.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I finally voted in favour of this initially controversial report on the activities of the European Central Bank in 2014. The rapporteur was not prepared to make concessions to assess the work of the ECB and its chairman differently, which is why the PPE, s&D and ALDE have negotiated what I believe is a viable and acceptable compromise.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the final result has diluted the important criticisms that the rapporteur made in the first version under discussion. The initial version of this report contained an express condemnation of the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, for the role played in the financial extortion to which this institution is subjecting the Member States to the periphery of the European Union. However, this initial text has been amended by most groups in this Parliament, leaving an idyllic, acrytic and decaffeinated vision of the activity carried out by this institution during the 2014 financial year. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the UK not being a member of the Eurozone (and it does not look like it is going to join the currency union in the near future), the ECB plays an important role in the EU and for the prosperity for those inside and outside the Eurozone. Britain has a vested interest in the success of the Eurozone and the efficiency of the ECB, the European Central Bank. The role that the ECB plays in regards to its non-conventional monetary policy operations is positive and vital. But, in my view, there are limits to what monetary policy can achieve, and structural reforms are needed and investments need to be more targeted if we are going to be able to see a real difference to people’s lives and lift people’s standards of living across this continent.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report, which states, among other things, that unemployment is expected to fall slowly in the euro area from 11.6% at the end of 2014 to 10.5% at the end of 2016. According to the same forecast, the fiscal outlook in the euro area should improve, with the expected general government deficit expected to decline from 2.4% in 2014 to 1.7% in 2016 and public debt from 94% at the end of 2014 to 92.5% at the end of 2016. The report concludes that even low energy prices could help to revive the economy. The report recalls that monetary dialogue once every quarter of a year is important to ensure the transparency of monetary policy vis-à-vis the European Parliament and the general public. ECB representatives shall also provide precise and detailed answers to MEPs' questions in writing if the answers provided during the negotiations are insufficient or exhaustive.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 According to the Commission's latest autumn forecast, the economic recovery in the euro area is expected to strengthen and real GDP is expected to increase by 1.4% in 2015, 1.7% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017.  The report concludes that in response to the complex environment characterised by the country's debt crisis, falling inflation, credit crunch and sluggish economic growth, the ECB has resorted to unconventional monetary policy instruments.  The report also reflects concerns about the possible adverse consequences and long-term effects of these instruments. Abandoning these measures will be complex and their careful planning will be required. This will prevent unwanted market disturbances, in particular as regards the proper, careful and timely organisation of the suspension and the choice of the right time. High and different levels of public and private indebtedness in some Member States, in addition to the structural weaknesses in the banking sector, constitute an obstacle to the correct transposition of monetary policy.  I believe that the ecb's unconventional monetary policy cannot in itself change this situation. A strong political commitment to implementing sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms is essential to boost economic growth.  As a result of this, I voted against the adoption of the 2014 Annual Report on the ECB in plenary.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the ECB's 2014 Annual Report. The report addresses, among other things, the ECB's non-conventional monetary policies. The report calls for a review of the ECB's actions and its role in the troika and calls for political independence of the ECB, which also supports ALFA.  However, the report lacks a thorough and critical analysis of the possible far-reaching negative consequences of the ECB's countervalued programme of ultra-loose monetary policy (quantitative easing). In the light of several actions pending before the Federal Constitutional Court, in particular against the ECB's OMT programme and its ultra-loose monetary policy, it is an absolute must to raise the ECB's potential mandate overruns. Parliament's report does not fulfil this obligation and subsequently failed to obtain my vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The European Central Bank remains an important part of the stability of the financial system within the euro area. Conditions for both public and private investment still need to be improved in order to support the economic recovery within the EU, which still cannot be considered across the board. In this context, particular attention should be paid to access by enterprises to sources of funding, with particular regard to small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to the Commission's latest autumn forecast, the euro area is expected to strengthen the economic recovery and is projected to grow real GDP by 1.4% in 2015, 1.7% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017. The foundations for growth are fragile, and a determined political commitment to implementing sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms is essential to boost economic growth. I therefore expect the ECB to contribute to general economic policies in the Union and to achieve their objectives in accordance with Article 282 of the TFEU, provided that their main objective of maintaining price stability is not called into question. I emphasise that the ECB's contribution entails efforts to increase the granting of low-cost loans to the real economy and to stimulate economic recovery, namely job creation, growth and stability. I welcome the Capital Markets Union project and the possibility to restore balance in funding channels through it, not by reducing or maintaining funding opportunities at existing levels, but by increasing them and diversifying them, which would help reduce the excessive dependence of euro area economies on the banking system and allow for the necessary absorbing of shocks in the monetary union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is an annual report on the work and activities of the European Central Bank, which are submitted at the initiative of Parliament itself. This report deals with a period in which the ECB has used unconventional measures to counter very low inflation rates. The report highlights that many Member States face high unemployment and that economic growth needs to be increased. Private and public investment in the euro area remains at a lower level than before the current crisis. Conditions for public and private investment need to be improved to stimulate growth and job creation.  The rapporteur believes that the bank has transcended its mandate in its relationship with Troy. 283 amendments to the report have been proposed. Informal negotiations were held between the EPP, S&D and ALDE, which resulted in numerous compromises. I support this annual report from the European Central Bank, as I think the recommendations made in it are useful and necessary for further economic progress by member states.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report.  Following the financial and economic crisis, weak growth and economic recovery and a slow fall in unemployment are perceived in the euro area. Forecasts for the coming years are also forecast in the same way. In order to further strengthen growth and contribute more effectively to reducing unemployment, we need a strong political commitment to implement sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms.  I support the warning that the geographically uneven and modest recovery expected in the euro area in the coming years will need to be strengthened, and that potential economic growth will need to be strengthened so that the high unemployment rate in many euro area Member States can be reduced and the debt burden reduced.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our position that the neoliberal austerity policies implemented in the euro area are inextricably linked to the democratic deficits of the construction of the euro. The ECB participates in the Troika, and the banking union is getting more and more supervisory rights from national central banks, thus promoting the interests of huge banks rather than co-operation and small banks that finance small and medium-sized enterprises.  The report also prevents state debt restructuring processes and supports macroeconomic adjustment programmes.  We voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 A single sentence of the report illustrates the essence of the existence of the European Central Bank, but also the economic policy of Germany and, by extension, of the European Union. Paragraph 11: 'welcomes the unequivocal commitment of the European Central Bank to make every effort to protect the euro which it undertook in August 2012'. Everything about money, not about citizens, not about nations, not even about countries. It is clear that the so-called stability of the euro is simply a means of enforcing Germany's financial interests, so part of the problem. To become part of the solution, the European Union must change direction. And this can only be done with nationalist governments that energize the citizen, the family and the nation against money.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Central Bank's report on the 2014 Annual Report, which acknowledges the achievements of the European Central Bank (ECB) but also highlights the additional challenges ahead. It is to be welcomed that the Bank has made significant progress in ensuring transparency. As highlighted in the report, the publication of summaries of the minutes of meetings is an important step, but there is still room for improvement in the transparency of its communication channel. It is also to be welcomed that the President of the ECB is committed to a more effective dialogue with the European Parliament and that, following the ECB's example, other central banks will publicly justify their decisions. I also agree with the need to improve the conditions for public and private investment in growth and jobs and that the ECB should pay particular attention to the possible unintended consequences and long-term effects of its unconventional monetary policy instruments.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament, in its document, supported the monetary policy pursued by the European Central Bank to not only guarantee price stability, but also to support the economic recovery towards job creation, growth and stability, m.in. by increasing the scale of low-interest loans to the real economy.  Nevertheless, in my opinion, the european central bank's use of unconventional monetary policy instruments – even if to some extent justified by the situation of the debt crisis, falling inflation, negative credit trends and sluggd economic growth – cannot continue indefinitely. It is up to the individual Member States to take decisive action to fully implement structural reforms and to comply with the rules in force, particularly as regards budgetary discipline. I am pleased that such a conclusion is also included in the European Parliament document.  Furthermore, in its report, the European Parliament appreciated the efforts made by the European Central Bank to increase its transparency, m.in. by publicly clarifying monetary policy decisions as soon as they are taken, or by publishing summary minutes of its meetings.  For these reasons, I have decided to support the European Parliament's report on the activities of the European Central Bank in 2014.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I would like to clarify why I voted against Amendment No 12. The profit share of the ECB's budget should not be allocated to the European Union budget, but to the Member States, which are the original contributors to the budget profit share. The EU must not receive extra funds from member states via detours.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have validated the annual report. I can only regret that, even if they are gradually reduced, there are differences between the financing rates granted to SMEs and those granted to large enterprises, between the interest rates applied to small and high-value loans, as well as between the credit conditions offered to SMEs located in different euro area countries. , but I can recognize the limitations of monetary policy in this regard. In this regard, we welcome the role played by savings banks, credit unions and mutual banks, while stressing that the regulatory framework should adapt to their particular operating principles and respect their specific mission, and that supervisors should be sensitive to these characteristics and taken into account in their practices and strategies.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2014. I welcome the setting-up of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) to maintain favourable financing conditions for private and public investment in the euro area. This is necessary to strengthen the expected uneven and modest recovery, to reduce the high unemployment rates, and to decrease the debt burden. I particularly hope that this will allow SMEs to get better financial support. I share my colleagues’ concern about the possible unintended consequences and long-term effects of the ECB’s current use of non-conventional monetary policy instruments. Furthermore, I agree that the ECB rules should be properly respected and enforced, without differentiations made between large and small Member States. Finally, I welcome the habit adopted by major central banks initiated by the ECB, to publicly explain monetary decisions, in the name of transparency.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒In this report, which is the European Parliament's response to the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report, the rapporteur referred critically to the ECB's unconventional monetary policy instruments. Also, particular emphasis is placed on the importance of the ECB's independence in managed monetary policy and on the necessity of thorough assessments of the way the Tripartite Commission, led by the European Commission, together with the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which I fully agree with. However, most of the MPs on the committee would not accept the very carefully worded criticism that the ECB had oversteps its powers in some elements, which I consider very dangerous. Although exposed with a touch of caution, the European Central Bank's annual report in some paragraphs is quite unrealistic. Yes, there are small developments for the better, in some Member States this recovery is greater, in others smaller, but ultimately we all know that the economic situation in Europe is still nowhere near recovery. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the European Central Bank's 2014 annual report. This is an annual report that the European Parliament is doing on its own initiative.  The 2014 report covers an interesting period of unconventional ECB measures aimed at combating the very low inflation rate. This is at a time when most Member States have been abandoning their programmes following the debt crisis, while the economic recovery in the euro area is still in the making.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report by the European Parliament on the ECB's activity in 2014. The report contains some progressive elements, pointing out the negative role the ECB has played in Greece and the ECB's democratic deficit, and emphasizing the austerity policies that the ECB has pushed. However, I voted against the report as a whole because it contains implicit validation of the ECB's current structure.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The Parliamentary report is the answer to the ECB's 2014 Annual Report. The report addresses, among other things, the ECB's non-conventional monetary policies. The report calls for a review of the ECB's actions and its role in the troika and calls for political independence of the ECB, which also supports ALFA.  However, the report lacks a thorough and critical analysis of the possible far-reaching negative consequences of the ECB's countervalued programme of ultra-loose monetary policy (quantitative easing). In the light of several actions pending before the Federal Constitutional Court, in particular against the ECB's OMT programme and its ultra-loose monetary policy, it is an absolute must to raise the ECB's potential mandate overruns. Parliament's report does not fulfil this obligation, which is why I had to refuse to give my assent.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report. At times of great distress for the EU it is fundamental that the ECB can count with support for its actions from the European Parliament.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. It is a delicate exercise to comment on the ECB's policy two years ago, when the news of 2015 and early 2016 is very rich: resumption of banking supervision of systemic banks, launch and gradual extension of QE. We get a report that actually comments more on current economic events and European policies, as much as the ECB's action.  As last year, there are some criticisms and concerns, for example about the difficulties of financing SMEs or the impact of securities purchases on the ECB's balance sheet. However, it can be blamed for its lack of a critical view of the deterioration of the macroeconomic situation and, even if mentioned, of the adverse effects of EQs and exit scenarios. Moreover, the main pillars of the Union's economic policies are not questioned at all, but are instead praised: Banking Union, Union of Capital Markets, budgetary governance of the "six-pack" and the "two-pack", independence of the central bank, prohibition of the direct monetisation of public debts, etc. So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the Commission's latest autumn forecast, economic recovery in the euro area is expected to expand, with real GDP projected to grow by 1.4 percent in 2015, 1.7 percent in 2016 and 1.8 percent in 2017. Growth is on an unstable footing; a strong political commitment to implementing sustainable and socially balanced structural reforms is key to economic growth. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report of which I have been shadow rapporteur, as it removes any elements of criticism of the ECB's actions, both as monetary authority, as a regulator and bank supervisor.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the general trend of the main central banks launched by the ECB, which publicly explains monetary policy decisions as soon as they are taken; I also welcome the publication of clearer and more transparent procedures for elablishing sourcing for solvent financial institutions (mainly national banks) facing temporary liquidity problems.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2014. The ECB’s report is composed of two chapters together with the annual accounts, a consolidated balance sheet of the Eurosystem as at 31 December 2014, and a series of annexes detailing the institutional framework and human resource developments in 2014. The report, among other things, describes the economic situation in the euro area in 2014. According to the report, three important global developments have had a significant influence: 1) uneven growth developments; 2) falling prices of oil and other commodities; and 3) a weaker euro exchange rate. As the report highlights that fiscal consolidation slowed down and progress in structural reforms lost momentum, the ECB stresses that credible and decisive growth-enhancing reforms are more important than ever. The report also describes a series of actions that the ECB undertook to strengthen the stability of and confidence in the European financial sector, such as assessments of the financial system’s resilience and shock-absorbing capacity, and its links to the real economy. Furthermore, the ECB’s analysis of financial stability risks in the euro area during 2014 shows there are both legacy issues from the global financial crisis and a broad set of emerging risks, linked primarily to low interest rates.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about the ECB's own-initiative report covering the period in which the Bank has taken relevant measures to combat low inflation at a time marked by the economic crisis in Europe. After hard work in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, a balanced text has been reached and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The European Parliament presented a report to assess the ECB's work in 2014. The report comes to the vote late because of the difficulty of finding a compromise with the People's Party and the Socialists, who defend the euro and the ECB religiously by not accepting the right considerations expressed by the rapporteur and some shadow rapporteurs. The initial draft contained a harsh criticism of the ECB's unconventional policies as ineffective in supporting the real economy. There was strong disapproval of austerity policies and some hints were directed at the inefficiency of the euro. Finally, the rapporteur attacked the ECB for its role in the Troika. We welcomed this initial position, which was very much in line with our amendments. In addition to criticising the single currency and unconventional policies, we have, in fact, denounced the management of the UNION supervisory mechanism within the ECB, to which we have also called for greater transparency and the role of lender of last resort. However, in order to find a compromise, all the critical and politically most important parts have been deleted from the text. The result has been a much more watered-down and untenable report. That is why we voted against it both in committee and in plenary.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the resolution on the annual report because, in times of great economic uncertainty, it is essential that the ECB can count on the support of the European Parliament.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report on the European Central Bank's Annual Report 2014 contained a number of points that I could not accept. Among other things, the report mentions that the ECB's 2012 opinion 'we will do everything possible to defend the euro' and that greater influence on the part of the ECB are desirable, and these constituted a whole that I cannot support. That is why I abstained in the final vote on the report on the annual report because I am opposed to greater power for the ECB.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This parliamentary report makes an annual assessment of the functioning of the ECB. Focusing on 2014, it has been the subject of more controversy than previous reports in the European Parliament. Initially, the report criticised the negative role played by the ECB in Greece and other countries subject to austerity policies. Unfortunately, in the final version of the report, these points have been removed and the criticism is limited to asking for a thorough assessment of how the "troika" operates and the ECB's participation in this "troika". For the rest, the report overall supports the ECB's monetary policy. As I have said in previous years, it is essential to put the ECB under political control. The ECB's activities must focus primarily on public investment, employment and social cohesion.  It is essential to put an end to austerity policies. The ECB must no longer intervene independently in European policies and it must act more transparently. We need an ECB that serves the people, the public interest and not finance.  Unsurprisingly, I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the report criticises some aspects of the ECB's monetary policy and the rules of its functioning, it does not call into question its existence and its deeply undemocratic nature, as well as the fact that it has far exceeded the area of its statutory powers, and is deeply involved in the economic policies of national states. The report goes so far as to express satisfaction with the progress of the Banking Union, which we firmly oppose. We voted against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The ECB wants a monetary union with this report; a transfer union from north to south is to be created. The ENF Group has already voted against it in the ECON Committee. I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the European Central Bank's 2014 Annual Report. Despite all the respect for the work of my esteemed colleague Marias, the report still contains pills that I do not want to swallow. We are certainly dealing with the most critical report on the ECB at all.  My main criticisms: the asset purchase programme (APP) has no positive effect and must not be extended, secondary market purchases are unfortunately welcomed and deemed admissible, the EFSI is inadmissibly praised, "whatever it takes" is welcomed and the ECB is also credited with a role as an emergency liquidity provider.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to emphasise that the European Central Bank must always include a social perspective in its decision-making on monetary policy. All of its innovative non-conventional policy instruments must aim to have a direct impact on the real-economy, and improve the lives of those who are most excluded, vulnerable, and marginalised in our society. The ECB must also take into account a gender perspective in all of its decision-making. As the ECB works to create favourable financing conditions for businesses, especially SMEs, it must take into account and give high priority to the needs of those facing obstacles in accessing finance, particularly those experiencing multiple discrimination, social marginalisation and exclusion. This includes specifically the access of women entrepreneurs to finance, particularly in vulnerable communities. The ECB and financial institutions across Member States must work with stakeholders to formulate policy instruments which will allow equitable access to finance and give attention to the key role played by cooperatives and mutuals in this respect.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the own-initiative report on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2014. The report talks about the need for further efforts to ensure that the real economy is financed in the context of a differentiated return of euro area economies. The rapporteur's attention to the SME sector is to be appreciated. He notes that there are still discrepancies between financing rates for SMEs and those for larger companies, between interest rates on small loans and those applied to large loans, and between the credit conditions proposed to SMEs in different euro area countries.  The report also shows that, despite the ECB continuing its actions to maintain favourable financing conditions, private and public investment in the euro area is still well below pre-crisis levels. The rapporteur also stresses that the ECB's supervisory role and its function in the development and implementation of monetary policy must be clearly differentiated and the combination of these functions should not create any conflict of interest for the ECB.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As every year, the European Parliament presented an own-initiative report to assess the ECB's actions in the previous year.  The initial draft of this report contained a harsh criticism of the unconventional monetary policies initiated by the ECB as ineffective in supporting the real economy and fostering growth. There was also strong disapproval of the austerity policies initiated after the crisis, and some hints were also made about the inefficiency of the single currency. Nevertheless, the rapporteur had launched a severe attack on the ECB for its role in the troika.
