Subsequently, in order to find a compromise position, all the politically stronger parties were deleted from the text and the result was a much more watered-down and no longer sustainable report.  In the ECON Committee, we expressed our criticism not only of the single currency and unconventional monetary policy, but also of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) managed within the ECB. We called for greater transparency and alternative methods of unconventional monetary policy in order to promote economic growth; these amendments have been rejected in the spirit of compromises. That is why I voted against it both in the ECON Committee and in plenary.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Central Bank (ECB) Annual Report 2014, which deals in particular with the ECB's actions on the government debt crisis, falling inflation, credit crunch and sluggish economic growth.  The ECB is a key eu body in defining monetary policy and addressing macroeconomic challenges. I support the European Central Bank's firm commitment of August 2012 to do whatever it takes to protect the euro.  I believe that measures should be introduced to strengthen the geographically uneven and modest recovery of the financial market and to increase economic growth.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Of course, I did not vote for this free trade agreement either, because every free trade agreement is an element of a certain set of values and worldviews. It is this particular set of values and worldviews that I would call a money- and profit-driven worldview that always asks what is good for money and profit. This should be replaced by a human-centred, community-centred and created nature-centred worldview that asks not what is good for profit, but what is good for people, for community and for created nature.  Those who watch us often desiter, well, there are about six of us in this room right now. Does it often say in comments that these members speak to the wall? I think of my fellow Member Kelly with infinite gratitude, do not take it as harassment on my part that he has given us positive feedback about thinking a little about what my fellow Member Moravian is saying, because free trade, for example, is something that has been entrenched in us since school age as something very positive. We look out for each other sometimes, we implant a little core of thought in each other, and we change each other's minds, so I see things a little more positively today than I did 24 hours ago, and I want us to move away from a money-driven and profit-driven worldview to a human and community-centric worldview.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Although geographically Australia and New Zealand are very far away from the European Union, from the beginning of the 20th century, the contacts between the two sides were rather intense, and both Australia and New Zealand were added to western civilisation, to western countries.  It must be said that both Australia and New Zealand are now trying to diversify their trade links as much as possible, in this respect they have much in common with us, with the European Union. Given the production structure of both countries, the diversity of goods and the principles of economic policy management, it is perfectly possible to bring them closer to the European Union. This is nothing fantastic and unrealistic, especially when it comes to regulation of laws. The opening of free trade agreements with these countries is therefore absolutely welcome, and I voted in favour.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would always be in favour of EU free trade agreements with democracies, but as my country, the UK, approaches its referendum on EU membership, agreements with the Commonwealth countries such as Australia and New Zealand are particularly welcome. For many of my Eurosceptic colleagues supporting the push to leave, one of the attractions is their belief that it will bring increased trade with the Commonwealth and the so-called Anglosphere. Negotiations on the EU-Canada FTA have been concluded and we are now moving towards the ratification process; TTIP negotiations are ongoing; and here we find ourselves now speaking of deals with Australia and New Zealand, not to mention the continued enthusiasm for a similar deal with India. Far from the EU preventing the UK from trading with the Commonwealth and the wider world, the push for FTAs within the EU will soon make membership more advantageous than any independent agreements that we in the United Kingdom could conclude on our own. In the CETA agreement we have seen the Canadians make concessions that did not even exist within the NAFTA agreement with the United States, and I am confident that agreements with Australia and New Zealand will be equally as ambitious and beneficial to the United Kingdom.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report, which UKIP chose to abstain on. In principle UKIP agrees with free trade agreements especially with our Commonwealth allies, New Zealand and Australia. However, we are totally opposed to the EU negotiating trade agreements with other countries on the UK’s behalf, therefore we abstained.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade relations between the EU, Australia and New Zealand play an important role in economic growth in Europe. With this own-initiative resolution, we have committed the negotiators to dealing significantly with a number of very important issues. These include investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, competition, the fight against corruption, international law and agriculture. Because of the importance of the EU-Australia-New Zealand relationship in the future of the Union, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because it seeks to deepen trade relations between Australia and New Zealand on the one hand and the European Union on the other without warning of the harmful effects they will have on their economies. This agreement seeks to strengthen trade relations to alleviate the diversionary effect that the recent trans-Pacific partnership may have. However, we believe that this agreement can have a deadly impact on our economy, especially on the European dairy sector, a sector which is already suffering from the demise of quotas and which, due to the contraction in Chinese consumption, will be flooded with the New Zealand surplus. This liberalizing agenda of international trade that takes place for the benefit of multinationals without taking into account the real effect it will have on the real economy is at the origin of many of our economic problems. That is why I have decided to vote against this motion for a resolution.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report to open negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. Indeed, many fields are affected in the text: investment, goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, state-owned enterprises, energy and plant protection barriers, but also agriculture. In this regard, the report recognises the need for safeguard measures such as quotas and transitional periods. However, Australian and New Zealand agriculture is highly competitive, especially in livestock, milk and cereals. Opening free trade negotiations would therefore be dramatic for french livestock and the dairy sector. Moreover, the stated preventive measures will certainly only be in place for a time to make way for full free trade. Deeply opposed to the "governance of the world economy" referred to in the text, I cannot support it.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This oral question to the European Commission concerns its intention to open negotiations on free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. In the context of this opening of negotiations we have managed to include provisions establishing strong labour security as well as minimum transparency required, while also ensuring that the present negotiations will not in any way impede other agreements already in force or the bilateral relations agenda and the corresponding open negotiations currently under way with these countries.  The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament voted in favour of this decision as it is our wish to include negotiating chapters in terms of the creation of strong trade links and sustainable development in all trade negotiations that begin with Australia and New Zealand. Finally, the aim of the group is to put back to the vote its rejected amendment on the creation of a common civil society forum aimed at monitoring the implementation of the agreement and respecting the commitments and obligations of each Contracting Party.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this resolution, Parliament is in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. Even though I am not against free trade per se, it is difficult for me to form an informed opinion on the opening of negotiations without having seen a mandate from the Council of the European Union in this regard. While the European Parliament is not involved in the drafting of such a mandate – which, incidentally, I regret just as much, as the negotiating mandates have so far only been made freely available under public pressure – I believe that it is only possible to express its views on the appropriateness of free trade agreements if these negotiating guidelines have been considered. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Because of the highly competitive nature of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, particularly in livestock, milk and cereals, it is very dangerous to open free trade negotiations with these two countries. This would complete the French dairy sector and livestock. We cannot trust the Commission and Parliament when they claim to "preserve" these sensitive sectors. Their vision here is to put in place transitional periods, quotas at the beginning, and then introduce aggressive free trade. I therefore objected to this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I wish to confirm I abstained in this vote. The demands made by the EU to monitor Australia and New Zealand’s agriculture in return for free trade is unreasonable. I want to have a free trade agreement with Commonwealth countries, outside the interference of the EU.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to open negotiations on free trade agreements (FTA) with Australia and New Zealand. On 30 July 2014, the EU concluded negotiations on a Partnership Agreement in the area of EU-New Zealand relations and cooperation and on 22 April 2015 on an EU-Australia Framework Agreement. The negotiations on a two-single and ambitious FTA with Australia and New Zealand are a practical way of developing a bilateral partnership and further strengthening existing bilateral trade and investment relations that have already been established. I support the calls to the Commission in its study to define the scope, to examine in detail all the additional market access opportunities offered by European economic operators, in particular SMEs, from possible FTAs with Australia and New Zealand. I agree that agreements must include investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, public undertakings, competition, the fight against corruption, technological research and, in particular, the needs of SMEs. The Commission should carry out a comprehensive assessment of the sustainability impact of possible agreements as soon as possible in order to provide a comprehensive assessment of the potential pros and cons of strengthening trade and investment links between the EU and Australia and the EU and New Zealand.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. While Australia and New Zealand recently signed the Trans-Pacific Treaty, the EU now wants its free trade agreement, still behind the United States. Australia produces a wide range of cereals and livestock, with 80% of its production exported: highly competitive, Australia is a strong advocate of the liberalisation of global agricultural markets. An equivalent situation in New Zealand, which is also the world's largest net exporter of dairy products... So do we want to finish off our farmers??!

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution aimed at deepening trade relations between the Union, Australia and New Zealand, but we must remain very attentive to the progress of the negotiations so that the original aim does not undermine the social, environmental or health protection of European citizens.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Australia and New Zealand are examples of established democracies in the Asia-Pacific region, countries where the rule of law is fully respectable and which currently guarantee a high level of environmental protection and the protection of human, social and employment rights. The European Union is the third largest trading partner of these states and has long-standing relations with them. The deepening of trade relations, with the opening of negotiations to establish free trade agreements, can be a great opportunity to strengthen political ties and economic growth. I supported this resolution because I firmly believe that agreements of this kind can have significant positive effects. However, the Eu ropean Union's commitment to this must always aim to strengthen standards in the fields of human rights, labour and environmental protection. Only with a strong focus on the social aspects and also on the most sensitive sectors, such as agriculture, will it be possible to make full use of the potential of these agreements.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. The same report recognises the possible adverse effects that the agreement may have on social and workers' rights, but we do not think it is convincing as to the clause that would nullify it if these negative effects were indeed given.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the opening of negotiations on the Free Trade Agreements with Australia and New Zealand. I think it is very important to deepen relations with the Asia-Pacific region for economic growth in Europe. I have deferred my vote with my group in Amendment No 11 of the GUE/NGL Group calling for a particular account of human rights and labour, social and environmental standards. I wanted to vote for it and I made a mistake. I have already made the relevant correction to support this amendment which differed from my group's line.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I rejected this resolution as a whole, the thinly veiled objective of which is the establishment of global governance based solely on the laws of the globalized market. The resolution calls for the inclusion of all sectors of the economy in this free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand: public procurement, state-owned enterprises, energy, etc. So many strategic sectors for France! But the real danger is the extreme competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, real dangers for our farmers already in a situation of extreme precariousness: remember that New Zealand is the world's largest net exporter of dairy products! As for Australia, it is a large producer of grain and livestock. Our farmers are already providing us with everything we need, despite an increasingly precarious situation for them. Should we, under the pretext of participating in the great mass of the world market, sacrifice them at the cost of becoming dependent on imports? Finally, what about the hypocrisy of the Commission and also of Parliament, which, in this resolution, merely says that we will have to be 'cautious' with our sensitive sectors? A perfect example of what the true defenders of the Europe of nations and freedoms we are fighting against every day.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I regard Australia and New Zealand as reliable trading partners with high quality standards, I am concerned about the legal system in force in these countries which sees geographical indications as non-tariff barriers to free trade and which would have the direct consequence of the failure to protect our typical products and our producers. That is why I did not intend to support this resolution with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations on future free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand which will serve to deepen trade and investment relations and contribute to economic development. While it is premature to assess the level of ambition of the agreements, the Socialists require rigorous previous impact studies, in particular in the agricultural chapter, appropriate public consultations, transparency in the negotiations, strong provisions on the protection of labour rights, the defence of the power of the EU and the Member States to legislate in the public interest and the inclusion of a chapter on sustainability and strong human rights , binding and enforceable. In addition, we defend multilateralism as a priority of EU trade policy. The Commission's efforts to move forward with new bilateral negotiations should not be detrimental to the resources it devotes to the multilateral agenda.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution, which stresses the importance of strengthening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for economic growth in Europe and stressing that this should be reflected in the European Union's trade policy. The European Parliament recognises that relations with Australia and New Zealand are a key part of this strategy and that developing and strengthening trade with these partners can help achieve this objective. Parliament calls on the Commission, in its study to define the scope, to examine in detail all the additional market access opportunities available to European economic operators, in particular SMEs, from possible FTAs with Australia and New Zealand, and to assess them in the light of any potential interests in defending the market, bearing in mind that Australia and New Zealand already have relatively open markets and very low tariffs internationally.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. There was no sign of major reservations within Parliament regarding the opening of australia-New Zealand free trade agreements within Parliament.  These are two comparable developed countries with which the EU can only gain from a good agreement. In fact, it's surprising that this hasn't happened before.  Of course, this is not only about trade, but also about facilitating the internationalisation of companies from all countries to foreign markets. Although these are areas that, from an EU perspective, are practically on the other side of the earth's face, modern technology today reduces the obstacles posed by distance. There are certainly opportunities for European companies in Oceania, but we can also learn a lot from their experiences.  I was happy to support the opening of the negotiations and I do not expect any major problems with them.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report, which UKIP chose to abstain on. In principle UKIP agrees with free trade agreements especially with our Commonwealth allies, New Zealand and Australia. However, we are totally opposed to the EU negotiating trade agreements with other countries on the UK’s behalf, therefore we abstained.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the opening of free trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand, in particular in view of the high competitiveness of their agricultural sectors (livestock, milk, cereals). This free trade agreement could end up killing French livestock and the dairy sector. I voted against it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The opening of negotiations for the establishment of a free trade area with the friends of Australia and New Zealand is to be welcomed, with a view to achieving a realisation functional to the global inclusion of democracies with stable market economies in the economic region of the European system. Only a fully global and stable market can develop economically and strengthen itself culturally, strengthening its democratic institutions and deeper the exchange of global goods and services.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution calls for the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, which must include a wide range of topics, such as trade in goods and services, liberalisation of agricultural trade and e-commerce. At a time when our farmers are suffering a significant drop in the price of raw materials and the disastrous consequences of the common agricultural policy, it would be absolutely grotesque to conclude this agreement with two countries that are particularly competitive in this sector. Despite the low level of government subsidies, Australia is able to export 80% of its cereal and livestock production, while New Zealand is the largest net exporter of dairy products. Despite the Commission's intention to set quotas and implement safeguard measures, we consider that this agreement could end up killing livestock and the dairy sector in France. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations for free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand comes as a natural step in strengthening the partnership between these countries and the European Union. Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest partners, with common values and committed to promoting prosperity and security under a global rules-based system. Australia and New Zealand also work together in several international for a, acting against common challenges. Moreover, the EU and New Zealand are parties to the Public Procurement Agreement and Australia is in the process of joining it. At the same time, the EU, Australia and New Zealand are engaged in multilateral negotiations to continue liberalising trade in organic products. Given the significant number of agreements under negotiation between the EU and its main trading partners, the conclusion of free trade agreements between the EU and Australia and Australia, respectively, New Zealand will deepen trade and investment relations, creating the prerequisites for advancing economic relations to a new level, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The text calls for negotiations on a free trade agreement between the EU and Australia and New Zealand to start as soon as possible. Our opposition does not mean that we do not regard these two states as reliable trading partners. The quality standards of the standards are very high on both fronts. What the Northern League delegation disputes is the fact that an agricultural reality such as Australia could represent, in the event of a free trade agreement, a real danger to our operators in the sector.  The Northern League has tabled two important amendments: - one calling for a careful assessment of Australia and New Zealand's rules on intellectual property and the quality of production processes; - one calling for the dairy sector and the beef and veal sector (beef and pigmeat) to be excluded from possible negotiations.  It should also be remembered that in countries such as Australia and New Zealand – as well as in the USA – there is a legal system based on trade marks, which therefore sees the latter prevail over our geographical indications. Not only that, in fact, like those under Anglo-Saxon law, geographical indications are considered to be real non-tariff barriers to free trade.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Australia and New Zealand, despite being members of the World Trade Organization, have yet to begin negotiations for a free trade agreement with the EU. In its new foreign trade and investment strategy, the European Commission proposes to open the door to new negotiations in the Asia-Pacific region. In this resolution, the European Parliament supports the Commission's approach by stressing the importance of strengthening the European Union's relations with the countries that make up the region. Parliament reiterates the need to negotiate two separate free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. In this way, the economic specificities of these two countries will be preserved. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled following the question with oral reply question B8-0101/2016 on the opening of ALS (free trade agreements) negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. I am particularly pleased that the report specifies that agriculture is a very sensitive sector and that a final, balanced outcome in the chapters on agriculture and fisheries must take due account of the interests of all European producers, for example those in the canning sector, producers of meat, dairy products, sugar, cereals and textiles. It is also worth noting the call for effective bilateral safeguard measures to be included, in order to avoid a surge in imports which could cause serious harm to European producers in sensitive sectors. In this regard, for example, it should be remembered that Australia has been imposing customs duties on products processed from Italian tomatoes since 2014. These, together with other key points, such as the request to make the opening of negotiations conditional on the commitment of all parties to conduct negotiations as transparently as possible, are the reasons why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution on opening free trade agreement negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. While fair trade that benefits all parties is something I am in favour of in general, the radical eradication of any trade barriers for the sake of it is not necessarily in the interest of the people. In this instance the move to open FTA negotiations is motivated by the conclusion of the TPP and a fear of the EU being cut out of the Asia-Pacific region. There are particular sensitivities to take into account when opening negotiations with countries such as Australia and New Zealand, the latter being known for its large agricultural and dairy outputs. The seasonal nature of trade patterns with these countries also mean that the abolition of trade barriers, tariff and non-tariff will cause market changes. Finally this agreement again includes the EU’s proposed ‘Investment Court’ which I have completely opposed in TTIP. For these reasons I voted against the resolution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise the economic importance of relations between the EU and Australia and New Zealand and I fully support the negotiations for a new trade agreement. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as such agreements will strengthen and deepen our economic and political ties and will bring benefits to all parties. I am of the opinion that the negotiations should focus, beside the traditional goods and services, on e-commerce, technology, innovation and common standards.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The own-initiative resolution stresses the importance for economic growth of deepening the Union's trade relations with the Asia-Pacific area, especially with Australia and New Zealand. They are a key component of the relative strategy as they are, moreover, markets capable of mitigating the potential diversional effects of the TPP recently concluded with the United States. The text also mentions the need for reinforced convergence and cooperation on international standards without lowering levels of consumer protection (e.g. food safety), environmental protection (e.g. animal health and welfare, plant health) or social and labour. It also stresses the central importance of the agricultural sector and the sensitivity of approach it requires. I voted in favour without delay.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as I am convinced there should be a swift initiation of negotiations on free trade agreements between the EU and Australia and New Zealand. The EU has already negotiated or started to negotiate agreements with all key trade partners but these two. Despite the fact that Australia and New Zealand are, notwithstanding geography, EU’s close allies not only in bilateral trade, but also in the multilateral trade agenda. The EU is Australia’s number one trade partner and a key source of foreign investments too.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and stress the importance of deepening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for economic development on both sides.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the proposals as I agree with the European Parliament's choice which, following the launch of the new European Trade and Investment Strategy, has decided to start preliminary talks with countries such as Australia and New Zealand in such a way as to strengthen the prospects for economic integration in the South East Pacific areas. The negotiations, which will have to lead to strong and enforceable provisions in various areas, require impact assessments on the overall sustainability of potential agreements with a view to being able to fully assess the possible benefits and losses that would result in a strengthening of the EU's trade and investment relations with Australia and New Zealand, to the benefit of their respective populations and businesses, including the outermost regions and overseas countries and territories.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on this proposal, which I voted in favour of, allows me to recall an important principle, which many seem to have forgotten: negotiations for international treaties are made on the basis of clear and precise mandates and in the interests of the citizens. This is true in the case of the future free trade area with Australia and New Zealand, it is true in the case of TTIP. Trade policy is not done with slogans, but by creating opportunities for companies and therefore for workers and consumers.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Australia and New Zealand are one of the oldest and closest partners in the European Union, sharing common values and even bilateral agreements in some specific sectors. I support the Resolution for the opening of negotiations on a Free Trade Agreement with these two countries, as I consider a further deepening of trade and investment relations to benefit the parties, in particular through convergence and cooperation on international standards without, however, lowering levels of consumer protection or social and labour rights.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report . UKIP yearns for the day we can make our own free trade deals with Commonwealth countries. However, we feel the EU would not conduct a deal with Australia or NZ that was fair, honourable or in the interest of the UK, Australia or New Zealand. Therefore we voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Deepening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region is important for economic growth in Europe and this is reflected in European trade policy which sees Australia and New Zealand as key components of this strategy. In this respect, I am in favour of opening negotiations on a modern, ambitious and balanced free trade agreement in accordance with the economic characteristics of the two states.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ New Zealand is one of the few countries to be recognised by the Commission as having an adequate level of private data protection. FTA negotiations with Australia and New Zealand need to consider opportunities as well as difficulties that may be created for European SMEs.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Both Australia and New Zealand have oriented their trade policies towards the EU. Today's global economy is highly integrated, and global supply chains have largely replaced traditional trade. The EU's trade strategy aims to strengthen the Union's policy and to contribute to the promotion of growth, employment and investment. For this reason, trade relations with Australia and New Zealand can help promote common values and interests by addressing the issues of investment, trade in goods and services, public procurement, energy, competition, the fight against corruption and the needs of SMEs, without placing a burden on consumer and environmental protection. Of course, the agricultural sector will have to be of strategic importance in relations between countries. I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because it seeks to deepen trade relations between Australia and New Zealand on the one hand and the European Union on the other without warning of the harmful effects they will have on their economies. This agreement seeks to strengthen trade relations to alleviate the diversionary effect that the recent trans-Pacific partnership may have. However, we believe that this agreement can have a deadly impact on our economy, especially on the European dairy sector, a sector which is already suffering from the demise of quotas and which, due to the contraction in Chinese consumption, will be flooded with the New Zealand surplus. This liberalizing agenda of international trade that takes place for the benefit of multinationals without taking into account the real effect it will have on the real economy is at the origin of many of our economic problems. That is why I have decided to vote against this motion for a resolution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution authorises the Commission to open negotiations for the free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. By voting in favour of the resolution, I intend to support the opening of transparent and inclusive negotiations involving civil society and all the social partners. Indeed, I believe that a deepening of trade relations with Australia and New Zealand, focusing on aspects such as investment, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, competition and the needs of SMEs, can make a positive contribution to economic growth in Europe in all sectors.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament has today given its consent to the comprehensive free trade agreements that may be concluded between the EU and Australia and the EU and New Zealand. Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners. The parliamentary report adopted today mentions the issues on which, in your opinion, the European Commission should focus during the negotiations. The report stresses that ambitious agreements between these three advanced economies should reasonably address investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, state-owned enterprises, competition, the fight against corruption, regulatory issues such as sanitary and phytitary restrictions, technology research and, in particular, the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises. It also notes that agriculture is a highly sensitive sector and that, in order to achieve a final, balanced outcome of the chapters on agriculture and fisheries, due account should be taken of the interests of all European producers, i.e. producers of meat, milk, sugar, cereals and textiles, as well as producers in the outermost regions, for example by introducing transitional periods and appropriate quotas, and by not making any commitments in the most sensitive sectors in these chapters. I consider it important that the report calls for effective bilateral precautions to be included in order to prevent a sudden increase in imports, which would seriously harm the interests of European producers in sensitive sectors.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The INTA Commission prepared a short resolution expressing its support for the Commission's decision to start preparatory work for the negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. The resolution recognises that Australia and New Zealand are a key part of the EU's overall Asia-Pacific strategy and that any agreement must benefit both sides, taking into account well-known sensitive issues and ensuring that the outermost regions with special status in the EU are adequately taken into account.  In view of the recent conclusion of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a free trade area of 12 Asia-Pacific countries, the resolution calls on the Commission to work as soon as possible to balance all possible counterproducts of the Trans-Pacific Partnership so that EU companies can continue to be competitive on an equal footing with companies from the US, Canada, Chile, Mexico, Japan and other countries. I voted in favour of the proposed document.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With the Commission proposal of ‘Trade for All’ and the Union seeking to negotiate directives for trade agreements between Australia and New Zealand, I believe that labour protection and transparency standards need to be included in the negotiations. A joint civil society forum is needed in order to have an effective monitoring of implementation of the parties’ respect for their commitments and obligations. These negotiations must seek to safeguard human rights, labour standards and environmental protection. The negotiations should be based on the principle of sustainability. However, the negotiations are a positive step forward, and this is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support advocating the strongest free trade ties with the two key Commonwealth members Australia and New Zealand, and therefore voted in favour of the opening of negotiations. I also support launching these negotiations in the shortest timeframe possible and hope, given the shared values, perspectives and economic systems of the EU, Australia and New Zealand, that mutually beneficial, ambitious and wide—ranging agreements can be concluded as soon as possible. Australia and New Zealand are two strong advocates of free trade agreement deals, with a recent example being the FTA signed with the twelve Pacific Rim countries. That is why I would like to see an FTA which promotes deeper trade and investment relations as quickly as possible, so that we can further deepen trade ties in the growing Asia-Pacific region.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations for the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Australia and New Zealand. Today there is a substantial trade flow between the European Union and Australia and New Zealand, countries with which our continent has always had close ties and shares common values and for which the EU is already the third most important trading partner. Australia and New Zealand, however, remain two of the few WTO member countries that do not have any preferential access to our market. I am convinced that establishing ever closer economic relations with countries such as Australia and New Zealand, advanced economies that have always been committed to advancing the multilateral agenda, is a great opportunity that the European Union must seize. At the same time, it will be necessary for the negotiators to work to achieve balanced, in-depth and ambitious agreements that take due account of the recommendations that the European Parliament has made in this resolution, with particular attention to sensitive sectors such as agriculture and fisheries and to the protection and promotion of intellectual property rights, including geographical indications. It will also be important to ensure the transparency of these negotiations, while maintaining a constant dialogue with civil society and social partners.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the European Parliament's position in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. This plan to launch the negotiations was announced by the Commission at the end of 2015 as part of the EU's trade strategy. The negotiating mandate will be granted to the Commission by the Council and will be preceded by an impact assessment. In the European Parliament, we recall that agriculture is a very sensitive sector with this third country, which is a major exporter. It is essential that the interests of European producers of meat, dairy products, sugar, cereals and textiles be taken into account in this agreement. Considering that it is necessary to preserve our agriculture within the framework of such trade agreements, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported Parliament's resolution on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand that calls for strengthening economic and trade relations between the European Union and the Asia-Pacific region. Negotiations are expected to lead to ambitious free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. In particular, I am in favour of these agreements taking full account of the needs and interests of SMEs in the context of market access measures.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution to start negotiations for the free trade area with Australia and New Zealand. The agreement will enable the European Union and its Member States to integrate further into the region's market. The European Commission will have to commit itself to starting negotiations as soon as possible to facilitate the conclusion of modern, innovative free trade and preferential access agreements with Australia and New Zealand.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand could provide new opportunities and opportunities for our businesses. However, it is essential to negotiate ambitious and balanced agreements in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefits. I the hope that the European agricultural sectors will be in association ahead of the opening of negotiations, the exclusion of certain products or the allocation of very small quotas and the recognition and protection of our protected geographical indications. As these points are enshrined in the resolution on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, I have decided to vote in favour.  Indeed, these are points which, in my view, cannot be negotiable.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand because I believe that strengthening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region can have a beneficial effect on European economic growth. Australia and New Zealand play a key role in this region. Expanding and expanding trade with these partners can help boost the economic growth of the three partners, especially as Australia, New Zealand and the EU share common values and work to promote prosperity and security within a rules-based international order. In addition, the EU, Australia and New Zealand are currently conducting multilateral negotiations to further liberalise trade in environmental goods and trade in services. Finally, Australia and New Zealand participated in the recently completed Trans-Pacific Partnership negotiations. I would not understand if the EU is not also involved in the conclusion of modern, ambitious, balanced and comprehensive free trade agreements. I do, however, call for transparent negotiations that respect European environmental, health and social standards.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the competitiveness of Australia and New Zealand in the areas of grain farming, livestock or dairy production, it is against the interests of Member States to put them in competition with the aforementioned countries. In the context of the crisis in these sectors in Europe, it would be irresponsible to move in the direction of greater free trade—with those countries, which have already signed the Trans-Pacific Treaty. Not adhering to the vision of Parliament and the European Commission, which claim to "preserve" these sectors, while exposing them to the aforementioned dangers, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short resolution prepared by the European Parliament's Committee on International Trade outlines its support for the European Commission's decision to start work on preparing for negotiations on free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. The resolution recognises that Australia and New Zealand form an essential part of the EU's overall strategy in the Asia-Pacific region, and that all agreements must be mutually beneficial to both sides. I agree, and that is why I supported the resolution. The competitiveness of European companies on the global market must be supported by such agreements. I also welcome the Commission's intention to carry out a preliminary impact assessment on the economies of the EU Member States and this is an important step in deciding on future action.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this motion for a resolution as we do not believe in the merits of free trade agreements and we reject the proposal to open negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. The conclusion of the EU-Australia and EU-New Zealand free trade agreements will change mutual trade and investment relations, particularly in the agricultural and livestock sectors, with market consequences and potential risks to European economic operators.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Deepening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region is important for economic growth in Europe, with Australia and New Zealand becoming crucial elements of this strategy. The negotiation of two distinct, modern, ambitious, balanced and comprehensive FTAs with Australia and New Zealand, in line with the specific characteristics of these economies, is a pragmatic way to deepen bilateral partnerships and strengthen existing mature bilateral and investment relations. I agree to a more in-depth analysis of all additional market access opportunities for European economic operators, including SMEs, offered by possible FTAs with Australia and New Zealand.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Australia and New Zealand are parties to the recently concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations between the US and a number of countries in Asia and Oceania. They are also parties to the negotiations on the Comprehensive Regional Economic Partnership (RCEP) in East Asia. We are dealing with trade and investment liberalisation agreements covering trade in goods and services (including public services), e-commerce, public procurement, the energy sector, sanitary, phytosanitary and other regulations, technology research, investments. In this context, it provides for an ISDS – private arbitration mechanism for state-investor dispute resolution. These are agreements that will be profiled with the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) and CETA (EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement), treaties that we firmly reject, demanding the immediate end of their negotiations, for calling into question the most basic democratic rights, public services, the right to work with rights and the sovereignty of the States. The possibility of deadlocks in the TTIP negotiations and the strategic commitment made by the US in the Pacific region lead the great European capital and the forces and powers that defend their interests not to neglect this region as well. We voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because, although Australia and New Zealand are reliable trading partners, free trade with these countries could pose a danger to economic operators.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this motion for a resolution as I do not believe in the advantages of free trade agreements and I reject the proposal to open negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. The conclusion of the EU-Australia and EU-New Zealand free trade agreements will change mutual trade and investment relations, particularly in the agricultural and livestock sectors, with market consequences and potential risks to European economic operators.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The leaders of EU and Australia, in their meeting on 15 November 2015, agreed to commence work towards the launch of negotiations for a free trade agreement. The EU and New Zealand, in their meeting on 29 October 2015, also announced the start of the process for negotiations on a comprehensive free trade agreement. I am strongly in favour of starting a discussion on key global issues such as human rights, security, development and protection of the environment with Australia and New Zealand. It is important to understand the possible risks of trade diversion resulting from the TPP, and how these affect the potential interest of the EU in concluding high-quality comprehensive FTAs with Australia and New Zealand. Launching negotiations for swift, high-quality and comprehensive agreements would further integrate the EU into value chains in the Asia-Pacific region. I hope that negotiations with these important trade partners will start as soon as possible.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners, share common values with EU values and are committed to promoting prosperity and security globally within the framework of a rules-based system. I consider it of the utmost importance to deepen relations between the European Union and the Asia-Pacific region for Economic Growth in Europe, and I stress that this is reflected in the European Union's trade policy. I believe that Australia and New Zealand play a key role in this strategy and that broadening and deepening trade with these partners can help achieve this goal.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as opening new markets outside EU limits can have positive effects on the Union as a whole. This should be the first step in opening bilateral negotiations and future treaties with Asian markets.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, tabled following the question with a request for an oral reply, pursuant to Rule 128 of the Regulation, on the opening of negotiations for free trade agreements (SASAs) with Australia and New Zealand. I believe, in fact, that the opening of the FSA negotiations can give the European Union the opportunity to strengthen and deepen relations with these two distant oceania countries, the only ones currently among the Member States of the World Trade Organisation without privileged trade channels with the EU. With a view to fair, fruitful and comprehensive agreements and closer cooperation between the two countries, I believe it is ambitious to follow up the existing investment partnerships with free trade agreements so as to create more business opportunities, especially for SMEs. Finally, I would like to stress the need to take due account, during the negotiation of the agreement, of the interests of all economic operators, especially those in the agricultural and fisheries sectors, and I call on the committee to carry out the impact assessment of these agreements in THE EU territories as soon as possible.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, as this trade agreement cleans up the very problems and mistakes that many criticise in other procedures that have already been concluded or are still in progress. The trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand has the opportunity to set new standards worldwide for functioning, forward-looking "fair trade agreements".

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners. They share the same values with us and are jointly committed to promoting prosperity and security in the world. The European Union and New Zealand are parties to the public procurement agreement and Australia is in the process of acceding to this agreement. In addition, they are conducting multilateral negotiations with a view to further liberalising trade in organic products and trade in services (TiSA). The EU is the third most important trading partner of Australia and New Zealand, and these countries rank 21st and 50th respectively among our largest trading partners (2014 data). Australia and New Zealand are two countries fully characterised by the rule of law and currently providing strong protection for the environment, human rights, social and labour rights. The conclusion of free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand will strengthen trade and investment relations and ensure entry to a higher level of economic relations. Contracts must take into account investments such as trade in goods and services, public procurement, competition, regulatory issues and technological research.  We call on the Commission to carry out an overall assessment of the impact of possible sustainable development agreements as soon as possible, with a view also to ensuring that all parties commit to conducting negotiations in the most transparent way possible, respecting best practices and through ongoing dialogue with the social partners and civil society.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the opening of FTA negotiations with Australia and New Zealand given the Asia-Pacific region, where 90% of world growth is estimated to happen over the next decade, is vital for us. With their European heritage, their relative proximity to the Asian market and their membership of the TPP (Trans-Pacific Partnership), Australia and New Zealand can be very important partners for us. I also welcome the strong and consistent commitment of Australia and New Zealand to the multilateral trade agenda and to the promotion of a global governance based on rules.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. The same report recognises the possible adverse effects that the agreement may have on social and workers' rights, but we do not think it is convincing as to the clause that would nullify it if these negative effects were indeed given.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of opening negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. Both countries play a very important role in the European Union's overall Asia-Pacific strategy. Nevertheless, appropriate analyses, including scope analysis and impact assessment, are necessary for the proper evaluation of the FTA. Furthermore, I call on the Commission to carry out a thorough review of the effects of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which will certainly allow European Union companies to develop and reach the level of countries such as Japan and Canada.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report, which UKIP chose to abstain on. In principle UKIP agrees with free trade agreements especially with our Commonwealth allies, New Zealand and Australia. However, we are totally opposed to the EU negotiating trade agreements with other countries on the UK’s behalf, therefore we abstained.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution. It is important to deepen relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for economic growth within Europe. This is reflected in the European Union’s trade policy. Australia and New Zealand have strong and consistent commitment to the multilateral trade agenda. Therefore, these two countries are a key part of this strategy and that widening and deepening trade with these partners can help to meet this goal.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted against the motion for a resolution because of the extreme liberal approach on which it is based and the fact that the possible negative effects/impact on European dairy farmers of the possible free trade agreement, in particular with New Zealand, which has a very competitive industry in the sector concerned, are not taken into account.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the opening of free trade agreement negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. Both are close political and trading partners of the EU and the opening of negotiations for two separate FTAs has the potential for economic growth and investment for all involved, but this must be done without lowering any consumer, environmental or social and labour protection levels. In the resolution we call on the Commission to study all additional market access opportunities for European economic operators, especially SMEs, offered by the possible FTAs and to weigh these against any possible defensive interests, given that both Australia and New Zealand have already comparatively open markets and very low tariffs. I also supported amendments to closely monitor certain agriculture sectors such as the dairy and meat sectors and where appropriate exclude them from the negotiations and to maintain high animal welfare standards. Ultimately the Parliament will have the final say on any agreed FTAs and the above issues will be crucial to achieving agreement.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it underlines the importance of deepening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for economic growth within Europe and stresses that this is reflected in the European Union’s trade policy. The resolution also recognises that Australia and New Zealand are a key part of this strategy and that widening and deepening trade with these partners can help to meet this goal. The full potential of the Union’s bilateral and regional cooperation strategies can only be realised by concluding high-quality FTAs with both Australia and New Zealand.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP yearns for the day we can make our own free trade deals with Commonwealth countries. However, we feel the EU would not conduct a deal with Australia or NZ that was fair, honourable or in the interest of the UK, Australia or New Zealand. Therefore we voted against.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is committed to free trade. Free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win for consumers in particular.  Australia and New Zealand are countries with a very similar cultural background to the EU countries. Both countries have been reliable partners in the past. Similar approaches can also be seen in regulation, so I hope that a fair and comprehensive treaty will be achieved.  I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report . UKIP yearns for the day we can make our own free trade deals with Commonwealth countries. However, we feel the EU would not conduct a deal with Australia or NZ that was fair, honourable or in the interest of the UK, Australia or New Zealand. Therefore we voted against.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the opening of free trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand although this does not preclude any objections I may have to any future outcome. I support Scotland’s membership of the EU and will vote accordingly in the forthcoming UK referendum. The EU operates as a trading block and that implies reaching international agreements. I have deep reservations about TTIP and will vote to reject an unsatisfactory agreement. Nevertheless, we should not object to the EU entering into new international negotiations – which in turn can be rejected if they are ultimately unsatisfactory.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution to open negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, as I think it is extremely important to strengthen relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region because it can contribute to economic growth within Europe in this way, and this will also affect the European Union's trade policy. Australia and New Zealand are important partners of the EU, have the same values and are committed to promoting prosperity and security globally under an international law-based system. I believe that an agreement between these three developed economies can contribute concretely to investment, trade in goods and services, and therefore I vote for this resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the high competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, particularly in livestock, milk and cereals, it is very dangerous to open free trade negotiations with these two countries. This could end up killing french livestock and the dairy sector. We cannot believe Parliament and the Commission in their desire to 'preserve' sensitive sectors. Their vision here is to put in place transitional periods, quotas at the beginning, but aggressive free trade afterwards.  So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report . UKIP yearns for the day we can make our own free trade deals with Commonwealth countries. However, we feel the EU would not conduct a deal with Australia or NZ that was fair, honourable or in the interest of the UK, Australia or New Zealand. Therefore we voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Bernd Lange and Daniel Caspary on a resolution on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. This resolution focuses on the influence that could have on the European growth of the consolidated relations between the Union and the Asia-Pacific region. The EU's trade policy must reflect this direction, with Australia and New Zealand being two very important economic weights in this region. Parliament believes that these free trade agreements will have to be ambitious, balanced and comprehensive, under a new generation model of free trade agreements. I support the opening of these negotiations, the results of which can be of significant weight in the governance of the world economy through the convergence of international standards.   This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which underlines the importance of strengthening relations between the European Union and the Asia-Pacific region and specifically Australia and New Zealand, major players in this region. These free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand are important for the Union to position itself in this region with significant economic growth, especially as the Union, Australia and New Zealand share common values. However, these negotiations must be clear, transparent and respectful of our European environmental and social standards.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Australia and New Zealand are two advanced countries with which a free trade agreement would be desirable, but I abstained from the resolution, as there is already a high degree of agreement or regulation in the area of economic and political relations between the EU and these two countries, such as agriculture and food standards.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is committed to free trade. With appropriately smart design, free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win, especially for consumers.  I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the proposal because it is not in the interest of fair trade between stakeholders to radically break down trade barriers. Similar investment and free market agreements raise a very dangerous issue of investment and their protection. Another point of criticism is the convergence of international standards, which in practice could lead to lower European standards as well as to lower consumer or environmental protection. Australia and New Zealand are countries relatively far from Europe, which is why transporting goods is an unnecessary financial burden, as well as a burden on the environment when European farmers are able to provide similar food. In addition, there is a risk of food degradation when transported over such a long distance (it is stated distance: Prague – Auckland 17 885 km).

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, since it is not a fair trade agreement and does not benefit all parties. We are against a simple market liberalisation. The trade agreement between Australia and New Zealand should also not include the Investor to State Dispute Settlement, since it is a biased system which promotes enterprises over states.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The opening of free trade agreement negotiations with Australia and New Zealand represents a significant step forward for economic growth and prosperity for all involved sides. An agreement will ensure EU trade reaches its full potential, particularly in the context of the eastern shift in the world’s economy. For Australia, removing trade barriers with the EU, which is the country’s third largest trading partner, will definitely result in increased export growth. On the other hand, for New Zealand, a trade deal with the EU will be beneficial for inward investment since the EU represents the country’s second largest source of investment. Last but not least, the FTA with Australia and New Zealand will not only highlight our common interests such as economic growth, human rights, security and peace but also facilitate political cooperation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest partners. Both participate in the recently concluded negotiations for a Trans-Pacific Partnership (PTP) and in the ongoing negotiations for a Comprehensive Regional Economic Partnership (RCEP) in East Asia, which includes australia's and New Zealand's most important trading partners. It is also possible to say with certainty that both countries guarantee a high level of environmental protection and the protection of human, social and employment rights. It is vital ly important for the European Union to strengthen relations with the Asia-Pacific region, and both countries are crucial to achieving this objective. The negotiation of two separate modern and ambitious free trade agreements must certainly address important aspects, such as investment, trade in goods and services, energy, state-owned enterprises, competition and, above all, the needs and interests of SMEs. I believe that these negotiations will have beneficial effects for all the parties concerned and I have therefore decided to give my positive opinion to this resolution.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. Given the high competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, particularly in livestock, milk and cereals, it is very dangerous to open free trade negotiations with these two countries. This could end up killing french livestock and the dairy sector. We cannot believe Parliament and the Commission in their desire to 'preserve' sensitive sectors. Their vision here is to put in place transitional periods, quotas at the beginning, but aggressive free trade afterwards.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it favours a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, which will aggravate the plight of French farmers, particularly in the milk and pig and cattle sectors.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because it seeks to deepen trade relations between Australia and New Zealand on the one hand and the European Union on the other without warning of the harmful effects they will have on their economies. This agreement seeks to strengthen trade relations to alleviate the diversionary effect that the recent trans-Pacific partnership may have. However, we believe that this agreement can have a deadly impact on our economy, especially on the European dairy sector, a sector which is already suffering from the demise of quotas and which, due to the contraction in Chinese consumption, will be flooded with the New Zealand surplus. This liberalizing agenda of international trade that takes place for the benefit of multinationals without taking into account the real effect it will have on the real economy is at the origin of many of our economic problems. That is why I have decided to vote against this motion for a resolution.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is committed to free trade. Free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win for consumers in particular.  Australia and New Zealand are countries with a very similar cultural background to the EU countries. Both countries have been reliable partners in the past. Similar approaches can also be seen in regulation, so I hope that a fair and comprehensive treaty will be achieved.  I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I support the free market with Australia and New Zealand.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Australia and New Zealand are considered the EU's oldest and closest partners, and this agreement allows for further strengthening of bilateral trade relations. Given the sensitivity of agriculture, it is necessary to take into account the characteristics and specificities of the agricultural sector in the Union. In addition to farmers, the needs and interests of SMEs should be taken into account in the context of facilitating market access. I supported this resolution because I believe it will have a positive impact on achieving growth in the European Union.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is the third most important trading partner of Australia and New Zealand. These are countries characterised by elements of a strong rule of law, respect for human and social rights, with strong protection of nature and the environment. I support the opening of negotiations on free trade agreements with these countries, which will be built on mutual partnership, benefit and reciprocity. The agreements will facilitate trade and market access, especially for SMEs, thus helping to promote economic growth in EU Member States.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union, Australia and New Zealand are currently negotiating to strengthen their trade relations.  If these negotiations were to lead to an agreement, it could deal a fatal blow to the economies of the French outermost regions (RUP). As Australia is the world's 10th largest producer of cane sugar, the cannier sector, particularly in Reunion, could be hit hard by the conclusion of such a free trade agreement, if special sugars are not excluded from the scope of negotiations. The resolution calls for bilateral safeguards to be provided to protect sensitive production, including those of the UPRs. It goes further, calling on the Commission to exclude special sugars from the negotiations.  With this text, the European Parliament expressly calls on the Commission to take due account of the specific interests of the UPRs in these trade talks. It is therefore only natural that I vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, because it is not complete and documented, and because the free trade agreement being passed will allow australia and New Zealand to import their livestock and agricultural products into the EU, and in particular Greece, which will economically harm the poor greek farmers and livestock farmers from the Memorandum and create serious problems in the smooth development of the primary sectors of our country as well as the Greek companies of the food production sector.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. The EU wants to increase its trade relations with Australia and New Zealand. All the following fields must be included in the agreement: investment, goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, state-owned enterprises, energy, plant protection barriers... Given the high competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, particularly in livestock, milk and cereals, it is very dangerous to open free trade negotiations with these two countries. This could end up killing the French livestock and dairy sector!

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the proposal to open negotiations on free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. It is important to continue to promote relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for economic growth in Europe and this should be reflected in the European Union's trade policy. Australia and New Zealand are a key part of this strategy and we must work to deepen trade relations with these partners, who have always demonstrated their firm and constant commitment to the multilateral trade agenda.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on the opening of negotiations on free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. I believe that such an agreement will create new opportunities for business and will bring benefits to consumers. Among other things, I strongly support the position set out in the resolution that it is particularly important to take into account the interests of European producers (e.g. meat, milk, sugar, cereals and textiles) when negotiating a free trade agreement and to agree on bilateral safeguards, such as transitional periods or corresponding quotas, or without any commitment in the most vulnerable sectors.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Australia and New Zealand recently signed the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which establishes a free trade area with the United States, Canada, Japan... Therefore, the EU is also proposing a free trade agreement with this area so as not to lag behind. The resolution thus defends the establishment of this free trade agreement between Australia and New Zealand on the one hand and the Union on the other. The resolution "underlines the importance of strengthening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for European economic growth", even as Australia and New Zealand rank 21st and 51st on the EU's list of trading partners (2014). I oppose these free trade agreements, which sow misery wherever they are applied and instead call for the establishment of solidarity protectionism. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report is interesting in that it makes the case for the agricultural sector through quotas and transitional periods. It also calls on the Commission to be transparent, which is good. That said, the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors are particularly powerful, especially in cereals, livestock and milk. French livestock farming, which is not doing well, is in danger with this report. I am not convinced by the guarantees that the Union is proposing for sensitive sectors. This being only a start, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the opening of negotiations on a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with Australia and New Zealand. Australia and New Zealand are among the oldest and closest partners in the EU and share many common values. Further trade and investment relations are needed.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of opening up FTA negotiations with Australia and New Zealand because deepening ties with two close partners in the rapidly developing Asia-Pacific region is important for Europe and for the two nations’ economic growth.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Despite the huge distance from Europe, Australia and New Zealand are very close to the European Union. We are connected not only by joint solutions to problems and cooperation in various areas, but especially by the values that make us partners and friends. European values are also reflected in the nature of these countries. These are states where respect for rights and freedoms comes first. These are strong legal states with which I find it welcome to conclude agreements. Agreements can bring many benefits to the European Union stem from the adjustment of trade and the economy. Of course, as with any free trade agreement, all negotiated provisions must be in line with our common values, while respecting European standards and rules.
