I support these steps, but subject to strict transparency! There's an old truth written by Thomas Mann: Free to make deals, but one that you can sleep happily at night.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution, which calls for strong trade and sustainable development chapters in any newly launched trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the opening of FTA negotiations with Australia and New Zealand, countries with which we share values and cooperate on many issues at the global level. I have publicly called for this as one of the measures that the Western World needs to undertake in order to tackle its ‘Big Contraction’. It is actually quite striking that Australia and New Zealand are two of only six WTO Members with which we have no preferential arrangement in place or under negotiation. Of course the agreement will have to be comprehensive, respect our sensitives, notably in the agricultural sector, and include an ambitious trade and sustainable development chapter.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners, share common values with EU values and are committed to promoting prosperity and security globally. The rule of law principle is fully applied in both countries and provides strong protection of the environment, human, social and labour rights. Negotiations on the Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation between the European Union and New Zealand (PARC) were concluded on 30 July 2014 and the EU-Australia Framework Agreement (FA) was concluded on 22 April 2015. The Committee on International Trade proposes that the EP take a position so that the potential potential of the Union's bilateral and regional cooperation strategies can only be exploited if, in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit, high-quality free trade agreements are concluded with both Australia and New Zealand. It therefore recommends that the Commission carry out comprehensive sustainability impact assessments on possible agreements as soon as possible in order to be able to thoroughly assess the potential benefits and disadvantages of enhancing trade and investment relations between the EU and Australia and the EU-New Zealand. I supported the resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. In an environment where Australia and New Zealand recently signed the Trans-Pacific Treaty, the European Union wants to increase trade relations with these countries in the following areas: investment, goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, state-owned enterprises, energy, plant protection barriers... Given the high competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, particularly in livestock, milk and cereals, it is very dangerous to open free trade negotiations with these two countries. This could end up killing french livestock and the dairy sector. Even if Parliament and the Commission express their desire to preserve sensitive sectors by setting up transition periods and quotas, we know very well that this will eventually result in a very aggressive free trade. As a result, we are vehemently opposed to this increase in trade relations.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the high competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, particularly in livestock, milk and cereals, it is very dangerous to open free trade negotiations with these two countries. This could end up killing french livestock and the dairy sector. That is why I voted against it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament stresses the importance of strengthening relations between the Union and the Asia-Pacific region for European economic growth and stresses the need to see this importance reflected in the European Union's trade policy. It recognises that Australia and New Zealand play a key role in this strategy and that the expansion and development of trade with these partners can help achieve this goal. It also believes that negotiating two separate, modern, ambitious, balanced and comprehensive free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand, in line with the specifics of the economies of these countries, represents a pragmatic way to strengthen bilateral partnerships, because it would further strengthen mature trade and investment relations and mitigate the impact. , in terms of reducing the volume of trade with the EU, the recently concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership. The European Parliament believes that the outcome of the negotiations should be a model for a new generation of free trade agreements. Furthermore, it stresses that any ambitious agreement between these three developed economies must adequately cover a number of areas relating to the economy and protection.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the opening of negotiations with Australia and New Zealand on a trade agreement to create a free trade area. The two countries are, in fact, historic allies of the European Union and share with it the same approach to the major global issues. The aim, in line with European trade policy, is to promote economic growth and, at the same time, to help define the rules of the playing field of globalisation. The proximity of values, for example in the field of data exchange, complementarity, which is particularly strong in the agricultural field because of the different seasons, and the low volume of trade also guarantee a low level of risk for the European production sector. In any case, we would like to see safeguard clauses included, with particular reference to agri-food imports, with the aim of ensuring maximum protection against possible distorting effects on the European market. Also in this area, we call on the European Commission to negotiate for the recognition and greater protection of geographical indications, which is offensive to the European Union. In line with the orientation of European trade policy, we stress the need for the final text of the agreement to contain a specific chapter on the needs and facilitation of the internationalisation of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the next 10 to 15 years almost 90% of the world’s demand will be generated outside the European Union. This is why through its agreements the EU should boost its growth potential by opening up market opportunities for European businesses abroad. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that should open the negotiations for a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand addressing investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, state owned enterprises, competition, anti-corruption and other regulatory issues.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. As we are seeing in the TTIP and CETA, how such negotiations are conducted and the dangers they pose to the citizen, I take a critical view of the opening of further negotiations on free trade agreements. Consequently, I would have voted against.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to open negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. This next-generation trade agreement therefore contains the new Investment Court system as proposed by the Commission. One of my main concerns was the competition of special sugars produced in Australia and New Zealand with those produced in the French overseas departments. My amendment to protect these sugars has been adopted.  Although I was reserved about the logic of the Union signing free trade agreements at all levels, Parliament's demand for the exclusion of special sugars led me to vote in favour of this demanding negotiating mandate.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In the interests of European economic growth, it is important to strengthen ties and to establish free trade with Australia and New Zealand, which are very important countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report, which UKIP chose to abstain on. In principle UKIP agrees with free trade agreements especially with our Commonwealth allies, New Zealand and Australia. However, we are totally opposed to the EU negotiating trade agreements with other countries on the UK’s behalf, therefore we abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We all know that Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners, sharing common values and committed to promoting prosperity and security within a rules-based system globally. We have always worked together to address common challenges on a wide range of issues, for these reasons concluding modern, ambitious, balanced and global agreements would raise economic relations to a new level. I therefore vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒2012 Statistics show that today the economies of Australia and New Zealand are one of the fastest growing in the world, and these two countries have been closely linked to the European Union for many years by trade links. The signing of the Free Trade Agreement both with Australia and New Zealand will bring mutual benefit and enhance already extremely active trade cooperation with the two countries. Australia and New Zealand are close to the European Union not only in terms of values and common interests, but also because of the attitudes they share with the Union on important international issues, such as fighting terrorism or tackling climate change. It is also not an issue but at this point to warn that the outcome of the negotiations, which can contribute to a better placement of competitive European agricultural products on this market by removing existing barriers, should not call into question the application of high EU standards for the placement of Australian and New Zealand agricultural products on the EU market.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. While French farmers are experiencing terrible difficulties, I am outraged by this draft agreement with New Zealand and Australia, major agricultural producers who will obviously make the situation of the French even worse. The Commission seems determined to kill French farmers to the last, since it is increasing the investigations against them and all those who would like to allow them to live decently by buying their produce at a reasonable price and it is increasingly opening up the European Union to competition from third countries. I reject these policies that are harmful to both the economy and the environment. I therefore vote against the opening of these negotiations.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The announced free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand fit into the new trade and investment strategy, which highlighted the need to strengthen the presence in the Asia-Pacific area, which is why I support the opening of negotiations. It can be expected that a diversion of trade and facilitation of market access, the TPP and other free trade agreements in the region could put European exporters and investors at a disadvantage to the main competitors who would enjoy a preferential approach. Australia and New Zealand are among the fastest growing developed economies. Together, the two countries are already valuable EU partners with EU exports of €34.1 billion in goods (2014) and €21.0 billion in services (2013). Australia is 15th, while New Zealand is the 50th largest export market for goods for the EU. While eu-Australia-New Zealand framework agreements will enhance political and sectoral cooperation between the parties, there is also untapped potential in the areas of trade, investment and economic cooperation. When negotiating, negotiators must not be burdened with time pressure but must primarily represent the interests of European producers and spending. I hope that the issue of recognition of products protected by geographical origin will be negotiated early and that recognition of this protection in New Zealand will finally be ensured.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The two countries in question are part of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations between the US and Asia and Oceania, as well as the negotiations on the Comprehensive Regional Economic Partnership (RCEP) in East Asia. We are dealing with trade and investment liberalisation agreements, covering trade in goods and services (including public services), public procurement, e-commerce, the energy sector, sanitary, phytosanitary and other regulations and technology research. In this context, it provides for an ISDS – private arbitration mechanism for the resolution of State-Investor disputes. In the same political register of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) and CETA (EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement), they are treaties that we firmly reject, demanding an immediate end to their negotiations for calling into question the most basic democratic rights, public services, the right to work with rights and the sovereignty of the States. The deadlocks in the TTIP negotiations and the Us strategic commitment to the Pacific region lead the great European capital and the forces and powers that defend their interests not to lose their footing in this region. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposals for resolutions to open negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, countries that strongly and consistently occupy the multilateral trade agenda. Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners, have the same values and are committed to promoting prosperity and security globally under a rules-based system. The EU, Australia and New Zealand are working to address common challenges related to a number of different problems and are working together in several international for a. They are two of only six WTO Member States that do not yet have preferential access to the EU market and do not engage in negotiations to this end, both of which fully respect the rule of law and currently strongly protect the environment and human, social and labour rights. New Zealand is one of the few countries identified by the European Commission as having an adequate level of protection of personal data, which, while respecting private life, is a fundamental right. By concluding modern, ambitious, uniform and comprehensive agreements, economic relations are reaching a new level, which is very important for the development and betterment of the EU. Strengthening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region is also crucial for Europe's economic growth, as reflected in EU trade policy.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's new trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand is an important step towards opening up a market in a region that is currently growing fastest in the world and which is to maintain this economic potential for the future. I am convinced that the trade agreement will open up new opportunities for cooperation, investment and create new jobs. Last but not least, the agreement will further strengthen relations based on the sharing of the same values of all partners, as consensus has been reached both on sustainable development and environmental protection, as well as on the protection of human and workers' rights. As a Social Democrat, I am, of course, glad that we are at the very heart of these important points. The fact is that there are still sectors, such as agriculture, in which we will have to exercise caution, yet I was very happy to support this agreement.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the opening of negotiations on two separate, modern and ambitious free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand is a way of further strengthening existing bilateral trade and investment relations. These negotiations must take place in a spirit of reciprocity and in search of benefits for both sides. At the same time, given that agriculture and fisheries are very sensitive sectors, I hope that the Commission will take due account of the interests of all European producers, for example by introducing transitional periods or by not engaging in the most sensitive sectors. I therefore voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution is about the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. It is to be feared that this free trade agreement is a ttip on a smaller scale. This motion mentions the need for harmonisation and an intensification of cooperation in the field of international standards. However, such processes must be transparent, which I do not believe in this free trade agreement. I am therefore voting against the motion for a resolution.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the opening of negotiations on future free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand which will serve to deepen trade and investment relations and contribute to economic development. While it is premature to assess the level of ambition of the agreements, the Socialists require rigorous previous impact studies, in particular in the agricultural chapter, appropriate public consultations, transparency in the negotiations, strong provisions on the protection of labour rights, the defence of the power of the EU and the Member States to legislate in the public interest and the inclusion of a chapter on sustainability and strong human rights , binding and enforceable. In addition, we defend multilateralism as a priority of EU trade policy. The Commission's efforts to move forward with new bilateral negotiations should not be detrimental to the resources it devotes to the multilateral agenda.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has agreed to launch negotiations for free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. The conclusion of these agreements will maximise the growth potential of strengthening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region and will enable cooperation on standards to be intensified without levelling food security, environmental protection, social protection or worker protection. The European Parliament also called for the consideration of the interests of SMEs and the inclusion of a "serious and ambitious" chapter on sustainable development, which incorporates basic labour standards, the ILO's four priority governance conventions and multilateral environmental agreements. The text of the resolution also stresses that agriculture is a "very sensitive sector" and calls for final and balanced results in agriculture and fisheries to take due account of the interests of all EU producers (particularly in the meat, dairy, sugar, cereals and textile sectors).

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against because I am incomprehensible how it is possible to talk now about free trade agreements, when agriculture in Europe can barely breathe under the grip of a crisis. New Zealand is the world leader in dairy exports. Do we need even more milk in Europe? This type of agreement would affect not only producers of milk, but also meat, cereals, textiles and sugar, and the fisheries sector would undoubtedly have negative consequences. Despite the fact that the text refers to the need to have safeguards in agriculture, it is not clear whether this provision would subsequently remain. We cannot risk the future of the sector that is already in difficult times.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I am pleased to welcome the opening of negotiations on a Free Trade Agreement with Australia and New Zealand, as these are two of the only six WTO members with whom the EU does not have a mutual preferential market access agreement. The start of the negotiating process will enhance further trade and investment relations between the two economic blocs, while also enabling the re-establishing of the pre-existing balance within the macro-framework of global trade relations, especially after the signing of the recently concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement.  The key sectors of this agreement should naturally focus on investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public contracts, energy, competition, the fight against corruption and, in particular, the needs of SMEs, in terms of facilitating market access, in order to generate business opportunities for both parties.  I also support the position that a more detailed analysis of the opportunities and constraints this agreement may have for European economic operators is necessary, while safeguarding the interests of SMEs, as well as respect for international standards for consumer protection, the environment and human, social and labour rights. For the reasons put forward above, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with trade discussions with Australia and New Zealand. For the time being, negotiations have not yet been launched and it is in this sense that this text calls for full and sustainable long-term impact assessments to be carried out by the European Commission.  Indeed, given the global economic context and the development of international trade relations, it is important that the European Union strengthens its relations with the Asia-Pacific region, notably through modern, ambitious, balanced and comprehensive agreements with Australia on the one hand and New Zealand on the other. However, I would like to point out that the text reminds us of the sensitivity of certain sectors, particularly the agricultural sector. In this sense, the interests of European producers must be given due account by allowing, among other things, the introduction of transition periods, appropriate quotas or the exclusion of the most sensitive sectors.  Finally, the resolution also underlines the importance of achieving, through these future negotiations, the recognition and protection of our geographical indications.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. The same report recognises the possible adverse effects that the agreement may have on social and workers' rights, but we do not think it is convincing as to the clause that would nullify it if these negative effects were indeed given.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of a draft motion for a resolution opening negotiations on free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand, because deepening the relationship between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region is important for economic growth within Europe. Furthermore, the negotiations on two separate, timely and balanced free trade agreements, which will act as a model for future free trade agreements, are a pragmatic means of deepening bilateral partnerships, with regard to the specific characteristics of economies. In terms of content, the agreement is intended to deal with investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, state-owned enterprises, competition, the fight against corruption and regulatory issues, in particular on the needs of SMEs, which are important to me personally, while maintaining the level of consumer, environmental, social and labour protection.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because it seeks to deepen trade relations between Australia and New Zealand on the one hand and the European Union on the other without warning of the harmful effects they will have on their economies. This agreement seeks to strengthen trade relations to alleviate the diversionary effect that the recent trans-Pacific partnership may have. However, we believe that this agreement can have a deadly impact on our economy, especially on the European dairy sector, a sector which is already suffering from the demise of quotas and which, due to the contraction in Chinese consumption, will be flooded with the New Zealand surplus. This liberalizing agenda of international trade that takes place for the benefit of multinationals without taking into account the real effect it will have on the real economy is at the origin of many of our economic problems. That is why I have decided to vote against this motion for a resolution.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report voted on today provides the European Parliament's position on the opening of negotiations for free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand.  The European Union enters into agreements and maintains relations with a large number of partners with a view to promoting growth and employment in Europe by opening up new markets with the rest of the world. Australia and New Zealand are a key component in relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region, so I believe that the expansion and deepening of trade relations with these two countries will lead to a strengthening of European trade policy in that region, with mutual benefits both in terms of market access, especially for SMEs, and in terms of sustainable development and investment.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The opening of negotiations on a possible free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand requires a balanced approach in the agricultural sector to ensure that European producers are looking after them.  The European Union should defend the quality names characteristic of European products, as well as the rules on sanitary and phytosanitary health.  New Zealand is a highly competitive country in the milk sector, being a determining player in the formation of world prices and exporting about 90% of its production. The European milk sector is experiencing a serious crisis and, in this process, guarantees of its defence must be given.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The peoples of Australia and New Zealand share a lot of cultural and economic ties with Europe. And I would like to see the strengthening of ties of the Anglophone peoples of the world with the EU and join my S&D colleagues in calling for strong trade and sustainable development chapters in any newly-launched trade negotiations with these countries.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I consider it important to deepen relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region. Close cooperation with this regional grouping is also important for economic growth in Europe. Australia and New Zealand are key partners in the region. For this reason, I voted in favour of starting negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I have decided to abstain from this Report, and this reasoning for voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The deepening of relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for economic growth in Europe is significant, which is why this is also reflected in the European Union's trade policy. The full potential of the Union's bilateral and regional cooperation strategy can only be exploited by concluding quality free trade agreements with both Australia and New Zealand in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit, without under any circumstances jeopardizing or diverting resources and attention from the ambition to make multilateral progress or implementing already concluded bilateral and multilateral agreements. The agreements between the three developed economies must meaningfully address investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, state-owned enterprises, competition, the fight against corruption, regulatory issues, technological research, the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, but also others such as environmental protection and consumer protection.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners. They share the same values and are committed to increasing prosperity and security within a world-based system based on rules. Both fully respect the rule of law and currently have consistent respect for environmental protection and the protection of human and social rights and workers' rights.  On 30.7.2014, the EU concluded negotiations on a partnership agreement with New Zealand on relations and cooperation and 22.4.2015 negotiations on a framework agreement with Australia. The motion for a resolution concerns the conclusion of free trade agreements between the EU and Australia and New Zealand. In particular, those agreements should deepen trade and investment relations.  However, there are major concerns about these agreements and what impact they would have on the European economy and, above all, on agriculture. It is a very sensitive sector, which would require taking into account the interests of all European producers, which has not yet taken place. Australia and New Zealand have also been involved in the recently concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership negotiations and the regional economic partnership negotiations taking place in East Asia, bringing together the most important trading partners.  In view of the increased doubt and the dominance of the possible negative effects of the proposed agreements, I voted against the motion for a resolution in plenary.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. ALFA is committed to free trade. Free trade helps both sides by raising comparative cost advantages and is a win-win for consumers in particular.  Australia and New Zealand are countries with a very similar cultural background to the EU countries. Both countries have been reliable partners in the past. Similar approaches can also be seen in regulation, so I hope that a fair and comprehensive treaty will be achieved.  I therefore agree with the opening of negotiations on the free trade agreement.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ The EU itself is built on the idea of free trade within the free market, so it is natural to conclude agreements with third countries. Free trade is the best way to increase the prosperity of the population as a whole. The forthcoming free trade area agreements with Australia and New Zealand will certainly bring a number of new business opportunities and jobs, but they will also strengthen mutual relations.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners, share the same values and are committed to promoting prosperity and security globally under a rules-based system. The EU, Australia and New Zealand work together to address common challenges related to a number of different problems and work together in several international for a. Holding negotiations on two separate, modern, ambitious, uniform and comprehensive free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand in line with the specific characteristics of these economies is a pragmatic way of strengthening bilateral partnerships and further strengthening already established bilateral trade and investment relations. The agreements should take full account of the needs and interests of SMEs in terms of facilitating market access in order to create concrete business opportunities. I also think that the sustainable development chapter is important to cover in the free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand and that is why I supported it.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Australia and New Zealand are among the Oldest and Closest Partners of the European Union who have the same values and are equally committed to promoting prosperity and security globally. All three sides work together to address common challenges and work together on several international for a. Australia and New Zealand are two of only six WTO Member States that do not have preferential access to the EU market. The two countries fully respect the rule of law and strongly protect the environment and human, social and labour rights. The EU is the third most important trading partner of both Australia and New Zealand. The full potential of the European Union strategy for bilateral and regional cooperation can be realised if quality free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand are concluded. Also, possible agreements should take full account of the interest of SMEs. I support the proposals expressed in this motion for a resolution, as I think it is important to strengthen relations between the European Union and the Asia-Pacific region for Europe's economic growth. I believe that Australia and New Zealand are instrumental in this strategy and strengthening trade with new partners can contribute to achieving this goal.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution to the oral question on the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand.  I support strengthening and upgrading relations between the European Union and Australia and New Zealand, which are regarded as one of the EU's oldest and closest partners. As the report rightly observes, deepening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region will have a positive impact on economic growth in Europe, and this fact should be taken into account in the European Union's trade policy.  Australia and New Zealand are a key part of this strategy and the expansion and deepening of trade with them as partners will contribute to achieving this goal.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution opening negotiations on a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand. The European Parliament stresses the importance of strengthening relations between the Union and the Asia-Pacific region. These proposals should bring enlargement and development to all three parties in the areas of investment, trade and service provision, energy, the public market, health, technological research. Furthermore, the negotiation of the contract will have a positive impact on consumer protection (e.g. food safety), environmental protection (e.g. protection of animals and plants), social protection or protection of workers.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Free Trade Agreements fully serve the intended benefits of the EU's dominant circles. They create interdependence - economic as well as political - with partners and promote extreme competition and investment for the benefit of large capital and at the expense of the interests of society and peoples. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We do not believe in the merits of free trade agreements and reject the proposal to open negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. The conclusion of the EU-Australia and EU-New Zealand free trade agreements will change mutual trade and investment relations, particularly in the agricultural and livestock sectors, with market consequences and potential risks to European economic operators.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I unreservedly supported the adoption of the report on the European Ombudsman's activities in 2014, because it reflects the valuable contribution of the Ombudsman re-elected that year to a more open, citizen-friendly European Union. The European Ombudsman's activities have clearly become more active during the reporting period, particularly in the area of own-initiative inquiries. As a Member, I consider it particularly important and will monitor your work recently and in the future on the issues of protecting the rights of migrants, introducing operating conditions and mandatory registers of EU lobbyists, and managing EU-funded funds and projects.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners, sharing common values with the Union and engaging in promoting global security and prosperity. Unfortunately, despite such close relations, the European Union has so far not concluded any bilateral trade agreement with the two world's leading economies. However, in its new trade and investment strategy 'Trade for All', the European Commission has identified the need to open negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. There is no doubt that an ambitious agreement, in addition to increasing trade and creating new investment, will clearly contribute to economic growth and job creation in Europe in the long term.  In its resolution, the European Parliament called on the European Commission to take action to negotiate a solid and ambitious agreement that will bring significant benefits to European citizens and businesses. In addition, the document states that the agreement should include arrangements for the protection of sensitive EU sectors while protecting European standards. The European Commission is now expected to carry out a comprehensive assessment of the impact of possible agreements on the European economy as soon as possible and to ask the Council for a negotiating mandate to start talks with Australia and New Zealand.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the opening of free trade agreement negotiations with Australia and New Zealand is very important for economic growth in the European Union, particularly from the point of view of small and medium-sized enterprises. Australia and New Zealand are two of the six WTO member states with which the EU does not have a valid free trade agreement. Australi, New Zealand, Japan and the USA are cooperating with each other within the framework of free trade agreements. The EU cannot opt out of this cooperation without taking into account all the key economies in the world.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. On the face of it, the opening of these free trade negotiations is not a problem. However, they must remain strictly commercial so that our European standards are not questioned and that, in the end, under the pretext of hypothetical gains, the rights of European citizens are not de-decoupled.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the launch of negotiations for free-trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. If concluded this agreement would help to optimise the growth potential stemming from strengthening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region. But the text adopted underlines that any agreement must address, ‘in a meaningful way’, investment, the trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, energy, state-owned enterprises, competition, anti-corruption, regulatory issues such as sanitary and phytosanitary barriers, technology research and, in particular, the needs of SMEs. The text also calls for a separate chapter to take account of the needs of SMEs with regard to market access facilitation issues, and for the inclusion of a ‘robust and ambitious’ chapter on sustainable development, covering core labour standards, the four ILO priority governance conventions and multilateral environmental agreements. Finally in a context of high tension in the agricultural sector in Europe, the text we adopted stresses that the final outcomes in agriculture and fisheries must give due consideration to the interests of all European producers (in particular in the meat, dairy, sugar, cereal and textile sectors), including those in the outermost regions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The EU, Australia and New Zealand are partners that have similar beliefs and share many common values and interests, are committed to promoting prosperity and security globally under a rules-based system, and agree on key global issues such as human rights, security, development and environmental protection. The importance of strengthening relations with these countries is unquestionable, as this will ultimately also be reflected in the European Union's trade policy. Australia and New Zealand are instrumental in this strategy, and expanding and strengthening trade with these partners can contribute to achieving this goal, namely the economic strengthening of all member states. So I voted positively. But what we must not ignore is the signing of the Trans-Pacific Agreement between the US and pacific rim countries and China's growing trade presence in that part of the world. It is therefore necessary to open negotiations as soon as possible so that the EU remains a global player in relation to the 12 countries of the recently signed Trans-Pacific Agreement and that any ECONOMIC losses of the EU are as small as possible.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the resolution on the opening of negotiations for a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand.  Deepening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region is very important for economic growth in Europe. Australia and New Zealand are a key part of the EU's growth strategy. The negotiations on two separate, modern, ambitious, balanced and comprehensive free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand must be in line with the specific characteristics of these economies and allow for the deepening of bilateral partnerships in a pragmatic manner.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it supports the opening of a free trade agreement which can only push for the deepening of the current neoliberal model and its contradictions. The same report recognises the possible adverse effects that the agreement may have on social and workers' rights, but we do not think it is convincing as to the clause that would nullify it if these negative effects were indeed given.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the high competitiveness of the Australian and New Zealand agricultural sectors, particularly in livestock, milk and cereals, it is quite dangerous to open free trade negotiations with these two countries. This could end up killing French livestock and the French dairy sector, already very fragile sectors.  So I'm voting AGAINST.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Australia and New Zealand are among the EU's oldest and closest partners, share common values with EU values and are committed to promoting prosperity and security globally within a rules-based system. I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. The Commission’s announcement in its new ‘Trade for All’ Strategy of starting negotiations with Australia and New Zealand is also entirely incongruent with the general idea of the Commission to strengthen multilateral trade rules. Moreover, FTAs with these two countries increase the difficulties of the fragile European dairy and meat markets.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome Australia's and New Zealand's strong and continued commitment to the multilateral trade agenda.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the opening of FTA negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. The resolution underlines the importance of deepening relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region for economic growth within Europe and stresses that the full potential of the Union cooperation strategies can only be realised by concluding high-quality FTAs with both Australia and New Zealand. The agreements between the three economies should address many important sectors such as investment, trade, public procurement, energy, competition, anti-corruption, regulatory issues, technology research and, especially, the needs of SMEs. The agreements help develop the significant market potential of the EU and could serve as an example for future free trade agreements.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe must continue to deepen relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region to promote its economic growth in Europe. In this context, Australia and New Zealand are constituted as strategic partners, so the promotion of dialogue and negotiations is necessary to improve existing bilateral agreements. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of opening these negotiations.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ While there remains much to be done in negotiations with New Zealand and Australia in the area of FTAs, particularly in relation to agriculture, I was happy to vote in favour of opening negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. These two countries represent an important market for EU nations, but are also vital international partners across a range of issues, and it makes a lot of sense to integrate them with Europe through the medium of free trade agreements. I hope that these negotiations are conducted in a spirit of compromise so that a deal can be found that is mutually beneficial to all parties.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'It is in the interests of the European economy that we strengthen ties with Australia and New Zealand and promote free trade with these two countries. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. While Australia and New Zealand have just signed the Trans-Pacific Partnership establishing a free trade area with the United States, Canada and Japan, the European Union has called for negotiations for a free trade agreement with these countries. This resolution is in favour of opening these negotiations and stresses in particular "the importance of strengthening relations between the Union and the Asia-Pacific region for European economic growth", even though trade with the area is far from being one of the EU's main partnerships. In reality, it is always the obsession with building a large market to impose free trade agreements and competition in ever-widening geographical areas. The GUE/NGL group had tabled amendments to obtain a minimum number of guarantees for the protection of social, environmental and human rights standards. These amendments were rejected.  Against the principle of free trade agreements, which no longer even need to be demonstrated the damage wherever they are implemented, and whatever the partners, I voted against the commitment of this type of negotiation which privileges the interests of multinationals at the expense of the people and especially of employees all over the world.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Australia and New Zealand are parties to the recently concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) negotiations and the current negotiations on the Comprehensive Regional Economic Partnership (RCEP) in East Asia. The agreements aim to cover investment, trade in goods and services, e-commerce, public procurement, the energy sector, public enterprises, sanitary and phytosanitary regulations and technology research and aim, of course, to impose the ISDS (Invester to State Dispute Settlement) system. If these agreements are made, trade treaties to which we oppose it will be profiled and that we call for an immediate end to the negotiations, because they call into question the most basic democratic rights, such as public services, but also the right to work with rights and the sovereignty of the States.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Free trade agreements among equally developed countries are not a bad thing in principle. But the impact must first be analysed. The crucial question is whether the European economy would benefit from such an agreement. This question has not yet been answered conclusively, so I abstained.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the EP resolution on the opening of negotiations for Free Trade Agreements (ALS) with Australia and New Zealand. In the resolution, the rapporteurs consider that the potential of the Union's bilateral and regional cooperation strategies can only be achieved in its entirety by concluding high-quality FTAs with both Australia and New Zealand. I agree with their view that the negotiation of modern, ambitious, balanced and comprehensive FTAs with Australia and New Zealand, depending on the specific features of their economies, is a pragmatic way of deepening bilateral partnerships and strengthening existing, existing, mature bilateral trade and investment relations, while also helping to mitigate the potential diversion effects of the recently concluded TPP.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Removing barriers to international trade is undoubtedly a good trend that contributes to economic growth and closer cooperation between the European Union and other world economies. In this context, the conclusion of a free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand, taking into account the interests of both parties, seems necessary and justified.  Despite their geographical location, both Australia and New Zealand are free-market countries with a long democratic tradition and a modern legal system guaranteeing the protection of their commitments. Both countries are participants in multilateral discussions on the liberalisation of trade in services and are an important link in the emerging Asia-Pacific free trade area integrating the countries of the Americas and East Asia. They are therefore important partners for the world's largest economies and the European Union should also be open to closer trade with these countries.  Of course, giving a mandate to the European Commission is not unconditional and mentions the expectations that the European Parliament has for future negotiations. Among these demands, it is necessary to emphasise the need for the negotiations to be as transparent as possible, the need to take into account in the discussions the specific role of European agriculture and its sensitivity to the rapid increase in imports from outside the EU, and the need to guarantee EU citizens the highest standards in terms of personal data protection, intellectual property and phytosanitary legislation. The adopted report shall take these issues into account.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the opening of free trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand, as I believe that the agreement would further strengthen trade and investment relations and cooperation on international standards without commenced consumer, environmental and social and labour rights protection. This step will have a positive impact on economic growth in the EU and represents a success for the EU's trade policy in the Asia-Pacific market.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – Pets make their owners happy every day and are surrounded with the best care. Unfortunately, however, more and more animals are also victims of illegal commercial practices, with detrimental consequences for their welfare. We must stop these practices. The identification and registration of pet animals is an essential tool. Flanders is one of the leaders in Europe in terms of the registration of dogs and cats. This not only allows us to bring stray animals back to their owners and thus to tackle the problem of stray animals, but also to dry up that illegal trade. But that trade doesn't stop at the borders. That is why my party, the N-VA, has long been calling for more European action. Although many Member States have mandatory registration systems for pets, there are major differences. The demand for better coordination is therefore a strong and necessary signal from Parliament to reduce this illegal trade in the interests of animal welfare.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I supported this motion for a resolution and I am very glad that we have adopted a declaration today that will lead to the creation of uniform registers of cats and dogs in Europe. This will significantly help in the fight against smuggling, illegal trade and, in general, cruelty to these animals.  For me, this is not another bureaucracy, for me it is the protection of animals and cats, which today, especially unfortunately in Central Europe, are artificially illegally multiplied in so-called multipliers and then smuggled into Western Europe. These are not unique phenomena, they are tens of thousands of dead animals that are born, raised and then taken to Western Europe every year in harsh conditions.  If animals are registered, then the trade in animals as living creatures will be given clear rules and we will, at least I hope, treat animals as living creatures, not just as commodities and goods.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Pets are an integral part of our lives. These are our home pets, sometimes our friends, mates, allies. Lonely people maybe it's the only friend he can have. And clearly, some people in their homes there not only cats and birds, but also hamsters, rats, guinea pigs. There are cases where people also hold crocodiles and snakes, but still, if we talk about the most common variants of pet animals – dogs and cats – it is long overdue to harmonise the maximum, standardise the maximum existing registration systems in all our Member States, because this would not only help to facilitate transport across borders, but would also contribute to the fight, including against animal smuggling, as we know that this problem exists in the European Union and it is extremely important.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Animal mobility is linked to people's mobility. In addition to the normal transport of pet animals in the Schengen area, numerous non-governmental organisations have highlighted the illegal trafficking of pets. In order to harmonise European legislation on the transport of pet animals and to protect the health of citizens and animals, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This motion for a Resolution focuses on the homogenisation of the criteria for the registration of domestic animals, as well as requesting the Commission to put in place measures to end the illegal trafficking of such animals. I supported this motion for a Resolution as I support the obligation to identify and register pets to prevent abuse and abandonment of domestic animals, for public health reasons and to avoid abusive practices among breeders. I also support the establishment of common criteria for raising and selling domestic animals to ensure minimum welfare conditions and to prevent illegal trafficking in them, often linked to organised crime. For all this, I voted for it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States. Drawing on numerous sources, this text states that the illegal trade in animals is the third largest in the world. In addition, the health aspect is mentioned since it is proven that the majority of sick animals are from the illegal trade and that the majority of diseases that have emerged in recent years are primarily animal diseases. Introducing compatible registration systems to all Member States is therefore a good initiative both from a health point of view and from an animal point of view. Moreover, this interstate cooperation is between sovereign nations, which I support.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution aims to introduce compatible systems for the registration of pets between EU Member States.  Although there is a general consensus among EP political groups on the need to record and identify pets throughout Europe, the EP Group of Socialists and Democrats wants the decision to focus more on combating the growing illegal trade in pet animals by strengthening existing legislation and the pet travel system.  The proposal by the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats, which I voted in favour of, calls on the Member States to improve the interaction and compatibility of their recording and identification systems so that there is greater traceability and a reduction in illegal trade.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this non-legislative resolution, Parliament wants to ensure that the national databases for the registration of dogs and cats are compatible with each other. Among other things, this is intended to prevent the illegal trade in pets, which is increasingly associated with organised crime. I voted in favour of the text because I agree that mandatory registration of dogs and cats can not only reduce document counterfeiting and illegal trade, but also constitutes a measure promoting animal welfare.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution refers to a wide range of references, not strictly at the Community level, and is based on several observations; first, the increase in pet trafficking, which would be the third most lucrative after drugs and weapons;  second, the fact that the majority of sick animals are from the illegal trade, and that the antibiotics provided strengthen their antimicrobial resistance; and that most of the diseases that have emerged in recent decades are animal diseases that have mutated to pass on to humans. This text then sets timid milestones for considering the compatibility of registration systems in all Member States; It is now clear that a pet registered in one Member State and lost in another cannot be found by its owner, due to the lack of compatibility of registration systems in all Member States. So I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support animal welfare. I do not want the EU to produce a single framework for the registration of pet animals in the EU as I believe national parliaments should decide if and how to legislate on this matter.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the registering of pet animals across the EU Member States. Not only because illegal trade of animals poses serious risks to public health, or because it is a significant source of revenue for the mafia, but mostly because of the wellbeing of these animals.  For this same reason I voted in favour of amendment four. This amendment recognises that poor socialisation and habituation are among the leading factors in the behavioural problems of pets, such as separation issues or fear of everyday objects, and pose a long-term threat to animal welfare. I voted in favour of both parts of recital G as well, since this would be an important step towards compulsory identification and registration of dogs and cats in an appropriate database, which will be linked to an EU database. This recital allows traceability of the animals to help protect their health and welfare, public health and improve consumer protection. I sincerely care for these animals and I believe that this registration will help protect them and their wellbeing.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to strengthen the fight against the illegal trade in animals. Animals entering the illicit trade are often poorly cared for and at higher risk of disease. As many as 70% of the new diseases that have sick people in recent decades are of animal origin. The proposal aims to encourage eu countries to exchange data on the registration of dogs and cats. Many EU countries already have mandatory systems for the identification and registration of pets, but the information they collect differ. It is therefore essential to harmonise the databases for the registration of dogs and cats in all EU countries and to include other pets in the long term. This will reduce the scope of document fraud and illegal trade in animals, as well as identify sources of outbreak of animal diseases and respond more effectively to the mistreatment of domestic animals.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion seeks to draw attention to the poor conditions in which pets are placed under the current system. It would be an important step to promote maximum application of animal welfare aspects if the Commission adopted a regulation on animal diseases and established a complex pet registration system, also in the framework of a delegated act. A clear advantage of a complex register would be that it would allow for the prevention of the spread of communicable diseases attacking such animals and the localisation of the infectious source, and on the other hand would allow for the coordination of the various official carnets issued to the animals by Member States and for better traceability of the passports of the animals. The current animal passport legislation includes loopholes that allow the black economy to take advantage of passports to trade pets from one Member State to another. This market generates billions of euros in annual revenue for the black economy, while at the same time seriously endangering the genetic deterioration of farmed domestic animals and the animal welfare of individual animals. It is important that, by eliminating loopholes, there is a regulation that allows for the verification of the origin of the animals and the recording of their veterinary data, thanks to the complex register. On the basis of the fore, I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The text is based on several observations: first, the increase in the trafficking of pets, which would be the third most lucrative trafficking after drugs and weapons; second, the fact that the majority of sick animals are from the illegal trade, and that the antibiotics provided also strengthen their antimicrobial resistance; and that most of the diseases that have emerged in recent decades are animal diseases that have mutated to pass on to humans. This text then sets timid milestones for considering the compatibility of registration systems in all Member States. The fact is that a pet registered in one Member State and lost in another cannot be found by its owner, due to the lack of compatibility of the registration systems. Interstate compatibility is a matter of this beneficial cooperation between sovereign nations that I call for: that is why I supported this joint resolution.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this joint resolution calling for the implementation of a compatible system for identifying and registering pets throughout the Union, which will not only combat the illegal trade in animals but also identify the origin of outbreaks of disease or combat animal abuse.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution introducing compatible systems for the registration of pet animals in the Member States. At present, several European countries have mechanisms for the registration and identification of pet animals, but most of these databases are not yet compatible. This blocking of the flow of information raises a problem of limited traceability, especially when movements within the Union. The failure to properly ascertain information on animals is an important factor hindering the fight against illegal trafficking. It is precisely the latter, in addition to widespread violations of the transport regime, eluments of controls and falsification of documents, that represent a real threat to the health and welfare of animals and human beings. Introducing compatible systems for the registration of animals therefore means recognising the important role that pets play in the lives of millions of European people and families while ensuring that they travel safely and controlled within the EU.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution proposal to ensure the possibility of travelling with pets under the necessary hygiene and safety conditions between the Member States of the Union, as well as to prevent the illegal trafficking of exotic and wild animals.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this Joint Resolution on the introduction of compatible pet after-order systems in the Member States. It highlights the positive contribution of pets to the lives of millions of individual owners and families across the EU. The improvements made to the travel regime are positive as the additional security elements of the animal passport. And we must also take into account the increase in trade, both legal and illegal, of wild animals commonly kept as pets.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this resolution, which is a real example of what could be done in Europe if cooperation between sovereign nations were given priority for the sole benefit of the citizens of the Member States. The introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States will both help defend animal welfare and the health of citizens. Indeed, it should be remembered that trafficking in pets is the third most lucrative trafficking after drugs and weapons. This illegal trade often leads to sickness of pets, which also poses risks to human health. Making pet registration systems compatible will not only combat these trafficking, but also protect our animals and the health of our families. With the cause of animal welfare at heart, I welcome the adoption of this resolution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the text of the resolution effectively addresses current animal welfare issues such as, for example, the illegal trade in wild animals sold as pets. I consider it important to develop a defined system for the identification and registration of pet animals at European level, in order to fill the current gaps in the relevant legislation, which is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. At the end of 2014, a new Regulation on the registration of pets and the conditions under which they may travel with their owners entered into force, non-commercial purposes (Regulation (EU) No 576/2013) A new passport model for these animals was then introduced and the requirements for vaccines and the need for vaccines to appear on the travel document were strengthened, requirements which also apply to animals from third countries wishing to enter the EU.  In view of the first results of the implementation of Regulation (EU) No 576/2013, I support with my vote the proposals contained in this proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in the Member States.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament notes with concern the evidence provided by non-governmental organisations, law enforcement authorities, competent authorities and veterinarians, which clearly shows that the system of illegal pet smuggling is becoming increasingly abusive for commercial purposes. Parliament is also concerned that there is an increasing number of legal and illegal wildlife trafficking, which are generally considered as pets. Keeping wild animals as pets seriously adversely affects the welfare of the animals concerned and puts human health and safety at risk. This trade has a serious impact on the conservation of the species concerned caught in the wild for commercial purposes. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to adopt strict and effective measures to combat the illegal trade in pet animals, including wild animals kept as pet animals. Parliament also calls on the Commission to adopt without delay a delegated act following the entry into force of the Regulation on communicable animal diseases (Animal Health Act) laying down rules on comprehensive and harmonised systems for the identification and registration of dogs and cats.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The illegal trade in pets is on the rise, with various animal abuses and illegal trade in exotic animal species often linked to organised crime.  I therefore supported the proposed resolution, which opens the way to technically harmonised registers of cats and dogs across all EU countries, and also encourages the possibility of introducing databases for other pets. The proposals aim at reducing the illegal trade in pets and ensuring adequate traceability within the EU.  It should be noted that in many countries there are already mandatory systems for the identification and registration of pet animals, but they are so different that cross-border exchange of information is not possible. I am therefore pleased that we will soon have a harmonised proposal for a regulation on the agenda, which will give the Commission or the Member States the possibility of establishing national pet registers and registering all breeders and sellers of pets, which will have an impact on reducing illegal trade in pet and improving traceability.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution supports the introduction of compatible registration systems for pets. Because of its health aspect and its good intention towards animals, this text is to be supported. Interstate compatibility is a matter of this beneficial cooperation between sovereign nations. I voted for it.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this resolution on the registration of pet animals across Member States which states the need for compatible systems for registration requirements for pet animals for the purposes of the protection of public and animal health. NGOs, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and vets have all given evidence of growing illegal abuse of the Pet Travel Scheme. Such illegality poses threats to public health given the lack of vaccination, veterinary and sanitary care common amongst illegally traded pet animals.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Pets that are illegally traded are often incorrectly reared, have poor socialization and are more at risk of disease. Illegal trade feeds the phenomenon of the flight of exotic or wild animals into an environment devoid of their natural enemies, which can lead to their uncontrolled spread, with harmful repercussions for the environment, public health and the economy. Furthermore, the illegal trade in wild animals is one of the most extensive activities of transnational organised crime worldwide and is a cause of habitat impoverishment and threat of species conservation.  It is therefore important for the European Union to have a common regulation and to embark on a process of establishing a European database of pet animals, with instruments for identifying and tracking animals on their cross-border movements, with the aim of restricting illegal trade and protecting the health of European citizens and the pets they own.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution highlights the shortcomings of the current legislation on national pet registration systems, whose incompatibility has contributed to strengthening illegal trade. The text therefore lays the groundwork for the compatibility of these registration systems, which would effectively combat the development of infectious diseases from these animals. Furthermore, it turned out that a pet lost by its owner in another Member State cannot be found because of the current provisions.  I therefore voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which does not interfere in any way with the sovereignty of the Member States, for which we fight on a daily basis.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Various non-governmental organisations, competent authorities, as well as veterinary organisations have reported increases in the illegal trade in pets, accompanied by numerous abuses in the pet movement system. This misuse of the pet movement system is estimated to be the third most profitable form of illegal trade in the EU, after drug trafficking and arms trafficking. The repercussions on this practice are serious, with negative implications for both human health and pets. Thus, 70% of diseases that have emerged in humans in recent decades are of animal origin, as a result, illegal trade in pets favours the spread of diseases that could endanger citizens' health. At the same time, pets that are most often marketed illegally are reared in poor conditions, posing a high risk of disease. I was in favour of this report because I believe that the introduction of compatible pet registration systems across all Member States would ensure compliance with animal welfare requirements and also limit the risks associated with the illegal marketing of pets.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. There is evidence to show the increasing abuse of the commercially exploited pet transport regime, as well as the growing legal and illegal trade in wild animals normally kept as pets.  The Commission is therefore asked to issue as soon as possible a delegated act defining the rules concerning detailed and compatible systems with regard to the means and methods of identification and registration of pet animals listed in Annex I to the Regulation on communicable animal diseases. The introduction of compatible systems for the identification and registration of pet animals in the EU will bring benefits that go beyond simply combating illegal trade; these benefits include the traceability of disease outbreaks, the fight against animal mistreatment and the response to other animal welfare concerns.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Establishing compatible pet registration systems is a necessity to combat illegal animal trafficking within the EU. Illegally traded pets are often mistreated and do not have the same health guarantees as other animals. In addition, the illegal trade in pets such as dogs and cats is proliferating given the disparities in Member States' legislation in this area. I voted in favour of this text which calls on the European Commission to set up a compatible pet registration system in all Member States.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals in the Member States. The report condemned the illegal practice of the trade in pets, including wild animals and exotic animals, pointing out that the lack of vaccination or appropriate antiviral treatment and veterinary and health care between illegally traded animals increases the dangers of contagion and this often results in the need to treat animals with antibiotics with an increased risk of antimicrobial resistance. In addition, the illegal trafficking of animals is one of the largest transnational organised crime activities in the world. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to consider putting in place additional measures to combat the illegal trade in pet animals and wild animals used as such.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the registration of pet animals across Member States which states the need for compatible systems for registration requirements for pet animals for the purposes of the protection of public and animal health. NGOs, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and vets have all given evidence of growing illegal abuse of the Pet Travel Scheme. Such illegality poses threats to public health given the lack of vaccination, veterinary and sanitary care common amongst illegally traded pet animals.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because action needs to be taken to improve the registration of pet animals in the European Union. Shortcomings are still present in the areas of identification, registration and transport of pet animals, which may have negative consequences on animal but also human health. I also recognise the dangers of keeping wild animals as pets and believe that regulation needs to be improved in this area.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution calls on the Commission to take measures to establish uniform rules on systems for the identification of domestic animals passing through the territory of the Member States. In fact, although some States already have systems for the compulsory registration and identification of pet animals, there are still differences as to the type of information to be recorded and the management of information. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that an integrated system for collecting and exchanging information between Member States can be an important means of combating deplorable phenomena such as illegal trafficking in animals and abandonment.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the motion for a resolution, stressing that non-governmental organisations, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and veterinarians have evidence of increasing illegal trafficking in pets, witnessing widespread abuse of the pet movement regime, avoidance of checks and falsification of documents.
