We note that the abuse of the pet movement regime is now considered the third most lucrative illicit trade within the EU after drugs and weapons, while the illegal trade in pet animals is increasingly linked to serious and organised crime by non-governmental organisations, law enforcement agencies and competent authorities.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that the introduction of compatible systems for the identification and registration of pet animals in the EU will bring benefits that go beyond simply combating illegal trade. These benefits include the traceability of disease outbreaks, the fight against animal mistreatment and the response to other animal welfare concerns.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased to have seen for my own eyes that the EU does not want to impose unnecessary obligations on pet owners, but to respond to an important scientific need: together with people, animals travel around Europe every day, and this can have an important health impact. That is why, of course, this is not yet another bureaucratic process, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Pets are a positive contribution to the lives of millions of EU citizens, and european legislation is already provided for the possibility for their owners to travel with their animals in a safe and controlled manner throughout the EU. However, while many Member States have implemented mandatory systems for the identification and registration of pet animals, there are discrepancies with regard to the type of information held, the animals covered by the identification and registration requirements, as well as the level of governance to which information is provided. In addition, the increasing illegal and abusive use of the system of movement of pet animals, exploited for commercial purposes. I support this Resolution, which call for a system of compatible standards for the registration and identification of these animals, thereby combating illegal trade and even outbreaks of animal disease.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution is based on the fact that non-governmental sources, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and veterinarians are increasingly highlighting an increase in the illegal trade in pet animals. This trafficking includes violations of the animal transport regime, circumvention of controls and falsification of documents. Furthermore, it has been confirmed that this form of illegal trade, which is increasingly linked to organised crime, is the third most profitable after drug and arms trafficking within the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of the creation of a system for the registration of animals on European territory, which will be facilitated by the current presence, in most Member States, of identification systems that will have to be linked to each other.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is ample evidence of a growing illegal trade in pet animals, with widespread abuse of the Pet Travel Scheme through evasion of controls and document falsification. This carries a cross-boarder concern which needs to be addressed by streamlining identification documents for the non-commercial movement of dogs, cats and ferrets. Public health is a primary concern. Improving patient safety and fighting antimicrobial resistance is also something which I support considering that 70% of the new diseases that have emerged in humans over recent decades are of animal origin, and animals commonly kept as pets.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the resolution aims to introduce compatible systems for the identification and registration of pet animals in the EU, seeking to create a common policy to overcome current regulatory differences in Member States. The new systems will bring benefits that include traceability of outbreaks of disease, combating animal mistreatment, combating illegal trade, as well as responses to other animal welfare concerns. I am voting in favour of the important role of pets in the lives of millions of people and families throughout Europe and the advantage of being able to travel safely and safely with their animals.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This motion for a Resolution focuses on the homogenisation of the criteria for the registration of domestic animals, as well as requesting the Commission to put in place measures to end the illegal trafficking of such animals. I supported this motion for a Resolution as I support the obligation to identify and register pets to prevent abuse and abandonment of domestic animals, for public health reasons and to avoid abusive practices among breeders. I also support the establishment of common criteria for raising and selling domestic animals to ensure minimum welfare conditions and to prevent illegal trafficking in them, often linked to organised crime. For all this, I voted for it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although many Member States already have mandatory systems for the identification and registration of pet animals, there are still many differences within the EU as regards the type of information recorded, the animals subject to identification and registration and the administrative level at which such information is held. These differences contribute significantly to phenomena such as falsification of documents and illegal trade. The European Parliament resolution that I voted in favour calls on the Commission to take measures for the identification and registration of pet animals. I believe that these measures will achieve many benefits that go beyond simply combating illegal trade and include the traceability of outbreaks of disease, the fight against animal abuse and the response to other animal welfare concerns.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – Pets are now part of the lives of many EU citizens and families, and animal husbandry is also a responsibility to preserve the welfare and health of animals that make a positive contribution to our lives. Livestock farming is linked to the controlled and safe transport of animals within the Union, which can also hinder the illegal trade. It is regrettable that pet travel systems are increasingly being illegally used for commercial purposes. The improvements to the pet travel system introduced by Regulation (EU) No 576/2013 have brought about positive changes which may be completed after the adoption of the Veterinary Regulation. Parliament's report calls on the Commission to adopt effective measures against illegal trade. It also calls on the Commission to publish the conclusions of the study on the welfare of dogs and cats affected by commercial practices, which can help to solve problems professionally. An EU-wide solution is needed in relation to the systems for the means and methods of identifying and registering pets. Identification and registration requirements for dogs and cats would reduce the level of falsification of documents and illegal trade, improving animal welfare, protecting public health and animal health; enabling effective traceability within the Union; I supported the report in order to achieve these objectives.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The review of pet transport system (PETS) rules under Regulation 576/2013 received broad support in Parliament in 2013 because it clarified the importance of commercial movement of animals and allowed for the introduction of security enhancement elements in animal passports. It has also introduced a new minimum age for the rabies vaccine, as well as new rules for those travelling with more than five animals. Compatible identification and registration systems can reduce the scope of illegal trade in pets and thus can better protect animal and public health and strengthen transparency.  Thus, in view of the forth coming into force of the Regulation on contagious animal diseases soon, this resolution calls on the Commission to consider adopting a delegated act in accordance with Article 114 in order to allow for the introduction of compatible systems for the registration of cats, dogs and other domestic animals in the European Union. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Combating the growing illegal trade in pet animals is an important issue that needs an effective and solid framework in order to be addressed properly. We should seek a system which takes into account and complements the rules that are already in place. We need greater traceability, a system providing an efficient identification procedure. As I strongly believe that the Member States should ensure compatible pet registration systems, which is important in order to tackle the growing illegal trade in pets, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution calling for a traceability system for the movement of pet animals within and into the European Union. We still need to await the outcome of the Commission study into the welfare of dogs and cats in commercial practices to come to full conclusions, but it is clear there are significant public and animal health risks arising from commercial practices concerning these animals. I know from my work with the dogs trust in the West Midlands that they are increasingly having to deal with the fall-out of unhealthy and often emotionally disturbed animals being imported into the UK. This situation is only likely to get worse unless we take action to tackle the illicit movement of pet animals across the EU.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since I believe in the positive effect of pets in the lives of millions of owners and families across the European Union, I believe that owners should be able to travel with their pets throughout the Union, safely and controlly, and in this context I welcome the improvements made to the pet movement system.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, we call for data sharing at EU level on the registration of pets, at a time when health risks are increasing in the face of the large-scale illegal trade in animals from poor breeding practices. Pet trafficking is increasingly linked to organised crime and is now considered the third most profitable type of illicit trade in the EU, after drugs and weapons. Considering that the implementation of a registration system for sellers and owners is necessary to improve the traceability of animals and prevent the risk of disease, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This text on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all EU Member States raises Parliament's concerns about the fraudulent and commercial use of the animal travel programme. The European Parliament has therefore rightly called on the European Commission to put in place measures to ensure that such a system of identification and registration of pets is introduced throughout the European Union. It is important to prevent the falsification of these documents and to ensure traceability in the European Union of domestic animals to combat their illegal trade and help strengthen animal welfare.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although many Member States have mandatory systems for the identification and registration of pet animals, there are discrepancies as to the type of information recorded and the animals to which these requirements apply. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that the existence of compatible systems for the identification and registration of dogs and cats would reduce the possibilities of falsification of documents and illegal trade, protecting public health and animal health and ensuring effective traceability within the Union.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The main purpose of this text is to combat the illegal trade in domestic animals, including dogs and cats, through the establishment of an identification and registration system. That is why I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States. Through this vote, I believe it is important that veterinary authorities monitor the vaccination of pets that are traded cross-border.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. After drugs and weapons, pet trafficking would be the third most lucrative. In addition, it appears that a large number of sick animals come from illegal trade, and that antibiotics constantly strengthen antimicrobial resistance, to the detriment of humans. This text is another step, albeit modest but no less real, towards compatibility of registration systems in all Member States, so that an animal lost in one state can be handed over to its owner in another state. For health reasons, common sense, and in the interests of animals, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution, leading in particular to the problem of public health of citizens and the fact that the introduction of a compatible system for the identification and registration of pets across the EU could contribute to the follow-up of the causative agent of outbreaks of pet diseases, which is inevitably linked to public health of humans. Citizens' right to travel with their pets within the EU must also be protected and, with a common register, such movement would be facilitated.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report underlines the positive contribution of pets to the lives of millions of individual owners and families across the EU, and confirms that owners must be able to move with their animals in a safe and controlled manner throughout the Union.  We are voting in favour of all the reports on proper vaccination, proper identification and registration of pets, as the protection of public and animal health is ensured, as well as the possibility of effective traceability within the Union to eliminate illegal trade.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The resolution calls on the countries of the Union to have uniform identification and registration systems and to apply stricter rules for the handling of pets. Trafficking in animals, including wild and exotic animals, is increasingly linked to organised crime and poses a risk to public health, 70 % of the new diseases that have arisen in humans in recent decades are of animal origin. The obligation to set up an all-encompassing database will reduce the possibility of falsification of documents and help to combat illegal trade, by promoting the traceability of outbreaks and the fight against the mistreatment of animals. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Non-governmental organisations, law enforcement authorities, competent authorities and veterinarians have demonstrated the existence of a growing illicit trade in pet animals, marked by a widespread violation of the system of movement of pet animals, leakage from controls and falsification of documents, and is also associated with serious and organised crime. I therefore agree with the existence of a compatible system for identifying and registering pet animals in the EU which will certainly have greater benefits than the mere fight against illegal trade, benefits including tracing the source of disease outbreaks and combating animal abuse, and other animal welfare concerns.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution calls on the European Commission to facilitate the establishment of a system of mandatory identification and registration of pet animals, allowing access to data of domesticly registered pet animals to obtain a traceability system across the EU, stressing that the personal data of pet owners and sellers should be respected in accordance with EU legal rules on the protection of personal data. It also calls on the European Commission to explore further measures to combat the illegal trade in pet animals contained in the findings of the study on the welfare of dogs and cats involved in commercial practices. It is proposed to harmonise the requirements for the identification and registration of dogs and cats, which could reduce the possibility of document forgery and illegal trade, thereby improving animal welfare and the protection of public and animal health, providing for effective traceability in the EU. Increasingly, pet owners travel with their animals. It is important that they can do this in a safe and controlled manner, taking into account the existence of more than 100 zoonoses in these animals and the risks that arise from them.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. No objections to the agreement.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report calling for a delegated act allowing the identification and registration of pet animals.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report underlines the positive contribution of pets to the lives of millions of individual owners and families across the EU, and confirms that owners must be able to move with their animals in a safe and controlled manner throughout the Union.  I am voting in favour of all the reports on proper vaccination, proper identification and registration of pets, as the protection of public and animal health is ensured and there is also the possibility of effective traceability within the Union to eliminate illegal trade.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the introduction of a new passport model, which stipulates that cats, dogs and ferrets can travel with their owners within the EU if they have a passport that contains proof of their identity and their anti-rabies vaccination, all of which must comply with specific conditions. EU countries must provide the public with clear and easily accessible information concerning the requirements applicable to the non-commercial movement of pets and the rules for compliance checks on such movement. I support the call for an EU-wide database for pet registration, and I welcome the fact that the Commission agreed to carry out a study on the welfare of dogs and cats forming the subject of commercial practices. If the Commission will find evidence that such practices incurred health risks, it should consider additional measures, including the introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals accessible across Member States. I am expecting the Commission to give an update on the progress made to date.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission financed the preparation of a study on the welfare of dogs and cats affected by commercial practices, published in 2015, and the Borderless Schengen Area ensures passport-free travel between Member States, thereby facilitating the unresianted movement of animals normally pets within the Union. In view of these factors, I stress that pets make a positive contribution to the lives of millions of keepers and families and that keepers and their animals must be able to travel within the Union in a safe and controlled manner.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as it is important from a health point of view to have a common register of pets because in the current situation it is difficult to control the spread of a possible epidemic.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, pet animals, loved by millions of European citizens, have been increasingly trafficked into illegal trafficking which not only causes them terrible suffering, but also feeds the illegal activities of many criminal organisations. With today's resolution, we have highlighted the weaknesses of the legislation and indicated the way to ensure both animal welfare and the fight against organised crime, through the introduction of standard European standards on microchips and national registers harmonised at European level.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals in the Member States because I believe that compatible European requirements for identification and registration would be a very effective tool in combating the illegal trade in pet animals and an additional element to guarantee animal health. Indeed, I think it is important for the EU to take action to stop the unfortunately widespread practice of ill-treatment of animals during transport and the absence of compulsory vaccinations, linked to the very serious phenomenon of trade in wild animals for domestic and company purposes. This is often a business in the hands of criminal organisations and puts at risk respect for and success of the important initiatives taken by Europe in the field of animal passports and animal health legislation. I therefore consider it necessary, in accordance with the regulations and characteristics of the different Member States, to bring the information provided and recorded by the Member States on the identification of dogs, cats and pets closer, combating the falsification of documents and allowing the traceability of sales and purchases within the Union.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the introduction of compatible cross-border systems for the registration of pets, as this proposal stems from a demand that I made as a member of the Animal Welfare Group back in the summer of 2014: it is a mandate that many citizens have given me. Dogs and cats often belong to the family, often they are the best friends for children, seniors and people with disabilities – they deserve our protection and our help. Europe, too, can do more than it has done so far: no new laws are needed for this, we can use the current legal framework to achieve much more! One of my goals: a European pet registration according to the Austrian model of success – this quickly reduces the number of abandoned and stray dogs. This is a problem that we have to address in a very different way in countries such as Romania and Bulgaria.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals across the EU because it is key that solid measures are taken to combat the growing illegal trade in pet animals including by increasing traceability. This is vital to stop harmful practices of pet animal trafficking and improve their living conditions.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution proposal to ensure the possibility of travelling with pets under the necessary hygiene and safety conditions between the Member States of the Union, as well as to prevent the illegal trafficking of exotic and wild animals.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States has won my full support. The movement of animals may pose a risk to their health as well as to public health. Animals are also traded. These compatible registration systems will ensure transparency, animal health and public health, and reduce the illegal trade in pets.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on joint motion for a resolution. A positive improvement was made to the Pet Travel Scheme introduced by Regulation (EU) No 576/2013, including the added security features contained in the Pet Passport, and the further improvements which will follow from the Animal Health Law once adopted by the co-legislators.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Pet smuggling is increasingly linked to organised crime and poses a threat to public health. For this reason, we voted in favour of the request for the exchange of data on the registration of pets at pan-European level, thereby further strengthening the fight against the illegal trade in pets which are often bred irrationally and pose a risk to the spread of diseases.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Pet owners should be able to travel with their pets in a safe, controlled manner throughout the Union. However, there are concerns of the illegal abuse of the Pet Travel Scheme, which is being exploited for commercial purposes and also of wild animals commonly being kept as pets. Pet animals that are traded illegally are often badly bred, poorly socialised and at increased risk of disease. A compatible system of identification and registration requirements for dogs and cats would reduce the scope for document falsification and illegal trading, thus improving animal welfare, protecting public and animal health and providing for effective intra-Union traceability. Therefore I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution due to the fact that non-governmental organisations, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and veterinarians have shown evidence of a growing illegal trade in pet animals, with widespread abuse of the Pet Travel Scheme, evasion of controls and document falsification. The abuse of the Pet Travel Scheme is now estimated to be the third most profitable illegal trade within the EU after narcotics and weapons. Pet animals that are traded illegally are often badly bred, poorly socialised and at increased risk of disease.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution to introduce compatible pet registration systems in the Member States, as the number of illegal pet trade has risen remarkably in recent years. As well as posing a risk to public health, pet trafficking is increasingly linked to organised crime within the EU.  In my view, owners should be able to travel with their pets in a safe and controlled manner across the Union and that Member States should harmonise mandatory pet identification and registration systems to address these problems.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Currently, pet trafficking would be the third most lucrative trafficking after drugs and weapons. Moreover, it is worth remembering that the majority of diseases that have emerged in recent decades are animal diseases that have mutated to be transmitted to humans. As such, it is observed concurrently that the majority of animals found ill are from the illegal trade. That is why I consider that the introduction of compatible registration systems for pets in all Member States is desirable and beneficial, since today a pet registered in one Member State and lost in another cannot be found by its owner, due to the lack of compatibility of registration systems. With this in mind, taking into account the health importance accompanied by cooperation between our sovereign nations contributes to the necessary recognition of animal rights in Europe and more broadly to the importance given to animal condition within the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States. The European Parliament wants to combat the illegal trafficking of domestic animals and proposes, to this end, the establishment of a system of identification and registration for all pets. It is also about limiting the spread of disease and better combating organised crime. I therefore support this resolution so that the Commission can take effective action in this area.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. While I am strongly in favour of a ban on the illegal trade in pets, I am critical of the Commission's legal harmonisation through delegated acts. That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Member States should be encouraged to put in place measures to ensure that their pet registration systems are compatible. This would make it possible to trace the movement of pet animals throughout the EU, and could help to tackle the growing illegal trade in pets.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States. This motion for a resolution supports the introduction of compatible registration systems for pets. The text refers to a wide range of sources, not strictly at the Community level, and is based on several observations. It then sets the groundwork for considering the compatibility of registration systems in all Member States. It is clear that today a pet registered in one Member State and lost in another cannot be found by its owner because of the lack of compatibility of the registration systems. This motion for a resolution, by its health aspect and its good intention towards animals, is to be supported. Interstate compatibility is a matter of this beneficial cooperation between sovereign nations.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it seeks to combat the disease-generating increase in cross-border trafficking of pets. It also has the merit of trying to improve the compatibility of national registration systems, which will make it easier for the owner of an animal lost in another Member State to find it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This motion for a Resolution focuses on the homogenisation of the criteria for the registration of domestic animals, as well as requesting the Commission to put in place measures to end the illegal trafficking of such animals. I supported this motion for a Resolution as I support the obligation to identify and register pets to prevent abuse and abandonment of domestic animals, for public health reasons and to avoid abusive practices among breeders. I also support the establishment of common criteria for raising and selling domestic animals to ensure minimum welfare conditions and to prevent illegal trafficking in them, often linked to organised crime. For all this, I voted for it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. Firstly, I do not agree with the EU determining to individual states what the animal registration system should be. Secondly, I believe that this proposal is ill-conceived and gives the Commission too much power to decide further on the method of such registration. Although the proposal does not directly mention mandatory animal chipping, I am concerned that this may be the first step towards its implementation in the future.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ NGOs, competent authorities and veterinarians point to the increasingly frequent illicit trade in pets in the European Union. Pet passports lack accurate information and are often forged. As a consequence, pets to which breeders illegally trade are often in poor physical condition, poorly socialized and at higher risk of disease. One of the biggest transnational activities of organized crime is animal trafficking.  I supported the proposal for a resolution for uniform pet registration procedures, which is important for reducing the scope of document forgery and their illicit trade.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the introduction of uniform EU-wide requirements for the registration of pet animals in the Member States. The identification and registration of animals, together with owner data, while protecting personal data, will contribute to the elimination of illegal trade in animals, their protection and the protection of life and public health.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the joint motion for a resolution on the establishment of compatible systems for the registration of pets in the Member States, because it contributes to the positive impact of pet animals on the lives of millions of individual owners and their families across the EU.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. This motion for a resolution supports the introduction of compatible registration systems for pets. These registration systems would help combat animal trafficking, which is the third most lucrative trafficking after drugs and weapons. They would also fill a legal loophole because, at present, a pet registered in one Member State and lost in another cannot be found by its owner because of the lack of compatibility of the registration systems.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the motion for a Resolution to combat the illegal trade in pets. We must increase the exchange of information in the Union on the registration of cats and dogs to combat trafficking in animals which are often raised without guarantees and which can spread disease. The Commission must ensure that all Member States have compatible databases of dogs and cats and even extend them to other animals. I am sure that the requirement to register pets, coupled with the exchange of information at Community level, would reduce the forgery of documents, help combat illegal trade and animal abuse and enable the source of disease to be detected.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Since 2013, a regulation on the non-commercial movement of pets (cats, dogs and ferrets) has been in place. Nevertheless, the illegal trade in pets is growing and is accompanied by a large-scale diversion of the pet travel program, a subtraction from controls and falsification of documents. However, illegally traded pets are often the result of poor breeding practices, poorly socialized and more at risk of disease. The resolution calls for the establishment of a compatible system for identifying and registering pets throughout the EU to combat illegal trade, but it also aims to prevent disease epidemics and combat animal abuse. I voted for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Pet trafficking is a large-scale traffic. The vast majority of sick animals come from illegal trade. The majority of current diseases are animal at the base, and mutated to be transmitted to humans. The compatibility of registration systems should allow the animal to be found abroad when it is only registered in the Member State of origin. Until now the lost animal could not be found by its owner. This text envisages laying down the first elements of a compatibility system. Being in favour of inter-state cooperation, I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the introduction of pet registration systems that are compatible in all Member States. Since the European Commission funded a study on the welfare of dogs and cats involved in commercial practices, and it has been demonstrated by the competent authorities and veterinarians that there is a growing illegal trade in pet animals, with the widespread violation of the system of movement of pet animals, the circumvention of controls and the falsification of documents, I think it makes perfect sense to approve this resolution.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in order to ensure the wellbeing of pet animals across the EU. By allowing for intra-Union traceability, pets can be transported easily across the EU, vaccination rates will improve and illegal trading of pets can be curtailed.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The Schengen area is of great benefit to Europe's economy, but it also carries risks that have been fully shown in this case. Schengen allows the movement of animals without control. Poorly regulated rules lead to the illegal trade in animals, which in turn results in concerns about the health and safety of both animals and people who come into contact with them. The report that 70% of the new diseases that have been occurring in humans in recent years are of animal origin is alarming. We must ensure that animals are vaccinated and kept under satisfactory conditions. The requirements concerning the identification of cats and dogs should be clearly harmonised. I welcome this proposal as the Commission has sufficiently examined the living conditions of dogs and cats traded.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals across Member States, which calls for establishment of robust compatible registration and ID systems throughout the MS to improve traceability and deter illegal trading.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the subject, the PPE and ECR Groups jointly tabled separate motions, while the ALDE, S&D, GUE/NGL and EFDD Groups tabled their own motions. With the exception of the EFDD, these groups reached a joint compromise agreement on the content of the proposed resolution, which was joined by the Verts/ALE Group. By my vote, I supported the compromise motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution supports the introduction of compatible registration systems for pets, referring to several findings. First of all, pet trafficking is the third most lucrative sector after drug and arms trafficking. Secondly, it was noted that most of the sick animals are from the illegal trade. And finally, many of the diseases that have emerged recently are animal diseases that have mutated in order to be transmitted to humans. This proposal therefore lays the groundwork for a compatible registration system between all Member States. The interstate compatibility, as well as the health and good intention of this text vis-à-vis animals, make us support it.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution, with its sanitary aspect and good intention towards animals, is to be supported. That is why I voted for it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution on compatible systems of identification and registration requirements for dogs, cats and wild animals kept as pets that should reduce illegal trading, thus protecting public and animal health and biodiversity.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I supported the text of this resolution because I believe that a joint approach through the establishment of compatible pet registration systems will help to address a number of problems that exist today. According to expert data, there has been an increase in the illegal pet trade, as well as a number of violations of the pet travel scheme, such as falsifying documents and avoiding checks.  Another problem with the pet trade is that they are often bred in poor conditions, as research shows that 70% of new diseases that have occurred in humans in recent decades are of animal origin and that animals normally kept as pets bear more than 100 zoonoses, including rabies.  The introduction of a single or mutually recognised registration system and requirements would be significant progress towards the protection of animal welfare and the protection of public health.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution deals with the exchange of data across Europe in the registration of cats and dogs. The increasing numbers of illegal trade in pet animals would make it a very important step to implement the exchange of information. That is why I would have voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Compatible identification and registration requirements for pets would reduce the scope of counterfeiting of documents and illegal trade in animals.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP strongly support animal welfare, also in relation to commercial practices. UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, we do not want the EU Commission to produce a single regulatory framework on registration of pet animals in the EU as we believe national parliaments should decide if and how they legislate on this issue.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that the third most profitable form of illegal trade within the EU is that of pets. Despite recent progress, there are still deep concerns that the information provided in the passports of these animals, for which they do not know the city of origin, the livestock from which they come and other important data, increases the various concerns. I therefore vote in favour of ensuring that the disease prevention and control measures laid down in the Regulation on communicable animal diseases are effectively applied and that they promote the traceability of pet animals, their movements within and between Member States and their entry into the Union.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dogs and cats may be moved between EU Member States or imported from third countries for trade purposes or other reasons. These movements could pose a risk to both animal and human health if measures are not taken to prevent diseases from being transferred between countries. Without a system for the identification and registration of dogs and cats, which is accessible across the EU, there is currently little traceability when animals are moved over borders. That is why I welcome the introduction of registration of pet animals across Member States.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the resolution to introduce harmonised pet registration systems for a number of reasons.  In view of the increasing illegal trade in pet animals, EZ Members should exchange data on registered dogs and cats. Illegal trade, including wild and exotic animal species, which is increasingly linked to organised crime, increases the risk of the spread of infectious diseases.  Appropriate action will reduce the potential for falsification of documents and illegal trade, thereby improving animal welfare, protecting public and animal health and ensuring traceability within the EZ.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Illegal pet trafficking is a problem not only from the point of view of organised crime but also public health and consumer protection, as animals can be carriers of hundreds of different diseases that can also be dangerous for humans. Therefore, the introduction of compatible pet registration systems should be a priority for the European Parliament in order to allow not only the addition of safety features to the pet passport, and the introduction of a new minimum age for rabies vaccination, but also to reduce the health risks to animal and human health arising from such commercial activities.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text deals with a growing problem. Domestic animal trafficking is becoming more and more important and, in addition to the problem of dirty money it poses like all trafficking, it also generates a great health concern because the animals victims of traffickers are often sick and mistreated. Improving the compatibility of registration systems can be done within the framework of free cooperation, without undermining the sovereignty of states. In these circumstances, I support this proposal and vote in favour of the text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ NGOs, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and veterinarians have pointed to the existence of a growing illicit trade in pets under serious and organised crime, with widespread abuse of the Pet Relocation Regulation, evasion of controls and falsification of documents.  There are still major problems with pet passport data, in particular as regards how the accuracy of the animal's age data can be verified. Pets illegally traded by breeders are often poorly bred, poorly socialized and at higher risk of disease. The illicit wildlife trade is one of the largest transnational organised crime activities in the world. Owners should be able to travel with their pets safely and in a safe and controlled manner throughout the Union.  I welcome that Regulation (EU) No 2020-2020 576/2013 achieves the improvement of the Pet Relocation Regulation and also applies to the additional security features of pet passports.

name: Joao Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 More and more there is the movement of pets, on the go, with their owners. Such movement must be able to be carried out in a safe and controlled manner, taking into account the existence of more than 100 zoonoses in these animals and the risks arising from it. The resolution calls on the European Commission to facilitate the establishment of a system for registering pet animals and mandatory identification that aggregates data at national level enabling the creation of an EU-based traceability system.  It stresses that the personal data of pet owners and sellers must be respected in accordance with EU legal rules on the protection of personal data. It also calls for further measures to combat the illegal trade in pet animals to be explored, contained in the findings of the study on the welfare of dogs and cats involved in commercial practices. It is proposed to harmonise the requirements for the identification and registration of dogs and cats, which could reduce the possibility of falsifying documents and illegal trade, thereby improving animal welfare and the protection of public and animal health.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ NGOs, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and veterinarians have pointed to the existence of increasing illicit pet trafficking and widespread abuse of the Pet Relocation Regulation, evasion of controls and falsification of documents. Abuse of the Pet Relocation Regulation is estimated to be the third most profitable branch of illicit trade in the EU, following drug and arms trafficking, and illegal wildlife trafficking being one of the largest transnational organised crime activities in the world. NGOs, law enforcement agencies and competent authorities are increasingly linking the illegal trafficking of pets to serious and organised crime, and despite recent improvements, major problems remain with pet passport data, in particular as regards how the accuracy of animal age data can be verified. It is important to point out that pets illegally traded by breeders are often poorly bred, under-socialised and at higher risk of disease, with 70% of new diseases occurring in humans over the past few decades originating in animals. Animals usually kept as pets are transmitters of more than 100 zoonoses, among which is rabies. For these reasons, I support the proposals for resolutions to introduce compatible pet registration systems in the Member States.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the introduction of better, more applicable and, above all, compatible pet registration systems is an essential step in the protection of animal rights, the protection of the environment and the protection of citizens' health. The illegal trade in these animals is increasing, it is even one of the world's most wide-used types of international organised crime. At this level, of course, they are treated very badly and cruelly. Exotic animals that survive transports often end up in unsudent conditions of uneached owners, suffering from climate change, lack of space and social life, which is vital for wildlife. In the event of these wild animals escaping into an environment where they do not have a natural enemy, their uncontrolled spread, environmental and public health may be endangered, and this may also have an adverse impact on the economy. I do not want to question that pets have a positive impact on the lives of individuals and families and their owners have the right to travel with them. However, we must always remember that animals are living beings, not things, and the illegal trade that exposes them to suffering must be stopped.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The illegal trade in pets and wild animals held as pets is growing and may pose risks to human and animal health. These animals, often the result of poor breeding practices, carry diseases that are transmitted to humans; 70% of new diseases that have emerged in humans in recent decades are of animal origin.  That is why I voted in favour of the resolution to introduce a compatible system for identifying and registering pets throughout the Union. Many Member States already have mandatory systems, but most databases are not compatible and traceability of animals travelling in the EU is limited. Such a system would, among other things, reduce the possibility of falsification of documents and illegal trade, identify the origin of outbreaks of disease, protect public and animal health and ensure effective traceability of animals in the Union.   We call on the Commission to adopt a delegated act to this effect as soon as the regulation on communicable animal diseases comes into force. It is time to take strong and effective action to address the illegal trade in pets.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. At the end of 2014, a new Regulation on the registration of pets and the conditions under which they may travel with their owners entered into force, non-commercial purposes (Regulation (EU) No 576/2013) A new passport model for these animals was then introduced and the requirements for vaccines and the need for vaccines to appear on the travel document were strengthened, requirements which also apply to animals from third countries wishing to enter the EU.  In view of the first results of the implementation of Regulation (EU) No 576/2013, I support with my vote the proposals contained in this proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in the Member States.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to ensure the compatibility of Member States' databases on cats and dogs, and to consider establishing databases for other pets as well. I believe that the obligation to register pets and share information at European level would reduce the possibility of falsification of documents, help to combat illegal trade, identify the source of outbreaks of disease and combat animal abuse and ill-treatment. Many Member States already have mandatory systems for identifying and registering pets, but there are disparities in the type of information held or the animals involved. Therefore, all national databases should be made compatible.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that differences in the registration procedures in the Member States do not solve the fundamental problems of animal protection. The illegal trade in animals is flourishing in Europe. This not only harms the animals themselves, but also poses a risk of diseases and viruses spreading. A harmonised registration procedure would allow the traceability of where the animal originated, what its actual age comes from, to understand where the disease could come from and to take measures to control the situation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The positive contribution of pet animals to the lives of millions of people and families in the EU is recognised and, as such, it is already provided for by European legislation that their owners can travel with their pets in a safe and controlled manner throughout the Union. However, despite the requirement on some Member States to implement systems for the identification and registration of pet animals, there are still numerous differences in the applicability of both animal information that is under identification and registration requirements and how that information is managed. Because of this somewhat complex reality, the illegal and abusive use of the pet movement regime has been exploited within the EU for illicit purposes and in the pursuit of easy profit. Unfortunately, this is a reality that tends to increase in recent years. I therefore voted in favour of this report, since the aim of unifying in a single system the rules for the registration and identification of these animals, thus seeking to effectively combat illegal trade and, in many cases, outbreaks of animal disease.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims, through the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States, to combat the illegal trade in wild animals frequently detained as pets.  For example, compatible systems that are demanding in the identification and registration of pets, particularly for cats and dogs, would help combat this illegal trade and allow veterinary authorities to better control pet vaccinations.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution proposal to ensure the possibility of travelling with pets under the necessary hygiene and safety conditions between the Member States of the Union, as well as to prevent the illegal trafficking of exotic and wild animals.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Pet Travel Scheme (PETS) is a system that allows animals to be moved freely from one Member State to another and that defines rules for the safety and well-being of dogs and cats involved in commercial practices.  It should be pointed out, however, that despite the existence of numerous rules for the protection of pet animals, there are still serious problems to be solved, first and most importantly the illegal transport of puppies from Eastern Europe. In Italy alone, puppy trafficking is a real business that handles about 300 million euros per year: eastern puppies bought for about 60 euros have come at prices up to 20 times higher, once their origin from East European to Italian has been transformed.  I therefore gave my full support to this report as it recognises that the introduction of an EU identification and registration system for the pet trade could bring benefits that go beyond simply combating illegal trade, such as the traceability of outbreaks of disease for the protection of public health and animals against the risk of infection and the fight against animal mistreatment.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have been calling for this for a while, and I am happy to see this finally getting into the Chamber to be voted on. There is a need for more compatible systems for the registration and identification of pets. Member States should be encouraged to put in place measures to ensure that their pet registration systems are compatible with one another. Not only would this enable the authorities to trace the movement of pet animals throughout the EU, helping to tackle the growing illegal trade in pets, but it would improve the standard of living for these animals.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because compatible systems for the registration of pet animals in the Member States need to be put in place. Pets traded illegally are often kept in poor conditions, under-socialised and at increased risk of disease. Up to 70% of the new human diseases that have occurred in recent decades are of animal origin, and animals commonly kept as pets are carriers of many zoonoses, including rabies. Many Member States already have a certain level of requirements for the registration or identification of pet animals, but most of them are incompatible and there is no possibility of monitoring the free movement of animals in the EU. Compatible identification and registration systems for dogs and cats would limit the scope for falsification of documents and trafficking, thereby also contributing to improving animal welfare, protecting public and animal health.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems in all Member States. Pet breeding brings joy to many people, but it can also bring worry. Personally, I dealt with the issue of pet dog tagging and registration during my parliamentary mandate in the Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic. It is a certain satisfaction for me that the EP is in a good way towards the idea of registering pets.  The European Parliament's report states that in some EU countries there is worrying ly proven information about increasingly frequent violations and abuses of pet rules for commercial purposes under conditions where animal cruelty occurs. Examples of such practices may be lack of vaccination and appropriate antiviral treatment and inadequate veterinary and sanitary care for animals trafficked illegally. The report draws attention to the increase in wildlife trade and the associated threats to human health and lives. The report states that compatible Pan-European requirements for the identification and registration of pet animals could, on the one hand, prevent illegal trade, animal cruelty and better protect citizens' public health. The EP called on the Commission to take strict and effective measures to tackle the illegal trade in pet animals, including wild animals.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. NGOs, law enforcement authorities, competent authorities and veterinarians have evidence of the increasing volume of illegal trade in pets, widespread abuses of pet movements, avoidance of checks and falsification of documents. According to them, the illegal trade in pets, including wildlife and exotic animals, is linked to serious crime and organised crime.  Despite recent improvements, there are still significant problems with data in pet passports. Pet animals illegally trafficked are often farmed in inappropriate conditions, are not socialised and are more at risk of disease. In doing so, I consider it important to point out that as many as 70% of the new diseases that have occurred in humans in recent decades are of animal origin.  In most Member States, certain requirements for the identification and registration of pet animals are already in force, but most of these databases are not yet harmonised and traceability in movements of pet animals across the EU is limited. I agree that harmonised EU-wide requirements for the identification and registration of pets would be an important step forward in the protection of animal welfare and public health.  For this purpose, I voted in plenary to adopt the motion for a resolution introducing harmonised systems for the registration of pet animals in the Member States.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ NGOs, law enforcement agencies, authorities and veterinarians have seen an increase in the illicit trade in pets with widespread abuse of the Pet Relocation Regulation, evasion of controls and falsification of documents. Despite recent improvements, there are still major problems with pet passport data, in particular as regards how the accuracy of the animal's age data can be verified. I therefore welcome the improvements to the Pet Relocation Regulation introduced by Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 576/2013, including additional safety features of pet passports, and additional improvements that will follow when co-legislators pass an animal health law. That's why I supported this report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ NGOs as well as law enforcement authorities, authorities and veterinarians point to the existence of a growing illicit pet trade. It is estimated to be the third most profitable branch of illicit trade in the Union, following drug and arms trafficking, and that the illicit trafficking of pets is increasingly linked to serious and organised crime.  Pets to which breeders illegally trade are often poorly bred, poorly socialized and at high risk of disease, and cases of sudden pet deaths are known. 70% of new diseases that have occurred in humans over recent decades come from animals due to inadequate care. The Schengen area allows citizens to move freely between Member States, thereby facilitating the relocation of animals within the Union without control.  I support the proposals expressed in this resolution, as I believe that introducing compatible pet identification and registration conditions would reduce the scope of document forgery and illicit trafficking, thereby protecting public and animal health. I also believe that pets contribute positively to many owners and families and could travel in a safe and controlled manner throughout the EU.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the introduction of harmonised systems for the registration of pet animals in the Member States.  Data from a number of NGOs and competent authorities show that we are seeing an intensifying of the illegal trade in pets, widespread abuse of regulation on the movement of pets, avoidance of checks and falsification of documents. As the report notes, the cultivation of wildlife as pets poses a significant threat to the welfare of these animals and the health and safety of humans.  I therefore support the call on the Commission to take decisive and effective measures to combat the illegal trade in pets, including wild animals kept as pets.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, according to official data there is a growing illegal abuse of the pet movement system, which is being exploited for commercial purposes.  The joint resolution put to the vote in plenary notes that many Member States have mandatory systems for the identification and registration of pets and recognises that greater cooperation between Member States is needed to limit the possibilities of document forgery and illegal trade, thereby improving animal welfare and protecting public health.  That is why we voted in favour of the joint resolution.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report underlines the positive contribution of pets to the lives of millions of individual owners and families across the EU, and confirms that owners must be able to move with their animals in a safe and controlled manner throughout the Union.  We are voting in favour of all the reports on proper vaccination, proper identification and registration of pets, as the protection of public and animal health is ensured and there is also the possibility of effective traceability within the Union to eliminate illegal trade.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the introduction of common, compatible pet registration systems. The resolution points out that the illegal trade in pets is on the rise, which involves widespread abuse of the pet travel system, avoidance of controls and falsification of documents. So much so that the illegal trade in these animals ranks third in terms of profitability in the European Union, after drugs and weapons. I consider it an important statement of the resolution that we must also address this issue because pet animals which are the subject of illegal trade are often poorly bred, poorly socialised and at increased risk of disease, and because 70% of the new human diseases that have emerged in recent decades are of animal origin. I believe that the development of a common system will not necessarily be complicated, as most Member States already have some kind of registration and/or identification system, but (nevertheless) the traceability of pet animals transported across EU borders is limited. I agree that compatible identification and registration requirements for dogs and cats would reduce the level of falsification of documents and illegal trade, thereby improving animal welfare, protecting public health and animal health and ensuring effective traceability within the Union.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the resolution to introduce compatible systems for the registration of animals in the Member States. The resolution aims to create a uniform European database for registering and identifying animals, which is also compatible with Member States' databases in order to have better traceability of pets. The existence of a compatible system for the identification and registration of wild animals commonly kept as pets would reduce illegal trade and improve the protection of public health and animal health, as well as biodiversity. A compatible system at European level must ensure the effective application of measures to prevent and control communicable animal diseases. Given that pets are very much present in the lives of many families, the EU has a duty to control and protect them.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has made its point in highlighting the positive role that pets play in the lives of millions of people and families throughout the Union and reaffirms that owners must be able to travel with their animals throughout the Union in a safe and controlled manner. We are generally pleased with the improvements made to the animal travel programme introduced by Regulation 576/2013, including additional safety features in the pet passport and future improvements that will be implemented once animal health legislation is adopted by co-legislators.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which calls for the introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals across Member States. I believe that it will enable pet owners to travel with their pets in a safe, controlled manner, to fight illegal trade, but also to reduce the unnecessary bureaucracy and time delays linked to incompatible registration systems. A unitary system across the EU can also allow the tracing of the source of disease outbreaks and address animal abuse and welfare concerns.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ NGOs, law enforcement agencies, competent authorities and veterinarians have pointed to an increase in the illicit trafficking of pets with widespread abuse of the Pet Relocation Regulation, evading controls and falsifying documents. Worryingly, this abuse of the regulation is the third most profitable branch of illicit trade in the EU, following drug and arms trafficking.  Most Member States already have a certain type of conditions for harmonising registration and/or standardisation with regard to the method of identifying pets, and many of these databases are not interconnected, preventing full traceability in the case of pets being relocated across Member States' borders.  The positive contribution of pets to the lives of millions of individual owners and families across the EU is unquestionable, which is why owners should be able to travel with their pets in a safe and controlled manner across the Union. It is for this reason that it is necessary to introduce compatible pet registration systems in the Member States. Therefore, I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the resolution on the introduction of harmonised systems for the registration of pet animals in the Member States.  The resolution contains, inter alia, recommendations that Union members should exchange data on registered dogs and cats, as the illegal trade in pets is increasing. Animals are often abused, the risk of the spread of infectious diseases is increasing, and the illegal trade in them, including wild and exotic animal species, is increasingly linked to organised crime.  Technically harmonised registers of cats and dogs must be ensured, as these measures will protect public and animal health.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution proposal to ensure the possibility of travelling with pets under the necessary hygiene and safety conditions between the Member States of the Union, as well as to prevent the illegal trafficking of exotic and wild animals.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Most Member States already have some kind of requirements for the registration and/or identification of pet animals. However, most of these databases are not yet compatible and the traceability of pet animals crosses EU borders is limited. I voted in favour of S&D's position.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, there are cases in Europe where pets or pets are kept in poor conditions and traded illegally.  Illegally sold pets are not vaccinated, do not receive the necessary medication in cases of viral disease, as well as veterinary and sanitary care, as a result of which they often have to be treated with antibiotics, which can increase antimicrobial resistance.  These unvaccinated animals are dangerous to humans, carrying more than 100 different types of diseases, including rabies. Seventy per cent of the new human-related diseases that have appeared in recent decades are diseases of animal origin. Eu national databases, in which each Member State records data on pets, are not yet compatible. As a a follow-up, the ability to trace animals moving to the EU is limited.  Support is therefore compatible with EU requirements for the identification and registration of pet animals. They will improve animal welfare, public and animal health protection, as well as reduce the counterfeiting of animal documents and illegal trade.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the non-binding resolution on the introduction of compatible systems for the registration of pet animals across Member States. The trafficking of pets, including wild and exotic animals, is increasingly connected to organised crime and poses a public health risk. The resolution calls for compatible databases of cats and dogs and other pet animals in all Member States. Registered pets, together with EU-wide data sharing, would reduce opportunities for falsifying documents and illegal trade, help to trace sources of disease outbreaks and restrict animal abuse and bad treatment.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The registration of pets is an important tool in the fight to prevent abuse and combat the illicit trade in animals, two activities that often, but not exclusively have a symbiotic relationship. Given the success of the policy of free movement it is only natural that there should be compatible systems for the registration of pet animals across Member States to ensure that there is a proper coherence within our system to protect our pets. Registration closes an important loophole, but without convergence across the single market then the job is far less than half done.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this resolution because I think it is necessary that there should be minimum standards across Europe on how we treat our pet animals. Legislation on and treatment of pets in the EU is very diverse, from Belgian law to the situation in the Romanian capital Bucharest, where hundreds of dogs roam freely. Much can still improve, but minimum rules are absolutely necessary.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. A resolution was adopted in 2013 on pet travel within the European Union, for which I had already voted in favour.  The latter guided the travel of animals with the installation of additional security features on animal passports.  Since then, it has been shown that numerous illegal falsifications have been identified and used for commercial purposes.  Every year, thousands of illegal sales of animals pose a real danger to animal welfare. It is also a public health problem in view of the risks of communicable diseases to humans, consumer protection and the fight against organised crime, which carries out a real trafficking of animals, especially tropical ones.  This new resolution is in line with the establishment of a common system of identification and registration in all Member States.  I voted for this resolution.  However, the resolution urges the Commission to step up its efforts and propose more measures against the illegal trade in animals.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although in many Member States there are mandatory systems for the identification and registration of pet animals, most of these databases are not interconnected, preventing full traceability when animals are moved across member states' borders. In addition, where these systems exist, there are discrepancies between the type of information maintained, the animals covered by the identification and registration requirements and the levels of governance at which the information is maintained. It then proposes that this resolution should harmonise the requirements for the identification and registration of dogs (Canis lupus familiaris) and cats (Felis silvestris catus), which would reduce the possibility of document forgery and illegal trade, thereby improving animal welfare and the protection of public and animal health by providing for effective traceability in the Union. We voted for it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. On the one hand, the resolution opposes the illegal trade of pet animals, which would be supported, but this is to be done by means of delegated acts of the European Commission. That is why I abstained.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the introduction of compatible pet registration systems. In the European Union, we have the free movement of persons without borders, and therefore the number of people who, for example, want to take their pets with them on holiday. However, in view of the possible transmission of various diseases, but also of the growing curve of crimes linked to the illegal trade in animals, it is necessary that these movements of animals take place in a controlled and safe manner. The measures called for by the European Parliament in this resolution are, on the one hand, in the interests of the people of the European Union, as statistically many human diseases are of animal origin and harmonised databases would help to prevent and protect public health more effectively. On the other hand, the new rules would also be in the interests of animal welfare. Unfortunately, illegal trade is associated with a lack of knowledge of the condition of the animals or a lack of care for these animals, which, in the case of traceable movement, could be easier to trace and prevent such situations.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The illegal trade in pets is not, contrary to appearances, a marginal phenomenon. The current national rules on the registration of pets are not sufficient to counteract this phenomenon. The proposed solution aims to better coordinate such systems at European level in order to detect such crimes more effectively. Given that pets carry many diseases, a lack of full knowledge of their origin or age poses a major threat to the health and safety of EU citizens.  The creation of European standards for the registration of pets will bring many benefits in the fight against rogue breeders and sellers who do not respect the rules on proper care of animals. This will also prevent abuse of pets and make it much easier for border authorities to control people travelling with pets within the EU. Of course, the proposed regulations must take into account the highest standards for the protection of the personal data of owners of registered animals and take into account only the information that is actually necessary for their proper and efficient functioning. Recognising the need to tackle the illegal trade in pets and being aware of the risks to public health arising from the lack of control over the movement of animals within the European Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: "After all the criticism that I always express here, let me give you another positive shift. At the request and pressure of many of us, and in the wake of his speeches, I see that there is a shift, as indicated by the Yemeni report. So far, here's the thing. The European Union has always stated that, unfortunately, for reasons that we do not look at, there is a terrible war going on in a third-world country in a miserable situation. That's where the refugees come from, and we have a duty to house the refugees and resettle them, for example, to Hungary. If you don't do it, say my country, you start insulting me. That's been the schedule so far. Now there is a change, please, because this Yemeni report is already going after it, and it is going after the underlying reasons relatively honestly. It begins to reveal, for example, that the military intervention in Yemen led by Saudi Arabia, including the use of internationally banned cluster munitions, has resulted in a catastrophic humanitarian situation. We are now critical of our good friend Saudi Arabia, a good friend of ours – the United States – as well as the arms exports of EU Member States. I think this is the right way to explore the underlying reasons and remedy, not to vilify those who cannot take in refugees from such situations.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
