text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Clearly, Yemen has been the poorest country in the Arabian Peninsula for decades. The revolution that was a few years ago, five years ago, not only did not change the situation, but worsened. And it is clear that, at the moment, the recent intervention by Saudi Arabia, in parallel with Iran's support for religious-related hussites, largely only worsened the already dramatic situation of civilians, because the absolute military activity and its opacity, the unclear routes of supply of weapons to hide there, all this is appalling. Consequently, in order to improve the humanitarian situation in Yemen, it is clear that it is extremely important for the European Union to implement and implement in life the arms embargo against Saudi Arabia. Consequently, I support this document.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen as it clearly and unequivocally points to Saudi Arabian-led military intervention as causing the humanitarian catastrophe. The Saudi regime has used internationally banned cluster bombs and bombed civilian targets, including medical facilities, severely damaging basic infrastructure. Despite the attempts to the right of the Eurochamber to avoid voting on this motion for a resolution, I have strongly supported the same position as we have also contributed to the adoption of an amendment calling on the European Union to impose an embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia for its non-compliance with international humanitarian law. Unfortunately, my country, partly thanks to the very close relations between the Spanish Royal Family and the Saudi dynasty, is one of the main suppliers of arms to the Saudi regime. I will continue to denounce this and hope that this Resolution will help bring this arms sales to an end.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today adopted by a narrow majority (359 in for, 212 against 31 abstentions) in a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, an amendment calling on Member States to put in place a European embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia. Two months after the Paris attacks, I had called for an EU embargo on arms exports to countries linked to terrorism. I welcome the adoption of this resolution.  The Union must go further and systematically stop its arms exports to countries with a direct or indirect link to terrorism. There is also an urgent need to enforce the UN Arms Trade Treaty, which came into force in December 2014. The adopted resolution also calls for the establishment of a humanitarian truce and investigations into accusations of violation of international law by Saudi Arabia and its allies. The Saudi-led coalition's intervention in Yemen, which began in March 2015, has claimed the lives of 6,000 people, half of them civilians. The humanitarian crisis is now affecting more than 21 million people, or 80% of the population. It is essential that Member States, arms exporters, take into account the protection of civilians.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This resolution follows on from the debate held in the European Parliament at the beginning of February. The humanitarian situation in Yemen as it has been shaped by the civil war is dramatic as there are more deaths in Yemen than in Syria every day.  The resolution condemns the actions of both the Saudi-backed coalition of forces and the Huthi rebels With an amendment tabled by the Socialist Group and four other political groups, we call on the European Union to consider imposing an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia because of the possibility that these weapons could be used in violation of International Humanitarian Law.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In view of the deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which is currently being hit by a terrible civil war, Parliament expresses its grave concern in this resolution. The question of a general arms embargo against Saudi Arabia, however, is a real choice between plague and cholera, given the complicated security situation in the Arabian Peninsula. The crimes committed by the Saudi state are, of course, unacceptable. In this sense, I therefore voted in favour of both the whole resolution and the sections stating that arms shipments should not be authorised when there is a clear risk that they will be used to deal with serious violations of international humanitarian law – and this must be monitored accordingly by inspectors. In my opinion, however, the supply of weapons should be allowed for the fight within the coalition against ISIS, because ISIS is, in my view, the predominant problem in the region at the moment. In the spirit of this coalition, I therefore do not consider a general arms embargo to be effective at the moment.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution full of good feelings but which has no idea of the background of the Yemeni case.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Firstly, I note that this is an ‘own-initiative’ report and therefore has very little, if any, actual impact upon the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The proposals contained in the report have no legal force whatsoever. I agree with much of the text of this resolution. I am indeed concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian situation in Yemen. I am concerned about Western – and indeed British – arms exports to Saudi Arabia. However, at the same time I note that this report calls for action to be taken at EU level. This would be a considerable precedent to be set in terms of taking power away from the UK to make our own decisions, both on defence and trade. I do not believe in this principle. However, I do have significant concerns about our own role in the United Kingdom and believe that it should be addressed by the British Parliament. On balance I felt it appropriate to abstain.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen has led to a catastrophic humanitarian situation affecting the population throughout the country, has serious consequences in the region and threatens international peace and security. Since the beginning of the conflict, at least 5 979 people have died, almost half of whom have been civilians and 28,208 have been wounded. I agree with the need to coordinate humanitarian action under the leadership of the UN, and I support calls for all parties to contribute to meeting Yemen's humanitarian needs. All countries must allow the introduction and supply of urgently needed food, medicines and other necessary assistance. I support calls for the EU to effectively promote compliance with international humanitarian law. Saudi Arabia and Iran must resolve this crisis together, act pragmatically and in good spirits and put an end to the fighting in Yemen.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this catalogue of good feelings totally disconnected from the very serious but above all very complex crisis that Yemen is going through.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this joint resolution, which underlines, First, the dire humanitarian situation (21 million Yemenis are in need of some form of humanitarian assistance) in the country since the beginning of a conflict in which nearly 6,000 people have already died and more than 28,000 have been injured as a result of airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition and the actions of the Houthis. Parliament therefore reiterates the importance of international humanitarian aid, underlines its concern about the airstrikes of the Saudi-led coalition, calls on all parties to respect humanitarian and human rights law and the Union to promote these values, particularly in its political dialogue with Saudi Arabia. He stressed that only a negotiated and non-exclusive solution could restore peace and added that all parties should engage in UN-brokered peace negotiations as soon as possible.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation of serious crisis, political and social uncertainty that continues to afflict Yemen is the result of the inability to give a political outlet to the demands for democracy and openness supported by the civilian population. Food insecurity, malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks on civilians, destruction of medical and civilian infrastructure are daily problems generated by the country's persistent state of internal warfare. The presence of a large number of hybrid players at stake does not make it easier to resolve the conflict which needs the cooperation of all the powers in the area, in particular Saudi Arabia and Iran, in order to start the peace process. I signed and supported the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because I am convinced that only a political, inclusive and negotiated solution can guarantee an end to the violence. The EU must work to promote respect for international humanitarian law and to promote a new round of negotiations under the aegis of the UN.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution since I believe that the European Union should promote with determination compliance with international humanitarian law, as provided for in the relevant Union guidelines and that, in its relations with Saudi Arabia, it will prevail the need to comply with international humanitarian law on other (commercial) considerations , geostrategics, etc.) and, if such a dialogue does not achieve results, assess other measures in accordance with the European Union Guidelines to promote compliance with international humanitarian law.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the Members who have negotiated this Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. I voted in favour of it while supporting my group's amendment to impose an EU embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia in view of the serious accusations of non-compliance with Saudi international humanitarian law in Yemen.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Apparently, the MePs who voted in favour of this resolution still did not understand that political problems were not being solved by declarations of good feelings. Although it has the common sense to question the strikes carried out by Saudi Arabia, so does this resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which I had to reject. Tribal conflicts and the country's general insecurity will not be resolved because the European Union is making a big eye. It must allow the United Nations to play its part in promoting the peace process. The dire humanitarian situation - 153 clinics that previously provided food to more than 450,000 children at risk have closed, as well as 158 outpatient clinics that provided essential care to nearly half a million children under the age of five - should not provide a pretext for the Union to override Member States' prerogatives in their international role on the international stage. , and Brussels, for example, has no legitimacy to impose its arms export policy on European sovereign nations.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The situation in Yemen is becoming more dramatic every day. According to the United Nations, 80% of its population would need some form of humanitarian aid and 47% live below the poverty line.  The conflict already leaves behind 2.5 million displaced people, 14.4 million in need of food aid and nearly 20 million who urgently need access to health care. To address this situation, I voted in favour of both the amendment which envisages imposing an embargo by the European Union on arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the Joint Resolution which stresses the importance of preserving Yemen's unity, sovereignty and integrity through the search for a political, inclusive and negotiated solution.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament expresses its deep concern at the ongoing violence in Yemen and its humanitarian crisis, which has affected millions of innocent men, women and children. In addition, there are great regrets about the people who died in the conflict and suffered from hostilities. Parliament also deeply regrets the deaths of civilian and humanitarian workers in Yemen and the blatant indiscriminate action against civilian infrastructure, including schools and hospitals. The European Parliament therefore calls on all parties to respect the human rights and freedoms of all Yemeni citizens and all those who seek peace and carry out humanitarian missions in the country, including workers, doctors and journalists. Calls for an independent investigation into all allegations of serious treatment, torture and targeted killing of civilians and other violations of international humanitarian law and human rights law.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The humanitarian situation in Yemen has been untenable since 26 March last year, when clashes between the Huthi and saudi-controlled government forces began. The constant bombardment of not only the locations of the rebels, but all other infrastructure and cultural heritage has become part of the everyday Yemeni. It is only a matter of time before the latter join the refugee wave towards Europe. Saudi Arabia undoubtedly creates some dirty work behind which business interests are hidden, and Europeans and the whole Of European policy are too lukewarm about these problems. Unfortunately, we Europeans do not understand the way of life in this part of the world, and there is not too much desire for a deeper understanding of the culture and customs of the people living in the area. This is largely due to strategic interests over oil and gas-rich areas, which is also the reason for The Attacks by Saudi Arabia. The situation is much more complex than it is often presented in public, and we need to draw attention to this.  In the context of the resolution by which we are calling for greater engagement from the Commission and the Council in establishing peace in Yemen, I also supported an amendment calling on the High Representative of this EU foreign policy to launch an initiative to establish an EU embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia, which is an eclatant violation of international humanitarian law through its intervention in Yemen.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the beginning of his mandate, the UN Special Envoy, Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed, has taken action to hold UN-facilitated peace talks to mediate in the difficult humanitarian situation due to the ongoing civil war in Yemen. These mediation efforts must be supported because the humanitarian cost in terms of civilian casualties and the destruction of housing and production and trade facilities is now considerable and is beyond the possibility of aid from international organisations. The military response cannot be the solution because all the efforts made so far by both the Saudi coalition and the Houti rebels and their allies have only aggravated the current serious humanitarian crisis and allowed Al-Qaeda and Daesh to strengthen their presence in the area and to increase the effectiveness and scope of their terrorist actions, with obvious negative repercussions for both sides and for the international community. UN mediation is needed for a truce between the parties and an international humanitarian operation to help yemen's civilian population.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution attempts to assess the current situation in Yemen, where community tensions have turned into a very complex ethnic conflict that has led to a serious humanitarian crisis now affecting almost the entire population.  This text is nothing more or less than a chain of banalities in an extremely complex conflict involving certain regional powers, such as Saudi Arabia and Iran. While we are in favour of these States, in close cooperation with the United Nations, trying to calm the situation in Yemen, we consider that the European Union has no legitimacy to intervene on this issue.  So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Final abstention vote. The situation in Yemen is very confused and the parties to the conflict are mutually charged with human rights violations. Furthermore, the adoption of sanctions against Saudi Arabia (referred to in Amendment No 1) is not only illiberal but also likely to harm the interests of our productive apparatus.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The humanitarian situation in the country remains serious: almost two thirds of the population needs aid and assistance. The United Nations ranked the ongoing humanitarian crisis at Level 3, the highest category. 80% of the population, over 20 million people, need urgent humanitarian assistance. Peace talks must be resumed, because this conflict can only be resolved by an inclusive and negotiated political solution capable of leading to the formation of a government of national unity, in order to restore peace and cope with the humanitarian crisis. The European Union must make its voice heard and ensure, working together with the international community, a political solution to the crisis.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I am deeply concerned about the situation in Yemen which does not seem to be improving. The ongoing conflict has a severe impact on the local civilian population, leaving hundreds dead and many more injured. Malnutrition is also an enormous problem, affecting children in particular, who additionally also suffer from limited access to educational facilities. The hostilities are destabilising the entire region and I worry that they may eventually pose a threat to peace and security on a wider scale. I therefore hope for coordinated humanitarian action under UN leadership and a swift resolution of the crisis.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen and I am particularly pleased with the adoption of the amendment expressly calling for the EU High Representative for Foreign Policy to launch an initiative to impose a blockade on the flow of arms to Saudi Arabia. The 5-Star Movement in Europe has fought hard for the adoption of this amendment and this is an important victory that sends a clear message from Europe about the ongoing conflict.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Yemen is the poorest country in the Arabian Peninsula: 47% of its population lives below the poverty line and is characterized by one of the highest rates of malnutrition in the world. Therefore, the conflict currently afflicting Yemen adds to the already precarious situation of poverty in the country, giving rise to a deep and rampant humanitarian crisis that has generated huge flows of internal migration and a sharp increase in the prices of goods of primary need. The figures provided by the humanitarian organisations portray a very distressing picture: there are 2.5 million displaced persons and 82% of the Yemeni population need humanitarian assistance. As is often the case in these cases, children are the individuals most affected by the conflict in Yemen today, with serious repercussions on children's access to education, as UNICEF has pointed out, and the closure of many of the hospitals providing primary health care to thousands of children, who are therefore now in a situation of extreme risk.  I fully share the concerns and demands contained in the motion for a resolution and have therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the motion for a resolution and stress that the existence of a stable and secure Yemen, with a well-functioning government, is vital for international efforts to combat extremism and violence in the region and beyond, as well as for peace and stability in Yemen itself.  We call on all sides to comply with international humanitarian law and international human rights law and to cooperate urgently with the UN and humanitarian organisations to assist those in need.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen is an attempt to express Europe's support for any action to protect citizens' rights and against brutal strategies, policies or practices being pursued.  As we have accepted that the crisis in Yemen is the result of the inability of political forces to guarantee stability and democracy in the region, it is our duty to express sympathy for the citizens of the region, as well as to give practical support to efforts to normalise the problems, putting pressure in every direction to restore normality.  For these reasons I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I believe it is parliament's duty to speak out in favour of a cessation of hostilities in Yemen. The conflict, characterised by a systematic violation of international humanitarian and human rights law, has led the country into a disastrous situation. The high death toll and the social tragedy of the population are combined with the serious damage done to Yemen's infrastructure and historical heritage. The European Parliament reaffirms its commitment to supporting Yemen and the Yemeni people and calls for the deployment of coordinated humanitarian action under the leadership of the United Nations.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to remember that the EU, not being a state, cannot intervene in the situation of other Member States, whatever it may be. However, this does not allow us to close our eyes to the serious humanitarian failings that Yemen is experiencing. I voted in favour of this resolution in order to put some diplomatic pressure on the competent authorities to realise that the problem needs to be resolved as soon as possible. It was all I could do and I did.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Before we seek a closer relationship with Yemen, which would provide for trade, economic and development cooperation, I believe that we need to engage more politically with trusted parties towards true democratic reform. This trust needs to be gained also with countries like Saudi Arabia and Iran, who are mentioned in this resolution as key drivers in resolving this situation. The resolution provides for improved security responding to basic needs which are lacking like water shortage and the need to start to build trust by introducing economic diversification as a stepping stone towards the continuous democratisation process to bring radical challenges for the country. We need to build further on recent cooperation agreements and programmes, but let us not miss the ultimate priority that the EU has, which is cooperation to support Yemen’s policy to promote good governance and to fight against poverty. The recent attack on an MSF health centre in the Razeh district further depicts the pressing security situation which the inhabitants are experiencing on a daily basis. This further reaffirms that the solution to the conflict must be a political one. We need to engage without preconditions and in good faith in another round of UN-facilitated negotiations with immediate effect because the humanitarian situation is of unprecedented proportions.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current crisis in Yemen is the result of the inability of successive governments to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. Unfortunately, this inability has created the conditions for the outbreak of a violent conflict which has led to a humanitarian situation that is disastrous for the population and has posed a threat to international peace and security. The resolution aims at coordinated humanitarian action between all countries, under the leadership of the United Nations, allowing the immediate entry and distribution of food, medicines and fuel and other necessary forms of assistance. It should be remembered that some EU Member States are complicit in this catastrophic situation, as they continue to authorise the transfer of arms and related articles to Saudi Arabia, in breach of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP on the control of arms exports.  I am voting in favour, in the hope that the EU and all Member States will be able to cooperate in ensuring that international humanitarian laws are respected and illegal attacks are stopped, and in particular the sending of arms to Yemen by certain European countries through the imposition of the embargo.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen as it clearly and unequivocally points to Saudi Arabian-led military intervention as causing the humanitarian catastrophe. The Saudi regime has used internationally banned cluster bombs and bombed civilian targets, including medical facilities, severely damaging basic infrastructure. Despite the attempts to the right of the Eurochamber to avoid voting on this motion for a resolution, I have strongly supported the same position as we have also contributed to the adoption of an amendment calling on the European Union to impose an embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia for its non-compliance with international humanitarian law. Unfortunately, my country, partly thanks to the very close relations between the Spanish Royal Family and the Saudi dynasty, is one of the main suppliers of arms to the Saudi regime. I will continue to denounce this and hope that this Resolution will help bring this arms sales to an end.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current crisis in Yemen, the result of governments' inability to respond to demands for democracy, development, stability and security; created the conditions for a violent conflict. The Saudi-led military intervention – including with the use of cluster bombs – has created a tragic humanitarian situation. Since the beginning of the conflict, just under 6 thousand people have been killed, almost half of them civilians, including hundreds of women and children. In addition, the clashes and bombings have led to the interruption of the provision of essential services, increasing humanitarian needs, which now affect more than 80% of the population. We are faced with two types of problem. On the one hand, there is a strong need for humanitarian action, also coordinated by the United Nations, with access to conflict zones, to distribute urgently needed food, medicines and fuel, as well as a humanitarian truce to provide assistance and first aid to the Yemeni people. Secondly, it is our duty to raise public awareness and the authorities of the imposition of an immediate embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia. We believe it is our duty to prevent by any means that private interests can contribute to increasing the suffering and emergency of the Yemeni people.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its motion for a resolution adopted today, the European Parliament expressed its grave concern at the worrying deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The situation in Yemen poses a serious risk to the stability of the region, in particular the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East. Despite repeated calls for an end to hostilities, previous internal conflicts, airstrikes carried out by the Saudi-led coalition have intensified, food supplies have become insecure as a result of fighting and bombardment, indiscriminate attacks on civilians and health and aid workers have been launched, and civilian and medical infrastructure has been destroyed. The report underlines the need for coordinated humanitarian action under the leadership of the UN and urges all countries to participate in meeting humanitarian needs. It also urges all parties to participate as soon as possible, in good faith and without preconditions, in a new round of UN-led peace talks, to resolve their differences through dialogue and consultations, to reject the use of force for political purposes and to refrain from provocation and any unilateral action capable of underpinning a political solution.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Despite UN peace efforts, there is concern that the violence in Yemen in recent months could turn into a widespread armed conflict in which the population, with access to heavy weapons, will plunge into tribal wars reflected by those from Syria or Iraq. Recently, there has been confusion over the government's decision in Yemen - eventually withdrawn - to recognise the UN human rights envoy, George Abu al-Zulof, as persona non grata. Of course, in a broader context, regular human rights violations, including attacks on journalists and media institutions, increasing disappearances, violations of the UN Convention against torture, intimidation and detention of representatives of religious minorities, and the alleged exploitation of children in armed conflicts, are also of concern. Given the content of the document and its content, I made the difficult decision to abstain. I believe that the document should be much more expressive in its content.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As I am extremely concerned about the alarming deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which is characterised by widespread food insecurity and severe malnutrition and indiscriminate attacks against civilians and medical and aid workers, the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure, I gave my support to this resolution. We need to address the unstable situation in Yemen effectively.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A hospital funded by Médecins sans Frontières in northern Yemen was bombed on 10 January 2016; this incident is not isolated and very serious, which has resulted in the loss of many lives and which testifies to the further deterioration of the situation within the country. A political crisis that has lasted for too many years and has led to a disastrous humanitarian situation – just think of the fact that 82% of people in Yemen now need humanitarian aid – while at the same time consolidating the presence of Daesh and other terrorist groups.  The solution to this humanitarian crisis can only be achieved through a diplomatic and political process that favours the resumption of negotiations and genuine dialogue between the parties, under the aegis of the United Nations and in compliance with the parameters set out in Resolution 2216 of 2015. The Union and its institutions must work in the coming months to stop this humanitarian crisis: Yemen cannot become fertile territory for terrorist organisations and the so-called Islamic State.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, we express our deep concern at the ongoing acts of violence between the Houthi rebels and the Saudi-led coalition. In the face of this humanitarian crisis, we call for respect for humanitarian law to enable the delivery of UN aid. Saudi Arabia and Iran, which have a key role to play in resolving the crisis, must find a compromise to end the fighting in Yemen. Considering that this resolution is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution calling for a ceasefire to end attacks on civilians, humanitarian and health personnel, ground fighting and bombings by Saudi aircraft and the Arab-Sunni coalition in yemen. The ceasefire is now more necessary than ever to enable humanitarian aid to reach the civilian population affected by the conflict. I believe that only an inclusive and negotiated political solution can restore peace and preserve Yemen's unity, which is why I urge the UN to conduct a new round of negotiations with all parties to the war.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'The N-VA delegation votes in favour of the amendment calling on the EU High Representative to initiate an EU arms embargo against Saudi Arabia in the event of a necessary violation of saudi Arabia's international humanitarian law in Yemen. We do believe, however, that such an arms embargo should cover actual military goods and not so-called dual use goods.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am extremely concerned about the alarming worsening humanitarian situation in Yemen: the risk of famine, indiscriminate attacks on civilians, including medical personnel and humanitarian workers, the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure as a result of intensified airstrikes and the use of cluster bombs. More than 2.51 million Yemenis have been displaced in the country. 21.1 million people (80% of the population) are in need of some form of protection or humanitarian assistance. More than 2.2 million children are or are at risk of malnutrition. In the face of this alarming finding, I support the call for coordinated humanitarian action under the aegis of the United Nations and a contribution from all countries to meet Yemen's humanitarian needs. I also support the request to the Union to effectively promote respect for international humanitarian law in its political dialogue with Saudi Arabia and its partners, but also with Iran, because both States have a key role to play in resolving the crisis.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text contains many good intentions, but shows a lack of knowledge of the ins and outs of the Yemeni affair. In addition, it tends to impose on states the Union's armaments policy, and to give the latter an unjustified international role. Finally, there is a lack of discernment with regard to Saudi Arabia, a controversial state. For these reasons, I objected to this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, as what is happening in the country is deeply disturbing, but also complex. Security in Yemen is steadily deteriorating and is beginning to gain an international dimension, but at the same time we are witnessing a struggle of interest between two countries – Saudi Arabia and Iran. On the one hand, Saudi Arabia is fighting an open war against the rebels, considering them Iranian combat troops, while Iran is calling for an immediate halt to air strikes carried out by the international coalition led by Saudi Arabia. Despite UN efforts to bring peace to the country, intense onshore fighting and aerial bombardments continue. In addition to the thousands of civilian casualties, more than a million and a half people have fled their homes. If no action is taken and a recent peace is not achieved, there is a great danger that the situation in the country will escalate into a real civil war, and hence into a regional ethnic war between Shiites and Sunnis.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We only vote in favour if Amendments Nos 2 and 3 do not pass and If Amendment No 1 passes. If the amendments are passed by the EPP, we are voting against! If we vote in favour we will do so because this resolution paradoxically adopts a correct and objective attitude, is not directly involved within Yemen and condemns Saudi Arabia and even proposes an arms embargo against it, to which we are in favour.  If we vote against, we will do so because the amendments that have been passed alter the true nature of the resolution and once again serve political purposes and economic interests.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The current crisis in Yemen is the result of successive governments' inability to respond to the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security, creating conditions for an outbreak of violence. Since the beginning of the conflict, at least 5,979 people have been killed, about half of them civilians, and 28,208 people have been injured. In 2015, the EU allocated €52 million in new humanitarian aid to the crisis in Yemen and its impact on the Horn of Africa and will allocate up to €2 million to the establishment of the UN verification and inspection mechanism. I express my concern at the alarming worsening of the humanitarian situation in the country, characterised by a situation of widespread food insecurity and acute malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks against civilians, doctors and members of humanitarian organisations, destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure and the intensification of saudi-led coalition air strikes, ground fighting and bombing, despite repeated calls for a new cessation of hostilities.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The serious situation in Yemen today is inseparable from a process in which foreign powers explore reminiscences, feelings, relationships, tribal and feudal, stumouring ethnic and religious conflicts, generalizing corruption and criminal trafficking, fomenting and instrumentalizing terrorism, always for their own benefit. Imperialism multiplies conflicts in the Middle East which, as in Syria, are causing immeasurable human suffering, destroying countries whose wealth transnational capital is intended to take over. This generally positive resolution identifies several problems felt at the present time by the Yemeni people, but sins for what is absent.  It does not expressly condemn the role of imperialist powers such as the US and other countries whose action has contributed to the deaths of thousands of innocents, such as the bombings of Sana and Aden. It proposes a political solution to the situation but does not reject future external interventions in Yemen. There is no condemnation of the role of the Persian Gulf dictatorships, particularly Saudi Arabia, in the military aggressions imposed on that country. Despite the difficult situation of Yemenis, we have full confidence that even in this tangle of contradictions and conflicts stirred by foreign aggression, the struggle for freedom that the people of Yemen continues will triumph.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it is an abomination that Saudi Arabia is sold any arms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain as the situation in Yemen is very confusing.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The humanitarian situation in Yemen is extremely worrisome, since the delivery of assistance has been impacted by continued fighting. Conflict combined with poverty, forced displacement and rising food prices have aggravated an already serious humanitarian crisis during the last year. I welcome the fact that the European Commission responded to the dramatic deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen with an additional EUR 15 million in emergency funding in December. This assistance will prioritise life-saving assistance in the sectors of health, water, nutrition and food security, which have been particularly affected by the conflict and the collapse of government services. Parties to the conflict have to abide by International Humanitarian Law and to ensure protection of civilians by refraining from direct and indiscriminate targeting of civilians and civilian infrastructure. Especially, the bombing of civilians and hospitals has to be avoided by all means, and represents a violation of international humanitarian law.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am deeply concerned about the violence in Yemen and the resulting humanitarian crisis, which has affected millions of innocent men, women and children, and the suffering of people killed in the conflict and those trapped in the region as a result of the fighting. I strongly support the efforts of THE UN Special Envoy Sheikh Ahmed, Ismaly Uld, for a lasting and peaceful resolution of the current crisis, as well as for all state and non-state actors involved in the conflict, to work towards peace and reconciliation and to participate in this process without preconditions.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because of the European Union's strong willingness to restore peace in this important region. That is why I also voted in favour of an amendment for the European Union to establish an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, in accordance with council common position 2008/944/CFSP of 8 December 2008. The current situation cannot be more dramatic, with more than 5,700 casualties since March 2015. From the European institutions we must contribute to reaching a coexistence agreement to end the conflict, thus avoiding the rise of terrorism in different areas of the Persian Gulf.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because I consider the conditions of the people of the Arabian Peninsula to be absolutely tragic and unacceptable.  The constant and unheeded demands of the Yemeni people for the opening of institutions in a democratic sense have led to the outbreak of a terrible civil war, with very high consequences in terms of human lives and strong repercussions not only for the security and stability of the Middle East region, but also in other hot areas of the planet.   The most dramatic consequences are for civilians who, as a result of clashes between the various militias and bombings, do not have access to essential services and food and are at serious risk of malnutrition, as well as being the target of indiscriminate attacks by al-Qaeda and ISIS terrorists, who have multiplied their presence on the ground.  I stress the need for humanitarian action under the aegis of the UN and for the immediate distribution of food, medicines and all necessary forms of assistance.  Finally, I welcome the approval here of the call for an initiative to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia because of the serious violations of human rights against the Yemenis.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen and a Europe-wide arms embargo against Saudi Arabia, because I realise that it is always weapons that make war possible and cause human suffering, in Yemen as in many other hotspots of the world.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Peace and stability in Yemen are important for reducing extremism and violence in the region. In view of international humanitarian aid efforts led by the United Nations, the EU must make an important contribution here.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution since I believe that the European Union should promote with determination compliance with international humanitarian law, as provided for in the relevant Union guidelines and that, in its relations with Saudi Arabia, it will prevail the need to comply with international humanitarian law on other (commercial) considerations , geostrategics, etc.) and, if such a dialogue does not achieve results, assess other measures in accordance with the European Union Guidelines to promote compliance with international humanitarian law.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Thursday, February 25, I voted in favour of a resolution calling for a ceasefire of attacks on civilians, emergency and medical personnel, ground combat and shelling in Yemen to enable emergency aid to reach the Yemeni people. It is with regret that we note that the humanitarian situation in Yemen is deteriorating severely by the day. The conflict in Yemen has killed more than 6,100 people, nearly half of them civilians, and injured about 30,000, according to the UN. Therefore, a new round of peace negotiations must be implemented as soon as possible. The European Parliament has also called for an embargo on arms deliveries to Saudi Arabia, criticizing its airstrikes in Yemen and the maritime blockade imposed on that country, which have left thousands dead.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. In Yemen, 6,000 people, including 3,000 civilians, have lost their lives in a conflict that clearly violates international law. In the face of this unacceptable situation, I supported this resolution to call for a ceasefire that allows humanitarian access to the Yemeni people and to call on the Union to declare an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the country leading the Arab-Sunni coalition which, since March 2015, has been pounding the population in its schools, hospitals and aid centres. My support for this embargo is in line with the EU's common position on arms exports in 2008. This decision requires Member States, when exporting arms, to take into account the country's respect for international humanitarian law. The embargo should be in place until the end of hostilities and the resumption of negotiations.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of joint motion for a resolution. My deepest concern is at the ability of Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula and ISIS to benefit from the deterioration of the political and security situation in Yemen. The humanitarian situation in Yemen sees around 21 million Yemenis in urgent need of humanitarian aid. Therefore, all the parties should ensure safe, rapid and unhindered access for humanitarian aid delivery to all affected governorates, in particular Taiz.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. In Yemen, a long-running standoff intensified in 2015, when Saudi Arabia, as the head of a U.S.-backed coalition, began bombing Yemen, while imposing a near-complete blockade of imports into the country. This situation has led the people to starvation and misery, while attacks on civilians, medical personnel and humanitarian organisations have caused huge loss of life. This conflict is yet another attempt by the US and its allies to maintain geopolitical control and sovereignty over the region. The EU is also complicit in this crime, which, with its tolerance of the dictatorships of the region and its Member States, which continue to export heavy defence equipment to Saudi Arabia, is leading to the deterioration of the conflict in the country. The serious deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen requires immediate humanitarian assistance, which is why we believe that voting in favour of the joint resolution is the right thing to do.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Yemen has now become a grave humanitarian concern for the European Parliament. Given the serious risk of increased conflict and worsened conditions for civilians, I believe that it is essential that an initiative to launch an EU arms embargo on Saudi Arabia be implemented. The Saudi-led coalition has conducted airstrikes and a naval blockade in Yemen which has destabilised the region, led to thousands of deaths and consequently broken down its entire internal infrastructure. This clearly presents a serious risk to the stability and security of the region, but also presents a danger to the civilian population who now find themselves on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe. Terrorist groups such as ISIS and AQAP have taken advantage of the worsening conditions by increasing their memberships. Cooperation from both Saudi Arabia and Iran is necessary in order to obtain peace in the region. Peace in Yemen is paramount to the security of the Arabian Peninsula region and for this reason I have decided to vote in favour of the motion.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the current crisis in Yemen is the result of a failure by successive governments to meet the legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security. This failure has created the conditions for an outbreak of violent conflict by failing to establish an inclusive government and fair power sharing, and systematically ignoring the country’s many tribal tensions, widespread insecurity and economic paralysis.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is deplorable that Yemen has become the ground for a proxy war between Saudi Arabia and Iran. This conflict has resulted in a major humanitarian crisis with many dead and the displacement of millions. Saudi Arabia and Iran must put an end to this war that has plagued the state of Yemen.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because I think it needs to be acted on as soon as possible to address the current problematic situation that is leading to a sharpening of relations between Iran and Saudi Arabia, where innocent civilians feel the consequences. Children, women and men, the death toll is indeed too great, and it is regrettable that peace and stability in Yemen seem so distant and difficult to reach at the moment.  I believe that stability and security must become the solid foundations of that state, with a government that will be crucial to international efforts to combat extremism and violence in the region and beyond. I also believe that the crisis in Yemen can be resolved in the long term through inclusive political dialogue.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution, like the European Union's "right-of-man" ideology in international relations, is full of good feelings, but has no idea of the background of the Yemeni affair. It does not address the real issues that are shaking the conflict, and removes the many implications of harmful actors in the region (Islamist terrorist groups). It does not raise the decisive role that Saudi Arabia and its allies have in this conflict, and takes a timid stance towards these actors, which are implicitly supported by Member States of the European Union.  So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. I am, of course, opposed to all acts that violate fundamental rights and international law proven by neutral and independent actors. The situation in Yemen is indeed untenable for a majority of civilians and a quick solution involving a political and democratic resolution for Yemen must be found so that civilians, humanitarians and journalists no longer suffer the effects of this war. However, this resolution, by unilaterally and unbalancedly accusing the actors involved in the conflict, unfortunately did not go in the direction of an exit from the crisis based on dialogue between all these actors. This resolution was adopted.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The humanitarian situation in Yemen has been particularly serious since the intervention of a coalition of states in the region against The Houthi rebels. The conflict has killed more than 6,000 people, injured more than 30,000 and 80 percent of Yemen's population is in need of humanitarian assistance, according to the UN. It is important that the European Union and its Parliament are the voices of respect for international law and fundamental rights. However, this resolution was more about punishing and accusing some of the players in this crisis than about actually pacifying the situation. I therefore abstained on this resolution.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this motion for a resolution. In particular, the fact that Saudi Arabia's role in this conflict is not trivialised or ignored has led me to do so.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as it is a clear humanitarian appeal to end the suffering of the people in Yemen.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support this resolution as I strongly believe that the EU can and must uphold international humanitarian law. The resolution highlights that some EU Member States have continued to authorise the transfers of weapons to Saudi Arabia in clear violation of the EU Common Position, despite evidence that these weapons have been used to commit human rights abuses in Yemen. Together with other MEPs, I have also raised this issue directly with the High Representative for Foreign Affairs in a written question and I welcome the adoption of a resolution on the matter as an additional means to build up pressure on the Commission and the External Action Service.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the European Parliament resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen to be a document that it deserved to support and I am very glad that I was able to do so. The resolution criticises the action of Saudi Arabia and the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen, and in particular the fact that the Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen, in which internationally banned cluster bombs were used, has caused a disastrous humanitarian situation affecting the population of the whole country, has serious consequences for the region and poses a threat to international peace and security. Nor has he forgotten the events of January 10, 2016, when a hospital in northern Yemen was bombed by Doctors Without Borders (Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)) and that at least six people died in the attack, ten were injured, including MSF staff, and that the medical facility was severely damaged. I demand that the whole event be investigated, and I hope it's not swept under the carpet. According to UNICEF, the conflict in Yemen is also having a serious impact on children's access to education, with 3,584 schools closed, or one-quarter, making it impossible for nearly 2 million children to attend school, with 860 schools damaged or displaced. I therefore hope that this conflict will end soon.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for resolution calls the EU to promote compliance with international humanitarian laws and to raise a dialogue with the civil society in Saudi Arabia. This resolution calls also for establishing an EU arms embargo against Saudi Arabia since the country does not respect international humanitarian law with Yemen. Only a political, inclusive and negotiated solution to the conflict can restore peace and preserve unity in Yemen. For those reasons I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ We all should be aware that the humanitarian situation in Yemen is very critical. It is an unspeakable shame for humanity for 20 million Yemenis to be living below the poverty line in dire living conditions without access to drinking water, sanitation, education, medical care and essential services. Furthermore, because of fighting and an embargo, 2.5 million people have been displaced internally while around 125 000 Yemeni refugees have fled the country. In this critical situation, the EU, as the world’s leading human rights champion and aid donor, should provide emergency humanitarian assistance to the civilian population in Yemen. Furthermore, together with the UN, the EU should use all of its political and economic capabilities to facilitate peace negotiations. If the EU manages to put an end to the civil wars in Yemen and Syria then it will be a matter of time untilwe find a long-term peaceful solution in the Middle East.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen has killed at least 5,979 people, while another 28,208 have been injured. It is unacceptable that almost 2.1 million people are malnourished, including more than 1.3 million children with severe acute malnutrition. The European Union has already allocated EUR 52 million in humanitarian aid in 2015 and will provide up to EUR 2 million for the creation of the United Nations Verification and Inspection Mechanism (UNVIM) for commercial shipments to Yemen. The European Union finds it regrettable that it has hit civilian targets, including hospitals, schools, markets, cereal warehouses, ports and a camp of displaced persons, seriously damaging infrastructure essential to the delivery of aid and contributing to the serious shortage of food and fuel in the country. We loudly condemn these actions and once again affirm our support for the Yemeni people. There is an urgent need for a political dialogue with Saudi Arabia, in order to enforce international humanitarian law, seeking effective diplomatic action to promote compliance with international humanitarian obligations.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. It is a text full of good feelings, but it has no idea of the background of the Yemeni case. I would like to denounce the postponement of the vote on this resolution, due to a mission by this Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee to Saudi Arabia which was to take place after the vote on this resolution at the first session in February. There is no point in voting on resolutions if we do not even have the courage to defend them against the governments concerned.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.
