text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen as it clearly and unequivocally points to Saudi Arabian-led military intervention as causing the humanitarian catastrophe. The Saudi regime has used internationally banned cluster bombs and bombed civilian targets, including medical facilities, severely damaging basic infrastructure. Despite the attempts to the right of the Eurochamber to avoid voting on this motion for a resolution, I have strongly supported the same position as we have also contributed to the adoption of an amendment calling on the European Union to impose an embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia for its non-compliance with international humanitarian law. Unfortunately, my country, partly thanks to the very close relations between the Spanish Royal Family and the Saudi dynasty, is one of the main suppliers of arms to the Saudi regime. I will continue to denounce this and hope that this Resolution will help bring this arms sales to an end.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the calls to the Commission and the High Representative. Any arms embargo should be a matter for the Member States.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Yemen, the warring parties launch massive and systematic attacks on civilians, as reported by the UN, information also received in the international press. In December 2015, the UN estimated that at least 5,700 civilians had been killed in Yemen. The conflict has led to an unprecedented humanitarian crisis, which has hitherto affected 80% of Yemen's population. The absence of security in rural areas forces the population to support the different tribes, including supporting the way in which conflicts are resolved in the absence of state institutions. Insecurity causes many tribal groups to be influenced by terrorist groups.  I call on Saudi Arabia and Iran, which directly or indirectly support the conflict, to make an effort for peace and reconciliation. This war through intermediaries has serious implications for security in the region.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Yemen is one of the poorest countries in the world with the fastest growing population, which has doubled in the last twenty years. The lack of education with high unemployment, economic, social disparities and religious intolerance associated with poverty have been and are a breeding ground for internal unrest and violence. This facilitates the violent activities of terrorist groups and organisations. As a result of the protracted crisis, Yemen ranks among the countries with the highest number of internally displaced persons. In addition to difficult access to food, the population is particularly at risk from a lack of health care. In conjunction with difficult hygiene and climatic conditions, this can accelerate the emergence of epidemics. The European Union cannot underestimate the situation in Yemen. It must therefore, in relation to Yemen, in particular through diplomatic channels, promote the necessary measures so that a ceasefire is concluded and that the refugee crisis in the EU is not further complicated.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The Saudi-led coalition's intervention in Yemen has resulted in more than 6,000 deaths, half of them civilians. This humanitarian crisis now affects 80% of the population.  An expert report to the UN Security Council states that the belligerents are deliberately targeting civilian populations and infrastructure, in violation of international humanitarian law.  The resolution therefore calls for a humanitarian truce, as well as investigations into accusations of violations of international law by Saudi Arabia and its allies. The Socialists and Democrats, through an amendment, wanted to go further by calling for a European embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia.  Such a decision would be in line with the EU's 2008 common position on arms exports, a decision which requires Member States, when exporting arms, to take into account the country's respect for international humanitarian law.  I therefore vote in favour of this resolution, because it sends a strong message to the belligerents.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the Joint Motion for a Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because it is not complete.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the motion for a resolution, which was supported across the majority of the political spectrum. We are all well aware of the critical humanitarian situation in Yemen, whose population is facing disastrous living conditions. The Saudi-led military conflict has resulted in the use of banned cluster bombs, causing the deaths of at least 6,000 people and, according to the UN, urgently needs help in the form of drinking water, food, medical aid and at least 200,000 civilians. I believe that the situation in Yemen poses a major risk to stability throughout the region. I believe that it is absolutely essential, under the leadership of the UN, to immediately launch coordinated humanitarian action, with all countries contributing to a peaceful resolution of the situation. I supported the resolution.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The situation in Yemen is becoming increasingly difficult and unsustainable for the inhabitants of Yemen and the people who have moved there to help them. I support this Parliament's motion for a resolution to demand a ceasefire and to take measures to enable emergency aid to arrive. May this call serve to make the parties facing sit down to negotiate a political solution to this conflict.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. I believe that only a political and negotiated solution to the conflict can restore peace and preserve Yemen's unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity. I support the resolution, which strongly urges Saudi Arabia and Iran to end the fighting in Yemen and the international community to provide humanitarian aid and to take care of the immediate needs of the civilians affected by the crisis.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The situation in Yemen has worsened since the Houthi captured the capital Sanaa. At least 5,979 people have died since the conflict began and, according to the 2016 Humanitarian Needs Survey (HNO) released in November 2015, 21.2 million people, or 82% of Yemen's population, are in need of humanitarian assistance. The resolution condemns "Saudi Arabia's military intervention in Yemen" and also condemns EU Member States for continuing to sell them weapons, arguing that they "serve to commit serious violations of international humanitarian law and harm regional peace, security and stability". The resolution deplores violations of the ceasefire and "underlines the need to coordinate humanitarian action under the aegis of the United Nations". I vote for this resolution, which clearly denounces the actions of Saudi Arabia and is within the framework of the United Nations.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Apart from the proposal for a resolution by the GUE group, which was very good on the merits, the others are full of good feelings but they do not, it seems to me, have a clear idea of the substantive problems in this case. Moreover, most groups intended to impose on the Member States the EU's policy in terms of arms exports. That is something that is not acceptable. As a result, I voted against these proposals.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Yemen. The instability experienced in Yemen is very worrying. There are now millions of people in need of humanitarian aid. It is extremely important that the EU continues to play a constructive role in trying to find solutions to the stability of the country and to put an end to violence.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I signed and supported this cross-party resolution which aims to plot the way forward in alleviating the worsening humanitarian situation in Yemen. The resolution highlights the fact that the situation on the ground is being exacerbated by external actors and by extremist and terrorist forces.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The civil war in Yemen is another blow to the Middle East. Today, we can literally say that the Middle East is burning in the flames of war and violence. Hospitals do not have enough electricity or fuel to operate ambulances, there is a huge number of doctors and staff who could help the injured. The poor state of sewers caused by bombardment can later cause the spread of dangerous diseases. This situation must be clearly addressed without undue delay. First of all, I strongly express my outrage that some European countries are supplying weapons to Yemen. These deliveries shall be terminated immediately. Furthermore, it is necessary to ensure that humanitarian workers enter the country. I agree with the rapporteurs that the only and best possible solution to the whole conflict is a political solution. The situation requires a quick solution. The world can no longer look at dying children, women and old people.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen, which criticises the actions of the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen that has led to a humanitarian crisis. It also criticises the actions of the Houthi rebels in Yemen. The resolution acknowledges that the arms sales from the EU Member States to Saudi Arabia, as one of the belligerent parties, are in violation of the EU Common Position on arms sales control. The resolution calls for the consideration of establishing an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, in accordance with the EU Common Position on arms sales, which rules out selling arms in cases where is a risk that they can be used to commit violations of international humanitarian law, which appears to be the case in the Saudi-led coalition’s war in Yemen.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Yemen is obviously reaching alarming proportions across the country, with grave risks for the stability of the region and a threat to international peace and security. It is clear to me that unless and until stability is restored, other major issues like food insecurity, poverty, spiralling violence and spread of terrorist organisations, illiteracy are hard to address. Thus I fully support this resolution that urges all stakeholders to open peace negotiations and political dialogue that would put an end to the Yemeni struggle.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the subject, the ECR, GUE/NGL, Verts/ALE, ALDE, S&D, PPE and EFDD political groups tabled a motion for a resolution. With the exception of the ECR, the other six groups agreed on a joint draft compromise, and I voted in favour of this.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is paved with good intentions, but it dismisses the root causes of the situation in Yemen and knowingly forgets the Yemeni reality. That is why I voted against it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We can only welcome the resolution. After careful consideration of the Saudi-led military campaign, we express our deep concern about the way in which it has been implemented. The use of cluster bombs, the destruction of hospitals and drug storage raises serious doubts about compliance with international humanitarian law. The failure to respect the ceasefire of all the parties involved and the ineffectiveness of diplomatic deterrence require us to take a clearer stand. In view of the violation of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP, which suspends the supply of armaments where there is a risk of their use in violation of international humanitarian law or if it is suspected that their use could lead to regional destabilisation, we would like to see an embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia. The humanitarian situation, with more than 21 million civilians in serious need of humanitarian assistance, has, in fact, deteriorated further as a result of the naval blockade and the destruction of national infrastructure by the Saudi-led coalition, which prevents the suffering of the Yemeni people from being alleviated. The resolution, calling for an immediate truce, is therefore a source of strong support.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls on all state and non-state actors involved in the conflict to work together towards peace and reconciliation. The motion for a resolution urges Saudi Arabia and Iran to work together in order to find a peaceful solution for this crisis.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The situation in the Middle East and its neighbouring regions remains the epicentre of instability with an overflowing effect towards Europe.  According to information available since the beginning of the conflict, there have been nearly 6,000 casualties and nearly 30,000 wounded.  I find the information from UNICEF particularly disturbing that the conflict has a serious impact on access to education for nearly 2 million children and that over 3,500 schools are closed. Deprived of education and the prospect of further development, these children become easily subject to radicalisation and the likelihood that this will lead to even more negative consequences and violence in the region in the years to come is growing.  Yemen is in a strategistic location for the region near other conflict zones. Due to the lack of a solution to the conflict and the will to do so, terrorist organisations have a wide scope to expand and strengthen their presence in the region.  For these reasons, I stand firmly behind the call on the international community to adopt measures that will contribute to stopping hostilities and conflict in the country.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have supported this report because Yemen is in urgent need of assistance because of its current humanitarian situation. Yemen is one of the poorest countries in the world, which is why I am in favour of aid directly on the ground.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU must make more efforts to resolve the violent conflict in Yemen and to put an end to the current catastrophic humanitarian situation. Internationally, saudi responsibility must also be increased. on the eu.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is concerned by the ongoing military and humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in particular the role played by both Saudi Arabia and Iran via proxies in the conflict. Amendment 1 calls for an arms embargo using the EU Common Position on Arms Exports 2008/944/CFSP. Whilst we are concerned by the role of Western arms exports to Saudi Arabia, we cannot support the use of EU mechanisms to address the issue and as such we abstained on Amendment 1 and the resolution as a whole.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ongoing conflict in Yemen is due to the inability of successive governments to respond to the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people, thus fuelling the discontent and divisions that have resulted in the current violence. I am voting in favour, hoping for an improvement in these situations.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The political and humanitarian crisis in Yemen threatens to destabilise the entire region and therefore I consider it extremely important to achieve a lasting ceasefire as soon as possible. The suffering of civilians in this country engulfed in bloody conflicts, where millions of people need humanitarian aid, must not leave us indifferent. In the first place, I would like to draw attention to the suffering of children in Yemen, who are one of the most vulnerable groups affected by the humanitarian Yemeni crisis and are threatened by shortages of food and medicine. Also of concern is the human rights situation in Yemen, which this resolution also mentions. Since the beginning of the conflict, cases of torture of civilians, especially members of religious minorities, attacks on journalists, their enforced disappearances, etc. have been common. Only the establishment of lasting peace and the start of a democratic process in Yemen can contribute to the cessation of human rights violations.  I call on the parties to the conflict in Yemen to approach the negotiations on a peaceful solution to the crisis. I also urge Saudi Arabia and its allies on the one hand, and Iran on the other, to support the process of Yemen's exit from the crisis through diplomatic efforts.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. As is often the case when it comes to foreign policy (in which it has no competence or legitimacy), the European Union is a lecturer and aligns the right feelings but does not analyse the real situation and does not take all the elements into account. This motion for a resolution further convinces me that it would be catastrophic for France to be locked into a diplomacy of the European Union without vision and without intelligence and that it must instead carry its sovereign voice in the midst of the concert of nations. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen has led to a catastrophic humanitarian situation affecting the population throughout the country, has serious consequences for the region and is a threat to international peace and security.  As of 26 March 2015, Saudi Arabia, which heads a US-backed coalition of the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain, Kuwait, Jordan, Morocco and Sudan, is bombing Yemen as part of an attack campaign aimed at restoring Hadi to power, with the aggregate effect of intense attacks affecting 80% of Yemen's population of 26 million. There are currently estimated to be nearly 2.1 million unused people, which includes more than 1.3 million children suffering from serious and acute malnutrition, and for 14.4 million people, food availability is uncertain. Children's access to education has been halted for nearly 2 million children. The provision of basic healthcare has been disrupted for almost half a million children under the age of five.  For this reason, I strongly condemn the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia and support a vote in favour of amendments to establish an arms sales embargo on Saudi Arabia in the context of violations of international humanitarian law. I would also like to stress the importance of finding a political solution to end the fight in Yemen and establish peace.

name: Joao Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The serious situation that is currently in Yemen is integrated in a process in which Imperialism explores tribal and feudal survivals, stirs up ethnic and religious conflicts, generalizes corruption and criminal trafficking and promotes and instrumentalizes terrorism, always for its own benefit. Imperialism multiplies conflicts in the Middle East, which, as in Syria, are causing unresoviated human suffering, destroying countries whose wealth transnational capital aims to take over. This draft resolution, generally positive, identifying various problems felt at the present time by the Yemeni people, sins for what is absent. It does not expressly condemn the role of imperialist powers, such as the US, and other countries whose action has contributed to the deaths of thousands of innocents, such as the bombings of Sana and Adem; proposes a political solution to the situation, but does not reject future external interventions in Yemen. There is no condemnation of the role of the Persian Gulf dictatorships, particularly Saudi Arabia, in the military aggressions imposed on that country. Despite the difficult situation of Yemenis, we have full confidence that, even in this tangle of contradictions and conflicts stirred by foreign aggression, the struggle for freedom that the people of Yemen continues will triumph.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the start of the conflict in Yemen, at least 5,979 people have been killed and 28,208 injured.  Among the victims are hundreds of women and children. Furthermore, the humanitarian impact on the civilian population, following the ongoing clashes between the various militias, the bombings and the interruption of the provision of essential services, is reaching alarming proportions. In 2015, the EU has already allocated EUR 52 million in humanitarian aid for the crisis in Yemen and will set aside a further EUR 2 million for the development of the UN Trade Transport Monitoring and Inspection Mechanism (UNVIM), thereby facilitating the free flow of trade items and humanitarian aid to the country. I hope that the conflict can be resolved by reaching a political solution, by starting a new round of peace negotiations under the leadership of the United Nations as soon as possible.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is committed to helping victims of natural and man-made disasters around the world. The EU institutions, together with the Member States of the Union, are the largest donors of humanitarian aid in the world. The European Union is assisting in all major crisis areas around the world, including Yemen. Several successive governments in Yemen have not met the democratic and social demands of the Yemeni people, causing ongoing discontent and unsathly violence. The current situation in Yemen increases the international danger sparked by the severe humanitarian crisis that has affected most of Yemen's population. It is clear that human rights violations are taking place in many cases in Yemen, which is reflected in attacks on the media, violations of the Convention against Torture or imprisonment of religious minorities. For these reasons, I am in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. I am of the opinion that an effective solution to the crisis in Yemen can be achieved through political dialogue, respect for the human rights of all citizens, as well as by the participation of Yemeni citizens in a legitimate and transparent political transition with a clear timetable based on the results of the Conference on National Dialogue and the Peace Agreement and the National Partnership.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. – This joint motion for a resolution deals with the humanitarian situation in Yemen and identifies past casualties and key locations where the conflict is being fought. He attributes the current crisis in Yemen to the fact that successive governments have failed to live up to the "legitimate aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, economic and social development, stability and security" and condemns the warfare of the warring parties Saudi Arabia and the Houthi rebels. The results of the so-called "Arab Spring" showed very well that democracy – from a Western point of view – only works to a limited extent in Islamic countries, because the rule of law and human rights have not been and will not be established to a sufficient extent, in addition to the possibility of free choice. The attempt to democratise such countries usually leads to a loss of stability and the outbreak of violent conflicts. I am strongly opposed to interference in foreign countries and have therefore voted against the motion.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The humanitarian situation in Yemen is alarming, characterized by a situation of widespread food insecurity and acute malnutrition, indiscriminate attacks against civilians, doctors and members of humanitarian organizations, destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure caused by intensified saudi-led coalition air strikes, ground fighting and bombing. The EU must reiterate the absolute need for a cessation of hostilities and to make every effort with regard to humanitarian aid

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text of this resolution, which expressed Parliament's grave concern at the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Yemen. The failure of successive governments to respond to the aspirations of the Yemeni people for democracy, stability and security has led to the current crisis, which has put 21 million Yemenis (82% of the total population) in need of humanitarian assistance and prevented two million children from attending school. The text voted this afternoon calls on the warring parties in Yemen to respect a ceasefire agreement to allow emergency aid, such as food or medicine, to reach the Yemeni people. It also calls on all parties to avoid directly targeting civilian infrastructure, medical facilities and water systems.  I believe that only a political, inclusive and negotiated solution can restore peace and preserve the unity of Yemen.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this European Parliament resolution calling for a truce in Yemen. Extremely concerned about the worsening humanitarian situation in the region and the airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition, Parliament calls for all parties to respect human rights and for humanitarian action to be coordinated. Above all, because of serious suspicions that schools, hospitals and aid centres are being targeted, the resolution calls for an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia to effectively protect human rights.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, conflicts and the resulting humanitarian crises continue to escalate and escalate around us. With today's vote on Yemen, we want to express deep concern about the ongoing violence in Yemen and the resulting humanitarian crisis, urge all Yemeni parties, especially the Houthi, to work to resolve their differences through dialogue, and we believe that Saudi Arabia and Iran are the key to resolving the crisis, and we urge them both to work pragmatically and in good faith to end the fighting in Yemen.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution since I believe that the European Union should promote with determination compliance with international humanitarian law, as provided for in the relevant Union guidelines and that, in its relations with Saudi Arabia, it will prevail the need to comply with international humanitarian law on other (commercial) considerations , geostrategics, etc.) and, if such a dialogue does not achieve results, assess other measures in accordance with the European Union Guidelines to promote compliance with international humanitarian law.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a Resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen as it clearly and unequivocally points to Saudi Arabian-led military intervention as causing the humanitarian catastrophe. The Saudi regime has used internationally banned cluster bombs and bombed civilian targets, including medical facilities, severely damaging basic infrastructure. Despite the attempts to the right of the Eurochamber to avoid voting on this motion for a resolution, I have strongly supported the same position as we have also contributed to the adoption of an amendment calling on the European Union to impose an embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia for its non-compliance with international humanitarian law. Unfortunately, my country, partly thanks to the very close relations between the Spanish Royal Family and the Saudi dynasty, is one of the main suppliers of arms to the Saudi regime. I will continue to denounce this and hope that this Resolution will help bring this arms sales to an end.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and I believe that it represents a clear humanitarian appeal to end the bloodshed in Yemen, and call on Saudi Arabia to pursue a political solution rather than resorting to violence. The amount of deaths in Yemen should not be ignored and I welcome the European Parliament vote today, which represents a serious take on the allegations of breaches of international humanitarian law by Saudi Arabia in Yemen. So serious, I would argue, that selling arms to the regime is something that would constitute a breach of the EU’s own legally-agreed Code of Conduct. However, we would like to see Saudi Arabia as a partner and help international efforts to solve the conflicts in Yemen, Syria and elsewhere, but the EU has a legal and moral duty and as long as Saudi Arabia continues to have this level of disregard for the Yemeni people, it should not receive our support. I am extremely concerned that David Cameron, around the time of this vote, boasted about the trade deal that he has made with the regime, by exporting more arms to the Saudi Government.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 The security situation in Yemen is still deteriorating. It is necessary to address this situation primarily politically, to achieve peace and to preserve the territorial integrity of Yemen. At the same time, however, there are concerns about ongoing human rights violations, including attacks on journalists and media institutions, disappearances, violations of the Convention against Torture, persecution and imprisonment of representatives of religious minorities, as well as the alleged use of children in armed conflicts. These acts need to be thoroughly investigated and corrected.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Up to 82% of the population, or 21.2 million people, are currently in need of humanitarian assistance in Yemen. An estimated 2.1 million people are currently malnourished, including 1.3 million children suffering from severe acute malnutrition. This situation in Yemen also poses serious risks to stability in the region. Therefore, the need for coordinated humanitarian action led by the UN, with the participation of all EU Member States, but also of the developed countries of the world, must be aimed at the immediate provision of food, medicines, fuels and other essential needs for the people of Yemen, in accordance with the principles of impartiality, neutrality and independence. In order for this assistance to reach the Yemeni people, it is essential to immediately suspend attacks on civilian infrastructure, in particular medical facilities and water systems. In parallel, it is necessary to involve all parties to the conflict in a new round of UN-led peace negotiations without precondience in order to resolve disagreements through dialogue and consultation, to reject acts of violence in order to achieve the political objectives for peace and stability in Yemen and the region.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution, with the exception of recital N of the preamble and point 7, which other political groups wanted to push into the resolution and which speak of imposing an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia. Another issue is human rights violations in this country. Here I have made my position clear by voting without hesitation in favour of awarding the Sakharov Prize to political prisoner Raíf Badawi. At the moment, coordinated humanitarian action is crucial under the UN leadership. All parties must enable the UN and international humanitarian organisations to enter and deliver vital food, medicine, fuel and other necessary assistance and meet the needs of civilians affected by the crisis. The people of Yemen clearly need to be given vital assistance. A stable and secure Yemen with a properly functioning government is crucial to international efforts to combat extremism.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The cause of the current conflict in Yemen is the failure of successive governments to satisfy the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people, fueling the discontent and division that has led to the current violence. The situation in Yemen poses a serious danger to the stability of the region, especially for the horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East. A stable and secure Yemen with a properly functioning government is key to international efforts to combat extremism and violence in the region and beyond, as well as to peace and stability within Yemen itself. That is why I express concern about the violence in Yemen that is not ending and the ensuing humanitarian crisis affecting millions of innocent men, women and children. I condemn any violence, attempts to carry out violence and the threat of violence to intimidate parties participating in the UN-mediate consultation. I also call on all Yemeni sides to respond to future talks, to participate in them without preconditions and in good faith, and to resolve their disagreements through dialogue and consultation, to reject the use of violence to pursue political goals, and to refrain from provocation and any unilateral action aimed at disrupting the political transition.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The cause of the current conflict is the inability of governments to meet the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people. The situation in Yemen poses a serious danger to the stability of the region, especially for the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle East. Iranian-backed Hutu rebels and a Saudi-led coalition of Arab countries are clashing, dragging the region into a complex conflict.  Fighting between militia groups has major humanitarian consequences for the civilian population and is reaching worrying proportions. Parliament encourages all parties to the conflict to try to resolve their disputes through dialogue, as the only political solution can lead to lasting peace. It also calls for respect for international law and for cooperation with the UN. Parliament also calls on the Yemeni sides to respond to and participate in future negotiations in good faith and to reject violence as a tool of action. I support the proposals in this resolution because I consider a stable and secure Yemen, with a functioning government, to be essential for international efforts to combat extremism and violence in the region. I also think it is necessary to stop the violence to provide people in Yemen with much-needed humanitarian assistance, especially to the most vulnerable children who do not currently have health care or food services available.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen.  In Yemen, we are witnessing a rapid deterioration of the humanitarian situation, which includes inadequate food security and severe malnutrition, indiscerated attacks on civilians and medical and humanitarian personnel, and the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure. All this is the result of saudi-led military intervention in Yemen.  I support the report, which stresses the need for coordinated humanitarian action under the leadership of the United Nations, and calls on all countries to help meet humanitarian needs.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of today's resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because, above all, it appeals to the ever-deteriorating humanitarian situation of yemen's civilians who are on the battlefield. The need to address this situation is highlighted not only by the European Parliament, but also by the UNHCR, UNICEF. As in the case of other countries in which there is a de facto civil war with the direct or indirect participation of various other states or terrorist organisations, it is necessary first to ensure, at least, respect for the fundamental principles of international humanitarian law, to gradually reduce and stop the fighting, and to find a way to form at least a minimally stable government that is respected by at least a majority of the parties to the current conflict. This is the only way to ensure the stability not only of these countries, but of the entire region, the instability of which we are then also felt in Europe.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the joint resolution as the serious deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen requires immediate humanitarian assistance.  The country is in a long-running standoff between the Huthi and yemen's government, which intensified in 2015 when Saudi Arabia as the head of a U.S.-backed coalition began bombing Yemen, while imposing a near-complete blockade of imports into the country. This situation has led the people to starvation and misery, while attacks on civilians, medical personnel and humanitarian organisations have caused huge loss of life.  This conflict is yet another attempt by the US and its allies to maintain geopolitical control and sovereignty over the region. The EU is also complicit in this crime, which, with its tolerance of the dictatorships of the region and its Member States, which continue to export heavy defence equipment to Saudi Arabia, is leading to the deterioration of the conflict in the country.  We condemn once again the attitude of the US, its allies and the dominant circles of the EU and call for the necessary measures to stop the humanitarian crisis in Yemen to be taken immediately.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because the amendments that have passed alter the true nature of the resolution and once again serve political purposes and economic interests.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the European Parliament to have its voice heard on one of the worst humanitarian disasters in the world at present and to give its international weight to Saudi Arabia and other parties to the conflict in order to improve the situation. I consider it urgent that the naval blockade be lifted and that combat activities throughout Yemen be lifted in order to bring humanitarian aid to an unhindered end. A particularly worrying a feature of the situation is the high number of children among the victims and the serious threats to the safety of international aid workers. Agreeing that international efforts to resolve the situation in Yemen should be conducted under un-direction, I also took into account the fact that there is even a specific responsibility of EU Member States on this issue, in particular with regard to compliance with and enforcement of the requirements relating to restrictions on arms shipments to the region. I believe that this aspect must continue to be closely monitored by the European Parliament's instruments in the future.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. By failing to follow a political path of cohesion, Yemen has become entangled in escalating tribal tensions and in the violent war in which Iranian-backed Houthi rebels and Saudi Arabia, which has been waging a military campaign against the rebels that has been directly plunging the entire region into a complex conflict that has been going on for several months, are fighting. Saudi Arabia sees Houthi rebels in Yemen as an Iranian proxy force, and Iran has condemned the Saudi-led offensive and called for an immediate halt to its airstrikes. The deteriorating security situation in Yemen, where at least 5,700 people, nearly half of them civilians, have been killed since the conflict escalated in March 2015 is a growing international concern. Houthi soldiers are accused of using heavy weapons in populated areas, while the Saudi-led coalition is accused of conducting several airstrikes on hospitals and other civilian buildings. This text reflects the European Parliament's concern and solidarity with the Yemeni people.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen expressing great concern over the alarming deterioration of the humanitarian situation, characterised by widespread food insecurity, attacks against civilians and aid workers, the destruction of civilian and medical infrastructure, as well as an intensification of airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition, ground fighting and shelling. This situation also led me to support the amendment on an EU arms embargo against Saudi Arabia, given its serious allegations of breaches of international humanitarian law in Yemen. I fully agree with the need for coordinated humanitarian action under UN leadership, the call on all sides to comply with international humanitarian law and international human rights law, and with the plea that Saudi Arabia and Iran work together to end the fighting in Yemen. Finally, I also believe that we will only achieve peace through a political, inclusive and negotiated solution.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. In 2014, following the Houthi rebellion against the government of Abd Rabbo Mansour Hadi, a civil war broke out in Yemen. The Yemeni president called on Saudi forces backed by the Gulf Cooperation Council, giving an open dimension to the conflict. This was followed by a rapid and tragic escalation by the deployment of Gulf Cooperation Council forces to the ground.  This war exacerbation has greatly degraded the humanitarian situation in the country and has created a major risk of destabilization of the Horn of Africa, worsening the situation in the Middle East. While 21 million people, more than 80% of Yemen's population, are in humanitarian need, the European Parliament has mobilised.  In this resolution, we call on the international community to take responsibility for delivering the necessary humanitarian aid. We urge the warring parties in the conflict to allow this humanitarian aid to be effectively implemented, with the end of the blockades and by decreeing a humanitarian truce. Finally, we call on the Commission to enact an embargo on arms deliveries to Saudi Arabia, in order to enforce international law.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conflict in Yemen is being fought with total disregard for the rules of war. In recent times medical activities in the country have been attacked several times. As the European Union, we must call on all the warring parties to authorise unconstrained and unimpeded access by humanitarian workers and relief workers to the Yemeni people, who urgently need basic assistance, which is why it is calling for a humanitarian pause that will allow this vital aid to reach the Yemeni people as a matter of urgency. The conflict can only be resolved by a political, inclusive and negotiated solution. All parties must commit themselves in good faith to starting a new round of peace negotiations under the leadership of the United Nations as soon as possible.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The deteriorating security situation in Yemen is causing growing international concern given the fact that at least 5,700 people have been killed since the conflict escalated in March 2015, almost half of them civilians. Soldiers from the Huthi movement have been accused of using heavy weapons in populated areas, while at the same time the Saudi-led coalition has been accused of carrying out several air strikes against hospitals and other civilian facilities.  I express my deep concern at the continuing violence in Yemen and the ensuing humanitarian crisis affecting millions of innocent men, women and children. I believe that all parties to the conflict in Yemen, primarily Saudi Arabia and Iran, which play a key role in resolving the crisis, should work to improve bilateral relations. A resolution by the European Conservatives and Reformists on Yemen, to which I am one of the authors, calls for respect for the human rights and freedoms of all Yemeni citizens, as well as for all persons working for peacekeeping and humanitarian missions in the country.  I therefore urge all state and non-state actors involved in the conflict to work towards peace and reconciliation and to engage unconditionally in this process that will prevent further casualties.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen.  I am concerned about the situation and the violence that is happening in Yemen. Violence is growing into a humanitarian crisis, and with this resolution, the European Parliament calls on all parties, in accordance with humanitarian law and together with the UN, to provide assistance to people in need.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Yemen has deteriorated from a chaos of civil war to a complete humanitarian catastrophe. The Saudi-led military intervention and its use of violence took the lives of civilians and continues to do so every day. Because of this imminent threat to the population, and also to the region, it is necessary to impose an EU arms embargo against Saudi-Arabia. The allegations of breaches of international law by the Saudi-led military intervention are serious. Therefore, Member States who are engaged in exports of military technology and equipment are in breach of the rules established by the Council on this topic. Only an embargo will send a signal which reflects our condemnation of the practices of the Saudi-led military in Yemen.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Joint Resolution since I believe that the European Union should promote with determination compliance with international humanitarian law, as provided for in the relevant Union guidelines and that, in its relations with Saudi Arabia, it will prevail the need to comply with international humanitarian law on other (commercial) considerations , geostrategics, etc.) and, if such a dialogue does not achieve results, assess other measures in accordance with the European Union Guidelines to promote compliance with international humanitarian law.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The current conflict in Yemen is due to the failure of successive governments to fulfilled the democratic, economic and social aspirations of the Yemeni people, thereby exacerbating the dissatisfaction and divisions that have led to the current violence. The key to resolving the crisis is in the hands of Saudi Arabia and Iran, and the proposal urges both sides to do more to improve their bilateral relations and seek cooperation to end the fighting in Yemen. I voted in favour of S&D's position.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which includes the request to sew all arms in the European Union against Saudi Arabia until the alleged violations of international humanitarian law in Yemen are thoroughly investigated.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I call on all parties to respect the human rights and freedoms of all Yemeni citizens and of all those who seek peace and carry out humanitarian missions in the country, including workers, doctors and journalists.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The resolution expresses serious concern with regard to the deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Yemen. Namely, 21 million Yemeni people (82% of the total population) are currently in need of humanitarian assistance and two million children are prevented from attending schools. A ceasefire aimed at stopping attacks against civilians, medical and aid workers, ground fighting and bombing in Yemen is urgently needed to allow life-saving aid to reach the Yemeni people. The resolution equally urges all parties in Yemen’s civil war and their foreign backers to engage in a new round of peace negotiations and seek a political settlement. I voted in favour of this resolution as only a political, inclusive and negotiated solution to the conflict can restore peace and preserve unity in Yemen.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The Socialist Group in Parliament supports with its vote strong action in the face of the dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen, a crisis of enormous human consequences for 20 million people, with very serious human rights violations, and on which the international community is not paying the necessary attention.   With our vote, we have urged the parties to the conflict in Yemen to immediately allow humanitarian and health access and to resume peace negotiations imminently in order to achieve a political solution that will end the conflict. We also condemn the increasingly frequent attacks on the health facilities of Doctors Without Borders and call on the international community to ensure that medical centres are respected as protected areas under international humanitarian law. On the specific issue of the arms embargo on Saudi Arabia, the Socialist Group has led support for its establishment. We therefore regret the vote against and the dubious ethics governing the positions of the conservative part of the Eurochamber, which supports the transformation of wars into a macabre opportunity for commercial gain.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ VVD does not support an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia, because we need to be on speaking terms with this political and economic power in the Middle East. However, VVD supports the improvement of the humanitarian situation in Yemen. Therefore, the final vote of VVD against the resolution should not be interpreted as condoning the human rights violations in Yemen, but as a rejection of the arms embargo against Saudi Arabia.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I support this resolution because I would like to call on High Representative Federica Mogherini to issue an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia. The situation in Yemen is extremely worrying. Not only is there a regional conflict with many victims, but the threat of terrorism from this region remains real. Several NGOs, as well as Unesco and Unicef, have already raised the alarm loud and clear. The UN trying to mediate, in vain so far. Yemen has become a place where the regional powers are fighting their own war among themselves, with ruthless adversaries killing civilians. The Saudi-led coalition has also been guilty of violations of international humanitarian law.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The scene of a formidable popular movement in 2011, Yemen has been at the heart of a deadly conflict for the past year, of which Saudi Arabia is the main culprit. The civilian population, already among the poorest in the world, pays for it every day, including as part of a political instrumentalization of the religious question. The resolution calls for a ceasefire to allow minimal access to humanitarian aid to the Yemeni people. It calls on all parties, including regional powers, to do everything possible to find a political solution to this war. The bombings carried out by Saudi Arabia and their disastrous consequences (infrastructure, schools and hospitals destroyed) aggravate the instability of the country and the main beneficiaries are terrorist groups...  I welcome the adoption of the amendment tabled by my group, in particular, calling on the Union to enact an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia.  I find it surprising, to say the least, that the elected representatives of the National Front, supposedly so critical of the Gulf countries, have chosen to reject both this amendment and the final text. Understand who can.   For my part, I voted in favour of this resolution, which is in the interest of the Yemeni people.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the measure it presents, the draft resolution presented here on the situation in Yemen falls short in many respects: it does not expressly condemn the military action of Saudi Arabia, which contributed to the provocation of this situation, which is responsible for the death of civilians; addresses the need for a political solution, but does not expressly reject new external military interventions; it does not condemn the collusion of the Member States with the dictatorships in the region, and does not yet expressly condemn the arms trade that is developing in this region. What is happening in Yemen is part of a process of widespread subversion, in which imperialism exploits all kinds of conflicts that exist in countries to justify their aggressive and militaristic strategy. The force that had the heroic struggle of the Yemeni people, which allowed to defeat imperialism and colonialism in the past, will be the same force that will allow this people to conquer the values of democracy and peace and achieve the social transformations it seeks.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The resolution contains important points for improving the situation in Yemen, in particular involving Saudi Arabia, which plays a central role in the conflict. That is why I agree with the motion for a resolution.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in order to express my deep concern and dismay at the humanitarian situation in Yemen. The international community must act to bring an end to the hostilities there, where those who pay the heaviest price, as always, are those who are most vulnerable. I have been in contact with an Ogadeni journalist who has been trapped in Saana for many months and have learnt from him directly of the suffering of innocent victims. No European Union Member State should ever sell or be complicit in the sale of weapons and military hardware which contribute to committing atrocities and to targeting civilians. This is why I support the resolution’s call for an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia and hope that Member States’ governments, particularly my own, will heed our call.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I supported the resolution on the humanitarian situation in Yemen because I believe that the parties to this conflict should respect the basic provisions of international humanitarian law and I am in favour of the Member States not transferring arms and providing military support to Saudi Arabia and its allies in the conflict.  More than 6,000 people have been killed and more than 35,000 injured in Yemen since the conflict escalated last March. More than 90% of this number are civilians. Shiite Houthi rebels and overthrown central authorities, backed by Sunni tribesmen, are in this bloody conflict only pawns as part of a larger political game between the governments of Iran and Saudi Arabia. The chaos that has engulfed the state has also led to economic catastrophe and an intensification of the actions of al-Qaeda and ISIS terrorists. Al-Qaeda extremists have seized the strategic coastal city of Ahwar in southern Yemen, strengthening their control in the region.  Political attempts to resolve the conflict have proved ineffective and the humanitarian situation is deteriorating day by day– more than 14 million people need food aid and bombattacks do not bypass hospitals and civilian settlements. In addition, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, 59% of arms imports to Saudi Arabia between 2009 and 2014 came from Europe. Eu countries cannot, on the one hand, promote democratisation and, on the other hand, contribute to numerous violations of international humanitarian law and human rights.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ despite an international ban on the use of cluster munitions, saudi-led weapons have been used in Yemen, leading to a catastrophic deterioration in the humanitarian situation in the country. The main victims are the civilian population, which is still living in difficult conditions. Food shortages and severe malnutrition are a signal for the immediate adoption of measures to stem this deteriorating humanitarian situation. In particular, the health care situation is alarming, with dozens of hospitals and ambulances in 18 of Yemen's 22 areas closed or largely restricted due to fighting or fuel shortages, according to Save the Children. It should therefore be recalled that hospitals and medical staff are protected under international humanitarian law and must therefore not be disrupted. I would welcome coordinated humanitarian action led by the UN and improved security for all peacekeepers and humanitarian workers, doctors, but also journalists, which is why I support the motion for a resolution.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The fragile political situation in Yemen, exacerbated by the conflict between the parties supported on the one hand by Iran and, on the other, by Saudi Arabia, has caused an extremely serious humanitarian crisis, affecting the country's civilian population in particular. These people do not have access to medical facilities, most hospitals do not work or are even bombed, children have no or difficult access to education and the security situation is very poor. Overall, this crisis threatens not only the people of Yemen, but also poses a threat to international peace and security. I therefore believe that, if the European Parliament can contribute at least a little to improving the situation in this area, it is necessary to support this effort and to stand up for an end to the reckless attacks on civilians, medical and humanitarian workers and to contribute to addressing humanitarian needs, but also, from an international point of view, to ensure that any arms supplies that might end up in the affected area are cut off.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. Military conflicts in Yemen have caused catastrophic humanitarian conditions affecting populations across the country, have had severe consequences for the whole region and pose a threat to international peace and security.  I therefore support the calls in the European Parliament resolution, which, among other things, signal that the parties at war should respect humanitarian law and international human rights law.  It is essential to protect civilians, prevent direct attacks on civilian infrastructure and to provide safe humanitarian routes for the life of civilians.
